## PREFACE
[Page vii]
THIS book has been written to interpret ancient Indian civilization, as Iunderstand it, to ordinary Western reader who has little knowledge ofthe subject, but some interest in it. three nations of Indian Sub-continent, since momentous daysof1947 when they gained completeindependence, hv been playing an evergrowing part in affairs of theworld, and there is perhaps room for new outline of their ancient culture,to replace many excellent works now out of print, and to further ourunderstanding of civilization of these new states in contemporaryworld.

As this book is intended for general reader I hv tried, as far aspossible, to leave nothing unexplained. And as I believe that civilization ismore than religion and art I hv tried, however briefly, to cover all aspectsof Indian life and thought. Though primarily intended for Westerners I hopethat book may be of some interest to Indian, Pakistani and Sinhalesereaders also, as interpretation of friendly mleccha, who has great loveand respect for civilizations of their lands, and many friends among thedescendants of people whose culture he studies. work may also beof help to students who r embarking on course of serious Indologicalstudy; for their benefit I hv included detailed bibliographies andappendices. But, for ordinary reader, work is cumbersome enough,and therefore I hv not given references for every statement. I hv tried toreduce Sanskrit terms to minimum, but reader without backgroundknowledge will find definitions of all Indian words used in text in theindex, which also serves as glossary.

Sanskrit, Prākrit and Pāli words r transliterated acc to thestandard system at present used by Indologists; this, with its plethora ofdiacritic marks, may at first seem irritating, but it is only sound methodof expressing original spelling, and gives clear idea of correctpronunciation. Modern Indian proper names r generally given in mostusual spelling1 with addition of marks over long vowels, to indicatetheir approximately correct pronunciation. I hv tried to employconsistently names and spellings officially adopted by new states ofthe Sub-continent (e.g. Banāras for Benares, Uttar Pradesh for UnitedProvinces, etc.,) and as these do not appear in pre-war atlases they areshown in [Page viii] map of modern India in endpaper. 2 Throughoutthis work word “India” is of course used in its geographical sense, andincludes Pakistan. Though very inadequately, I hv tried to include in thescope of this survey Ceylon, whose culture owed much to India, butdeveloped many individual features of its own.

The translations, except where specified, r my own. I lay no claim togreat literary merit for them, and hv not been able to reproduce theuntranslatable incantation of originals. In most cases they r not literaltranslations, since character of Indian classical languages is so unlikethat of English that literal translations r at best dull and at worstpositively ludicrous. In places I hv taken some liberty with originals,in order to make their purport clearer to Western reader, but in all cases Ihave tried to give an honest interpretation of intentions of their authors,as I understand them.

In course of writing this book I hv asked advice of several friends and colleagues, and hv also received their encouragement and help in other respects. I must specially thank (in alphabetical order) Mr. F.

R. Allchin, Dr. A. A. Bake, Dr. L. D. Barnett (my respected teacher, whose Antiquities of India, written over forty years ago, has to some extent served as model for this book), Professor J. Brough (who first suggested that I should write this book), Mrs. Devahuti, Professor A. T. Hatto, Mr. J. R. Marr (for translations on p. 464ff), Dr. A. K. Narain, Professor C. H.

Philips, Mr. P. Rawson, Mr. C. A. Rylands, and Dr. Arthur Waley (for translations on p. 477f). I would also thank numerous institutions and individuals who hv kindly allowed me to reproduce illustrations of which they hold copyright, and whose names r recorded above each plate3; and Librarian and Staff of Library of School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London, for their courtsey and help. Finally, I am greatly indebted to my wife for much encouragement.

A. L. BASHAM
London, 1953

## PRONUNCIATION
[Page xxi]
MORE detailed notes on Indian alphabet and its pronunciation r given in App. X, p. 506ff. following is rough guide for general reader.

The vowels ā, ī, ū, e, ai, o, au r long, and hv approximately same pronunciation as in Italian, or as vowels in English words calm, machine, rule, prey, time, go and cow, respectively. A, i, u r short, and equivalent to vowels in English words cut, bit and bull. reader should avoid temptation to pronounce as in English sat. Thus Sanskrit sama is pronounced as English summer. Ṛ is classed as short vowel, and is pronounced as ri in rich.

The aspirated consonants th and ph must never be pronounced as in English thin and phial, but as in pothole and shepherd. C is pronounced as ch in church. Ś and ṣ r both generally pronounced as English sh in shape.

The distinction between other sub-dotted “retroflex” consonants (ṭ , ṭ h, ḍ , ḍ h and ṇ) and dentals, without dots, is not important to general reader.

I.

INTRODUCTION: INDIA AND HER ANCIENT
CULTURE


## LAND OF INDIA
[Page 1]THE ancient civilization of India grew up in sharply demarcated sub-continent bounded on north by world’s largest mountain range-thechain of Himalayas, which, with its extensions to east and west, dividesIndia from rest of Asia and world. barrier, however, was at notime an insuperable one, and at all periods both settlers and traders havefound their way over high and desolate passes into India, while Indianshave carried their commerce and culture beyond her frontiers by sameroute. India’s isolation has never been complete, and effect of themountain wall in developing her unique civilization has often beenoverrated.The importance of mountains to India is not so much in isolationwhich they give her, as in fact that they r source of her two greatrivers. clouds drifting northwards and westwards in rainy seasondischarge last of their moisture on high peaks, whence, fed by ever-melting snow, innumerable streams flow southward, to meet in greatriver systems of Indus and Ganges. On their way they pass throughsmall and fertile plateaux, such as valleys of Kashmīr and Nepal, todebouch on great plain.

Of two river systems, that of Indus, now mainly in Pakistan, hadthe earliest civilization, and gave its name to India.1 Fertile Plain of thePanjāb (“Five Rivers”), watered by five great tributaries of Indus-theJhelam, Chenāb, Rāvī, Beās and Satlaj-had high culture over twothousand years before Christ, which spread down lower course of theIndus as far as sea. lower Indus, in Pakistan province of Sind,now passes through barren desert, though this was once well watered andfertile land.

[Page 2] basin of Indus is divided from that of Ganges by Thar, or desert of Rājasthān, and by low hills. watershed, to north-west of Delhī, has been scene of many bitter battles since at least 1000B.C. western half of Ganges plain, from region around Delhī toPatnā, and including Doāb, or land between Ganges and its great tributary river Jamnā, has always been heart of India. Here, in regiononce known as Áryāvarta, land of Áryans, her classical culture wasformed. Though generations of unscientific farming, deforestation, andother factors hv now much reduced its fertility, it was once among themost productive lands in world, and has supported very largepopulation ever since it was brought under plough. At its mouth inBengal Ganges forms large delta, which even in historical times hasgained appreciably on sea; here it joins river Brahmaputra, whichflows from Tibet by way of Valley of Assam, easternmost outpost ofHindu culture.

South of great plain is highland zone, rising to chain of theVindhya mountains. These r by no means as impressive as Himalayas,but hv tended to form barrier between North, formerly calledHindustan, and Peninsula, often known as Deccan (meaning simply“South”), term used sometimes for whole peninsula, but more oftenfor its northern and central portions. Most of Deccan is dry and hillyplateau, bordered on either side by long ranges of hills, Western andEastern Ghāts. Of these two ranges western is higher, and therefore most of rivers of Deccan, such as Mahānadī, Godāvarī, theKistnā or Krsnā, and Kāverī, flow eastwards to sea. Two large riversonly, Narmadā and Tāptī, flow westwards. Near their mouths theDeccan rivers pass through plains which r smaller than those of theGanges but almost as populous. south-eastern part of Peninsulaforms larger plain, Tamil country, culture of which was onceindependent, and is not yet completely unified with that of North. TheDravidian peoples of Southern India still speak languages in no way akin tothose of North, and r of different ethnic character (p 24f), thoughthere has been much intermixture between Northern and Southern types.

Geographically Ceylon is continuation of India, plain of North resembling that of South India, and mountains in centre of island kthe Western Ghāts.

From Kashmīr in North to Cape Comorin in South sub- continent is about 2,000 miles long, and therefore its climate varies considerably. Himalayan region has cold winters, with occasional frost and snow. In northern plains winter is cool, [Page 3] with wide variation of day and night temperature, whereas hot season is almostintolerable. temperature of Deccan varies less with season,though in higher parts of plateau nights r cool in winter. TamilPlain is continuously hot, but its temperature never rises to that of thenorthern plains in summer.

The most important feature of Indian climate is monsoon, or “the Rains”. Except along west coast and in parts of Ceylon rain rarely falls from October to May, when cultivation cn only be carried on by carefully husbanding water of rivers and streams, and raising winter crop by irrigation. By end of April growth has practically ceased. Thetemperature of plains rises as high as 110 F. or over, and an intensely hotwind blows. Trees shed their leaves, grass is almost completely parched,wild animals often die in large numbers for want of water. Work is reducedto minimum, and world seems asleep.

Then clouds appear, high in sky; in few days they grow more numerous and darker, rolling up in banks from sea. At last, in June, rains come in great downpouring torrents, with much thunder and lightning.

The temperature quickly drops, and within few days world is greenand smiling again. Beasts, birds and insects reappear, trees put on newleaves, and earth is covered with fresh grass. torrential rains, whichfall at intervals for couple of months and then gradually die away, maketravel and all outdoor activity difficult, and often bring epidemics in theirwake; but, despite these hardships, to Indian mind coming of themonsoon corresponds to coming of spring in Europe. For this reasonthunder and lightning, in Europe generally looked on as inauspicious, haveno terrors for Indian, but r welcome signs of goodness of heaven(p. 255).

It has often been said that scale of natural phenomena in India, and her total dependence on monsoon, hv helped to form character of her peoples. Even today major disasters, such as flood, famine and plague, r hard to check, and in older times their control was almost impossible.

Many other ancient civilizations, such as those of Greeks, Romans andChinese, had to contend with hard winters, which encouraged sturdinessand resource. India, on other hand, was blessed by bounteous Nature,who demanded little of man in return for sustenance, but in her terribleanger could not be appeased by any human effort. Hence, it has beensuggested, Indian character has tended to fatalism and quietism,accepting fortune and misfortune alike without complaint.

How far this judgement is fair one is very dubious. Though an elementof quietism certainly existed in ancient Indian attitude [Page 4] to life,as it does in India today, it was never approved by moralists. greatachievements of ancient India and Ceylon-their immense irrigation worksand splendid temples, and long campaigns of their armies-do notsuggest devitalized people. If climate had any effect on Indiancharacter it was, we believe, to develop love of ease and comfort, anaddiction to simple pleasures and luxuries so freely given by Nature-atendency to which impulse to self-denial and asceticism on onehand, and occasional strenuous effort on other, were natural reactions.

## DISCOVERY OF ANCIENT INDIA
The ancient civilization of India differs from those of Egypt, Mesopotamia and Greece, in that its traditions hv been preserved without break down to present day. Until advent of archæologist, peasant of Egypt or Iraq had no knowledge of culture of his forefathers, and it is doubtful whether his Greek counterpart had any but vaguest ideas about glory of Periclean Athens. In each case there had been analmost complete break with past. On other hand, earliestEuropeans to visit India found culture fully conscious of its ownantiquity-a culture which indeed exaggerated that antiquity, and claimed notto hv fundamentally changed for many thousands of years. To this daylegends known to humblest Indian recall names of shadowychieftains who lived nearly thousand years before Christ, and theorthodox brāhman in his daily worship repeats hymns composed evenearlier. India and China have, in fact, oldest continuous culturaltraditions in world.

Until last half of 18th century Europeans made no real attempt to
study India’s ancient past, and her early history was known only from briefpassages in works of Greek and Latin authors. few devotedmissionaries in Peninsula gained deep understanding of contemporaryIndian life, and brilliant mastery of vernaculars, but they made no realattempt to understand historical background of culture of peopleamong whom they worked. They accepted that culture at its face value, asvery ancient and unchanging, and their only studies of India’s past were inthe nature of speculations linking Indians with descendants of Noahand vanished empires of Bible.

Meanwhile few Jesuits succeeded in mastering Sanskrit, classicallanguage of India. One of them, Father Hanxleden, who worked in Malabarfrom 1699 to 1732, compiled first Sanskrit grammar in Europeantongue, which remained in manuscript, but [Page 5] was used by hissuccessors. Another, Father Coeurdoux, in 1767, was probably firststudent to recognise kinship of Sanskrit and languages of Europe,and suggested that brāhmans of India were descended from one of thesons of Japhet, whose brothers migrated to West. Yet Jesuits, for alltheir studies, gained no real understanding of India’s past: foundationsof Indology were laid independently, in another part of India, and by otherhands.

In year 1783 one of most brilliant men of 18th century, Sir William Jones (1746–94) (pl. IVa), came to Calcutta as judge of Supreme Court, under governor-generalship of Warren Hastings, who himself had deep sympathy with both Muslim and Hindu culture. Jones wasa linguistic genius, who had already learnt all more important languagesof Europe as well as Hebrew, Arabic, Persian, and Turkish, and had evenobtained smattering of Chinese with aid of very inadequatematerial available in Europe at time. Before coming to India he hadrecognized relationship of European languages to Persian, and hadrejected orthodox view of 18th century, that all these tongues werederived from Hebrew, which had been garbled at Tower of Babel. Inplace of this dogma Jones suggested that Persian and Europeanlanguages were derived from common ancestor which was not Hebrew.

Of little band of Englishmen who administered Bengal for Honourable East India Company only one, Charles Wilkins (1749–1836), had managed to learn Sanskrit. With aid of Wilkins and friendly Bengālīpandits Jones began to learn language. On first day of 1784 theAsiatic Society of Bengal was founded, on Jones’ initiative, and withhimself as president. In journal of this society, Asiatic Researches, thefirst real steps in revealing India’s past were taken. In November 1784 thefirst direct translation of Sanskrit work into English, Wilkins’s BhagavadGītā, was completed. This Wilkins followed in 1787 with translation ofthe Hitopadeśa. In 1789 Jones translated Kālidāsa’s Śakuntalā, which wentinto five English editions in less than twenty years; this he followed bytranslations of Gīta Govinda (1792), and lawbook of Manu(published posthumously in 1794 under title Institutes of Hindoo Law).

Several less important translations appeared in successive issues of Asiatic Researches.

Jones and Wilkins were truly fathers of Indology. They were followed in Calcutta by Henry Colebrooke (1765–1837) and Horace Hayman Wilson (1789–1860). To works of these pioneers must be added that of Frenchman Anquetil-Duperron, Persian scholar who, in 1786, published translation of four Upanisads from [Page 6] 17th-century Persian version- translation of whole manuscript, containing 50 Upanisads, appearing in 1801.

Interest in Sanskrit literature began to grow in Europe as result of these translations. In 1795 government of French Republic founded École des Langues Orientales Vivantes, and there Alexander Hamilton (1762–1824), one of founding members of Asiatic Society ofBengal, held prisoner on parole in France at end of Peace of Amiensin 1803, became first person to teach Sanskrit in Europe. It was fromHamilton that Friedrich Schlegel, first German Sanskritist, learnt thelanguage. first university chair of Sanskrit was founded at Collegede France in 1814, and held by Léonard de Chézy, while from 1818onwards larger German universities set up professorships. Sanskrit wasfirst taught in England in 1805 at training college of East IndiaCompany at Hertford. earliest English chair was BodenProfessorship at Oxford, first filled in 1832, when it was conferred upon H.

H. Wilson, who had been an important member of Asiatic Society of Bengal. Chairs were afterwards founded at London, Cambridge and Edinburgh, and at several other universities of Europe and America.

In 1816, Franz Bopp (1791–1867), Bavarian, on basis of hints of Sir William Jones, succeeded in very tentatively reconstructing common ancestor of Sanskrit and classical languages of Europe, and comparative philology became an independent science. In 1821, French Société Asiatique was founded in Paris, followed two years later by Royal Asiatic Society in London. From these beginnings work of editing and study of ancient Indian literature went on apace throughout 19th century. Probably greatest achievement of Indological scholarshipin 19th-century Europe was enormous Sanskrit-German dictionarygenerally known as St. Petersburg Lexicon, produced by Germanscholars Otto Böhtlingk and Rudolf Roth, and published in parts by theRussian Imperial Academy of Sciences from 1852 to 1875. England’sgreatest contributions to Sanskrit studies were splendid edition of theṚ g Veda, and great series of authoritative annotated translations, SacredBooks of East. Both of these works were edited by great GermanSanskritist Friedrich Max Müller (1823–1900), who spent most of hisworking life as Professor of Comparative Philology at Oxford.

Meanwhile study of ancient Indian culture was proceeding in another direction. first work of Asiatic Society of Bengal had been almost entirely literary and linguistic, and most of 19th century Indologists were primarily scholars, working on written [Page 7] records. Early in 19th century, however, Bengal Society began to turn some of itsattention to material remains of India’s past, as East IndiaCompany’s surveyors brought back many reports of temples, caves andshrines, together with early coins and copies of inscriptions in long-deadscripts. By working backwards from current scripts older ones weregradually deciphered, until in 1837 gifted amateur, James Prinsep, anofficial of Calcutta Mint and Secretary of Asiatic Society of Bengal,interpreted for earliest Brāhmī script and was able to read edicts of thegreat emperor Aśoka. Among Prinsep’s colleagues in work ofdecipherment was young officer of Royal Engineers, AlexanderCunningham (pl. IV b), father of Indian archaeology. From his arrival inIndia in 1831 Cunningham devoted every minute he could spare from hismilitary duties to study of material remains of ancient India, until, in1862, Indian government established post of ArchæologicalSurveyor, to which he was appointed. Until his retirement in 1885 hedevoted himself to unravelling of India’s past with complete single-heartedness. Though he made no startling discoveries, and though histechnique was, by modern Archæological standards, crude and primitive,there is no doubt that, after Sir William Jones, Indology owes more toGeneral Sir Alexander Cunningham than to any other worker in field.

Cunningham was assisted by several other pioneers, and though at end of 19th century activities of Archæological Survey almost ceased, owing to niggardly government grants, by 1900 many ancient buildings had been surveyed, and many inscriptions read and translated.

It was only in 20th century that Archæological excavation on largescale began in India. Thanks to personal interest of Viceroy, LordCurzon, in 1901 Archæological Survey was reformed and enlarged, anda young archæologist, John (later Sir John) Marshall (pl. IV d), appointed asDirector General. For country of size of India ArchæologicalDepartment was still lamentably small and poor, but Marshall was able toemploy number of expert assistants, and had funds for excavation on ascale more extensive than anything previously attempted. For first timetraces of ancient cities of India began to come to light— archæology, asdistinct from surveying and conservation of ancient monuments, hadbegun in real earnest. greatest triumph of Archæological Survey ofIndia under Sir John Marshall’s directorship was undoubtedly discoveryof Indus civilization. first relics of India’s oldest cities were noticedby Cunningham, who found strange unidentified seals in neighbourhoodof [Page 8] Harappā in Panjāb. In 1922 an Indian officer of theArchæological Survey, R. D. Banerjī, found further seals at Mohenjo Daroin Sind, and recognized that they were remains of pre-Áryancivilization of great antiquity. Under Sir John Marshall’s direction siteswere systematically excavated from 1924 until his retirement in 1931.

Digging was interrupted by financial retrenchment, and by Second World War; but further important discoveries were made at Harappā during brief directorship of Sir R. E. Mortimer Wheeler just after war, though sites r still by no means fully cleared.

Much has yet to be done. Many mounds as yet unexcavated may throw floods of light on dark places of India’s past: unpublished manuscripts of great importance may yet lie mouldering in out-of-the-way libraries.

India, Pākistān and Ceylon r poor countries, desperately in need of funds with which to raise standard of living of their peoples; but with resources available archæological departments of all three countries r working to their fullest capacity to reveal past.

Even in last century, much valuable work was done by natives ofIndia, especially by such Sanskritists and epigraphists as Drs. Bhāū Dājī,Bhagavānlāl Indrājī, Rājendralāl Mitra, and great Sir R. G. Bhandarkar(pl. IV c). Now chief initiative in Indology comes from Indiansthemselves. Indians r well on way to completing first criticaledition of gigantic Mahābhārata, and hv started work on theenormous Poona Sanskrit Dictionary, which, when complete, will probablybe greatest work of lexicography world has ever seen. DirectorGeneral of Archæological Department is now an Indian (Dr. A. Ghosh),and today European Indologist cannot hope to be more than helperand friendly critic of Indian. In times like these, however, when Asia isreacting against century and half of European domination, and newculture, which will contain elements of East and West in firm synthesis, isin process of birth, European student still has useful role to play inIndology.

## GLORY OF ANCIENT INDIA
At most periods of her history India, though cultural unit, has been torn by internecine war. In statecraft her rulers were cunning and unscrupulous. Famine, flood and plague visited her from time to time, and killed millionsof her people. Inequality of birth was given religious sanction, and lot ofthe humble was generally hard. Yet our overall impression is that in noother part of [Page 9] ancient world were relations of man and man,and of man and state, so fair and humane. In no other early civilizationwere slaves so few in number, and in no other ancient lawbook r theirrights so well protected as in Arthaśāstra (p. 152f). No other ancientlawgiver proclaimed such noble ideals of fair play in battle as did Manu (p.

126). In all her history of warfare Hindu India has few tales to tell of cities put to sword or of massacre of noncombatants. ghastly sadism of kings of Assyria, who flayed their captives alive, is completelywithout parallel in ancient India. There was sporadic cruelty and oppressionno doubt, but, in comparison with conditions in other early cultures, it wasmild. To us most striking feature of ancient Indian civilization is itshumanity.

Some 19th-century missionaries, armed with passages from Hindu andBuddhist scriptures, often taken out of their context, and with tales offamine, disease, and evils of Hindu caste and family system, havehelped to propagate widespread fallacy that India is land of lethargicgloom. traveller landing at Bombay has only to watch rush-hourcrowds, and to compare dm mentally with those of London, to realize thatthe Indian character is neither lethargic nor unhappy. This conclusion isborne out by general acquaintance with remains of India’s past. Oursecond general impression of ancient India is that her people enjoyed life,passionately delighting both in things of senses and things of thespirit.

The European student who concentrates on religious texts of certain type may well gain impression that ancient India was land of “life-negating” 2 ascetics, imposing their gloomy and sterile ideas upon thetrusting millions who were their lay followers. fallacy of thisimpression is quite evident from secular literature, sculpture andpainting of time. average Indian, though he might pay lip-service tothe ascetic and respect his ideals, did not find life vale of tears from whichto escape at all costs; rather he was willing to accept world as he foundit, and to extract what happiness he could from it. Dandin’s description ofthe joys of simple meal served in comparatively poor home (p.,44ff) isprobably more typical of ancient Indian everyday life than r theUpanisads. India was cheerful land, whose people, each finding niche ina complex and slowly evolving social system, reached higher level ofkindliness and gentleness in their mutual relationships than any other nationof antiquity. For this, as well as for her great achievements in religion,literature, art and mathematics, one European student at least would recordhis admiration of her ancient culture.

II.

PREHISTORY: HARAPPĀ CULTURE
AND ARYANS


## PRIMITIVE MAN IN INDIA
[Page 10]LIKE prehistoric Europe, Northern India experienced ice ages, and it wasafter second of these, in Second Interglacial Period, from about400,000 to 200,000 B.C., that man first left surviving traces in India. Theseare palæolithic pebble tools of Soan Culture, so called from littleriver in Panjāb where they hv been found in large numbers. In typethey resemble tools widely distributed all over Old World, from Englandto Africa and China. In India no human remains hv been found inassociation with tools, but elsewhere such industries hv been shownto be work of primitive anthropoid types, such as Pithecanthropus ofJava and China.

In South there existed another prehistoric stone industry, which is notconclusively dated, but which may hv been approximatecontemporary of that of Soan Valley. men of this culture made coretools, especially fine hand axes, formed by striking off flakes from largepebble, and they evidently had muchbettercommandovertheirmaterialthantheSoan men. This Madras Industry, as it is called by thearchæologists, has affinities with similar core tool industries in Africa,western Europe, and southern England, where it hasbeenfound inassociation with more advanced type of man—a true Homo sapiens.The Ganges Valley is one of newest parts of earth’s surface, andmany geologists believe that at time of these two stone-age industriesmuch of it was still shallow sea; but there may hv been contact betweenthem by way of Rajasthan, for tools of one culture hv been foundsporadically in region of other. men who used these palæolithsmust hv lived in India for many millennia. Who they were and whatbecame of dm we do not know. Their blood may still flow in theinhabitants of modern India, but if pebble industry of Soan was thework of proto-human anthropoids they must hv vanished long ago, likethe Neanderthal men in Europe and Pithecanthropi of Far East.

Homo sapiens continued in India, his skill and technical equipmentimperceptibly improving down ages. He learnt to fashion microliths,[Page 11] tiny and delicate stone arrowheads and other implements, whichhave been found in many parts of India, from N.–W. Frontier to theextreme south. Similar microlithic industries occur in many parts of theNear East and Africa, but their chronological relationship with themicrolithic industry of India is not clear. In parts of Deccan microlithsare often found together with polished stone axes, and it would seem that inthe remoter parts of Peninsula their use was only fully replaced by thatof iron tools around beginning of Christian age. 1


## FIRST VILLAGES
Palæolithic man was hunter and food gatherer, and lived in very small communities, which were usually nomadic. In course of time he learnt to kindle fire, to protect his body from weather with skin, bark or leaves, and to tame wild dog which lurked round his campfire. In India, as all over world, men lived thus for many millennia.

Then, very recently in perspective of geological time, great changes took place in man’s way of living. Certainly not much earlier than 10,000B.C., and perhaps as late as 6000 B.C., man developed what Professor GordonChilde calls “an aggressive attitude to his environment”. He learnt how togrow food crops, he tamed domestic animals, he made pots, and he wovegarments. Before discovering use of metal, he taught himself to makewell-polished stone implements far in advance of those of palæolithicage. Such implements hv been found all over India, but mostly in theNorth-West and in Deccan, and usually on or near surface. In muchof country neolithic culture survived long, and many of wilder hilltribes of present day hv only recently emerged from this stage.

Developed agriculture and permanent villages probably began in 5th millennium B.C., in Middle East. In India earliest remains of settled culture r of little agricultural villages in Balūchistān and lower Sind,perhaps dating from end of 4th millennium.

Classical writers show that when, in 326 B.C., Alexander of Macedoncrossed Indus, climate of N.–W. India was much as it is today,though perhaps little moister. river valleys were fertile and wellwooded, though coastal strip to west of Indus, now called theMakrān, and much of Balūchistān, were already dry and desolate. But in3000 B.C. climate was very different. whole Indus region was wellforested, providing fuel to burn [Page 12] bricks and food for wildelephants and rhinoceros, and Balūchistān, now almost waterless desert,was rich in rivers. This region supported many villages of agriculturists,who had settled in upland valleys of Balūchistān and in then fertileplain of Makrān and lower Indus.



Fig. i.—Some Prehistoric Sites of N.–W. India
These people belonged to several cultures, primarily distinguished by different types of painted pottery. Each culture had distinctive features of its own, but all were of same generic pattern as those of Middle East.

Though their settlements were small, rarely more than few acres in extent,their material standards were comparatively high. villagers dwelt incomfortable houses of mud brick with lower courses of stone, and madegood pottery, which they painted with pleasant patterns. They knew useof metal, for few copper implements hv been discovered in sites.

[Page 13]


Fig. ii.—Terracotta Figurines of Goddesses. a. Kullī, c. 2500–2000 B.C. b. Zhob, c. 2500–2000
B.C. c. Harappā, c. 2000 B.C. d. Kaūāambī, c. 100 B.C.

The village cultures had varying customs, for secluded valleys of Brāhūī Hills and comparative simplicity of lives of inhabitants did not encourage very close contact. Thus northern villages madepredominantly red pottery, and southern buff; people of KullīCulture, in Makrān, burnt their dead, while those of Nāl Culture, inthe Brāhuī Hills, practised fractional burial, or inhumation of bonesafter partial disintegration by burning or exposure.

Their religion was of type practised by other early agriculturalcommunities in Mediterranean region and Middle East, centringround fertility rites and worship of Mother Goddess. Figurines of theGoddess hv been found in many sites, and in those of Zhob Culture,to north of Quetta, phallic emblems hv also been found. In many ancient cultures worship of Mother [Page 14] Goddess wasassociated with that of bull, and these were no exception. Bull figurineshave been discovered, and bull forms favourite motif for thedecoration of pottery of Kullī and Rānā Ghundāī, one of mostimportant of Zhob sites.

The people of Kullī culture excelled in making small boxes of soft stone, delicately engraved with linear patterns. Such boxes hv beenoccasionally found in early Mesopotamian sites, and we may assume thatthey were exported by Kullī people, perhaps filled with unguent orperfume of some kind. At Susa and elsewhere hv been found few piecesof painted pottery which r evidently imitated from wares of Kullīpeople, who obviously traded with Middle East. Otherwise there is littleevidence of contact. No certainly identifiable Mesopotamian remains havebeen found in BalūichistĀn, and there is no trace of objects from KullīCulture along overland route. It seems that Kullī people madecontact with earliest Mesopotamian civilizations by sea.



## HARAPPĀ CITY CULTURE
In early part of 3rd millennium, civilization, in sense of an organized system of government over comparatively large area, developed nearly simultaneously in river valleys of Nile, Euphrates, and Indus.
We know great deal about civilizations of Egypt and Mesopotamia, for they hv left us written material which has been satisfactorily deciphered.

The Indus people, on other hand, did not engrave long inscriptions on stone or place papyrus scrolls in tombs of their dead; all that we know of their writing is derived from brief inscriptions of their seals, and there is no Indian counterpart of Rosetta Stone. Several brilliant efforts havebeen made to read Indus seals, but none so far has succeeded. Hence ourknowledge of Indus civilization is inadequate in many respects, and itmust be classed as prehistoric, for it has no history in strict sense of theterm.

The civilization of Indus is known to archæologist as Harappa Culture, from modern name of site of one of its two great cities, onthe left bank of Rāvī, in Panjāb. Mohenjo Daro, second city, ison right bank of Indus, some 250 miles from its mouth. As well asthese two cities at least three small towns r known, and large number ofvillage sites, from Rūbpar on upper Satlaj to Rangpur in Kāthiāwār. area covered by Harappā Culture therefore extended for some 950 milesfrom north to south, and pattern of its civilization was so uniform thateven bricks were usually of same size and shape from one [Page 15]end of it to other. Outside this area village cultures of Balūchistānseem to hv continued much as before.

This great civilization owed little to Middle East, and there is no reason to believe that it was formed by recent immigrants; cities were built by people who had probably been in Indus Valley for several centuries. Harappā people were already Indians when they planned their cities, and they altered hardly at all for thousand years. We cannot fix precise date for beginning of this civilization, but certain indications synchronize it roughly with village cultures of Balūchistān. site ofRana Ghundai produced stratification which showed, in third phase ofthe village’s history, type of pottery with bold designs in black on redbackground. From evidence discovered by Sir R. Mortimer Wheeler in1946 it seems that city of Harappā was built on site occupied bypeople using similar pottery. There is no evidence of date of thefoundation of other great city of Mohenjo Daro, for its lowest strata arenow below level of Indus, whose bed has slowly risen with thecenturies; though diggings hv reached 30 feet below surface, floodinghas prevented excavation of earliest levels of city.

Thus Harappā Culture, at least in Panjāb, was later in itsbeginnings than village cultures, but it was certainly in partcontemporary with them, for traces of mutual contact hv been found; andsome of village cultures survived great civilization to east ofthem. From faint indications which r all evidence we have, itwould seem that Indus cities began in first half, perhaps towards themiddle, of 3rd millennium B.C.; it is almost certain that they continuedwell into 2nd millennium. When these cities were first excavated nofortifications and few weapons were found, and no building could becertainly identified as temple or palace. hypothesis was then putforward that cities were oligarchic commercial republics, without sharpextremes of wealth and poverty, and with only weak repressiveorganization; but excavations at Harappā in 1946 and further discoveriesat Mohenjo Daro hv shown that this idyllic picture is incorrect. Each cityhad well-fortified citadel, which seems to hv been used for bothreligious and governmental purposes. regular planning of streets,and strict uniformity throughout area of Harappā culture in suchfeatures as weights and measures, size of bricks, and even layout ofthe great cities, suggest rather single centralized state than number offree communities.

Probably most striking feature of culture was its intense [Page 16] conservatism. At Mohenjo Daro nine strata of buildings hv been revealed.

As level of earth rose from periodic flooding of Indus newhouses would be built almost exactly on sites of old, with onlyminor variations in ground plan; for nearly millennium at least streetplan of cities remained same. script of Indus people wastotally unchanged throughout their history. There is no doubt that they hadcontact with Mesopotamia, but they showed no inclination to adopt thetechnical advances of more progressive culture. We must assume thatthere was continuity of government throughout life of civilization.

This unparalleled continuity suggests, in words of Professor Piggott, “the unchanging traditions of temple” rather than “the secular instability of court”. 2 It seems in fact that civilization of Harappa, like those of Egypt and Mesopotamia, was theocratic in character.

The two cities were built on similar plan. To west of each was “citadel”, an oblong artificial platform some 30–50 feet high and about 400 x 200 yards in area (pl. V). This was defended by crenelated walls, and on it were erected public buildings. Below it was town proper, in eachcase at least square mile in area. main streets, some as much as 30feet wide, were quite straight (pl. VI a), and divided city into largeblocks, within which were networks of narrow unplanned lanes. In neitherof great cities has any stone building been found; standardized burntbrick of good quality was usual building material for dwelling housesand public buildings alike. houses, often of two or more stories, thoughthey varied in size, were all based on much same plan—a squarecourtyard, round which were number of rooms. entrances wereusually in side alleys, and no windows faced on streets, which musthave presented monotonous vista of dull brick walls. houses hadbathrooms, design of which shows that Harappan, like modernIndian, preferred to take his bath standing, by pouring pitchers of waterover his head. bathrooms were provided with drains, which flowed tosewers under main streets, leading to soak-pits. sewers werecovered throughout their length by large brick slabs. unique seweragesystem of Indus people must hv been maintained by some municipalorganization, and is one of most impressive of their achievements. Noother ancient civilization until that of Romans had so efficient systemof drains.

The average size of ground floor of house was about 30 feet square, but there were many bigger: obviously there were numerous well-to-do families in Indus cities, which perhaps had middle [Page 17] class larger and more important in social scale than those of contemporary civilizations of Sumer and Egypt. Remains of workmen’s dwellings hv also been discovered at both sites-parallel rows of two-roomed cottages, atMohenjo Daro with superficial area of 20 x 12 feet each, but at Harappāconsiderably larger; they bear striking resemblance to “coolie lines” ofmodern Indian tea and other estates. At Harappā rows of such buildingshave been found near circular brick floors on which grain was pounded,and they were probably dwellings of workmen whose task was togrind corn for priests and dignitaries who lived in citadel. Drab andtiny as they were, these cottages were better dwellings than those in whichmany Indian coolies live at present day.


Fig. iii.—Interior of House of Harappā Culture
(By permission Dept. of Archæology Government of India, and Arthur Probsthain, London.)

The most striking of few large buildings is great bath in citadel area of Mohenjo Daro. This is an oblong bathing pool 39 x 23 feet in area and 8 feet deep, constructed of beautiful brickwork made watertightwith bitumen (pl. VI b). It could be drained by [Page 18] an opening in onecorner and was surrounded by cloister, on to which opened number ofsmall rooms. Like “tank” of Hindu temple, it probably had religiouspurpose, and cells may hv been homes of priests. specialattention paid by people of Harappā culture to cleanliness is hardlydue to fact that they had notions of hygiene in advance of those of othercivilizations of their time, but indicates that, like later Hindus, they hada strong belief in purificatory effects of water from ritual point ofview.

The largest building so far excavated is one at Mohenjo Daro with superficial area of 230 x 78 feet, which may hv been palace. At Harappā great granary has been discovered to north of citadel; thiswas raised on platform of some 150 x 200 feet in area to protect it fromfloods, and was divided into storage blocks of 50 x 20 feet each. It wasdoubtless used for storing corn which was collected from peasantsas land tax, and we may assume that it had its counterpart at Mohenjo Daro.

The main food crops were wheat, barley, peas, and sesamum, latter still an important crop in India for its seeds, which provide edible oil. There is no clear evidence of cultivation of rice, but Harappā people grew and used cotton. It is not certain that irrigation was known, although this is possible. main domestic animals known to modern India had already been tamed-humped and humpless cattle, buffaloes, goats, sheep, pigs,asses, dogs, and domestic fowl. elephant was well known, and mayalso hv been tamed. Harappa people may hv known of horse,since few horse’s teeth hv been found in lowest stratum of theBalūchistān site of Rānā Ghundāī, probably dating from several centuriesearlier than foundation of Harappā. This would indicate that horse-riding nomads found their way to N.-W. India in small numbers long beforethe Āryan invasion; but it is very doubtful whether Harappa peoplepossessed domestic horses themselves, and if they did they must hv beenvery rare animals. bullock was probably usual beast of burden.

On basis of this thriving agricultural economy Harappa peoplebuilt their rather unimaginative but comfortable civilization. Theirbourgeoisie had pleasant houses, and even their workmen, who may havebeen bondmen or slaves, had comparative luxury of two-roomed brick-built cottages. Evidently well organized commerce made these thingspossible. cities undoubtedly traded with village cultures ofBalūchistān. where outposts of Harappa culture hv been traced, butmany of their metals and semi-precious stones came from much longerdistances. From Kathiawar and [Page 19] Deccan they obtained conchshell, which they used freely in decoration, and several types of stone.

Silver, turquoise and lapis lazuli were imported from Persia and Afghanistan. Their copper came either from Rajasthan or from Persia, while jadeite was probably obtained from Tibet or Central Asia.

Though their culture extended nearly to mouth of Indus people of Harappā and Mohenjo Daro seem to hv cared little for sea.

Only two representations of ships hv been found among their remains,and these r of small river vessels. But whether by sea or land, theproducts of Indus reached Mesopotamia, for number of typical Indusseals and few other objects from Indus Valley hv been found inSumer at levels dating between about 2300 and 2000 B.C. Evidence ofSumerian exports to India is very scant and uncertain, and we must assumethat they were mainly precious metals and raw materials. finding ofIndus seals suggests that merchants from India actually resided inMesopotamia; their chief merchandise was probably cotton, which hasalways been one of India’s staple exports, and which is known to hv beenused in later Babylonia.

It seems that every merchant or mercantile family had seal, bearing anemblem, often of religious character, and name or brief inscription in thetantalizingly indecipherable script. standard Harappā seal was squareor oblong plaque, usually made of soft stone called steatite, which wasdelicately engraved and hardened by heating (pl. IX). Mesopotamiancivilizations employed cylinder seals, which were rolled on clay tablets,leaving an impressed band bearing device and inscription of seal;one or two such seals hv been found in Mohenjo Daro, but with devicesof Harappa type. Over 2,000 seals hv been discovered in Induscities so far, and it would seem that every important citizen possessed one.

Their primary purpose was probably to mark ownership of property, but they doubtless also served as amulets, and were regularly carried on persons of their owners. Generally they depict animals, such as bull,buffalo, goat, tiger and elephant, or what appear to be scenes from religiouslegend. Their brief inscriptions, never of more than twenty symbols andusually of not more than ten, r only significant examples of theHarappa script to hv survived.

This script had some 270 characters, evidently pictographic in origin, which had an ideographic or syllabic character. It may hv been inspired by earliest Sumerian script, which probably antedates it slightly, but it bears little resemblance to any of scripts of ancient Middle East, though attempts hv been made to connect [Page 20] it with one or otherof them. most striking similarities r with symbols used untilcomparatively recent times by natives of Easter Island, in easternPacific,3 but distance in space and time between two cultures is sogreat that there is scarcely any possibility of there having been any form ofcontact or influence. We do not know what writing media were used,though it has been suggested that small pot found at lesser site ofChanhu Daro is an inkwell. Certainly Harappans did not inscribe theirdocuments on clay tablets, or some of these would hv been found in theremains of their cities.

They were not on whole an artistic people. No doubt they had aliterature, with religious epics similar to those of Sumer and Babylon, butthese r forever lost to us. inner walls of their houses were coated withmud plaster, but if any paintings were made on these walls all trace of themhas vanished. outer walls, facing streets, were apparently of plainbrick. Architecture was austerely utilitarian, few examples of simpledecorative brickwork being only ornamentation so far discovered. Notrace of monumental sculpture has been found anywhere in remains, andif any of larger buildings were temples they contained no large icons,unless these were made of wood or other perishable material.

But if Harappā folk could not produce works of art on large scale they excelled in those of small compass. Their most notable artistic achievement was perhaps in their seal engravings, especially those of animals, which they delineated with powerful realism and evident affection.

The great urus bull with its many dewlaps, rhinoceros with knobbly armoured hide, tiger roaring fiercely, and many other animals (pl.

IX) r work of craftsmen who studied their subjects and loved them.

Equally interesting r some of human figurines. red sandstone torso of man (pl. VIII a) is particularly impressive for its realism. modelling of rather heavy abdomen seems to look forward to style of later Indian sculpture, and it has even been suggested that this figurine isa product of much later times, which by some strange accident found itsway into lower stratum; but this is very unlikely, for figure hascertain features, notably strange indentations on shoulders, whichcannot be explained on this hypothesis. bust of another male figure, insteatite (pl. VII), seems to show an attempt at portraiture. It has beensuggested that head is that of priest, with his eyes half closed inmeditation, but it is possible that he is man of Mongolian type, thepresence of which type in Indus Valley has been proved by thediscovery of single skull at Mohenjo Daro.

[Page 21] Most striking of figurines is perhaps bronze “dancing girl” (pl. VIII b). Naked but for necklace and series of bangles almost covering one arm, her hair dressed in complicated coiffure, standing in provocative posture, with one arm on her hip and one lanky leg half bent,this young woman has an air of lively pertness, quite unlike anything in thework of other ancient civilizations. Her thin boyish figure, and those of theuninspiring mother goddesses, indicate, incidentally, that canons offemale beauty among Harappa people were very different from those oflater India. It has been suggested that this “dancing girl” is representativeof class of temple dancers and prostitutes, such as existed in contemporaryMiddle Eastern civilizations and were an important feature of later Hinduculture, but this cannot be proved. It is not certain that girl is dancer,much less temple dancer.

The Harappā people made brilliantly naturalistic models of animals, specially charming being tiny monkeys and squirrels used as pinheads and beads (pl. IX g). For their children they made cattle with movable heads, model monkeys which would slide down string, little toy carts, andwhistles shaped like birds, all of terracotta. They also made rough terracottastatuettes of women, usually naked or nearly naked, but with elaboratehead-dresses (fig. ii, c); these r certainly icons of Mother Goddess,and r so numerous that they seem to hv been kept in nearly every home.

They r very crudely fashioned, so we must assume that goddess was not favoured by upper classes, who commanded services of best craftsmen, but that her effigies were mass produced by humble potters to meet popular demand.

Though they had not completely given up use of stone tools theHarappā people used implements of copper and bronze; but in manyrespects they were technologically backward in comparison withMesopotamia. Sumerians very early invented knives and spearheadswith ribs in middle for extra strength, and axeheads with holes for theshafts; but blades of Harappā were flat and easily bent, while theaxeheads had to be lashed to their shafts; only in topmost levels do wefind tools of better type, which were probably left by invaders. In onerespect Harappā people were technically in advance of theircontemporaries-they had devised saw with undulating teeth, whichallowed dust to escape freely from cut, and much simplified thecarpenter’s task. From this we may assume that they had particular skill incarpentry. They made beautiful beads of semi-precious stones and faience,and their pottery, though mostly plain and uninteresting, was well made,and few specimens r delicately painted (fig. iv).

[Page 22] men wore robes which left one shoulder bare, and garments of upper classes were often richly patterned. Beards wereworn, and men and women alike had long hair. elaborate headdressesof Mother Goddess figures probably had their counterparts in festiveattire of richer women. goddesses often wear only very short skirt,but on one seal women, perhaps priestesses, r depicted with longer skirts,reaching to just below knee. coiffures of women were oftenelaborate, and pigtails were also popular, as in present-day India. Womenloved jewellery, and wore heavy bangles in profusion, large necklaces, andearrings.

As far as we cn reconstruct it from our fragmentary knowledge, thereligion of Harappā people had some features suggesting thosecharacteristics of later Hinduism which r not to be found in earlieststratum of Indian religious literature. Mother Goddess, for instance,reappears only after lapse of over thousand years from fall ofHarappa. As already stated she was evidently divinity of people, andthe upper classes seem to hv preferred god, who also shows featuresfound in later Hinduism. As well as figurines already mentioned, whichmay represent divinities, there r few in terracotta of bearded nude menwith coiled hair; their posture, rigidly upright, with legs slightly apart,and arms held parallel to sides of body, but not touching it,closely resembles stance called by Jainas kāyotsarga, in whichmeditating teachers r often portrayed in later times; repetition of thisfigure, in exactly same posture, would suggest that he was god. Aterracotta mask of horned deity has also been found.

Fig. iv.—Painted Pottery of Harappā CultureThe most striking deity of Harappā culture is horned god of theseals (pl. IX c). He is depicted on three specimens, in two [Page 23] seatedon stool or small dais, and in third on ground; in all three hisposture is one well known to later Indian holy men, with legs drawn upclose to body and two heels touching, position quite impossible tothe average European without much practice. god’s body is nude,except for many bangles and what appear to be necklaces, and he wears apeculiar head-dress, consisting of pair of horns, which may hv beenthought of as growing from his head, with plant-like object between them.

On largest of seals he is surrounded by four wild animals, an elephant, tiger, rhinoceros and buffalo, and beneath his stool r two deer, as in representations of Buddha preaching his first sermon in Deer-park at BanĀras animals, plant-like growth from head,and fact that he is ithyphallic, indicate that he is fertility god. His facehas fierce tigerish aspect, and one authority has suggested that it is notmeant to be human; 4 to right and left of head r smallprotuberances which were believed by Sir John Marshall to represent asecond and third face on either side. Marshall boldly called this god Proto-Śiva, and name has been generally accepted; certainly horned godhas much in common with Śiva of later Hinduism, who is, in his mostimportant aspect, fertility deity, is known as Paśupati, Lord of Beasts,and is sometimes depicted withthreefaces.Sacred animals played big part in religion of Indus people.Though all animals shown on seals may not hv been particularlysacred, bull occurs in contexts which prove that he at least was so; onmany seals he stands before peculiar object which is evidently not amanger, and has no utilitarian purpose, but is “cult object”, probably atable on which corn was grown for fertility rites. 5 On some seals small linesemerge from table, which may represent growing corn, no doubteaten by sacred bull as part of ceremony. bull is usuallydepicted with single horn, and has sometimes been referred to as aunicorn, though there is little doubt that artist was trying to portray anormal bull, whose second horn was concealed by first. In Hinduism thebull is specially associated with god Siva, but he does notseemtohavebeenconnectedwiththe“ProtoSiva” of Harappa, for he is not among theanimals surrounding god on famous seal1. cow, so revered inlater Hinduism, is nowhere depicted.Certain trees were sacred, as they r in Hinduism today, notably thepīpal, which is specially honoured by Buddhists as species under whichthe Buddha found enlightenment. One very interesting seal (pl. IX d)depicts horned goddess in pīpal tree, worshipped [Page 24] by figurealso wearing horns, with human-headed goat watching ceremony anda row of seven pigtailed women, probably priestesses, in attendance.One of few traces of Sumerian contact is to be found in sealshowing hero grappling with two tigers (pl. IX e)—a variant of famousMesopotamian motif in which hero Gilgamesh is depicted fighting twolions. rotund face of hero, and peculiar treatment of his hair,suggest that he represents sun, and that night-prowling tigers r thepowers of darkness.Phallic worship was an important element of Harappā religion. Manycone-shaped objects hv been found, which r almost certainlyformalized representations of phallus. linga or phallic emblem inlater Hinduism is symbol of god Śiva, who is more commonlyworshipped thus than as an icon; it is fair inference that these objects wereconnected with ithyphallic “Proto-Śiva” of seals. It has beensuggested that certain large ringshaped stones r formalizedrepresentations of female generative organ and were symbols of theMother Goddess, but this is most doubtful.Until Sir Mortimer Wheeler’s work at Harappā in 1946 nothing wasknown with certainty of way in which these people disposed of theirdead; but from cemetery then discovered, containing at least 57 graves, itappears that burial was usual rite. whole cemetery has not beenexcavated and evidence is not yet fully assessed, but it is clear that thedead were buried in an extended posture with pottery vessels and personalornaments.

Who were people who built this great civilization? Some Indianhistorians hv tried to prove that they were Aryans, people whocomposed Ṛ g Veda, but this is quite impossible. From skeletalremains so far examined it appears that some of Harappans were peopleof long-headed, narrow-nosed, slender Mediterranean type, found allover ancient Middle East and in Egypt, and forming an importantelement of Indian population at present day. second element wasthe Proto-Australoid, with flat nose and thick lips, related to Australianaborigines and to some of wild hill-tribes of modern India. singleskull of Mongolian type has been found, and one of short-headed Alpinetype. bearded steatite head to which we hv referred shows elementsof both latter types, while bronze dancing girl seems certainly Proto-Australoid. Then as now, N.-W. India was meeting-place of many races.The modern South Indian is usually blend of Mediterranean and Proto-Australoid, two chief ethnic factors in Harappā culture; [Page 25]moreover Harappā religion seems to show many similarities with thoseelements of Hinduism which r specially popular in Dravidian country.In hills of Balūchistān. where people of Nal and Zhob Culturesbuilt their little villages, Br?hu?s, though ethnically now predominantlyIranian, speak Dravidian language. Thus it has been suggested that theHarappā folk were Dravidians, and Father H. Heras, one of authoritieswho hv tried to read their script, has even claimed that their language wasa very primitive form of Tamil.

## PIONEERS OF INDOLOGY
PLATE IV
It might be suggested that Harappā people consisted of Proto- Australoid element, which at one time may hv covered whole of India, overlaid by Mediterranean one, which entered India at very earlyperiod, bringing with it elements of civilization. Later, under thepressure of further invasions, this Mediterranean element spread throughoutthe sub-continent, and, again mixing with indigenous peoples, formedthe Dravidians. chief objection to this theory is that megalithserected by early Dravidians in South India hv been shown to be notvery ancient; recent theory even holds that Dravidians came to Indiafrom west by sea as late as second half of 1st millennium B.C. 6We cn only say with certainty that some of inhabitants of Induscities were of typewidelyfoundfurthertothewest,andthattheirdescendants must survive in present-day population of India.There is no Archæological evidence of cities of Harappā peoplebeyond Indus basin, but small outposts existed in Kathiawar; yet it doesnot follow that rest of India was wholly ignorant of Harappā culture.Certain finds of copper implements in district of R?nch? (S. Bih?r)suggest that peoples of North India learnt use of metal fromHarappa, for blades r without strengthening midrib; but datingof these objects is very uncertain, and they may be much later than fallof Harappā.Whatever case may be, pre-Āryan India made certain advances inhusbandry for which whole world owes her debt. Cotton was to thebest of our knowledge first used by Harappā people. Rice was not oneof their staple crops, nor was it grown in neolithic China, whose main foodcrop was millet. Wild rice is known in Eastern India, and it is here, in theswampy Ganges Valley, that it was probably first cultivated by neolithiccontemporaries of Harappa people. water buffalo, known to theHarappā people, was comparatively late arrival in China, and it may havebeen first domesticated in Gangetic Plain, though some authoritiesbelieve that it originated in Philippine Islands.[Page 26] Perhaps most widely appreciated of prehistoric India’s giftsto world is domestic fowl. Ornithologists r agreed that alldomestic species descend from wild Indian jungle fowl. Harappapeople knew domestic fowl, though its remains r few and it is notdepicted on seals. It was probably first tamed by neolithic Indians in theGanges Valley, whence it found its way by Burma route to China, whereit appears in middle of 2nd millennium. Egyptians knew it atabout same time, as rare luxury bird.7 Clearly India, even at thisremote period, was not wholly cut off from rest of world.

## END OF INDUS CITIES
When Harappā was first built citadel was defended by great turreted wall, 40 feet wide at base and 35 feet high. In course of centuriesthis wall was refaced more strongly than before, though there is no evidencethat city was dangerously threatened by enemies. But towards end ofHarappa’s existence its defences were further strengthened, and onegateway was wholly blocked. Danger threatened from west.

First to suffer were Balūichistān villages. earliest level of site of Rānā Ghundāī shows that bands of horse-riding invaders were present in region before 3000 B.C., but they soon disappeared, to give way to peasant culture which occupied site in 3rd millennium and was contemporary with Indus cities. Then, in 2000 B.C. or little later, village was burnt, and new, coarser type of pottery appears-evidently invaders had occupied site. Soon afterwards came other invaders, usingunpainted encrusted pottery. Similar though less complete evidence appearsin other North Balūchistān sites, while in South Balūchistān an intrusiveculture founded settlement at Shāhī Tump, not far from Sutkagen Dor,which was Harappā Culture’s most westerly outpost. Shāhī Tumppeople used shaft-hole axe and round copper seals, and replaced theearlier local culture, known to archæologists as Kullī Culture. In lastphase of life of Mohenjo Daro painted pottery and stone vesselsresembling those of Balūchistān appear, and this may indicate large influxof Kullī refugees, who brought their crafts with them.

After barbarians had conquered outlying villages ancient lawsand rigid organization of Indus cities must hv suffered great strain. AtMohenjo Daro large rooms were divided into smaller, and mansions becametenements; potters’ kilns were built within city boundaries, and oneeven in middle of street. [Page 27] street plan was no longermaintained. Hoards of jewellery were buried. Evidently city wasoverpopulated and law and order were less well maintained, perhapsbecause barbarians were already ranging provinces and city wasfull of newcomers, whom city fathers could not force into age-oldpattern of city’s culture.When end came it would seem that most of citizens of MohenjoDaro had fled; but group of huddled skeletons in one of houses andone skeleton of woman lying on steps of well suggest that fewstragglers were overtaken by invaders. In this level fine copper axehas been found, with very strong shaft-hole and an adze blade oppositethat of axe-a beautiful tool, adapted both for war and peace, andsuperior to anything Harappa people possessed (fig. v). Swords withstrengthening midribs also make their appearance. single pot burial of aman of some-what Mongol type may be that of one of invaders.


Fig. v.-Axes of Indus Citiesa. Inscribed unsocketed axe-head. b. Shaft-hole axe-adzeFrom Harappā comes evidence of different kind. Here, near oldercemetery of interments, is another cemetery on higher level, containingfractional burials in pots of men with short-headed Armenoid skulls. Askull of similar type was buried in citadel itself. At Chanhu Daro, on thelower Indus, Harappā people were replaced by squatters, living in smallhuts with fireplaces, an innovation which suggests that they came from acolder climate. These people, though unsophisticated in many respects, hadsuperior tools and weapons. Similar settlements were made in Balūchistānat about same time. Among scanty remains of these invaders there isclear evidence of presence of horse. Indus cities fell tobarbarians who triumphed not only through greater military prowess, butalso because they were equipped with better weapons, and had learnt tomake full use of swift and terror-striking beast of steppes.The date of these great events cn only be fixed very approximately fromsynchronisms with Middle East. Sporadic traces of contact cn be foundbetween Indus cities and Sumeria, and there is some reason to believethat these contacts continued under First [Page 28] Dynasty of Babylon,which produced great lawgiver Hammurabi. This dynasty was alsooverwhelmed by barbarians, Kassites, who came from hills of Iranand conquered by virtue of their horse-drawn chariots. After Kassiteinvasion no trace of contact with Indus cn be found in Mesopotamia,and it is therefore likely that Indus cities fell at about same time asthe dynasty of Hammurabi. Earlier authorities placed latter event in thefirst centuries of 2nd millennium B.C., but new evidence, whichappeared shortly before outbreak of Second World War, has resultedin revised chronology. fall of First Babylonian Dynasty is nowthought to hv taken place about 1600 B.C.The earliest Indian literary source we possess is Ṛ g Veda, most ofwhich was composed in second half of 2nd millennium. It isevidently work of an invading people, who hv not yet fully subjugatedthe original inhabitants of N.-W. India. In his great report on theexcavations at Mohenjo Daro, Sir John Marshall maintained that some twocenturies or more elapsed between fall of Indus cities and theinvasion of Aryans; but more recent excavations at Harappā andelsewhere, revision of chronology of Babylon, and indications in theṚ g Veda itself, hv all tended to reduce gap. Many competentauthorities, led by Sir R. Mortimer Wheeler, now believe that Harappā wasoverthrown by Aryans. It is suggested that interments in latercemetery at Harappā r those of “true Vedic Aryans”, and that forts orcitadels which Vedic war-god Indra is said to hv destroyed includedHarappā in their number.There is not enough evidence to say with certainty that destroyers ofthe Indus cities were members of group of related tribes whose priestscomposed Ṛ g Veda, but it is probable that fall of this greatcivilization was an episode in movement of charioteering peoples whichaltered face of whole civilized world in 2nd millennium B.C.

## INDO-EUROPEANS AND ĀRYANS
The invaders of India called themselves Āryas, word generally anglicized into Āryans. name was also used by ancient Persians, and survives in word Iran, while Eire, name of most westerly land reached by Indo-European peoples in ancient times, is also cognate.Here we cannot discuss many theories on origin of these people, butcan only give that which seems to us most reasonable, and which, webelieve, would be accepted by majority of those who specialize in thesubject.
