PLATE VI
[Page 29] About 2000 B.C. great steppeland which stretches from Poland to Central Asia was inhabited by semi-nomadic barbarians, who were tall, comparatively fair, and mostly long-headed. They had tamed horse, which they harnessed to light chariots with spoked wheels, of much faster and better type than lumbering ass-drawn cars with four solid wheels which were best means of transport known to contemporarySumer. They were mainly pastoral, but practised little agriculture. Thoughthey may never hv come into direct contact with Sumerians, they hadadopted some Mesopotamian innovations, notably shaft-hole axe. In theearly part of 2nd millennium, whether from pressure of population,desiccation of pasture lands, or from both causes, these people were on themove. They migrated in bands westwards, southwards and eastwards,conquering local populations, and intermarrying with dm to form rulingclass. They brought with dm their patrilinear tribal organization, theirworship of sky gods, and their horses and chariots. In most of lands inwhich they settled their original language gradually adapted itself to thetongues of conquered peoples. Some invaded Europe, to become theancestors of Greeks, Latins, Celts and Teutons, while others appeared inAnatolia, and from mixture of these with original inhabitants thegreat empire of Hittites grew up. Yet others remained in their old home,the ancestors of later Baltic and Slavonic peoples, while others movedsouthwards and, from Caucasus and Iranian tableland, led manyattacks on Middle Eastern civilizations. Kassites, who conqueredBabylon, were led by men of this stock. In 14th century B.C. thereappeared in N.-E. Syria people called Mitanni, whose kings had Indo-Iranian names, and few of whose gods r familiar to every student ofIndian religion: Indara, Uruvna (the Vedic god Varuna), Mitira, andNaśatiya. As well as Mitanni other chiefs in Syria and Palestine hadnames of Indo-Iranian type.The marauding tribesmen gradually merged with older populations ofthe Middle East, and ancient civilizations, invigorated by fresh bloodand ideas, rose to new heights of material culture; peaceful andconservative cities of Indus valley could neither withstand nor absorbthe invaders. culture which was to succeed that of Harappā was, as weshall see, diametrically opposed to its predecessor. Only after manycenturies did some elements of older civilization, kept alive no doubt bythe poorer people and serfs, begin to influence conquerors.The Āryan invasion of India was not single concerted action, but onecovering centuries and involving many tribes, perhaps not all [Page 30] ofthe same race and language. It seems certain that many of old villagecultures of western hills were destroyed before cities of IndusValley, but otherwise course of Āryan expansion cannot be plotted,owing to paucity of material remains. Evidently invaders did nottake to living in cities, and after fall of Harappā and Mohenjo Daro thePanjāb and Sind became land of little villages, with buildings of wood andreed remains of which hv long since perished. For over thousandyears from fall of Harappā India is almost an Archæological blank,which at present cn only be filled by literary sources.
## ĀRYANS IN INDIA. PROTO-HISTORIC PERIOD
Among many peoples who entered India in 2nd millennium B.C.was group of related tribes whose priests had perfected very advancedpoetic technique, which they used for composition of hymns to be sungin praise of their gods at sacrifices. These tribes, chief of which was that ofthe Bharatas, settled mainly in East Panjāb and in region between theSatlaj and Jamnā which later became known as Brahmāvarta. Thehymns composed by their priests in their new home were carefully handeddown by word of mouth, and early in 1st millennium B.C. were collectedand arranged. They were still not committed to writing, but by now theywere looked on as so sacred that even minor alterations in their text werenot permitted, and priestly schools which preserved dm devised themost remarkable and effective system of checks and counter checks toensure their purity. Even when art of writing was widely known in Indiathe hymns were rarely written, but, thanks to brilliant feats of memoryof many generations of brāhmans, and extreme sanctity which thehymns were thought to possess, they hv survived to present day in aform which, from internal evidence, appears not to hv been seriouslytampered with for nearly three thousand years. This great collection ofhymns is Ṛ g Veda, still in theory most sacred of numeroussacred texts of Hindus.

The period of Vedas, Brāhmanas and Upanisads is sort of transition from prehistory to history. If history, as distinct from archæology, is study of human past from written sources, then India’s history beginswith Aryans. Ṛ g Veda, and great body of oral religious literaturewhich followed it in first half of 1st millennium B.C., r part of theliving Hindu tradition. Vedic hymns r still recited at weddings andfunerals, and in daily devotions of brāhman. Thus they r part of[Page 31] historical India, and do not belong to her buried prehistoric past.But they tell us little about great events of time, except in irritatinglyvague incidental references; evenonsocialconditionstheirinformationisscant; only on religion and thought is historian more fully informed.Yet from hymns of Rg and Atharva Vedas, sacrificialinstructions of brāhmanas, and mysticism of Upanisads, theoutlines of culture emerge, though often all too vaguely, and here andthere we see faint wraiths of great sages and tribal leaders, whoseimportance for their times was such that their names were recorded insacred literature. Around these phantoms later tradition draped glitteringmantle of legend, legend in which many Indians still implicitly believe, andwhich, in other contexts, is exceedingly important. But when mantlesare removed only vague shadows remain, little more than names ofchieftains who three thousand years ago waged successful war against theirenemies. For period before time of Buddha we canonly trace thegeneral character of civilization which produced Vedic literature andgive brief and tentative sketch of its expansion.## CULTURE OF Ṛ g VedaNo real synchronisms r contained in Ṛ g Veda itself, to give us anycertain information on date of its composition. Some authorities in thepast claimed an exceedingly early date for it, on basis of tradition andambiguous astronomical references in hymns themselves-it was evenbelieved by one very respected Indian scholar that it was as old as 6000 B.C.The discovery of Indus cities, which hv nothing in common with theculture described in Veda and r evidently pre-Vedic, proves that thehymns cannot hv been composed before end of Harappa. greatdevelopment in culture, religion and language which is evident in laterVedic literature shows that long period must hv elapsed between thetime of composition of last hymns of Ṛ g Veda and days ofthe Buddha-perhaps as much as 500 years. It is therefore probable that mostof Ṛ g Veda was composed between 1500 and 1000 B.C., though thecomposition of some of most recent hymns and collation of thewhole collection may hv taken place century or two later.When hymns were written focus of Āryan culture was regionbetween Jamnā (Sanskrit Yamunā) and Satlaj ( Śutudrī), south of themodern Ambālā, and along upper course of river [Page 32]Sarasvatī. latter river is now an insignificant stream, losing itself in thedesert of Rajasthan, but it then flowed broad and strong, and probablyjoined Indus below confluence of Satlaj. Vedic poets knewthe Himalayas, but not land south of Jamnā, and they did notmention Vindhyas. To east Aryans had not expanded far beyondthe Jamnā, and Ganges ( Gangā) is mentioned only in one late hymn.At this time Āryans had not wholly subjugated indigenousinhabitants. Though many hymns refer to battles between one Aryan tribeand another, there is, underlying this intertribal rivalry, sense of solidarityagainst Dāsas or Dasyus, who evidently represent survivors of theHarappā Culture, and kindred peoples of Panjāb and North-West.The Dāsas r described as dark and ill-favoured, bull-lipped, snub-nosed,worshippers of phallus, and of hostile speech. They r rich in cattle,and dwell in fortified places called pur, of which Āryan war-god Indrahas destroyed hundreds. main work of destroying settlements of theDāsas had been accomplished some time before composition of thehymns, and great battles which must then hv taken place r alreadymisted over with legend; but Dāsas r still capable of massing armiesof 10,000 men against invaders.Other enemies of Āryans r Panis, who r described as wealthypeople who refuse to patronize Vedic priests, and who steal cattle ofthe Aryans. They were not so strongly hated as Dāsas, and theirsettlements seem often to hv continued unmolested. It has been suggestedthat Panis were Semitic traders, but evidence is so slight that thisconclusion cannot be accepted.

The Aryans were not uninfluenced by earlier inhabitants. In classical Sanskrit word d?sa regularly means “slave” or “bondman”, and in later hymns of Ṛ g Veda it was already acquiring that meaning, while feminine form dāsī is used in sense of “slave-girl” throughout book; but, though many of vanquished Dāsas must hv been enslaved, some seem to hv come to terms with conquerors, and one Dāsa chief is mentioned as following Āryan ways and patronizing brāhmans.8 Oneresult of this contact of Āryan and non-Āryan is evident even in earlieststratum of Ṛ g Veda, language of which is appreciably affected bynon-Indo-European influences. All Indian languages, from Vedic to themodern vernaculars, contain series of sounds, retroflex or cerebralconsonants, which cannot be traced in any other Indo-European tongues,not even in Old Iranian, which is closely akin to Sanskrit. These soundsmust hv developed quickly, from efforts of non-Aryans to master thelanguage of their [Page 33] conquerors. No doubt invaders oftenmarried indigenous women, whose children would be bilingual, and after afew generations Aryans’ original language would show effect of theadmixture of aboriginal blood. Numerous words in Ṛ g Veda r notconnected with any known Indo-European roots, and were evidentlyborrowed from natives. Non-Aryan influence on religion and culturemust also hv been felt very early, and gradual disappearance of muchof original Indo-European heritage beneath successive layers of non-Aryan innovations cn be traced through early religious literature ofIndia.The primitiveness of early Āryan society was much exaggerated by some19th-century Indologists, who thought they found in highly formalizedand rigidly controlled style of Ṛ g Veda first outpourings of thehuman spirit and an echo of Rousseau’s noble savage. In fact, by timethat even earliest hymns were composed Aryans were not savages,but were on fringes of civilization. Their military technique was inadvance of that of Middle East, their priestly schools had raised thetribal sacrifice to fine art, and their poetry was elaborate and formalized.On other hand they had not developed city civilization. completeabsence of any words connected with writing in Ṛ g Veda, despite itssize and many contexts in which such words might be expected tooccur, is almost certain proof that Aryans were illiterate. They were apeople of warlike stockbreeders, organized in tribes rather than inkingdoms. Their culture bears generic likeness to that of Beowulf, theearlier Icelandic sagas, and old Irish prose epics, and was less advancedthan that depicted in Iliad.The tribes were ruled by chiefs who bore title rājā, word related tothe Latin rex. rājā was not an absolute monarch, for government ofthe tribe was in part responsibility of tribal councils, sabhā andsamiti. These two words occur together in many contexts and distinctionbetween dm is not wholly clear-perhaps first was meeting of thegreat men of tribe, while second was mass gathering of all freetribesmen, or of heads of families. These two bodies exerted muchinfluence on king and their approval was necessary to ensure hisaccession. Some tribes seem to hv had no hereditary chief, but weregoverned directly by tribal council, for in one passage9 we read of kingssitting down together in assembly, which suggests that, as in some lateroligarchic clans, title of raja was taken by all great men of tribe,who governed it through folk-moot.

But hereditary kingship was rule, and rājā, dwelling in fine hall,had rudimentary court, attended by courtiers ( sabhāsad) [Page 34] andchiefs of septs ( grāmanī). Already he had general (senānī), who wasresponsible under king for minor campaigns and cattle-raids againstneighbouring tribes. Very important was chief priest ( purohita), who byhis sacrifices ensured prosperity of tribe in peace, and its victory inwar. Often purohita appears as tribal medicine-man, performingmagical ceremonies and muttering spells for victory both before and duringbattle.

The Āryans looked on king primarily as leader in war, responsiblefor defence of tribe. He was in no sense divine at this early period,and had no religious functions, except to order sacrifices for good of thetribe and to support priests who performed them. priest-king ofsome other early cultures had no counterpart in Vedic India. There was noregular revenue system and king was maintained by tribute of hissubjects and booty won in battle. If king had judicial functions, as hecertainly had later, there is no reference to them; murder was probablypunished by system of wergeld, as with Anglo-Saxons and some otherearly Indo-European peoples, but beyond this we hv no information onthe administration of justice in time of Ṛ g Veda.Several chieftains r mentioned by name, and around some of dm latertradition has embroidered very unreliable stories-but only one raja isrecorded in Ṛ g Veda as performing any deed of historical importance.This is Sudās, king of Bharatas, tribe dwelling on upper reachesof Sarasvatī River. Three poems of collection describe great“Battle of Ten Kings” at which Sudās defeated coalition of ten tribesof Panjāb and North-West, on banks of River Parusnī, themodern Rāvī. most powerful of these ten tribes was that of Pūrus,who dwelt on lower Sarasvatī, and were Bharatas’ westernneighbours; their king, Purukutsa, was apparently killed in battle. In thesucceeding age we hear no more of either Bharatas or Pūrus, but newtribe, that of Kurus, controls old land of Bharatas and much ofthe northern Ganges-Jamnā Doāb. In traditional genealogy of Kuruchiefs both Bharata and Pūru occur as names of their ancestors, and they arereferred to indiscriminately as “sons of Bharata” and “sons of Pūru”. Thetwo tribes no doubt merged as result of conquest of one by other,and this process of fusion, whereby tribes became peoples and nations, musthave been going on all through Vedic period.When Āryans entered India there was already class division in theirtribal structure. Even in earliest hymns we read of ksatra, thenobility, and viś, ordinary tribesmen, and records of several otherearly Indo-European peoples suggest that [Page 35] tribal aristocracy wasa feature of Indo-European society even before tribes migrated fromtheir original home. As they settled among darker aboriginals theAryans seem to hv laid greater stress than before on purity of blood, andclass divisions hardened, to exclude those Dāsas who had found place onthe fringes of Aryan society, and those Aryans who had intermarried withthe Dāsas and adopted their ways. Both these groups sank in socialscale. At same time priests, whose sacrificial lore was becomingmore and more complicated, and who therefore required greater skill andtraining, were arrogating higher privileges to themselves. By end of theRg Vedic period society was divided into four great classes, and thisfourfold division was given religious sanction and looked on asfundamental. This is evident from one of most important hymns of thecollection, in which four classes r said to hv emanated from thedismembered primeval man, who was sacrificed by gods at thebeginning of world (p. 240f).The four classes, priest ( brāhmana), warrior ( ksatriya), peasant( vaiśdya) and serf (śūdra), were crystallizing throughout period of theṚ g Veda. They hv survived to present day. Sanskrit word used forthem, varna, means “colour”, and itself indicates their origin in thedevelopment of old tribal class structure in contact with people ofdifferent complexion and alien culture. term varna does not mean“caste”, and has never meant “caste”, by which convenient word it is oftenloosely translated (p. 148).

The basic unit of Āryan society was family. group of related families formed sept or grāma, term which later regularly meant “village”, but which in Ṛ g Veda usually refers to group of kinsfolk rather than to settlement. family was staunchly patrilinear andpatriarchal. wife, though she enjoyed respectable position, wasdefinitely subordinate to her husband. Marriage was usually monogamous,and apparently indissoluble, for no reference to divorce or remarriage ofwidows occurs in Ṛ g Veda.Āhe Aryans followed mixed pastoral and agricultural economy, inwhich cattle played predominant part. farmer prays for increase ofcattle; warrior expects cattle as booty; sacrificial priest is rewardedfor his services with cattle. Cattle were in fact sort of currency, and valueswere reckoned in heads of cattle. There is no evidence that they were heldsacred at this time-the cow is in one or two places given epithet “not tobe killed”, but this may only imply her economic importance. In any case itis quite clear that both oxen and cows were slaughtered for food.The horse was almost as important as cow, though mainly for militaryreasons. chestnut horses of Aryans, harnessed to [Page 36] lightchariots, must hv terrifiedthepeopleof Indus Valley, as horses ofthe conquistadores terrified Aztecs and Incas. few hymns of Ṛ gVeda, which, acc to rubric, describe adivinehorseDadhikra,contain some of finest lines on horse in world’s literature, andrecall famous passage in praise of war-horse in theBookofJob.10“Rushingtoglory,tothecapture of herds, swooping down as ahungry falcon, eager to be first, he darts amid ranks of chariots,happy as bridegroom making garland, spurning thedustandchampingat bit.“And victorious steed and faithful, his body obedient [to hisdriver] in battle, speeding on through mêlée, stirs up dust to fallon his brows.“And at his deep neigh, like thunder of heaven, foementremble in fear, for he fights against thousands, and none cn resisthim, so terrible is his charge.” 11Though there r passages which appear to refer to riding, horsenormally drew chariot. References to this vehicle-a favourite subject forsimiles and metaphors-are so numerous that it is possible to reconstruct it inconsiderable detail. It was light chariot with two spoked wheels, drawn bytwo horses yoked abreast, and carrying two warriors.Among other domestic animals Āryans knew sheep, whichprovided wool, their chief textile, and goat. elephant is onlymentioned in late hymns, and then as wild animal.A divine bitch, Sarama, plays an important part in legend which cannotbe fully reconstructed, but dog did not mean as much to people ofthe Ṛ g Veda as it did to kindred Āryan pastoral people, ancientIranians, who made it sacred animal.

Though stockbreeding receives more attention from poets, agriculturemust also hv been important, but it seems to hv been looked on asrather plebeian, and therefore was not much referred to. Only one word isused for corn— yava, which later meant barley, but at this period may haveimplied all species of cultivated grain. There r references to ploughingand reaping, and others which hv been doubtfully interpreted as showingthat Aryans knew something of irrigation.The Āryans were wild, turbulent people and had few of taboos[Page 37] of later India. They were much addicted to inebriating drinks, ofwhich they had at least two, soma and surā. Soma was drunk at sacrificesand its use was sanctified by religion (p. 235f). Surā was purely secular, andwas evidently very potent; in more than one passage it is mentioned withdisapproval by priestly poets.

They loved music, and played flute, lute and harp, to theaccompaniment of cymbals and drums. They used heptatonic scale,similar to our own major scale, which is thought by some to hv originatedin Sumeria and to hv been spread by IndoEuropean peoples. There arereferences to singing and dancing, and to dancing-girls, who may hv beenprofessional.

Besides these amusements Āryans delighted in gambling. At all timesIndia has loved to gamble. In remains of Indus cities numerous dicehave been found, and Aryans hv left their own record of theirgambling propensities in beautiful “Gamester’s Lament”, one of fewpredominantly secular poems which by lucky chancehavefoundtheirwayinto Ṛ g Veda (p. 403ff).Though they had not developed city civilization, and did not build instone or brick, Aryans were technically well equipped. Their bronze-smiths were highly skilled, and produced tools and weapons much superiorto those of Harappā Culture. They, and carpenters and chariot-makers, r frequently referred to in hymns with much respect. There isno good reason to believe that iron was used in India at this period. Ayas,one of terms for metal in Ṛ g Veda, came to mean iron at later date,and is related to German word Eisen and English iron; but it is alsoakin to Latin aes, meaning bronze, and it certainly means this metal orcopper in Ṛ g Veda. No trace of iron has been found in upper levelsof remains of Indus Culture, and at this period iron implements wererare, even in advanced civilizations of Mesopotamia. Iron ore iscommon enough, but its smelting demands higher skill than Aryans haddeveloped. At time of composition of Ṛ g Veda process ofsmelting iron was hardly known outside Anatolia, where Hittite kingstried to keep it secret. Only at very end of 2nd millennium did theuse of iron begin to spread widely over civilized world, and it is veryunlikely that it had reached India by this time. 12As might be expected of people without cities, Aryans did not havean advanced economic system. In Mesopotamia silver shekel, thoughunstamped, served as means of exchange, but Aryans relied for theirunit of value and means of barter on unwieldy cow. niska, termlater used for gold coin, is also mentioned as sort of currency, but at thistime was probably gold [Page 38] ornament of some kind. There is noevidence of regular class of merchants or moneylenders, thoughindebtedness is sometimes referred to.The religion of early Aryans, about which we know much more thanwe do about their everyday life and customs, will be discussed in laterchapter (p.232 ff).

## LATER VEDIC AGE
Between composition of Ṛ g Veda and age of Buddha, when we begin to trace history of India with comparative clearness, period of some four or five hundred years elapsed. During this time Aryans pushed eastwards down Ganges, and their culture adapted itself to changed conditions. Very recently Indian archæologists hv excavated asite which belongs to this period, that of ancient city of Hastin?pura, thelowest level of which has been reasonably fixed at between 1000 and 700B.C., time of later Vedas. 13 town was almost completelydestroyed by flood at end of its existence, and little remains but sherdsof painted grey pottery, few copper implements, and traces of houses ofunbaked brick. typical pottery has been found from Sarasvatī Valleyin west to Ahicchatr?, near upper Ganges, in east. With theseexceptions we hv scarcely any direct knowledge of period, and oursources r still almost entirely sacred texts, later Vedas, brāhmanas andUpanisads, which will be treated elsewhere from religious and literarypoint of view (p. 241 ff).Besides these contemporary documents there r many legends containedin other sources, notably Epics and Pur?nas, which seem to refer to thisperiod; but these r so overlaid by accretions of later centuries that noattempt at interpreting dm historically has so far won general acceptance,and it may never be possible to sift fact from fiction. Even socialconditions described in Epics, stories of which may hv beencomposed in primitive form at this time, mainly refer not to this age, butto obscure period between Mauryan and Guptan Empires. Attemptsof some earlier authorities to create an “Epic Age” in history of India, asdistinct from age of later Vedas, r quite unconvincing. There wasno Epic Age, and for our knowledge of this period we may only rely on theliterature of period itself. This, like Ṛ g Veda, is wholly religious, andtells us little more than older source about history of time.One event, not definitely recorded in these contemporary sources, but sostrongly remembered that it must hv been very important, [Page 39] wasthe great battle of Kuruksetra, not far from modern Delhi. This battle,magnified to titanic proportions, formed basis of story of greatestof India’s epics, Mahābhārata. acc to legend whole ofIndia, from Sind to Assam and from Himalayas to Cape Comorin, tookpart in war, which arose through dynastic dispute in great Kurutribe (p. 408). It is by no means certain that war was in fact civil one,and story has been plausibly interpreted as muddled recollection of theconquest of Kurus by tribe of Mongol type from hills. Butcertainly great war took place, and succeeding generations looked on it asmarking end of an epoch. names of many of heroes of theMahābhārata may genuinely be those of contemporary chieftains, but wemust regretfully record that story is of less use to historian even thanthe Iliad, or most of Norse and Irish saga literature. It compares better tothe Nibelungenlied, product of an age very different from that which itpurports to describe, and result of assimilation of many diversemartial traditions. It is as futile to try to reconstruct political and socialhistory of India in loth century B.C. from Mahābhārata as it wouldbe to write history of Britain immediately after evacuation of theRomans from Malory’s Morte d’Arthur.According to most popular later tradition Mahabharata War tookplace in 5102 B.C., which, in light of all evidence, is quite impossible.

More reasonable is another tradition, placing it in 15th century B.C., but this is also several centuries too early in light of our Archæological knowledge. Probably war took place around beginning of 9th century B.C.; such date seems to fit well with scanty archæological remains of period, and there is some evidence in brāhmana literatureitself to show that it cannot hv been much earlier. 14 From this timeonwards centre of culture and political power shifted to GangeticDoāb and Kuru capital, Hastināpura or Āsandīvant. Throughout most ofthe later Vedic period Kurus and their neighbours Panicalas were thegreatest and most civilized of Indian peoples. names of severalKuru kings hv been passed down in legend and two at any rate, Pariksitand Janamejaya, r mentioned in literature of time as mightyconquerors.Early in this period Aryans pressed further eastward, and set upkingdoms in Kosala, to east of Doāb, and in Kāsī, region ofBanaras. former, which grew in importance with time, was realm ofRāma, hero of second of great Indian epics, Rāmāyana (p.412f). For all his later fame literature of period ignores Rama andhis father Dasaratha completely, so we must [Page 40] conclude that theywere both comparatively insignificant chieftains, whose exploits were bychance remembered, to be elaborated and magnified by later generations ofbards until, around beginning of Christian Era, they received theirfinal form. It is not even certain that Rama was king of Kosala at all, forthe earliest version of legend that we possess makes him king ofBanaras, which was for time kingdom of some importance, but wasconquered by Kosala towards end of this period.Another important kingdom was Videha, to east of River Gandakand north of Ganges. One of Brāhmanas15 tells that once fire-god Agni moved eastwards, burning up earth, until he came to RiverSadanira (the modern Gandak), where he stopped. In his wake followed achieftain from Sarasvati, Videgha Mathava. Before his arrival no Āryanwould cross river, because purifying fire-god had not burnt landon its eastern bank; but Agni instructed Mathava to carry him over, and thusthe land of Videha was Aryanized, and took its name from that of its firstcolonizer. legend is important because it is only significant accountof process of colonization in an approximately contemporary source. Inthe progress of Agni, burning up earth, we see not only gradualeastward expansion of Āryan fire cult, but also clearing of jungleand waste by burning, as bands of migrating warrior peasants founded newsettlements.Though Rāma is ignored in literature of period his tradiionalfather-in-law, Janaka, king of Videha, is more than once mentioned and isclearly historical figure. He was great patron of hermits andwandering philosophers who propagated new mystical doctrines of theUpanisads, and himself took part in their discussions. By time of theBuddha kingdom of Janaka had disappeared, and his capital city,Mithila, had lost its importance. kingdom was replaced by tribalconfederacy of Vrjjis, headed by Licchavis, who may hv beenMongols from hills, but were perhaps second wave of Árynimmigrants.South of Videha, on right bank of Ganges, was region knownas Magadha, then of little account. It was not wholly Āryanized, but bandsof nomadic renegade Āryans called vrātyas, who did not follow Vedicrites, roamed land with their flocks and herds. Only in time of theBuddha, under great king Bimbisāra, did Magadha begin to show theenergy and initiative which were to lead to setting up of first greatIndian empire. To east of Magadha, on borders of modernBengal, small kingdom of Anga had arisen, while, beyond Auga, Bengaland Assam were still outside pale.

PLATE X
Thus texts of period r mainly concerned with region from Jamnā eastwards to borders of Bengal. area south of Ganges receives little attention, and it has been reasonably suggested that main line of Āryan penetration was not down river, banks of which were then probably thick swampy jungle, but along Himalayan foothills.  Expansion was not wholly confined to north of Ganges, however.

Contemporary literature has little to say about rest of Northern India, but conditions at time of Buddha were such that it must hv beencolonized some time previously, and this is confirmed by tradition. On theJamnā tribe of Yadavas had settled in region of Mathurā, whilefurther down river kingdom of Vatsa was ruled from its capital ofKausambl, very important in later times. By end of this period theAryans had advanced down Chambal River, had settled in Malwa, andhad reached Narmada. Probably parts of N.-W. Deccan were alsounder Āryan influence. acc to Epic tradition Kathiawar wascolonized by branch of Yadavas, led by great hero Krsna, and,though association of Krsna with story is probably unhistorical (p.  304f), legend may be founded on fact.

While Aryans had by now expanded far into India their old home in Panjāb and North-West was practically forgotten. Later Vedic literature mentions it rarely, and then usually with disparagement and contempt, as an impure land where Vedic sacrifices r not performed.

It may hv been once more invaded by Indo-Iranian tribes who did not follow orthodox rites.

The culture of later Vedic period was materially much in advance of that of Ṛ g Veda. Āryan tribes were by now consolidated in little kingdoms, which had not wholly lost their tribal character, but had permanent capitals and rudimentary administrative system. old tribal assemblies r still from time to time referred to, but their power was waning rapidly, and by end of this period king’s autocracy was in most cases only limited by power of brahmans, weight oftradition, and force of public opinion, which was always of someinfluence in ancient India. Here and there old tribal organizationsucceeded in adapting itself to changed conditions, and ganas, or tribalrepublics, survived for many centuries in outlying districts; but politicaldivisions based on kinship were giving place to those based on geography,and in many parts of India tribes were rapidly breaking up. This, and thestrong feeling of insecurity which it caused, may hv been an importantfactor in growth of asceticism and of pessimistic outlook on world,which is evident throughout this period.

[Page 42] If popular assemblies had lost power, another element inthe state was rising in influence-the ratnins, or “jewel bearers”, therelatives, courtiers and palace officials of king, who were looked on asso important that at king’s consecration special sacrifices wereperformed to ensure their loyalty. list of ratnins includes purohita,or chief priest of palace, general, chamberlain, king’scharioteer, and various other influential palace servants. Two of ratnins,the samgrahītr and bhāgadugha, hv been dubiously explained astreasurer and revenue-collector respectively, and if these interpretations arecorrect they indicate rudimentary ministerial system and civil service.The period saw great development of sacrificial cult, which tookplace pari passu with rising royal pretensions. Much of brāhmanaliterature is devoted to instructions for meticulous performance of newroyal sacrifices, not mentioned in Ṛ g Veda; among these were thelengthy rājasūya, or royal consecration, and vājapeya, or “drink ofstrength”, sort of rejuvenation ceremony, which not only restored vitalforces of middle-aged king, but raised him from status of simple rajato that of samrāt, complete monarch free of all allegiance and withlesser kings subordinate to him. Most famous and significant of all newsacrifices was aśvamedha, or horse-sacrifice, wherein speciallyconsecrated horse was set free to roam at will for year, followed by achosen band of warriors. Chieftains and kings on whose territory horsewandered were forced to do homage or fight, and if it was not captured by aneighbouring king it was brought back to capital and sacrificed at theend of year. It was ambition of every important king to perform ahorse-sacrifice, and evil effects of sacrifice on inter-state relationswere felt to end of Hindu period.By now Aryans had nearly all equipment of civilization of theancient type. Where Ṛ g Veda speaks only of gold and copper or bronzethe later Vedic texts also mention tin, lead, and silver, and probably iron.2The elephant was tamed, though little used in war. Aryans nowcultivated large range of crops, including rice, and they understoodsomething of irrigation and manuring.Specialized trades and crafts had appeared. In place of fewoccupations in Yajur Veda many r now referred to, includingjewellers, goldsmiths, metal-workers, basketmakers, ropemakers, [Page 43]weavers, dyers, carpenters and potters. Various types of domestic servantare mentioned, and rudimentary entertainment industry existed, withprofessional acrobats, fortune-tellers, fluteplayers and dancers, while thereare also references to usurers and merchants.Though Āryan culture had by now made great advances there is still nomention of coined money or writing, both of which were certainly used inIndia before time of Mauryas. Coinage may hv been introducedtowards end of 6th century B.C., through Persian influence, but it isnot completely certain that we cn accept negative evidence of laterVedic literature to show that writing was wholly unknown. This literaturewas intended for limited audience of priests, who had developed uniquesystem of memory training, and who may well hv looked on writing as anobjectionable innovation. There is evidence in literature itself of faintcontacts with Mesopotamia, notably in Indian flood legend (p. 302),which first appears at this time, and bears some similarity to that ofBabylon. After break of many centuries Indian merchandise was againfinding its way to Mesopotamia, and it is possible that Semitic merchants,or Indian merchants returning from West, brought an alphabetic systemof writing, which was gradually taken up by learned, and adapted to thephonetics of Indian speech, to become Brāhmi script of Mauryan times(p. 394f).

The most important developments of this age were religious, and will beconsidered elsewhere (p. 242ff). Culturally period of later Vedicliterature saw Indian life and thought take direction which it hasfollowed ever since. end of this shadowy age, with its kings growing inpower, its priests arrogating to themselves ever greater privileges, and itsreligious outlook rapidly changing, marks beginning of great periodof India’s culture in which pattern of her society, religion, literature andart gradually assumed something of its present shape.

1The horns of “Proto-Śiva” r evidently those of buffalo.

2“Black bronze” is referred to in Yajur Veda, but no iron has been discovered in remains of Hastinapura at this level. Iron was probably comparatively rare metal until Mauryan times.

III.

HISTORY: ANCIENT AND MEDIEVAL
EMPIRES


## SOURCES OF HISTORY
[Page 44]
AT courts of ancient Indian kings careful records were kept of events of chief importance to state, but unfortunately these archives r completely lost to us. In 12th century A.D. Kashmiri poet, Kalhana, thought fit to write history of his native land in verse, but his “River ofKings” ( Rajatarangimni), although of great value for study of thehistory of Kashmir, has little to tell us about India as whole, and there isno real evidence that similar chronicles were composed elsewhere. TheCeylon Chronicle (Mahavamsa)isprimarily history of Buddhism inCeylon, though it gives reliable information on political history. It isperhaps unjust to maintain that India had nosenseofhistorywhatever,butwhatinterest she had in her own past was generally concentrated on thefabulous kings of legendary golden age, rather than great empireswhichhadrisenandfalleninhistoricaltimes.Thus our knowledge of political history of ancient India is often tantalizingly vague and uncertain, and that of medieval period, which we may take as beginning in 7thcentury A.D., is but little more precise.History must be pieced together from passing references in texts bothreligious and secular, from few dramas and works of fiction purporting todescribe historical events, from records of foreign travellers, and fromthe many panegyrics or other references to reigning monarchs and theirancestors which hv been found engraved on rocks, pillars and templewalls, or incorporated as preambles to title-deeds of land grants; thelatter, fortunately for historian, were usually engraved on copper plates(pl.LXXXIX). early history of India resembles jigsaw puzzle withmany missing pieces; some parts of picture r fairly clear; others maybe reconstructed with aid of controlled imagination; but many gapsremain, and may never be filled. Few dates before middle ages cn befixed with certainty, and history of Hindu India, as far as we canreconstruct it, is almost completely lacking in interesting anecdotes andvivid personalities which enliven study of history for professional andamateur historians alike. Moreover there is much disagreement amongcompetent authorities on many important topics.[Page 45] As our knowledge is so vague and unsatisfactory readermay well suggest that political history of Hindu India should be left tothe expert; here, however, we cannot agree with him. Too many Indologistshave studied Indian religion, art, language and literature in political andhistorical vacuum, and this has tended to encourage widespread fallacythat ancient Indian civilization was interested almost solely in things ofthe spirit. However defective our knowledge may be, we hv ampleevidence to show that great empires rose and fell in India, and that, as inreligion, art, literature and social life, so in political organization Indiaproduced her own system, distinctive in its strength and weakness.Therefore some knowledge of her political history is essential for trueunderstanding of her ancient civilization.

## AGE OF BUDDHA
It is in 6th century B.C. that Indian history emerges from legend and dubious tradition. Now for first time we read of great kings, whose historicity is certain, and some of whose achievements r known, and fromnow on main lines of India’s political development r clear. Oursources for this period, Buddhist and Jaina scriptures, r in manyrespects admittedly inadequate as historical documents. Their authors caredlittle for political affairs; like Vedas, these texts were passed down byword of mouth for centuries, but, unlike Vedas, they evidently grew andaltered with time. Yet they contain authentic reminiscences of historicalevents, and, though composed independently in different languages, theypartially confirm one another.The age in which true history appears in India was one of greatintellectual and spiritual ferment. Mystics and sophists of all kinds roamedthroughout Ganges Valley, all advocating some form of mentaldiscipline and asceticism as means to salvation; but age of theBuddha, when many of best minds were abandoning their homes andprofessions for life of asceticism, was also time of advance in commerceand politics. It produced not only philosophers and ascetics, but merchantprinces and men of action.By now focus of civilization had shifted eastwards, and four greatkingdoms, outside earlier area of brahmanic culture, had eclipsed theold land of Kurus in both political and economic importance; these wereKosala, Magadha, Vatsa and Avanti, of which first three hv beenlocated in last chapter and fourth was approximately equivalent tothe region later known as Malwa. Of four we know most about Kosalaand Magadha, chief scenes [Page 46] of activities of Buddha andof Mahavira, founder of Jainism. Kosala, home of legendaryRama, was already in decline. Her king, Prasenajit (in Pali, Pasenadi), wasindeed still mighty monarch, ruling an area little smaller than France; butfrom fleeting references in Buddhist scriptures it seems that he wasinefficient, and squandered his time and wealth on holy-men, both orthodoxand heretical. His kingdom, which was infested by robbers, was looselycontrolled through tribal chieftains and vassal kings.Bimbisara of Magadha, on other hand, was man of differentstamp. sources show us resolute and energetic organizer, ruthlesslydismissing inefficient officers, calling his village headmen together forconferences, building roads and causeways, and travelling over his kingdomon tours of inspection. In general he seems to hv been man of peace,and to hv kept on good terms with kingdoms to west of him,exchanging courtesies even with king of far-off Gandhāra on upperIndus. His one conquest was that of little kingdom of Afiga, on theborders of modem Bengal. Campa, capital city of Afga, was alreadyof considerable commercial importance, for it was river port from whichships would sail down Ganges and coast to South India, returning withjewels and spices which were already much in demand in North.Although Afiga was Bimbisara’s only conquest, he seems also to havegained control of part at least of district of Kasi(Banaras),asthedowryofhis chief queen, who was sister of Prasenajit of Kosala. His capitalwas Rajagrha, some sixty miles to south-east of moder Patna.Bimbisara was deposed, imprisoned and murdered about 490 B.C.-someseven years before death of Buddha-by his son, Ajatagatru. Soonafter usurping prosperous kingdom built up by his father, parricidewent to war with his aged uncle Prasenajit, and gained complete control ofKaii. Just after this Prasenajit, like Bimbisara, was deposed by his son, anddied. new king, Virudhaka (in Pali, Vidudabha), then attacked andvirtually annihilated little autonomous tribe of Sakyas, in theHimalayan foothills, and we hear no more of people which produced thegreatest of Indians, Buddha. Probably Virudhaka, like Ajatagatru ofMagadha, had ambitions of empire, and wished to embark on career ofconquest after bringing outlying peoples, who had paid loose homage tohis father, more directly under control of centre; but his intentionswere unfulfilled, for we hear no more of him except an unreliable legendthat he was destroyed by miracle soon after his massacre of Sakyas. Alittle later his kingdom was incorporated in that of Magadha.[Page 47] After his war with Prasenajit Ajatagatru turned his attention tothe tribal confederation of Vrjjis, on north bank of Ganges,which had often caused trouble by raiding Magadhan territory. After aprotracted war he succeeded in occupying their chief city, Vaigali, and inannexing their lands. chief element of confederation, tribe of theLicchavis, succeeded in preserving its identity, however, and survived atleast until 4th century A.D., when it was again influential in politicsof Eastern India. early stages of Ajatasatru’s war with Vrjjis tookplace around time of Buddha’s death, in about 483 B.C.The accounts of reigns of Bimbisara and Ajatagatru give evidence ofa definite policy, aimed at control of as much of course of theGanges as possible. It seems that they were first Indian kings toconceive possibility of far-flung empire. Legend indeed tells of earlieremperors who controlled whole land from coast to coast, but these veryshadowy figures r almost certainly exaggerations of later story-tellers,inspired by memory of mighty Mauryas. There is little doubt that thelegendary emperors, such as Rama, do represent historical figures of thedays before Buddha, but they were probably small tribal chieftains onlypowerful in comparison with their fellows. For tradition of theirimmense conquests we hv no historical evidence whatever.If there was any source of inspiration of two great kings ofMagadha it must hv been Achaemenid Empire of Persia, whosefounder, Cyrus Great (558–550 B.C.), came to throne about sixteenyears before accession of Bimbisara, and proceeded rapidly to build upthe greatest empire world had then seen. At this time city ofTaksagila, in North-West, was already centre of learning and trade.

Young men from Magadha were sent there to finish their education, and Bimbisara was in diplomatic contact with Puskarasarin (in Pali, Pukkusati),king of Gandhāra, whose kingdom probably included Takjasila. But in aninscription of about 519 B.C. Darius I, third of Achaemenidemperors, claims possession of Gandhāra, and in slightly later one he alsoclaims Hindush, or “India”, which, acc to Herodotus, became thetwentieth satrapy of Persian Empire. extent of Persian provinceof Hindush is not certain, but it probably included much of Panjāb. It ishardly likely that kings of Magadha were ignorant of what washappening in North-West; we believe that their expansionist policy wasin part inspired by example of Persians.

The Buddhist and Jaina scriptures give us little information on [Page 48] events which took place after deaths of their founders, and therefore we know scarcely anything about latter part of Ajatasatru’s reign. There is evidence that he fought Pradyota, king of Avanti, and that for time at least fortunes of war did not favour him; but he certainly succeeded increating most powerful empire India had yet known, controlling bothbanks of Ganges from Banaras to borders of Bengal, which was thenstill beyond pale of Aryan civilization. In succeeding century and ahalf Magadha continued to expand, for, when curtain is again lifted onIndia’s past in 4th century B.C., Pataliputra (now Patna), new capitalof Magadha, controls all Ganges basin; rest of Northern India, withthe exception of Rajasthan, Sind, Panjāb and NorthWest, is part of theMagadhan Empire, and other kingdoms r either annihilated or reducedto insignificant vassalage.

## ALEXANDER AND MAURYAS
In middle of 4th century B.C., Mahapadma Nanda was emperor of Magadha. He was an unpopular upstart, but, as far as cn be gathered from few references to him, he was an energetic and ambitious king, who succeeded in gaining control of Kalifiga (the modern Orissā and northern coastal strip of Andhra), and perhaps of other parts of Deccan.

His death seems to hv been followed by disputed succession, which coincided with important events in North-West. Out of confusion of times emerged greatest and most powerful of India’s many empires. In 330 B.C. Alexander of Macedon defeated Darius III, last of theAchaemenids, and set out to subdue whole of former PersianEmpire, which had long ceased to exercise effective control over its remoterprovinces. In decisive battle of Gaugamela Alexander had already metIndian troops, for small contingent of soldiers from west of Indus,with fifteen elephants, had fought with Darius. Over hundred years earlierGreeks had already measured swords with Indians, for, acc toHerodotus, detachment of Indians fought in Persian army at Plataea.After long campaign in Bactria, region on borders of modernSoviet Union and Afghanistan watered by River Oxus, Alexandercrossed Hindu Kush and occupied district of Kabul. Then, fiercelybut unsuccessfully resisted by hillmen, he descended Kabul Valleyand reached Indus, which he crossed in spring of 326. Omphis,1 kingof Taksagila (known to classical [Page 49] writers as Taxila), had alreadysubmitted, and city offered no resistance. Beyond Jhelam, however,lay territory of most warlike king of Panjāb, Porus, 2 for fear ofwhom Omphis had willingly thrown in his lot with Alexander. It was onlywith great difficulty, after surprise crossing of Jhelam, that theMacedonians succeeded in defeating troops of Porus, who was captured.

Porus was very tall and handsome man, whose courage and proud bearing made great impression on Greeks; when brought before his conquerorhe was found to hv received nine wounds, and he could barely stand; butwhen Alexander asked him how he wished to be treated he boldly replied:“As befits me-like kingl” Alexander was so impressed by his captive thathe restored him to his kingdom as vassal and, on retreat of Greekforces, left him in charge of Panjāb.After defeat of Porus Alexander continued his advance, subduingnumerous tribes and petty kingdoms; but at Beas he was forced to turnback, for his generals feared mutiny if his troops were made to advancefurther into unknown country. Alexander returned across Panjāb andfought his way down Indus, often meeting stiff opposition from themartial tribes. At mouth of Indus army divided, part returning toMesopotamia by sea, and part, led by Alexander himself, by land, followingthe coast through desolate Makran. After much hardship bothdetachments reached Euphrates, together with smaller body which hadbeen sent back earlier by way of Arachosia (the moder Kandahar). There isno doubt that Alexander intended to retain control of his Indian conquests,for he left garrisons behind him and appointed satraps to govern theconquered territories. But revolts in Indian provinces and suddendeath of Alexander in 323 B.C. made Macedonian position in Indiauntenable, and last of Alexander’s generals, Eudamus, left North-West in 317.Although Greeks had known something of India before invasionof Alexander, their knowledge was mostly of nature of fantastictravellers’ tales. Now for first time Greeks and Indians came into closecontact. It is clear from classical accounts of Alexander’s campaign that theGreeks were not unimpressed by what they saw of India. They muchadmired courage of Indian troops, austerity of naked asceticswhom they met at Taksasila, and probity and simplicity of tribes ofthe Panjāb and Sind.The immediate effects of invasion were slight. little kingdomsand tribes of North-West were disorganized and [Page 50] overthrown,but Alexander made so small an impression upon India that in whole ofher surviving ancient literature there is no reference to him. In latercenturies Indians came to know Greeks, but of Greek influence inIndia at this time there is scarcely trace. However, it may be that theinvasion, and political vacuum created in North-West byAlexander’s retreat, had indirect effects of utmost importance.

Classical sources speak of young Indian named Sandrocottus — identical with Candragupta Maurya of Indian sources-who supported invaders. Plutarch states that Sandrocottus advised Alexander to advancebeyond Beds and attack Nanda emperor, who was so unpopular thathis people would rise in support of an invader. Latin historian Justinadds that later Sandrocottus offended Alexander by his boldness of speech,and that conqueror ordered that he should be put to death; but heescaped, and, after many adventures, succeeded in expelling Greekgarrisons and gaining throne of India. Whether or not these stories aretrue, it is reasonable to believe that emperor Candragupta Maurya, whorose to power soon after Alexander’s invasion, had at least heard of theconqueror, and perhaps derived inspiration from his exploits.

Both Indian and classical sources agree that Candragupta overthrew thelast of Nandas and occupied his capital, Pataliputra; latter add thatafter Alexander’s retreat Candragupta subdued North-West, driving outthe Greek garrisons. It is not clear which of these operations was firstundertaken, and, with annoying uncertainty of much ancient Indianhistory, estimates of date of Candragupta’s accession vary within adecade (324–313 B.C.); but though detailed history of his rise to power isuncertain, it is evident that he was chief architect of greatest ofIndia’s ancient empires. acc to all Indian traditions he was muchaided in his conquests by very able and unscrupulous brahman adviser,called variously Kautilya, Canakya and Visnugupta; indeed in play TheMinister’s Signet Ring, work of 6th century A.D., which purports todescribe last stages of Candragupta’s triumph over Nanda (p. 441),the king is depicted as weak and insignificant young man, real ruler ofthe empire being Canakya. minister is reputed author oftheArthasastra, or “Treatise on Polity”, very valuable source of informationon state administration. text as we hv it at present is certainly not thework of Kautilya (p. 79), but it isvery valuable nevertheless, and containsgenuine Mauryan reminiscences.Soon Greeks were again at doors of India. Alexander’s [Page 51]general Seleucus Nicator had succeeded in gaining control of most of theAsiatic provinces of shortlived Macedonian Empire, and turned hisattention to East. About 305 B.C. he met Candragupta in battle, andseems to hv suffered worst of engagement, for not only did he failin his attempt to recover Alexander’s Indian provinces, but he wascompelled to yield parts of what is now Afghanistan to Candragupta,receiving in exchange only 500 elephants. peace was concluded by amatrimonial alliance, exact nature of which is uncertain;1 but it is notimpossible that successors of Candragupta had Greek blood in theirveins.Seleucus sent an ambassador, Megasthenes, to reside at Mauryancourt at Pataliputra, and envoy wrote detailed account of India whichbecame standard textbook on subject for later classical writers.Unfortunately no manuscript of Megasthenes’ description of India hassurvived, but many Greek and Latin authors made abundant use of it, andfrom their works it may be partially reconstructed. record ofMegasthenes, though by no means as complete and accurate as might bewished, is of great importance as first authentic and connecteddescription of India by foreign traveller. It is evident from comparisonof fragments of Megasthenes with Arthasastra that Mauryanempire had developed highly organized bureaucratic administration,which controlled whole economic life of state, and that it had verythorough secret service system, which was active among all classes fromthe highest ministers to submerged tenth of towns.Megasthenes much admired Emperor Candragupta for his energeticadministration of justice, which he presided over personally in opendarbār.3 He dwelt in great luxury in an enormous palace at Pataliputra,which, though built wholly of wood, was of unbelievable beauty andsplendour; but his life was not happy one, for he was in constant fear ofassassination, an ever-present danger to many Indian kings, and verystringent precautions were taken for his security. capital was largeand fine city, surrounded by wooden wall; it was controlled by anadministrative board of thirty members, who regulated in detail wholesocial and economic life of city. Megasthenes noticed existence ofcaste, though his classification of population in seven endogamousgroups is certainly erroneous (p. 147).According to Jaina tradition Candragupta abdicated throne, became aJaina monk, and fasted to death, in manner of Jaina [Page 53] saints, atthe great Jaina temple and monastery of Sravana Belgola, in modemMysore. Whether or not this legend be true, he was succeeded after reignof twenty-four years by his son Bindusara, about whom little is knownexcept that he was in touch with Antiochus I, Seleucid king of Syria.

According to Athenaeus, Bindusara requested of Greek king presentof figs and wine, together with sophist. Antiochus sent figs and wine,but replied that Greek philosophers were not for export. This quaint littlestory seems to indicate that Bindusara, like many other Indian kings, sharedhis attentions between creature comforts and philosophy, but he wascertainly energetic enough to hold great empire intact, and it is evenprobable that he added to it in Deccan. He was succeeded, about 269B.C., probably after short interregnum, by his son Asoka, greatest andnoblest ruler India has known, and indeed one of great kings of theworld.

[Page 52]

Fig. vi.
## Empire of Asoka
(The pillars originally at Mirath and Topra r now at Delhi) acc to Buddhist sources Agoka usurped throne, killed all possible rivals, and began his reign as tyrant, but this story is not borne out by Agoka’s own inscriptions, which r oldest surviving Indian written documents of any historical significance. They consist of series ofedicts engraved in very similar form on rocks and pillars at widely scatteredpoints all over India (fig. vi), and form unique monument to great king’smemory. edicts r in part inspired by Achaemenid precedent, but theircontents r very different from great inscriptions of Darius I, forinstance, which glorify emperor, catalogue his conquests, and enumeratethe peoples and tribes under his sway. Asoka’s edicts r in nature ofofficial pronouncements of policy, and instructions to his officers andsubjects. They contain many personal touches, and drafts were probablywritten by emperor himself.

They tell us that when king had been consecrated eight years heunderwent complete change of heart, and embarked on new policy. InAsoka’s own words:“When King, of Gracious Mien and Beloved of Gods, had beenconsecrated eight years Kaliiga was conquered. 150,000 people were thencetaken captive, 100,000 were killed, and many more died. Just after thetaking of Kalifiga Beloved of Gods began to follow Righteousness,to love Righteousness, to give instruction in Righteousness. When anunconquered country is conquered, people r killed, they die, or r madecaptive. That Beloved of Gods finds very pitiful and grievous. …Today, if hundredth or thousandth part of those who suffered in Kaliigawere to be killed, to die, or to be taken captive, it would be very grievous tothe Beloved of Gods. If anyone does him wrong it will be forgiven asfar as it cn be forgiven. Beloved of Gods even reasons with the[Page 54] forest tribes in his empire, and seeks to reform them. But theBeloved of Gods is not only compassionate, he is also powerful, and hetells dm to repent, lest they be slain. For Beloved of Gods desiressafety, self-control, justice and happiness for all beings. Beloved of theGods considers that greatest of all victories is victory ofRighteousness, and that [victory] Beloved of Gods has already won,here and on all his borders, even 600 leagues away in realm of theGreek king Antiyoka, and beyond Antiyoka among four kingsTuramaya, Antikini, Maga and Alikasudara, and in South among theCōlas and Pandyas and as far as Ceylon.“2Thus we see that keynote of ASoka’s reform was humanity in internaladministration and abandonment of aggressive war. In place of thetraditional policy of territorial expansion he substituted conquest byRighteousness (as we here inadequately translate very pregnant worddharma). He claims to hv won many victories by this method, evenamong five Hellenic kings whose names, loosely disguised byIndianization, r to be read in above extract-Antiochus II Theos ofSyria, Ptolemy II Philadelphus of Egypt, Antigonus Gonatas of Macedonia,Magas of Cyrene and Alexander of Epirus. It seems that Asoka believedthat, by setting an example of enlightened government, he might convincehis neighbours of merits of his new policy and thus gain moralleadership of whole civilized world. He by no means gave up hisimperial ambitions, but modified dm in accordance with humanitarianethics of Buddhism.In domestic affairs new policy was felt in general relaxation of thestern justice of earlier times. Asoka declared that all men were his children,and more than once reproved his local governors for their failure to applythis precept thoroughly. He strongly supported doctrine of ahimsd (non-injury to men and animals), then rapidly spreading among religious peopleof all sects, banned animal sacrifices, at least in his capital, and regulatedthe slaughter of animals for food, completely forbidding killing ofcertain species. He took pride in fact that he had substituted pilgrimagesto Buddhist holy places for hunting expeditions, traditional sport of theIndian king, and he proclaimed that he had reduced consumption ofmeat in palace to negligible proportions. Thus Asoka’s encouragementwas in part responsible for growth of vegetarianism in India.From passage above quoted, as well as from other indications, it isclear that Asoka was not complete pacifist. wild tribesmen of hill andforest were constant source of danger to more settled parts of theempire, and it would seem that earlier kings had [Page 55] kept dm incheck by ruthless campaigns of extermination. Asoka clearly intended to tryto civilize them, but it is quite evident that he was ready to repress dm byforce if they continued their raids on more settled parts of his empire.

He made no mention of reducing army, and if, under influence of Buddhism, he had done so, he would surely hv taken pride in fact.Despite his remorse at conquest of Kalifga, he was too much of realistto restore it to its original rulers, whoever they may hv been, butcontinued to govern it as an integral part of his empire. For all hishumanitarianism he maintained death penalty, which was abolishedunder some later Indian kings, and merely granted stay of execution ofthree days to men condemned to death, so that they might put their affairs inorder and prepare their minds for next world. Though Buddhist traditionrecords that he abolished judicial torture, this is not clearly stated in hisedicts.Among his positive social services Agoka mentions improvement ofcommunications by planting fruit trees along roads to provide shade andfood, digging wells at intervals, and setting up rest-houses for wearytravellers. He developed cultivation of medicinal herbs, which, withother drugs, were supplied to men and animals alike. To ensure that hisreforms were put into effect he inaugurated new class of official, the“Officers of Righteousness” ( dharma-mahdmdtra), who, taking theirinstructions direct from centre, were ordered to investigate affairs ofall provinces, to encourage good relations between man and man, and toensure that local officials carried out new policy. Thus Asoka’sreforms tended to centralization rather than devolution.It is evident that, after his change of heart if not before, Asoka was aBuddhist, and some authorities believe that he actually entered Buddhistorder. But inscriptions show that he was no metaphysician, and indeedhe probably had little interest in or understanding of finer points ofBuddhism. Although he never mentions Buddhist nirvana, he speaksfrequently of heaven; and he seems to hv held naive belief that, as aresult of growth of morality through his reforms, gods hadmanifested themselves on earth, phenomenon which had not occurred formany years previously.3 For Agoka, Buddhism seems to hv been systemof morals which led to peace and fellowship in this world and heaven in thenext. His metaphysical presuppositions were not distinctively Buddhist, butwere evidently those traditional in India at time. streak of puritanismin Emperor is to be inferred from edict banning rowdy popular fairsand allowing religious gatherings only.

Aśoka’s Buddhism, though enthusiastic, was not exclusive. More [Page 56] than once he declared that all sects were worthy of respect, and he dedicated artificial caves to sect of Ajlvikas, who were among chiefrivals of Buddhists. His relations with Buddhist clergy seem to havebeen erastian, for he had no compunction in prescribing passages ofscripture which order was specially to study, and he instructed localofficers to ensure that all ill-behaved Buddhist monks were unfrocked. Itwas in Asoka’s reign that Buddhism ceased to be simple Indian sect andbegan its career as world religion. acc to tradition great councilof Buddhist clergy was held at Pataliputra, at which Pali canon wasfinally codified, and after which missions were sent throughout lengthand breadth of India and beyond.

Tradition unanimously ascribes conversion of Ceylon to Mahendra(in Pali, Mahinda), son, or in some sources brother, of Asoka, whohad become Buddhist monk. Though relationship of apostle ofCeylon to Asoka is very doubtful, there cn be no doubt of his historicity, orof that of King Devanampiya Tissa, his first convert. Though Aryans mayhave settled in Ceylon nearly three centuries before this time, it was nowthat culture of island began to develop, under fertilizinginfluence of Buddhism. Ceylon Chronicle, which, being nationalist inits sympathies, is not likely to be false in this particular, implicitly admitsthat Tissa was loosely subordinate to Asoka, since it states that heunderwent second consecration and was converted to Buddhism onAsoka’s instructions. Thus at least one of Asoka’s “victories ofRighteousness” outside his empire was successful; his attempts at moralconquest of Hellenic kings certainly ended in failure, for there is noreference to his embassies in any classical source, and if they reached theirdestinations they cn hv had little effect on ambitious successors ofAlexander.

To modern student Agoka towers above other kings of ancient India, if for no other reason than that he is only one among dm whose personality cn be reconstructed with any degree of certainty. But even Asoka is not as clear figure as we would wish, and his policy has been thesubject of varied judgements. Critics hv accused him of ruining theMauryan Empire, either by antagonizing brāhmans or by sapping themartial spirit of ruling classes. 4 We cannot accept either of theseaccusations. It appears that old Emperor, who died about 232 B.C.,somewhat lost grip in his latter years,5 and succession was disputed byhis sons. Empire began to fall apart on his death, when governors ofthe great provinces, usually members of royal family, established theirvirtual independence. successors of [Page 57] Aśoka were lesser menthan he, and little is known of dm but their names.
