The Asoka of Buddhist legends is, in words of 19thcenturyauthority, “half monster and half idiot”,6 his humanity and practicalbenevolence overlaid by accretion of monkish legends of later centuries;but king of rock and pillar inscriptions comes alive, as real man,and man far ahead of his times. Asoka was by no means an other-worldlydreamer, but every inch king, little naive, often rather self-righteous andpompous, but indefatigable, strong-willed and imperious. It is with goodreason that Indian Republic has adopted for device of its state sealthe capital of an Asokan column (pl. XXIII a).

## AGE OF INVASIONS
For some fifty years Mauryan kings continued to rule in Magadha until, about 183 B.C., Pusyamitra Śunga, brahman general of Brhadratha, lastMauryan king, succeeded in gaining power by palace revolution.Pusyamitra was supporter of orthodox faith, and revived ancientVedic sacrifices, including horsesacrifice; but flourishing state ofBuddhism at this period is attested by remains at Bhārhut, and thestories of his persecution of Buddhist monks r probably muchexaggerated by sectarian tradition. kingdom of Sungas was by nomeans closelyknit centralized empire, like that of Mauryas, but one ofa looser type, which was to become normal in Hindu India, and which maybe broadly termed feudal (p. 93ff). Its centre was in Vidisa (E. Malwa),which at most times seems to hv been directly controlled by king,whose domains were surrounded by circle of vassal states, small andgreat, in varying degrees of subservience, but some evidently autonomousenough to issue their own coins. Beyond realm of Pusyamitra much ofthe old Mauryan Empire was now independent, and little is known of thecondition of Magadha, former centre of culture and power.The inspiration of Mauryas was soon almost forgotten. Later theGuptas tried to build an empire of more centralized type, and directlycontrolled much of North India for over hundred years, but, with thismajor exception and few minor ones, all later Hindu imperialism was ofthe quasi-feudal type, loose and unstable. memory of Asoka’srenunciation of further conquest was soon forgotten, and aggressive waragain became sport of kings, and was looked upon by theorists as anormal activity of state. In general history of post-Mauryan India isone of struggle of one [Page 58] dynasty with another for regionaldominance, and political, though not cultural, unity of India was lostfor nearly two thousand years.Pusyamitra is mentioned in several sources, and his name is recorded inone brief inscription, referring to an obscure descendant.7 He did not takeregal titles, but was throughout his reign referred to by simple titlesendpati, or “general”. Agnimitra, his son, who seems to hv been kingduring his father’s lifetime, is known from Kalidasa’s drama Mdlavikd andAgnimitra, while his grandson Vasumitra is recorded in same source ashaving defeated Greeks. An inscription on column at Besnagar (pl. Xc), near Bhilsa, records that Śunga king Bhāgabhadra received anambassador named Heliodorus from Greek king of Taksaśilā, Antialcidas.Otherwise Śungas r mere names, recorded, usually in garbled form,among muddled king-lists of Purānas, religious texts dating fromGupta times onwards.

Meanwhile events were taking place on India’s north-western borders which were to hv profound effect both on her own history and on that of Asia generally. series of invasions, all inadequately documented, brought whole of what is now West Pākistin, Malwa and Kathiāwār, much of Uttar Pradesh and Rajasthan, and even for while part of Western Deccan, under control of alien kings.

The first invaders were Bactrian Greeks. Small colonies of Asiatic Greeks had been settled in Bactria by Achaemenids, and these werestrengthened by settlements established by Alexander and Seleucus Nicator.About middle of 3rd century B.C. Diodotus, governor of Bactria,declared himself independent of Seleucid Empire, and Iranianprovince of Parthia became independent at about same time. Diodotuswas succeeded by his son, also named Diodotus, who was soon overthrownand replaced by usurper, Euthydemus. Euthydemus came to terms withthe Seleucid emperor, Antiochus III, who had vainly attempted to regain thelost province; now with his flank secure, he began to expand over HinduKush, and gained foothold on N.-W. Frontier, which had probablyalready broken away from Mauryan Empire. Demetrius, son andsuccessor of Euthydemus, early in 2nd century B.C. pressed further intoIndia. He and his successors occupied most of Indus Valley and thePanjāb, and led great raids far into India, at least one of which, perhaps ledby King Menander, reached Pataliputra. Soon home domains of theBactrian Greeks were wrested from dm by another usurper, Eucratides,but descendants of Euthydemus continued to rule in Panjāb and parts ofthe North-West. Then Eucratids, too, were tempted to try their fortunesbeyond mountains, and gained control of Kabul [Page 59] Valleyand district of Taksagila. Greek domains in India were divided intoseveral petty kingdoms, those of Kabul Valley and N.-W. Frontierchiefly ruled by kings of line of Eucratides, and those of Panjābunder line of Euthydemus.Little is known of history of Greeks in India, and their fortunescan only be faintly reconstructed from their remarkable coins (pl.LXXXIV), most of which bear legends in Greek on obverse and inPrakrit on reverse. From now on, however, ravanas (a termborrowed by India through Persian from Greek) r mentioned fromtime to time in Indian literature. Through Greco-Bactrian kingdomsWestern theories of astrology and medicine began to enter India, andperhaps development of Sanskrit drama was in part inspired fromthis source. More than one Indian tradition speaks of great Yavana raids.One of Greek kings of Panjāb is specially remembered byBuddhism, as patron of philosopher-monk Nagasena; this wasMilinda, or Menander, who ruled at gakāla (?Siālkot), and whose longdiscussions with sage r recorded in well known Pali text, theQuestions of Milinda. Menander is said to hv become Buddhist, but theBesnagar column, to which we hv already referred, shows that Greeksalso sometimes supported orthodox creeds, for it was erected by theambassador Heliodorus in honour of early Vaisnavite deity Vasudeva.Thus some of Greeks, while not completely merging with Indianpopulation, soon felt influence of their ways of thought, and made manycompromises with their culture. author of law-book of Manu,writing probably century or two later than Heliodorus, describes theYavanas as degenerate ksatriyas, or members of warrior class, and thusgives dm place in Hindu society.

The Greco-Bactrian kingdoms, however, did not long survive. Bactria itself was occupied by Parthians early in second half of 2nd century B.C., and Greeks were confined to their possessions in India andAfghanistan. Then fresh invaders appeared from north. complexchain of causes, climatic and political, led to new movements of peoplesof Central Asia. consolidation of Chinese Empire under greatemperor Ch’in Shih Huang Ti (247–210 B.C.), and perhaps also dryingup of their pasture lands, had driven large bands of nomads westwards,from confines of China to region east of Caspian. Soon anomadic people, called by Chinese Yieh-chih, was bearing heavily onthe Scythian tribesmen on borders of Bactria. Scyths, whom Indiawas to know as Sakas, were driven by pressure from north and east to attack Bactria, which they occupied, soon to be followed by [Page 60]Yiieh-chih. Sakas moved on from Bactria to attack first Parthianrulers of Iran, and then Greeks in India. By middle of 1st centuryB.C. only few petty Greek chiefs still ruled in India, and power of thegakas reached as far as Mathurā. gakas continued earlier practice ofissuing coins with inscriptions in Greek and Prakrit. earliest gaka kingknown to hv ruled in India was Maues (? c. 80 B.C.).Towards end of 1st century B.C. line of kings with Iraniannames, usually known as Pahlavas, gained brief suzerainty of N.-W.India. One of them, Gondophernes, is worthy of mention, as ruler towhose kingdom St. Thomas is said to hv brought India’s first knowledgeof Christianity (p. 342). Some authorities hv cast doubt on truth of thelegend, maintaining that Gondophernes’ date was too early for him to havebeen St. Thomas’s contemporary;8 but at any rate he was important enoughfor his fame to reach West, and that St. Thomas preached in India is byno means impossible.The Pahlavas were in turn conquered by Yiieh-chih. racialaffinities of these people r uncertain; physically they were of Turkishtype, but they perhaps spoke an Iranian language, like Sakas. For acentury or more they dwelt in Bactria and neighbouring regions ofCentral Asia, divided into autonomous tribes, until control was consolidatedin hands of Kujula Kadphises, of tribe of Kusanas. At some timein first half of 1st century A.D. Kujila led his warriors over themountains, and he and his son Vima Kadphises between dm gainedcontrol of N.-W. India. Kujula was perhaps responsible for extinction ofthe last of Greek kings, Hermaeus, whose line had held out in Kabulagainst Sakas.Vima Kadphises was succeeded, probably after short interregnum, byKaniska, who controlled all western half of Northern India at least as faras Banaras, and whose dominions in Central Asia were very extensive. TheChinese annals speak of Kusana king, either Kaniska or one of theKadphises, demanding hand of princess of imperial house of Hanin marriage, and being soundly defeated for his arrogance by greatgeneral Pan Ch’ao, who, at end of 1st century A.D., carried Chinesearms as far as Caspian.This period was very important one in history of Buddhism, andKaniska is remembered in Northern Buddhist tradition as great patron ofthe faith. Numerous remains testify to importance and popularity ofBuddhism at time, and it was now that it began to spread to Central Asiaand Far East. Some intimations of Indian religion had alreadyreached China, but it exerted no real influence until now, when Kusanaand Chinese empires were in [Page 61] close contact. period is alsonoteworthy for Gandhāra school of art, which was influential not only inIndia but also, indirectly, in Far East (p. 368f).Professor B. Rowland, Harvard ‘UniversityThe Great Caitya-hall, Karll, Bombay, c. 1st century B.C.-1st century A.D.PLATE XIIIDept. of Archaoologyu Government of IndiaaFacade of Cave XIX, Ajanta. Gupta PeriodA. L. Bashamb## Caves of AjantaThe date of Kaniska, like chronology of whole gakaKusanaperiod, is very uncertain, and estimates of year of his accession havevaried from 58 B.C. to A.D. 288. At present opinions of most competentauthorities r divided between A.D. 78 and 144. former date is that ofthe foundation of one of most widespread Indian systems of dating, laterknown as gaka Era. Kaniska was not, strictly speaking, gaka, but theterm was very loosely applied, and he is known to hv founded an era.Though date A.D. 78 fits well with other Indian evidence, certaincomplicated synchronisms mainly based on non-Indian sources suggest thathe reigned some decades later than this, and question cannot be finallysettled until new evidence appears. successors of Kaniska continued toreign in N.-W. India, but their empire was soon much reduced. About themiddle of 3rd century Vasudeva, one of Kaniska’s successors, wassoundly defeated by Shapur I, of new Sasanian dynasty of Persia, andfrom now on North-West came much under Iranian influence.Meanwhile new kingdoms had been set up in Peninsula. In Orissa agreat conqueror, Kharavela, appeared about middle of 1st centuryB.C.; he raided far and wide over India and was great patron of Jainism;but his empire was short-lived, and we know nothing of his successors. Atabout same time an important kingdom arose in N.-W. Deccan fromthe ruins of that of Mauryas-the kingdom of Satavahanas orAndhras, centred on Pratisthana (modern Paithan). This survived for 300years or more, until 5rd century A.D., its power often reaching beyondthe Narmada into Malwa and, in 2nd century A.D., from coast to coast.Traditionally first Sātavāhana king, Simuka, put an end to lastinsignificant unfigas and to Kanva kings, who reigned for short timein part of old unfiga Empire. For while, around beginning of the2nd century A.D., Satavahanas were driven from N.-W. Deccan byinvading gakas of clanof Ksaharata, whose great satrap Nahapana left anumber of inscriptions; but Satavahanas, under greatest of theirrulers, Gautamiputra Satakarnin, recovered their landsaboutA.D. 130, andnothing more is heard of Ksaharatas.Another gaka dynasty, generally known as “Western Satraps”, gainedcontrol of Kathiawar and Malwa at about same time, and ruled untilsoon after A.D. 388, at its height governing much of Rajasthan and Sind. Thegreatest ruler of this line [Page 62] was Rudradaman, who has left theearliest important inscription in correct Sanskrit, long panegyric whichrecords his martial exploits and his reconstruction of great artificial lake atGirnar in Kathiawar, which had been excavated under Candragupta andimproved in time of Asoka. This inscription is among earliestcertainly dated records of ancient India, and proves that Rudradaman wasreigning in A.D. 150.At this time Dravidian South first begins to appear in light ofhistory. Traditionally Tamil country has always been divided into threekingdoms-C6la (the Coromandel Coast), Kerala or Cera (Malabar), andPandya (the southern tip of Peninsula). These three r mentioned byAsoka as scenes of his “victories of Righteousness” beyond his owndominions, and few rough inscriptions indicate that Buddhist and Jainaascetics visited Tamil land before beginning of Christian era. Inthe earliest stratum of Tamil literature, which was probably composed in theearly centuries A.D., we find three kingdoms in state of almostcontinual warfare. Their kings, and numerous lesser chieftains who arealso mentioned, seem to hv been more bloodthirsty than those of theNorth, and literature contains hints of massacres and other atrocitiessuch as r rarely heard of in Sanskrit literature; one passage even suggestscannibal feasts after battle. 9 ancient Tamil, by no means perfectlyAryanized, was man of very different stamp from his gentle andthoughtful descendant. Wild and ruthless, delighting in war and drink,worshipping fierce gods with bacchanalian dances, passionate in love, hecompares strikingly with grave and knightly warriors of Sanskritepics, which were probably receiving their final form at time when thepoems of Tamil anthologies were being written. few centuries were toalter picture somewhat, and next stratum of Tamil literature shows amuch deeper penetration of Āryan ideals and standards, but streak ofruthlessness and disregard for individual life is evident in Dravidiancharacter down to fall of Vijayanagara.Very early Tamils took to sea. Even in end century B.C. theytwice invaded Ceylon, first time soon after death of great kingDevanampiya Tissa, and second little later. latter invasion resultedin long occupation of whole of northern half of island by theTamil king Elara, who was expelled with great difficulty by Sinhalesenational hero, King Dutugamunu (in Pali, Dutthagamani) (161–137 B.C.).Tamils probably found their way to S.-E. Asia at about same time, andin 1st century A.D. were in close contact with Egypt and RomanEmpire, through flourishing trade with West (p. 227ff).## GUPTAS AND HARSA[Page 63] We know little of events in North India after decline of theKusanas, but it seems that by 3rd century A.D. all India east of thePanjāb and Malwa was in hands of small Indian kings and tribal chiefs.Some authorities hv tried to depict great Gupta emperors as liberatorsof India from foreign yoke, but it seems that by this time invadershad become thoroughly Indianized, and that their expulsion was work ofthe little known predecessors of Guptas.In A.D. 320 new Candra Gupta,4 arose, whose successors in greatmeasure restored splendour of Mauryas. He owed his rise to powerlargely to his marriage with princess Kumaradevī, of tribe of theLicchavis, who now reappear on scene, eight centuries after their defeatby Ajatasatru. From prominence given to Licchavi princess in thegenealogies of later Gupta kings, and minting of special coins tocommemorate her marriage to Candra Gupta (fig. xxiv a, p. 381), it seemsthat Licchavis had profited by absence of any strong central controlto carve new kingdom, and were very influential in Magadha at time.Candra Gupta I possessed fairly large domains, including regions ofMagadha and Kosala.Under his successor, Samudra Gupta (c. A.D. 335–376), Pataliputra oncemore became centre of great empire. Samudra’s power reached fromAssam to borders of Panjāb. He aimed at establishment of aclosely knit empire of Mauryan type, for in his great Allahabadinscription he is said to hv “violently uprooted” no less than nine kings ofNorthern India, and to hv annexed their kingdoms to his own. martialtribes of Rajasthan, however, merely rendered him homage, as did severalkingdoms on his frontiers, while in Eastern Deccan, where Samudra leda very successful expedition as far as Kāñcī (Conjeeveram), defeatedkings were reinstated on giving homage and tribute, and probably heard nomore of their titular overlord.Samudra Gupta’s main effort was in direction of west, where theSakas had ruled for over 200 years and land was enriched by thelucrative western trade. From their capital of Ujjayini (modern Ujjain) theŚakas still controlled Malwa and Kathiawar, and were power to bereckoned with. Though Samudra’s inscription makes vague reference tohis receiving homage from “the Saka Lords”, it is probable that he did notmeasure swords with them, or, [Page 65] if he did, was unsuccessful, for itis unlikely that he would hv allowed dm to remain independent if hecould hv prevented it. There is indeed story that on his death gakasactually succeeded in shaking Gupta Empire, and forced weak king,Rama Gupta, to conclude dishonourable peace. Most authorities reject thestory, and deny historicity of Rama Gupta, but recent discovery ofcopper coins bearing this name tends to strengthen our belief that it has abasis of fact. 10

[Page 64]

Fig. vii. Gupta Empire
It was Candra Gupta II (c. 376–415), son of Samudra and younger brother of shadowy Rama Gupta, who finally defeated Sakas, soon after A.D. 388. Thus he became paramount sovereign of all NorthernIndia, with exception of NorthWest; and he had some control overmuch of Northern Deccan, thanks to marriage of his daughterPrābhavatī with Rudrasena, king of Vakatakas, who ruled largekingdom in modern Madhya Pradesh and Hyderabad. Rudrasena diedyoung, and his widow reigned until her sons came of age. It is evident fromPrābhavatī’s charters that during her regency Vakataka court was muchunder Gupta influence.The reign of Candra Gupta II perhaps marks high watermark ofancient Indian culture. Later Indian legend tells of great and good KingVikramaditya, who drove Sakas out of Ujjayini, and ruled over all India,which in his reign was most prosperous and happy. Vikramaditya wascertainly one of titles of Candra Gupta II, and legend seemstherefore to refer to him. only important discrepancy is that thetraditional Vikramaditya is said to hv founded Vikrama Era, mostimportant of India’s many systems of dating, which is still widely current inNorth India, and which commences in 58 B.C.; thus legend places him some400 years too early. Kalidasa, greatest of India’s poets and dramatists, istraditionally associated with Vikramaditya, and internal evidence of hisworks points to fact that he wrote at about this time.The prosperity and happiness of Candra Gupta’s empire is attested by another foreign traveller, unfortunately not as observant and informative asMegasthenes. This was Fa-hsien, Chinese Buddhist monk who travelledto India in order to obtain authentic copies of scriptures. account ofhis travels gives much information about temples and monasteries, andrepeats many Buddhist legends, but only few passing phrases mentionsocial conditions, and nothing at all is said about Candra Gupta himself,although Fa-hsien was in India for some six years of his reign. pilgrimdid, however, note peacefulness of India, rarity of serious crime, andthe mildness of administration. He stated that it was possible to [Page66] travel from one end of country to other without molestation, andwithout need of passports. In his remarks on social custom he noted thatall respectable people were now vegetarians, meat eating being confined tolow castes and untouchables, in regard to whom he gives us earliestclear reference to “pollution on approach”. He found Buddhism flourishingstill, but theistic Hinduism very widespread.The record of Fa-hsien shows that India had changed much since thedays of Megasthenes, some 700 years earlier. mild ethics of Buddhismand Jainism had gradually leavened Indian society, which was now moregentle and humane than in days of Mauryas. tn place of oldsacrificial Brahmanism, Hinduism had appeared, in form not very greatlydifferent from that of recent centuries. Soon harsher and.more primitiveelements were to re-emerge, but in best days of Gupta Empire Indianculture reached perfection which it was never again to attain. At this timeIndia was perhaps happiest and most civilized region of world, forthe effete Roman Empire was nearing its destruction, and China waspassing through time of troubles between two great periods of theHans and T’angs.

Candra Gupta II was succeeded by his son Kumara Gupta I (c. 415–454),who, like Samudra Gupta, performed Vedic horsesacrifice, which, intheory at least, might only be performed by great conquerors. There is noevidence, however, that he added to his empire, although for most of hisreign he preserved it intact. But in last years of Kumara Gupta I theempire suffered severe blow; as with many other important events of earlyIndian history, details r annoyingly absent, but it is clear that among thechief enemies with whom Guptas had to contend were new invaders,called in India Hūnas. They were Central Asian people, known toByzantine writers as Hephthalites or White Huns, and it is usuallyconsidered that they were branch of great group of TurkoMongolpeoples who were threatening Europe at about same time; certainmodern scholars, however, claim that they were in no way related to theHuns of Attila, but were of Iranian stock.11 Hūnas had occupied Bactriasome time before, and now, like earlier Greeks, gakas and Kusanas, theycrossed mountains and attacked plains of India; it is probable thatkindred Central Asian tribes came in their train.Once more Western India was prey of fierce raiders, who were withthe greatest difficulty kept at bay by Emperor’s son, Skanda Gupta.During war with Hūnas Kumara Gupta died, and Skanda Gupta (c.455–467) assumed power, though not born of [Page 67] chief queen andtherefore not regular heir to throne. He succeeded in re-establishingthe Gupta Empire, and by end of 455 it was again at peace; but hereigned for little more than twelve years, and on his death great days ofthe Guptas were over. empire continued, but central control weakened,and local governors became feudatory kings with hereditary rights. BeyondMagadha and Bengal Gupta emperors now exercised little more thantitular control.At close of 5th century fresh Hūna inroads occurred, and this timewere even more difficult to repel. empire was disunited, and no strongman of calibre of Skanda Gupta came forward to drive out invader.For some thirty years, from A.D. 500 onwards, Western India was in thehands of Huna kings, two of whom, Toramana and his son Mihirakula, wereapparently mighty monarchs. latter is remembered by 7th centuryChinese traveller Hsiian Tsang as fierce persecutor of Buddhism, and inKashmir, one of centres of his power, memories of his sadistic tyrannywere still alive in 12th century, when they were recorded by thehistorian Kalhana. Mihirakula seems to hv been driven from plain ofthe Ganges by Narasimha Gupta, who had cognomen Baladitya, underwhich his triumph is recorded by Hsüan Tsang; about 530 Mihirakula wasalso defeated in Western India, this time by Yasodharman, an energetic kingof Mandasor, who built large kingdom which did not survive his death.Though Mihirakula apparently retained his hold on Kashmīr and parts ofthe North-West, Hūna power never again seriously threatened India, and theHūnas soon lost their individuality.

These incursions were death-blow of Gupta Empire, which by A.D.550 had completely vanished. new Gupta line, probably not related to thegreat one, ruled in Magadha until 8th century. North of Gangesanother kingdom, that of Maukharis, rose to prominence, and first gaveimportance to city of Kanyakubja, modern Kanauj, which was tobecome cultural centre of Northern India until coming of theMuslims, and its largest and most prosperous city. In Gujarat line ofGupta feudatories, Maitrakas, became strong and independent.Evidently all semblance of political unity had again vanished. It is at thistime that we first hear of Gurjaras, new people who were to provideone of strongest dynasties of Middle Ages. invasions of theHūnas destroyed or dispersed older martial tribes of Rajasthan, and theirplaces were taken by newcomers, probably acclimatized invaders, fromwhom most of Rajput clans of Middle Ages were descended.[Page 68] centre of interest now shifts for time to Sthanvlsvara(modern Thanesar), in watershed of Satlaj and Jamna, which isso important for India’s security, and where so many decisive battles havebeen fought. Here local king, Prabhakaravardhana of family ofPusyabhuiti, had grown in power as result of successful raids on WesternIndia and against Hūnas, who still held parts of Panjāb. His motherwas princess of second Gupta line, and his daughter, Rajyasri, wasmarried to Maukhari king, Grahavarman. Thus Prabhakaravardhanakept on good terms with his neighbours in east, while he gatheredstrength in west. But Guptas and Maukharis were hereditaryenemies, and, at about time of Prabhakaravardhana’s death, war brokeout between them. Rajyavardhana, new king of Sthanvilvara, hurried tothe support of Maukharis, while Guptas had assistance ofSasiaka, king of Bengal. In war both Grahavarman of Kanyakubjaand Rajyavardhana of Sthanvlsvara were killed. former died without anheir, and two kingdoms were combined under Harsavardhana or Harsa,the second son of Prabhakaravardhana and brother-in-law ofGrahavarman.Harsa ascended throne in 606 at age of sixteen, and in forty-one years of his reign he succeeded in partially restoring glories of theGuptas. Some of his fame is due to fact that, in comparison with mostother early Indian kings, his reign is remarkably well documented. poetBāna, who was patronized by Harsa, has left florid account of eventsleading up to his rise to power (p. 446ff), while in latter part of his reignIndia was visited by another Chinese pilgrim, Hsiian Tsang, who wrote avery valuable description of India, which, unlike account ofMegasthenes, has survived intact. While his main purpose, like that of Fa-hsien, was to obtain Buddhist manuscripts and visit sacred sites, HsüanTsang was less other-worldly than earlier pilgrim, and he was in closetouch with Harsa, whom he much admired and who gave him an honouredplace at his court. His work is therefore of much greater historical valuethan that of Fa-hsien.

Although Harsa gained control of most of Northern India, fromKāthiāwār to Bengal, his empire was feudal in structure. Outside theimmediate domains of Kānyakubjaand Sthanvisvara, many of old kingsretained their thrones. Śaśnka, fierce anti-Buddhist king of Bengal, whooverran Magadha at time of Harsa’s accession, was driven back to hisown domains and his kingdom fell to Harsa, but Deva Gupta, king whohad been chiefly responsible for downfall of Harsa’s brother-in-lawGrahavarman Maukhari, was replacedbyarelative,Madhava Gupta, andthe Maitraka king of [Page 69] Kathiawar, after being defeated by Harsa,was allowed to retain his throne as vassal. Harsa controlled his greatempire by ceaselessly travelling from province to province, both in his owndomains and in those of his feudatories, who seem to hv spent much timein attendance on their overlord. When he died without heirs it is notsurprising that his empire fell to pieces.

Harsa seems to hv been man of great gifts and intense energy. As Candragupta by Megasthenes, he is described by Hsüan Tsang as hearingthe complaints of his humbler subjects with unwearying patience, not in hisaudience hall, but in small travelling pavilion by roadside. He lovedpomp, however, and in his progresses he was accompanied by tremendoustrain of attendants, courtiers, officials, Buddhist monks, and brahmans. Hewas loyal and warm friend, and, if we cn believe sources,fantastically generous to those whom he favoured. He loved philosophy andliterature, and in his leisure found time to write three very competentdramas (p. 441).

His empire was very extensive. Even Bhaskaravarman, king ofremote Assam, attended his court, and if not technically feudatory to himwas much under his influence. It would seem that Bhaskaravarman assistedHarsa against Sas’ika at beginning of his reign, and two kings werelifelong friends. Only in Deccan Harsa could make no progress. Here heattacked Calukya king Pulakegin II, but was thoroughly defeated, andcould never again pass Narmada.

Hsian Tsang shows that Buddhism was definitely declining in India at this time, although in latter part of his reign Harsa fell increasinglyunder its influence. Now certain elements of later Hinduism, of which thereare few traces in time of Guptas, were strongly in evidence. Thegrowth of tantric cults (p. 337) and of such practices as sati (p. 187f) showsthat cultural decline had already set in. Law and order were not as wellmaintained as in Gupta times, for, in contrast to Fa-hsien, who was soimpressed by peaceable and law-abiding state of India, Hsiian Tsangwas twice robbed by bandits in Harsa’s domains, and on one occasion wasnearly sacrificed to goddess Durga by river pirates, in very heart ofthe empire.

## MIDDLE AGES IN NORTH
The history of succeeding centuries is rather drab story of endemicwarfare between rival dynasties. It cn be followed in some detail, thanks tothe numerous inscriptions and copper-plate charters [Page 70] of period,but detail is monotonous and uninteresting to all but specialist.On Harsa’s death there was great confusion. usurper, Arunāśva,temporarily seized Kānyakubja, and attacked Wang Hsüan-ts’ê, who hadcome with small detachment of troops as ambassador to Harsa from theChinese emperor, T’ai-tsung. Wang escaped with his little force andgathered reinforcements from Tibet, Nepal and Assam; with aid of thesehe captured Arunāśva, who was taken back to China to end his days inattendance on T’ang Emperor. After this Bhāskaravarman of Assamextended his power westwards, and occupied part of Magadha. Meanwhilethe second Gupta dynasty revived, and Adityasena Gupta was mostimportant monarch of latter half of 7th century, and one of lastgreat Indian kings to perform Vedic horse-sacrifice. Early in 8thcentury an upstart named Yasovarman established an empire at Kanyakubja,which for while controlled much of North, but which soon fell toLalitaditya, one of few Kashmīr kings to play an important part in thepolitics of Gangetic Plain. In following two centuries two greatdynasties, Palas of Bihār and Bengal, and Gurjara-Pratiharas ofKanyakubja, divided hegemony of Northern India between them.The Palas of Eastern India were first to gain ascendancy, and for awhile, in early part of 9th century, were masters of Kānyakubja.The long reign of great king Dharmapala (c. 770–810) marks apogeeof Pala power; by time of his death control of Kānyakubjawas lost, buthis successor, Devapala (c. 810–850), was still very important king, whowas in diplomatic contact with Śailendra kings of Sumītra. Palakings r chiefly notable for their patronage of Buddhism, which, in rathercorrupt form, flourished in their dominions during three centuries oftheir rule. It was from Pala empire that Buddhism was introduced intoTibet, where, combined with many native beliefs, it survives to presentday.In 9th and 10th centuries Gurjara-Pratiharas, who probablyoriginated in Rajasthan, were masters of Kanyakubja, and mostpowerful kings of Northern India. They successfully resisted Arabs,who, in 712, had occupied Sind, and who for over century made frequentattacks on their eastern neighbours. two most powerful Pratihara kings,Mihira Bhoja (c. 840–885) and Mahendrapala (c. 885–910), pushed backthe Palas, and were overlords of most of Northern India as far as bordersof Bengal. But they were weakened by repeated invasions of theRāstrakūtas of Deccan, who, in 916, temporarily occupied Kānyakubja.

These [Page 72] persistent raids from south seem to hv turned attention of Pratihara kings away from North-West, where new forces were gathering which were ultimately to overthrow Hindu India.

Though Pratihāras regained their capital after its occupation by Rastrakutas, they never regained their strength, and throughout loth century Pratihara feudatories grew more and more powerful at expense of their former masters.

[Page 71]

Fig. viii. India in early 11th century, A.D.

(Names in brackets r of dynasties which were feudatory at time, but became important later)
In Afghanistan line of Turkish chieftains had established powerfulkingdom at Ghazni, and began to look covetously at rich plains of India.In 986 one of their amirs, Sabuktigin, made his first raid on mostimportant king of N.-W. India, Jayapala; in second raid he occupiedPeshawar. In 997 he was succeeded by his son Mahmūd, who soonembarked on deliberate policy of raiding rich and divided kingdoms ofIndia. In 1001 he defeated and captured Jayapala, who committed suicide.Jayapala’s son, Anandapala, formed league of Hindu princes against theinvader, but unwieldy and disunited Indian forces, basing their strategyand tactics on ancient precepts and relying on unpredictable morale ofthe fighting elephant, were defeated near Peshāwar by smaller and moremobile Muslim army, and whole of India lay open to invader.Between 1001 and 1027 Mahmid made seventeen great raids on India. Thewhole western half of land felt force of Turuskas; palaces andtemples were looted and desecrated, and enormous caravans of booty andslaves were taken back to Ghazni. raids reached as far as greatshrine of Somnath in Kathiawar, and kingdom of Candellas inBundelkhand. Among India’s great cities Kānyakubjaand Mathurā werecaptured and plundered.Mahmud did not remain in India, however, for, though Muslimchroniclers depict him as staunch propagator of Islam, intent onconverting infidel and bringing India under control of true faith,his expeditions were rather for purpose of plunder than of conquest. Butthe N.-W. Frontier and Panjāb were annexed to his kingdom, as were theArab kingdoms of Sind, which had long ceased to be menace to rest ofIndia. After sack of Kānyakubjathe great Pratihara dynasty, which hadbeen losing power for hundred years, soon disappeared. Its last importantking, Rajyapala, was defeated and dethroned by his neighbour Vidyadharathe Candella, whose kingdom had formerly been tributary to Pratiharas,and who profited by their discomfiture at hands of Muslim to extendhis own power; but Vidyadhara himself was too weak to resist Mahmūdeffectively, and was forced to pay him tribute.For about century and half Northern India retained its independence.In Banāras and Kānyakubjaa new ruling family, Gāhada [Page 73]valas, managed to build fairly prosperous kingdom. In Rajasthan thedynasty of Cahamanas rose in prominence and power. influence ofthe Candellas of Bundelkhand grew with fall of Pratiharas. InGujarat there ruled prosperous line of Caulukyas or Solankīs, muchunder influence of Jainism. In Mālwā Paramara dynasty flourishedunder King Bhoja (1018–1055), famous in legend, who was anaccomplished scholar and great builder of dams and artificial lakes forirrigation (p. 192f). Madhya Pradesh was in hands of Kalacuridynasty. In Bengal Palas were replaced by Senas, who were strongsupporters of orthodox Hinduism, and who inaugurated something of anantiBuddhist reaction.

cPilaster, Temple of SrIrangam. 16th century A.D.PLATE XVIIIThus Northern India, in twilight of Hindu independence, washopelessly divided. As well as main dynasties, whose names we havementioned, there were many lesser lines, theoretically tributary to thegreater, but virtually independent in their own territories and always readyto revolt against their overlords. conservative kings of India had learntno lessons from Mahmiid’s raids. They were still incapable of serious co-operation, and their enormous armies were slow and unwieldy. At endof 12th century three chief kings of Northern India-PrthvīrājaCāhamāna, Jayaccandra Gahadavala, and Paramardideva Candella5 —werein state of tripartite war.A new Turkish ruling house supplanted line of Mahmūd inAfghanistan. In 1173 Ghiyas-ud-din of Ghor annexed Ghazni. His youngerbrother, Shihab-ud-din, usually known as Muhammad of Ghor, proceededto conquer Ghaznavid possessions in Panjāb and Sind, and thenturned his attention to Hindu states. initiative in resistance camefrom Prthviraja, who patched up his quarrels and prepared to meet theinvader. In 1191 Hindu army met Muhammad at Tarain, not far fromThanesar, once capital of great Harsa. invaders were defeated,but in following year they returned with larger force. This time themounted archers of Muslims overpowered Hindu army andPrthviraja was defeated and killed. He is remembered to this day by theRajputs as model of chivalry and courage, and is hero of many folkballads.Muhammad returned home, and left work of conquest to his generals.The chief of these, Qutb-ud-din Aibak, occupied Delhi, an important city ofthe Cahamana kingdom, and made it his headquarters. Another general,Muhammad ibn Bakhtiyar, pressed on down [Page 74] Ganges andoverran Bihār, where he put many Buddhist monks to sword. He thenoccupied Bengal with little difficulty. Candella kingdom ofBundelkhand fell in 1203. In 1206 Muhammad, who had succeeded hisbrother as sultan of Ghor, was assassinated, and his general Qutb-ud-din, amanumitted slave, became first sultan of Delhī.In Rajasthan and other outlying districts Hindu kingdoms continued,sometimes paying tribute to more energetic sultans, but often virtuallyfree, while regions with sharply defined natural boundaries, such asKashmir, Nepal, Assam and Orissā, retained their autonomy. Thesekingdoms had always been in effect independent, only occasionallyrendering tribute and homage to greater kings of Plains, and ingeneral they had little political effect on India as whole, and were littleaffected by it politically. From now on, until 18th century, Muslimrulers dominated Northern India, and great days of Hindu civilizationwere at an end.


## MIDDLE AGES IN PENINSULA
While in Northern India standards of Hindu culture declined somewhat after Gupta age, in Deccan they flourished and advanced.  By this time Āryan influence had penetrated whole of Peninsula, and contact of Āryan and Dravidian produced vigorous cultural synthesis, which in turn had an immense influence on Indian civilization as whole.

Power was generally centred on two foci, one in Western Deccan and other in Cōla country, Coromandel coast. political history ofthe medieval Deccan is largely concerned with struggles between thedynasties controlling these two centres. Many lsser kingdoms also existed,however, often tributary to larger ones, but sometimes rising toconsiderable power.In Northern Deccan Vakatakas vanished at about same time asthe Guptas, and in middle of 6th century west and centre of thePeninsula came under control of Calukya Dynasty, ruling fromVātāpi (now called Badami) in Hyderabad. Its greatest king, Pulakegin II(c. 609–642), was approximate contemporary of Harsa, whom hesuccessfully resisted, only to be defeated at end of his reign byNarasimhavarman, Pallava king of Kāñcī (Conjeeveram). Pallavas,who had been ruling since 4th century, were great temple builders (p.355), and seem to hv much encouraged growth of Āryan institutionsin South.In 7th century Calukyas divided into eastern and western [Page75] branches, and in following century western branch was replacedby Rastrakutas of Manyakheta (modern Malkhed, in Hyderabad), whosemartial efforts were largely directed against North, and who made manyraids beyond Narmada. revived Calukya line, ruling from Kalyani,replaced Rastrakutas in 973, and controlled Deccan until end ofthe 12th century, when their empire was divided between Yadavas ofDevagiri in Northern Deccan, Kākatīyas of Warangal in Telugu-speaking areas of east, and Hoysalas of Dōrasamudra in Mysore.The Pallavas of Kanci persisted with declining fortunes until end ofthe 9th century, when their territories were annexed by Cola kings ofTanjore, Aditya I (c. 870–906), and Parāntaka. I (c. 906–953). Cōlakingdom, one of three great kingdoms of Tamil tradition, had beenvirtually submerged by Pallavas for centuries. Now it rose again, and forsome 300 years ruled Coromandel Coast and much of EasternDeccan, giving large measure of security to its people and supporting aflourishing social and cultural life. most notable of Cōla kings wereRajaraja I (985–1014) and Rajendra I (1014–1042), in whose reigns thepower of dynasty reached its zenith. former conquered Ceylon, andthe latter carried his power by land to mouth of Ganges, and sent outa great naval expedition, which occupied parts of Burma, Malaya andSumatra. This was perhaps despatched with intention of suppressing thepiratical activities of Indonesian kings, who interfered with theflourishing trade between South India and China. Cōla hold on S.-E.Asia does not appear to hv lasted long, however, and Rajendra’s navalexpedition is unique in annals of India.The Cōlas held Northern Ceylon until soon after 1070, when they wereexpelled by Sinhalese king Vijayabahu I (1070–1114). From now on theCōla power declined, and Pāndya kings of Madurai were continuallyattempting to regain their independence, while pressure from Calukyasincreased. Vijayabahu of Ceylon inaugurated period of success andprosperity for island, which culminated in reign of Parakramabahu I(1153–1186), greatest of Sinhalese kings (pl. LX a), whose splendourcan be seen in remains of his capital, Polonnaruva, whither seat ofgovernment had been transferred from earlier capital of Anuradhapuraat time of Tamil invasions. Parakramabahu for while turned thetables on Tamils, and Sinhalese troops, profiting by Pandyanrebellions against Cōlas, attacked Indian coast, and even temporarilyoccupied Madurai.

Though their power declined, Cōlas long maintained central [Page76] part of their empire, region around Kāñcī and Tanjore. politicalstability and freedom from attack afforded by their efficient governmentgreatly encouraged Tamil culture, and large number of donativeinscriptions of this period testifies to flourishing economy.Administratively Cōla Empire is remarkable for influence exertedby local autonomous bodies; village and district councils, under thesupervision of central government, introduced an element into thestructure of state which, if not democratic, was at least popular (p. 106).The Cōlas fell in 13th century when their territory was shared by theHoysalas of Mysore and revived Pandya dynasty of Madurai. Now theDeccan was soon to feel force of Islam, which was already master ofNorthern India. In reign of theablesultanofDelhi,Ala’-ud-din Khalji(1296–1315), series of brilliant raids, led by eunuch general MalikKafur, converted Hindu, crushed Deccan kingdoms, and for time aMuslim sultanatewasset up even in Madurai, in extreme south.The Dravidians were not finally subjugated, however. Within few yearsof Malik Kafur’s raids, in 1336, an independent Hindu kingdom wasfounded at Vijayanagara, on Tufigabhadra River. This kingdom, afterdesperately resisting Bahmani sultans of Northern Deccan,established its hegemony over whole Peninsula from Krsna Riversouthwards. Learning something of military strategy from their Muslimenemies, kings of Vijayanagara maintained their independence until themiddle of 16th century, and, in reduced form, even later. Of thesplendour and affluence of their capital we hv European accounts, fromthe Italian Nicolo dei Conti, who visited India in early 15th century andfrom Portuguese travellers Paes and Nuniz, who made contact with thekingdom of Vijayanagara about hundred years later from recentlyestablished Portuguese settlement of Goa. All were impressed by thesplendour of capital and wealth of court. great king KrsnaDeva Raya (1509–1529) (pl. LXXI), had he lived longer, might hv driventhe Muslims from Deccan altogether. Of him Paes wrote in terms rarelyused by European traveller of an oriental monarch:“He is most feared and perfect king that could possibly be, cheerfulof disposition and very merry; he is one that seeks to honour foreigners, …asking about all their affairs whatever their condition may be. He is greatruler and man of much justice, but subject to sudden fits of rage.… He isby rank greater lord than any, by reason of what he possesses in armiesand territories, but … he has nothing compared to what man like himought to have, so gallant and perfect is he in all things.” 12[Page 77] Paes, in reign of Krsna Deva Raya, remarked on theprosperity of people and cheapness of provisions; but Nuniz, thesecond Portuguese traveller, who visited Vijayanagara in reign ofKrsna’s successor Acyuta (1529–42), was less impressed, and stated thatthe underlings of king were overbearing and common people muchoppressed. It is evident that beneficient regime of Krsna Deva Raya wasnot continued after his death. His successors were weaker men than he, andembroiled themselves unnecessarily in intrigues of Muslimsultanates of Northern Deccan, relying on prestige gained for themby their more powerful predecessor. In 1565, at Talikota, de facto rulerof Vijayanagara, Rama Raja, was utterly defeated by coalition of Deccansultans, great city was mercilessly sacked, and greatness of theempire was at an end.This was last important Hindu kingdom of older type. That of theMarathas, which arose in Western Deccan in late 17th century andwas most forceful element in Indian politics in 18th, lies beyond ourprovince.

The ultimate importance of this period in history of Peninsula was
cultural and religious. Jainism was once very strong in Mysore and other
parts of South, and often, under royal patronage, it became virtually the
state religion. But in Tamil country at this period new ecstatically
devotional theism arose, looking for inspiration rather to hymns in the
vernacular than to Vedas or earlier sacred texts in Sanskrit. This was
subsequently to set standard for popular religion of whole of
India, through work of missionary theologians who travelled all over the
sub-continent in later middle ages. work and influence of great
medieval Dravidian saints and philosophers will be discussed in another
chapter.

This brief outline of political history of Hindu India shows that sheproduced many bold adventurers and imperious conquerors. As ourfollowing chapter tells, they were ruthless in gaining and retaining power,and looked on war as normal political expedient. Except during theMauryan period political unity was unknown, and highly organized andtightly controlled administration of ancient Indian state had nocounterpart in inter-state relations, where endemic anarchy was onlymitigated by tradition of fair play in warfare, which was by no meansalways followed. Here, and in conservatism of medieval period, laythe great weakness of Hindu India, which made her prey to successiveinvaders. Of these wild tribes of Central Asia were rapidly assimilated,but Muslims with their rigidly codified religion, were too much for eventhe omnivorous Hindu culture to digest. Interaction between two [Page78] religions and ways of life indeed took place, and once at least modusvivendi was almost reached (p. 480). It is not wholly surprising, however,that, when India began to reassert herself, two nations should hv replacedthe single British Raj; but all impartial students must regret that unity ofthe Indian sub-continent has been once more lost, and trust that twogreat nations of India and Pakistan may soon forget bitterness born ofcenturies of strife, in cooperation for common welfare of their peoples.

IV.

THE STATE: POLITICAL LIFE AND
THOUGHT


SOURCES
[Page 79]
FROM days of Plato and Aristotle European thought has turned its attention to such questions as origin of state, ideal form ofgovernment, and basis of law, and politics has long been looked on as abranch of philosophy. India also thought on such questions, but she had noschools of political philosophy in Western sense. problems whichform stock-in-trade of European political philosopher r answeredin Indian texts, but in take-it-or-leave-it manner, with little discussion;often indeed only argument in favour of proposition is citation ofan old legend, used much as Plato’s adaptations of older myths to reinforcehis theories.

Though India had no formal political philosophy, science of statecraft was much cultivated, and number of important textbooks on this topic hv survived. Dandanīti, administration of force, or rājanīti, conduct of kings, was severely practical science, and texts cursorilydismiss more philosophical aspect of politics, but give comparativelydetailed advice on organization of state and conduct ofgovernmental affairs. later Vedic literature tells us something,incidentally, about political life and thought in pre-Buddhist period, andwe cn gather much from Pāli scriptures of Buddhism; but earliestand most important textbook specifically devoted to statecraft is theKautilīya Arthaśāstra, which is attributed to Kautilya, famous ministerof Candragupta Maurya (p. 50). Some authorities still maintain fullauthenticity of work, but there r grave objections to this view. Thetext refers to people and places (notably China) which do not seem to havebeen known to Indians in 4th century B.C. It does not use much ofthe official terminology employed in Aśokan inscriptions or in Pāliscriptures, but it contains many governmental terms which apparently didnot become popular until post-Mauryan times. Yet it is certainly pre-Guptan, and is, we believe, elaboration of Mauryan original whichwas perhaps work of Kautilya himself. Whatever its age, Arthaśāstragives very detailed instructions on control of state, organizationof national economy, and conduct [Page 80] of war, and it is mostprecious source-book for many aspects of ancient Indian life.

The next important source, in chronological order, is great epic, Mahābhārata, of which twelfth book, known as Santi Parvan, is acollection of many disparate passages on statecraft and human conduct,inserted into body of epic in early centuries of Christian era.Other passages on statecraft r found elsewhere in Mahābhārata, and inthe second of great epics, Rāmāyna. great body of literaturegenerally called Smrti, giving instruction in Sacred Law, is veryimportant in this connexion, and will be discussed later (p. 128f); especiallysignificant is seventh section of lawbook ascribed to primevalsage Manu, probably composed early in Christian era.

From Gupta period and Middle Ages number of political texts survive, most important of which r Nītisāra (“Essence of Politics”) of Kāmandaka, perhaps written during Gupta period, Nītivākyāmrta(“Nectar of Aphorisms on Politics”) of Somadeva Sūri, Jaina writer of the10th century, and Nītiśātra (“Treatise on Politics”) attributed to theancient sage Śukra, but evidently of late medieval origin. These repeatmuch that has been said before, but here and there contain original ideas.Besides sources specifically dealing with political life and thought, ancientIndian literature as whole, from Rg Veda onwards, yields muchinformation, and inscriptions of one kind and another r extremelyvaluable in this connexion.

The texts do not discuss wholly impossible utopias; their advice is often pedantic, but usually more or less feasible. However, it is not likely that anyking conducted his affairs wholly on textbook lines, and there is ampleevidence that recommendations of experts were not always put intoeffect. reader must always bear in mind that in texts on statecraftand Sacred Law authors describe things not as they were in fact, but asthey believed they ought to be. Probably in no kingdom of ancient India,not even in that of Mauryas, was influence of state quite so all-pervading as in system envisaged by Arthaśāstra, though its authorevidently based his precept upon current practice. Similarly viciouspunishments laid down by Manu for religious crimes (for example śūdrawho “arrogantly teaches brāhmans their duty” shall hv boiling oil pouredin his mouth and ears1) r suggestions of fanatic and were rarely ifever put into practice. Moreover texts r permeated with pedantry, andshow passion for sterile classification to which Indian pandit hasoften been prone. It is unlikely that more energetic and self-reliant rulersworried [Page 81] overmuch about Arthaśātra’s discussion of differentschools of thought on such questions as whether it is better to acquire wildand rebellious but prosperous country, or pacific but poor one. Manyerrors hv been made by historians through their uncritical acceptance ofthese political texts as giving an exact picture of things as they were.

## KINGSHIP
The earliest legend on origin of kingship occurs in Aitareya Brāhmana, 2 one of later Vedic texts, perhaps of 8th or 7th century B.C. This tells how gods and demons were at war, and gods were suffering badly at hands of their enemies. So they met together and decided that they needed rājā to lead dm in battle. They appointed Indra as their king, and tide soon turned in their favour. This legend suggests that in earliest times kingship in India was thought to be based uponhuman need and military necessity, and that king’s first duty was to leadhis subjects in war. little later Taittirīya Upanisad3 repeats story,but in significantly altered form; discomfited gods did not elect Indra,but sacrificed to high god Prajāpati, who sent his son Indra to becometheir king. At this stage king was still thought of as primarily leader inwar-“they who hv no king cannot fight” says text-but kingship wasalready given divine sanction and king of immortals, who was theprototype of all earthly kings, held his office by appointment of theMost High.

Even at this time, before days of Buddha, king was exalted far above ordinary mortals, through magical power of great royal sacrifices. Royal Consecration (rājasūya), which in its full form comprised series of sacrifices lasting for over year, imbued king with divine power. In course of ceremonies he was identified with Indra “because he is ksatriya and because he is sacrificer”, 4 and even with high god Prajāpati himself.5 He took three steps on tiger’s skin, and was thus magically identified with god Visnu, whose three paces covered earth and heaven. chief priest addressed gods with words: “Of mighty power is he who has been consecrated; now he has become one of yours; you must protect him.”6 king was evidently fellow of gods, if not god himself.

The magical power which pervaded king at his consecration wasrestored and strengthened in course of his reign by further rites, such asthe ceremonial rejuvenation of vājapeya and horse-sacrifice( aśvamedha, p. 42), which not only ministered to his [Page 82] ambitionand arrogance, but also ensured prosperity and fertility of kingdom.Implicit in whole brāhmanic ritual was idea of king’s divineappointment, and though rājasūfya was replaced in later times by asimplified abhiseka, or baptism, ceremony still had this magical flavour.

But centre of brāhmanic culture was Ganges-Jamnā Doāb. Ifamong Kurus and Pañcālas, who were chief tribes of this region, theking was hedged about with divine mystery, elsewhere his status may havebeen less exalted, for Buddhists had their own legend of origin ofkingship, which involved no heavenly prototype, but looked back to aprimitive social contract.7 story is put into mouth of Buddhahimself, and, whether or not it is really his, it certainly represents thethought on subject in eastern part of India in centuries followingthe Buddha’s death, for Jainas, who rose at about same time and inthe same region, had very similar legend.8In early days of cosmic cycle mankind lived on an immaterialplane, dancing on air in sort of fairyland, where there was no need of foodor clothing, and no private property, family, government or laws. Thengradually process of cosmic decay began its work, and mankind becameearthbound, and felt need of food and shelter. As men lost their primevalglory distinctions of class ( varna) arose, and they entered into agreementsone with another, accepting institutions of private property and thefamily. With this theft, murder, adultery, and other crime began, and so thepeople met together and decided to appoint one man among dm tomaintain order in return for share of produce of their fields and herds.

He was called “the Great Chosen One” ( Mahāsammata), and he received title of rājā because he pleased people. etymology of word rājā from verb rañayati (“he pleases”) is certainly false one, but it was widely maintained and is found even in non-Buddhist sources. story of Mahāsammata gives, in form of myth worthy ofPlato, one of world’s earliest versions of widespread contractualtheory of state, which in Europe is specially connected with namesof Locke and Rousseau. It implies that main purpose of government isto establish order, and that king, as head of government, is firstsocial servant, and ultimately dependent on suffrage of his subjects.Thus in ancient Indian thought on question of origin of monarchytwo strands r evident, mystical and contractual, often ratherincongruously combined.

In thought, if not in practice, it was mystical theory of kingship [Page83] which carried most weight with succeeding generations. author ofthe Arthaśāstra had no illusions about king’s human nature, and seemsto hv had little time for mysticism, but he recognized that legends aboutthe origin of kingship had propaganda value. In one place he advises thatthe king’s agents should spread story that, when anarchy prevailed at thedawn of aeon, men elected mythical first king Manu Vaivasvata tokingship. 9 He thus encourages contractual theory. In same passage,however, he states that people should be told that, as king fulfils thefunctions of gods Indra (the king of gods) and Yama (the god ofdeath) upon earth, all who slight him will be punished not only by thesecular arm, but also by heaven. When king harangues his troops beforebattle he is advised to tell dm that he is paid servant just as they are; 10but at same time he is told to go to length of having his secret agentsdisguised as gods, and allowing himself to be seen in their company, inorder that his simpler subjects may believe that he mixes with gods onequal terms.11 Aśoka and other Mauryan kings took title “Beloved ofthe Gods” ( Devānampiya), and, though they seem not to hv claimedwholly divine status, they were no doubt looked on as superior semi-divinebeings.

In period of later Vedas, though there is no evidence that reallylarge Indian kingdom had existed since days of then forgottenHarappā Culture, possibility of realm reaching to sea wasrecognized, perhaps as result of what Indians had heard of Babylonia orPersia. With Mauryas possibility was realized, and though they toowere soon largely forgotten, they left behind dm tradition of theUniversal Emperor ( cakravartin), which was incorporated into Buddhisttradition, and, blended with later Vedic imperialist ideas, was taken over byorthodox Hinduism. Just as Buddhas appear from time to time in cosmiccycle, heralded by auspicious omens and endowed with favourable signs, tolead all living beings along road to enlightenment, so do UniversalEmperors appear, to conquer all Jambūdvīpa and rule prosperously andrighteously. concept of Universal Emperor was also known to theJainas, and in Epics numerous kings of legend, such as Yudhisthira andRāma, r said to hv been digvijayins, conquerors of all four quarters.

The Universal Emperor was divinely ordained figure with special place in cosmic scheme, and as such was exalted to semi-divine status. tradition was an inspiration to ambitious monarchs, and in Middle Ages some even claimed to be Universal Emperors themselves. invasions of Greeks, Śakas and Kusānas brought new influencesfrom West and East. Their kings, following practice [Page 84] of theorientalized Seleucids and other rulers of Middle East, took semi-divine title trātāra, equivalent to Greek(saviour); they were notsatisfied with simple title of rājā, which had served Aśoka, but were“great kings” ( mahārāja) and “kings of kings” ( rājaāirāja) on Persianmodel. Kusānas, perhaps from influence of China, where theemperor was Son of Heaven, took further title “Son of Gods”( devaputra). Later, from Gupta times onwards, every important king wouldtake some such title as “Great King of Kings, Supreme Lord”( mahārājādhirāja-paramabhaāraka), while even title mahārāja wasused only for small vassal kings.

Fig. ix. Cakravartin
After relief from stūpa of Jagayyapeta on lower Kistnā c. 200–100 B.C. On his right the
wheel, symbolizing universal empire, and his chief queen On his left chief minister and crown
prince. At his feet imperial elephant and horse.

With these influences at work doctrine of royal divinity was explicitly
proclaimed. It appears first in Epics and Lawbook of Manu. The
latter declares in dignified language:
“When world was without king and dispersed in fear in all
directions, Lord created king for protection of all. [Page 85]
“He made him of eternal particles Of Indra and Wind, Yama, the
Sun and Fire, Varuna, Moon, and Lord of Wealth.

“And, because he has been formed of fragments of all those gods,
the king surpasses all other beings in splendour.

“Even an infant king must not be despised, as though mere mortal,
for he is great god in human form.” 12
To ideal of Universal Emperor was added inspiration of the
revival of such brāhmanic ceremonies as horse-sacrifice, which
apparently fell into desuetude under Mauryas, but was revived by the
Śungas, and was performed by many later kings both in north and south.

Even comparatively feeble and petty monarchs managed to perform horse-sacrifices of some sort, and claimed exalted status of emperors oflegend. After time of Guptas these sacrifices became rare, however-the last we hv been able to trace took place in Cōa Empire in 11thcentury13—but tradition of royal divinity continued. Kings referred totheir divine status in their titles and panegyrics, and they were regularlyaddressed by their courtiers as deva, or god. Cōla kings and someothers were even worshipped as gods in temples.

In period between Mauryas and Guptas anarchy frequentlyprevailed. Mass lawlessness, riot, pillage and rape, were widespread.Raiding bands of invaders from North-West penetrated far into heartof India, and some brāhmans even believed that end of aeon wasdrawing near and that world would soon be destroyed. It was then thatan almost pathological dread of anarchy ( mātsyanyāya, literally “the way ofthe fishes”, of whom stronger eat weaker) grew in minds ofIndian thinkers. In words of Rāmāyana:“Where land is kingless cloud, lightning-wreathed and loud-voiced, gives no rain to earth.

“Where land is kingless son does not honour his father, nor wife her husband.

“Where land is kingless men do not meet in assemblies, nor make lovely gardens and temples.

[Page 86] “Where land is kingless rich r unprotected, and shepherds and peasants sleep with bolted doors.

“A river without water, forest without grass, herd of cattle without herdsman, is land without king.” 14
Passages such as this, which may be paralleled in many sources, further
assisted in strengthening royal prestige, and it is in their light that we
must read later legends on origin of kingship.

There is very ancient story of first man, Manu, who combined thecharacteristics of Adam and Noah in Hebrew tradition (p. 302). This storyappears in many forms and versions, one of which, found in theMahābhārata, 15 tells that at beginning of this period of cosmic time,when greed and wrath had disturbed human relations, men inflicted untoldmisery upon one another. As in Buddhist legend, they agreed to respecteach other’s life and property, but they had no confidence in their contracts,and so they approached high god, Brahmā, to help them; he nominatedManu, here thought of not as man, but god, to be their first king. Somesuch legend as this was in mind of author of Laws of Manu,when he composed passage we hv quoted. Variants of this story occurin other parts of Mahābhārata and elsewhere, some making firstking Virajas, son of god Visnu. 16 All adapt earlier legends tostress divine status of king, and his divine appointment to kinglyoffice. With exception of few Rājput families who claimed descentfrom fire-god Agni, nearly all medieval Indian kings traced theirgenealogies back to Manu, either through his son Iksvāku or his daughterIlā; descendants of Iksvaku r referred to as of solar, and those of Ila asof lunar line.

Despite growth of royal pretensions through centuries claims
of king did not go unchallenged, and in practice his divinity often made
little difference to body politic. Divinity was cheap in ancient India.

Every brāhman was in sense god, as were ascetics with reputation for sanctity. Householders sponsoring and financing sacrifices were in theory raised to divinity, at least for duration of ceremony, while even sticks and stones might be alive with inherent godhead. Moreover gods were fallible and capable of sin. If king was god on earth he was onlyone god among many, and so his divinity might not always weigh heavilyupon his subjects. Buddhists and Jainas explicitly denied king’sgodhead, and one court poet at least, Bāsa, who was patronized by greatHarsa, had temerity to reject whole rigmarole of royal divinity as thework of sycophants who befuddled minds [Page 87] of weak and stupidmonarchs, but did not fool strong and wise. 17 king was usuallyheld in great awe and respect, but it is doubtful if he was ever treated withquite same abject servility as were, for instance, more psychopathicRoman or Chinese emperors.

Though king was an autocrat, not limited by constitutional controls, there were many practical checks on his sovereignty. Arthaśāstra, totalitarian and secular in tendency, maintains that royal ordinance cn rightly override all other sources of law, but most theorists would hv disagreed with this statement. king’s function was not conceived interms of legislation, but of protection, and this involved protection notonly of his subjects from invasion, but also of order of society, rightway of life for all classes and ages ( varnāśrama-dharma, p. 137), as laiddown in sacred texts. If he infringed sacred custom too blatantly heincurred hostility of brāhmans, and often of lower orders also. Insuch case his fate was pointed out to him in many cautionary tale, themost common of which was that of legendary Vena. This kingapparently took his divinity too seriously, for he forbade all sacrificesexcept to himself, and confused society by enforcing interclass marriages.

The divine sages (rsis) remonstrated with him, but Vena continued in his evil courses. At last exasperated sages beset him in body and slew him with blades of sacred grass ( kuśa), which miraculously turned to spears in their hands. This story, repeated in numerous sources, must hv been continual warning to secularly-minded king tempted to flout SacredLaw. No doubt many headstrong kings succeeded in breaking it withimpunity, but recognition of moral justification of revolt against animpious king must always hv acted as some check on his autocracy. Morethan one great dynasty, such as Nandas, Mauryas and Śungas, fell as aresult of brāhmanic intrigue. Mahābhārata explicitly sanctions revoltagainst king who is oppressive or fails in his function of protection,saying that such ruler is no king at all, and should be killed like maddog. 18The brāhmans and Sacred Law were not only checks on king.

All textbooks on statecraft recommend king to listen to counsel of his ministers, who r advised to be fearless in debate, and more than one king was overthrown through intrigues of his councillors. Another and very important check was public opinion. Vedic rājā was limited by popular or semi-popular assemblies, and though these disappeared in later times kings were invariably advised to keep finger on pulse of public feeling, and never to offend it too blatantly. Buddhist Jātaka stories [Page 88] (p. 267), which r certainly not historical, but reflect conditions in Northern India well before beginning of Christian Era, give more than one instance of kings deposed by mass revolt. In legend of Rāma(p. 412f), who was held up as an ideal king to later Hindu rulers, heroexiles his beloved wife Sītā, though he is himself convinced of herinnocence, on hearing news that his subjects suspect her chastity, andfear that her presence in palace will bring misfortune on nation. Atthe very end of our period great king of Vijayanagara, Krsna Deva Rāya(p. 76) remitted marriage tax because it was not popular. 19 Indiantown mob was dangerously inflammable, and king who seriouslyoutraged popular opinion did so at his own peril. Most textbooks insist thathe must at all costs keep masses contented.

Nevertheless ancient India had her supporters of passive obedience. TheMahābhārata, which, as we hv seen, in places expressly allows revoltagainst wicked king, elsewhere states that any king is better than none.The dread of anarchy was potent factor in preserving even weak andoppressive king on his throne.“A man should first choose his king, then his wife, and only thenamass wealth; for without king in world where would wife andproperty be?” 20


## ROYAL FUNCTION ROYAL FUNCTION
The idea of body politic, of state as an organism transcending its component parts, though it appears in rather vague form, does not seem tohave taken any great hold on ancient Indian thought. classificationpopular with theorists enumerates seven elements of sovereignty, which r occasionally compared to limbs and parts of human body-the king to head, ministers to eyes, ally to ear, thetreasury to mouth, army to mind, fortifications to arms,and land and people to legs. Such weak analogies carried littleweight, however. Society, age-old divinely ordained way of Indian life,transcended state and was independent of it. king’s function was theprotection of society, and state was merely an extension of king forthe furtherance of that end.The king’s function involved protection not only of his kingdomagainst external aggression, but also of life, property and traditional customagainst internal foes. He protected purity of class and caste by ensuringthat those who broke caste custom were excommunicated; he protected thefamily system by punishing adultery, and ensuring fair inheritance offamily property; he protected widows and orphans by making dm hiswards; he protected rich against poor by suppressing robbery; and heprotected poor against rich by punishing extortion and oppression.Religion was protected by liberal grants to learned brāhmans and temples,and frequently to heterodox sects also. duty of protection was oftenlittle more than preservation of status quo, but it was neverthelessonerous, and involved positive duties, such as developing irrigation,relieving famine, and generally supervising economic life of realm.
