The ideal set before king was one of energetic [[beneficence]]. Aśokawas not only king of India to proclaim that all men were his children, orto take pride in his ceaseless activity. Arthaśāstra, despite its advocacyof every dishonest expedient for acquisition and maintenance of power,puts kingly duty in simple and forceful language, setting an ideal suchas few ancient civilizations cn boast of. Comparing king and theascetic it says:“The king’s pious vow is readiness in action, his sacrifice, thedischarge of his duty.

“In happiness of his subjects lies king’s happiness, in the
welfare of his subjects, his welfare. king’s good is not that which
pleases him, but that which pleases his subjects.

“Therefore king should be ever active, and should strive for
prosperity, for prosperity depends on effort, and failure on the
reverse.”21

Elsewhere Arthaśāstra suggests time-table for king’s day, which allows him only four and half hours’ sleep and three hours for eating and recreation, rest of day being spent in state affairs of one kind or another. No doubt such programme was rarely kept in practice, but it at least shows ideal at which king was expected to aim. Candragupta Maurya is said by Megasthenes to hv listened to petitions of hissubjects even while in hands of his masseurs, while his grandson Aśokaordered that important business was to be set before him at all times, evenwhen he was in his harem. In all sources king is told that he must beprompt in administration of justice and always accessible to his [Page90] people. swarms of guards, ushers, and other officials whosurrounded king’s person must often hv demanded bribes, andotherwise hv obstructed access of subject to his sovereign, but thebest of Indian kings at all times hv made public audience, or darbār,an important instrument of government.

Nearly all foreign travellers who visited India during our period were much impressed by pomp and luxury of Indian king, and their impressions r confirmed by native sources. king’s splendid palace was controlled by chamberlain, who had large staff of palace servants of both sexes; spiritual life of palace was cared for by courtchaplain, or purohita, and many lesser brāhmans; while numerousastrologers, physicians, poets, painters, musicians and learned men dwelt inthe purlieus of palace and enjoyed royal patronage. An important figurein early days, though he is not referred to in inscriptions of later times,was sūta, who combined functions of royal charioteer, herald andbard, and was often friend and confidant of king. Another memberof royal entourage was vidūsaka, known to us chiefly fromtheSanskritplays,whocorresponded approximately to court jester ofmedieval Europe.Many kings were almost constantly on move, touring their kingdomswith enormous trains of troops, courtiers, wives, concubines and servants.On such tours business was combined with pleasure-hunts were arrangedand famous shrines visited, but also recalcitrant vassals were chastised andlocal grievances investigated. Many inscriptions on stone and copper, fromthe days of Aśoka onwards, record munificence of pious kings toreligious foundations and brāhmans while on such tours.Kings were expected to patronize art, letters and learning. Like most menof upper classes they were literate, and often devoted much of theirleisure to hearing recitations of their court poets. Some were themselvescompetent writers, and numerous works ascribed to royal authors havesurvived. Samudra Gupta was famous musician, and is depicted on someof his coins playing harp (fig. xxivb, p. 381).Despite injunctions of Arthaśāstra king often found time forother, less intellectual, pursuits. Hunting was usually among chief of hispleasures, and though doctrine of non-injury discouraged it, tacitexception was made in case of kings and nobles. Kings r oftenreferred to as gambling with their courtiers, and sometimes as indulging indrinking bouts, not only with court, but in privacy of harem withthe queens and concubines. textbooks reprobate all these amusements,which r reviewed [Page 91] in Arthaśāstra, whose author quaintlyquotes opinions of various earlier authorities on their comparativeperniciousness.The harem ( antahpura) was in charge of an official ( kañcukin), usuallynot eunuch, as in many other ancient civilizations, but an elderlyman,whoisgenerally depicted in literature as benevolent and fatherly friendboth of king and his ladies. ladies of theharem,whetherqueensorconcubines,seem,fromseveralplaysandstories dealing with this aspect ofpalace life, to hv been fairly well treated; though kPoth they and kingoften went in some fear of chief queen ( mahisī),whosepowerintheharem was very great and was often wielded rather harshly over lesserqueens and concubines.Ideally royal family was of ksatriya or warrior class, but in practicethiswasoften not case. Śusgas and Kāsvas were brahmans, as wereseveral other Indian dynasties; family of Harsa is said by Hstian Tsangto hv been of vaiśya,ormercantileclass; while Nandas, andperhaps even Mauryas, sprang from despised śūidras. In practice theaphorism “whoever bears rule is aksatriya”wasapplied,andafterafewgenerations kingly families from lower orders were quietly assimilatedin martial class.Kingship was normally reserved for male, though few small Orissanruling families in Middle Ages seem regularly to hv permitted adaughter to inherit throne. Diddā, wicked 10thcentury queen ofKashmīr, managed to retain control of state by acting as regent for hersons, and putting dm to death one after other before they reached theirmajorities. benevolent queen of Kākatīyas of Warangal, Rudrammā(c. 1259–1288), governed by legal fiction, drafting her state documents inthe masculine gender. Queens did, however, act as regents during theirsons’ minorities, as in case of Diddā and Prabhāvatī Guptā (p. 65), androyal ladies sometimes wielded much power in state. Thus Rājyaśri,widow of Grahavarman, last Maukhari king of Kānyakubja, regularlytook seat of honour beside her brother Harsa, and shared in statedeliberations. Women in politics were often to be found in medievalkingdoms of Peninsula; for instance Akkādevī, sister of Cślukyaking Jayasimha II (1015–1042), was provincial governor, and Kundavai,the elder sister of great Cōla Rājarāja I, seems to hv played rolesimilar to that of Rājyaśrī. Women even sometimes took part in war-Akkādevī fought battles and superintended sieges, while Umādevī, queen ofthe Hoysala king Vīraballāla II (1173–1220), led two campaigns againstrecalcitrant vassals.[Page 92] Succession was normally by primogeniture, but exceptions mightoften occur for Sacred Law did not allow diseased, maimed orseriously infirm prince to ascend throne, and line could not passthrough such prince. Thus in Mahābhārata legend (p. 408) thePāndava princes were quite within their rights in claiming throne fromthe blind Dhrtarāstra. Moral perversity might also exclude prince fromsuccession. “A wicked son, though an only one,” says Arthaśāstra,“should never ascend throne”. 22 Kings sometimes nominated theirsuccessors, overriding claims of their eldest sons if these were given toevil courses. Thus Samudra Gupta was nominated by his father, CandraGupta I, against other claimants, at great darbār, after which old kingapparently abdicated; and similar instances cn be found. absence of astrict rule of primogeniture was cause of dynastic disputes, and henceundoubtedly led to weakening of empires.Princes were trained with great care, and heir to throne ( yuvarāja)was often associated with his father in government. This custom waswidespread, and was especially strong with invaders of North-West,and with Cōlas, whose crown princes often issued charters in their ownnames and acted independently of their fathers while latter were still onthe throne. Śakas and Pahlavas often inscribed name of rulingking on obverse of their coins, while that of sub-king was given onthe reverse.Princes might be great source of danger to their parents. acc to aBuddhist tradition Magadha was ruled from Ajātaśatru onwards by fiveparricides in succession, which suggests that at time this region of Indiafollowed widespread primitive practice of putting king to deathwhen his vital powers failed, practice of which customary nature wasnot remembered by succeeding generations. Kings r warned against theintrigues both of sons and wives, “for princes, like crabs, eat their ownparents”.23 activities of princes must be strictly controlled, and theymust be constantly spied upon, to ensure that they will not revolt againsttheir fathers.The prince’s impatience to acquire his patrimony was often gratified by thevoluntary abdication of an elderly king-a practice approved by precept andtradition, examples of which may be found at all times and in all parts ofIndia. Sometimes abdication was followed by religious suicide. Severalkings, most notable being Candragupta Maurya, r said to haveabdicated and slpwly starved themselves to death under influence ofJainism. Others passed straight to heaven by drowning in sacred river,notably Cālukya king Someśvara I (c. 1042–1068), who, when hispowers began to [Page 93] fail, waded into holy Tungabhadrā anddrowned himself to sound of religious music, while his courtiers linedthe banks. In some of medieval principalities of Malabār ritualsuicide of king became regular institution.

PLATE XXII
Other systems of inheritance prevailed in few cases. Thus throne of Śaka satraps of Ujjayinī passed not to king’s son, but to his younger brother, and only when all brothers were dead did eldest son of theeldest brother inherit. There r indications that brother-to-brothersuccession was not wholly unknown elsewhere in India, and it was almostregularly followed in Ceylon. This system prevailed in China under theShang dynasty (c. 1500–1100 B.C.), and was also followed by many CentralAsian tribes; it is still known in East Africa.In early days of Cera kingdom of Malabār inheritance wasthrough male line, but about 12th century matrilinear systembecame regular, acc to which heir to throne was not son ofthe king, but of his eldest sister. This system, called Marumakkattāyam,continued in Cochin and Travancore until very recent times, both for royalsuccession and inheritance of estates. Perhaps it existed in Malabār at anearly period, but was dropped by upper classes for while underbrāhmanical influence, to be revived in course of centuries. Other tracesof matrilinear succession cn be found in ancient India, notably in verycommon use of metronymics in royal titles, but it was not regularlyfollowed by any important kingdoms.If king died with no heir to throne much power was wielded bythe magnates of realm, for courtiers, nobles, ministers, religiousleaders and wealthy merchants would sometimes meet together and choosea king. Thus nobles of Kānyakubja invited Har to assume thronewhen Grahavarman died childless. Gopāla, founder of Pāla line ofBengal and Bihār, was chosen as king by great men of land. Afurther example is appointment of boy Nandivarman (755–797) asthe Pallava king of Kāñcī by an assembly of nobles and ministers. TheKashmīr Chronicle provides other instances.
## QUASI-FEUDALISM
Authorities differ on definition of feudal system. Some would confine term to complex structure of contractual relations covering whole of society from king to villein, which prevailed in medievalEurope. Others use term so loosely that they apply it to any systemwhere political power is chiefly in [Page 94] hands of those who ownland. Most British historians would prefer narrower definition,according to which ancient India never had true feudal system. Somethingvery like European feudalism did evolve among Rājputs after theMuslim invasions, but this is outside our period. Ancient India had,however, system of overlordship, which was quasi-feudal, though never asfully developed as in Europe, and resting on different basis.

In later Vedic period there were already lesser chiefs tributary to greater. Terms in these texts like adhirāja and samrāt, often loosely translated “emperor”, seem actually to imply lordship over number of feudatories. Magadhan imperialism aimed at centralized realm, thougheven in Mauryan times vassal chiefs existed in more remote regions ofthe empire. With fall of Mauryas typical large kingdom had acentral core of directly administered territory, and circle of vassalkingdoms subordinate in varying degrees to emperor. vassals themselves had vassals of their own in petty local chieftains calling themselves rājās. Indian system differed from that of Europe in that relations of overlord and vassal were not regularly based on contract, whether theoretical or otherwise, and ancient India had nothing quit  comparable to European manor.

When decisively defeated in battle king might render homage to hisconqueror and retain his throne. Thus vassals usually became so byconquest rather than by contract, though Arthaśāstra advises weakking to render voluntary homage if necessary to stronger neighbour. Thisstate of affairs was supported by Epics and Smrti literature, whichdiscouraged outright conquest. “Lawful conquest” ( dharmavijaya) did notinvolve absorption of conquered kingdom, but merely its reductionto vassal status. Though many later kings, such as Samudra Gupta, ignoredthe Sacred Law and incorporated conquered kingdoms into their empires,custom was against such practice.

The degrees of control of overlord over vassal varied much. Ideally vassal was expected to pay regular tribute to his emperor, and to assist him with troops and funds in war. He attended overlord’s court on ceremonial occasions, and panegyrics of powerful medieval kingsregularly mention jewels of many splendid turbans glittering like thewaves of sea, as vassals bow before their lord. In his charters thevassal was expected to mention name and title of his overlord before hisown. In some cases resident representative of overlord was stationedat vassal’s capital. vassal’s sons might be educated with princesof his master, and serve as pages, and his daughters might be demanded[Page 95] for imperial harem. Often vassal king acted as minister ofhis suzerain, or minister or favourite might be set up as vassal king byhis master. Hence in medieval period status of minister often mergedwith that of vassal, and provincial governor, holding office at king’spleasure, tended to become feudatory king or chief in his own right.The great vassal ( mahāsāmanta) was always very powerful, and had hisown administration and army. Among many threats to security of aking revolting vassal was one of most dangerous. history of theWestern Deccan offers typical examples. Here, from 6th centuryonwards, Cālukya dynasty held sway; vassal, Dantidurga Rāstrakūta,overthrew it and established his own dynasty about 753, and Calukyaswere reduced to insignificant vassalage; but some 200 years later theyprofited by weakness of Rastrakutas to regain hegemony, whichthey maintained until end of 12th century, when their vassals, theYādavas, Kākatīyas and Hoysalas, shared their domains between them.In fact suzerain’s hand weighed very lightly on more powerfuland remoter vassals, and many claims to homage and tribute amounted tovery little. Samudra Gupta, for instance, even claimed king of Ceylon,Śrī Meghavarna, as his vassal; but it is clear from reliable Chinese sourcethat claim was based merely on reception of Sinhalese missionbearing gifts and requesting permission to erect Buddhist monastery at thesacred site of Gayā.The lesser chiefs, on other hand, had little more power than lordsof manor in medieval Europe, though they claimed proud title ofrājā. In this connection an interesting story is told in an inscription atDūdhpānī, in S. Bihār, dating from 8th century A.D.Three merchant brothers were returning from port of Tāmraliptito their home in Ayodhyā, with caravan of merchandise andprovisions, and rested for night at village calledBhramaraśālmali. Meanwhile local king, Ādisimha, passed by on ahunting expedition, with large train of followers, and, as was thecustom, demanded food and fodder of villagers. But they weresuffering from temporary shortage, and could scarcely meet thisdemand. So they sent deputation to merchants, who at theirrequest gave king provisions from their own stock. king foundthe companionship of eldest brother, Udayamāna, very agreeable,and so he and his brothers became members of Ādisimha’s court. Oneday, Udayamāna revisited village of Bhramaraśālmalī, and thevillagers, remembering his former kindness, asked him to become theirking. King Ādisimha approved request, and so merchantUdayamāna became [Page 96] rājā of Bhramaraśālmalī, while his twobrothers were made kings of adjoining villages.24This little story illustrates another means whereby quasi-feudal relationsarose. After Mauryan period it became usual for kings to pay theirofficers and favourites not with cash, but with right to collect revenuefrom village or group of villages. Such right often carried otherprivileges, and usually made recipient intermediary between kingand taxpayer. It greatly encouraged tendency towards devolution,instability, and inter-state anarchy.

## OLIGARCHIES AND REPUBLICS
Though monarchy was usual in ancient India, tribal states also existed,which were governed by oligarchies. term “republic” is often used forthese bodies, and though it has been criticized by some authorities, it isquite legitimate if it is remembered that ganas, or tribes, were notgoverned like Republic of India by an assembly elected by universalsuffrage. Roman Republic was not democracy, but it was republicnevertheless, and evidence shows that in some of these ancient Indianrepublican communities large number of persons had some say in thegovernment.

Vedic literature gives faint indications of such tribes at very early date(p. ss), and Buddhist scriptures recognize existence of manyrepublics, chiefly in foothills of Himālayas and in N. Bihār. Thesewere mostly tributary to greater kingdoms, but exercised internalautonomy. One such people was Śākyas, who dwelt on borders ofmodern Nepāl, and to whom Buddha himself belonged. Though in laterlegend Buddha’s father, Śuddhodhana, is depicted as mighty kingliving in great pomp, he was in fact tribal chief, depending on supportof large assembly of householders, who gathered regularly to discusstribal politics in meeting hall (in Pāli, santhāgāra).The most powerful non-monarchical state at this time was Vrjjianconfederacy, of which chief element was tribe of Licchavis, andwhich long resisted great Ajātaśatru. acc to rather dubiousBuddhist tradition Licchavis had no less than 7707 rājās, term whichmust hv covered all heads of families of tribe who were eligible totake part in tribal assembly. Jaina sources tell of an inner council ofthirty-six tribal chieftains controlling affairs of Licchavis, Mallasand allied tribes in their war with Ajātaśatru. whole confederation had arājā-inchief, an executive head who, like rājā of Śākyas, seems[Page 97] to hv held office for life and often to hv passed on his officeto his heir.It has been reasonably suggested that organization of Buddhistclergy, which is said to hv been laid down by Buddha himself, ismodelled on constitution of one of these republican tribes, perhaps theŚākyas. Buddhist monastic affairs were managed by general meeting ofthe monks, with regular system of procedure and standing orders, not verydifferent from that of business meeting of present-day society. TheBuddhist chapter differed from modern committee, however, in that alldecisions needed unanimous consent of assembled monks.

Differences which could not be settled were referred to committee of elders.

In Buddha’s day free tribes were standing up with difficulty to internal pressure of changing social and economic conditions, and external pressure of rising kingdoms of Eastern India. We hv seen that both Śākyas and Vrjjis were conquered at about time of Buddha’s death, former never to rise again (p. 46). Buddha himself,though friend of kings, seems to hv had deep affection for oldrepublican organization, and in remarkable passage he is said to havewarned Vrjjis shortly before his death that their security depended onmaintaining their traditions and holding regular and well attended folk-moots.Western India did not feel force of imperialism as strongly as east,and here republican tribes survived for much longer. Several such peoplesare mentioned in classical accounts of Alexander’s invasion, and theArthaśādastra devotes whole chapter to means whereby such tribesmay be reduced to vassalage by an ambitious king-the main method beingto sow dissension between leading tribesmen so that tribal assemblyloses its unanimity and tribe is divided against itself. Such procedure,according to Buddhist legend, was employed by Ajātaśatru’s wily ministerVassakara to weaken Vrjjis before invasion. Arthaśāstra probablyrefers ironically to martial arrogance and practical ineptitude of therepublics when it states that members of seven named tribes “make aliving by their title of rājā”. 25The Mahābhārata takes full cognisance of existence of republicantribes in Western India, and their survival until 5th century A.D. isattested by numerous coins and few short inscriptions. Perhaps mostimportant western republic was that of Yaudheyas in NorthernRājasthān, which issued numerous coins, bearing inscription “Victory tothe Yaudheya tribe”; one of their official seals has been found, with theproud legend, “Of Yaudheyas, who [Page 98] possess magic spell ofvictory” and one fragmentary Yaudheya inscription survives. This mentionsthe chief of tribe, whose name has unfortunately been worn away by theweathering of stone; he has regal title of mahārāja, but he is alsocalled mahāsenāpati, or general-in-chief, and he is “placed at head ofthe Yaudheya people”.26The Malava tribe may be same as Malloi described by Greekhistorians as living in Panjāb at time of Alexander. If so, tribemoved south during centuries, for its coins r found in Rajasthan, andit gave its name to Malwa, region around Ujjayinī, north of theNarmadā. Some brief 3rd-century inscriptions at Nandsā in Rājasthān referto Mālava Śrīsoma, who “supported ancestral yoke of government”,and whose position was therefore hereditary.27 It is probable that theMālavas founded era later known as Era of Vikrama, for severalearly inscriptions refer to this as “the Era handed down by Mālavatribe”.

Most of these western tribes became tributary to Guptas afterSamudra Gupta’s great conquests in 4th century (p. 63). After this wehear little more of them, and they probably vanished as result of Hūnainvasions. We know very little of their organization, which may hv beenloosely feudal, with large number of petty chieftains more or lesssubordinate to single head, who held office with their consent and coulddo little without their help. In any case modern India may take legitimatepride in fact that, though she may not hv had democracies in themodern sense, government by discussion was by no means unknown in herancient civilization.

## COUNCILLORS AND OFFICIALS
“A single wheel cannot turn”, says Arthaśātra, rather inaccurately,“and so government is only possible with assistance. Therefore kingshould appoint councillors and listen to their advice.”28 At head ofaffairs was small body of elder statesmen, whom king was advised tochoose with utmost care. size of this privy council ( mantri-parisad)varied, and authorities suggest figures ranging from seven to thirty-seven; we hv little evidence of its size in practice, but it seems more oftento hv approached smaller of these figures than larger.

The council was not cabinet in modern sense, but an advisory body,with few corporate functions. Thus king is in one place advised to layhis most secret plans before only one member of council, to avoidleakage. council’s purpose was primarily to [Page 99] advise and aidthe king, and not to govern; but it was no mere rubberstamping body, for allauthorities stress that councillors should speak freely and openly, and thatthe king should give full consideration to their advice.

In fact council often exerted great powers. It might transact business in king’s absence, and Aśokan inscriptions show that it might make minor decisions without consulting him. gaka satrap Rudradāman (p.  62) referred question of rebuilding Girnar dam to his councillors, who advised against it, so that he was forced to undertake work against their advice, apparently at expense of privy purse and not of publicfunds. Kashmīr Chronicle gives one case of privy council deposingthe king, and another of its vetoing king’s nomination of his successor.At its meetings council took strictest precautions to preservesecrecy of deliberations, for agents of king’s enemies at home or abroadwere constantly in search of information. texts advise that women,notoriously unreliable, and even talking birds such as parrots and mynahs,whose vocal powers were much overestimated in ancient India, should beexcluded from vicinity of council chamber. Though Arthaśāstra advises king to appoint ministers by meritalone it would seem that in later times most of privy councillors, andindeed of whole civil service of kingdom, enjoyed their positions byvirtue of inheritance. Candella inscriptions show that line of fivegenerations of councillors held office during reigns of seven generationsof kings, and there r many similar examples.Sometimes minister succeeded in obtaining complete control of akingdom, and king became mere puppet. This tendency wasexemplified in later times in Marāthā state, where descendants ofŚivājī were completely eclipsed by Peshwās, or hereditary ministers,and similar state of affairs has prevailed in Nepāl until present day. Inancient India there were many cases of ministerial usurpation and ofministers who became de facto rulers under weak kings. aged RāmaRāja of Vijayanagara (p. 77), who lost battle of Tālikota, and thusbrought about end of last great empire of Hindu India, was not thelegal king, but hereditary minister of insignificant Sadasiva, whowas later murdered by Rama Rajā’s brother.

The functions of councillors were not always sharply defined or delimited, and terminology varied considerably. There seems usually to hv been chief counsellor, mantrin par excellence, often called “great counsellor” ( mahāmantrin). With orthodox [Page 100] kings purohita or court chaplain was very influential, and one source even suggests that before coming to final decision king should deliberate privately with him.29 treasurer and chief taxcollector (called in ArthaśāstrasannidhātR and samāhartR respectively), were important, as was the“minister of peace and war” ( sāndhivigrahika), title which does notappear until Gupta times. This minister approximated to foreignsecretary of modern state, but had more definite military functions andoften accompanied king on campaign. prāDivāka, or chief judgeand legal advisor, seems to hv been important in medieval Hindukingdoms, and senāpati, or general, was always influential, while themahāk apa alika, or chief record keeper and secretary no doubt attendedthe council meetings.

In theory neither king nor his council were legislative bodies in modern sense of term. royal decrees ( Śāsana) which they promulgated were not generally new laws, but orders referring to specialcases. Dharma and established custom were usually looked on as inviolable,and king’s commands were merely applications of Sacred Law.Heterodox kings, however, did from time to time issue orders which were inthe nature of new laws, most notable case being AŚoka.To transmit royal decrees corps of secretaries and clerks wasmaintained, and remarkable precautions were taken to prevent error. Underthe Cō as, for instance, orders were first written by scribes at king’sdictation, and accuracy of drafts was attested by competentwitnesses. Before being sent to their recipients they were carefullytranscribed, and number of witnesses, sometimes amounting to as many asthirteen, again attested them. In case of grants of land and privileges animportant court official was generally deputed to ensure that royaldecrees were put into effect. Thus records were kept with great care, andnothing was left to chance; royal scribes themselves were oftenimportant personages.Councillors and high officials in general r often referred to in earlysources as mahāmātras, and from Gupta times onwards as kumārāmātyas,or “princely ministers”; latter epithet seems to hv been title ofhonour. There was no high degree of specialization, and councillors, likemodern cabinet ministers, often changed their posts. All of them, even agedministers of brahman class, might perform military functions. In somesources they r divided into two groups-deliberative officials ( matisacivaor dhīsaciva), and executive officials ( karmasaciva). former werecouncillors, while latter approximately corresponded to high-rankingcivil servants of modern times.

PLATE XXIV
[Page 101] Of seven occupational classes into which Megasthenes divided all inhabitants of India, two were connected with government; last of seven, “those who deliberate on public affairs”, must represent councillors, while penultimate class of “overseers” r adhyak as or superintendents of Arthaśāstra. As well as most of
the officials we hv mentioned this text enumerates many others-the superintendents of crown lands, of forests of forest-produce, of state herds, of waste lands, of treasury, and of mines, chief goldsmith, comptroller of state granaries, superintendent of commerce, of tolls and customs, of state spinning and weaving workshops, of slaughter houses, of passports, and of shipping. Military requirements were cared for by superintendents of armoury, of cavalry, of elephants, of chariots, and of footmen, all of whom seem to hv been rather civil than military officials, as far as it is possible to draw dividing line between dm in ancient India.The less reputable amusements of populace were controlled by thesuperintendents of liquor, of gaming, and of prostitutes. Asoka inaugurateda further class of official called dharma-mahāmātra, or minister ofRighteousness, whose duty was to supervise affairs of all religiousbodies, and to ensure that officials followed Emperor’s new policy;this class of official existed under different titles in some later empires, asdid officers who administered great royal donations to religiousestablishments.

Thus in Mauryan times every aspect of life of individual was watched over, and as far as possible controlled, by government. Though no later state developed same degree of control as Mauryas, ideal of Arthaśāstra did not wholly disappear. Not only did government regulate economic life of country, but it also took an important part in it. All mines, which term included, for ancient Indian,pearl fisheries and salt pans, were owned by state, and were eitherworked directly with labour of criminals or serfs, or let out toentrepreneurs, from whom king claimed percentage of their output asroyalty. produce of forests, from elephants to firewood, was theproperty of state. There were large state farms, cultivated either bydirect labour or on share-cropping basis, products of which went to thestate granaries. state owned manufactories for spinning and weaving,which were staffed by indigent women, rather like houses of industryunder Elizabethan poor-law. Munitions of war were made in statearsenals, and ships were built in state shipyards, to be let out to fishermenand merchants. In fact there was no question of laissez-faire in ancientIndia.[Page 102] This highly organized bureaucracy was much tied up with“red tape”. Arthaśāstra 30 suggests that departments should be headedby more than one chief, to prevent excessive peculation, and to ensure thatno one individual grew too powerful; text adds that officials should betransferred frequently and states that no government servant should beallowed to take any decision without reference to his superior, except inemergency.The Arthaśāstra envisages payment of many officials of statein cash, and gives lengthy tariff of salaries. 31 This is very obscure,however, since bare figures r quoted, without specifying type of coinor period of payment. period was probably month, and coinswere pa as, but these might be either silver or copper. Whatever they were,the list makes it clear that crown servant of ancient India, like Indiancivil servant of modern times, enjoyed standard of life much above that ofhis less fortunate fellows. chief councillor, purohita, heirapparent, chief queen, queen-mother, king’s preceptor, and thechief sacrificial priest of palace received 48,000 pa as monthly, while atthe lower end of scale even palace workmen, attendants, andbodyguards received sixty. In contrast to these labourer on crownlands received only one and quarter pa and provisions.32 last figureis so low that we cannot but believe that coin referred to by theArthaśāstra was silver one, otherwise single copper cooking pot wouldcost more than labourer’s annual wage.

These data apply to Mauryan epoch, or to period immediately following it. Later it became usual for kings to reward their officers by grants of revenue of village or district, system not unknown even in earlier times, and which, as we hv seen, helped in development of quasi-feudal system of medieval India.

## LOCAL ADMINISTRATION
The ancient Indian kingdom was divided into provinces and these into divisions and districts, all with very variable terminology. In Maurya and Gupta periods provincial governor was appointed directly by king, and was usually member of royal family. In later times his status was often hereditary and he approximated to vassal king. We cn see thedevelopment of this in series of inscriptions from Western Bengal, issuedby governors of Gupta emperors in 5th and 6th centuries A.D. 33Here we read of three successive generations of governors, of whom thefirst, Ciratadatta, is merely an uparika, viceroy; with [Page 103]decline of central administration under Budha Gupta his successors callthemselves uparika-mahārāja, and r well on way to becoming kings,holding office by birth rather than by appointment. Numerous independentdynasties did in fact arise through provincial governors growing too strongfor their masters.

District governors were not usually appointed from centre, but by provincial governors. Like District Officers of Indian Civil Service, they combined judicial and administrative functions. At this level, in some parts of India at least, government was assisted by council, for from Gupta inscriptions already mentioned we find that decisions of district officer were made after consultation with body of leadingresidents which included chief banker, chief caravan leader, thechief craftsman, and chief scribe. These members of council were nodoubt heads of guilds or castes, and probably held office by hereditary right.In Peninsula, especially under Cō as, similar district councilsexisted, and had even wider powers, levying local taxes and exercisingjudicial functions with concurrence of representative of centralgovernment.Cities too had their councils. Megasthenes’ description of thegovernment of Pā aliputra by committee of thirty members divided intosix sub-committees is not exactly confirmed elsewhere, and some doubtshave been cast on his accuracy. But some cities issued their own coinage,and must therefore hv had considerable local autonomy. Councils existedin small towns and large villages in various parts of India, especially Cōa country, where they were very vigorous.In general most important element in city administration was thegovernor ( nāgaraka, purapāla). His chief responsibilities were revenuecollection, and preservation of law and order by means of police, secretagents and troops, which were stationed in chief towns under captain( da anāyaka), who might be governor himself. watchmen orpolice were sometimes fierce and oppressive, and amongst privilegesgiven to brāhman villages by benevolent kings immunity from entry bypolice was one of most valued.

The system of government envisaged by Arthaśāstra involved careful check on movements and activities of all inhabitants of city through petty officials called gopa, probably often working in part- time capacity, who were responsible for collection of revenue, and supervision of forty households each. These men not only kept careful note of births, deaths, income and expenditure in families under their charge, but even of visitors they received and of any importantdevelopments in [Page 104] households. information obtained bythe gopa was passed on to town office and permanently recorded, andsimilar records were kept in villages. We cannot be sure that systemadvocated by Arthaśāstra was ever wholly put into effect, butMegasthenes confirms that registers were maintained and movements ofstrangers carefully supervised. It would seem, in fact, that conditions in thelarger Mauryan cities approximated to those of modern police state, withthe open supervision of gopas supplemented by vigorous secretservice.

The city governor had other, more positive duties. He was responsible for cleanliness of streets and prevention of fire. His duties also involved prevention or alleviation of such disasters as famine, flood andplague. Thus last record we hv of Girnar dam tells how it burst,and was reconstructed by local city governor, Cakrapālita, in 455,during reign of Skanda Gupta. 34 Cakrapālita, son of provincialgovernor Parnadatta, is praised in inscription commemorating therebuilding of dam in terms which r evidently formal panegyric, butcertain passages r quite unexpected, and depict city governor as apopular figure on most friendly terms with citizens. In any case,these verses show us ideal set before local official in Gupta times,and r therefore very significant.

“He caused distress to no man in city, but he chastised wicked.

Even in this mean age he did not fail trust of people.

He cherished citizens as his own children and he put down crime.

He delighted inhabitants with gifts and honours and smiling
conversation,
and he increased their love with informal visits and friendly
receptions.”


## VILLAGE ADMINISTRATION
At all times village was unit of government. In South, andoccasionally in North, districts were classified acc to numberof villages they were supposed to contain, for instance Gangāvādi96,000 or Nidgundige 12. number of villages supposed to exist inthe larger units is evidently exaggerated, but it must be remembered thatalmost any settlement, even tiny group of huts in jungle clearing,qualified for name of grāma; but grāma might also contain as many as1,000 families, and there was no clear dividing-line between village and atown.

PLATE XXVI
[Page 105] From pre-Mauryan times collectors were appointed over groups of villages, and in villages themselves two elements, which survive to present day, represented last link in chain of governmental control. These were village headman and village council.The headman’s was normally hereditary position, though he wasfrequently looked on as king’s representative, to be replaced at hispleasure. He was usually one of wealthier peasants, and wasremunerated with tax-free land, dues in kind, or both. In larger villageshe was very important functionary, with small staff of village officials,such as an accountant, watchman and toll-collector. These offices toowere often passed from father to son, and were remunerated in sameway as that of headman.

In some sources headman seems an oppressive local tyrant. gāmabhojaka, who appears in numerous Pāli Jātaka stories, is not so much representative of his people and one of their number as squire, withwide powers over villagers, fining dm for minor offences andexpelling dm for serious ones. In more than one passage in this source weread of villagers appealing to king for protection against wickedheadmen. Usually, however, headman appears rather as champion ofthe villagers. He was responsible for defence of village, and in theSouth, where village council received greater recognition, this was hismost important function. Villages were liable to raids from neighbouringkingdoms, or by wild tribesmen of hill and jungle. In less settled timesbandits roamed country in large gangs, and Āryans and Dravidians alikehad very ancient tradition of cattle-raiding. When central governmentwas weak, village feuds and cattle-raids might lead to pitched battles. Allover Deccan r to be found “hero-stones” ( vīragal) recording deathof village warrior, often headman, “while defending cattle”. Thepseudo-Śukra, writing in late Middle Ages, speaks of headman asthe mother and father of village, protecting it from robbers, from theking’s enemies, and from oppressions of king’s officers.35 By thistime headman seems often to hv been incorporated into quasi-feudal system. merchant Udayamāna (p. 95f), for instance, thoughdignified by title of rājā, was in fact little more than village headman.

The village council is rarely referred to in most sources, though it certainly existed all over India. In most kingdoms it was not recognized as part of state machine. One lawbook gives it brief mention, 36 and statesthat its powers derive from king, but [Page 106] this is certainly falseinterpretation. There is no evidence that rights of village councilever depended on delegation of royal power. It was independent of thegovernment and continued to function, whatever dynasty was ruling thedistrict. Southern kings, however, seem increasingly to hv given itrecognition, and hence in Cō empire it played an important part inadministration.

We hv no record of composition of village council in North,where in later times it traditionally consisted of five of most respectedvillagers, including headman. Southern councils had constitutionsthat differed acc to local custom. In some villages of WesternDeccan all householders attended village meeting, although they mayhave had chiefs who formed an inner council. Elsewhere villages weregoverned by committees, often chosen by lot. At Uttaramērūr, in Cō akingdom, large village inhabited by brāhmans ( agrahāra), number ofinscriptions from 10th century onwards throw much light on localpolitics. village was divided into thirty wards or sections, each ofwhich had representative on council, chosen annually by lot. Thecouncil was divided into five sub-committees, first three of which wereresponsible for gardens and orchards, tanks and irrigation, and thesettlement of disputes respectively, while functions of last two areuncertain. Members were unpaid, and could be removed from office formisconduct. right to sit on council was limited by propertyqualification of house and small plot of land. Membership was confinedto men between ages of thirty-five and seventy, and those who hadserved for year were ineligible for reappointment for another three years.

The two latter features of Uttaramērūr constitution r also found inthe constitutions of other villages of which records hv survived. All seemto hv closed their councils both to youth and old age, and in some theminimum age was as high as forty. Most had checks on reappointmentof retiring members, no doubt to avoid corruption and to prevent anyindividual from growing too influential. In one case even close relatives ofa retiring member were debarred from membership for five years, and inanother retiring member could not be reappointed for ten years.

These Southern councils not only arbitrated disputes and managed socialaffairs outside jurisdiction of government, but were responsible forrevenue collection, assessing individual contributions and negotiating thevillage’s collective assessment with king’s representative. They hadvirtual ownership of village’s waste land, with right of sale, and theywere active in irrigation, road-building, and other public works. Theirtransactions, recorded on [Page 107] walls of village temples, show avigorous community life, and r permanent memorial to best side ofearly Indian politics.

## PUBLIC FINANCE
All ancient Indian authorities on statecraft stress importance of full treasury for successful government, and India had evolved regular system of taxation before Mauryan period. At all times basic tax was taxon land, usually called bhāga or “share”, which was fixed proportion ofthe crop. figure generally given in Smrti literature is one sixth, butMegasthenes gives it as one quarter, while Arthaśāstra suggests onequarter or even one third for fertile lands; there is some reason to believethat one quarter was proportion generally levied even in mild reignof Aśoka. tax was usually paid in kind, and Jātakas refer to theroyal officers measuring out grain on threshing floor for conveyance tothe king’s granary; but in middle ages, especially in South, manyvillages had commuted their land tax for regular annual cash payment.

Numerous exemptions and remissions were granted; thus land broughtnewly under plough was not taxed fully for five years, while taxmight be wholly or partially remitted in times of bad harvest. Remissionsmight also be given to village embarking on collective irrigation projector some other enterprise in public interest. Generally tax was leviedon gross yield, but sometimes an allowance was made to cover therequirements for consumption and seed until next harvest, and somemedieval Indian assessmentsseem to hv been levied on net yield only.According to Sacred Law women, children, students, learnedbrahmans and ascetics should not be taxed in any form, and many grants oftax-free land were made to brāhmans and temples; but in practice evenreligious establishments often paid tax, though at lower rate than theordinary peasant. At other extreme, classes which society in generaldisliked often had to pay extra taxes, especially in South; these includedthose who followed objectionable trades, such as leather workers, andfollowers of heterodox faiths, such as Muslims and Ājīvikas (p. 294ff).

As well as basic land tax several other taxes fell upon cultivator, such as fixed annual cash payments, and dues for use of water from tank or canal owned by king. Taxes were paid on cattle and other livestock, and on all kinds of agricultural and dairy produce. Peasants in South India often paid house taxes, and taxes were also levied on shops and necessary industrial equipment such [Page 108] as looms, potters’ wheels and oil presses. Many of these lesser taxes were perquisites of local council, and were devoted to needs of village.

According to Arthaśāstra merchants travelling from place to place paid small road tolls which were collected by an officer called antapāla, who was responsible for upkeep of road and its safety. If we r to believe text these taxes formed sort of insurance, for antapala wasexpected to make good any loss suffered by merchants from thieves. Itis doubtful whether this system was regularly adopted in later times, whenkingdoms were less well organized, but something like it must haveprevailed in Mauryan period. Tolls were also levied at city gates onincoming merchandise, on varying ad valorem tariff. Arthaśāstrasuggests that essential goods such as grain, oil, sugar, pots and cheaptextiles should be taxed at one-twentieth of their value, and other goods atrates varying from one fifteenth to one fifth. Various market dues were alsolevied, but ten per cent sales tax recorded by Megasthenes is nowherementioned in an Indian source.All craftsmen were expected to devote one or two days’ work per monthto king, but this tax was probably often commuted to sort of incometax on average daily earnings. There was also liability to forced labour ( vii), though this does not seem always to hv fallen very heavily upon themasses. Services in labour and gifts of provisions were expected by kingand his officers when on tour, and this might put small rural communitiesinto serious difficulties (p. 95). Such obligations of forced labour andservice prevailed in some Indian states until very recent times.

So complex system of taxation could not be maintained without surveying and accountancy. Jātaka stories refer to local officers as “holders of [surveyor’s] cord” ( rajjugāhaka), and officers called in Aśokan inscriptions rajjūka may hv been same; Megasthenesrecords that land was thoroughly surveyed. Land was only transferred toa new owner after reference to local land records, and this fact, with thename of record keepers who had certified its transferability, was oftennoted in copper-plate title deeds. better organized kingdomsevidently kept full and up-todate records of land ownership correspondingto English Domesday Book. Unfortunately they were written onperishable materials, and all hv long since vanished.Taxation was burdensome, especially in times of bad harvest or underrapacious kings. There r numerous references in Jātaka stories to theharsh exactions of local officers, and to peasants emigrating en masse fromtheir villages to escape crushing taxation. In [Page 109] later South Indianinscriptions we read of something like rentstrikes of later times, and of awhole village council being imprisoned for failure to pay tax. Oneinscription records an appeal to Cō emperor Rājarāja I, in protestagainst looting of village in punishment of tax default; in this case theking upheld action of his local officers. defaulting taxpayer was liableto eviction, though he might be given year’s grace or more in case of real need.

The textbooks on statecraft invariably stress danger of unduly heavy taxation. Nobody cn hold honey in his mouth without tasting some of it, and it is to be expected that local officers will claim more tax than their due,but really extortionate collectors r great danger to king’s safety.Certain admirable general principles r laid down in our sources-taxationshould never act as check on trade and industry; king should tax as abee sucks honey, without hurting flower; taxes should be fixed so asalways to allow profit to taxpayer; articles of commerce should not betaxed more than once; increases in taxation should not be imposed withoutdue warning. No doubt better monarchs tried to maintain theseprinciples in their fiscal policy.

Taxation was theoretically justified as return for protection granted by king. In story of primeval king, Manu (p. 86), it is said that when Brahmā first appointed him he demurred, fearing that he would be responsible for sins of people; but people were so direly in need of government that they promised that their sins would be upon their own heads, and undertook to give Manu share of their crops and herds if he would protect them. Buddhist story of first king (p. 82) records similar promise as part of contract. Generally it is stated that king is only entitled to tax his people if he protects them, and that he obtains in addition share of religious merit acquired by them, especially by his brāhman subjects; if he fails in his duty he has no moral right to receive tax, and reaps share of all demerit accruing to his subjects.

On other hand more than one source speaks of king as ownerof all land and water in his kingdom; corollary of this propositionwould be that tax on crops and other products of earth was sortof rent in return for tenancy. That this idea, as well as doctrine oftaxation in return for protection, underlay ancient Indian practice, is evidentfrom fact that king had right to evict defaulting peasants, that heclaimed reversion of property of those dying without heirs, that he sometimes demanded fee comparable to medieval European heriotbefore holding was transferred to heirs of dead householder, and that[Page 110] he was owner of treasure trove. Manu speaks of king asultimate lord ( adhipati) of land,37 and therefore entitled to his share oftreasure and minerals. Bha asvāmin, medieval commentator on theArthaśāstra, declares bluntly that king is lord of land and water, but thatother things r property of individual householders. 38 His statement isborne out by several other sources, and by record of Megasthenes. Morethan one legend tells of kings giving away or trying to give away theirkingdoms, as though they were personal property.

A few sources, however, reject idea of king’s ultimate ownership of land. Thus in Jataka story king tells his mistress that he cannot give her his kingdom, for he is not its owner. When legendary king, Viśvakarman Bhauvana, gave land to priests, goddess of earth rose up in person and rebuked him, saying that he had no right to give her away.  medieval commentator, probably basing his statement on this old story, says that kings cannot give away land, because it is owned in common.39 16th century jurist Nīlakantha states that land is property of its owner, and kings hv only right to tax it; he adds that gift of landdoes not imply gift of soil itself, but only of right to make use ofit. 40The attempts of some scholars to prove that idea of royalownership of land never existed in ancient India seems to hv sprung fromthe implicit presupposition, perhaps derived from laissez-faire socialphilosophy of Herbert Spencer, that there was something primitive andshameful in such conception. It is noteworthy that those authorities whodenied royal ownership most forcibly were also those who overstressed thedemocratic element in ancient Indian way of life. Such patriotic scholars

as Dr. K. P. Jāyaswāl, writing when India’s independence had not been achieved, did much to give her people faith in themselves, and therefore may hv served practical purpose. Now, with free India, there cn be no excuse for attempting to force interpretation of texts whose meaning is perfectly obvious, in order to try to prove that king laid no claim to ownership of land and water of his domains. On this question, as on many others, ancient Indian opinion differed, 41 but our sources show that majority of thinkers on subject favoured doctrine of royal ownership.

Whatever theory, we may assume that in practice royal ownership weighed lightly on peasant who paid his taxes regularly; but Arthaśāstra suggests that not only tax defaulters but also peasants who failed to cultivate their holdings efficiently should be evicted, though we hv no evidence that this was regularly done.

[Page 111] system which we hv outlined was followed with many variations in normal times throughout pre-Muslim India; but in emergencies whips might be changed for scorpions. acc to theorists king in serious financial straits was justified in adopting most drastic and oppressive measures, rather than lose his throne. He might raise taxes indefinitely, levy forced loans and benevolences from wealthy people, resume grants and immunities promised in perpetuity, confiscate hoarded wealth of goldsmiths and even rob religious establishments, especially those of heterodox sects. There is good evidence from Kashmīr chronicle and elsewhere that kings did sometimes go to these extreme lengths. In fairness, however, it must be pointed out that theorists give as justifiable motives for such extortion not only danger from external and internal enemies, but hunger of poor through famine, flood or plague.

We know much about income of Indian king, but comparatively little about his expenditure. Much of income of state was stored, and wealth of even small kingdoms is attested by foreign travellers and by records of booty obtained by Muslim invaders. late textbook on polity ascribed to Śukra states that total annual income of an emperor might amount to 500 m. kar as, by which term author probably means silver coins of about weight of modern rupee, but with much greater purchasing power. Of this considerable income Śukra advises king to reserve one sixth in his treasury.42 acc to accepted theory well- stocked treasury was king’s chief source of strength, and no kingdom could function properly without it. effect of this doctrine was certainly bad. great reserves of precious metals and jewels, never touched except in direst emergency, were economically useless, and treasury of king was inevitably target of greed of his neighbours. royal treasures, existence of which was reported by early Muslim travellers, were important factors in encouraging invasions which ultimately destroyed Hindu India.

After storing one sixth of his income in his treasury king was advised by Śukra to allot one half to what is nowadays called defence —a euphemism which many Indian kings would hv scorned. This proportion of expenditure on military needs probably does not compare unfavourably with that of many modern states. One twelfth of revenue was for king’s personal use, and one twelfth for charity, chiefly no doubt to religious causes. further twelfth was devoted to payment of civil servants, and last twelfth to prak taya. This term is very ambiguous in many contexts, since it [Page 112] may mean either ministers or subjects. In former case it would overlap somewhat with previous head of expenditure, and it may be that Śukra intended it to apply to works of public value, such as building of roads, canals and tanks, which were certainly undertaken by many Indian kings, and which would not otherwise be covered by any head in list.


LEGAL LITERATURE
With passage of time sacrificial instructions of Brāhmanas became obscure, and new group of texts was composed to elucidate them.

These were Śrauta Sūtras: term sūtra literally means “thread”, but was used with secondary meaning of manual of instruction in form of brief aphorisms; whole title may be translated “Manuals Explaining Scriptures”. little later G hya Sūtras were composed on domestic religious ceremonies, and finally manuals of human conduct, Dharma Sūtras. set of three sūitras, one on each of these topics, and attributed to same legendary sage, was called Kalpa Sūtra. Dharma Sūtras r our earliest sources for Hindu law, most important being those attributed to Gautama, Baudhāyana, Vasi ha and Āpastamba. They were probably mainly composed between 6th and 2nd centuries B.C., but in some respects they look back to earlier times, while they contain later interpolations. first three seem to hv been written in more westerly part of India than early Buddhist scriptures, with which they r approximately contemporary, and Āpastamba may hv been composed in Northern Deccan.  Later, from early centuries of Christian era onwards, prose sūtras, including several now lost to us, were expanded and remodelled in verse form. These r Dharma Śāstras (“Instructions in Sacred Law”). latter term is sometimes used for Dharma Sūstras also, but most modern authorities reserve it for longer versified texts of later days. There r numerous Dharma Sastras, earliest of which is that of Manu, probably composed in its final form in 2nd or 3rd century A.D.  Other important Dharma Sastras after Manu r those of Yājñavalkya, Vi u and Nārada, which date from Gupta period and Middle Ages, and there r numerous others of less importance, or preserved in fragmentary form. Manu is still largely concerned with human conduct generally, but works of his successors approach more and more closely to purely legal textbooks.  Sūtras and Śāstras taken together r known as Smrti (“remembered”), as distinct from earlier Vedic literature, which [Page 113] is Śruti (“heard”), and which was believed to hv been directly revealed to its authors, and therefore of greater sanctity than later texts.  Thus Mānava Dharma Śāstra, or lawbook of Manu, is often known as Manu-Smrti. Epics and Puranas were also looked on as Smrti, and contain much legal lore. In fact hundreds of verses in Manu r also to be found in Mahābhārata, and were probably not plagiarized, but inherited from common source.  Many medieval jurists wrote lengthy commentaries on Smrti literature. Of these most important was Vijñāneśvara, who wrote at court of great Cālukya emperor, Vikramāditya VI (c. 1075–1127). His Mitāk arā, commentary on lawbook of Yājñavalkya, played very important part in forming civil law of modern India. Other important jurists of middle ages were Hemadri (c. 1300), and Jāmūtavāhana (12th century), whose treatise on inheritance ( Dāyabhāga), part of great compilation called Dharmaratna, has also influenced law of modern India.  It cannot be too strongly stressed that whole Smrti literature is work of brāhmans, who wrote from their own point of view. Arthaśāstra, written from more secular angle, differs from Smrtis in many particulars. It is certain that advice of Sm tis was not regularly followed in many ancient kingdoms, though it became increasingly authoritative with time. statements of Smrtis must as far as possible be checked by comparison with Arthaśāstra and by passing references to law and custom in general literature, inscriptions, and writings of foreign travellers.

THE BASIS OF LAW
Though we know very little about legal system of Ṛg Vedic period it is clear that idea of divine cosmic order already existed. ta, regularity of universal process, was perhaps forerunner of later concept of Dharma. latter word, etymologically akin to English word “form”, is untranslatable, and had many meanings. In Aśokan inscriptions and some other Buddhist sources it seems to hv broad general meaning of “righteousness”; but in legal literature it may perhaps be defined as divinely ordained norm of good conduct, varying acc to class and caste. In this context we translate it as “Sacred Law”.

As well as Dharma there are, acc to textbooks, other bases of law: contract, custom and royal ordinance. earlier religious lawbooks give little attention to these, but their importance increases with time. It was recognized that, owing to decadence of age, Dharma was not now known in its fullness and purity and [Page 114] therefore supplementary sources of law were needed. Generally Dharma was thought to override all other bases of law, but Arthaśāstra and one other lawbook43 maintain that royal ordinance overrides others, doctrine which we must ascribe to totalitarianism of Mauryas, and which few jurists would hv supported.

The king’s duty of protection was chiefly protection of Dharma, and as protector of Dharma he was Dharma incarnate. From Asoka onwards kings sometimes assumed title Dharmarāja, which was also one of names of Yama, god of death and departed. Both Yama and king maintained Sacred Law by punishing evil-doers and rewarding righteous.  Another concept, much in evidence in some sources, was that of Da a.  primary meaning of this word is “a stick”, from which its secondary meanings may be easily inferred. In varying contexts it may be translated as “military force”, “coercion”, “punishment”, “a fine”, or simply “justice”.  Human nature was evil and corrupt. In benighted age in which most ancient Indian writers on law and morals believed themselves to be living mankind could only be disciplined to observe Sacred Law by fear of punishment. In stern words of Manu: “If king did not inflict punishment untiringly on evil-doers stronger would roast weaker, like fish upon spit….  “The whole world is controlled by punishment, for guiltless man is hard to find….  “Where dark and red-eyed Punishment walks land, destroying sinners, people r not harassed, if he who inflicts it is discerning.” 44 king’s responsibility for maintaining Dharma by means of Danda was not taken lightly. Impartial administration of justice brought him same spiritual reward as Vedic sacrifices. Kings failing in their duty suffered in Hell. Even delay in justice was visited with dire penalties, for legendary king called Nrga was reborn as lizard, because he kept two litigants waiting in dispute over cow. Some sources declared that it was incumbent upon king to restore full value of stolen articles to plaintiff, if thief could not be brought to justice. Moreover, king was [Page 115] believed to incur demerit of criminals not brought to book, and to suffer in next life accordingly, while from secular point of view king who perverted justice or was negligent in its administration was in danger of losing his throne.


CRIME
Megasthenes speaks of Indians as remarkably law-abiding, and states that crime was very rare; similar evidence is given by Fa-hsien and by medieval Arab travellers, though Hsüan Tsang gives somewhat less favourable picture. impressions of foreign travellers r not wholly confirmed by Indian sources, however, and profound sense of insecurity of life and property underlies much of legal literature.  In earlier part of period with which we deal, process was going on in some ways comparable to that which is now taking place in parts of Africa. Uncivilized or semi-civilized tribes were breaking up under pressure of Āryan Culture; even as early as Mauryan times villages were often overpopulated; many poor folk from country and hills drifted to towns, as they r doing at present day, and found life even more difficult than in their old surroundings. Some of these unfortunate and uprooted people provided submerged tenth of habitual criminals which seems to hv existed in all ancient Indian cities. In order to suppress crime Arthaśāstra advises imposition of stringent curfew from about two and half hours after sunset to same time before dawn. Later sources speak of castes of professional thieves who had developed stealing to fine art, and who made use of written manuals on their profession.  Crime was equally rampant in countryside, where existence of large robber bands is attested from time of Buddha onwards. Hsüan Tsang gives earliest account of hereditary bandits who robbed their victims and murdered dm as religious duty, like later thugs. Trading caravans were heavily guarded, but were nevertheless frequently plundered by highwaymen. Thus ancient India was faced with very serious crime problem, though evidence of most of foreign travellers suggests that best ancient Indian kings managed to cope with it. Crime was suppressed through local officers and garrison commanders, who had large staffs of police and soldiers, as well as secret agents who served as detectives. Watchmen kept guard through night in city and village, and in some medieval kingdoms special officers ( duhsādhasādhanika) were deputed to track down and apprehend bandits.



ADMINISTRATION OF JUSTICE
[Page 116]
In small kingdoms to which early Dharma Sūtras refer king might be sole source of justice and indeed his own executioner, striking down condemned thieves with his mace; but in general administration of justice was delegated, king’s court being reserved for appeals and serious crime against state. In medieval kingdoms, councillor called Prādvivaka, king’s chief legal adviser, seems to hv been responsible for justice and might also himself act as judge.

The composition of courts varied with time and place, but evidence indicates that ancient India preferred bench of magistrates to single judge. Jātaka story tells of bench of five magistrates, all of whom, incidentally, r corrupt, while Arthaśāstra advises that court with bench of three magistrates be set up for every ten villages, with higher courts in districts and provinces. Manu suggests bench consisting of Pradvivaka and three lesser judges, while drama called “The Little Clay Cart” (p. 441) contains scene in court of justice, presided over by chief judge, here called adhikara ika, wealthy merchant ( śre hin), and representative of caste of scribes ( kāyastha). title given to chief judge is derived from adhikarana, “a government office”, and suggests that he was an official who combined judicial and administrative functions; two other magistrates were evidently leading citizens, who served on bench as do our justices of peace.  Though judicial corruption is often referred to, standards set for judges and magistrates were very high; they were to be learned, religious, devoid of anger, and as impartial as humanly possible. To prevent bribery it is suggested that no private interviews should be allowed between judges and litigants until cases r settled. Arthaśāstra advises that honesty of judges should be periodically tested by agents provocateurs, while Vi u Smrti prescribes banishment and forfeiture of all property for judge found guilty of corruption or injustice—the most severe penalty brāhman
could incur under Sacred Law.

False witness was generally looked on with great abhorrence, and, besides various temporal penalties, incurred hundred unhappy rebirths in afterworld. In serious criminal cases evidence might be accepted from all sources, but in civil law only certain witnesses were qualified; generally women, learned brahmans, government servants, minors, debtors, persons with criminal records, and persons suffering from physical defects could not be called on to give evidence, while evidence of low-caste people was not valid against persons [Page 117] of higher caste. Several tests, some very sound psychologically, r laid down to assess veracity of witnesses.  Where accused was open to grave suspicion not amounting to certainty he might be tortured to elicit confession. tortures enumerated for this purpose r not all of most extreme type, and include various forms of whipping. Brahmans, children, aged, sick, lunatics and pregnant women were theoretically exempt from torture, while only light torture was prescribed for women.  Another means of ascertaining guilt was ordeal, which could be used in both civil and criminal cases, and in certain forms is still sometimes resorted to in India to settle disputes out of court. Ordeal is but little mentioned in early texts, but seems to hv grown more popular in later times. Smrti writers apparently distrusted ordeals, and generally limited their application to cases in which there was no concrete evidence on either side. Several ordeals r mentioned, however, including ordeals by fire and immersion similar to those known in medieval Europe, and possibly having common Indo-European origin in remote past. Specially interesting is ordeal of ploughshare, in which accused man had to touch red- hot iron ploughshare with his tongue; if it was not burned he was deemed innocent-psychologically fairly sound test of his own confidence in result, since if he had guilty conscience his salivary glands would not function properly, and his tongue would be burnt.  Megasthenes remarked that Indian was not inclined to litigation, and he may hv been correct, though same could not be said of India of more recent times. In any case, though there were many brāhmans learned in law they never constituted class of professional pleaders, and those who did not serve on bench presumably used their knowledge to settle cases out of court. There is evidence, however, that by end of our period class of lawyers, in modern sense, was beginning to develop, for some late textbooks allow litigants to employ proxies, who r to be rewarded with share of money involved, while one source grants to any learned brahman right to give his views on case from body of court. 45

PUNISHMENT
The penalties imposed for criminal offences developed from two very ancient customs, wergeld and religious penance imposed for ritual offences. influence of both cn be clearly traced in system of punishment followed in later times. [Page 118] early Sūtras laid down fines for punishment of murder 1,000 cows for killing ksatriya, 100 for vaiśya, and 10 for śūdra or woman of any class; killing of brāhman could not be expiated by fine. cattle were handed to king, who passed dm on to relatives of slain man, bull being added as king’s perquisite. Later sources lose sight of true nature of fines as means of buying off vengeance of family of dead man, and lay down that cattle r expiatory gifts, to be given to brāhmans. But wergeld left its mark on legal system in form of fines, which, with or without other punishment, r special feature of ancient Indian justice. Fines ranging from small copper coin to confiscation of all property were levied, and could atone for all but most serious crime. They were an appreciable source of income to state, and many medieval charters, giving revenue rights over village or district, specifically include right to receive fines levied at local court. condemned person who could not pay his fine was reduced to bondage until it was paid by his labour. Smrti writers rarely mention imprisonment, but all other sources show that it was common. Aśoka was proud of many gaol-deliveries which he had ordered in course ofhis reign; acc to later tradition he is said to hv maintained in his unreformed early years prison in which most fiendish tortures were inflicted, and from which no prisoner came out alive.46 Hsüan Tsang mentions imprisonment as usual form of punishment under Harsa. Forced labour in state mines and elsewhere is mentioned as punishment in ArthasJstra, and no doubt amounted to imprisonment of very severe type. Mutilation and torture were common penalties for many crimes, and numerous forms r described by legal writers. Such punishments were often looked on rather as penances, and idea of religious penance was never completely absent from thought of pious authors of Smrtis, in considering punishment of crime. It was generally believed that by undergoing punishment in this life criminal escaped evil consequences of his crime in next. death penalty is laid down in many forms and for many crimes. Unlike early Sūras Arthaśāstra prescribes it for murder, even as result of duel or quarrel, if injured man dies within seven days. Hanging is penalty for spreading false rumours, housebreaking, and stealing king’s elephants and horses. Those who plot against king, force entry into king’s harem, aid his enemies, create disaffection in army, murder father, mother, son, brother or an ascetic, or commit serious arson, r to be burnt alive. Beheading is penalty laid down by Arthaśāstra for [Page 119] wilful murder or stealing herd of cattle. man who deliberately breaks dam is to be drowned in same dam. Women murdering their husbands or children, killing others by poison, or committing arson r to be torn apart by oxen. Civilians stealing military supplies r to be shot to death with arrows. These r some of many forms of execution suggested by Arthaśāstra. This text is comparatively lenient towards sexual crime, but Manu also prescribes death in various unpleasant forms for most types of adultery and sexual assault. Even benevolent Asoka, for all his distaste for taking of life, did not abolish death penalty (p. 55). usual form of execution, little mentioned in textbooks on law, but often referred to in general literature, was impalement. Nevertheless it is evident that some opinion definitely opposed death penalty, and question is considered from both sides in remarkable passage in Mahābhārata. 47 Here argument against capital punishment and heavy penalties in general is not based, as might be expected, on doctrine of non-violence, which in no way forbade either capital punishment or war, but rests wholly on humanitarian considerations. In most cases mutilation, long imprisonment and execution result in untold suffering for many innocent people, especially for wife and family of criminal. argument is quickly refuted-in this dark age innocent must suffer with guilty, in order that society may be protected, anarchy avoided, and men enabled to pursue Sacred Law in peace.
Humanitarian ideas, probably encouraged by Buddhism, were effective in Gupta times in moderating fierce punishment of earlier days. Fa-hsien records that death penalty was not imposed in Northern India, but most crime punished by fines, and only serious revolt by amputation of one hand. Chinese traveller may hv exaggerated, but his testimony at least suggests that executions were rare. Hsüan Tsang 200 years later, reported that prisoners were not executed under Har a, but were left to rot in dungeons. In later times there is good evidence that capital punishment was inflicted, and criminals often became victims of human sacrifice, but in medieval period we read of sentences which, even by modern standards, seem surprisingly mild. Thus Cō inscription records gift of 96 sheep to endow perpetual lamp in temple, donor being man who had stabbed an army officer to death; this was apparently only penalty he suffered. Other South Indian instances cn be found of murderers being let off with comparatively small penances of this nature. It would seem that here blood feud had by no means disappeared, and if murderer could appease enmity of his victim’s family court would let him off lightly. [Page 120] Killing in self-defence was justified in law, as was stealing of small quantities of food to stave off starvation. In later times lives of many animals were protected by law, especially that of cow. story of Cō king who ordered execution of his own son for accidental killing of calf is certainly legend, and we need not believe that Kumārapāla (c. 1143–1172), Jaina king of Caulukya dynasty of Gujarāt, so strictly enforced non-violence that heavy
fines were inflicted on people who killed fleas, but these stories show climate of opinion in medieval India. wanton killing of cow, in later period, was among most serious of crimes. legal system envisaged by Smrtis would impose graduated punishment acc to class. Thus brāhman slandering ksatriya should, acc to Manu, pay fine of fifty panas, but for slandering vaiśya or śūdra fines r only twenty-five and twelve pa as respectively. For members of lower orders who slander their betters penalties r much more severe. Similar gradations of penalty acc to class of offender r laid down for many crimes, and equality of all before law was never admitted in ancient India, and was quite contrary to most Indian thought. If samatā, which Aśoka instructed his officials to employ in their judicial dealings,48 means equality case is unique; it is probable that word implies no more than consistency, or perhaps mildness. It is hardly likely that even Aśoka was bold enough to introduce so drastic change in administration of justice-one which no other ancient lawgiver, Indian or otherwise, would hv agreed to. In later Vedic period some brāhmans claimed to be above law altogether. At proclamation of king at end of royal consecration ceremony chief officiating brahman turned to assembled multitude and cried “Here is your king, 0 Kurus-for us, our king is [the god] Soma”. At all times priestly class claimed many privileges in law. acc to most orthodox sources brāhmans were exempt from execution, torture, and corporal punishment, worst penalty that could be imposed on dm being humiliation of losing their topknot (p. 160), followed by confiscation of property and banishment. But Sm ti of Kātyāyana allows execution of brāhman for procuring abortion, murder of respectable woman, and theft of gold, while Arthaśāstra admits it for sedition, and also sanctions branding of brahmans. In “The Little Clay Cart” hero, though brāhman, is threatened with torture and sentenced to death, and there is much other evidence that brāhmans did not always obtain privileges which they claimed.
