PLATE XXVIII
[Page 121] In fairness to Hindu legal system, we must note that it did not always work in favour of brāhma . Manu lays down that as penalty for theft śūdra should pay fine equal to eight times value of stolen goods, while vaiśya, ksatriya and brāhman should pay sixteen, thirty-two, and sixty-four times value respectively. upper classes were expected to follow higher standards of conduct than lower, and their thefts were correspondingly more heinous.
As well as royal courts there were other tribunals which could arbitrate disputes and deal with minor crime. These were councils of villages, castes and guilds, whose validity as judicial bodies for their members was fully recognized in legal literature. They could punish offenders by fines and excommunication, latter very serious penalty indeed, and they probably played as important part in life of community as did king’s courts. Unfortunately we hv little knowledge of their procedure.


THE SECRET SERVICE
Perhaps least pleasant feature of political life in ancient India was espionage system. most detailed picture of working of this secret service is given in Arthaśāstra, author of which devotes two chapters to its organization, and refers to it throughout his treatise. text visualizes country riddled from top to bottom with secret agents or spies.  They were organized through “institutes of espionage” to which they delivered information, sometimes in cipher, and from which they received their orders. These institutes were not responsible for whole organization of espionage, however, for there were special spies, directly subordinate to king or high minister, and employed to spy on ministers themselves.  spies might be recruited from any walk of life, and might be of either sex. Brāhmans unable to make living by their learning, merchants fallen on evil days, barbers, astrologers, humble servitors, prostitutes, peasants-all might be enrolled as secret agents. special class of spy was satr, an orphan trained from childhood for work, and usually masquerading as holy-man or fortuneteller, two professions members of which were specially trusted by public and might gain access to information which others might find difficulty in obtaining. further class was that of desperado, recruited from professional prize-fighters, whose main duty was assassination of those enemies of king for whom public trial was not expedient, but who also performed other secret deeds of daring and violence on behalf of his master.  [Page 122] ancient Indian secret service has incurred much criticism, some of which is not wholly fair. Probably no government at any time has been able to function without secret agents of some sort, if only honest detectives for suppression of crime, and every ancient civilization had its spies, though perhaps not so thoroughly organized as in system of Arthaśāstra. ancient Indian spy system was not quite comparable to secret political police of some modern states, since its function was by no means confined to suppression of criticism and sedition, and it was looked on not as mere macchiavellian instrument for maintaining power, but as an integral part of state machinery.  Certainly one of spy’s chief duties was protecting king’s power.  He sought out sedition, whether in brothel or in palace of crown- prince. He served as agent provocateur, to test loyalty of high ministers, generals, and judges. In territory of enemies, whether potential or actual, he not only obtained information on strength and plans of enemy but encouraged sedition, and plotted assassination of enemy king and his ministers. He also acted as detective for suppression of crime. For this purpose he frequented taverns, brothels and gambling dens in disguise, listened to conversation of men in their cups, and carefully watched those who seemed abnormally affluent.  But he had also other duties of more positive character. He was an important means of keeping finger on pulse of public opinion. In the
story of Rama (p. 412f) it is spy who informs king that his subjects
suspect Sītā’s chastity. secret service, in fact, kept king in touch
with his people. It was also means of maintaining king’s popularity.

One of spy’s duties was to spread stories favourable to king, to praise him in public, and to argue with those who criticized administration. There is no reason to believe that mild criticism of king or his administration was normally punished. ancient Indian secret service might no doubt, in hands of an unjust king, be very evil thing, but under just administration it had positive and useful functions, and was not mere instrument of repression.

HINDU MILITARISM
The rule of law in personal, family and class relations was fundamental element of ancient Indian thought, but in sphere of international affairs there was no real conception of its possibility. few enlightened people recognized evil effects of warfare which afflicted Indian sub- continent during most of its history, but [Page 123] their message was generally unheard. Aśoka was possibly only ancient Indian king who finally broke with tradition of aggression, though his spirit cn perhaps be heard in certain passages in Buddhist texts, and many ordinary people must hv echoed his sentiments. Nevertheless, positive condemnations of war r rare in Indian literature. In one story Buddha himself is depicted as intervening in tribal war between Śakyas and their neighbours Koliyas, and persuading contestants to come to terms. In beautiful Dhammapada, an early collection of Buddhist verse, we read: Victory breeds hatred, for conquered sleep in sorrow; above victory or defeat calm man dwells in peace.49 Buddhism was specially popular with mercantile classes, who stood to lose much from constant warfare, and passing and rare references to evils of war in Buddhist texts may in part represent mild protest of vaiśyas against continual campaigning which interfered with their trading ventures. In any case war was generally accepted as normal activity of state, even by Buddhist kings. doctrine of non-violence, which in medieval India had become very influential, and had made most of respectable classes vegetarian, was never at this time taken to forbid war or capital punishment. It was only in modern times that Mahātmā Gāndhī reinterpreted it in this sense. intense militarism of ancient India did not lead to building of permanent empire over whole sub-continent. In this respect early history of India contrasts strikingly with that of China, where, from 3rd century B.C., single empire was rule, and division exception. In India Mauryas succeeded in creating unified empire for century, and in heyday of Guptas much of North India was under one hand, but with these exceptions numerous factors prevented unification of recognized cultural unit of Bhāratavar a, which so many ambitious monarchs desired. One of these factors was mere size of land, but Chinese emperors conquered equal difficulties. Another reason for failure of Indian empire builders was that, for all wise counsel of Arthasastra, no king of India was able to develop bureaucracy capable of functioning without strong guiding hand; in China examination system and ethics of Confucius ensured that those in charge of affairs would usually be men of character and intellect, [Page 124] if rather pedantic and conservative. But main factor which prevented unification of India was martial tradition itself.  For post-Mauryan king idea of empire was something very different from that to which West is accustomed. acc to Arthaśāstra there r three types of conquest: righteous conquest, conquest for greed, and demoniac conquest. * first is conquest in which defeated king is forced to render homage and tribute, after which he or member of his family is reinstated as vassal. second is victory in which enormous booty is demanded and large portions of enemy territory annexed. third involves political annihilation of conquered kingdom and its incorporation in that of victor. two latter types r generally disapproved of by all sources except Arthaśāstra. Thus Mahābhārata declares: “A king should not attempt to gain earth unrighteously, for who reveres king who wins unrighteous victory? Unrighteous conquest is impermanent, and does not lead to heaven.” 50 idea of “righteous conquest” or “conquest acc to Sacred Law” may hv developed among Āryans soon after their occupation of North India, as an expression of their solidarity against dark-skinned natives. It is evident, though not explicitly stated, in later Vedic literature. kings of Magadha, from Bimbisāra onwards, ignored it, and annexed territory without compunction; but doctrine that war should be waged for glory and homage rather than sordid aims such as wealth and power grew in importance with fall of Mauryas, and was accepted by medieval quasi-feudal order. “Demoniac conquest” still took place from time to time, notably under Guptas, but “righteous conquest” was ideal which Hindu kings were expected to follow, and it is evident that they usually did. War became sport of kingsa sport which was often very profitable and always very serious, in which shame of defeat might well only be expunged by suicide, but sport nevertheless. Peninsula, inheriting fierce Dravidian tradition never completely submerged by Āryan influence, had more realistic approach; here conquest with annexation was more common, as well as ruthlessness towards captives and non-combatants, but even South was not unaffected by ideal of “righteous conquest�.

PLATE XXX
[Page 125] In most of texts on statecraft we read of “six instruments of policy” ( ādgu ya): peace, war, waiting for enemy to strike first blow, attack, alliance, and “double policy” or making peace with one enemy and continuing war with another. * list is stock one, and gives further example of delight of Indian theorist in pedantic classification, but it is nevertheless significant. Peace is only one of six categories; others r aspects of war in all its branches. Arthaśāstra quotes an earlier authority, Vātavyādhi, as disagreeing with sixfold classification, and maintaining that statecraft involved only two aspects, peace and war.51 Of this view text strongly disapproves; pacific relations r straightforward and obvious, while war is complex and highly developed. It is significant that one of words commonly used for enemy, para, has simple primary meaning of “other”. At all times conquest was chief ambition of Indian king. Even Aśoka, who abjured aggressive war, did not give up hope of conquest (p. 54). position is succinctly put by Arthaśāstra: “The king who is weaker than ‘the other’ should keep peace; he who is stronger should make war.” 52 same aphorism is repeated in many other sources, in slightly varying forms, but difference of attitude is apparent as we leave Mauryan recollections of Arthaśāstra for later texts, outlook of which reflects memories of later Vedic age, adapted to often anarchic conditions of period between Mauryas and Guptas.  For earlier source war is “continuation of policy by other means”. Its purpose is not glory, but wealth and power, and passage we hv quoted, defining three types of conquest, is, we believe, either sop to conventional doctrine or later interpolation, for it is inconsistent with tenor of book. whole work is written for king who aspires to become an emperor on Mauryan model, and such king is not advised to embark on war lightly. There r many other ways of gaining power, intrigue and assassination among them, and these should always be resorted to in preference to war, which should only be looked on as last resort. If king suffers decisive defeat he must submit, in hope that he will be allowed to retain his throne as vassal and ultimately again achieve independence and conquer his former overlord. Arthaśāstra says nothing about fair play in battle, and evidently looks on conquest of demoniac variety as most profitable and advisable. Though in one passage, not in keeping with main tenor of work, it suggests allowing conquered king to remain as vassal, it ends on note [Page 126] of humanitarian imperialism. victor must do everything in his power to conciliate conquered people; if their economy has suffered badly from war, taxes must be remitted; ministers of defeated king must be won round, and law and order restored as quickly as possible; when in conquered country king should wear local dress and follow local customs. Evidently, from point of view of Arthaśāstra, main motive of war is gain and building up of great empire. more orthodox texts, however, take different point of view. Here major motive of war is glory, not gain. War is not merely means to an end, but part of warrior’s dharma, and good for its own sake. As soon as king has established himself on throne he should, as matter of course, attack his neighbours. Rules of fair fighting r laid down, which r not heard of in Arthaśāstra. For later sources, such as Manu, battle was ideally gigantic tournament with many rules: warrior fighting from chariot might not strike one on foot; an enemy in flight, wounded or asking quarter might not be slain; lives of enemy soldiers who had lost their weapons were to be respected; poisoned weapons were not to be used. Homage and not annexation was rightful fruit of victory. These rules were not always kept. heroes of Mahābhārata infringe dm many times, even at behest of their mentor Krsna, and infringements r explained and pardoned by recourse to casuistical arguments of expediency and necessity. rules of war could only be maintained strictly by king certain of victory or certain of defeat. Where chances were narrow claims of selfpreservation inevitably made themselves felt. But chivalrous rules of warfare, probably based on very old tradition, and codified in their present form among martial peoples of Western India in post-Mauryan times, must hv had some effect in mitigating harshness of war for combatant and non-combatant alike. It is doubtful if any other ancient civilization set such humane ideals of warfare. Together with these rules, later texts introduce conception of military honour, which is not found in realistic Arthaśāstra, except in form of propaganda to maintain morale of troops. Flight is deepest of shames; soldier slain in flight incurs guilt of his lord, and suffers proportionately in after-life, but soldier slain while fighting to last passes straight to heaven. Such ideals culminated in jauhar, final holocaust which was fate of many medieval Rājput king, with his family and bodyguard, women and children burning alive in inner chambers of fort while men fought to last on battlements. [Page 127] live dog was no longer thought to be better than dead lion, in so far as spirit of Epics permeated Hindu life. But Arthaśāstra was not wholly forgotten, and not every king of medieval India was willing to sacrifice himself and his family when defeat stared him in face. As well as kings who resisted Muslim invaders to last there were many who tried to buy dm off, and who retained diminished kingdoms under suzerainty of hated Mleccha. In this political climate it is not surprising that inter-state relations were of most macchiavellian character. basic concept which governed relations of one king with another was doctrine of “circles” ( ma ala), which, like many other concepts, was pedantically elaborated by theorists on statecraft. king on whose territory circle is centred is known as “he who desires conquest” ( vijig u). king whose territory adjoins that of would-be conqueror is “the enemy” ( ari)—“when he is in trouble he must be attacked, when he has little or no help he may be uprooted, otherwise he must be harassed and weakened”. 53 Beyond enemy lies “the friend” ( mitra) natural ally of conqueror. So far system of circles is simple and obvious, but theorists enlarged it further. Beyond friend is “the enemy’s friend” ( arimitra), and beyond him “the friend’s friend” ( mitramitra). opposite frontier of conqueror’s kingdom provides further series of potential foes and allies, “heelsiezer” ( pār graha), who is an ally of conqueror’s enemy and is liable to attack him in rear, “defender” or rearward friend ( ākranda), heelsiezer’s ally ( pār grāhisāra), and rearward friend’s friend ( ākrandāsāra). main purport of this enumeration is clear-a king’s neighbour is his natural enemy, while king beyond his neighbour is his natural ally. working of this principle cn be seen throughout history of Hindu India in temporary alliances of two kingdoms to accomplish encirclement and destruction of kingdoms between them. In such conditions diplomatic relations were not thoroughly organized, and there is no evidence of system of permanent ambassadors. Relations between one court and another were maintained by envoys ( dūta), who resided at court to which they were sent only while transacting business in hand. As in most civilizations, person of envoy was
inviolable, and king slaying an envoy was thought to be reborn in hell
with all his councillors.

Megasthenes states that peasants would till their fields peacefully, even when battle was raging nearby, but this is probably too optimistic generalization. Devastation of crops to weaken [Page 128] enemy was quite legitimate acc to textbooks, and, although there was strong feeling that lives of non-combatants should be respected, this rule was not always kept. In any case, except in favoured times and localities peasant could never feel wholly safe from raiders, and, though wholesale sacking of cities was not common in ancient India, townsman could rarely feel altogether secure against looting and exactions of enemy occupation. Conditions in Hindu India were not unlike those in medieval Europe, where there was broad and recognized cultural unity accompanied by inter-state anarchy resulting in perpetual warfare. In Europe, however, well-organized. and centralized Roman Church often acted as pacifying element in situation; in India Hinduism, which had no all-embracing super-national organization, rather encouraged inter-state anarchy by incorporating many martial traditions into Sacred Law.

MILITARY ORGANIZATION AND TECHNIQUE ancient Indian army contained more than one type of soldier, and troops r sometimes classified into six categories: hereditary troops, forming backbone of army; mercenaries; troops provided by corporations ( śreni); troops supplied by subordinate allies; deserters from enemy; and wild tribesmen, used for guerilla fighting in hill and jungle. Of this list third category is obscure, but it perhaps refers to private armies, maintained by merchant guilds for protection of their caravans and trading posts, which might be loaned to king. In medieval Ceylon corporation of Malabar merchants called Ma igrāma (p. 223), like Honourable Company in 18th century India, became an important and often decisive factor in island’s politics through its private army. fierce mercenaries of Kerala (Malabār) and Karnāta (Mysore) found ready employment in armies of many Indian and Sinhalese kings throughout Middle Ages. Of four great classes ksatriya was warrior par excellence, and no doubt most of hereditary troops considered themselves to belong to this class, but all classes took part in war. Brāhmans holding high military rank r mentioned in Epics and in many medieval inscriptions, and their participation in war is expressly permitted in some texts. lower orders fought also, usually as auxiliaries or subordinates, but late textbook on polity ascribed to Śukra lays down that highest military posts, even to that of general, may be filled by śūdras or outcastes.54 In early Vedic period all free men were no doubt liable to [Page 129] military service by tribal custom, but, with strengthening of caste ideas, liability vanished in most parts of India. There is no evidence of general conscription in any major Indian kingdom from Mauryas onwards, though Arthaśāstra mentions villages which provided troops in lieu of taxes, and such villages of warriors existed in quasi-feudal Middle Ages; martial character of tribes of N.-W. India, Rājasthān, and parts of Western Deccan, seems to hv altered little from earliest times, despite numerous invasions and changes of overlord, and survives to present day; among such people most able-bodied men took part in war. traditional divisions of Indian army were four: elephants, cavalry, chariots, and infantry; some sources add other categories, such as navy, spies, pioneers, and commissariat, to bring total up to six or eīght. Of these elements most important, from point of view of contemporary theory, was first. Elephants trained for war r first mentioned in Buddhist scriptures, where it is said that king Bimbisara of Magadha owned large and efficient elephant corps. They were trained with great care and attention, and, marching in van of army, acted rather like tanks in modern warfare, breaking up enemy’s ranks and smashing palisades, gates, and other defences (p. 457f); line of elephants might also act as living bridge for crossing shallow rivers and streams. Elephants were often protected by leather armour, and their tusks tipped with metal spikes. Chinese traveller Sung Yiin, who visited kingdom of Hū as in early 6th century, speaks of fighting elephants with swords fastened to their trunks, with which they wrought great carnage, but there is no confirmation of this practice in other sources. As well as mahout elephant usually carried two or three soldiers, armed with bows, javelins and long spears, and advanced with small detachment of infantry to defend it from attack. great reliance placed on elephants by Indian tacticians was, from practical point of view, unfortunate. Though fighting elephants might at first strike great terror in an invading army unused to them, they were by no means invincible. Just as Romans found means of defeating elephants of Pyrrhus and Hannibal, so Greeks, Turks, and other invaders soon lost their fear of Indian fighting elephant. Even best trained elephant was demoralized comparatively easily, especially by fire, and when overcome by panic would infect its fellows, until whole squadron of elephants, trumpeting in terror, would turn from battle, throw riders, and trample troops of its own side. pathetic Indian faith in elephants’ fighting qualities was inherited by Muslim conquerors, who, after [Page 130] few generations in India, became almost as reliant on elephants as Hindus, and suffered at hands of armies without elephants in just same way. Cavalry, though important, was not up to standard of that of many other early peoples, and weakness of their cavalry was an important factor in defeat of Indian armies attacked by invaders from North- West; decisive victory of Alexander over Porus in 326 B.C. and that of Muhammad of Ghor over Prthvīrāja in A.D. 1192 were both largely due to superior, more mobile, cavalry. Mounted archers were special danger to Indian armies. chariot as vehicle of war disappeared soon after commencement of Christian era. In Vedic period it was major fighting arm, and it retained this importance in Epic stories. Arthaśāstra and other evidence shows that in Mauryan times it was still widely used in war, and early sculpture depicts few fighting chariots; but by Gupta times chariot was little more than means of transport. light two-horsed chariot of Vedic period, carrying only driver and warrior, developed into larger and more cumbrous vehicle. Four-horsed chariots r mentioned by classical sources, and r depicted at Sānchī and elsewhere, with horses yoked abreast, and carrying four men. Fig. x.—Royal Warriors (after terracotta plaque from Ahicchatrā, U.P. c. 6th century A.D.) There r several references to ships being used for military purposes, but little evidence that Indian kings had real conception of value of sea-power, or naval warfare. Ships were chiefly used for conveying troops, usually along great Indian rivers; but [Page 131] Cālukya king Pulakeśin II employed navy to besiege Purī, not far from modern Bombay (p. 511, n), and two great Cō kings, Rājarāja I and Rājendra I (p. 75), developed positive maritime policy and evidently had regular navy. Sinhalese conqueror Parākramabāhu I (p. 75) is said to hv invaded Burma by sea. Ships of war were used to put down many pirates who infested Indian Ocean, and Arab writers of Middle Ages show that petty chiefs of West Coast themselves organized pirate fleets; but, with exception of Cō as, it is doubtful if any Indian king possessed navy in modern sense. infantry, though little mentioned in texts, must at all times hv been real backbone of army. An élite corps, sort of Pretorian Guard, existed in most kingdoms. In medieval South this royal guard was pledged to defend king’s person to death, and its loyalty was confirmed by ceremonial meal eaten with king on his accession. privilege of eating with king conferred on guardsmen sort of nobility, and they r mentioned by Marco Polo as “Companions of Honour”. Arthaśāstra envisages corps of physicians to care for wounded, ready in rear with drugs, bandages, and other equipment. existence of such corps, and of staff of horse and elephant doctors attached to army, is confirmed by other sources. same text mentions employment of women to cook for troops in rear of battle. acc to most theorists basic unit of Indian army was patti, sort of mixed platoon consisting of one elephant, one chariot, three horses, and five foot-soldiers. Three of these constituted senāmukha, three senamukhas gulma, and so on up to “complete army” ( ak auhiznī), of 21,870 pattis. exaggerated precision of this list is another example of pedantry which beset most ancient Indian writing on practical matters, and there is no good evidence that army was regularly divided in this way, with all arms intermixed. Other sources speak of commands rising in units of ten, and Arthaśāstra mentions unit consisting of 45 chariots, 45 elephants, 225 horses, and 675 footmen; five of these detachments formed full battle array ( samavyūha), resembling Roman legion in size. Arthaśāstra allows wide variation in these numbers acc to availability of resources and requirements of situation. Indian army was usually very large one. Classical accounts state that forces of last Nanda king consisted of 20,000 cavalry, 2,000 chariots, 200,000 footmen, and number of elephants variously given as 3,000, 4,000, or 6,000. Plutarch records that [Page 132] Candragupta Maurya overran India with 600,000 men. Hsüan Tsang states that Harsa had 5,000 elephants, 20,000 cavalry, and 50,000 footmen at beginning of his career, which were increased to 60,000 elephants and 100,000 cavalry at height of his power. 9th-century Arab traveller Al Mas’ūdī says that Pratihara king Mahendrapala had four armies of 800,000 men each, while Cō king Rajaraja I is said to hv invaded kingdom of Calukyas with an army of 900,000. All this evidence is far from reliable, but it is noteworthy that estimates of size of medieval armies r considerably larger than those of armies of earlier period, and this may bear some relation to fact. Fully mobilized, and including auxiliaries and non-combatants, it is not impossible that total fighting force of larger medieval kingdom numbered well over million. acc to Megasthenes Mauryan army was organized under committee of thirty, divided into sub-committees which controlled corps of infantry, cavalry, chariots, elephants, navy, and commissariat. This system seems to be modelled on Megasthenes’ description of city government of Pātaliputra (p. 103), and is not confirmed by any other source. Arthaśāstra describes army as organized under number of superintendents, with general ( senāpati) at head of all military affairs. Medieval armies often had numerous generals, with “great general” ( mahāsenāpati) in supreme command. general was always very important figure in realm, and often member of royal family. He took orders direct from king, who was expected to take command in major engagements, even when aged. Kings often fought in van of battle, but cautious Arthaśāstra advises dm to direct operations from rear. Below general were numerous captains ( nāyaka, da anāyaka), who, in medieval period, often approximated to feudal nobility. Regiments, divisions, and squadrons were recognized by distinguishing standards, and often had definite corporate life. In medieval South India we hear of troops of regiment subscribing to fund for dependants of comrade killed in battle, and there r records of religious donations made by regimental subscription. arms of ancient India were not appreciably different from those of other early civilizations. Efforts hv been made by some scholars, not all of dm Indian, to show that firearms and even flying machines were known, but this is certainly not case. one clear reference to firearms occurs in Śukra, which is late medieval, and passage in question is probably an interpolation of Mughal times. mysterious and magical weapons of Epics, slaying hundreds at blow and dealing fire and death all around them, must be products of poet’s imagination. If India had had firearms her Greek, Chinese and Arab visitors would certainly hv recorded existence of such wonders, and also, fortiori, of marvellous aerial pavilions described in Rāmāyana, early Tamil texts, and elsewhere, making of which was quite beyond technical ability of any ancient civilization. Gandhāra School PLATE XXXII [Page 133] In fact Indians possessed ancient world’s equipment of artillery-ballistas (not known before Mauryan times), battering rams and other siege engines. inspiration for wonderful weapons of poets may hv come from incendiary missiles, fireballs, fire-arrows and like, which were special feature of Indian military equipment, though disapproved of as unfair by Smrti writers. Arthaśāstra especially stresses value of incendiarism in war, and even suggests use of birds and monkeys to carry fire to enemy’s rooftops. It gives brief formulae for composition of inflammable material, which r clear enough to show that this was not gunpowder. usual Indian bow in Mauryan times was some five or six feet long, and often made of bamboo; it shot long cane arrows. acc to classical accounts it was very powerful instrument, which was rested on ground and steadied with one foot, but bows of few archers shown in early sculpture r raised from ground. Poisoned arrows were known and used, though condemned in religious texts. less cumbersome composite bow, often made of horn ( śar iga), was also known, and became more popular in later times. Swords were of various types, most dangerous being ni rimśa, long two-handed slashing sword. Lances and javelins were among usual equipment of Indian soldier, including special long lance ( tomara) used in fighting from backs of elephants. Iron maces and battle-axes were also used. Terracotta slingstones hv been found in remains of Indus cities, and sling was used in later times, though it does not seem to hv been an important weapon. warriors depicted in early sculpture (pl. XXIV) r only lightly defended with armour, but use of armour of metal or leather developed as result of influx of invaders from NorthWest, and in Middle Ages coats of mail became more usual, together with armour for horses and elephants. Shields of bent cane covered with leather, or of metal, were regularly used, sometimes protecting whole body. Helmets r not often depicted until Middle Ages, and it would seem that Indian soldier relied mainly on thick folds of his turban to protect his head.  [Page 134] Fortification was an important branch of military science, but nearly all fortresses of pre-Muslim India hv been so developed and adapted in later times that they no longer give true picture of ancient Indian military architecture. An important exception is long wall of rough-hewn stone protecting site of ancient Rajagrha, capital of Bimbisara of Magadha, which probably dates back to Buddha’s day.  Another example is Śiśupālgarh in Orissā, where small section of city wall dating from pre-Gupta times, has recently been excavated. It was []()workmanlike brick wall, set on an earthwork and probably surrounded by moat.

The ideal durga, or fortified city, as described in Arthaśāstra, was circled by three very wide moats, within which was an earthwork, covered with spiny shrubs, and surmounted by wall thirty-six feet high, with numerous square towers and roofed balconies for archers. With this may be compared Megasthenes’ description of defences of Pataliputra, which is said to hv had mighty wooden wall, with 570 towers and 64 gates. Arthaśāstra advises against use of wood for fortifications, owing to its liability to fire and rot, but archæology bears out Megasthenes, for remains of some of gigantic timbers of wall of Mauryan Pataliputra hv been excavated near modern Patna. defences of Śiśupalgarh were certainly smaller and less elaborate (pl. XIa).  Fig. xi.—A Siege (from relief at Sānchī, c. beginning of Christian era) most important surviving pre-Muslim fortress is Devagiri (modern Daulātābad), capital of Yādava kings of Northern Deccan until its capture by troops of Ala’-ud-din Khaljī in 1312. outer fortifications hv mostly been replaced and developed by later Muslim rulers, but citadel, on an almost inaccessible hill, (pl. IIc), still contains corridors cut by Hindu kings through solid rock, which were virtually only means of reaching summit, and r memorial to engineering skill of medieval India.  In sieges attackers relied mainly on close investment and reduction of their enemy by starvation and thirst, but capture by [Page 135] storm was not unheard of, and mining was regularly employed. word []()for mine or underground tunnel was sura ga, borrowed from Greek  word, which had same secondary meaning; from this we may infer that Indians learned something of siegecraft from Greco-Bactrian kings.  Indian army was slow and ponderous. Arthaśāstra declares that []()a good army cn march two yojanas day, while bad army only march one. yojana, like medieval English league, is an uncertain measure []()of distance, varying from four to ten miles; but internal evidence shows that author of Arthaśāstra had in mind yojana of about five miles. Thus march of ten miles per day was most that could be expected even of well-organized and efficient army. This is not surprising, when we read of its complex and cumbrous organization.  []()The army dwelt in an enormous camp which was, in fact, temporary kcity, with royal quarters, quarters for king’s harem, and for camp followers, merchants and prostitutes. king and his chief officers took many members of their families with dm on campaign, including representative selection of their wives and concubines, and probably lower ranks did likewise. Rā rakuita king Amoghavarsa I (817–877) was actually born in camp, while his father Govinda III was campaigning in Vindhyas. This large body of non-combatants not wholly subject to army discipline must hv appreciably slowed pace of army and impaired its efficiency. One theorist disapproved of women in camp,55 but it seems that his advice was rarely if ever followed.  Arthaśāstra envisaged strict discipline in camp; it was to be thoroughly guarded and policed, and exit and entry were to be controlled by rigorous system of passes. In fact it was probably less well organized than []()this source suggests, especially in later times, when secret of detailed organization, which Mauryas possessed and Arthaśāstra reflects, was largely lost. Bāna’s vivid description of Harsa’s army striking camp (p. k 448f) does not suggest very efficient quartermaster’s department.  []()The Arthaśāstra gives much advice on preliminaries of battle, but unfortunately says little on actual conduct of fighting, for which we must turn to exaggerated accounts of Epics and other sources.  Battle was great religious rite, highest sacrifice of warrior, and as such was not entered without proper preliminaries. day and time of giving battle were chosen with great care by astrologers, whenever this was possible, and purificatory rites were performed on its eve. Before battle  troops were harangued by brahmans, and [Page 136] by king himself, and were encouraged with promises of booty and glory, with certainty of heaven for slain.  Arthaśāstra advises employment of heavy infantry in centre, with light infantry, chariots, and cavalry on wings. elephants were generally concentrated in centre, while archers took up positions behind spearmen. Descriptions of battles r usually turgid, and overlaid with fanciful and supernatural elements; but it is clear that at most times great emphasis was placed on single combat between picked warriors.  Though mass fighting of rank and file must often hv played decisive part in encounter, it is given little notice in literary sources on which we must depend. For ordinary soldier courage and morale depended on leader. Only noble or elite warrior could be relied kon to fight to last, and there is more than one account of an army fleeing []()in panic when its chief was killed or wounded.  k[]()[]()The Arthaśāstra suggests that price should be put on every enemy head, varying acc to rank from twenty pa as upwards; this would not encourage giving of quarter, but massacre of prisoners was unusual, and it was very strongly deprecated in Smrti texts. Captives were usually released on payment of ransom, and those who could not pay, and these probably included most of common soldiers, were enslaved; but their enslavement was usually temporary, and they were released when they had paid their ransom by their labour.  From these notes it will be seen that inter-state relations and war were weakest aspects of Indian polity. kingdoms of medieval Hindu India, incapable either of empire building or of firm alliances, and maintaining enormous unwieldy armies which were continuously at war, indeed produced their heroes, but they were quite incapable of withstanding Turks, whose military science was not overburdened by pedantic theory or ancient tradition.

V.

SOCIETY: CLASS, FAMILY AND INDIVIDUAL


LAWS OF CLASS AND STAGE OF LIFE
[Page 137]

OFTEN and in many contexts we read of “the Dharma of class and stage of life” ( varnasrama-dharma), which, in golden age of remote past, was self-evident and uninfringed, but which is now vague, misunderstood and partly forgotten, and which brahmans interpret and king preserves and enforces. implication of this phrase is that Dharma is not same for all. There is indeed common Dharma, general norm of conduct which all must follow equally, but there is also dharma appropriate to each class and to each stage in life of individual. kdharma of men of high birth is not that of humbler folk, and dharma of student is not that of old man.  This thoroughgoing recognition that men r not same, and that there is hierarchy of classes, each with its separate duties and distinctive way of life, is one of most striking features of ancient Indian sociology.  []()Criticisms of pretensions of higher classes were heard from time to time, and equalitarian propositions were occasionally put forward, but in general this concept has held its ground from end of Ṛg Vedic period to present day.


THE FOUR GREAT CLASSES

We hv seen that by end of Ṛg Vedic period fourfold division of society was regarded as fundamental, primeval, and divinely ordained (p.  35). four varnas of India developed out of very early Āryan class divisions, for some class stratification existed in many Indo-European communities, and ancient Iran had four pištras or classes, comparable in some respects to those of India. In India class stratification grew more rigid when, in Vedic period, situation arose rather like that prevailing in South Africa today, with dominant fair minority striving to maintain its purity and its supremacy over darker majority. Tribal class-divisions []()hardened, and dark-skinned aboriginal found place only in basement of Āryan social structure, as serf with few rights and many disabilities. Soon idea of varna had become so deeply embedded in [Page 138] Indian mind that its terminology was even used for []()classification of precious commodities such as pearls, and useful materials like timber. Theoretically all Aryans belonged to one of four classes, with exception of children, ascetics and widows, who were outside system.  Varna came to Dravidian South comparatively late, for earliest Tamil literature shows society divided into tribal groups with little sense of precedence of one over other. Succeeding centuries saw gradual hardening of class, until South Indian brahmans became even stricter in their ritual observances and untouchables even more debased than in North.  sharp distinction was made between three higher classes and śūdra. former were twice-born (dvija), once at their natural birth and again at their initiation, when they were invested with sacred thread and received into Āryan society1 (p. 161f). śūdra had no initiation, and was often not looked on as Āryan at all. fourfold division was in theory functional. Manu1 lays down that duty of brāhman is to study and teach, to sacrifice, and to give and receive gifts; ksatriya must protect people, sacrifice, and study; vaisya also sacrifices and studies, but khis chief function is to breed cattle, to till earth, to pursue trade and to lend money; sudra’s duty is only to serve three higher classes-and “it is better”, Manu adds elsewhere, 2 “to do one’s own duty badly than  another’s well”. This epigram, elaborated so beautifully in Bhagavad Gita, was leading theme of most Indian social thought; for each man there was place in society and function to fulfil, with its own duties and rights.

This was ideal, but though in Middle Ages it was perhaps approached, it has never been wholly reached. precepts of texts which lay down laws for conduct of four classes were rarely fully carried out in practice, and were often blatantly infringed. texts, which we hv already discussed (p. 1 l2f), were written by brāhmans and from brāhmanic point of view, and represent conditions as brāhmans would hv liked dm to be. Thus it is not surprising that they claim utmost honour for priestly class and exalt it above measure.

The brāhman was great divinity in human form. 3 His spiritual power was such that he could instantly destroy king and his army, if they attempted to infringe his rights. In law he claimed great privileges (p. 120), and in every respect he demanded precedence, honour and worship. Even Buddhist scriptures, though they do [Page 139] not admit more extravagant brahmanical claims and regularly exalt kṣatriya over brahma0., recognize his greatness, if he is pious and sincere.

These Buddhist sources show us two types of brāhman. There were learned brahmans, performing all rites of Āryan and receiving great respect; but there were also village brahmans, who made much of their living by fortune-telling and sorcery, and who were less honoured. For all rigidity of class system brahmans soon lost their racial purity, and it has even been suggested that, as Āryan culture expanded, schools of aboriginal sorcerers and medicine men managed to obtain footing in brahmanic order, just as aboriginal chiefs were certainly assimilated to warrior class. Thus, it may well be, proto-Hinduism of Harappā culture was ultimately assimilated to Āryan faith.

Of professional priests there were various types and classes-in earliest times we read of semi-legendary ṛṣ is, or seers, who composed Vedic hymns, while sacrificial ritual demanded number of priests (ṛ tvij) with specialized duties-invokers ( hotr), cantors ( udgdtr), and priests to perform manual operations of ceremony ( adhvaryu). term brāhmaṇ meant originally “one possessed of brahman”, mysterious magical force of type widely known to modern anthropologists by Polynesian word mana. It was first applied to specially trained priest who superintended whole sacrifice, and was ready to counteract with his magic spells any evil influence caused by minor errors of ritual. By end of R.g Vedic period term was used for all members of priestly class.

There were other divisions within order. brāhmans of later Vedic period were divided into exogamous septs ( gotra), system which was copied in part by other classes and has survived to present day (p. 153ff). Later brahman class formed many castes, linked together by endogamy and common practices. further division was śākhā or branch, based on recension of Vedic texts accepted as authoritative by family in question.

Often brahman lived under patronage of king or chief, and was provided for by grants of tax-free land, farmed by peasants, who would pay their taxes to brahman instead of to king; but there were also land- owning brahmans, who cultivated large estates by hired labour or serfs. religious brahman might hv high post at court, and purohita’s2 importance in state has [Page 140] already been noted (p. 100). Other brāhmans might earn competence as teachers of Veda, and of other branches of learning.

At all times many brāhmans led truly religious lives. Kalidasa’s Sakuntala gives charming picture of settlement of such pious brahmans, living simply but not too austerely in huts in forest, where even wild deer were unafraid of gentle hermits, and woodland was forever perfumed with fragrance of their sacred fires. Such brahman colonies were supported by gifts of kings and chiefs and of peasants of neighbourhood. Other brāhmans became solitary ascetics, while in Middle Ages brahman monastic orders were founded, rather on Buddhist model.

But varied religious activity of ancient India did not provide livelihood for more than few of brahmans. Smrti literature contains special sections on “duty when in distress” (apad-dharma), which carefully define what man may legitimately do when he cannot earn living by profession normally followed by his class, and by these provisions brāhmans might pursue all manner of trades and professions.

Many were employed in important government posts, and several royal families were of brāhman. origin. Generally lawbooks disapprove of brāhmans engaging in agriculture, because it inflicts injury on animals and insects, but this rule was often ignored. brahman is forbidden to trade in certain commodities-among dm cattle and other animals, slaves, weapons, and spirituous liquor-and his lending money at interest is also disapproved of, though Manu4 allows him to lend at low interest to “wicked people”, by whom he probably means those who do not maintain Āryan rites. But though he kept these rules rigidly, brahman would find many trades and professions open to him.

Opinions differed as to whether brahman engaged in secular profession was worthy of respect accorded to practising member of his class, and no clear ruling is laid down. Manu, most authoritative of Smrtis, is uncertain on this point, and in different parts of text diametrically opposed views r given. 5 As far as cn be gathered from general literature special rights of brahman were usually only granted to those who lived by sacrifice and teaching. Carudatta, poor brahman hero of play “The Little Clay Cart” (p. 120), receives scurvy treatment at hands of court, probably because he is brahman by birth only, and not by profession.

For all his prestige, brahman was often butt of satire. Even in Ṛ g Veda 6 croaking of frogs at beginning of rainy season is compared to monotonous reciting of priests, though here no sarcasm may be intended. But there cn be no other [Page 141] explanation of remarkable passage in early Chāndogya Upanisad, 7 which describes vision of sage Vaka Dālbhya, wherein dogs move round in circle, each holding tail of preceding dog in its mouth, “just as priests do when about to sing praises”; and then, repeating very sacred syllable Ōm, they sing:” Ōm! let us eat! Om! let us drink! Om! may gods Varuna, Prajapati and Savitr bring us food!” Another early reference to gluttony of brāhmaṇs occurs in Aitareya brāhmaṇ a, 8 in an interesting passage which describes other three classes from point of view of warrior; here brāhmaṇ is “a receiver of gifts, drinker of soma, an eater of food, to be expelled at will”. vidūṣ aka, fool of Sanskrit drama (p.

90), an amiable but gluttonous figure of fun, is invariably brāhmaṇ.

There are, however, few frontal attacks on brāhmaṇical pretensions, even
in literature of Buddhists, who came nearest to an anti-brāhmaṇical
point of view; but one brief Buddhist tract, “Diamond Needle”
( Vajrasūci), ascribed to Aśvaghoṣa, of 1st or 2nd century A.D., attacks
the claims of priesthood, and indirectly whole class system, with
vigorous dialectical skill. claims of brāhmaṇ were, in fact, often
ignored, and not wholly unchallenged.

The second class was ruling one, members of which were in the
Vedic period called rājanya, and later kṣ atriya. theoretical duty of the
ksatriya was “protection”, which included fighting in war and governing in
peace (p. 88f). In early times he often claimed precedence over the
brāhmaṇ; this claim is implicit in Aitareya brāhmaṇ passage which we
have quoted, inclusion of which in brāhmaṇ ical scripture is hard to
account for. acc to Buddhist tradition, in times when brāhmaṇs
are highest class Buddhas r born in that class, while when ksatriyas
are highest they r born as ksatriyas. historical Buddha was a
ksatriya, and his followers evidently had few doubts about class priorities.

Where names of four classes r mentioned together in Pali
scriptures that of ksatriya usually comes first.

A strong king was always check on brāhmaṇic pretensions, just as the
brāhmaṇs were check on pretensions of king. Tradition speaks of
many anti-brāhmaṇical kings who came to evil ends, and legend of
Parasurama, who destroyed whole ksatriya class for its impiety (p. 303),
must contain recollection of fierce strife between two classes in pre-
Buddhist times. After Mauryan period brāhmaṇ’s theoretical
position was established throughout most of India, but ksatriya was in
fact still often his equal or superior.

[Page 142] martial class of ancient India, from great emperors to
petty chiefs, was recruited from all races and ranks, and all invaders of
India down to coming of Muslims were given place in social
order in this way. Manu9 describes warlike peoples on fringes of
Āryan civilization, including Greeks ( Tavana), Scyths ( Saka), and
the Parthians ( Pahlava), as ksatriyas who had fallen from grace through
their neglect of Sacred Law, but who could be received once more into
the Āryan fold by adopting orthodox way of life and performing
appropriate penitential sacrifices. This provision might be applied to almost
any conquering people, and Rajputs, in later times ksatriyas par
excellence, were no doubt largely descended from such invaders.

The ksatriyas claimed and received certain privileges. They continued
old customs not in keeping with orthodoxy, with such persistence that the
brāhmaṇic lawgivers were forced to give dm legal status. Thus marriage
by capture was permitted to ksatriya, as were clandestine liaison and
the svayaṃ vara, at which girl chose her husband from among the
assembled suitors (p. 169). Like brāhmaṇs, they did not always live by
fulfilling their ideal function. rules of āpad-dharma applied to them
also, and there r many records of men of warrior stock becoming
merchants and craftsmen.

In Vedic times vaiśya, or mercantile class, though entitled to the
services of priesthood and to sacred thread of initiation, was but a
poor third to brāhmaṇs and kṣatriyas. In Aitareya brāhmaṇ a
passage to which we hv referred vaiśya is described as “paying tribute
to another, to be lived on by another, to be oppressed at will”. Other
passages in early brāhmaṇic literature show him as wretched and down-
trodden cultivator or petty merchant, who is of no interest to his betters
except as source of profit.

According to Manu10 special duty of vaiśya was keeping cattle,
which were made over to his charge at creation of world. class
evidently originated in ordinary peasant tribesman of R.g Veda, but
long before lawbook ascribed to Manu was composed it had many other
activities. śūdras, humblest of four classes, had by now taken to
agriculture, and Manu admits many other legitimate vaiśya occupations
besides cattle rearing and farming. ideal vaiśya has expert knowledge
of jewels, metals, cloth, threads, spices, perfumes, and all manner of
merchandise-he is, in fact, ancient Indian business-man.

Though brāhmaṇa literature gives vaiśya few rights and humble
status, Buddhist and Jaina scriptures, few centuries later in date and of
more easterly provenance, show that he was not always [Page 143]
oppressed in practice. They mention many wealthy merchants living in
great luxury, and powerfully organized in guilds. Here ideal vaiśya is
not humble taxpaying cattle-breeder, but asītikotivibhava, man
possessing eight million panas. Wealthy vaiśyas were respected by kings
and enjoyed their favour and confidence. It was they, rather than the
ksatriyas, who chiefly favoured rising unorthodox religions of
Buddhism and Jainism. They formed by this time, at least in regions of
Magadha and Kosala, true bourgeoisie, no doubt small in number, but
very important. Numerous inscriptions from Sunga times onwards record
the great donations of vaiśya merchants and skilled craftsmen to religious
causes, especially to Buddhism, and show that they were prosperous and
influential.

If vaiśya, acc to Aitareya Brdhmana, was to be oppressed at
will, lot of śūdra was even more unfortunate. He was “the servant of
another, to be expelled at will, to be slain at will” -but latter phrase may
be interpreted “to be beaten at will”, and import of whole passage
seems to be satirical.

śūdras were not “twice-born”. For dm there was no initiation into full
Āryan status, and they were not regularly considered Āryans, though the
Arthaśāstra in its chapters on slavery11 specifically mentions dm as such.

The śūdra was in fact second-class citizen, on fringes of Āryan
society. word śūdra is of doubtful etymology, and occurs only once in
the Ṛ g Veda; it was perhaps originally name of non-Āryan tribe, which
became subordinate to conquerors, and origin of śūdra class may
be accounted for in this way, though it certainly included other elements. As
the rigidity of brāhmaṇic observances increased, groups which refused to
accept orthodox custom, or clung to old practices which were no longer
respectable, fell to rank of śūdras. There r today castes which
themselves claim to be ksatriyas, but which r branded by brāhmaṇs as
śūdras because they adhere to customs which hv long become
objectionable, such as meat eating or remarriage of widows. Persons
born illegitimately, even when of pure high-class blood, were officially
counted as śūdras. 12
śūdras were of two kinds, “pure” or “not-excluded” ( aniravasita) and
“excluded” ( niravasita). latter were quite outside pale of Hindu
society, and were virtually indistinguishable from great body of people
later known as untouchables. distinction was made on basis of the
customs of śūdra group in question, and profession followed by its
members. acc to brāhmaṇical textbooks chief duty of the
pure śūdra was to wait on other three classes. He was to eat the
remnants of his [Page 144] master’s food, wear his cast-off clothing, and
use his old furniture. Even when he had opportunity of becoming
wealthy he might not do so, “for śūdra who makes money is distressing to
the brāhmaṇs”.13 He had few rights, and little value was set on his life in
law. brāhmaṇ killing śūdra performed same penance as for killing a
cat or dog. 14 śūdra was not allowed to hear or repeat Vedas. land
where śūdras were numerous would suffer great misery.

Thus textbooks give small hope of happiness to wretched śūdra,
who could do little but serve his betters in unpleasant and servile tasks, and
whose only hope was rebirth in higher social class; but there is good
evidence that śūdras did not always live humble and wretched life laid
down for dm in Sacred Law. There is mention of śūdras engaged in
manufacture and commerce, and by Mauryan times many śūdras were free
peasants.15 śūdra had place of sorts in Hindu fold, and was
encouraged to imitate customs of higher classes. Though he might
not hear Vedas, Epics and Puranas were open to him, and he had a
part in devotional religion which became more and more popular from
postMauryan times onwards, and ultimately eclipsed older cults; in the
Bhagavad Gītā lord K
a himself promises full salvation to those
śūdras who turn to him.16 From point of view of most medieval sects,
class and caste were affairs of body rather than of spirit, and verses
expressing fundamental equality of all men r to be found in Dravidian
devotional literature and in vernacular religious literature of later times.

Theoretically Buddhism and Jainism made no class distinctions in religious
affairs. As we hv seen, śūdra kings were not unknown, and many śūdras,
despite injunctions of lawbooks, must hv been prosperous.



UNTOUCHABLES
Below śūdras were early representatives of people who were
later called untouchables, outcastes, depressed classes, or scheduled castes.

Buddhist literature and early Dharma Sūtras show that several centuries
before Christ there already existed groups of people who, though serving
the Āryans in very menial and dirty tasks, were looked on as quite outside
the pale. Sometimes they were called “fifth class” ( pañcama), but most
authorities rejected this term, as if to insist that they were excluded from the
Āryan social order altogether.

Numerous groups of these people r mentioned, by names which are
non-Āryan in origin, and were probably those of aboriginal tribes [Page
145] which came under sway of advancing Āryans. Chief of these
groups was caṇḍ āla, term which came to be used loosely for many
types of untouchable. caṇḍāla was not allowed to live in an Āryan
town or village, but had to dwell in special quarters outside boundaries.

Though some caṇḍālas had other means of livelihood, in theory their main
task was carrying and cremation of corpses, and they also served as
executioners of criminals.

According to lawbooks caṇḍāla should be dressed in the
garments of corpses he cremated, should eat his food from broken
vessels, and should wear only iron ornaments. No man of higher class
might hv any but most distant relations with caṇḍāla, on pain of
losing his religious purity and falling to caṇḍāla’s level. By Gupta times
caṇḍālas had become so strictly untouchable that, like lepers in medieval
Europe, they were forced to strike wooden clapper on entering town, to
warn Āryans of their polluting approach.

Certain classes of outcastes or untouchables seem to hv gained their
unenviable position through growth of sentiment of nonviolence-for
instance niṣ āda, who was hunter, fishing caste called kaivarta, and
the leather worker ( kārāvara). pukkusa,3 who appears as sweeper in
Buddhist literature, may hv fallen in status because members of his class
made and sold alcoholic liquor. More difficult to account for r such base
classes as basket-maker ( veṇ a) and chariot-maker ( rathakāra). In early
Vedic times latter was most respected craftsmen, but soon fell to the
status of an impure śūdra or outcaste.

By beginning of Christian era outcastes themselves had
developed caste hierarchy, and had their own outcastes. Manu17 mentions
the antyāvasāyin, cross between caṇḍāla and nisada, who was
despised even by caṇḍālas themselves. In later India every untouchable
group imagined that some other group was lower than itself, and this
stratification evidently began quite early.

Even lot of untouchable was not altogether without hope. Though
he was denied access to temples and comforts of orthodox religion,
Buddhist monks preached to him, and more enlightened wandering
ascetics would give him instruction. untouchable dying in defence of
brāhmaṇs, cows, women, and children secured place in heaven. Orthodox
texts contain frequent warnings on evils which arise when śūdras and
outcastes grow too powerful, and this would seem to show that caṇḍāla
might occasionally become influential.

Another class of untouchable was mleccha, word commonly used
for outer barbarians of whatever race or colour. As an invader [Page 146] he
was loathed, but once he had come into contact with Indian ways and was
less strange and forbidding his status might improve. In fact it was not
blood which made group untouchable, but conduct. Generally there was
no chance of an individual rising in social scale, but for group this was
possible, over number of generations, by adopting more orthodox
practices and following rules of Smśtis. Thus Indian class system
was always somewhat fluid.



“CONFUSION OF CLASS”
An early legend tells of Viśvāmitra, ksatriya who, by penance and piety,
became brāhmaṇ and seer ( rsi) to boot; but as time went on such raising
of one’s status became more and more difficult, and finally virtually
impossible, though convenient fictions sometimes permitted kings and
chiefs of low status to find legendary ksatriya ancestors and advance in the
class hierarchy. While it became very difficult for individual to rise, it
grew progressively more easy for him to fall. Every breach of manifold
regulations of one’s class entailed impurity and outcasting, either permanent
or temporary. lawbooks give long lists of penances for restoration
of unfortunate offender, ranging from trivial ones, such as bathing, or
touching Ganges’ water, to others so rigorous that they must usually have
resulted in death of penitent. Secular literature, however, tells many
stories of high-class people infringing rules of purity without doing
penance, and no doubt more sophisticated townsman often took his
class responsibilities lightly.

The continual injunctions to king to ensure that “confusion of class”
( varṇ a-saṃ kara) did not take place indicate that such confusion was an
ever-present danger in mind of orthodox brāhmaṇ. class system
was indeed very fragile thing. In golden age classes were stable,
but legendary king Vena (p. 87), among his many other crimes, had
encouraged miscegenation, and from this beginning confusion of class had
increased, and was special feature of Kali-yuga, last degenerate
age of this æon, which was fast nearing its close. good king, therefore,
should spare no effort to maintain purity of classes, and many
dynasties took special pride in their efforts in this direction.

Before tightening of social system in Middle Ages confusion
of class was comparatively frequent, and some forms of interclass marriage
were expressly permitted. type of marriage known to anthropologists as
hypergamous, when husband is of higher class than wife, was by no
means disapproved of; on [Page 147] other hand hypogamous marriage,
when wife’s status was higher than that of husband, was always
frowned on. former was “in accordance with direction of hair”
( anuloma), smooth and natural, while latter was “against hair”, or
“brushing wrong way” ( pratiloma). This distinction is to be found in
other societies; for instance in Victorian England peer who married an
actress rarely incurred same scorn and ostracism as lady who
married her groom.

The earlier legal literature permitted anuloma or hypergamous marriage,
provided that man’s first wife was of his own class. Generally brāhmaṇs
were forbidden to take śūdra wives, but one lawbook allowed even this,18
and Bana, 7th-century poet, who was brāhmaṇ, had stepbrother by a
śūdra mother. Various mixed classes, many of dm forerunners of later
castes, were said to be products of marriages of this type, and their
members were not looked on as in any way unclean, but enjoyed position
intermediate between that of two parents. Of groups thought to have
descended from hypergamous marriage only nisada, in theory cross
between brāhmaṇ and śūdra woman, was thought to be impure.

Hypogamous or pratiloma marriage, on other hand, produced
offspring whose status was lower than that of either parent. Thus the
caṇḍālas were believed to hv descended from marriages between śūdras
and brāhmaṇ women. only exceptions were class of charioteers, or
sūtas, thought to hv sprung from hypogamy of ksatriyas and
brāhmaṇs, and bards or māgadhas, descended from vaiśya fathers and
ksatriya mothers, both of whom were well respected. complex system
of sub-classes low in social scale, out of which Indian caste system
developed, was believed to be wholly result of “confusion of class”.

This tradition was accepted by early Indologists, but, as we shall see, is
completely unfounded.



CASTE
Relations between classes and social groups in later Hinduism were
governed by rules of endogamy (marriage was only legitimate within the
group), commensality (food was only to be received from and eaten in the
presence of members of same or higher group), and craft-
exclusiveness (each man was to live by trade or profession of his own
group, and not take up that of another). Megasthenes noted seven
endogamous and craft-exclusive classes in India-philosophers, peasants,
herdsmen, craftsmen and traders, soldiers, government officials and
councillors. His sevenfold division is certainly [Page 148] false, but he
gives evidence to show that in Mauryan times class divisions were already
hardening. Even in Gupta period, however, regulations were by no
means rigid. Hypergamous intermarriage was recognized, rule of craft-
exclusiveness was often ignored, or circumvented by convenient escape
clauses of apaddharma (p. 140), and in earlier lawbooks brāhmaṇ
was permitted to accept food from any Āryan. It was only in late medieval
times that it was finally recognized that exogamy and sharing meals with
members of other classes were quite impossible for respectable people.

These customs, and many others such as widow-remarriage, were classed as
kalivarjya—customs once permissible, but to be avoided in this dark Kali
age, when men r no longer naturally righteous.

In whole of this chapter we hv hardly used word which in most
minds is most strongly connected with Hindu social order. When the
Portuguese came to India in 16th century they found Hindu
community divided into many separate groups, which they called castas,
meaning tribes, clans or families. name stuck, and became usual
word for Hindu social group. In attempting to account for the
remarkable proliferation of castes in 18th– and 19th– century India,
authorities credulously accepted traditional view that by process of
intermarriage and subdivision 3,000 or more castes of modern India had
evolved from four primitive classes, and term “caste” was applied
indiscriminately to both varna or class, and jāti or caste proper. This is a
false terminology; castes rise and fall in social scale, and old castes die
out and new ones r formed, but four great classes r stable. They are
never more or less than four, and for over 2,000 years their order of
precedence has not altered. All ancient Indian sources make sharp
distinction between two terms; varṇ is much referred to, but jāti very
little, and when it does appear in literature it does not always imply the
comparatively rigid and exclusive social groups of later times. If caste is
defined as system of groups within class, which r normally
endogamous, commensal and craft-exclusive, we hv no real evidence of
its existence until comparatively late times.

Caste is development of thousands of years, from association of
many different racial and other groups in single cultural system. It is
impossible to show its origin conclusively, and we cn do little more than
faintly trace its development, since early literature paid scant attention to it;
but it is practically certain that caste did not originate from four classes.

Admittedly it developed later than they, but this proves nothing. There were
subdivisions in four classes at very early date, but brāhmaṇ gotras,
which go back [Page 149] to Vedic times, r not castes, since gotras are
exogamous, and members of same gotra r to be found in many castes.

Perhaps first faint trace of caste is to be found in careful
cataloguing of trades and professions in later Vedic literature, as if their
members were looked on almost as distinct species. In Pali scriptures
many trades and professions r described as living apart; thus we read of
villages of brāhmaṇs, potters, hunters and robbers, and of separate quarters
in towns for different trades and professions. Many trades were
organized in guilds, in which some authorities hv seen origin of the
trade castes; but these trade groups cannot be counted as fully developed
castes. 5th-century inscription from Mandasor19 shows us guild of silk-
weavers emigrating in body from Lata (the region of lower Narmada)
to Mandasor, and taking up many other crafts and professions, from
soldiering to astrology, but still maintaining its guild-consciousness. We
have no evidence that this group was endogamous or commensal, and it was
certainly not craft-exclusive; but its strong corporate sense is that of caste
in making. Hsüan Tsang, in 7th century, was well aware of four
classes, and also mentioned many mixed classes, no doubt accepting the
orthodox view of time that these sprang from intermarriage of the
four, but he shows no clear knowledge of existence of caste in its
modern form.

To present day life of lower orders is much more affected by
caste than by varṇa-it is not being vaiśya or śūdra, but being an ahir, a
kāyasth, or sonār which matters, and corporate feeling is centred around
this caste group, whether based on region, race, profession or religion. The
same strong corporate sense existed among Mandasor silk weavers, and
evidence of its existence at an even earlier date cn be gathered from many
sources. Indian society developed very complex social structure, arising
partly from tribal affiliations and partly from professional associations,
which was continuously being elaborated by introduction of new racial
groups into community, and by development of new crafts. In the
Middle Ages system became more or less rigid, and social group
was now caste in modern sense. Professor J. H. Hutton has interpreted
the caste system as an adaptation of one of most primitive of social
relationships, whereby small clan, living in comparatively isolated
village, would hold itself aloof from its neighbours by complex system of
taboos, and he has found embryonic caste features in social structure of
some of wild tribes of present-day India. caste system may well be
the natural response of many small and primitive peoples who were
forced to come to terms with more complex economic and social system.

It [Page 150] did not develop out of four Āryan varnas, and two
systems hv never been thoroughly harmonized.

By end of our period many of present-day caste groups were
already in existence. Even brāhmaṇ class was much subdivided into
endogamous groups, often based on locality and race, with many different
practices. Rajputs were divided into clans which, if not regularly
endogamous, were castes of sort, and vaiśyas, śūdras, and
untouchables had evolved hundreds of castes. They were governed by local
committees of elders, usually hereditary, which had power to expel
members and regulate caste rules, and whose decisions, from time of the
Arthaśāstra onwards, had force of law.

After large joint family, caste provided social security, helping
destitute members and providing for widows and orphans. man expelled
from his caste was also automatically expelled from his family, unless the
whole family accompanied him in his social ostracism. He was lost to
society, and could only consort with lowest of low. Though he might
sometimes retain some of his former wealth he was isolated, tree torn up
by roots. Permanent loss of caste was greatest catastrophe, short of
death and major chronic diseases, which could happen to man.

Early Tamil literature gives no evidence of caste, but growth of Āryan
influence and development of more complex political and economic
structure produced system in some ways more rigid than that of North.

By Cōla period an important feature of South Indian caste structure had
appeared, which has survived to present day. In Dravidian country
families claiming to be ksatriyas were few, other than ruling families,
and vaiśyas were equally rare. Nearly whole of population were
brāhmaṇs, śūdras or untouchables, and śūdra castes, which formed the
mass of people, were divided into two great caste groups, known as the
right and left hands. great animosity and rivalry which still exists
between these groups is at least thousand years old. On right r the
trading castes, some weaving castes, musicians, potters, washermen,
barbers, and most of cultivating and labouring castes; on left are
various castes of craftsmen, such as weavers and leather workers, cowherds,
and some cultivating castes. We hv no evidence of how this strange
bisection of society arose.

Hypergamy never wholly disappeared. In Malabar, where matrilinear
succession has continued almost to modern times, men of great
brāhmaṇ caste of Nambūdiris hv regularly married women of the
dominant secular caste, Nayyars. In Bengal Raḍhi caste of
brāhmaṇs and important and respectable castes of [Page 151] scribes
( kāyastha) and doctors ( vaidya) r divided into subcastes, which are
hypergamous. system is known as “kulīnism”, from name of the
highest subcaste of brāhmaṇs ( kulina); it was by tradition imposed by
the Bengal king Vallala Sena (12th century), but is no doubt survival from
much earlier times.

The organization of castes, independent of government, and with
social ostracism as its most severe sanction, was powerful factor in the
survival of Hinduism. Hindu, living under an alien political order
imposed from above, retained his cultural individuality largely through his
caste, which received most of loyalty elsewhere felt towards king,
nation and city. Caste was so strong that all attempts at breaking it down,
until recent years, hv ended in failure. Equalitarian religious reformers of
the late Middle Ages, such as Basava, Ramanand, and Kabir, tried to
abolish caste among their followers; but their sects soon took on the
characteristics of new castes, and in some cases divided into castes within
themselves. Sikhs, despite outspoken sentiments of their gurus and
the adoption of rites deliberately intended to break down caste prejudice,
such as ritual meal eaten in common, did not overcome caste feeling.

Even Muslims, for all their equalitarian faith, formed caste groups. The
Syrian Christians of Malabar early divided into sections which took on a
caste character, and when in 16th century Roman Catholic missionaries
began to make converts in South India their flocks brought their caste
prejudices with them, and highcaste converts held themselves aloof from
those of lower orders.

Only in last fifty years has caste system shown real signs of
breaking down, thanks to many inventions of West not designed for
use in society divided into watertight compartments, spread of
Western education, growing national sentiment, and intensive
propaganda of enlightened leaders. process is not yet complete, and it
will be many years before all trace of caste feeling is eradicated; but when
Mahatma Gāndhī, in many ways socially conservative, persuaded his
followers to sweep their own floors and clean their own latrines he sounded
the death knell of old Hindu social order, which, for all its faults, has
preserved identity of Indian society over centuries of foreign
domination.



SLAVERY
Megasthenes declared that there were no slaves in India. He was
certainly wrong, but Indian slavery was milder than form to which he
had been used, and slaves were much less numerous than in civilizations
of West; hence he may not hv recognized [Page 152] dāsa as a
slave. There was no caste of slaves; though Arthaśāstra declares that
servitude is not in nature of Āryan (in which term humble śūdra
is explicitly included), an individual of any class might in certain
circumstances become slave, although most slaves were no doubt of low
caste.

The word dāsa originally meant member of peoples conquered by
the Āryans in their first invasions of India. Its later connotation no doubt
developed from reduction to bondage of many dasas captured in
battle, and here we find probable origin of Indian slavery. The
Mahābhārata declares that it is law of war that vanquished should be
the victor’s slave, 20 and captive would normally serve his captor until
ransomed. But there were several other classes of slaves in later times.

Children born of slaves normally became slaves of their parents’
masters. Slaves might be bought, given away, or mortgaged. free man
might sell himself and his family into slavery in times of dire distress. He
might also be reduced to slavery for crime or debt, but in these cases his
servitude might be only temporary. All these types of slavery are
recognized in Smrti literature and elsewhere.

As in other slave-owning civilizations, slave might become an
important man, and there r even references in stories to slaves serving as
royal counsellors. Slaves might sometimes perform work of economic
importance, such as agriculture or mining, but they were usually domestic
servants or personal attendants. slave was, in fact, subordinate
member of his master’s household. His maintenance was his master’s
responsibility, and if he died sonless it was incumbent on master to
perform funeral and commnemorative rites for welfare of his soul.

According to most lawbooks slave’s property ultimately belonged to his

master, and he might be bought, sold, loaned or given away; but masters
had no rights over lives of their slaves, and were not allowed to abandon
them in old age, as was done in many other ancient civilizations. “A man
may go short himself or stint his wife and children, but never his slave, who
does his dirty work for him. “21 Some lawbooks even limit right of a
master to give corporal punishment to his slave. “A wife, son, slave, a
servant or younger brother may, when they do wrong, be beaten with a
rope or cane, but only on back and not on head. If man beats
them otherwise he should be punished as thief.” 22 manumission of a
slave is commended by textbooks as pious act, and in any case a
person enslaved for debt became free when he had paid debt with his
labour.

The Arthaśāstra, in many ways more liberal than religious lawbooks,
lays down regulations appreciably milder than those we [Page 153] have
outlined. sale of children into slavery is explicitly forbidden except in
dire emergency. Slaves r entitled to own and inherit property, and to earn
money freely in their spare time. Slaves of upper classes cannot be
forced to perform defiling duties. chastity of slave-girls is protected-the
master who rapes slavegirl must set her free and pay her compensation,
and if she has child by her master, even with her own consent, both
mother and child become free. promise made by man in dire necessity
to sell himself and his family into slavery is not binding.
