The humane regulations of Arthaśāstra, probably unique in the
records of any ancient civilization, r perhaps survivals of Mauryan laws,
and it is therefore not surprising that Megasthenes declared that there was
no slavery in India. India, unlike most ancient civilizations, was never
economically dependent on slavery; labourer, farm worker, and
craftsman alike were normally free men, and latifundia of Roman
magnate had no counterpart in India. Slave markets r not mentioned in
early sources, and though provision was made for sale of slaves they do
not seem at first to hv been regular article of commerce. In early
centuries of Christian era, however, there was trade in slave-girls
between India and Roman empire in both directions, and slave markets
existed in 16th-century Vijayanagara empire.

There r numerous references in literature to slaves being badly treated
by their masters, and slave’s lot must hv been often very unhappy
one; but he was probably better off in India than in most parts of ancient
world. Indeed in many contexts it would seem that word dasa implies
rather bondman or serf than chattel slave.



GOTRA AND PRAVARA
The Hindu social order was complicated by other features which had no
original relationship to class or caste, but were roughly harmonized with
them. These r institutions of gotra and pravara, which were in
existence in late Vedic times, and probably earlier, and r very important to
the orthodox brāhmaṇ to this day.

The original meaning of gotra is “a cowshed”, or “a herd of cows”; in the
Atharva Veda, 23 word first appears with meaning of “a clan”, which
it has retained with special connotation. Some ancient Indo-European
peoples, such as Romans, had exogamous clans, as well as generally
endogamous tribes. It may well be that gotra system is survival of
Indo-European origin which had developed specially Indian features.

Gotra as it existed in historical times was primarily brāhmaṇic [Page
154] institution, adopted rather half-heartedly by other twice-born classes,
and hardly affecting lower orders. All brāhmaṇs were believed to have
descended from one or other ṛṣi, or legendary seer, after whom gotras
were named. religious literature generally speaks of seven or eight
primeval gotras, those of Kasyapa, Vasistha, Bhrgu, Gautama, Bharadvaja,
Atri and Viśvāmitra. eighth gotra, that of Agastya, is named after the
sage who is said to hv taken Vedic religion beyond Vindhyas, and
who is sort of patron saint of Dravidians. His name may hv been
added to those of original seven as South became progressively
Āryanized. These primeval gotras were multiplied in later times by the
inclusion of names of many other ancient sages.

Though gotras perhaps evolved from local units within Āryan
tribe they had quite lost their tribal character by historical times, and
brāhmaṇs from furthest parts of India and of different caste groups
might hv same gotra. chief importance of gotra was in connexion
with marriage, which was forbidden to persons of same gotra.

The position was further complicated by pravara. In brāhmaṇ’s daily worship he mentioned not only name of founder of his gotra, but also names of certain other sages who were believed to be remote ancestors of his family. formula generally contained three or five names, and set up further bar to marriage, for same names would occur in pravaras of families of other gotras. acc to custom of some gotras, marriage was impossible with member of another gotra having one pravara name in common, while others barred intermarriage only when there were two common names in pravaras. Thus matrimonial choice was much restricted, especially when in Middle Ages endogamous caste system was fully established.

The social prestige of brāhmaṇs led to respectable classes adopting gotra system of some sort. Ksatriyas and vaiśyas took same gotra names as brāhmaṇs; their gotras, however, were not based on the claim to descent from an ancient sage, but merely on gotra of family of brāhmaṇs which traditionally performed their domestic rituals. As imposed on non-brāhmaṇic families system was quite artificial. Non- brāhmaṇ families were also expected to take pravaras of their domestic priests, but this rule counted for little. real gotras of ksatriyas and vaiśyas were secular ( laukika) ones, founded by legendary eponymous ancestors. Legal literature takes little note of these secular gotras, but numerous references in inscriptions show that term was used in the sense of [Page 155] “sept” or “clan”, and that many non-brāhmaṇ gotras existed which do not occur in lists of any of lawbooks.

Early lawgivers take comparatively liberal view of breaches of gotra regulations. man marrying woman of same gotra must perform a cāndrāyaṇ penance, severe fast of month’s duration, and henceforth maintain his wife as he would sister;24 no stigma attaches to child of such marriage. With ruthless logic, however, later jurists declare that this rule applies only to inadvertent marriage within gotra; when the relationship is known sin is equivalent to that of incest.

THE FAMILY
The Indian family was, and usually still is, joint one-that is to say a close link was maintained between brothers, uncles, cousins and nephews, who often lived under one roof or group of roofs, and who owned the immovable property of line in common. Like European and Semitic  family, it was patriarchal and patrilinear. father was head of house jand administrator of joint property, and, except in Malabar (p. 174f), the headship descended in male line.

The ancient Indian family included parents, children, grandchildren, uncles and their descendants, and various collaterals on male side. It might include adopted children, and unless poor it would also possess a varying number of servants, domestic serfs, and clients; brāhmaṇ family might, in addition, find room for number of students, who were engaged in lengthy course of training under head of house, and were treated as members of family. Thus, especially in polygamous society where girls were married very young, it formed very large group.

The family, rather than individual, was looked on as unit of the social system; thus population of given region was generally estimated in families rather than in heads. bonds of family were such that relationships within group were often blurred or lost sight of; for instance son might commonly refer co all his father’s wives indiscriminately as his mothers, and distinction between brother and paternal cousin was not always made clearly-even today same word is used for both.

The group was bound together by śrāddha, rite of commemorating the ancestors, at which balls of rice called piṇḍ were offered (p. 177).

Sons, grandsons and great-grandsons of deceased joined together in śrāddha, and three generations of dead were [Page 156] believed to participate in benefits of ceremony. Thus dead and living were linked together by this rite, which, like ancestor worship of the Chinese, was most potent force in consolidating family. śrāddha defined family; those who were entitled to participate in ceremony were “co-piṇḍas” ( sapiṇḍ a), members of family group. rite, which is still practised, goes back to Vedic times.

This deep sense of family solidarity led, as might be expected, to
nepotism and various other abuses, and today joint family system is
beginning to weigh heavily on younger generations; but it gave a
measure of social security to its members. In distress man could rely on
his sapindas, and ne’er-do-well cousin or indolent good-for-nothing
uncle, living in corner of family home in comparative comfort while
adding little or nothing to family fortunes, was probably just as common
a figure in ancient India as he is today.

Though powerful and awe-inspiring figure, paterfamilias was not
usually an arbitrary tyrant; his power, like that of king, was somewhat
limited by Sacred Law and custom. jurists differed on question of
his rights over family property. In modern times there r two great
schools of family law, called after legal texts on which they r based
Mitākṣ arā and Dāyabhāga (p. 113); most families of Bengal and Assam
follow rules of Dayabhaga, while rest of India generally follows
Mitākṣarā. acc to latter school sons and grandsons hv right
in family property even before death of paterfamilias, who is
little more than trustee and manager on behalf of family, without the
right to give property away so as to impoverish his dependents. Dayabhaga
maintains that sons only obtain rights over property on death of the
father, but even this school recognizes that he is not an outright owner, but
only steward for his descendants. Both schools existed in medieval times,
and represent codifications of much earlier practices.

At very early time fathers may hv had absolute rights over their
children, for certain ancient and popular stories remind us of Hebrew
legends of Abraham and Isaac and Jephthah’s daughter. most famous of
these is story of Śunahśepa.

King Hariścandra of Ayodhya was childless, and vowed that if he had a
son he would sacrifice him to god Varuṇa. Soon son was born to him,
and named Rohita; but Hariscandra was naturally disinclined to perform his
share of bargain. In punishment Varuna afflicted him with dropsy. After
some years he decided to sacrifice Rohita, who was now youth, but he

refused to give his life for sake of his father’s health, and fled to the
forest, where he lived for six years.

PLATE XXXVIII
[Page 157] One day Rohita met brāhmaṇ, Ajigarta, and bought his
second son Śunahśepa for hundred cows, as substitute for himself.

Varuna agreed to accept sacrifice of Śunahśepa in place of Rohita, and
the brāhmaṇ boy was sent to court of Hariscandra to be prepared for
sacrifice. Ajigarta agreed to earn another two hundred cows for binding his
son. to sacrificial stake and slaying him. sacrifice was made ready,
and Śunahśepa led to slaughter; he commenced to sing hymns in praise
of gods, and his devotion was such that Varuna was moved to
compassion. Hariscandra was cured of his disease, and Śunahśepa lived to
become great and famous sage.

Another well-known story of same tenor is that of Naciketas, the
interlocutor of Katha Upanisad.

The brāhmaṇ Vajasravasa gave away all his wealth to priests performing
sacrifices on his behalf, having promised to give up all that he possessed.

His son, Naciketas, saw that he still had one possession, and asked “Dear
Father, to whom will you give me?” father made no reply, but when
Naciketas repeated question third time he said angrily, “I shall give
you to Death!”
Naciketas obediently went to palace of Yama, god of dead, but
found him not at home; only after he had waited for three nights did god
return. Yama so regretted his impoliteness in keeping guest waiting for so
long that he offered Naciketas three boons. With first boy was
restored to life, and his father pacified; with second he learnt secret
of fire sacrifice; and with third he obtained from Yama full
knowledge of mystery of life after death, which makes up body of
the poem.

Certain early legal texts do allow father to give away, sell or abandon
his son, 25 and legends we hv mentioned would confirm that this was
done, 4 but other sources positively forbid such action.26 father’s right
over life of his child is nowhere explicitly admitted, but Arthaśāstra
looks on killing of son as among most heinous forms of murder;
on other hand even parricide is permissible in self-defence.

Left to itself, joint family would tend to increase in size until it became
so large as to be unmanageable; hence Sacred Law made provision for
its break-up. partition of large joint family was favoured by the
lawyers, since thus more domestic rites would be performed, and gods
receive more honour and bless land more readily. Commonly partition
took place on death of paterfamilias, when property was divided
among sons. There was no provision for wills in ancient India, and the
eldest son received no special inheritance, except sometimes very small
weightage amounting to one twentieth of share. partition of the
family property [Page 158] was not necessarily postponed until father’s
death. It regularly occurred if he renounced world to become an ascetic,
and under Mitaksara system it might take place even without his
consent, by agreement among sons, if he was senile, incurably diseased,
had taken to evil courses, or was otherwise incapable of managing the
family affairs. Individual sons, like Prodigal in Gospel, might
demand their share and leave family, though this was not wholly
approved, and was virtually impossible under Dayabhaga system.

In partition minute rules, varying somewhat with different authorities,
were laid down as to shares to be received by other relatives when there
were no sons. Most authorities rejected rights of women to inherit; but
Yājñvalkya27 lays down an authoritative list of priority in inheritance,
which places wife, followed by daughters, immediately after the
sons. right of wife to inherit if no sons were living was accepted by
the Mitākṣarā school, which was chiefly based on Yājñvalkya.

The joint family property did not include individual possessions of
the members; at least from medieval times onwards personal earnings, gifts,
and so on were generally thought to belong to member of family
who earned them. This was, however, probably late concept. Manu28, for
instance, states that property of son, wife, or slave belongs to head
of household, and same precept is repeated by some other early
lawgivers; rights of paterfamilias, it would seem, tended to grow
less with time.



THE FOUR STAGES OF LIFE
We hv seen that for theorist society involved two concepts; one of
these was class, or varṇ a, while other was stage of life, or asrama. This
was later idea than that of class, and was evidently more artificial. Just as
Āryan society was divided into four classes, so life of individual
Āryan was divided into four stages; on his investiture with sacred
thread, when he put his childhood behind him, he became brahmacārin,
leading celibate and austere life as student at home of his teacher;
next, having mastered Vedas, or part of them, he returned to his parental
home, and was married, becoming householder ( grhastha); when, well
advanced in middle age, he had seen his children’s children and had thus
surely established his line, he left his home for forest to become a
hermit ( vānaprastha); by meditation and penance he freed his soul from
material things, until at last, very old man, he left his hermitage, and
became homeless wanderer ( sannyāsin), with all his earthly ties broken.

[Page 159] This scheme, of course, represents ideal rather than the
real. Many young men never passed through first stage of life in the
form laid down, while only few went beyond second. Many of the
hermits and ascetics of ancient India were evidently not old men, and had
either shortened or omitted stage of householder. series of four
stages is evidently an idealization of facts, and an artificial attempt to
find room for conflicting claims of study, family life, and asceticism in a
single lifetime. It is possible that system of āśamas was evolved
partly as counterblast to unorthodox sects such as Buddhism and
Jainism, which encouraged young men to take up asceticism, and by-pass
family life altogether, practice which did not receive approval of the
orthodox, though in later times provision was made for it. Despite their
artificiality, however, four stages of life were an ideal which many men
in ancient India attempted to follow, and thus they deserve our
consideration. Moreover they serve as framework round which we can
model life of individual.

According to scheme of four stages life began not with physical
birth, but with second birth, or investiture with sacred thread. Thus
the child was not full member of Āryan community, but nevertheless
his existence was hedged around with religious rites, which began even
before his birth. Few religions cn hv marked course of life of
their members with so many rites and ceremonies as Hinduism. According
to most orthodox calculations there were some forty ceremonies
( saṃ skāra), which covered whole life of man from his conception to
his death, some of which were of great importance, and were performed by
all respectable members of Āryan community.



THE CHILD
Of various saṃskāra, or personal ceremonies, in life of pious
Hindu first three took place before birth: these were garbhādhāna to
promote conception, puṃ savana, to procure male child, and
simantonnayana, to ensure safety of child in womb. birth
ceremony ( jātakarma) took place before cutting of umbilical cord,
and involved whispering of sacred spells ( mantra) in baby’s ear,
placing mixture of honey and ghee in his mouth, and giving him name,
to be kept secret by his parents until his initiation. At birth child and his
parents were ritually impure, and therefore not entitled to take part in
ordinary religious ceremonies until some ten days later, when child was
given his public name and period of impurity ceased. Minor rites of
infancy, not [Page 160] always looked on as particularly sacred, were the
ear-piercing ceremony, and niskramana, when child was taken out of
the house, and shown sun for first time.

More important was first feeding (annaprasana). In child’s sixth
month he was given mouthful of meat, fish, or rice (in later times usually
the latter) mixed with curds, honey and ghee, to accompaniment of
Vedic verses and oblations of ghee poured on fire. tonsure
(cūdākarma) took place in third year, and was confined to boys; with
various rites child’s scalp was shaved, leaving only topknot, which, in
the case of pious brāhmaṇ, would never be cut throughout his life.

Another ceremony, not looked on as of first importance, was carried out
when child first began to learn alphabet.

Many of these ceremonies r now rarely if ever practised in their full
form, and it is doubtful if every ancient Indian family, even of higher
classes, performed dm regularly, especially in case of girls. Their
number, however, shows importance of child in life of his
parents. From earliest hymns of Ṛ g Veda sons were looked on as
great blessings. At least one son was almost essential, to perform funeral
rites for his father, and thus ensure his safe transit to other world.

Adopted sons were but poor substitutes for true sons, and their efficacy at
sraddha ceremonies was dubious. Thus there were strong religious reasons
for procreation of children. intense family feeling of Hindu India
enhanced desire for sons, without whom line would disappear.

Girls, on other hand, were incapable either of helping their parents in
the other world or of perpetuating line, for on marriage, acc to
orthodox practice, they became members of their husbands’ families. The
necessity of providing dm with dowries also lessened their desirability.

There were thus very practical reasons why girls should be unwanted, and
in civilization so heavily weighted in favour of male it is surprising
that there is little evidence of exposure or infanticide of girls. Rajput
families in later times certainly often destroyed their infant girls, and the
same may well hv been done by very poor at all periods; but no
special reference is made to exposure or infanticide in early legal texts.

In best Indian families daughters, though their birth may hv been
regretted, were cared for and petted just as sons.

The general impression obtained from literature is that in ancient
India child’s life was happy one. Maxims of type of “spare rod
and spoil child” r rare or non-existent. small child of ancient
India was generally pampered, humoured, and allowed degree of freedom
which few children in Europe obtained [Page 161] until modern times. The
loving descriptions of children in poetry nearly always show dm as the
spoilt darlings of their parents. Thus Kalidasa:
“With their teeth half-shown in causeless laughter,
and their efforts at talking so sweetly uncertain,
when children ask to sit on his lap
a man is blessed, even by dirt on their bodies.”29
The speaker of this verse is great king, and it shows us even little
children of princes playing naked in dust, and loved with tenderness by
their elders.

But undisciplined life of small child soon came to an end. For the
poor child there was work to do almost as soon as he could walk, and for
the wealthier there were lessons. Normally boy began to learn the
alphabet in his fourth or fifth year. In richer homes tutors were
maintained for children of family, but, in Middle Ages,
education was also given at village schools attached to temples. Though
women’s education was never looked on as essential, girls were by no
means neglected, and well-bred women were usually literate.

The curriculum of child’s early studies seems always to hv included
reading and elementary arithmetic, but at this stage of his life he was not a
full member of Āryan community, and his formal schooling had not yet
commenced. Only on his investiture with sacred thread was he ready to
learn Vedas and embark on detailed course of study calculated to
equip him for his ancestral calling.



INITIATION
The great rite of upanayana, second birth, whereby boy became a
full member of his class and of society, was confined to brāhmaṇs,
ksatriyas, and vaiśyas. śūdras and lower orders could not undergo it,
and were never allowed to hear or learn most sacred of scriptures.

The ideal age for ceremony varied acc to class-eight for a
brāhmaṇ, eleven for ksatriya, and twelve for vaiśya.

It was very ancient rite, going back to times before Āryans divided
into Indian and Iranian branches, for Zoroastrians had similar
ceremony, form of which is still practised by modern Pārsīs. The
kernel of ceremony was investing of boy, clad in garments of
an ascetic and with staff in his hand, with sacred thread ( yajñopavāta),
which was hung over his right shoulder, and under his left arm, and which
he was expected to wear continuously from that day forward. It was cord
of three threads, each [Page 162] of nine twisted strands, made of cotton,
hemp, or wool, for brāhmaṇs, ksatriyas, and vaiśyas respectively, and it had
great religious significance, which it still has for orthodox. Its removal
or defilement involved its owner in great humiliation and ritual impurity,
which could only be expunged by rigorous penance.

The ceremony also involved whispering of Gāyatrī in ear of
the initiate by officiating brāhmaṇ. This is verse from hymn of the
Ṛ g Veda,30 addressed to old solar god Savitr, which is still looked on as
the most holy passage of that most holy scripture. It is repeated in all
religious rites and ceremonies, and has position in Hinduism rather like
that of Lord’s Prayer in Christianity, except that Gayatri may only be
uttered by three higher classes.

Tát Savitur váreniam
bhārgo devásya dhīmahi,
dhiyo yó nah pracodáyāt.

Let us think on lovely splendour
of god Savitr,
that he may inspire our minds.

Probably even before Christian era many ksatriyas and vaiśyas had
ceased to perform initiation ceremony in full form, for term
“twice-born”, applying to all who had undergone ceremony, became
more and more looked on as synonym of brāhmaṇ. Some non-brāhmaṇ
castes, however, maintain ceremony to present day, and it is still
performed in orthodox brāhmaṇ families. Normally initiation was
confined to boys, though in Vedic times girls were also sometimes initiated.

In this initiation ceremony there was little or no trace of overt sexual
symbolism, and it was never thought of, like circumcision and other
initiation ceremonies among more primitive peoples, as rite fitting the
initiate for sexual life. initiated boy was still minor, but he had taken
the status of an Āryan, and it was now his duty to master religious lore
of Āryans in order to prepare himself for role of householder. As a
brahmacārin or religious student he had as yet several years of celibacy
before him.



EDUCATION
According to ideal of sacred texts, training of brahmacarin
took place at home of brāhmaṇ teacher ( guru). In some early sources
the guru is depicted as poor ascetic, and it is one [Page 163] of the
student’s duties to beg food for his teacher, but this rule seems not to have
been regularly followed. student was, however, expected to treat his
teacher with utmost reverence, ministering to all his needs, and obeying
all his commands implicitly.

Among first lessons of student was performance of sandhyā,
the morning, noon, and evening devotions, which included reciting the
Gayatrl, restraint of breath, sipping and sprinkling water, and pouring
libations of water to sun, which was looked on rather as symbol of the
special deity of worshipper, whether Visnu or Śiva, than as Sungod
himself. These rites were incumbent upon all twice-born, and in various
forms r still performed.

The main subject of study was Veda, and long hours were devoted to
its mastery. teacher would instruct few students seated on the
ground about him by rote, and for many hours daily they would repeat verse
after verse of Vedas, until one or more was mastered. Sometimes, to
ensure correctness, hymns were taught in more than one way, first with
the words connected, then in their isolated form ( padapatha), and then with
the words interwoven in ab, be, cd pattern ( kramapātha), or in even more
complicated ways. This remarkable system of mnemonic checks and the
patience and brilliant memories of many generations of teachers and
students preserved Vedas for posterity in much same form as that in
which they existed nearly thousand years before Christ.

The boys in guru’s home did not confine their attention wholly to the
Vedic texts. There were other fields of study, notably “Limbs of the
Veda”, or subsidiary sciences, necessary for its proper understanding. These
six vedāngas consisted of: kalpa, performance of sacrifice; śiksā,
correct pronunciation, or phonetics; chandas, metre and prosody; nirukta,
etymology, interpretation of obscure words in Vedic texts;
vyākarana, grammar; and jyotisa, astronomy, or science of calendar.

Moreover in post-Vedic times teachers would often instruct their students in
the six schools of metaphysics, or in that school which they specially
favoured. Those versed in Sacred Law would expound it to their
students, while others would teach special secular subjects, such as
astronomy, mathematics or literature.

The writers of Smrti envisaged all young men of upper class as
undergoing this training. Such was not case-in fact it is doubtful if more
than small proportion of young men ever went through full course of
Vedic education. Princes and sons of chiefs and nobles were trained in
arms and in all manifold sciences needed to fit dm for government,
while most boys of lower orders [Page 164] probably learnt their trades
from their fathers. Buddhist scriptures, however, show that there was a
form of apprenticeship, and lawbooks lay down rules governing it.

Certain cities became renowned for their learned teachers, and achieved a
reputation comparable to that of university cities of medieval Europe.

Chief among these were Banāras and Taksasila, which were already famous
in time of Buddha; later, around beginning of Christian era,
Kāñcī acquired similar reputation in South. Banaras, then usually
called Kāśī, was particularly renowned for its religious teachers, but
Taksasila, in far NorthWest, laid more emphasis on secular studies. The
Buddhist Jataka tales show that young men from all over civilized part
of India sought education in this city, through which trickle of Iranian and
Mesopotamian influence found its way to India. Among famous learned
men connected with Taksasila were Panini, grammarian of 4th
century B.C. (p. 388), Kautilya, brāhmaṇ minister of Candragupta
Maurya, and traditionally chief master of science of statecraft, and
Caraka, one of two great masters of Indian medical science.

Though it was ideal of Smrtis that small number of students
should study under single teacher, it seems that veritable colleges existed
at these “university towns”. Thus we read of an establishment at Banāras
with 500 students and number of teachers, all of whom were maintained
by charitable donations. Ideally, again, teacher asked no fee; the
students repaid him for his teaching by their reverent service, and only at
the end of their studies was he presented with gift, traditionally cow.

Manu, however, makes it quite clear that there were venal teachers who
were willing to teach Vedas for money. 31 Jataka story tells of a
teacher of Taksasila who made his ordinary pupils wait on him all day,
while those who paid fees were treated like his own children. At Taksasila,
also, rules of Smrti were relaxed in another respect, for we read of
married students, who did not live in their masters’ houses, but had homes
of their own, and only visited their teachers for lectures.

With Buddhism and Jainism education centred not on teacher’s home,
but on monastery. Every monastery might give training to postulants,
but quite early in history of these two religions certain establishments
acquired special reputation as centres of learning. In Middle Ages
some developed into true universities. most famous of these was the
Buddhist monastery of Nalanda in Bihār, which, founded in Gupta times,
remained most famous teaching centre of medieval Buddhism until it
was pillaged by invading Muslims. Our knowledge of day-to-day
life of [Page 165] Nalanda depends chiefly on Hsüan Tsang, who shows us
the monastery in 7th century as full of intellectual activity. Under its
aged and saintly abbot, Śīlabhadra, Nālandā did not confine itself to training
novices for Buddhist order, but also taught Vedas, Hindu philosophy,
logic, grammar and medicine. It would seem that student population
was not confined to Buddhist order, but that students of other faiths who
succeeded in passing strict oral examination were admitted.

PLATE XL
According to Hsüan Tsang, Nālandā was supported by revenues of an
enormous estate of one hundred villages, and by alms of many patrons,
including great Harsa himself; it provided free training for no less than
10,000 students, who had large staff of servants to wait on them. The
remains of Nalanda, however, belie Hsüan Tsang (pl. XII). monastery
consisted of very large complex of buildings, but it could hardly have
accommodated thousand monks in anything like comfort described by
the Chinese traveller.

Many other Buddhist monasteries all over country, and Jaina
monasteries in West and South, served as centres of learning, as did
their Christian counterparts in medieval Europe. In Middle Ages a
Hindu monasticism developed, and maṭ has of Hindu orders also
became centres of learning.



MARRIAGE
Ideally studenthood lasted for twelve years, though it might be
terminated when student had mastered one Veda. few very earnest
students took vows of perpetual celibacy, and continued religious studies
throughout their whole lives. Normally, however, young man in his
early twenties would return home, to resume everyday life of his class.

He would take ritual bath, and reward his teacher acc to means
of his family. From now on he was snātaka (“one who has bathed”), and
he might enjoy normal worldly pleasures, eat any kind of food usually eaten
by his class, and wear fine clothes and jewellery, which he put on at a
special homecoming ceremony ( samāvartaṇ a).

It was generally thought advisable for snataka to marry as soon as
possible, for unless he had taken vow of religious celibacy marriage and
the procreation of children were positive duty. Marriage had three main
purposes: promotion of religion by performance of household
sacrifices; progeny, whereby father and his ancestors were assured of a
happy after-life, and line was continued; and rati, or sexual pleasure.

[Page 166] normal religious marriage was and still is arranged by the
parents of couple, after much consultation, and study of omens,
horoscopes, and auspicious physical characteristics. couple were
usually of same class and caste, but of different gotras and pravaras, if
they were of high class. Rules of prohibited degrees were very strict,
especially in Northern India, where, even in caste which disregarded
gotra, marriage was forbidden between persons with common paternal
ancestor within seven generations or maternal ancestor within five. In the
Deccan, however, this rule was not strictly followed, and there r records
of cousin-marriage even in ruling families.

Though in early times it was usual for girls to be fully adult before
marriage, Smrtis recommend that while husband should be at least
twenty girl should be married immediately before puberty. So
philoprogenitive had Hindu orthodoxy become that it was even declared
that father who did not give his daughter in marriage before her first
menstruation incurred guilt of one procuring abortion (a very grave sin,
worse than many kinds of murder) for every menstrual period in which she
remained unmarried.32 general view was that ideal marriage was
one in which bride was one third age of groom-thus man of
twenty-four should marry girl of eight.33
The marriage of boys, whether before or just after puberty, is nowhere
suggested, but ideal of rigorous period of studentship before marriage
is always maintained. child-marriage of both parties, which became
common in later times among well-to-do families, has no basis at all in
sacred literature, and it is very doubtful whether child-marriage of girls
was at all common until late medieval period. heroines of poetry
and fiction r apparently full grown when they marry, and numerous
inscriptions which throw much light on customs of time give little or
no indication of child-marriage. Ancient Indian medical authorities state
that best children r produced from mothers over sixteen, and
apparently recognize practice of child-marriage as occasionally
occurring, but disapprove of it.34
The reasons for development of child-marriage cannot be given with
certainty. Some hv suggested that fear of marauding Muslims
encouraged parents to marry their daughters in childhood and to confine
their wives more strictly in their homes; but both these customs existed in
pre-Muslim times, so this cannot be only reason. It may in part be due to
the growing religious insistence on necessity of progeny, but this was
strong at all times. sexuality of Indian character may hv played
some part in it. [Page 167] woman was thought to be naturally libidinous;
an unmarried girl attaining puberty would proceed to find lover, however
strictly her parents guarded her; once she had lost her virginity she would
become unmarriageable and parents would hv choice of the
disgrace and expense of maintaining an unmarried daughter indefinitely, or
the even greater disgrace of casting her out to become beggar or a
prostitute. From point of view of her parents daughter was serious
economic liability, and this may hv encouraged custom.

Religious marriage was solemnized by very complicated ceremonies, the
expenses of which fell on family of bride, and, with dowry, were
a very heavy burden to her father and family. To this day Hindu parents will
often involve themselves in crippling debts in order to marry their
daughters. Though rules for wedding ceremony laid down in
different textbooks vary in details, rite differed little from that of the
present day, or from marriage ceremony of Ṛ g Veda. The
bridegroom, decked in great finery and attended by train of friends and
relatives, proceeded to bride’s home and was received by her father with
a madhuparka, an auspicious ceremonial drink of honey and curds. Usually
the ceremony was held in gaudy temporary pavilion in courtyard of
the house. Bride and groom entered pavilion separately, and sat on
either side of small curtain. To accompaniment of sacred verses
muttered by officiating brāhmaṇ curtain was removed, and the
couple saw one another, often for first time. bride’s father stepped
forward, and formally gave her to groom, who promised that he would
not behave falsely to her in respect of three traditional aims of life-piety,
wealth, or pleasure. Next, offerings of ghee and rice were made in the
sacred fire. groom then grasped bride’s hand while she offered
grain in fire, round which he then led her, usually with their garments
knotted together, after which she trod on millstone. couple then took
seven steps together, bride treading on small heap of rice at each step.

Then they were sprinkled with holy water and main part of the
ceremony was completed.

As described above rite seems comparatively simple, but it was
complicated by recitation of many mantras, or Vedic and other verses
believed to hv magical and spiritual efficiency. Even at this stage the
marriage ceremony was not completely over. newly married pair
returned to bridegroom’s house, where further sacrifice to the
domestic fire was performed. In evening it was incumbent upon dm to
look at Pole Star, symbol of faithfulness. For three nights couple
were expected to remain continent; in some [Page 168] texts they are
allowed to sleep together with staff between them, but others instruct
them to sleep apart on ground. On fourth night husband
performed rite to promote conception, and marriage was
consummated.5
The length and solemnity of this ceremony will give some idea of the
importance and sanctity of marriage in eyes of ancient Indian lawgivers;
but form of marriage which we hv described, though now regular
among respectable Hindus, was not only one known to ancient India,
and marriage might be considered binding even when religious
ceremony had not been performed. textbooks enumerate eight types of
marriage, named after various gods and supernatural beings:
(1) brāhma, marriage of duly dowered girl to man of same class
by ceremony described above.

(2) Daiva, when householder gives daughter to sacrificial priest as
part of his fee.

(3) Ārṣ a, in which, in place of dowry, there is token bride-price of a
cow and bull.

(4) Prājādpatya, in which father gives girl without dowry and
without demanding bride-price.

(5) Gāndharva, marriage by consent of two parties, which might
be solemnized merely by plighting troth. This form of marriage was often
clandestine.

(6) Asura, marriage by purchase.

(7) Rākṣ asa, marriage by capture.

(8) Paiśāca, which cn scarcely be called marriage at all-the seduction of
a girl while asleep, mentally deranged, or drunk.

Of these eight forms first four were generally approved, and were
permissible to brāhmaṇs; these were religious marriages, and were
indissoluble. other forms were looked on with varying degrees of
disfavour by pious. GĀndharva marriage, which often might amount to
no more than liaison, was surprisingly respected. Some doubts existed as
to whether it was possible to brāhmaṇs, but it was certainly allowed to the
warrior class and lower orders. It forms basis of many romantic
stories, and has given rise to one of stock figures of later poetic
convention-the abhisārikā, girl who secretly leaves her father’s home by
night to meet her lover at appointed trysting place.

Asura marriage, in which bride was bought from her father, was
looked on with disfavour by all sacred texts, though Arthaśāstra
allows it without criticism. There is evidence that [Page 169] marriage by
purchase, as well as orthodox marriage with dowry, existed even in
Vedic times, but it was not true Āryan custom, and was only allowed as a

sop to evil propensities of man. Rākṣ asa marriage, or marriage by
capture, was practised especially by warriors. most famous example,
according to later tradition, was marriage of Prthvlraja Cahamana, the
last great Hindu king of North India, with daughter of Jayaccandra of
Kanyakubja, whom he carried off as not unwilling captive. Epigraphy and
tradition record several other instances. Paiśāca marriage was universally
reprobated. names of last three types r derived from those of
demons, of which Paiśāca was lowest and most repulsive. This form
of marriage, acc to lawbooks, was not fitted for higher
classes, and could only be allowed on suffrance to lower orders.

PLATE XLII
Some authorities hv tried to explain away less reputable forms of
marriage, and to prove that they were non-existent or very rare; but it is
hardly likely that lawgivers would hv admitted these forms, of which
they wholeheartedly disapproved, if they had not had solid basis in
ineluctable social custom. It would seem that, with surprising realism, they
recognized wide range of relationships, so that girl seduced by her
lover’s promises or carried off by raiders would hv some legal claim to
wifely status, and her child some degree of legitimacy. No doubt among the
upper classes most marriages were of first type, and any of other
forms might be solemnized later by religious rites and thus raised in status.

A special form of gandharva marriage was svayaṃ vara or “self-
choice”. law books lay down that if girl is not married by her parents
soon after attaining puberty she may choose her own husband, and
evidently marriage by choice of bride sometimes took place. Epic
literature shows that more than one form of svayamvara was practised.

Princess Sāvitrī toured country in her chariot in search of suitable
mate, until she found Satyavant, woodcutter’s son. Damayanti chose her
husband Nala at great ceremony, at which she passed along assembled
ranks of her suitors until she found man of her choice. Another form of
svayaṃvara was that by which Rama won Slta, at great archery contest.

We hv references to performance of svayaṃvaras as late as 11th
century, for Vikramaditya VI, great king of Calukyas, is said to have
obtained brides by this method. svayamvara was normally concluded
by performance of rites of religious marriage, and later legal
commentators maintain that no form of marriage is complete without the
religious ceremony, at least in an abridged form.

[Page 170] With long marriage ceremony completed householder
might devote himself to three ends of life, classification commonly
found in both religious and general literature. three are: dharma,
gaining religious merit through following Sacred Law; artha, gaining
wealth by honest means; and kama, pleasure of all kinds. three were of
descending order of importance, and it was thought that where interests
of one end conflicted with those of another higher should hv priority.

The two latter ends need little explanation, but for high class Indian the
first involved numerous religious duties, notably performance of birth,
marriage, funeral, and other ceremonies, and regular carrying out of the
“Five Great Sacrifices” ( pañca-mahāyajña).

The greatness of these sacrifices lay not in their expense or complexity,
but in their importance. They were to be performed daily and consisted of:
(1) Brahmayajña, worship of Brahman, World-Spirit, by reciting
the Vedas.

(2) Pitṛ ryajña, worship of ancestors, by libations of water and
periodical sraddhas.

(3) Devayajña, worship of gods, by pouring ghee on sacred fire.

(4) Bhutayajna, worship of all things living, by scattering grain and
other food on threshold for animals, birds, and spirits.

(5) Puruṣayajña, worship of men, by showing dm hospitality.

Ideally five great sacrifices should be performed thrice day, at the
sandhyas, or periods of worship at sunrise, noon and sunset.



SEXUAL RELATIONS
Though learned brāhmaṇs who composed Smrti literature and
laid down canons of behaviour for Indian layman were puritanical in
many respects, they did not disparage physical love. Of three ends of
life third, pleasure, though less important than other two, was a
legitimate branch of human activity, for which provision had to be made in
the scheme of existence. In its broadest sense word kama means desire
of every kind and its fulfilment, but, like such English words as “desire”
and “passion”, it usually had sexual connotation. Of all legitimate
pleasures sexual pleasure was thought to be best.

The literature of Hindu India, both religious and secular, is full of sexual
allusions, sexual symbolism, and passages of frank eroticism. The
preoccupation with such themes increased in Middle Ages, when the
process of cosmic creation was figured as union of god [Page 171] and
goddess, and figures of closely embracing couples ( maithuna) were carved
on walls of temples. Some religious sects even introduced ritual
intercourse as part of their cult, and potent aid to salvation. But the
exaggerated sexual religiosity of later Middle Ages was only an
expression of vigorous sexuality which was to be found in Indian social
life at all times. Sexual activity was indeed positive religious duty-the
husband must hv intercourse with his wife within period of eight days at
the close of every menstruation.

The Indian passion for classification, though it did not result in the
emergence of experimental science, led to development of rather
pedantic schools on many aspects of human activity, including sexual
relations. On this topic number of textbooks survive, most important
and earliest of which is Kāmasūtra, attributed to sage Vatsyayana,
and written in early centuries of Christian era, or perhaps in the
Gupta period. This remarkable work gives, as may be imagined, detailed
instructions on erotic technique, aphrodisiac recipes and charms, and much
very valuable information about life of ancient Indian. From texts
such as this, and from many passages in courtly literature, we may learn
much about sexual life of upper classes.

Sexuality was not looked on as mere vent for animal passions of the
male, but as refined mutual relationship for satisfaction of both
parties. sophisticated townsman for whom Kāmasūtra was written
was advised to consider satisfaction of his mistress as well as his own,
for she was as passionate as himself, and it was even said by some that her
pleasure in sex was greater than his. Loveplay was manifold and thoroughly
classified; thus Kāmasūtra defines no less than sixteen types of kiss.

There was much tenderness in lovemaking, though it often culminated in
very violent embraces; it was favourite poetic convention to describe
lovers of both sexes, whether married or single, as displaying tokens of
their passion to their confidential friends, in form of marks of nails
and teeth.

The erotic preoccupations of ancient India r made very evident in art
and literature. ideal of feminine beauty in ancient India differed very
greatly from matronly type of Greeks, or slender more boyish
type of modern Europe and America. Indian ideal, thick-thighed, broad
hipped, but very slender-waisted, and with heavy breasts, seems evidently
chosen for physical satisfaction. poets loved to describe their heroines
in terms of luxurious frankness. They did, however, observe certain
conventional restraints. preliminaries of sexual intercourse r treated,
and it is recollected in tranquillity in general terms, but act itself is
rarely if [Page 172] ever described in detail until very late period.

Detailed descriptions occur in vernacular poetry, but poets of India’s
greatness preferred to leave something at least unsaid.

As an example of better side of Indian sexual life we quote from the
Kāmasūtra:
“For first three days after their marriage husband and wife
should sleep on floor and abstain from intercourse…. For next
seven days they should bathe to sound of music, adorn themselves,
dine together, and pay their respects to their relatives and to other
people who attended their wedding…. On evening of tenth day
the husband should speak gently to his wife… to give her
confidence…. Vatsyayana recommends that man should at first
refrain from intercourse, until he has won over his bride and gained her
confidence, for women, being gentle by nature, prefer to be won over
gently. If woman is forced to submit to rough handling from man
whom she scarcely knows she may come to hate sexual intercourse,
and even to hate whole male sex… or she may grow to detest her
husband in particular, and will then turn to another man.”35

Vatsyayana then gives detailed example of courtship of newly
married bride by her husband, which would win approval of most
modern psychologists.

The erotic life of ancient India was generally heterosexual.

Homosexualism of both sexes was not wholly unknown; it is condemned
briefly in lawbooks, and Kāmasūtra treats of it, but cursorily, and
with little enthusiasm. Literature ignores it. In this respect ancient India was
far healthier than most other ancient cultures. Another unpleasant feature of
ancient civilizations, eunuch, was also rare, though not completely
unknown. Castration, whether of men or animals, was disapproved of, and
harems were generally guarded by elderly men and armed women.



DIVORCE
From point of view of Sacred Law marriage was indissoluble,
once seven steps had been taken together. Even if not consummated it
could not be annulled, and divorce was quite impossible. An errant wife lost
most of her rights, but her husband was still responsible for her bare
maintenance if it was demanded, and she was not entitled to remarry. The
lawbooks vary in their attitude to adulterous wife; generally if she had
wilful intercourse with man of base caste her lot was hard; Manu36 and
some other sources even lay down that she should be torn apart by dogs.

But [Page 173] adulteress who strayed with man of higher caste was
more fortunate; most authorities agree that she should be made to wear dirty
clothes, sleep on ground, and eat only enough food barely to sustain life,
until her next menstruation; thereafter she might be restored to her
husband’s bed and her old position in household.

Though religious lawbooks leave no room for divorce, the
Arthaśāstra37 shows that it was possible in early times, at least in marriages
not solemnized by religious rites. In this case divorce was allowed by
mutual consent on grounds of incompatibility, and one party might obtain
divorce without consent of other if apprehensive of actual physical
danger from his or her partner. Arthaśāstra would allow divorce even
after religious marriage to wife who has been deserted by her husband,
and lays down waiting periods of from one to twelve years, which vary
according to circumstances and class.38 These provisions, however, do not
appear in later lawbooks, and were probably forgotten by Gupta times,
when divorce became virtually impossible for people of higher classes.

Among many lower castes, however, divorce is still permitted by custom,
and this must also hv been case in earlier days.



POLYGAMY
The ordinary people of India, as of every other part of world, were
generally monogamous, though even in time of Ṛ g Veda polygamy
was not unknown. Kings and chiefs were almost invariably polygamous, as
were many brāhmaṇs and wealthier members of lower orders.

Polygamy, in ordinary circumstances, was not encouraged by earlier
legal literature. One Dharma Sūtra39 definitely forbids man to take a
second wife if his first is of good character and has borne him sons. Another
later source states that polygamist is unfit to testify in court of law.40
The Arthaśāstra 41 lays down various rules which discourage wanton
polygamy, including payment of compensation to first wife. The
ideal models of Hindu marriage r hero Rama and his faithful wife
Sita, whose mutual love was never broken by rivalry of co-wife.

However, polygamous marriages r so frequently mentioned that we may
assume that they were fairly common among all sections of community
who could afford them.

A husband was told to treat his wives alike, but this was rule which
could hardly be enforced by law and which was usually psychological
impossibility. Tied to her husband’s home, first wife often felt bitterly
the happiness of her rival.

[Page 174] “Grief of man who loses all his wealth,
and of him whose son is slain;
grief of wife who has lost her lord,
and of him whom king has made captive;
grief of childless woman,
and of him who feels breath of tiger at his back;
grief of wife whose husband has married another woman,
and of one convicted by witnesses in court—
these griefs r all alike.”42
Several of courtly dramas deal with jealousy of king’s senior
wife towards latest object of her lord’s affections, but they invariably
end on happy note, with acceptance by old queen of her younger
rival. Polygamous households were not necessarily unhappy, and first
wife might console herself, if she had male children, with knowledge
that she was chief wife, mistress of household, entitled to the
first place beside her husband at family rites.

If polygamy was common, its reverse, polyandry, was not wholly
unknown, though it was impossible for ordinary people of respectable class
in most parts of India. “For brother to take wife of brother,” writes one
legal text, “is great sin, though in other lands it is even known to marry a
girl to an entire family”.43 locus classicus of ancient Indian polyandry
is Mahabharata, where heroes, five Pandava brothers, shared
their wife, Draupadi, in common. Lawyers were hard put to it to explain
this abnormal matrimonial arrangement, but it is well known among the
Mongolian hill tribes to this day, and also among certain low castes in the
Deccan. There r few other references to polyandry here and there in
Indian literature.

Among Nayyars of Malabar practice prevailed until comparatively
recent times, no doubt survival of remote antiquity, which was different
from group marriage of Himalayan tribes, and was connected with
the local matrilinear family system. girl was married, as sop to Āryan
convention, to man hired for purpose; marriage was not
consummated and she might never see her husband again. She remained in
the family home, and fact of her marriage was published; when it
became known, she was courted by eligible men of neighbourhood,
from whom she chose her true husband, often Nambūidiri brāhmaṇ, who
was accepted without ceremony. children of union took their
mother’s name, and inheritance passed through her line, though the
eldest male of family acted as head of house. husband had no
rights over his wife’s family at all, and might take less interest in his
children [Page 175] than did their maternal uncle. He might be discarded by
the mother of his children and replaced by another suitor, though real
promiscuity on her part was frowned upon. Malabār system of
marumakkattāyam shows that pattern of matrimonial relations had more
variety than allowed by legal texts.

In his efforts to produce son man might without slur on his character
take second wife, if his first was barren, and so on indefinitely; indeed in
these circumstances polygamy was religious duty. If husband was
sterile or impotent he had to take further measures. In last resort he
would appoint close relative, usually brother, to produce offspring on his
behalf. From several stories in Epics and elsewhere it appears that holy
men of special sanctity were also often in demand for this purpose, and
practices of this kind r said to take place occasionally even at present
day.

Similarly, if husband died without producing male issue his brother
might act on his behalf. This practice of levirate ( niyoga) was well known
in many ancient societies, and references to it r common in early Indian
legal literature. Before beginning of Christian era, however, it began
to be disapproved of, and medieval writers include it among now
forbidden kalivarjya customs, which were permitted in earlier ages.



OLD AGE AND DEATH
According to letter of Sacred Law, when householder’s hair
turns white, and he sees his sons’ sons, he should become hermit, either
leaving his wife to care of his children or taking her to forest with
him. There, living in little hut on alms of villagers or food collected
from wilds, he should perform regular rites at his sacred fire and study
the Upanisads, in order to raise his soul above earthly things. He may add to
his hardships by deliberate selfmortification. “In summer he should sit
exposed to heat of five fires, in rainy season he should live under the
sky, in winter he should wear wet clothes, and so he should gradually
augment his hardships.”44 This is stage of life of vānaprastha, the
forest hermit.

Before death there is yet another stage through which to pass. When all
last attachments to worldly things hv passed away hermit may leave
his forest retreat, give up performance of all ceremonies, and become a
homeless wanderer ( sannyasin), with nothing but staff, begging bowl,
and few rags of clothing:
“He should not wish to die,
nor hope to live,
but await time appointed,
as servant awaits his wages….

[Page 176] “He must show no anger
to one who is angry.

He must bless man who curses him…
He must not utter false speech.

“Rejoicing in things of spirit, calm,
caring for nothing, abstaining from sensual pleasure,
himself his only helper,
he may live on in world, in hope of eternal bliss.”45
We must not imagine that more than small proportion of elderly men
followed these drastic means of achieving salvation. For ordinary man
the status of householder was enough, and he was content with hope of
a long period of conditioned bliss in heaven, followed by another happy
birth on earth-the fate assured to householder who fully maintained the
rites and ethics of Āryan. But number of elderly men who took up
asceticism was considerable, and desire of adult and married sons to
obtain control of family property no doubt encouraged asceticism of
their parents. Even today it is not unusual for an elderly man to follow the
course laid down by ancient sages, and to end his days in asceticism,
though nowadays his hermitage may be hut in family compound, or a
secluded room in his old home.

As man was born in impurity so he died in impurity. Nearly all ancient
peoples had horror of contact with corpse, and India was no exception.

No doubt idea of ritual impurity originated in very primitive belief in
demons, but it survived in advanced civilization of classical India, when
its basis was no longer properly recognized. acc to Sacred Law
mourners must avoid all close contact with outsiders for fear of carrying
pollution; they must submit to rigid dietary restrictions, and sleep on the
ground; they must not shave their hair, or worship gods. caṇḍālas,
who had duty of laying out and shrouding body and carrying it to the
cremation ground, were most inauspicious of creatures, and lowest
of low.

The funeral ceremonies ( antyesti) were last of many sacraments
which marked stages of man’s life. acc to most favoured
Āryan custom corpse was carried to burning ground as soon as
possible after death, followed by mourners, eldest leading; it was
cremated, to accompaniment of sacred texts; mourners
circumambulated pyre, not in auspicious clockwise direction, but
anti-clockwise; then they bathed in nearest river, tank or lake, and
returned home, this time led by youngest. [Page 177] On third day
after cremation charred bones of dead were gathered up and
thrown into river, preferably Ganges.

For ten days after cremation libations of water were poured for the
dead, and offerings of rice-balls ( piṇḍ a) and vessels of milk were made for
him. On death man’s soul became miserable ghost ( preta), unable to
pass on to World of Fathers or to new birth, and liable to do harm
to surviving relatives. With performance of last antyesti rite on
the tenth day it acquired subtle body with which to continue its journey,
speeded on its way and nourished in after-life with pindas offered at
periodical sraddha ceremonies. With tenth day, mourners ceased to
be impure, and resumed their normal lives.

This funeral ceremony was that followed by upper classes in ancient
India, and is no different from that of present-day Hinduism. There were
other funeral customs, however. Harappā people buried their dead,
while early Āryans did not throw charred remains into river, but
buried them, in case of important people under large barrow. Small
children, whose bodies do not carry same impurity as those of their
elders and who r not full members of Āryan community, r still often
buried, as r ascetics and members of some low castes in South India.

These customs hv probably survived from very early days. In most
literary references śmaśāna, or cremation ground, is described as
covered with putrefying corpses, and haunted by dogs and vultures, rather
than as scene of cremation. descriptions of such places show that
many people in ancient India did not cremate their dead, but, like the
Zoroastrians of Persia, merely abandoned their bodies to wild beasts. No
doubt economic considerations played big part in this practice, especially
in those parts of country where timber was scarce; even to this day the
poorer Indians must be content with an exiguous funeral pyre, and their
corpses r often not completely burnt.



WOMEN
A woman, acc to most authorities, was always minor at law. As a
girl she was under tutelage of her parents, as an adult, of her husband,
and as widow, of her sons. Even under liberal rules of Buddhism a
nun, however advanced in faith, was always subordinate to youngest
novice among brethren. Early lawbooks assess woman’s wergeld as
equivalent to that of śūdra, whatever her class.

Most schools of law allowed woman some personal property [Page
178] ( stridhana) in form of jewellery and clothing. Arthaśāstra
allowed her also to own money up to 2,000 silver panas, any sum above this
being held by her husband in trust on her behalf.41 husband had certain
rights over his wife’s property; he might sell it in dire emergency, and he
might restrain her from giving it away wantonly, but for practical purposes
it was her own, and when she died it passed not to her husband or to her
sons, but to her daughters. Thus property rights of women, limited
though they were, were greater than in many other early civilizations. In
fact women sometimes possessed more than was usually allowed to them
by rules of stridhana. Jaina tradition mentions potter-woman of the
town of Śrāvastī who owned pottery with one hundred potter’s wheels.

Her status is nowhere mentioned, and it may be that she was thought of as a
widow, for we hv seen that some legal schools allowed widow to inherit
when there were no sons.

Women could at all times take up life of religion, though of course they
could not officiate as priests. few Vedic hymns r ascribed to women
seers, and among voluminous Buddhist scriptures is whole collection
of poems ascribed to nuns of early church, many of which r of
great literary merit (p. 456). Brhadāraṇ yaka Upaniṣ ad 46 tells of a
learned lady, Gargi Vacaknavi, who attended discussions of sage
Yājñavalkya, and for time so nonplussed him with her searching questions
that he could only jestingly reply, “Gargi, you mustn’t ask too much, or
your head will drop off!” References occur here and there in later texts to
girls occasionally attending lectures of gurus, and mastering at least part
of Vedas. By time of Smrtis, however, around beginning of
the Christian era, Vedic knowledge was closed to women, although the
heterodox sects still catered for them. tantric sects of Middle Ages,
who worshipped feminine divinities, gave women an important place in
their cult and instituted orders of female ascetics.

In general, however, women were not encouraged to take up life of
religion or asceticism. Their true function was marriage, and care of
their menfolk and children. But better class laywomen seem to have
been educated, and there r several references to works of Sanskrit poetry
and drama by women authors, of which some fragments survive. In Tamil
the early poetess Avvaiyar has left work of great merit, and splendid
martial ode describing great victory of early Cōla king Karikalan at
Veṇṇi is ascribed to an unnamed potter’s wife. 47 ladies of Sanskrit
courtly literature r often described as reading, writing, and composing
songs, and they seem to hv been well versed in arts of time.

Though from [Page 179] medieval times until very recent years arts of
music and dancing were looked on as quite unfit for respectable Indian
girls, and were practised only by low-caste women and prostitutes, this was
not case in ancient days, when well-to-do girls were taught singing and
dancing, as well as other ladylike arts such as painting and garlandmaking.

In Muslim times Hindus of Northern India adopted system of
parda, by which, from puberty to old age, women were carefully screened
from sight of all men but their husbands and close relatives. Though
such system did not exist in ancient India freedom accorded to married
women has been often exaggerated by authorities anxious to show that the
more objectionable aspects of later Hindu custom had no place in India’s
ancient culture. Certainly Ṛ g Veda depicts young men and unmarried
girls mixing freely, and gives no evidence that married women were in any
way secluded, but this text belongs to time which had long passed in the
great days of Hindu culture. Kings, at any rate, kept their womenfolk in
seclusion. detailed instructions of Arthaśāstra make it quite clear
that antahpura, or royal harem, was closely guarded, and that its
inmates were not allowed to leave it freely. It was certainly not so strictly
secluded as in later Muslim communities, however, for early Arab travellers
remarked that queens were often to be seen in Hindu courts without veils,
and many other references show that, though screened from general
public and carefully watched, royal ladies were not completely
inaccessible, as in Muslim system.

The women of upper classes were kept at distance from opposite
sex. Arthaśāstra, 37 in many ways more liberal than religious
lawbooks, lays down quite stringent rules for punishment of immodest
wives. woman who insolently takes part in games, or drinks, against her
husband’s wishes, is to be fined three paṇas. If she leaves her home without
his permission to visit another woman she is to be fined six paṇas; if she
visits man fine is twelve; while if she goes on such errands by night
the fine is doubled. If she leaves house while her husband is asleep or
drunk she is to be fined twelve paṇas. If woman and man make gestures
of sexual import to one another, or converse facetiously in secret, the
woman is to be fined twenty-four paṇas and man twice that sum. If their
conversation takes place in suspicious place, lashes may be substituted for
paṇas and “in village square caṇḍāla shall give her five lashes on
each side of body”. Thus husband had almost unlimited rights over
his wife’s movements.

Elsewhere Arthaśāstra gives evidence of different kind to show that
even in Mauryan times freedom of high-class women [Page 180] was
considerably restricted by custom. In instructions to king’s
Superintendent of Weaving we r told that staff of royal weaving
and spinning establishments should be made up of indigent women-a
motley collection, including widows, cripples, orphans, beggar-women,
women who had failed to pay fines and were compelled to work dm off,
and broken-down prostitutes. These were all of low class, and worked under
male overseers.48
It might happen that sometimes better-class woman fell on evil days,
and was compelled to earn living in this way. She was catered for,
however, in different manner. If she could still maintain maid, maid
might fetch yarn from weaving shop, and bring it back in form
of cloth; but if lady was compelled to fetch and deliver her own material
stringent precautions were laid down so that her modesty should in no way
be offended. She was to go to weaving shop in dim light of dawn,
when she would not be easily seen. official who received her work
should only use lamp to examine its workmanship; if he looked her in the
face, or spoke to her about anything other than her work, he incurred the
fine known as “the first amercement”, from forty-eight to ninety paṇas. It is
evident from these instructions that upper-class women, though their faces
were unveiled, were not normally seen in public without their menfolk.

There were certainly wide differences of custom however. Girls of good
class and marriageable age r described in story as visiting temples and
taking part in festivals without guardian or chaperone. Early Tamil
literature, more popular in character than that of Āryan North, makes
many references to free association of young men and women. Early
sculpture gives same impression. At Bharhut and Sānchū wealthy
ladies, naked to waist, lean from their balconies to watch processions,
and scantily dressed women in company of men worship Bodhi
Tree, under which Buddha gained enlightenment. We may conclude
that, while woman’s freedom was generally much restricted, it was rarely
completely taken away.

A wife, however, had little initiative. Her first duty was to wait on her
husband, fetching and carrying for him, rubbing his feet when he was
weary, rising before him, and eating and sleeping after him.

“She should do nothing independently
even in her own house.

In childhood subject to her father,
in youth to her husband,
and when her husband is dead to her sons,
she should never enjoy independence….

[Page 181] “She should always be cheerful,
and skilful in her domestic duties,
with her household vessels well cleansed,
and her hand tight on purse-strings….

“In season and out of season
her lord, who wed her with sacred rites,
ever gives happiness to his wife,
both here and in other world.

“Though he be uncouth and prone to pleasure,
though he hv no good points at all,
the virtuous wife should ever
worship her lord as god.”49
Passages of this type r frequent in literature of religious and semi-
religious type, and stories of obedient and faithful wives r numerous. The
great models of Indian womanhood r Sita, who faithfully followed her
husband Rama into exile and endured great hardships and temptations for
his sake (p. 412f), and Savitrl, who, like Greek Alcestis, followed her
husband Satyavant when he was being carried away by death-god
Yama, and so impressed god with her loyalty that he released her lord.

A medieval tale gives an even more striking example of wifely fidelity:
A woman was holding her sleeping husband’s head in her lap, as
they and their child warmed themselves in winter before blazing fire.

Suddenly child crawled towards fire, but woman made no
attempt to save it from flames, since thus she would wake her lord.

As baby crawled further into flames she prayed to fire-god
Agni not to hurt him. god, impressed by her obedience, granted
her prayer, and child sat smiling and unharmed in middle of the
fire until man awoke.50
Though early Indian mind, prone to exaggeration, perhaps overdid
the necessity of wifely obedience, her status was not without honour.

“The wife is half man,
the best of friends,
the root of three ends of life,
and of all that will help him in other world.

“With wife man does mighty deeds…
With wife man finds courage.

A wife is safest refuge….

[Page 182] “A man aflame with sorrow in his soul,
or sick with disease, finds comfort in his wife,
as man parched with heat
finds relief in water.

“Even man in grip of rage
will not be harsh to woman,
remembering that on her depend
the joys of love, happiness, and virtue.

“For woman is everlasting field,
in which Self is born.” 51
Passages like these, showing honour and esteem in which women were
held, r quite as numerous as those which stress their subservience.

Everywhere it is stated that woman should be lovingly cherished, well fed
and cared for, and provided with jewellery and luxuries to limits of her
husband’s means. She should never be upbraided too severely, for gods
will not accept sacrifice of man who beats his wife. ancient
Indian attitude to women was in fact ambivalent. She was at once goddess
and slave, saint and strumpet.

The latter aspect of her character is frequently brought out in
semireligious and gnomic literature. Women’s lust knows no bounds:
“The fire has never too many logs,
the ocean never too many rivers,
death never too many living souls,
and fair-eyed woman never too many men.”52
No one man cn satisfy libidinous woman’s cravings; unless constantly
watched she will consort with every stranger, even with hunchback, a
dwarf or cripple (p. 443), and in last resort will hv recourse to
Lesbian practices with members of her own sex. Her deception is as all-
embracing as her lust, and she is incorrigibly fickle.

Moreover, women r quarrelsome and given to pique. They quarrel with
one another, with their parents, and with their husbands. henpecked
husband, as we show elsewhere (p. 459f), was wellknown in ancient India.

Many verses in medieval anthologies depict emotion of māna, an
untranslatable word implying mixture of anger, wounded pride and
jealousy. Early Tamil literature contains whole class of poems describing
the efforts of husband to calm his wife’s anger, roused by his attentions
to rival, usually prostitute. If Sita, heroine of Rāmāyaṇ a, is
invariably meek and [Page 183] compliant before her lord, Draupadī of the
Mahābhārata cn round on her five husbands and reproach dm in no
uncertain terms. Mauryan kings were guarded by amazons trained in
the use of sword and bow, and Greeks were impressed by ferocity
with which women of some of Panjāb tribes aided their menfolk in
resisting Alexander. In later times women sometimes took part in war (p.

91), and tradition was continued among Rajputs until quite recently;
there r numerous records of masterly and warlike widows resisting the
enemies of their husbands-the last being famous Rānā of Jhānsū, whose
part in Indian Mutiny has made her national heroine of modern India.



PROSTITUTION
Ancient India contained one class of women who were not bound by the
rules and restrictions which limited freedom of highcaste wife.

These were prostitutes ( veśyā, gaṇ ikā). There were certainly many poor
and cheap prostitutes, who would end their days in beggary, or as menials
and work-women; but typical prostitute of literature was beautiful,
accomplished, and wealthy, enjoying position of fame and honour
comparable to that of Aspasias and Phrynes of classical Greece.

As in Greece higher class hetaira was an educated woman. The
authorities on erotics demand that, as well as in art immediately
essential to her profession, she should be thoroughly trained in “the sixty-
four arts”. These were stock list, which included not only music, dancing
and singing, but also acting, composition of poetry, impromptu and
otherwise, flower-arrangement and garland-making, preparation of
perfumes and cosmetics, cooking, dress-making and embroidery, sorcery,
conjuring and sleight of hand, composition of riddles, tongue-twisters
and other puzzles, fencing with sword and staff, archery, gymnastics,
carpentry and architecture, logic, chemistry and mineralogy, gardening,
training fighting cocks, partridges and rams, teaching parrots and mynahs to
talk, writing in cipher, languages, making artificial flowers, and clay
modelling.

It is hardly likely that prostitute did in fact study all arts of this
rather bizarre list, but it shows what was expected of her. If she mastered
those arts most suited to her profession brilliant future awaited her. “A
courtesan of pleasant disposition, beautiful, and otherwise attractive, who
has mastered arts… has right to seat of honour among men. She
will be honoured by king and praised by learned, and all will seek
her favours and treat her [Page 184] with consideration.”53 literature of
the Middle Ages fully bears out this statement.

Typical of such accomplished courtesans was Ambapālī, hetaira of
Vaiśālū, famous in Buddhist legend. Much that is said of this lady is
certainly legendary, but it gives significant indication of status of the
better type of courtesan in ancient India. Ambapall was immensely wealthy,
highly intelligent, and famous throughout civilized portion of India. She
was one of most treasured possessions of her city, and mixed on equal
terms with princes. On his last journey to Hills, as he passed through
Vaisali, Buddha accepted her invitation to dine in preference to that of
the city fathers, who wished to give him civic reception. Ambapālī is said
to hv become Buddhist nun, and one of most beautiful poems of the
Pali canon is attributed to her (p. 456).

The prostitute was protected and supervised by state. The
Arthaśāstra54 suggests appointment of Superintendent of Prostitutes
who should be responsible for care and supervision of palace
courtesans, inspection of brothels, and collection of two days’
earnings from each prostitute every month, as tax to government.

Teachers and trainers of prostitutes were to be given encouragement by the
state. As in all other societies, around prostitute congregated men of
doubtful character, either outside law or on its borderline-thieves,
rogues, pseudo-magicians, and confidence tricksters of all kinds. texts
on statecraft recommend that for this reason special watch should be kept
on brothels and that prostitutes should be enlisted in secret service. This
fact was noted by Megasthenes, who remarked that spies did much of
their work with help of prostitutes. From example of play “The
Little Clay Cart” it would seem that prostitute might become an honest
woman by marriage, for here heroine, high-souled courtesan
Vasantasena, ultimately becomes second wife of brāhmaṇ hero
Carudatta.

The position of courtesan merged with that of concubine. Kings
and chiefs retained numerous prostitutes in their palaces, who were salaried
servants, and who often had other duties to perform, such as attending on
the king’s person. status of these women is somewhat obscure, but
apparently they were not only at service of king, but also of any
courtier on whom he might choose temporarily to bestow them, and thus
they were not on par with regular inhabitants of his harem. Prostitutes
of this type accompanied king wherever he went, and even awaited him
in rear when he went into battle.


Another type of prostitute pursued her trade in an odour of [Page 185]
sanctity. In Middle Ages god in his temple was treated like an
earthly king; he had his wives, his ministers and attendants, and all the
paraphernalia of court-including his attendant prostitutes. These were
often children of mothers of same profession, born and reared in the
temple precincts, but they might be daughters of ordinary citizens, given in
childhood to god as pious offerings. They attended on god’s person,
danced and sang before him, and, like servants of an earthly king,
bestowed their favours on courtiers whom he favoured, in this case the
male worshippers who paid their fee to temple.
