PLATE XLIV
We hv no evidence of temple prostitution in very early times, though it
certainly existed in other ancient civilizations, and it has been suggested,
without valid evidence in our opinion, that it was known in prehistoric
Indus cities (p. 21). earliest record of religious prostitution comes from
a cave at Ramgarh, in Vindhya hills some 160 miles south of Banaras,
which contains two significant Prakrit inscriptions in script which shows
that they were written not long after days of Aśoka. first of these is
in verse:
“Poets, leaders of lovers,
light up hearts which r heavy with passion.

She who rides on seesaw, object of jest and blame,
how cn she hv fallen so deep in love as this?”
And then, in prose:
“The excellent young man Devadinna painter loved Sutanuka, the
slave-girl of god.” 55
The enamoured Sutanuka is referred to by word later regularly used
for temple prostitute— devadasi—and was evidently something of the
kind herself. There r no other clear references to devadāsīs in early
sources, however, and we must assume that they were rare until Middle
Ages. Temple prostitution was most common in South, where it
survived until recent times. wild fertility cults of early Tamils
involved orgiastic dancing, and their earliest literature shows that
prostitution was common among them; thus religious prostitution came
naturally to Dravidian. Many inscriptions and charters of medieval
South commemorating donations to temples refer specially to devadāsīs; for
instance general of Vikramaditya VI Cālukya, named Mahādeva, is
recorded as founding temple in memory of his late mother, with quarters
for most beautiful temple-prostitutes in country. 56 In his eyes, and in
those of his contemporaries, there was no incongruity in such memorial.

Prostitution, though in many contexts honoured and respected, [Page
186] was much disapproved of by Smrti writers, whose works contain
passages of warning against evils of prostitution reminiscent of those in
the Jewish Book of Proverbs. Manu and some other texts class harlot
and gambler with thief and blackmailer, and declare that brāhmaṇs must
never consort with prostitutes, on pain of very heavy penances. One source
even maintains that murderer of prostitute commits no sin and should
incur no punishment at law. 57 But, as we hv noticed in many other cases,
the secular attitude differed very greatly from religious ideal, and here it
was secular view which prevailed. By Middle Ages brāhmaṇs
who propounded the. Sacred Law might themselves be attached to temples
with hundreds of prostitutes on their staffs.



WIDOWS
In general widow could not remarry. By medieval times this rule was
applied so strictly in upper classes that it included even girls widowed in
childhood, whose marriages had not been consummated. Even custom
of niyoga, which gave childless widow chance to conceive son by
her brother-in-law (p. 175), passed into desuetude in early centuries of
the Christian era.

All evidence shows, however, that remarriage of widows was fairly
common in earlier times. Arthaśāstra admits its possibility. In the
famous old story of Nala and Damayanti, hero, who has long been
parted from his wife, is reunited with her by subterfuge of her
announcement that she presumes his death and plans to hold second
svayaṃvara. One or two minor authorities admit possibility of a
woman’s remarriage if her husband disappears, dies, becomes an ascetic, is
impotent, or loses caste;58 but later commentators explain away these
awkward references by easy fiction of kalivarjya (p. 148), and all agree
with Manu: ‘nowhere is second husband permitted to respectable
women”.59 Thus practice of widow remarriage, together with many
other healthy old customs, gradually disappeared among higher classes.

In those families which adhered to letter of law lot of the
widow was very hard. She was to all intents and purposes an ascetic,
sleeping on ground, and eating only one simple meal day, without
honey, meat, wine or salt, wearing no ornaments or coloured garments, and
using no perfumes. In medieval times widows were also expected to shave
their hair. widow had to maintain this austere regimen to end of her
days, in hope of being remarried to her former husband in next life;
her time was spent in prayer and other religious rites on his behalf, and any
breach [Page 187] of her ascetic discipline not only made her liable to a
very unhappy rebirth, but also endangered welfare of soul of her
departed husband, who might suffer in after-life for shortcomings of
his other half on earth.

Moreover widow was inauspicious to everyone but her own children.

Wherever she went her presence cast gloom on all about her. She could
never attend family festivals which played so big part in Hindu life,
for she would bring bad luck on all present. She was still member of her
husband’s family, and could not return to that of her parents. Always
watched by parents and relatives of her lord, lest she broke her vows
and imperilled dead man’s spiritual welfare, shunned as unlucky even
by servants, her life must often hv been miserable in extreme.

In these circumstances it is not surprising that women often immolated
themselves on their husbands’ funeral pyres, practice noticed with much
disapprobation by European travellers and only put down in last
century. word sati (written suttee by older English writers) means “a
virtuous woman”, and word was erroneously applied by early officials
and missionaries to satī’s self-immolation.

The history of custom takes us back to earliest cultures. Many
ancient peoples buried or burnt man’s widows, horses, and other cherished
possessions with his corpse, in order that he might hv all that he loved
and needed in other world. We know that such practices were followed
by kings of Ur, and also by ancient Chinese and some early Indo-
European peoples. One of funeral hymns of Ṛ g Veda shows that in
the earliest form of cremation rite known to us widow lay down
beside dead man, and his bow was placed in his hand; bow was
removed, and wife called on to return to land of living. 60 This
practice must look back to time long before composition of hymn,
when wife was actually burnt with her husband.

The earliest datable notice of self-immolation of sati occurs in
Greek accounts of Alexander’s invasion. One or two cases r mentioned in
the Epics, but rarely enough to show that custom was uncommon at the
time of their composition. Early Smrti literature allows it, but in general
does not strongly emphasise it. first memorial of sati is found at Eran,
near Saugor in Madhya Pradesh, where brief inscription engraved on a
pillar in A.D. 510 records tragic passing of hero and his wife in short
verses of un-Indian simplicity, which suggest epitaphs of Greek
Anthology:
[Page 188] “Hither came Bhānu Gupta, bravest man on earth,
a great king, hero bold as Arjuna;
and hither Goparaja followed him,
as friend follows friend.

“And he fought great and famous battle,
and passed to heaven, god among chieftains.

His wife, loyal and loving, beloved and fair,
followed close behind him into flames.” 61
It is known that nomads of Central Asia practised this custom, and it
may hv received some stimulus from their invasions. In any case, from
this time onwards it became more common, and there r numerous satī-
stones all over India, commemorating many faithful wives who
followed their slain lords in death.

Criticisms of custom were not unknown. It was condemned by the
humane poet Bana, in 7th century, and by tantric sects, which even
declared that woman burning herself on her husband’s pyre went
straight to hell. But some medieval writers roundly declare that satī, by
her self-immolation, expunges both her own and her husband’s sins, and
that two enjoy together 35 million years of bliss in heaven.

The living cremation of sati was always in theory voluntary, but, if
we r to judge from later analogy, social and family pressure may have
made it virtually obligatory on some high-caste widows, especially those of
the warrior class. 15th-century traveller Nicolo dei Conti states that as
many as three thousand of wives and concubines of kings of
Vijayanagara were pledged to be burnt with their lord on his death. 6
The widow was, as we hv seen, an inauspicious encumbrance to her
husband’s family, and might seriously endanger welfare of his soul by
the least breach of her vows. In polygamous household objection to
widows would be correspondingly multiplied. widow herself, if she
had no young children, might well prefer even painful death, in hope
of reunion with her husband, to dreary life of hunger, scorn, and domestic
servitude. It is thus not surprising that satīs were so common in medieval
Hindu society.

VI.

EVERYDAY LIFE: DAILY ROUND IN
CITY AND VILLAGE


THE VILLAGE
[Page 189]
WE hv no certain means of assessing population of ancient India,
since detailed registers which were kept in many kingdoms hv long
since vanished. One authority has suggested that during medieval period
the total population of Sub-continent was between 100 and 140
millions, 1 figure which seems reasonable, although based on very slender
evidence. But whatever India’s population in ancient and medieval times, it
was certainly mainly rural. At present day it is said that 85 per cent of
India’s total population dwell in villages, and we may be sure that the
proportion in past was no less, but probably more. average man in
ancient India was countryman.


Fig. xii.-A village (from relief at Amarāvatī. c. 2nd century A.D.)

No one who has travelled from Delhi to Calcutta by train could fail to be
impressed by monotony of great Gangetic Plain. shabby little
villages, often very close together, r punctuated only by rivers and canals.

They hv few trees on their outskirts, [Page 190] and here and there a
small grove divides one from another. Otherwise there is nothing to be seen
between villages but little fields separated by narrow footpaths and
occasional rough roads. But this was not case in ancient times.

Even when first Englishmen set up their trading stations in Madras,
Bombay and Calcutta there were more trees in countryside; and in the
earlier period India was much better afforested. Hsüan Tsang’s account of
India shows that, in 7th century, dense jungle lined banks of the
Ganges for many miles on end. countryside was wilder than it is today.

The tiger, now rare except in certain districts, roamed length and
breadth of land. In West lion, now almost extinct, was common.

Herds of wild elephants, carefully preserved by kings, were numerous in
regions where they r now unknown. foothills of Vindhyas and the
Ghats, now in many places almost denuded of larger trees by centuries of
woodcutting and many generations of browsing goats, were richly forested.

In fact age-old agricultural techniques of India had not yet exhausted
her soil, and her peasants had not yet torn up her forests, though in some
places, notably Magadha (South Bihār) and parts of Tamil country, this
process was almost complete by Middle Ages, if not before.

The Indian village differed very little from that of present day, but
while most villages in North r now open and undefended, in earlier
times they were usually walled or stockaded, as they r still in many parts
of Deccan. village was cluster of huts, small and large, often
grouped round well or pond, near which was small open space with a
few trees. In earlier times villages often had clubrooms, which served as
rest-houses for travellers and as centres of social life; later place of these
halls was taken by village temples. villagers formed self-
conscious community, and often had an energetic communal life. We quote
from Jātaka story.

“One day they stood in middle of village to transact village
business, and they. … [decided to] do good works; so they would get
up betimes, and go out with knives, axes and crowbars. With their
crowbars they rolled away stones on four highways; they cut
down trees which caught axles of their carts; they levelled the
irregularities [of roads]; they built an embankment and dug tanks;

they made village hall; they showed charity and kept [Buddhist]
commandments.”2
This vigorous corporate life continued into Middle Ages. Tamil
inscriptions show that village councils (p. 106) took an active interest in
the communal welfare, dug and renewed reservoirs, made [Page 191]
canals, improved roads, and cared for village shrines. This strong
sense of community was one of chief factors in survival of
Hindu Culture.

Most of villagers were free peasants, and their land was to all intents
and purposes their own, though king claimed its ultimate ownership (p.

109f). lot of peasant was hard, though perhaps poverty was not so
grinding as it later became, and agricultural indebtedness was certainly less
heavy. Most peasant holdings were small, and were usually worked by the
owner and his family; but there were few large farmsteads, owners of
which cultivated their estates with hired labour. Kings too had large
demesnes, worked by serfs and labourers, who in Mauryan times received
one and one quarter paṇa per month with maintenance. 3 Other land was let
out by owners to share-croppers in return for one half of crop.


Fig. xiii.-Country scene (from terracotta plaque found at Bhītā, near Allahabad.? 1st century
B.C.)


These landless labourers existed in Indian village at least from
Mauryan times, and probably earlier, their state an unhappy and despised
one. Illness, famine, idleness, or some other cause would sometimes compel
a peasant to sell his holding, or result in his eviction for non-payment of
tax, and he would be reduced to shame and penury as casual labourer. But
this process, whereby land tended to become concentrated in hands of a
few landowners, was more than counteracted by Indian joint family
system. On death of head of house there was usually partition
of family lands, and thus few generations might see break-up of a
large [Page 192] estate. real class of squires or large farmers never
appeared in Hindu India.

To heavy taxation, forced labour, and visitations of king and his
officers, were added periodical dearths and famines to afflict and
impoverish peasant. Though Megasthenes declared that famine was
unknown in India, he certainly wrote in this particular from inadequate
knowledge. References to famine, with its attendant horrors, r fairly
common in ancient Indian literature (p. 443). Indeed great famine is said
to hv occurred not long after Megasthenes left India, at end of the
reign of Candragupta Maurya. more energetic and conscientious kings
did what they could to prevent and relieve famine. Arthaśāstra even
suggests that king is justified in confiscating hoarded wealth of his
subjects to feed hungry. state granaries would be opened in
emergency, and charity of religious establishments and private persons
was no doubt of some help; but with such poor communications famine was
even more severe than it is now. There is reason to believe that rainfall was
rather heavier than in recent years, and pressure of population on the
means of subsistence was not as great as it has now become. Hence
outbreaks of dearth and famine were probably less frequent in ancient days,
but when they did occur they caused even greater hardship and loss of life.

Throughout our period there was gradual expansion of cultivation as a
result of pressure on land. Arthaśāstra4 suggests positive policy
of colonization, clearing of waste, and development of new villages, while
the Jataka stories show us groups of hardy peasants from overpopulated
villages cutting new settlements from jungle, and even tell of whole
villages emigrating en masse to wilds to escape attentions of
extortionate tax-collectors.

In flat plains land was cut by canals running from great rivers, and dotted with artificial reservoirs (usually referred to in Anglo-Indian jargon as “tanks”), which were made by damming smaller streams or enlarging lakes by stopping their outlets. From these water-supplies, whether natural or artificial, water was raised by counterpoised “sweeps”, and fed into smaller channels which watered fields. “Persian wheel”, turned by an ox, is nowhere clearly mentioned in early sources, though it may hv been used.

Irrigation works, often of enormous size, were undertaken by beneficent kings as religious and social duty. most famous of these reservoirs was that of Girnar, history of which has come down to us, thanks to two inscriptions on site (pp. 62, 104). We do not know when great embankment, over 100 feet thick at base, finally crumbled. Probably largest achievement of Indian [Page 193] irrigation until recent years was lake at Bhojpur, near Bhopal, built in middle of 11th century by Bhoja Paramara, king of Dhara. This too has vanished; embankment was breached by Muslims in 15th century, and has never been restored; but it is evident from those traces which remain that lake originally covered no less than 250 square miles.5 In extreme north of India we read of Suyya, great engineer in service of king Avantivarman of Kashmīr (9th century), who “made streams of Indus and Jhelam flow acc to his will, like snake-charmer his snakes”. In south, at end of our period, Paes saw building of mighty tank at Vijayanagara, embankment of which, he says, was crossbow-shot wide. first efforts at its construction were unsuccessful, so King Kṛṣṇa Deva Raya ordered great human sacrifice of prisoners to appease gods, and finished work with labour of 20,000 men.

Most of larger irrigation works of Hindu India hv now vanished,
but in Ceylon ancient reservoirs of enormous size still exist (pl. III a),
though canal systems which they served hv largely disappeared, and
are only now being repaired. After many centuries of neglect, recent
governments, both in India and Ceylon, hv begun to redevelop the
irrigation systems without which tropical agriculture cannot flourish, and
which were among first concerns of kings of ancient times.



AGRICULTURE AND STOCKBREEDING
The staple corn crops of ancient India were, as they r today, wheat and
barley in cool north and elsewhere as winter crops, rice in irrigated
plains, and millet in dryer lands, such as parts of Deccan Plateau,
where rice would not grow. Among other crops sugar cane was widely
grown, and sugar exported to Europe, while leaf vegetables and gourds of
various kinds were grown nearly everywhere, as was sesamum, much
valued for its edible oil. Numerous types of peas, beans and lentils were
grown everywhere. South India, especially Keraḻa (Malabar), grew many
spices, particularly pepper, cardamom, ginger and cinnamon, which were
carried all over India and exported to Europe. Himalayan foothills
produced precious saffron. Cotton was at all times staple textile
crop.

Of fruits pride of place was taken by mango, which was grown in
orchards and much valued. small Indian banana, or plantain, was also
grown in damper parts of land. coconut was comparatively late
importation from S.-E. Asia, and is not mentioned [Page 194] in early
sources, though it was known in Middle Ages. In coastal areas were
grown palmyra and talipot palms, which provided India’s chief writing
material, and also alcoholic drinks now known as toddy and arrack.

Another valued palm was areca, whose hard, slightly narcotic nut,
broken up, mixed with lime and other ingredients, and wrapped in leaf
of betel vine, formed tāmbūla, or chewing quid, which was
introduced into Northern India from South early in Christian era,
and has ever since been most popular source of post-prandial solace to the
Indian. date palm was grown in dryer regions of West, but is
little mentioned in literature. sour fruit of tamarind was much used
to flavour curry. grape, introduced from Persia with almond and
walnut, was cultivated in Western Himalayas. Sandal and other trees
provided much-prized fragrant woods; these trees mostly grew in South.

The Greek travellers were most impressed by fertility of India’s soil
and energy and ability of her cultivators. modern traveller’s
impressions r diametrically opposite, but Greeks judged Indian
agriculture by standards lower than ours, and soil was less exhausted
then than now. Greeks found it great source of wonder that India
produced two crops year. In wetter parts of land two crops
might even grow without irrigation, while in plains summer crop of
rice would grow during monsoon, and second irrigated crop in dry
season.

Ancient India knew use of manure, and Arthaśāstra lays down
several rules for management of king’s farms which indicate well-
developed agricultural technique. Indian peasant of today is so
conservative in his methods that we may assume that ordinary villagers
of ancient days cultivated land much as they do now, ploughing with
shallow wooden ploughs drawn by oxen, harvesting with sickles, threshing
with oxen, and winnowing by tossing their corn in wind. Iron
ploughshares were certainly known, however, for they r mentioned in
literature.

The basic livestock of peasant was cattle, used for ploughing,
transport and food. Villages employed communal cowherd, who drove the
cattle, branded with their owners’ marks, to waste beyond ploughed
fields every morning, and returned with dm at dusk. We hv no means of
comparing yield of cattle of ancient days with that of their scraggy
modern counterparts, but as there was more pasture and waste it may have
been better. Milk and curd were important articles of diet, as was ghee
( ghrta), made from melted butter by skimming off solid fat, and leaving
only liquid butter-oil, which would keep indefinitely in hot climate.

[Page 195] inviolability of cow was of slow growth. Though
there seems to hv been some feeling against killing of cows even in
Vedic times, Asoka did not forbid slaughter of cattle, and oxen, at any
rate, were killed for food even later. But Arthaśāstra refers to the
existence of herds of aged, diseased and sterile cattle, 6 and it therefore
appears that before Christian era cattle were normally allowed to die a
natural death, at least in some parts of country. same work suggests
that those who kill cattle should be put to death, but from context it is
clear that this prescription applies only to killers of cattle stolen from the
royal herds.

As well as cattle owned by cultivating peasants there were large herds
belonging to professional herdsmen, who led semi-nomadic life in the
wilder parts of country. One important tribe of these people, the
Abhiras, which dwelt in widely scattered localities of South Rajasthan,
Malwa and Sind around beginning of Christian era, was perhaps
responsible for development of cult of Kṛṣṇa in his pastoral aspect,
and Abhira chiefs set up short-lived kingdom in N.-W. Deccan on the
ruins of Sātavahānas.

Other domestic animals included buffalo, second only to ox as a
beast of burden, and favourite victim of sacrifices to goddess Durga,
whose cult became very popular in Middle Ages. goat was bred
widely, as was sheep in cooler districts. fine goats’ wool fabric
of Kashmīr was known and used widely in Northern India, and heavier
sheep’s and yaks’ wool blankets were exported in small quantities from the
hills to Northern Plains, where winter nights r usually cold enough
to make their comfort pleasant. domestic pig was also known, though it
did not play very important part in rural economy.

Horses were bred chiefly in Sind and North-West. They would not
breed well in Deccan, and were regularly imported by sea from Sind,
Persia and Arabia to ports of Western India. horse was always a
luxury animal, used chiefly by warrior class. For ordinary people the
chief means of conveyance was ox, of which certain varieties could
draw carts at considerable pace. kings of Vijayanagara delighted in
watching races of light carts to which an ox and horse were yoked.

The elephant was certainly tamed by time of Buddha. It rarely
breeds in captivity, and therefore it had to be hunted and captured alive.

Special forest tracts were designated as elephant preserves, inhabited by
trackers, hunters and tamers, in employ of king. Generally the
ownership of elephants was confined to kings and chiefs, and peasants
living in vicinity of elephant [Page 196] forests must hv cursed the
depredations of these beasts, which would frequently leave jungle to
raid clearings.

The camel is not often mentioned, but it was certainly known and used as
a beast of burden in dryer parts of country, and by Middle Ages
was also found in Deccan. Some medieval dynasties employed the
camel in war. mule and ass were other common beasts of burden.

The half-wild pariah dog was as common in early India as it is today, and
dogs were also used in hunting. In hills special breed of large dog,
perhaps resembling modern Tibetan mastiff, was famous beyond the
bounds of India. Persian emperor Artaxerxes I (465–424 B.C.) is said by
Herodotus to hv exempted inhabitants of four Babylonian villages
from taxation in return for their breeding Indian dogs for war and hunting.

These dogs were also known in Egypt of Ptolemies. dog is only
once mentioned with respect and affection in Indian literature, and was
rarely if ever treated as pet. exception occurs in Mahābhārata,
where five Pandava brothers and their wife Draupadi take their dog with
them on their final pilgrimage to heaven, and eldest brother Yudhisthira
refuses to enter without his faithful friend. It has been suggested that the
episode shows Iranian influence, for with Zoroastrians dog was a
sacred animal. domestic cat is rarely mentioned.

The hunting leopard or cheetah ( citraka) is only referred to as wild
beast until Middle Ages, and similarly hawk was not tamed in early
times. Hawking and hunting with cheetahs did not become popular among
the ruling classes until 11th century, and custom may hv been
learnt from Muslims.

The fowl was known, though eggs played but small part in diet of
early India. peacock, in earlier times, was certainly used as food, and
was favourite dish of emperor Aśoka, 7 until he adopted vegetarian
diet. We read of whole villages of peacockrearers, who supplied their birds
to kings and wealthy people, at first largely for food, but later chiefly for
ornament. Several other ornamental fowl, especially ruddy sheldrake or
brahmany duck ( cakravāka) were kept in parks of rich, and parrots
and mynahs were very popular as pets, especially with ladies, who are
referred to as devoting long hours to teaching birds to talk.

Silkworms were bred and reared, chiefly in Bengal and Assam. It has
been suggested by some that silk was known even in Vedic times, and silk-
making moths were certainly indigenous to India; but it is probable that silk
was first introduced to India from China by way of Burma Road, in the
second half of 1st millennium B.C. [Page 197] earliest certain
references to silk r found in Buddhist scriptures, and in the
Arthaśāstra, where it is called cinapatta, “the Chinese cloth”. In 2nd

century B.C. Chinese traveller Chang K’ien found that Chinese silk was
imported into Bactria by way of India, and this suggests that even at this
time Indians had not yet fully mastered art of spinning and weaving
fine silks, which they certainly did later. Besides silkworm another
insect of commercial importance was lac-insect, which provides both
the resin used for shellac (and in India for articles of ornament), and also
the dye known as “lake-dye.”


Raymond Burnier, “Hindu Medieval Sculpture”, La Palme, Paris
Apsaras. Khajurāho. 10th–11th century A.D.

PLATE XLVIII


THE WILD TRIBES
In Himalayan foothills and remoter parts of Vindhyas and the
Deccan wild tribes still exist. Most of dm r now partly civilized and
Hinduized, but some, though happy folk, knit together by tribal custom into
solid, self-supporting and self-sufficient communities, still preserve vestiges
of ferocious and barbaric tradition. Gonds of Eastern Deccan
offered human sacrifices at their fertility ceremonies until well into last
century, victims often being unfortunate villagers kidnapped from the
more civilized settlements, while head-hunting among Nagas of Assam
is even now not completely stamped out.

At one time, of course, practically whole of India was inhabited by
such peoples, and in ancient and medieval times they were more numerous
and occupied wider area than at present. From earliest invasions they
waged losing battle against advancing culture of Āryans, and at all
times they were source of danger to outposts of civilization in the
vicinity of their lands. brief statement of Asoka’s policy towards the
forest tribes (p. 53f) throws flood of light on ruthless policy of earlier
kings towards them. Many primitive peoples were exterminated and many
more lost their identity in course of growth of Hindu civilization; but
some accepted suzerainty of their civilized overlords, and retained their
ancestral lands. Arthaśāstra mentions such people as useful in time of
war. Many of these tribes came more and more under influence of
Āryan ways, and their tribal cults were roughly assimilated to Hinduism by
wandering brāhmaṇs. Such tribes were undoubtedly ancestors of many
lower Hindu castes of later times. Some primitive tribes may well have
learnt enough from Āryans to become powerful, and it has been
reasonably suggested that more than one important medieval dynasty
originated in such way.

At all times, however, uncivilized tribal peoples continued to exist [Page
198] in outlying districts in virtual independence, perhaps occasionally
paying tribute in kind to representative of their overlord. last great
king of Hindu India, Krsna Deva Raya of Vijayanagara, mentioned dm in
a brief textbook on government in Telugu, Āmuktamālyada. When the
forest folk multiplied in kingdom, he wrote, they caused no little trouble
to king and his subjects; but, like Asoka, he advocated fair and honest
treatment towards them. “If king grows angry with them, he cannot
wholly destroy them, but if he wins their affection by kindness and charity
they serve him by invading enemy’s territory and plundering his forts.”8
At all times wild tribesmen were danger to settled villagers in
the outlying parts of country. In medieval literature, both in Sanskrit and
the Dravidian vernaculars, r references to these wild raiders pillaging
crops and herds and houses, and capturing victims for human sacrifice. The
area of their operations was gradually pushed back, and as more and more
primitive tribes were assimilated to Hindu order they became gradually
less dangerous; but throughout period covered by this book they were a
source of fear in many parts of India, bogey men with which mothers
frightened their naughty children. No doubt many of characteristics of
the demons and malevolent spirits of Hindu mythology, Nagas, YaKṛṣṇas,
Raksasas and like, were acquired from wild tribes (p. 317f).



THE TOWN
By time of Buddha, there were small towns all over North India,
and some, such as Kasi (Banaras) and Kauśāmbī, had an antiquity of
centuries; but even at this time large cities were few. acc to an
ancient Buddhist tradition, at time of Buddha’s “Great Decease” the
disciple Ananda said that he regretted that his master was to die in so small
a town as Kuśinagara, and mentioned six cities which he considered
important enough for Buddha to die in: Śrāvastī, Campā, Rājagrha, Sāketa
(later generally known as Ayodhyā), Kauśāmbī, and Kāśī. These were
evidently greatest cities of 5th century B.C., but their sites r still not
wholly excavated, and we hv no good means of judging their size, except
in case of one of them. This is Rajagrha, walls of which still remain,
and show that fortified area had perimeter of twenty-five miles. The
whole area was not built upon, but Rajagrha was garden city, with a
central core, and houses in suburbs surrounded by extensive parks and
fields.

Pataliputra in time of Mauryas, acc to Megasthenes, [Page
199] was long narrow city, stretching nine miles along bank of the
Ganges, and reaching only one and half miles inland. It was no doubt
mainly built-up, unlike Rajagrha, which covered larger area but must have
had smaller population. At end of our period Paes states that
Vijayanagara was larger and more populous than Rome and contained
100,000 houses, from which we may infer that its population was at least
half million, and probably more.

At time of writing several small excavations hv been made at
various Indian city sites, but only one such site, and that not representative,
has been excavated sufficiently to reveal plan of city. This is
Taksasila, where two cities hv been discovered, one dating from time
of Achæmenid kings of Persia and other from Greco-Bactrian
period. Both were built on either side of broad main street, and larger
houses of both had central courtyards, in manner traditional in India
from days of Harappā Culture; but in other respects two were

very different. first city, known to archæologists as Bhir Mound, shows
no trace of town planning; on irregular and crooked main street opened
a maze of narrow alleys, ramifying in all directions at whim of many
private builders. second city, known as Sirkap, had fine main street
some twenty feet wide, running due north and south, with lesser [Page 200]
roads running off it at right angles and at regular intervals; it was evidently
strictly planned.


Fig. xiv.-An ancient Indian city, c. 2nd-1st century, B.C. (based on evidence of contemporary
sculpture). (Reproduced from Percy Brown’s “Indian Architecture (Buddhist and Hindu period),”
published by D. B. Taraporevala Sons & Co. Ltd., Bombay)
We cannot attribute regular layout of Sirkap wholly to orderly
Greeks. Two thousand years before their arrival in India cities of
Mohenjo Daro and Harappā had been laid out on similar regular lines, and
there is little doubt that other Indian cities were carefully planned. It was by
no means uncommon for powerful king to build wholly new capital, and
this would give much scope to town-planner. Arthaśāstra9 gives
detailed instructions for establishment of such new city. It advises a
square gridiron plan, divided into wards or sectors by six main roads, three
running north and south, and three east and west. chief temples were to
be located in centre, and different classes of community were to be
segregated in separate wards. fortified city of Sisupalgarh was certainly
built as an almost exact square of nearly mile on each side (pl. XIa), but it
has not been sufficiently excavated to ascertain whether street plan
conformed to Arthaśāstra’s scheme.10 It is possible that northern
city of Ahicchatra in Uttar Pradesh did so approximately, but here again the
excavated portions r not sufficient to tell with certainty.

The city had two foci, palace and temple. Of ancient Indian palace
architecture we know little; fragments of highly polished columns of
the Mauryan palace at Pataliputra, and large building at Taksasila which
may hv been palace, r all that hv survived except from very late
period; but from this and other evidence it would seem that palace was
usually situated in or near centre of city, and that it was often
defended by fortifications as sort of citadel.

Temples hv survived better, though we hv no Hindu temples from
pre-Gupta times. In temple religious sentiments of people were
largely concentrated. From temple came great and splendid religious
processions which filled and still fill heart of ordinary Hindu with
almost superhuman exaltation. temple, especially if it was great and
famous temple in one of sacred cities, 1 was itself city in miniature in
the medieval period (fig. xv). It was enormously wealthy, and source of
wealth to town from many pilgrims who visited it. Such temple
was great landowner, with many employees, such as priests, musicians,
attendants, and dancing girls for temple services, staff of scribes and
accountants, and many craftsmen and labourers. Often [Page 201]
temple maintained schools and refuges for sick men and animals; it
dispensed charity to beggars, and relieved poorer citizens in time of
distress and famine. Like medieval European monastery it might grant
land and privileges to its servants in princely wise. great temple,
especially in Deccan, was corporate body which often played bigger
part in life of ordinary citizen than civil government. larger
Buddhist and Jaina monasteries were similarly influential in their own
districts, though they were usually located outside big cities.

PLATE L
From literary sources, and from evidence of sculpture and painting,
we cn get some idea of houses of wealthy, which probably did not
differ greatly, except in size, from palaces of kings. typical larger
town house was one of several storeys; threestoreyed buildings seem to
have been quite common, and there r literary references to houses of
seven and even eleven storeys, though latter at least r hardly credible.


Down to Gupta times most houses, from palaces to small cottages, were
built with barrel-vaulted roofs, with gable-ends and often ornate finials (fig.

xiv). Roofs were both thatched and tiled. Later high barrel-vaulted roof
gave way to flatter type, with overhanging eaves. Larger houses of later
times usually had raised terraces or flat roofs on which members of the
household slept in hot weather. In historical times houses were not, like the
houses of Indus cities, closed in by bare [Page 202] walls, but had
windows and balconies overlooking street. In medieval period the
balconies were often screened with lattices, so that ladies of the
household might see without being seen, but balconies of houses
depicted at Bhārhut and Sānchū hv no such screens. walls were
whitewashed, and, as today, might be decorated with painted pictures and
ornamentation, both on flat and in stucco relief. usual larger house
had square courtyard surrounded by veranda, behind which were the
living quarters. Bathrooms r mentioned in literature, sometimes with
running water, probably diverted from nearby stream.


Fig. xv— temple of Srirang am. 13th-18th centuries, A.D. (Reproduced from Percy Brown’s
“Indian Architecture (Buddhist and Hindu Period)”, published by D. B. Taraporevala Sons & Co.

Ltd., Bombay)
The ancient Indian greatly loved flowers and trees. Megasthenes
describes with wonder beautiful parks surrounding palace of
Candragupta Maurya, and many references in Sanskrit literature show that
wealthy citizens had gardens attached to their houses, and often larger parks
in suburbs containing pavilions in which they spent much of their
leisure. There r references in poetry to artificial hillocks ( krīdāśaila),
which suggest that landscape gardens of Japanese type were sometimes
laid out.

As in all hot climates an expanse of water was an almost essential feature
of garden, and parks of wealthy contained artificial lakes and
pools, often with fountains, and with steps leading down to dm for
bathing. further refinement, for cooling air in hot season, was the
“water-machine”( variyantra), which, from description of poet
Kālidāsa, 11 seems to hv been sort of revolving spray, rather like that
used to water lawns at present day. In bathing pools citizens
would cool themselves in hot weather, and literature contains many
references to kings and heroes playing in water with their wives and
concubines. We also read of subterranean chambers at one end of such
bathing tanks, 12 cooled by water surrounding dm on all sides, in which
the tired bather might rest. Another feature of pleasure garden which
was looked on as almost indispensible was swing, in which adults of both
sexes took delight. Gardens were watered by channels which led from the
main tank to trees and flower beds.

Specially loved were flowering trees, which r very frequently
mentioned in poetry, especially asoka (Saraca indica), smallish tree
bearing mass of lovely scarlet or orange blossoms, which, it was said,
would only flower if kicked by beautiful woman; other favourites were
the tall pale-flowered sirisa ( Albizzia spp. ), fragrant, orange-flowered
kadamba ( Anthocephalus cadamba), and red kiṃśuka ( Butea frondosa);
the banana ( kadalī) was grown for ornament as well as for its fruit. Bushes
and creepers were also much loved, especially jasmine, of which there
were many varieties, and [Page 203] white atimukta (Hiptage
madablota); other popular trees were campaka (Michelia champaca),
with very fragrant yellow flowers, and hibiscus, or China rose ( japā).

Most beloved of all flowers, and subject of much religious and other
symbolism, was lotus or water-lily, in its many varieties. This beautiful
flower poets never tired of mentioning, giving it dozens of synonyms
and epithets. rose, common enough in North India today, was
apparently unknown, and was probably introduced by Muslims.

As well as private gardens of rich there were public gardens and
parks, often mentioned in story. In vicinity of most cities were groves
which were favourite resorts of townspeople. Asoka took pride in
the fact that he had planted such groves for recreation of man and beast,
and some other kings r recorded as having followed his example.

Of life and homes of city poor we r told little in literature, but
the cottages here and there depicted in early sculpture are, like larger
houses, barrel-roofed, and apparently one-roomed. We must assume that the
poorer folk dwelt, as they do today, in huts made of wood, reed or mud
brick, and thatched with straw. Many no doubt had no homes at all, but
slept in odd corners of city with their few possessions around them.

Efforts were made by more energetic authorities to provide some
amenities for poorer citizens. Arthaśāstra suggests that public
well should be provided for every ten families. same text recommends
a fixed tariff of fines for leaving rubbish in streets, and stringent
precautions against fires; every home was to keep elementary fire-fighting
equipment in readiness, and on an outbreak of fire all able-bodied citizens
in neighbourhood were liable to be called on to help put out flames.

The city authorities were to provide drainage for surface water, and fines
were to be imposed for blocking drains.13 We cannot tell how far these
recommendations were put into practice, but it is hardly likely that they had
no basis whatever in fact.

Undoubtedly most remarkable description of an ancient Indian city is
contained in early Tamil poem Garland of Madurai, said to have
been written in honour of 2nd century Pāṇḍyan king Neduñjeliyaṉ, but
probably century or two later. After long panegyric on king, poet
describes various regions of his kingdom, and concludes with an
account of his capital city, Madurai. This is too long to quote, but we must
at least summarize this part of lovely poem, which has realism rare in
the literature of North.

The poet enters city by its great gate, posts of which are
carved [Page 204] with images of goddess Laksmi, and which is
grimy with ghee, poured in oblation upon it to bring safety and
prosperity to city it guards. It is day of festival, and city is gay
with flags, some, presented by king to commemorate brave deeds,
flying over homes of captains, and others waving over shops
which sell gladdening toddy. streets r broad rivers of people,
folk of every race, buying and selling in market-place or singing to
the music of wandering minstrels.

A drum beats, and royal procession passes down street, with
elephants leading to sound of conchs. refractory beast breaks his
chain, and tosses like ship in an angry sea until he is again brought to
order. Chariots follow, with prancing horses and fierce footmen.

Meanwhile stall-keepers ply their trade, selling sweet cakes,
garlands of flowers, scented powder and betel quids. Old women go
from house to house, selling nosegays and trinkets to womenfolk.

Noblemen drive through streets in their chariots, their gold-
sheathed swords flashing, wearing brightly-dyed garments and wreaths
of flowers. From balconies and turrets many jewels of the
perfumed women who watch festival flash in sunlight.

The people flock to temples to worship to sound of music,
laying their flowers before images and honouring holy sages.

Craftsmen work in their shops-men making bangles of conch shell,
goldsmiths, cloth-dealers, coppersmiths, flower-sellers, vendors of
sandalwood, painters and weavers. Foodshops busily sell their wares-
greens, jak-fruit, mangoes, sugar candy, cooked rice and chunks of
cooked meat.

In evening city prostitutes entertain their patrons with
dancing and singing to sound of lute ( yāḻ), so that streets are
filled with music. Drunken villagers, up for festival, reel in the
roadways, while respectable women, make evening visits to the
temples with their children and friends, carrying lighted lamps as
offerings. They dance in temple courts, which r clamorous with
their singing and chatter.

At last city sleeps-all but goblins and ghosts who haunt the
dark, and bold housebreakers, armed with rope ladders, swords and
chisels, to break through walls of mud houses. But watchmen
are also vigilant, and city passes night in peace.

Morning comes with sound of brāhmaṇs intoning their sacred
verses. wandering bards renew their singing, and shopkeepers
busy themselves opening their booths. toddy-sellers again ply
their trade for thirsty morning travellers. drunkards reel to their
feet and once more shout on streets. All over city is heard the
sound of opening doors. Women sweep faded flowers of the
festival from their courtyards. Thus busy everyday life of city is
resumed.14
The ancient Indian city was source of pride to its inhabitants. One of
the most memorable records of such pride is contained in 5th century
Mandasor inscription of guild of silk-weavers, already mentioned in
another connexion (p. 149). This commemorates building and
subsequent repair by guild of splendid temple of [Page 205] Sun.

A poem recording event was composed “with great care” by one
Vatsabhatti, probably local hack-poet commissioned for occasion, and
was engraved on stone as perpetual memorial. No doubt echoing the
thought of his patrons, Vatsabhatti writes in glowing terms of his city,
“Where water-lilies r ever shaken by tremulous ripples,
and geese r as though shut in cage of pollen,
blown from lotuses, which shine in lakes,
bent by weight of their own stamens;
“Where groves r adorned with trees
bowed under burden of blossoms,
and with bee-swarms, drunk with honey,
and with women ever-singing;
“Where lovely women dwell
in houses a-flutter with flags,
most purely white, most lofty,
like fair hills of cloud that glitter with vine of lightning;
“Where other mansions, adorned with groves of swaying bananas,
lovely as high peak of Mount Kailāśa,
shine with their long roof-ridges and pavilions,
loud with noise of music, and gay with pictures.”
And so poet in fanciful language describes beauty of city, the
goodness of local king, benevolence of guild, and splendour
of new temple, until he concludes:
“As moon clear heavens,
as kaustubha2 breast of Visnu,
this fairest of temples adorns
our wholly noble city.”15


THE MAN ABOUT TOWN
We cn learn much about life of Greek and Roman bourgeoisie
from literature and archæological remains; but comparable literature of
India was less realistic, and there is no Indian counterpart of Pompeii.

Nevertheless there is enough evidence to reconstruct life of well-to-
do young Indian in some detail from secular literature, one of our most
important sources being treatise on erotics, Kāmasūtra (p. 171),
which was composed to instruct him in one of his chief recreations.

His room, we r told, 16 should contain pleasant and soft bed, [Page
206] with pure white coverlet, decorated canopy, and two pillows, one at
the foot and other at head. It should also hv divan, at head of
which perfumed unguents, flowers, and pots of collyrium should be kept on
a little table. On floor nearby should be placed cuspidor, to receive the
red expectoration caused by betel chewing, and chest for ornaments and
clothes. On wall should hang lute ( vīṇ ā), and room should also
contain drawing table, few palm-leaf books, round seat and gaming-
board. Attached to house should be an aviary, garden containing
swings, an arbour of climbing plants, and grass bank on which owner
might sit in shade with his guests.

Rising in morning man about town washes, cleans his teeth,
anoints his body with unguents and perfume, puts collyrium on his eyes,
dyes his lips with red lac, and looks at himself in mirror. Then he chews
a betel quid to sweeten his breath. He baths every day, rubs his body with
oil every other day, shaves his face every fourth day, and his whole body
every fifth or tenth day. He eats three meals daily. Much of his time is spent
in charming, graceful idleness. He amuses himself by teaching his parrots
and mynahs to talk, or by watching fighting cocks, quails or rams; he
converses with parasites who surround him. In hotter weather he
takes an afternoon nap.

He had many intellectual pleasures however. He was not merely patron
and passive admirer of arts, but was encouraged by society to be himself
creative. He should know something of sixty-four arts (p. 183). He
might be poet in his own right, and some of surviving Sanskrit poetry
is not work of professionals. Large gatherings were often held under the
patronage of kings or wealthy men for recitation of poetry, and smaller
groups would often meet together for same purpose, either at home
of one of group, or at house of courtesan. These literary parties are
mentioned in Kāmasūtra as among chief pleasures of educated
man. members of such circles might form regular social clubs, and
“should stand together in time of trouble as in prosperity, … and hospitably
entertain newcomers to their group”.17 ancient Indian, like his modern
descendant, was usually an extrovert, delighting in company of his
fellows, and warm-hearted in his friendships. immense stress laid in
sacred literature on duty of hospitality encouraged and gave religious
sanction to social propensities of time.

Sometimes literary parties were held in open air, in gardens and
groves about town, and might be diversified with cock-fighting and
bathing. educated man might also be painter; his [Page 207] sanctum,
as we hv seen, contained painting-board or easel, and Kāmasūtra
even suggests that he should hv special room for sculpture, wood-
carving and clay modelling.



AMUSEMENTS
The amusements of ancient Indian townsman were by no means all
creative or intellectual. Numerous festivals, participated in by rich and poor
alike, divided Hindu year, and were marked by merrymaking and
processions. most popular festival in early times was Festival of
Spring, in honour of Kama, Love-god, who, though he played only a
small part in thought of theologians, was evidently very popular
divinity. At this festival even respectable citizens forgot their caste
restrictions, and paraded streets scattering red powder over their
neighbours, squirting dm with coloured water, and playing all kinds of
practical jokes. festival still survives under name Holi, though the
Love-god now plays no part in it. It is clearly survival of primitive and
bloody fertility ceremony; but even at its earliest appearance grim
significance of red powder seems to hv been lost, and it was sort of
Hindu saturnalia, time of universal merrymaking, and licence of all kinds.

Though much reprobated by brāhmaṇ authors of Smtri literature,
gambling was popular at all times and among all classes except more
rigidly religious people. Six-sided dice hv been found in Indus cities,
and “Gamester’s Lament” of Ṛ g Veda testifies to popularity of
gambling among early Āryans (p. 403ff).

The word aksa in context of gambling is generally roughly translated
“dice”, but aksas in earliest gambling games were not dice, but
small hard nuts called vibhīśaka or vibhīdaka; apparently players drew a
handful of these from bowl and scored if number was multiple of
four. Later, oblong dice with four scoring sides were used; like the
European gamester Indian employed special terminology for the
throws at dice: krta (cater, four), treta (trey), dvāpara (deuce), and kali
(ace). So important was gambling in Indian scheme of things that these
four terms were applied to four periods ( yuga) of æon (p. 321).

Gambling played small but significant part in ritual of royal
consecration ceremony, and gambling hall attached to king’s palace
in later Vedic period had some magical or religious significance, though
its import is not wholly clear. Among chief men of realm, whose
loyalty was confirmed by special ceremony at consecration of king
[Page 208] (p. 42), was akṛṣṇ avāpa, or thrower of nuts or dice,
evidently organizer of royal gambling parties. plot of the
Mahābhārata hinges round great gambling tournament, at which
Yudhisthira lost his kingdom to his wicked cousin Duryodhana, and the
Epic tells similar story in episode of Nala. Arthaśāstra 18
advocates strict control of gambling, which it would confine entirely to
officially-managed gambling houses, financed by tax of five per cent of
the stakes and charge for hire of dice to gamblers, who were to be
forbidden to use their own. Stringent fines were laid down for cheating.

With dice were played board games, similar to our children’s games
such as ludo, which involved combination of chance and skill. By the
early centuries of Christian era one of these, played on board of sixty-
four squares ( aṣṭ apāda), had developed into game of some complexity,
with king-piece, and pieces of four other types, corresponding to corps
of ancient Indian army-an elephant, horse, chariot or ship, and four
footmen. original game needed four players, and their moves were
controlled by throw of dice. As game was played with pieces
representing military forces, and its strategy suggested that of campaigning
armies, it was known as caturanga, or “four corps”. In 6th century the
game was learnt by Persians, and when Persia was conquered by the
Arabs it quickly spread all over Middle East, under name shatranj,
the Persian corruption of caturanga. It developed into game for two
persons, each with two “armies”, king of one army becoming the
“general” or “minister” of other, and use of dice to control the
moves was given up. It is not quite certain whether these improvements
were made in India or Persia, but latter is more probable.

The game was learnt by crusaders from Muslims, and soon spread
over Europe. By late Middle Ages it had almost attained its modern
form as chess, “general” of Muslim game becoming queen. Thus
the world’s most intellectual game is product of three cultures, each of
which contributed something to its finished form.

Organized outdoor games were not common, except among children and
young women, who r sometimes referred to as playing ball, like Nausicaa
in Odyssey. form of polo, introduced from Central Asia, became
popular among warriors in Middle Ages, though it is little mentioned in
literature, and kind of hockey was also played. But, in general, ancient
India did not put such stress on athletics as did Mediterranean world.

Chariot racing is mentioned as early as Ṛ g Veda, and bullock racing was
popular [Page 209] in late medieval period. Boxing and wrestling are
often referred to, but were not generally hobbies of respectable young
men, but preserve of low-caste professional pugilists, who performed
for amusement of an audience. archery contest, however, was a
much-loved amusement of warrior class, and vivid descriptions of such
contests occur in Epics.

Classical sources refer to gladiatorial contests at court of Candragupta
Maurya, and in medieval Deccan duelling became frequent. The
Portuguese traveller Nuniz writes that if two nobles of Vijayanagara
quarrelled they would fight to death in presence of king and his
court. 19 Despite growth of doctrine of non-violence throughout our
period, animal fights were always very popular. favourite animals to be
pitted against each other were fierce little Indian quail ( lāvaka), cock
and ram; we also read of fights between bulls, buffaloes and elephants
(pls. LXXVII, LXXVIII b).

One form of animal contest confined to Dravidian South was the
bullfight, of which we hv vivid description in an early Tamil poem.20
This sport did not closely resemble Spanish bullfight, where scales
are heavily weighted against bull, for here bull appears to hv had
the advantage. fights were popular among herdsmen, who entered the
arena unarmed, and “embraced bull” in an attempt to master it, rather
like cowpunchers of an American rodeo. They made no attempt to kill
the bull, and it was not previously irritated, but bullfight was evidently a
sport of great danger, for poem contains gory description of a
victorious bull, his horns hung with entrails of his unsuccessful
opponents. bullfight was looked on as an ordeal to test manhood of
young men, since it is stated that girls who watched performance
would choose their husbands from among successful competitors in a
sort of Tamil svayaṃ vara. Though Tamil literature gives no evidence of
this, bullfight had certainly some ritual significance, and was connected
with fertility of crops. similar sport was practised, as part of a
religious ceremonial, by ancient Cretans, and this fact, like many others,
links Tamils with earliest civilizations of Mediterranean world.

Wrestling with young steers is still favourite pastime of some pastoral
peoples of India.

Many of amusements of ancient India were provided by professional
entertainers. As well as those who practised highly developed arts such as
drama, music and dancing, there were others who travelled through town
and village, diverting ordinary folk, who could not fully appreciate the
nuances of more developed art [Page 210] forms. We read of musicians,
bards, acrobats, jugglers, conjurors and snake-charmers, popular then as
now. As well as courtly theatre there was folk-drama, occasionally
referred to in literature, which portrayed scenes of mythology and legend in
dance, song and mime, and from which Sanskrit drama developed.



CLOTHES AND ORNAMENTS
The garments worn from Vedic times onwards did not fundamentally
differ from those of modern Indian. Like most ancient peoples living in
hot climates Indians usually wore lengths of cloth, draped around body
and over shoulders, and fastened with belt and pins. lower
garment ( paridhāna, vasana) was usually such cloth, fastened round the
waist with belt or string ( mekhalā, raśanā); and upper garment
( uttarīya) was another such length, draped shawl-wise over shoulders.

The latter garment was often discarded in home, or in hot weather,
especially by lower orders. third garment ( prāvāra) was also worn,
draped like mantle or cloak, in cold season.

This was general garb of both sexes, as it is today, and varied only in
the size and pattern of cloths and in manner of wearing them.

Sometimes lower garment was of very small proportions, or mere
loincloth (pl. LXXV), but lower garments of rich often reached
almost to feet. In early sculpture lower garment is depicted as
elaborately pleated in front, and held with long girdle, end of which
hung down in front of garment between legs (pl. XXVIa). In some
sculptures girdle appears to hv been end of cloth itself, which
might also be thrown over shoulders in manner of present day
sārī. Sometimes end of cloth was drawn between legs and
fastened at back in manner of dhotī.

Though all these garments were unstitched art of sewing was not
unknown, and women r often depicted wearing jackets or bodices
( colaka, kañcuka) (pl. LXXXI). With invasions of Śakas and
Kuṣāṇas from Central Asia trousers were introduced, and were in vogue
among ruling classes at least until Gupta times, for Gupta kings are
often shown on their coins as wearing trousers (fig. xxiv, p. 381). Kuṣāṇa
kings r shown on their coins, and in remarkable headless statue of
Kaniṣka (pls. XXXb, LXXXIIIe), wearing long quilted coats and quilted
trousers and boots of typically Central Asian type, which must hv been as
uncomfortable in temperature of over one hundred degrees as thick
European clothing worn by pioneers of East India Company. The
wearing of shirts and [Page 211] trousers seems to hv been quite common
in medieval Kashmīr and North-West. In medieval South India
goddesses and queens were often depicted as wearing what seem to be light
close-fitting trousers. cloth used for all these garments varied from
wool, worn in Northern winters, to diaphanous silks and muslins, which
showed limbs of wearer. paintings of Ajanta and Bagh show
that they were often dyed or otherwise patterned with gay stripes and
checks.

In most parts of India footwear was primarily used to protect feet
against scorching earth of Indian summer, but in Himalayas felt
boots of Central Asian pattern were worn.

On their heads men usually wore turbans, which were fastened in many
elaborate patterns (pl. XXIIIe). In early times, at least on festive occasions,
women wore large and complicated headdresses of type not seen
nowadays, but by Gupta period they r usually depicted either bare-
headed, or wearing head-veils or simple tiaralike headdresses. Orthodox
brāhmaṇs shaved whole head with exception of topknot, which
was never cut, but with other classes both sexes usually allowed their hair
to grow long. most popular coiffure with women was large bun at the
nape of neck, often ornamented with fillet or string of jewels (pl.

LXIIe). pigtail, most common at present day, though attested in the
Harappā culture and mentioned in literature, does not often appear in
sculpture until medieval period.

There is some controversy on character of women’s dress in ancient
India. Throughout our period women r depicted in painting and sculpture
as naked to waist, while on other hand great physical modesty of
modern Hindu womanhood is common knowledge. James Fergusson, one
of first serious students of ancient Indian sculpture, declared
categorically that, until Muslim conquest, Hindu women exposed their
breasts in public without least shame.21 This conclusion has, however,
been controverted.22
It is asserted that, like Greeks and Romans, Indian artist and
sculptor followed tradition of showing female form in state of semi-
nakedness, when this had no counterpart in real life. objection,
however, is hardly valid. When portraying real life, rather than mythology
or figure studies, classical artist usually draped his women. In early
sculptures of Bhārhut and Sānchū, on other hand, there is scarcely a
woman with covered breasts, even among crowds in very realistic
reliefs of Indian city life. References to bodices in literature r numerous,
and women with covered breasts do sometimes appear in painting and
sculpture; but [Page 212] in Northern Plains, and hillier parts of the
Deccan, weather is quite cool for several months of year, and use
of bodices may hv been due rather to climate than to modesty. In
Malabar, where many old customs survived long, it was quite normal until
comparatively recent times for women of Nayyar caste to appear in
public naked to waist, and same is true of island of Bali, which
adopted Hindu culture early in Christian era. In some literary sources
there r references to married women wearing veils, but there is no
evidence that these were regularly more than headcoverings, or that they
concealed form of wearer. It is only in late medieval literature that
clear expressions of need of physical, as distinct from mental, modesty
are found. Women in ancient India were considerably restricted in their
activities, and high standard of modesty was demanded of those of the
higher classes (p. 179f); but it is clear that their ideas of propriety in dress
were very different from those of their descendants.

If clothes were simple and few, ornaments were complex and many.

Gold, silver and precious stones of every available kind were always in
demand for personal adornment. Women wore jewelled ornaments on their
foreheads, and along partings of their hair. Earrings were worn by both
sexes, and ears were stretched by heavy and large ornaments, as is done
by women in Tamil country districts to this day. Ornate necklaces were
worn, and wide girdles of linked gold with hanging ropes of pearls. Bangles
and armlets were popular from days of Harappā Culture onwards,
and anklets, often set with little tinkling bells, or with their hollows filled
with rattling pebbles, were as popular then as now. Nose ornaments,
without which Indian women of older generation felt positively
undressed, r nowhere mentioned or depicted, and their use cn only have
been widely adopted after Muslim conquest. few surviving pieces
of jewellery, and representations of jewellery in sculpture and painting,
show that Indian jeweller attained very high standards in his art (pl.

LXXXIIb). It would seem that early Indian, like his modern counterpart,
would often save his money by investing it in jewellery for his wife and
himself. Even poorer people, who could not afford gold or gems, loaded
themselves with jewellery of silver, brass, glass and painted pottery, and all
classes adorned their hair, ears and necks with beautiful flowers which
India provides in abundance.

Cosmetics were used by both sexes. Chief among these was paste made
of finely ground dust of sandalwood, which was smeared over whole
body or applied in patterns, often coloured with lac and other dyes. It was
believed to cool skin in hot season. [Page 213] Collyrium or eye-
salve ( anjana), usually made of black powdered antimony, was very
popular, and, as well as enhancing beauty of eye,was thought to
prevent ophthalmia. Vermilion ( sindura), lac ( lākṣ ā), and yellow pigment
called gorocana, were used to mark beauty-spot on forehead
( tilaka), which might often be large and ornate, and which is still popular
with Indian ladies. lips, tips of fingers and toes, and palms
and soles of feet, were often dyed red with lac. Though exposed parts of
the body were often painted with complicated patterns there is no clear
evidence of tattooing, which is popular nowadays in many parts of India.



FOOD AND DRINK
When Fa-hsien visited India in early 5th century he reported that no
respectable person ate meat, consumption of which was confined to low
castes. He probably exaggerated, but certainly by this time many Hindus of
the higher classes were vegetarians. growth of vegetarianism was of
course linked with doctrine of non-violence, which was already old at
the time of Fa-hsien. It was known in days of Upanisads and was
elaborated by Buddhism and Jainism, which were largely responsible for
the gradual disappearance of greater Vedic sacrifices at which large
numbers of animals were killed and eaten. reign of Asoka is a
landmark in development of vegetarianism, for he encouraged it by his
own example, and forbade outright killing of many animals. But the
Arthaśāstra accepts meat-eating as quite normal, and lays down rules for
the management of slaughterhouses and maintenance of purity of
meat. 23 It was only with growth of Mahayana Buddhism and new
Hinduism that strict vegetarianism became widespread. Even then hunting
and meat-eating were practised by warrior class, and tantric cults of
the Middle Ages restored practice of sacrifice and meat-eating in new
form. Medical texts, even of late period, go so far as to recommend the
use of both meat and alcohol in moderation, and do not forbid eating of
beef. It is doubtful if complete vegetarianism has ever been universal in any
part of India, though in many regions it was and still is practised by most
high-caste Hindus. With prohibition of meat-eating some religious texts
included that of eating garlic and onions, objection to which arose for
obvious reasons, and was never given real religious basis; but it is very
doubtful if this ban ever had any great effect until very late period, except
on pious brāhmaṇs.

There r several references to science of cookery ( supasastra),
which was not disdained even by kings, but no ancient textbook on [Page
214] cookery has survived. From passages in literature we know that
ancient Indian cookery did not differ much from that of present day.

Meat and vegetables alike were seasoned in curries and eaten with rice,
boiled or fried. With curry and rice flat cakes of flour, modern
chapādī, were eaten, and water, milk, or curd were drunk. favourite
cooking medium was ghee, in which food was fried and which was
poured liberally over dish; poorer folk often substituted for ghee oil
of sesamum or mustard. Fruit and sweetmeats of many kinds were as
popular as they r today, but many of Indian sweets eaten nowadays,
such as jalebi, r Muslim importations.

In modern Hinduism there is strong taboo on drinking of alcoholic
beverages, and most of those who drink regularly r either very
Europeanized in their ways or of low caste. moral objection to alcohol
is very ancient, but it was long before ban became widespread, except
among brāhmaṇs. Though Asoka discouraged meat-eating his edicts say
nothing about drinking, and it is therefore evident that he had no strong
moral objections to it, though Buddhism counts drinking of spirits as
one of five cardinal sins (p. 286). In Asoka’s day Buddhism was
apparently more lax in this respect than it later became. lawbooks
condemned drinking, and Fa-hsien stated that respectable Indians did not
drink, but drinking and drunkenness r so frequently mentioned in
literature, especially in that of Tamils, that it is clear that religious
precept was not regularly followed in this particular. Only in 12th
century do we find Kumarapala, Jaina king of Gujarat, forbidding the
production and sale of liquor throughout his kingdom.

The Arthaśāstra advises manufacture of liquor in government
breweries and distilleries, and gives several brief and cryptic recipes,24
which show that there were many alcoholic drinks, some of which r not
popular nowadays; among these were rice beer ( medaka), sort of spiced
beer made of flour ( prasannā), wood-apple wine ( āsava), maireya, liquor
made of raw sugar, bark of meṣ aśṅ ga tree, and pepper, and mango
spirit ( sahakārasurā). Wine from grapes was made in North-West, and
exported in small quantities to rest of India. In South, toddy, the
fermented sap of palmyra or coconut, was staple alcoholic liquor,
and is frequently mentioned in early Tamil literature.

The Arthaśāstra, perhaps reflecting Mauryan conditions, suggests the
appointment of “superintendent of liquor”, not only to control sale and
consumption of alcoholic drinks but to organize their manufacture. text
advises stringent control of private brewing, and of taverns. Tavern-
keepers were to be instructed to make [Page 215] their establishments well-
furnished and comfortable, and to prevent their patrons from over-
indulgence; text even suggests that they should indemnify dm for any
loss sustained while under influence of liquor, and pay fine into the
bargain. Unlike most other oriental traders tavern-keepers, acc to the
Arthaśāstra, were not to be allowed to build their premises close together,
thus discouraging ancient Indian equivalent of “pub-crawling”; text
also suggests complete prohibition of consumption of alcohol “off
the premises”. taverns were often haunts of criminals, and the
king’s spies were advised to keep watchful eye on them. Arthaśāstra
evidently recognizes drinking as an evil, which cannot be wholly forbidden,
but which must be strictly controlled.



ECONOMIC LIFE
It has often been said that ancient Indian society was not an acquisitive
one. Admittedly brāhmaṇs, who claimed moral and spiritual leadership,
set themselves ideals of dignified austerity, but these ideals were not always
followed in practice. brāhmaṇ who attained good local reputation for
the efficient performance of sacrifices and domestic ceremonies might
amass considerable wealth, and if patronized by kings might become a
really rich man. Corporations of such brāhmaṇs often lived on proceeds
of large agricultural estates ( agrahāra), transferred to dm by kings, and
there r accounts of brāhmaṇ landowners living in great wealth. Other
brāhmaṇs, not sufficiently trained to teach Vedas or to sacrifice,
obtained high posts in government service, or even became wealthy by
trade. We hv seen (p. 170) that, acc to doctrine of three
aims of life, place of wealth in Hindu scheme of things was well
established.

In most early Indian literature world is viewed from angle of the
well-to-do. Poverty, it is more than once said, is living death; to serve
another for one’s keep is dog’s life, and not worthy of an Āryan. From the
time of Ṛ g Veda, which contains many prayers for riches, worldly
wealth was looked on as morally desirable for ordinary man, and indeed
essential to full and civilized life. ascetic, whether Buddhist or Jaina,
who voluntarily abandoned his wealth, performed an act of renunciation
which entitled him to utmost respect. Though by this renunciation he
assured himself of spiritual advancement, and was well on way to
salvation ( mokṛṣṇ a), fourth and ultimate aim of existence, ascetic’s
life was not that of ordinary man, and theoretical classification of
the four stages of life (p. 158f) gave ample scope in second stage to the
[Page 216] householder, who was indeed encouraged to build up family
fortunes, and to spend part of dm at least on pleasures of senses.

Thus ideals of ancient India, while not perhaps same as those of the
acquisitive West, by no means excluded money-making. India had not only
a class of luxury-loving and pleasure-seeking dilettanti, but also one of
wealth-seeking merchants and prosperous craftsmen, who, though less
respected than brāhmaṇs and warriors, were honoured in society.

Though basis of ancient Indian industry was at all times the
individual craftsman, aided chiefly by members of his own family, larger
manufactories, worked chiefly by hired labour, were by no means unknown.

Not only did Mauryan state own spinning and weaving workshops (p.

179f), but also shops for manufacture of weapons and other military
supplies, employing salaried craftsmen. larger mines were also owned
and worked by state. But though economic order approximated to a
sort of state socialism in time of Mauryas, it always left scope for
the individual producer and distributor. We read here and there of private
producers who had far transcended status of small home craftsman,
and who manufactured on large scale for wide market. Thus an early
Jaina text25 tells of wealthy potter named Saddalaputta who owned 500
potters’ workshops, and fleet of boats which distributed his wares
throughout Ganges valley; there r few other references, which
confirm that large scale production for wide market was not unknown in
ancient India, though such industrialists as Saddalaputta were no doubt
comparatively rare.

A form of industrial organization on larger scale than individual
craftsman, and probably more common than entrepreneur, was the
workmen’s co-operative group, perhaps comparable to pre-
revolutionary Russian artel; such groups r mentioned in Pali Jataka
stories and elsewhere as carrying out large scale enterprises such as the
building of temples and houses. Their existence tended to encourage
division of labour; thus one man would fashion shaft of an arrow, a
second would fix flights, and third would make and fix point.

Rules r laid down in lawbooks for punishment of breach of
contract by such co-operatives or their individual members.

Much of work of craftsman was sold at door of his workshop
direct to purchaser. Normally each craft or trade was concentrated in a
separate street or bazaar, where craftsman had his workshop, stall and
home. testimony of Megasthenes, corroborated by Arthaśāstra,
shows that in Mauryan times prices were regulated by market officials. The
latter text suggests that, as [Page 217] further effort at maintaining just

price, government officers should buy on open market when any staple
commodity was cheap and plentiful, and release stocks from government
stores when it was in short supply,26 thus bringing down price and
making profit for king into bargain. We hv no definite evidence
that this idea was ever put into effect, but it is striking that ancient Indian
political theorists anticipated by over 2,000 years plans put forward by
the Food and Agriculture Organization of United Nations for
maintaining stable level of prices of staple commodities on world-wide
scale.
