GUILDS
As well as state, another element did much to control prices and
standards of work. This was guild ( śreṇ i), form of industrial and
mercantile organization which played as big part in economy of
ancient India as it did in that of any other ancient or medieval civilization.

There r faint and uncertain references to some sort of guild organization
even in Vedic literature, but by time of composition of Buddhist
scriptures guilds certainly existed in every important Indian town, and
embraced almost all trades and industries-we even read of guild of
thieves.

The guild united both craftsmen’s co-operatives and individual
workmen of given trade into single corporate body. It fixed rules of
work and wages, and standards and prices for commodities in which its
members dealt, and its regulations had force of law, and were upheld by
the king and government. Over its own members guild had judicial
rights, which were recognized by state. guild court could, like caste
council, expel refractory member, penalty which would virtually
preclude him from practising his ancestral trade and reduce him to beggary.

We read in Buddhist literature of guild courts settling quarrels between
members and their wives, and rules of Buddhist order lay down that
a married woman may not be ordained nun without consent of her
husband and his guild. Thus guild had power not only over the
economic, but also over social life of its members. It acted as guardian
of their widows and orphans, and as their insurance against sickness. Its
powers and functions in this respect were very similar to those of caste
councils in more recent times, and, though some authorities would disagree
with us, we cannot but conclude that guilds played an important part in
the evolution of trade castes.

The guild was headed by chief, usually called “Elder” ( jyeṣṭ haka,
in Pāli jeṭṭ haka), who was assisted by small council of [Page 218] senior
members. office of Elder was usually hereditary and held by one of the
richest members of guild. In Pali scriptures Elder is invariably
described as very wealthy man, often with much influence at palace,
and counselling king himself. guilds had corporate life,
symbolized, as in medieval Europe, by possession of banners, and also
of chauris,3 ceremonial yak’s tail flywhisks which were insignia of
nobility. These and other emblems were sometimes granted by royal
charter, and were carried in local religious processions by guildsmen.

Some guilds, again like those of medieval Europe, had their own militias,
which served as auxiliaries of king’s armies in time of need (p. 128).

All over India r to be found inscriptions recording donations of
guilds to religious causes of all kinds, most famous being that of the
Mandasor silk-weavers, to which we hv already referred. guilds must
have had considerable funds to make such large donations, and no doubt
received regular subscriptions from their members, which were augmented
by fines levied on those who transgressed guild law. They sometimes
acted as bankers and trustees. There r references in legal literature to
guilds accepting deposits, and lending money at interest to merchants and
others. They would often act as trustees of religious endowments; pious
would pay sum of money to guild, on condition that it would maintain a
perpetual lamp in temple, or provide new robes annually for monks of
a Buddhist monastery. Inscriptions recording such acts of benevolence are
quite numerous, and no doubt guilds, while duly carrying out their part
of agreement, profited from transactions.

The corporate spirit of guild gave better type of craftsman and
merchant degree of self-respect which he would not otherwise have
found. There is more than one record of riots and affrays between different
guilds and trade groups; this was specially case in medieval Deccan,
where guild and caste often overlapped in function or were virtually
synonymous, and strange division of right and left hand castes led to
much friction (p. 150). fact that more than one guild of same craft is
occasionally recorded in same place suggests that guilds sometimes
broke up.



TECHNICAL ACHIEVEMENT
At all times work of Indian craftsman, however primitive and
simple his tools, has been admired for its delicacy and skill, and the
technical achievement of ancient India was far from negligible. [Page 219]
Her spinners and weavers could produce semi-transparent silks and muslins
of extreme thinness, which r clearly depicted in sculpture (pl. XXXVIb),
and which were much in demand in Roman Empire. Unlike ancient
Greece and medieval China, India developed no true ceramic art; indeed
from æsthetic point of view no pottery of historical times is as good as
the simply patterned but well designed wares of prehistoric North-West
(fig. iv); but bright hard polish of type of pottery usually called
“northern black polished ware” is very creditable technical achievement.

In working of stone on large scale India’s skill is attested by the
enormous monolithic columns of Mauryan times. Many of these bear
Aśoka’s inscriptions, but it is not certain that they were made and erected
by him; some may hv existed before his time. All r made of sandstone,
from same quarry at Chunar, about twenty-five miles south-west of
BanĀras Some thirty columns hv been found in many parts of Northern
India, from Sānchū in south to Nepalese Tarāī in north. Their
sculptured capitals r great as works of art, but as evidence of Indian
technological achievement columns r even more significant.

Weighing as much as fifty tons, and measuring some forty feet, they were
carved from single blocks of stone, given polish of wonderful hardness
and lustre, and often transported many hundreds of miles to their present
positions. process of their manufacture, polishing and transport has not
yet been fully explained, and secret was apparently lost soon after the
Mauryan period, when school of craftsmen who worked Chunar
sandstone vanished. Though many fine examples of later stone carving have
come down to us, some much more impressive artistically than the
Mauryan columns, it is doubtful whether India ever again showed such
complete mastery of handling of enormous pieces of stone.



Fig. xvi.—Carting Pillar (from an engraved sketch on wall of medieval fortress of
Raichūr, Hyderābād). (Reproduced by permission of Archæological Department, Government of
India)
The Iron Pillar of Meharauli, near Delhi, is even more remarkable,
though of little artistic value and less immediately impressive than the
Mauryan columns. It is memorial to king called [Page 220] Candra, who
was probably Candra Gupta II (c. 376–415), and now stands not far from
the famous Kutb Minar, one of greatest monuments of Muslim India,
though it was originally erected on hill near Ambālā. It is over twenty-
three feet high, and consists of single piece of iron, of size and weight
which could not hv been produced by best European ironfounders
until about one hundred years ago. As with Mauryan columns we have
no clear evidence of how it was made, but it must hv demanded immense
care and labour, and great technical proficiency in preparing and heating the
metal. metallurgical skill of ancient India is further attested by fact
that this pillar, though it has weathered torrential rains of over 1,500
monsoons, shows no sign of rusting. This is not due to fact that the
Indians had discovered some form of stainless steel alloy, for column is
of iron almost chemically pure. process of oxidization demands a
catalyst, and it is great purity of metal which has preserved it so
long, as another memorial to India’s technical skill.



TRADE AND FINANCE
A money economy only existed in India from days of Buddha.

That coinage was introduced from west cannot be proved with certainty,
but earliest clear references to coined money r found in texts looking
back to period shortly after foundation of Achæmenid Empire in
Persia, which was first great empire to mint an official coinage, and
which for time controlled Panjāb. Babylonians and Assyrians
managed with unstamped silver shekels, but Achæmenid emperors
adopted stamped coinage from Lydia and Greek cities of Asia Minor,
which had already employed it for century or two. If India did not learn
the use of coinage from Persians she invented it independently, but the
coincidence is too striking to make this seem probable.

The earliest Indian coinage4 consisted of flat pieces of silver or bronze,
of irregular shape, but fairly accurate in weight. They bore no inscriptions,
but number of punch-marks, significance of which is not finally
established, but which probably included emblems of kings who minted
the coins, and control marks of local officials and merchants. Inscribed
coins were not regularly minted in India until 2nd century B.C., and
though literary evidence suggests that gold coinage may hv existed earlier
the oldest surviving gold coins, other than one or two very rare specimens,
are those of Vīma Kadphises of 1st century A.D. As well as three
usual metals, [Page 221] coins of nickel were minted by some of Greco-
Bactrian kings, while Satavahanas of Deccan made coins of lead,
and various alloys r attested. Small purchases were regularly paid for in
cowryshells ( varāṭ aka), which remained chief currency of poor in
many parts of India until recent times.

The concept of legal tender never seems to hv taken root in Hindu
India, and coins were often current far beyond borders of kingdoms
which minted them. Some important dynasties, such as Palas of Bengal,
did not regularly mint coins, but relied on those of other states. Coins
circulated less rapidly than they do nowadays, and might be current for
centuries; thus Periplus of Erythrean Sea, Greek text of end of
the 1st century A.D., notices that coins of Menander, who ruled in the
Panjāb at least two centuries earlier, were current in port of Barygaza
(Bhrgukaccha, modern Broach, at mouth of Narmada), which
was probably at least 500 miles from Menander’s kingdom. Foreign
currency circulated freely. In North-West, Athenian drachms, as well as
local imitations, were current before invasion of Alexander, and
Achæmenid, Seleucid, Parthian, Roman, Sasanian and Islamic coins were
used at different periods. In South, numerous hoards of Roman imperial
coins hv been found.

Though there is no evidence of highly organized financial machinery of
cheques, drafts and letters of credit, usury was widespread, and
moneylending, except by brāhmaṇs, did not incur reprobation of Hindu
moralists, as it did that of medieval Christianity and Islam. Even in Ṛ g
Veda we read of indebtedness (p. 404), and earliest Dharma Sūtras lay
down rates of interest, and regulations governing debts and mortgages. The
just rate of interest is generally given as 1¼ per cent. per month, or fifteen
per cent per year. Later commentators interpret this as applying only to
secured loans, and in practice rates of interest were often much higher.

Manu27 and some other lawgivers lay down sliding scale of interest for
unsecured loans, acc to class of debtor: brāhmaṇs 24 per
cent., ksatriyas 36 per cent., vaiśyas 48 per cent., and śūdras 60 per cent. per
year. Arthaśāstra28 gives, beside “just rate”, three other rates of
interest, inadequately defined, but apparently applicable to short-term loans
for commercial ventures: normal commercial rate, 5 per cent. per
month; rate for merchants travelling through forests (overland caravan
traders), 10 per cent. per month; and rate for seafaring merchants, 20 per
cent. per month. These enormous rates of interest, 60, 120, and 240 per
cent. per year respectively, r measures of both profit and risk of
ancient Indian commerce.

[Page 222] Humane regulations on indebtedness r laid down in the
Arthaśāstra and some other legal texts. Interest payments should cease
when total interest paid equals principal. Loans advanced on
securities used by creditor for his own profit (e.g. beasts of burden)
should be free of interest. Husbands r responsible for their wives’ debts,
but not wives for those of their husbands. But later lawbooks provide
many escape clauses and sometimes completely set aside these earlier
injunctions. Debtors might be imprisoned, or enslaved by their creditors,
until they had worked off their debts. We read of debtors, dogged
everywhere by their creditors, and at last committing suicide in desperation.

The immense expense of family ceremonials of Hinduism, periodic
dearth, dowering of daughters, and many other factors, worked then as
now to drive less fortunate into debt, and, then as now, Indian
creditor might be hard man.

We hv seen that trade guilds might act as bankers, both receiving
deposits and issuing loans. king or his local officer might make loans to
peasants to relieve dearth, or to encourage cultivation of waste lands and
the development of irrigation. larger temples also sometimes served as
bankers, and in South village communes occasionally made loans to
peasants. There were many professional bankers and moneylenders,
however, śreṣṭ hins (in Pali, seṭṭ hi).5
The sresthin was not merely moneylender or banker, but usually a
merchant as well. At all times until coming of Europeans, banking in
India was by-product of trading, and most sresthins had other sources of
income besides moneylending. They appear as leading members of guilds,
often fabulously wealthy. Though craftsman frequently sold his wares
direct to consumer peasants’ surplus products were largely in the
hands of middlemen, and class of large merchants, as distinct from small
traders and pedlars, existed at least from time of Buddha. In the
Jataka stories we read of sresthins cornering grain, and buying at their own
price products of craftsmen who were virtually their employees. The
term sresthin seems sometimes to hv been title of honour, held only by
merchants of wealth and consequence. In Buddhist scriptures we read of
chief sresthins, honoured by kings, and with places in royal councils.

Under Guptas chief banker or sresthin was sometimes member of
the local advisory council which aided district officer in controlling
local affairs (p. 103).

Though in early literature and inscriptions srenis or guilds seem [Page
223] to hv been chiefly organizations of producers, there were also guilds
or companies of merchants. Such merchant corporations became very
important in medieval Deccan, and had branches in many cities. One
such was Viravalanjigar, freely translated “the Company of Gentlemen
Merchants”, which had members in every important city of Peninsula
and was controlled by central council at Aihole, in Southern Hyderabad.

The company known as Maṇ igrāma functioned not only in Southern India,
but also in Ceylon, where it hired its mercenaries to Sinhalese kings.

Co-operative ventures both in production and distribution were well
known in Hindu India, but they were normally carried out by temporary
associations of craftsmen and merchants, and these merchant companies
were in no way comparable to modern joint stock company. Their
members may from time to time hv undertaken corporate ventures, but
the normal function of mercantile companies was not trading itself, but
protecting, furthering and regulating activities of their members.

Overland caravans, though consisting of carts and pack animals owned and
led by individual merchants, would be organized and controlled by officers
of company, and guarded by company’s mercenaries. They played a
similar part in maritime trade, and probably owned warehouses and
“factories”, where their members might store their wares in safety.

Members travelling to strange cities would receive help from officers of the
local branch, and, like craft guilds, mercantile companies no doubt
helped members who fell on hard times, prevented adulteration,
undercutting and other malpractices, and represented their members at the
king’s court.



CARAVANS AND TRADE-ROUTES
By time of Buddha recognized trade-routes covered most of
Northern India, and by Mauryan times similar routes existed in the
Peninsula. Among chief of these was one which ran from Ganges
port of Tāmraliptī, not far from modern Calcutta, up river to old
city of Campā, and thence through Pataliputra and Banāras to Kauśāmbī,
whence branch went to port of Bhrgukaccha on mouth of the
Narmada by way of Vidiśā and Ujjayinī. From Kauśāmbī main trunk
road passed along south bank of Jamnā to Mathurā, from which a
branch crossed modern Rājasthān and Thar Desert to port of
Patala, near mouth of Indus. main route passed on by the
modern Delhi and crossed five rivers of Panjāb by way of Sākala (?

Siālkot) to north-western city of Takṣaśilā, whence it continued up the
Kabul Valley and on into Central Asia. great cities to north of the
[Page 224] Ganges and Jamnā were linked to trunk route by recognized
branch roads. Though its course has varied somewhat through centuries
this has always been main artery of Northern India. Mauryan
emperors cared for this great road, which was marked with milestones, and
provided with wells and rest-houses at regular intervals.

The main route to South went from Ujjayini to city of
Pratiṣṫhāna, in N.-W. Deccan, capital of Sātavāhana empire
around beginning of Christian era. Thence it passed across the
Deccan Plateau to lower Kistna, and went on to great southern cities
of Kāñcī (Conjeeveram) and Madurai. network of roads developed early
in Christian era from this old route, linking all more important cities
of Peninsula. Contact between North and South by way of east does
not at first seem to hv been close or frequent, but routes from Pataliputra
to Orissa must hv existed before Mauryan period. In more
unsettled times after Mauryas wild uncivilized forests of Central
India much discouraged travel, and western route was most
important until at least Gupta period.

The larger rivers crossed en route by these roads were not bridged. Indian
engineering, though very competent in many respects, seems never to have
mastered art of bridging large river; but regular ferry services, in
Mauryan times regulated by State, were maintained at every important
crossing.

European visitors to Mughal Empire in 17th century, were
impressed by badness of roads, which were atrocious even by the
low Western standards of time. As road builders Indians never
equalled Romans, but references in Asoka’s inscriptions, the
Arthaśāstra and elsewhere, show that under more energetic governments
roads were well maintained, and conditions under Mughals may not
have been typical of earlier times. medieval text on statecraft attributed
to Sukra tells of main roads forty-five feet wide, which were cambered, had
drains at both sides, and were regularly repaired with gravel.29
In rainy season, roughly corresponding to European summer, the
roads were practically impassable; rivers in spate could not be ferried, and
all travelling ceased; even thousands of wandering religious mendicants,
who walked length and breadth of India from one shrine to another,
would settle down until rains had passed, in precincts of temple,
the outhouse of kindly patron, or cave near village. But at other times
of year, especially in cool, bright winter, when weather of
Northern India resembles rainless late May in England, long caravans of
rumbling [Page 225] bullock carts and pack animals—oxen, asses, mules
and camels—travelled dusty roads.

The roads were dangerous to merchant-caravans. Many of trade
routes linking centres of civilization passed through dense jungle, and over
hills where wild tribes dwelt. There were whole villages of professional
robbers, ready at all times to waylay merchant. Other dangers were
incurred from wild beasts—tigers, elephants and snakes in particular-and
the remoter parts of country were reputed haunts of demons of many
malevolent kinds. In these circumstances merchants preferred to share their
perils together, and we read of as many as 500 men travelling in caravan.

Pali literature tells. of bands of professional caravan guards, who would
undertake to give guidance and safe conduct over specified route, and
who seem to hv been regular feature of caravan trade, at least where
the merchant corporations did not provide their own guards. If the
Arthaśāstra’s instructions on duties of antapāla (p. 108) hv any
relation to facts it would seem that Mauryan kings did much to
safeguard roads, and same is true of many other important dynasties;
but danger that beset caravans from thieves is attested by many stories,
and by enormous rate of interest which Arthaśāstra permits on loans
to finance long distance trading ventures.

The caravan leader (sārthavāha) was an important figure in the
commercial community, and Gupta copper-plates of Northern Bengal
(p. 103) show that chief caravan leader of locality might occupy an
important place on district council. Another figure associated with the
caravan trade was land-pilot (in Pali, thalaniyyāmaka), whose existence
is attested in Pali scriptures; he guided caravans through deserts and
waste places, steering by stars.

The great rivers were used to carry both goods and passengers in vessels
large and small. Chief of these was Ganges, artery of Great
Plain, but Indus and rivers of Deccan were also important as
trade routes. Like land routes they were full of dangers: river pirates
were numerous, and in some rivers sandbanks, and in others submerged
rocks, were peril to navigators.

Luxury articles formed chief objects of long-distance trade—spices,
sandal-wood, gold and gems from South, silks and muslins from Bengal
and Banaras, musk, saffron and yaks’ tails from Hills; but these were
not only merchandise of caravans. Many regions had to import
metal. chief source of iron in India was South Bihār, and control of the
route from iron producing areas around modern Rānchī to the
Ganges may well hv been one of [Page 226] chief factors in early
rise of Magadhan power. Copper was mined and smelted in various parts of
the Deccan, in Rajasthan, and in Western Himalayas. Salt, an absolute
necessity in hot climate, was imported from sea coast, and from
various rock-salt deposits, notably in Salt Range in Panjāb. Certain
foodstuffs were articles of long-distance commerce: sugar was carried to
cooler and dryer regions where cane would not grow, and rice imported
as luxury food to parts of North-West.



SEA-TRADE AND OVERSEAS CONTACTS
Whether or not Āryans of Ṛg Vedic period knew sea, by the
time of Buddha hardy sailors had probably circumnavigated sub-
continent, and perhaps made first contacts with Burma, Malaya and the
islands of Indonesia. In early centuries of Christian era maritime
trade became most vigorous, especially with West, where Roman
Empire demanded luxuries of East in great quantities. With fall
of Roman Empire trade with West declined somewhat, though it
was maintained by Arabs, and improved gradually with rising
material standards of medieval Europe. Before time of Guptas
contact was made by sea between South India and China, and as trade with
the West declined that with China increased, Chinese demand for Indian
spices, jewels, perfumes, and other luxury commodities continuing down to
the present day.

Certain over-enthusiastic Indian scholars hv perhaps made too much of
the achievements of ancient Indian seafarers, which cannot compare with
those of Vikings, or of some other early maritime peoples. Much of the
merchandise exported from India was carried in foreign bottoms, and
though Indian literature mentions ships carrying 1,000 passengers this
seems certainly an exaggeration. largest Indian ship known to Pliny,
who obtained some accurate information about maritime trade of the
Indian Ocean, measured 3,000 amphorae, or only seventy-five tons. In the
5th century Fahsien, who had no reason not to tell truth in this respect,
travelled from Ceylon to Java in ship carrying 200 people, which is the
largest complement of passengers and crew attested in reliable source
relating to early India. few illustrations of ships surviving from this
period give little impression of size, though one, at Ajanta, has three masts
(fig. xvii); and vessels so vigorously and realistically depicted on the
friezes of great Buddhist temple of Barabudur in Java, r all small, the
largest containing only fifteen people. All hv steadying outriggers, like
the fishing boats of present-day [Page 227] South India and Ceylon, and all
are steered by large oars—the rudder was unknown in our period.


Normally timbers of ancient Indian ships were not nailed or riveted,
but lashed together; this was done to avoid imaginary danger of
magnetic rocks, for technique of nailing ship’s timbers was certainly
known in India in medieval period. In fact sewn or lashed timbers were
more resilient than nailed ones, and could stand up better to fierce
storms of monsoon period and many coral reefs of Indian Ocean.

An early Jātaka story30 tells of ships sailing from port of
Bhrgukaccha to place called Baveru, which must be Babylon. Pali
Questions of Milinda, probably of 1st century A.D., mentions the
possibility of merchant sailing to Alexandria, Burma, Malaya or China. A
story of 6th or 7th century, tells of merchant’s son who sailed to “the
Island of Black Yavanas” 31, which must surely be Madagascar or
Zanzibar. These records indicate limits of Indian seafaring.


Fig. xvii.—A ship, c. 6th century, A.D. (From Cave II Ajantā). (By permission of Oxford
University Press).

The chief ports of ancient India were on West Coast—Bhrgukaccha,
already mentioned, Supara, not far from modern Bombay, and Patala, on
the Indus delta. Hence coastal shipping plied to South and to Ceylon,
and westwards to Persian Gulf and Red Sea until, in 1st century
A.D., seamen took to using monsoon winds to sail straight across the
Indian Ocean to ports of South India. In East Ganges Basin was
served by river port of Campa, from which ships sailed down the
Ganges and coasted to [Page 228] South and Ceylon. By Mauryan
times, with eastward expansion of Āryan culture, Tamralipti became the
main seaport of Ganges basin, and Campa lost its importance. From
Tāmraliptī ships not only sailed to Ceylon, but, from before beginning
of Christian era, to South-East Asia and Indonesia.

The merchants and seamen of Roman Egypt knew India well, and there
survives remarkable seaman’s guide, compiled in Greek by an anonymous
author towards end of 1st century A.D., Periplus of Erythrean
Sea. From Periplus, Ptolemy’s Geography, of following century,
and early Tamil poems which look back to this period, we learn much of
the trade of Tamil lands. Here many flourishing ports r mentioned, the
three chief being Musiri, known to Greeks as Musiris, in Cera
country (Malabar), Korkai, in land of Pāṇḍyas, not far from the
modern Tuticorin, and Kavirippattinam, chief port of Cō country,
at mouth of Kaviri.

The Tamil kings did much to develop their harbours and encourage sea-
trade. We read of lighthouses, and wharves, where “the beautiful great ships
of Yavanas” discharged their merchandise to be examined by customs
officials, stamped with king’s seal, and stored in warehouses.

Kavirippattinam, now decaying fishing village silted up by river mud,
had an artificial harbour, built, acc to late Sinhalese source, by
soldiers captured by great King Karikālaṉ in raid on Ceylon.32
At this time Socotra had considerable Indian colony, and name of
the island may be of Indian origin. 6 Indian merchants were met by Dion
Chrysostom in Alexandria. One such merchant, crossing desert from the
Red Sea to Nile on his way to Alexandria, left brief inscription in a
temple at Redesiye; “Sophon Indian does homage to Pan for good
journey”. 33 “Sophon” probably represents some such Indian name as
Subhanu, and Pan was no doubt identified in merchant’s mind with
Kṛṣṇa, who was also god of flocks and herds, and played rustic flute. It
is evident that author of this inscription was much Hellenized.

As well as merchants, we read of Indian fortune-tellers, conjurors, and
prostitutes in Rome, while mahouts often accompanied their elephants to
the West. There r records of several embassies from Indian kings to the
Caesars. earliest of these is said by Strabo to hv been sent by king
of Pāṇḍyas, and was met by Augustus at Athens about 20 B.C. This
mission included an ascetic called Zarmanochegas (Skt. Śramaṇācārya),
who, growing tired of [Page 229] life of earthly bondage, burnt himself to
death at Athens. It has been suggested that when St. Paul wrote “though I
give my body to be burned, and hv not charity, it profiteth me nothing”,
he had in mind this incident of some sixty or seventy years earlier, of which
he had heard from his Athenian colleagues. theory is, of course,
fanciful, but not wholly impossible. Later embassies r recorded as having
been sent to Claudius (from Ceylon), Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Julian the
Apostate and Justinian. latter emperor of Constantinople had an Indian
cook.

The main requirements of West were spices, perfumes, jewels and
fine textiles, but lesser luxuries, such as sugar, rice and ghee were also
exported, as well as ivory, both raw and worked. finely carved ivory
statuette of goddess or yaksi has been found in ruins of Herculaneum
(pl. LXXXVIIb). Indian iron was much esteemed for its purity and
hardness, and dyestuffs such as lac and indigo were also in demand.

Another requirement was live animals and birds; elephants, lions, tigers and
buffaloes were exported from India in appreciable numbers for wild
beast shows of Roman emperors and provincial governors, though these
larger beasts went mainly overland through desert trading city of
Palmyra; smaller animals and birds, such as monkeys, parrots and peacocks,
found their way to Rome in even larger quantities as pets of wealthy Roman
ladies. Emperor Claudius even succeeded in obtaining from India a
specimen of fabulous phoenix, probably golden pheasant, one of the
loveliest of India’s birds.

In return for her exports India wanted little but gold. Pottery and
glassware from West found their way to India, and many sherds of
Arretine and other wares, mass-produced in Western factories, hv been
found in remains of trading station at Arikamedu, near Pondicherry.34
There was some demand for wine, and Western traders also brought tin,
lead, coral and slave-girls. But balance of trade was very unfavourable
to West, and resulted in serious drain of gold from Roman Empire.

This was recognized by Pliny, who, inveighing against degenerate
habits of his day, computed annual drain to East as 100 million
sesterces, “so dearly do we pay for our luxury and our women”. 35 drain


of gold to East was an important cause of financial difficulties in the
Roman Empire from reign of Nero onwards. Not only gold, but coinage
of all types was exported to India; Roman coinage has been found in such
quantities in many parts of Peninsula and Ceylon that it must have
circulated there as regular currency.

There is good evidence that subjects of Roman Empire, if not actual
Romans, settled in India. There is mention of temple of [Page 230]
Emperor Augustus at Muśiṟi. Early Tamil literature contains several
references to Yavanas, who were employed as bodyguards by Tamil
kings, or as engineers, valued for their knowledge of siegecraft and the
construction of war-engines. While term Yavana was often used very
vaguely, and, from its original meaning of “a Greek”, came to be applied to
any Westerner, it is by no means impossible that Yavanas of South India
included fugitives from Roman legions in their number.

Contacts between India and West r testified in language. Even a
few Hebrew words r believed by some to be of Indian origin-notably
koph, “a monkey” (Skt. kapi) and tukki, “a peacock”, (Tamil togai). Though
the details of Book of Kings may not be historically accurate the
statement that navy of Tharshish brought to King Solomon gold and
silver, ivory, apes and peacocks36 shows that Hebrews received
commodities from India at an early period. It has been suggested that the
land of Ophir, from which King Hiram of Tyre brought gold, precious
stones and “almug” trees to Solomon, 37 was Supara, ancient port near
Bombay; this suggestion is strengthened by fact that in Septuagint,
the Greek version of Old Testament, word occurs as
; the
almug trees may hv been sandal, one of Sanskrit words for which is
valguka, from which Hebrew word may be derived. Indian loan-words
in Greek and Latin r nearly all of articles of trade: precious stones, such
as
, emerald (Skt. marakaṭa)7 and
, beryl (Skt. vaidurya);
spices, such as
, ginger (Skt. śṛṅ gavera) and
, pepper (Skt.

pippali); foodstuffs, such as, sugar (Skt. śarkara) and
rice (Tamil
ariśi); and
, cotton (Skt. karpāśa) as well as several others.

Dubious is suggested etymology of word, elephant, from the
Sanskrit ibha, meaning elephant, with Semitic definite article al or el
prefixed.



Greek loan-words in Sanskrit include several connected with
mathematics and astronomy, of which some r common, and hv passed
into vernaculars of India:
horā, an hour (
), kendra, centre (
) and kona, angle (
); two coins, dramma and dīnāra (from the
Latin denarius, through Greek); and two words connected with war,
suranga, mine (see p. 135), and kampana, camp (a rare word used in
Kashmir, and borrowed from Latin through Greek); of words connected
with writing melā, ink (
), and kalama, pen (
) r certain
borrowings, though there r synonyms of purely Indian origin for both
these words. derivation of pustaka, book, from Greek
, is no
longer supported by competent authorities.

[Page 231] Chinese in Middle Ages demanded many of same
commodities as Westerners, but they had more to offer in exchange.

Though Indians made splendid silks and muslins of their own they were
ready to buy stuffs of China, and Chinese porcelain found market in
South India and Ceylon, as did pottery of Muslim World, numerous
sherds of which hv been found.

Though maritime trade never ceased it became more and more affair
of foreign merchants. Indians never wholly abandoned sea, but by the
time of Muslim invasion travel to foreign lands was believed to incur
grave impurity for members of upper classes, which, acc to some
authorities, could never be expunged. 38 This religious objection to sea
travel was measure of growing fear of and distaste for sea, which
in some degree existed at all times. Though Indian mariners were
resourceful and by no means lacking in courage, sailing sea was always
depicted as hateful and desperately perilous. By Middle Ages Arabs
and Chinese had outstripped Indians in art of ship construction, and
it became more profitable for merchant to sell his wares to foreign
middlemen than to take dm abroad himself. Muslim invasions
encouraged xenophobia, and people who had planted their colonies
from Socotra to Borneo became, with religious sanction, nation of
landlubbers.

northern Uttar Pradesh, where Ganges meets Plain), Kāñcī
(Conjeeveram), Ujjayini (Ujjain), Dvāravati (Dwārkā in Kāthiāwār), and of
course Kāśī (Banāras); but others were almost equally sacred, notably
Pravaga (Allahabad), Madurai, and Puri (Orissā).

VII.

RELIGION: CULTS, DOCTRINES AND
METAPHYSICS


(1) RELIGION OF VEDAS
Gods of Gods of Ṛ g Veda
[Page 232]
THE earliest civilized inhabitants of India worshipped Mother Goddess
and horned fertility god; they had sacred trees and animals, and ritual
ablutions apparently played an important part in their religious life. Beyond
this much has been said and written about religion of Harappā
people, but in absence of intelligible texts any efforts at further defining
it r very speculative. salient features of Harappā religion appeared
again in new form at much later date, and we must assume that it never
died, but was quietly practised by humbler people, gradually developing
from contact with other doctrines and cults, until it gathered enough
strength to reappear, and largely to overlay old faith of Āryan rulers
of India.

We hv much knowledge of religion of early Āryans from the
1028 hymns of Ṛ g Veda, which is oldest religious text in world
still looked on as sacred, and which was probably composed between 1500
and 900 B.C. The. Ṛ g Veda is collection of hymns for use at sacrifices
of aristocratic Āryan cult. three later Vedas, Sāma, Yajur and
Atharva, r of somewhat different character. Sāma Veda is almost
useless to historian, being collection of certain verses of Ṛ g Veda
arranged for liturgical purposes. Yajur Veda, compiled century or two
later than Ṛ g Veda, contains sacrificial formulæ in prose and verse to be
pronounced by adhvaryu, or priest who performs manual part of the
sacrifice. It exists in various recensions (saṃhitā), which r of two types,
the “Black” giving formulæ with rubricated instructions, and the
“White” adding detailed instructions in lengthy appendix called a
Brāhmaṇa. Atharva Veda consists mainly of magical spells and
incantations in verse, and was certainly compiled after Rg and Tajur. It
possesses, however, an atmosphere of simple animism and sympathetic
magic on lower cultural level than that of Ṛ g Veda, deriving from the
plebeian religion of Āryans and containing many non-Āryan elements.

The massive [Page 233] Brāhmaṇas, which r looked on as appendices to
the Vedas, and mystical Araṇ yakas and Upanisads, which r in turn
appendices to Brāhmaṇas, complete literature generally known as
Vedic. material in Brāhmaṇas looks back in main to period
between c. 800 and 600 B.C., and earliest Upanisads overlap with the
latest Brāhmaṇas, though some Upanisads r certainly of much more
recent date. religion of people who composed this literature was not
that of later India, and many scholars refer to it as Brāhmaṇism or Vedism,
to distinguish it from Hinduism, to which it bears relation similar to that
between sacrificial Judaism of temple and later Judaism of the
synagogue.

PLATE LIV
Much of Ṛ g Veda is imperfectly understood; oldest exegetical
work on it, Nirukta (Etymology) of Yaska, perhaps dating from 500 B.C.,
shows that at very early period brāhmaṇs had forgotten true
meaning of many obsolete words. But broad outlines of religion of
the Ṛ g Veda r clear enough. chief objects of worship were devas,
a word cognate with Latin deus. root from which this word is
derived, div, is connected with brightness and radiance, and devas by
connotation were “the shining ones”. early gods of Āryans, like
those of Greeks, were chiefly connected with sky and were
predominantly male. few goddesses occur in Ṛ g Veda; for instance
Pṛ thvī, vague and rarely mentioned personification of earth, Aditi, a
mysterious and tenuous figure, great mother of gods, Usas, the
goddess of dawn, to whom number of lovely hymns were addressed,
Rātrī, spirit of night, who has beautiful hymn to herself (p. 402),
and Araṇ yāni, Lady of Forest, nature goddess of little importance
who is praised in one very late hymn (p. 402f); none of these, however,
played significant part in cult.

At remote period ancestors of Āryans, Iranians, Greeks,
Romans, Germans, Slavs and Celts had similar, if not identical, religions;
but by time Āryans had entered India their religion had developed
far from old Indo-European faith. great father god of Indo-
European peoples, who appears in Greek as Zeus and in Latin as Ju-piter,
was known to Āryans as Dyaus, personified heavens, but his star
had already set. Father Heaven was often mentioned as parent of other
divinities, but few hymns were composed in his honour, and he was
eclipsed by his children.

From point of view of Āryan warrior greatest god was Indra,
who fulfilled dual function of war-god and weather-god. Though his
name was different he had many of characteristics of Greek Zeus
and Germanic Thor. As Indra tonans he rode [Page 234] at head of
the Āryan host, and destroyed fortresses of Dasas; as Indra pluvius
he slew evil dragon Vrtra, who held back waters, and thus brought
rain to parched land (p. 400ff). Indra was associated with storm and
thunder, and, like Zeus and Thor, his hand bore thunderbolt ( vajra), with
which he destroyed his enemies. He was rowdy amoral deity, fond of
feasting and drinking. One hymn, acc to usual interpretation,
shows us drunken Indra, bragging in his cups, though it may well
represent feelings of worshipper who has drunk liberally of sacred
drink soma:
“Like wild winds
the draughts hv raised me up. hv I been drinking soma?

“The draughts hv borne me up,
as swift steeds chariot. hv I …?

“Frenzy has come upon me,
as cow to her dear calf. hv I … ?

“As carpenter bends seat of chariot
I bend this frenzy round my heart. hv I … ?

“Not even as mote in my eye
do five tribes count with me. hv I … ?

“The heavens above
do not equal one half of me. hv I … ?

“In my glory I hv passed beyond sky
and great earth. hv I … ?

“I will pick up earth,
and put it here or put it there. hv I … ?” 1
With Indra in his course across sky rode bright host of Maruts in
their chariots, singing martial songs as they aided war-god in his battles.

They were lesser spirits of storm, conceived on analogy of the
host of Āryan warriors charging into battle beside their leader. Āryans
evidently had many legends in which Indra was protagonist, but none of
them cn be reconstructed in detail from cryptic allusions of hymns.

Two of his traits connect him with Indo-European mythology, for they were
applied to various gods and heroes throughout ancient Europe—Indra was a
dragon-slayer, and wild rider of storm. former feature of his
character may hv been very early borrowing from Mesopotamia.

Several gods were associated with sun. Sśrya (the common word for
sun) drove across sky in flaming chariot, like Greek Helios. Savitṛ,
the Stimulator, was another solar god, beautiful [Page 235] verse in whose
honour is most holy of all verses of Veda (p. 162). Pūṣ an too
was in some measure solar god, driving daily across sky, but his main
function was that of guardian of roads, herdsmen and straying cattle. Viṣṇ u,
a god connected in part with sacrifice, also had solar characteristics,
covering earth in three paces, trait which he retained in later
Hinduism, when his importance greatly increased. On fringes of the
solar pantheon was Sūryā, sun-god’s daughter, who seems never to have
been worshipped, but merely served to connect her two husbands, the
Aṣ vins (“Horsemen” also called Nāsatyas), with sun; these are
described as driving across sky in their three-wheeled chariot, but in the
hymns they r not closely associated with natural phenomena. They are
twins-a fact which connects dm with Greek Dioscuri and twin gods of
pre-Christian Baltic mythology. Aśvins appear chiefly as helpers of
men; among their many good deeds they r said to hv rescued
shipwrecked mariners, provided artificial legs for maimed, and found
husbands for old maids.

The fire-god, Agni (which means simply “fire”, and is related to Latin
ignis), was object of much primitive mysticism and speculation. He was
the god of priest, who dealt with him at fire-sacrifice; he was also
the god of home, for he dwelt in domestic hearth; he was the
intermediary between gods and men, for he consumed sacrifice and
carried it to gods. He dwelt in waters of heaven, in form of
lightning, and on earth in many forms. He was hidden in fire-sticks,
with which sacrificial fire was kindled, and which were personified as
his parents. Agni, in fact, was here, there and everywhere. Was there only
one Agni, or were there many Agnis? How could Agni be one and many at
the same time? Questions like these r asked in Ṛ g Veda, and show the
earliest signs of tendency towards monism, which was to bear fruit in
the Upaniṣads.

Soma was divinity of special character. Soma was originally plant, not
certainly identified, from which potent drink was produced, which was
drunk only at sacrifices, and which caused most invigorating effects, as
we hv seen from hymn quoted above. Zoroastrians of Persia had
a similar drink, which they called haoma, same word as soma in its
Iranian form; plant identified with haoma by modern Pārsīs is a
bitter herb, which has no specially inebriating qualities, and which cannot
have been soma of Veda. drink prepared from plant can
scarcely hv been alcoholic, for it was made with great ceremony in the
course of sacrifice, when herb was pressed between stones, mixed
with milk, strained and drunk on same day. Sugar and honey, [Page 236]
which produce fermentation, were not usually mixed with it, and brief
period between its brewing and consumption cannot hv been long enough
for generation of alcohol in appreciable quantity. effects of soma,
with vivid hallucinations, and sense of expanding to enormous
dimensions, r rather like those attributed to such drugs as hashish. Soma
may well hv been hemp, which grows wild in many parts of India,
Central Asia and South Russia, and from which modern Indians produce a
narcotic drink called bhang.

Like many ancient peoples Indians connected growth of plants
with moon, with which Soma, king of plants, was later identified. So
important was god Soma considered by ancient editors of Ṛ g
Veda that they extracted all hymns in his honour and placed dm in a
separate “book” ( maṇḍ ala), ninth of ten which constitute whole.

Varuna, second only to Indra in importance, was god of type rather
different from others. He is known as an Asura, term, also applied to
certain lesser gods, which in later Hinduism came to mean class of
demons, but which was in Persia adopted by reformer Zarathustra in its
local form as part of title of great god of light, Ahura Mazda. Just as
the shadowy Dyaus represents high god of Indo-European peoples
before their separation, so Varuna may hv been high god of Indo-
Iranians before two peoples divided, one to settle in N.-W. India and the
other in Persian highlands. name is connected by some authorities
with shadowy Greek heaven-god Uranus. At time of the
composition of Veda, Varuna’s prestige was waning before that of Indra,
but he retained some importance for many centuries.

Varuna was first and foremost king-not boisterous tribal warlord, like
Indra, but mighty emperor, sitting in great palace in heavens, often
with associated gods around him. Most important of these was Mitra, god
with some solar characteristics, but mainly connected with vows and
compacts. Mitra was also represented in Zoroastrian pantheon, and,
under his Greco-Iranian name Mithras, was widely worshipped in the
Roman Empire during early Christian centuries. Around Varuna sat his
scouts, or spies ( spas), who flew all over world, and brought back
reports on conduct of mortals.

Varuna was guardian of Rta, cosmic order, concept which was
perhaps highest flight of Ṛg Vedic thought. world takes its regular
course, day follows night and season succeeds season, because of Rta; man
must live acc to Rta; in later days “nonrta” ( anrta) became one of the
commonest words for untruth and [Page 237] sin. Rta depended on Varuna,
who was sometimes looked on as its maker, and was thus sort of creator-
god.

Of all Āryan gods Varuna was ethically highest. He was always
aware of deeds of men, and was omnipresent, in theistic, as opposed
to pantheistic sense. Two men, even in most secret of places, or at
the ends of earth, cannot make plans alone-a third person, Varuna, is
always there.2 worshipper approached Varuna in spirit different from
that in which he prayed to other gods, most of whom were lively,
cheerful fellows, whom men need not fear if they offered regular sacrifices.

Varuna was so pure and holy that mere performance of sacrifice would
not ensure his favour, for he abhorred sin, or that which was not
conformable to Rta. idea of sin included many purely ritual sins and
breaches of taboo, but it also certainly included lying, which Varuna and
Mitra particularly loathed, and evil deeds prompted by anger, drink,
gambling, and influence of wicked men. When he sang to Varuna the
cheerful Vedic poet often put on sackcloth and ashes, and prayed to his
deity with fear and trembling, for Varuna was severe punisher of sin.

Not only did Varuna punish sins of individual but, like Yahweh
of Old Testament, he visited sins of his ancestors upon him, and his
ubiquity ensured that there was no escape for sinner. He caught and
bound evil-doers in his snares, so that they became diseased, especially with
dropsy, and when they died they descended to “House of Clay”,
apparently sort of gloomy subterranean Sheol, very different from the
cheerful “World of Fathers”, Āryan heaven.

So humble was worshipper in Varuna’s presence, so conscious of
weakness, guilt and shortcoming, that on reading hymns to Varuna one
is inevitably reminded of penitential psalms of Old Testament. It has
even been suggested that Varuna owes much of his character to Semitic
influence—certainly not to Jews, for penitential psalms were
composed long after hymns to Varuna, and as far as we know early
Hebrews never came in contact with Āryans, but perhaps to the
Babylonians, who often approached their gods in similar penitential spirit.

We quote typical hymn to Varuṇa; it is obviously prayer of man
afflicted with dropsy.

“Let me not go to House of Clay, O Varuṇa!

Forgive, O gracious Lord, forgive!

When I go tottering, like blown-up bladder,
forgive, O gracious Lord, forgive!

[Page 238] “Holy One, in want of wisdom I hv opposed you.

Forgive, O gracious Lord, forgive!

Though in midst of waters, thirst has seized your worshipper.

Forgive, O gracious Lord, forgive!

“Whatever sin we mortals hv committed
against people of gods,
if, foolish, we hv thwarted your decrees,
O god, do not destroy us in your anger!”3
Tama, lord of dead, was sort of Adam, first man to die, who
became guardian of World of Fathers, where blessed dead, those
who hv performed rites of Āryans, feast in bliss forever.

Rudra (perhaps meaning “the Howler”), like Varuṇa, had dangerous
side to his character, but, unlike Varuna, was quite amoral. He was an
archer-god, whose arrows brought disease. In this he resembled Greek
Apollo. Like Indra, he was associated with storm, but he lacked Indra’s
popular and genial character. He was remote god, dwelling in the
mountains, and was generally an object of fear, invoked to ward off his
arrows of plague and disaster. He had, however, beneficent aspect, for he
was guardian of healing herbs, and as such might give health to those whom
he capriciously favoured.

There were many other gods, such as Tvaṣṭṛ, Vedic Vulcan,
Aryaman, guardian of compacts and marriage, and Vāyu, windgod, who,
though important, cannot be described here. There were also demigods of
various kinds, among dm Viśvedevas, vague group of indeterminate
deities, Maruts, or storm-spirits, already mentioned, Rbhus, gnomes
who worked in metal, Gandharvas, divine musicians, originally single
divinity but later looked on as many, and lovely Apsarases, comparable
to nymphs of Greece, who might become mistresses of gods and
men.



No Homer or Hesiod attempted to construct definitive genealogy of all
these gods; their relationships r usually vague, and there is no tidy
scheme of precedence among them. Each god must hv had his own
special devotees and priests, and Ṛ g Veda is result of an imperfect
syncretism of many tribal beliefs and cults. Already in latest stratum of
the Vedic hymns gods r equated or paired together, and there r doubts
as to which god is really greatest. In one hymn4 this important question
is asked as refrain to every verse— “Whom, then, shall we honour with
our oblations?”; later theologians were so puzzled by this that they decided
that there was god called Ka (Who?), to whom hymn was addressed.

[Page 239]
Sacrifice
The centre of Āryan cult was sacrifice. cult of domestic
hearth existed in many ancient Indo-European communities, and small
domestic sacrifices, performed by head of house, must hv been as
important in days of Ṛ g Veda as they were in later Hinduism, but the
earliest texts describing dm r Grhya Sśtras (p. 112) of much more
recent period. Ṛ g Veda is rather concerned with great sacrifices, paid
for by chiefs and wealthier tribesmen. They were already complex rites
involving much preparation, slaughter of numerous animals, and the
participation of several well-trained priests.

The chief purpose of sacrifice was gratification of gods in
order to obtain boons from them. gods descended to sacred straw
( barhis) on sacrificial field, drank and ate with worshippers, and
duly rewarded dm with success in war, progeny, increase of cattle, and
long life, on quid pro quo basis. solemn Varuna and grim and
unpredictable Rudra r exceptional in Vedic pantheon. Most of the
gods were good natured. Guilt-offerings and thank-offerings, of kind
offered by ancient Hebrews, r almost unheard of in Veda.

Nevertheless ceremony must hv had its element of awe and
wonder. worshippers, inebriated with soma, saw wondrous visions of
the gods; they experienced strange sensations of power; they could reach up
and touch heavens; they became immortal; they were gods themselves.

The priests, who alone knew rituals whereby gods were brought to
the sacrifice, were masters of great mystery. With these ideas, which are
explicitly stated in hymns, went others less obvious. Often in Ṛ g
Veda we read of mysterious entity called brahman; in some contexts
brahman is magical power in sacred utterance ( mantra), but often it
has wider connotation, and implies sort of supernatural electricity,
known to students of primitive religion as mana. possessor of brahman,
by common process of secondary word formation in Sanskrit, became
known as Brāhmaṇ a, 1 tribal priest and magician. In later Vedic times
the connection of brahman with speech became more and more pronounced,
and brahman’s magic was thought to lie in words he uttered. The
words and syllables of Veda were analysed, and, though texts were
still unwritten, letters of alphabet were recognized and personified
as eternal divinities. metres used in Veda were also thought of as
gods. Later certain syllables were believed to be particularly holy,[Page
240] notably Ṓ M (the praṇ ava), which contains essence of Vedas
and is pregnant with utmost power and mystery.

A second conception, which is hinted at in many hymns of Ṛ g Veda,
and becomes prominent in latest stratum, is also widely known in
primitive religions-the mystical identification of god, victim and sacrificer.

From these ideas sacrifice developed an even greater importance in the
scheme of things than it had had in earliest period of Ṛ g Veda. By
the end of period it was widely believed that universe itself arose
from primeval sacrifice.

Though Varuna may hv been sometimes looked on as sort of creator,
and there r suggestions of Indra’s having fulfilled same function (p.

400), there is no clearly defined creator-god in main body of Ṛ g
Veda. By end of Ṛg Vedic period, however, such god had
developed, whether wholly from speculations of brāhmaṇs or from
non-Āryan influences. This god was Prajāpati, “the Lord of Beings”, later
called Brahmā, masculine form of neuter brahman. Prajapati was
thought of as primeval man ( puruṣ a), who existed before foundation
of universe. man was sacrificed, presumably to himself, by the
gods, who apparently were his children. 2 From body of divine
victim universe was produced. great “Hymn of Primeval Man”,
in which first cosmic sacrifice is described, bristles with obscurities, but
its purport is quite clear.

“When gods made sacrifice
with Man as their victim,
Spring was melted butter, Summer fuel,
and Autumn oblation.

“From that all-embracing sacrifice
the clotted butter was collected.

From it he3 made animals
of air and wood and village.

“From that all-embracing sacrifice
were born hymns and chants,
from that metres were born,
from that sacrificial spells were born.

“Thence were born horses,
and all beings with two rows of teeth.

Thence were born cattle,
and thence goats and sheep.

[Page 241] “When they divided Man,
into how many parts did they divide him?

What was his mouth, what were his arms,
what were his thighs and his feet called?

“The brahman was his mouth,
of his arms was made warrior,
his thighs became vaiśya,
of his feet śūdra was born.”
“The moon arose from his mind,
from his eye was born sun,
from his mouth Indra and Agni,
from his breath wind was born.

“From his navel came air,
from his head there came sky,


from his feet earth, four quarters from his ear,
thus they fashioned worlds.

“With Sacrifice gods sacrificed to Sacrifice—
these were first of sacred laws.

These mighty beings reached sky,4
where r eternal spirits, gods.”5
By this time new attitude to sacrifice had developed, and it had
become supernal mystery. By means of it priests mystically repeated
the primeval sacrifice, and world was born anew. Without regular
sacrifices all cosmic processes would cease, and chaos would come again.

Thus order of nature was on ultimate analysis not dependent on gods
at all, but on brāhmaṇs, who by magic of sacrifice maintained
and compelled them. brahman was more powerful than any earthly
king, or any god; by his accurate performance of sacrifice he maintained all
things, and was therefore supreme social servant; by slightest
variation of ritual he could turn sacrifice against his patrons and destroy
them, and was therefore most dangerous of enemies.

This is basic doctrine of Brāhmaṇ as, and it prevailed in many
Āryan communities in North India from about 900 B.C. onwards, and left its
mark on Hinduism in exaltation of brahman. In this period many of
the old gods of Ṛ g Veda lost their greatness, and became comparatively
unimportant, while others rose in popularity, notably Visnu and Rudra; the
latter was already sometimes called by epithet Śiva, “the Propitious”,
originally deprecatory euphemism.

[Page 242] New Developments of Doctrine
As Āryan culture pressed further down Ganges it absorbed new ideas
about after-life. In Ṛ g Veda fate of dead seems to hv been
finally decided when they died-they went either to “World of the
Fathers” or to “House of Clay”, where they remained indefinitely. But
in one late hymn6 it is suggested in cryptic language that they might pass to
the waters or remain in plants. This seems to be reference to
metempsychosis in crude form believed in by many primitive peoples,
according to which souls of dead pass to an animal, plant or natural
object, before being reborn in human body. Brāhmaṇ literature,
which had lost optimism of Ṛ g Veda, recognized possibility of
death even in heaven.

In Brhadāraṇ yaka Upaniṣ ad7 first form of doctrine of
transmigration is given. souls of those who hv lived lives of sacrifice,
charity and austerity, after certain obscure peregrinations, pass to World
of Fathers, paradise of Yama; thence, after period of bliss, they go
to moon; from moon they go to empty space, whence they pass to
the air, and descend to earth in rain. There they “become food,… and
are offered again in altar fire which is man, to be born again in fire
of woman”, while unrighteous r reincarnated as worms, birds or
insects. This doctrine, which seems to rest on primitive belief that
conception occurred through eating by one of parents of fruit or
vegetable containing latent soul of offspring, is put forward as rare
and new one, and was not universally held at time of composition of
the Upaniṣad. Even in days of Buddha, transmigration may not have
been believed in by everyone, but it seems to hv gained ground very
rapidly in 7th and 6th centuries B.C. Thus magnificently logical
Indian doctrines of saṃsāra, or transmigration, and karma, result of the
deeds of one life affecting next, had humble beginnings in soul theory
of quite primitive type; but even at this early period they had an ethical
content, and had attained some degree of elaboration.

In whatever way doctrine of transmigration was developed it
involved belief in repeated passage of soul from life to life, either
for all eternity or for an inestimably long time. It linked all forms of life
into single system. gods themselves must pass away, and be replaced
by other gods. As one Indra died, another was born. souls of the
departed, though now in bliss, would sooner or later pass to new abodes.

Animals, insects, and even, acc to some sects, plants, all lived under
the same law. With remarkable imaginative insight some sages taught that
even water, [Page 243] dust and air were filled with minute animalculæ, and
that these too had souls which were same, in essence, as those of men.

The whole of life thus passed through innumerable changes.

It was generally, though not universally, thought that these changes were
determined by conduct. As one behaved in present life so one’s status in
the scale of existence would in future be exalted or abased, and one’s lot be


happy or wretched. This doctrine of karma (literally “deed”) soon became
fundamental to most Indian thought. It provided satisfactory explanation
of mystery of suffering, which has troubled many thoughtful souls all
over world, and it justified manifest social inequalities of Āryan
community.

To ordinary man such doctrine might not appear distasteful, and the
fact that it quickly obtained almost universal acceptance shows that it met
in great measure ancient India’s spiritual needs. Indeed in many respects the
idea of saṃsāra, which offers infinite potentialities of new experience to
the soul, and which holds out hope even to humblest of living things and
the most evil of beings, might seem more attractive than traditional
static heaven and hell of West. But to greater minds of time the
thought of transmigration was not pleasant. Death was always terrible, and
the prospect of having to die innumerable times was not happy one. Life,
even when devoid of major sorrows, was drab and inadequate, while
continual rebirth seemed monotonously boring. growth of doctrine
of transmigration coincided with development of pessimistic ideas.

Rebirth in heaven was not enough-a way had to be found to escape the
cycle of birth and death altogether. It was found, to satisfaction of the
best minds of times, in knowledge, achieved by much meditation and
asceticism.

Asceticism
In late hymn of Ṛ g Veda 8 we read of class of holy men different
from brāhmaṇs, “silent ones” ( munis), who wear wind as a
girdle, and who, drunk with their own silence, rise on wind, and fly in
the paths of demigods and birds. muni knows all men’s thoughts,
for he has drunk of magic cup of Rudra, which is poison to ordinary
mortals. Another class, much mentioned in Atharva Veda, 9 was the
vrātya. This term, in its later broad meaning, implied an Āryan who had
fallen from faith and no longer respected Vedas; but vratya of the
Atharva Veda was priest of non-Vedic fertility cult, which involved
ritual dancing and flagellation. He travelled from place to place in cart,
with woman, whom he prostituted, and musician, who performed for
him at his rites. status and nature of vratyas r still [Page 244] not
wholly clear, but it is evident that great efforts were made to convert them
to Āryan faith, and to find room for dm in orthodox cult, and they
were probably one of chief sources of new doctrines and practices.

By time of Upanisads asceticism had become very widespread,
and it was through ascetics, rather than orthodox sacrificial priests,
that new teachings developed and spread. Some ascetics were solitary
psychopaths, dwelling in depths of forests, and suffering self-
inflicted tortures of hunger, thirst, heat, cold and rain. Others dwelt in
“penance-grounds”, on outskirts of towns, where, like some of less
reputable holy-men of later times, they would indulge in fantastic self-
torture, sitting near blazing fires in hot sun, lying on beds of thorns or
spikes, hanging for hours head downwards from branches of trees, or
holding their arms motionless above their heads until they atrophied.

Most of new developments in thought, however, came from ascetics
of less rigorous regimen, whose chief practices were mental and
spiritual exercises of meditation. Some of these dwelt alone on outskirts
of towns and villages, while others lived in groups of huts, under the
leadership of an elder. Others wandered, often in large groups, begging
alms, proclaiming their doctrines to all who wished to listen, and disputing
with their rivals. Some were completely naked, while others wore simple
garments.

The original motive of Indian asceticism was acquisition of magical
power. brāhmaṇs claimed this already, by virtue of their birth and
training, but there were other types of power, obtainable by other means. By
the time of Upanisads faith in cosmic mystery of sacrifice had
perhaps begun to wane, even among brāhmaṇs themselves. Though
sacrificial mysticism did not immediately disappear rite once more
came to be thought of as means of obtaining prosperity, long life, and
rebirth in heaven, rather than of sustaining cosmos. Indeed wealthy
patrons of sacrifices had probably always had former as their main
motive. In eastern parts of Ganges Basin brahmanism was not so
deeply entrenched as in west, and older non-Āryan currents of belief
flowed more strongly. sacrificial cult did not wholly meet needs of
these lands, where firmly founded kingdoms were growing in power, and
material civilization rapidly progressing.

The ascetic, even though his penance was of most severe type, rose
far above heights achieved by sacrificial priest. Once he had inured
his body to pain and privation immeasurable joys awaited him. hermit
of lower type had much to look forward to even on material plane—
honour and respect which as an [Page 245] ordinary man he could never
hope for, and complete freedom from worldly cares and fears. This sense of
freedom, of great load lifted from one’s shoulders by casting aside one’s
family and possessions, is evident in many passages of calm joy in the
religious literature of India. But there were greater incentives to asceticism
then these. As he advanced in his self-training hermit acquired powers
beyond those of ordinary mortals. He saw past, present and future; he
mounted heavens, and was graciously received at courts of gods,
while divinities descended to earth and visited him in his hermitage. By the
magical power acquired in his asceticism he could work miracles—he could
crumble mountains into sea; if offended, he could burn up his enemies
with glance of his eye, or cause crops of whole people to fail; if
respected, his magical power could protect great city, increase its wealth,
and defend it from famine, pestilence and invasion. In fact magic
potency, formerly ascribed to sacrifice, now began to be attributed to
asceticism. In succeeding age idea that universe was founded
and maintained through sacrifice slipped into background; in its place it
was widely believed that universe depended on penances of the
great god Śiva, meditating forever in fastnesses of Himalayas, and
on continued austerities of his human followers.

If ascetism had its charms even for less spiritual, they were still
greater for questing souls who took to life of hardship from truly
religious motives. As his mystical exercises developed his psychic faculties,
the ascetic obtained insight which no words could express. Gradually
plumbing cosmic mystery, his soul entered realms far beyond the
comparatively tawdry heavens where great gods dwelt in light and
splendour. Going “from darkness to darkness deeper yet” he solved the
mystery beyond all mysteries; he understood, fully and finally, nature of
the universe and of himself, and he reached realm of truth and bliss,
beyond birth and death, joy and sorrow, good and evil. And with this
transcendent knowledge came another realization—he was completely,
utterly, free. He had found ultimate salvation, final triumph of soul.

The ascetic who reached goal of his quest was conqueror above all
conquerors. There was none greater than he in whole universe.

The metaphysical interpretation of ascetic’s mystical knowledge
varied from sect to sect, but fundamental experience was same, and,
as has been many times pointed out, was not appreciably different from that
of Western saints and mystics, whether Greek, Jewish, Christian or
Muslim. But Indian mysticism is unique in its elaboration of techniques for
inducing ecstasy, and in complex metaphysical systems built upon
interpretations of that experience. [Page 246] Where in other religions
mysticism is of varying importance, in those of India it is fundamental.

The great development of asceticism and mysticism soon became too
strong for more earthbound and materialistic brahmanism to ignore.

Places were found for hermit and wandering ascetic in Āryan
social structure by formula of four stages of life (p. 153f), which
first appear in Dharma Sūtras. Accounts of discussions and
teachings of some of more orthodox of early mystics were collected
and added to Brāhmaṇas as Āranyakas and Upaniṣads. little later
short treatises of mystical character were composed in verse, and also
appended to Brāhmaṇas as Upaniṣads. Later still system of mystical
training, often known as yoga (“union”) (p. 325ff), was accepted as an
orthodox element of Hindu system. Indian religion had taken new
direction.

It has been suggested that development of ascetic and mystical
doctrines, especially in heterodox systems of Buddhism and Jainism,
represents reaction of warrior class to pretensions of brāhmaṇs
and to sterility of sacrificial cult. This, however, is certainly not the
whole truth. Buddha and Mahāvīra, founder of Jainism, were ksatriyas;
they proclaimed futility of sacrifice, and more than one passage in the
Buddhist scriptures may be interpreted in an anti-brahmanic sense. But
many of teachers of new doctrines were themselves brāhmaṇs. The
Upaniṣads, which represent thought of more orthodox mystics, in no
way oppose sacrificial cult, but maintain its qualified validity; and
passages speaking respectfully of brāhmaṇs r quite as frequent in the
Buddhist scriptures as those which disparage them.

There was certainly some opposition to brahmanic pretensions, and
dissatisfaction with sacrificial cult; but behind this, and growth of
pessimism, asceticism and mysticism, lay deep psychological uneasiness.

The time of which we speak was one of great social change, when old tribal


units were breaking up. feeling of group solidarity which tribe gave
was removed, and men stood face to face with world, with no refuge in
their kinsmen. Chieftains were overthrown, their courts dispersed, their
lands and tribesmen absorbed in greater kingdoms. new order was
coming into being. “[Great heroes and mighty kings] hv had to give up
their glory; we hv seen deaths of [demigods and demons]; oceans
have dried up; mountains hv crumbled; Pole Star is shaken; Earth
founders; gods perish. I am like frog in dry well”; so speaks king
in one of Upaniṣads. 10 Despite great growth of material civilization
at time hearts of [Page 247] many men were failing dm for fear of
what should come to pass upon earth. It is chiefly to this deep feeling of
insecurity that we must attribute growth of pessimism and asceticism in
the middle centuries of first millennium B.C.

Speculation and Gnosis
Asceticism was not merely means of escape from an unhappy and
unsatisfying world; it had positive aspect. It was in part inspired by a
desire for knowledge, for wisdom which four Vedas could not give.

Thus growth of asceticism is not only measure of psychological
uncertainty which was felt at time, but also of thirst for knowledge.

It is not wholly just to India to stigmatize her ancient wisdom as mere “life-
negation”.

All through first millennium B.C. intelligent minds in India were
striving for convincing explanations of cosmic mystery. In latest
phase of Ṛ g Veda poets began to wonder about creation, which was not
adequately explained by current mythology. As we hv seen, creation
was thought of by some as effect of primeval sacrifice. It was also
suggested that it was due to sort of sexual act; 11 elsewhere world was
said to hv originated in “Golden Embryo” ( Hiraṇ zyagarbha), 12 the
prototype of Cosmic Egg (p. 488) of later Hindu mythology. In one
hymn poet puts forward suggestion that world arose from
warmth ( tapas, later usually meaning penance or asceticism), and then
rather regretfully admits that he is not sure of this hypothesis, and suggests
that perhaps even high god Prajāpati does not know truth.

This wonderful “Hymn of Creation”, one of oldest surviving records
of philosophic doubt in history of world, marks development of
a high stage of abstract thinking, and it is work of very great poet,
whose evocation of mysterious chaos before creation, and of mighty
ineffable forces working in depths of primeval void, reminds us of
the cosmic phantasies of William Blake.

“Then even nothingness was not, nor existence.

There was no air then, nor heavens beyond it.

What covered it? Where was it? In whose keeping?

Was there then cosmic water, in depths unfathomed?

“Then there were neither death nor immortality,
nor was there then torch of night and day.

The One breathed windlessly and self-sustaining.

There was that One then, and there was no other.

[Page 248] “At first there was only darkness wrapped in darkness.

All this was only unillumined water.

That One which came to be, enclosed in nothing,
arose at last, born of power of heat.

“In beginning desire descended on it—
that was primal seed, born of mind.

The sages who hv searched their hearts with wisdom
know that which is is kin to that which is not.

“And they hv stretched their cord across void,
and know what was above, and what below.5
Seminal powers made fertile mighty forces.

Below was strength, and over it was impulse.

“But, after all, who knows, and who cn say
whence it all came, and how creation happened?

The gods themselves r later than creation,
so who knows truly whence it has arisen?

“Whence all creation had its origin,
he, whether he fashioned it or whether he did not,
he, who surveys it all from highest heaven,
he knows-or maybe even he does not know.”13
In centuries succeeding composition of Ṛ g Veda, however,
speculation was mainly concerned with symbolism of sacrifice.

“Dawn is head of sacrificial horse, sun its eye, wind
its breath, fire its mouth; year is body of sacrificial horse,
heaven its back, sky its belly, earth its chest, four quarters its
sides… seasons its limbs, months and fortnights its joints; days
and nights r its feet, stars its bones, heavens its flesh. Its
halfdigested food is sand, its bowels rivers, its liver and lungs the
mountains, its hair plants and trees. When sun rises it is horse’s
fore-quarters, when it sets it is its hind-quarters. When horse
shakes itself it lightens; when it kicks, it thunders; when it makes
water, it rains. Sound is its voice.” 14

The symbolism of sacrifice was carried much further than this. Every
word or action of ritual was identified with some aspect of cosmos.

The intellectual ingenuity spent on this process of finding pratikas or
symbols must hv been considerable, but it was largely sterile. Yet the
questing spirit of “Hymn of Creation” never wholly disappeared, and in
the 6th century B.C. it bore fruit in [Page 249] great wave of thought which
was to alter whole religious life of India.
