PLATE LVI
The early Upanisads and scriptures of Buddhism and Jainism, all of
which look back to 7th or 6th centuries B.C. (though latter were much
later in their final composition), show that there existed bewildering
variety of speculations and theories on origin of universe, nature
of soul, and kindred problems. Some of these were accepted by one or
other brahmanic school and incorporated into orthodox belief. Others were
the germinal bases of heterodox sects, two of which survive to this day, but
most of which hv long since vanished, and r only remembered in
passing references of scriptures of their opponents.

Among more orthodox teachings we find creation ascribed to self-
consciousness of primeval Person ( Puruṣ a, i.e. Prajāpati), who felt fear,
loneliness, and need of companionship. Person divided himself, and
produced wife. This couple, taking forms of animals and men, created
the whole universe. 15 idea of creation by cosmic sexual act was one
which played great part in later religious thought. theme is repeated
in various forms in later Vedic literature, in some of which tapasāthe power
derived from asceticism-is an essential feature in process of creation-a
significant shifting of emphasis from older theory that world
depended on primeval sacrifice.

Other more heterodox teachers put forward naturalistic and atheistic
cosmogonic theories. Some believed that world began as water; others
postulated fire, wind, or ether ( ākāṣ a, p. 497) as ultimate basis of the
universe. For some universe was based neither on deity nor even on an
impersonal entity, but on principle —fate ( niyati), time ( kala), nature
( svabhāva), or chance ( saṃ gati). It was suggested that world developed
not by intervention of god or forces external to it, but by process of
internal evolution or “ripening” ( pariṇ āma). Some teachers, like the
Buddha, taught that speculation on first causes was futile waste of time.

There were out-and-out pyrrhonists, denying possibility of any certain
knowledge at all, and materialists, who rejected existence of soul
and any other immaterial entity, while some teachers proclaimed that the
world was made of eternal atoms. intellectual life of India in 7th
and 6th centuries B.C. was as vigorous and pullulating as jungle after
rains.

The propagators of these doctrines, even of materialism and scepticism,
were nearly all ascetics, though literature of time mentions more
than one king who took keen interest in new ideas. Chief of these
philosopher kings were Janaka of Videha and Ajāta [Page 250] satru of
Banaras, both of whom probably lived in 7th century B.C. forest
hermits ( vānaprastha) seem to hv departed less far from Vedic orthodoxy
than wanderers (parivrājaka), who maintained bewildering variety of
doctrines. It was chiefly among former that literature of the
Upanisads developed.

The term Upanisad means literally “a session”, sitting at feet of a
master who imparts esoteric doctrines. There r said to be 108 Upanisads
altogether, but many of these r late sectarian works of little importance.

The earlier Upanisads, like great Brhadāraṣ yaka and Chāndogya,
are in prose and consist of series of short expositions of some aspect of
the new doctrines, often in form of question and answer. Upanisads
of somewhat later composition, like Kaṭ ha and Śvetāśvatara, r in
verse, and their contents r more closely integrated. Though the
speculations of Upanisads differ very considerably, their main purport is
the same. One entity, often called Brahman, term used in Ṛ g Veda to
mean magic of sacred word (p. 239), fills all space and time. This is
the ground beyond and below all forms and phenomena, and from it the
whole Universe, including gods themselves, has emerged.

The great and saving knowledge which Upanisads claim to impart
lies not in mere recognition of existence of Brahman, but in
continual consciousness of it. For Brahman resides in human soul-
indeed Brahman is human soul, is Atman, Self. When man realizes
this fact fully he is wholly freed from transmigration. His soul becomes one
with Brahman, and he transcends joy and sorrow, life and death. In sleep a
man’s spirit is set free; it wanders through universe as bird or god, it
becomes king or brahman. Beyond dreaming is dreamless sleep, where
the soul’s experiences r such that they cannot be expressed; and beyond
this again is Brahman. When he reaches Brahman, man is free.

In their struggle to express inexpressible sages of Upanisads
used imagery of every kind. Sometimes idea of soul is rather
primitive, and it is described as tiny manikin in heart; sometimes it is
said to be breath, or mysterious fluid which flows in veins; but
sometimes it is thought of as quite incorporeal and immeasurable:
“‘Fetch me fruit of banyan tree.’
“‘Here is one, sir.’
“‘Break it.’
“‘I hv broken it, sir.’
“‘What do you see?’
“‘Very tiny seeds, sir.’
[Page 251] “‘Break one.’
“‘I hv broken it, sir.’
“‘Now what do you see?’
“‘Nothing, sir.’
“‘My son,’ father said, ‘what you do not perceive is essence, and
in that essence mighty banyan tree exists. Believe me, my son, in that
essence is Self of all that is. That is True, that is Self. And you
are that Self, Śvetaketu!’”16
Here soul is inmost self of being, in no sense material, though
ideas of sort of soul-stuff, subtle matter of which soul was
composed, persisted, especially among Jainas. term Atman came to
mean indiscriminately “soul”, and “self”, which lends certain ambiguity
to many passages in Hindu scriptures.

The identity of souls of individual and universe is reiterated
throughout Upanisadic literature, with varying emphasis, and with
differing interpretations of nature of identity and character of the
universal soul. Tat tvam asi, “you (the individual) r that (universal
essence)”, words of father to son in passage we hv quoted,
is leading theme of Upaniṣads. one eternal undifferentiated
essence, above good and evil, is in condition of consciousness which is
beyond deep sleep (suṃupti), but is yet awake and living. Though it fills
the whole of space, by mysterious verity which defies logic but is proved
by experience it dwells in core of human heart. It is generally
thought of as uniform and impersonal, and word Brahman is of neuter
gender. Thus all multifariousness and incoherence of universe is
explained away, and reduced to single entity.

“‘Put this salt in water, and come to me in morning.’
“The son did as he was told. father said: ‘Fetch salt.’ The
son looked for it, but could not find it, because it had dissolved.

“‘Taste water from top,’ said father. ‘How does it taste?’
“‘Of salt,’ son replied.

“‘Taste from middle. How does it taste?’
“‘Of salt,’ son replied.

“‘Taste from bottom. How does it taste?’
“‘Of salt,’ son replied.

“Then father said: ‘You don’t perceive that one Reality (sat)
exists in your own body, my son, but it is truly there. Everything which
is has its being in that subtle essence. That is Reality! That is Soul!

And you r that, Svetaketu!’” 17

The Universal Essence is sometimes defined in purely negative terms.

“The Self cn only be described as ‘Not this, not this’. It [Page 252] is
incomprehensible, imperishable, … unattached, … unfettered,… it does not
suffer, … it does not fail.” 18 But, despite negations of this passage, the
sage Yājñavalkya, to whom it is attributed, could not escape giving the
Universal Essence degree of personality, and in one place almost
identified it with High God.

“That great unborn Self, comprised of knowledge, is … ether in the
heart. In that is ruler and lord, king of all things. He grows no
greater by good deeds, nor smaller by evil deeds, but he is lord of all
things, king of all things, protector of all things.”19
In verse Upanisads World Spirit is described rather as god than
as cosmic essence.

“He encircles all things, radiant and bodyless,
unharmed, and untouched by evil,
All-seeing, all-wise, all-present, self-existent,
he has made all things well for ever and ever.” 20
In Upanisad from which this is taken World Spirit is referred to as
Īśa, “the Lord”. Katha Upanisad calls Spirit “the Person” ( Puruṣ a),
reminding us of divine victim of primeval sacrifice from which the
world was born. In one passage World Spirit is mentioned with fear and
dread, recalling that earlier felt for god Varuna:
“All things whatever, whole world,
produced [from Brahman] tremble in its breath.

It is great terror, an upraised thunderbolt.

They who know this become immortal.

“From terror [of Brahman] Fire burns.

From terror [of Brahman] Sun shines.

From fear of Brahman Indra, and Wind,
and Death as fifth all run away.”21
The Śvetāśvatara Upaniṣ ad, which is later than those previously
mentioned, describes World Spirit in completely theistic terms. It is no
longer an impersonal essence, but creator god—in fact god Rudra, or
Siva. Rudra may be reached not only by meditation and penance, but also
by devotion and worship.

“The snarer, who rules alone in his might,
he who governs world in his power,
is always one and same,
though all else rise and decay….

[Page 253] “There is one, Rudra alone,…
who rules world in his might.

He stands behind all beings, he made all worlds,
and protects them, and rolls dm up at end of time.

“The Lord lives in faces of all beings.

in their heads, in their necks.

He lives in inmost heart of all,
the all-pervading, all-present Siva.” 22
This brings us very near to religious atmosphere of Bhagavad
Gītā, most exalted and beautiful of India’s religious poems, which
teaches fully-fledged theism and is part of more recent Hinduism,
rather than of old brahmanism, which slowly changed from religion of
sacrifice to one of devotion.



Ethics of Upanisads
In general Upanisads proclaim salvation by knowledge or realization,
rather than by faith or works. Their ethics r fundamentally pragmatic.

Good and evil r resolved in all-pervading Brahman, and r relative
terms only. From point of view of seeker after truth, that is good
which leads him to realization of Brahman, and evil reverse. Thus
anything which discourages meditative life is ultimately bad, and among
the most serious of these obstacles r selfish desires. In more than one
context it is said that universe came into existence through primeval
desire of World Soul; to attain bliss hermit must, so to speak, restore
the state of things before creation. normal values of world,
sacrifice, benevolence, and even asceticism, r only good in so far as they
lead soul upwards.

“There r three branches of Law. Sacrifice, study and charity r the
first, austerity is second, and to dwell in celibacy in house of one’s
teacher… is third. By all these one only reaches worlds of the
blessed, but man who is fixed in Brahman finds immortality.” 23
“The wise men of old did not want children. ‘What should we do with
children,’ they said, ‘when we hv Brahman and world besides?’ And
they conquered their desire for sons and wealth and heavenly worlds,
and wandered about as beggars…. He who knows [the mystery of brāhman]
becomes calm, restrained, satisfied, patient and confident, and he sees
himself in [Great] Self, sees all things as Self…. Evil does not
overcome him, but he overcomes evil. … Free from evil, free from decay,
free from hatred, free from thirst, he becomes [true] brahman.” 24
Occasionally it is suggested, especially in later Upanisads, that all
desires whatever r incompatible with saving knowledge.

[Page 254] “When all desires which cling to heart
fall away
then mortal becomes immortal,
and in this life finds Brahman.

“When all earthly ties of heart
are sundered,
then mortal becomes immortal.

This is end of all instruction.” 25
A life of ascetism was not absolutely necessary to salvation-even kings
are said to hv realized Brahman while still ruling; but saving
knowledge was at best very hard to obtain, and doubly difficult for one
whose mind was full of material cares and desires. All pleasure was
therefore suspect.

“The good is one thing and pleasant another.

Both, with their different ends, control man.

But it is well with him who chooses good,
while he who chooses pleasant misses his mark.”26
Though often rather negative, ethical attitude of Upanisads is
neither unmoral, nor antinomian. He who has not ceased from evil conduct
will never obtain Brahman. Here and there r passages of high ethical
value among reiterated mystical similes and parables of texts. Thus
honesty is highly extolled.

“Satyakama son of Jabālā said to his mother: ‘Mother, I want to be a
student. What is my family?’
“‘I don’t know your family, my dear,’ she said. ‘I had you in my
youth, when I travelled about lot as servant-and I just don’t know!

My name is Jabālā, and yours is Satyakāma, so say you r Satyakama
Jābālā.’6
“He went to Gautama Hāridrumata, and said: ‘I want to be your
student, sir. May I come?’
“‘What is your family, my friend?’ he asked.

“‘I don’t know my family, sir,’ he answered. ‘I asked my mother,
and she said that she had me in her youth, when she used to travel
about lot as servant…. She said that as she was Jabālā and I was
Satyakāma I was to give my name as Satyakāma Jābālā.’
“‘Nobody but true brahman would be so honest!’ he said…. ‘Go
and fetch me fuel, my friend, and I will initiate you, for you hv not
swerved from truth.’”27

A further fine ethical passage occurs in form of legend in the
Bṛ hadāraṇ yaka Upaniṣ ad. We quote this passage partly because an
allusion to it must hv puzzled many readers of T. S. Eliot. 28
[Page 255] “The threefold descendants of Prajapati, gods, men and
demons, were once students at feet of their father. When they had
finished their training gods said: ‘Sir, tell us something [good for our
souls]’. He uttered syllable DA, and then asked dm whether they had
understood.

“‘We understood’, they answered. ‘You told us DAmyata (be
selfcontrolled).’ ‘Yes,’ he said, ‘you understood indeed!’
“Then men asked him, and he uttered same syllable DA, and then
asked dm whether they had understood. ‘We understood,’ they answered.

‘You told us DAtta (give),’ ‘Yes,’ he said, ‘you understood indeed!’
“Then demons asked him, … and he uttered same syllable DA,
and then asked dm whether they had understood. ‘We understood,’ they
answered. ‘You told us DAyadhvam (be merciful).’ ‘Yes,’ he said, ‘you
understood indeed!’
“And blessed voice of thunder ever repeats DA DA DA7—be
self-controlled, give, be merciful. So these three should ever be taught—
self-control, charity and mercy.”29
Perhaps highest ethical flight of Upanisads occurs in the
instructions said to hv been given by Yājñavalkya to his favourite wife
before taking up life of an ascetic. Remembering double meaning of
the word ātman, “self” or “soul”, passage may be read in two ways, but
the context shows that Higher Self is intended. This Higher Self, the
World Soul, mystic recognizes in all things, and loves dm for their
participation with himself in unity of spirit. passage is too long
to quote in full, but we paraphrase its most important parts.

“Yājñavalkya had two wives, Maitreyi and Katyayani. Maitreyi
knew something of World Soul, but Kātyāyanī only knew what
every woman knows. When he wished to enter on another phase of life
Yājñavalkya said: ‘Maitreyī, I am leaving home. Let me make a
settlement on you and Kātyāyanī.’
“Maitreyī asked: ‘My lord, if I owned whole earth and all its
wealth, should I be immortal?’
“‘No,’ Yajnavalkya replied, ‘your life would be life of the
wealthy, and there is no prospect of immortality in wealth.’
“Maitreyi said: ‘Of what use to me r things which will not give
me immortality? Give me rather your knowledge, my lord.’
“‘Lady,’ he replied, ‘you r truly dear to me, and now you r even
dearer. So if you like I will teach you. Listen carefully!

“‘A husband is not dear for love of husband-a husband is dear
for love of Self. Similarly wife, sons, wealth, cattle, priests and
warriors, worlds, gods, Vedas, everything—none of dm r dear
in their own right, but all r dear for love of Self.

“‘Truly you cn see and hear and perceive and know Self,
Maitreyi. [Page 256] And when you hv seen, heard, perceived and
known Self you will know all things.

“‘Where there seems to be duality of self and not-self one sees,
smells, tastes, perceives, hears, touches and knows something other.

But when all is Self there is no consciousness of anything other
than Self. … Thus Maitreyi I hv instructed you-this is immortality!’
“When he had said this Yājñavalkya went away.” 30


(II) BUDDHISM
The Buddha
While doctrines of Upanisads found place in brahmanic
system, there were other teachings which could not be harmonized with
orthodoxy, but were fostered and developed by heterodox sects. Chief
among teachers of such doctrines was man who at end of the
sixth and beginning of fifth century B.C. established community of
yellow-robed followers, and was known by dm as Buddha, the
Enlightened or Awakened. Even if judged only by his posthumous effects
on world at large he was certainly greatest man to hv been born in
India.

The traditional story of Buddha, like those of most saints and heroes
of ancient days, has suffered much at hands of higher criticism. The
story of his birth and early life appears only in later books of the
Buddhist Scriptures, and even some of references to him in those parts
of canon which purport to give his teachings verbatim r by no means
reliable. Even “Sermon of Turning of Wheel of Law”, which
is said. to be first sermon preached after Buddha’s enlightenment,
and which is basic teaching of all Buddhist sects, is of dubious
authenticity, and in form in which we hv it is not among earliest
parts of canon. Much doubt now exists as to real doctrines of the
historical Buddha, as distinct from those of Buddhism. One eminent
authority suggested that they differed but little from teachings of the
Upanisadic sages,31 while another held that he rejected doctrine of
transmigration, and taught merely almost self-evident truism that one
generation is affected by deeds of preceding one. 32 We here discuss,
however, not life of Buddha, but what his later followers believed
about his life, and not what he taught, but what Buddhism taught.

Certain facts about Buddha’s life r reasonably certain. He was the
son of chief of Śakyas, small tribe of Himalayan foothills. He
became an ascetic, and propounded new doctrine which gained the
support of numerous disciples. After many years [Page 257] of teaching in
the kingdoms of Kosala and Magadha and in tribal lands to north of
the Ganges, he died at age of eighty at some time between years 486
and 473 B.C., probably nearer former date than latter. story of his
life as told by his followers is far more vivid and colourful than this dry
outline, and it is infinitely more important, for it has influenced lives of
countless millions throughout whole of Asia east of Afghanistan.

One night Mahamaya, 8 chief queen of Suddhodhana, king of Sakyas,
dreamt that she was carried away to divine lake Anavatapta in the
Himalayas, where she was bathed by heavenly guardians of four
quarters of universe. great white elephant with lotus flower in his
trunk approached her, and entered her side (pl. XXIIIc). Next day dream
was interpreted for her by wise men-she had conceived wonderful son,
who would be either Universal Emperor (p. 83) or Universal Teacher.

The child was born in grove of sāl trees called Lumbini, near capital
of Sakyas, Kapilavastu, while his mother was on way to her parents’
home for her confinement. At birth he stood upright, took seven strides, and
spoke: “This is my last birth-henceforth there is no more birth for me.”
The boy was named Siddhartha, at great ceremony on fifth day
from his birth. His gotra name was Gautama (in Pali, Gotama) by which he
is commonly referred to in Buddhist literature. soothsayers prophesied
that he would become Universal Emperor, with exception of one, who
declared that four signs would convince him of misery of world, and
he would become Universal Teacher. To prevent this prophecy coming
true King Śuddhodhana resolved that he should never know sorrows of
the world. He was reared in delightful palaces, from whose parks every sign
of death, disease and misery was removed. He learned all arts that a
prince should learn, and excelled as student. He married his cousin
Yaśodharā, whom he won at great contest at which he performed feats of
strength and skill which put to shame all other contestants, including his
envious cousin Devadatta.

But for all his prosperity and success he was not inwardly happy, and for
all efforts of his father he did see four signs foretold, which were to
decide his career, for gods knew his destiny, and it was they who placed
the signs before him. One day, as he was driving round royal park with
his faithful charioteer Channa, he saw an aged man, in last stages of
infirmity and decrepitude-actually god, who had taken this disguise in
order that Siddhartha Gautama might become Buddha. Siddhārtha asked
Channa who this repulsive being was, and when he learned that all men
must grow old he was even more troubled in mind. This was first sign.

The second came little later, in same way, in form of very sick
man, covered with boils and shivering with fever. third was even more
terrible-a corpse, being carried to cremation [Page 258] ground,
followed by weeping mourners. But fourth sign brought hope and
consolation—a wandering religious beggar, clad in simple yellow robe,
peaceful and calm, with mien of inward joy. On seeing him Siddhartha
realized where his destiny lay, and set his heart on becoming wanderer.

Hearing of this King Suddhodhana doubled his precautions. Siddhartha
was made virtual prisoner, though still surrounded with pleasures and
luxuries of all kinds; his heart knew no peace, and he could never forget the
four signs. One morning news was brought to him that Yaśodharā had
given birth to son, but it gave him no pleasure. That night there were great
festivities, but when all were sleeping he roused Channa, who saddled his
favourite horse Kanthaka, and he rode off into night, surrounded by
rejoicing demigods, who cushioned fall of his horse’s hoofs, so that no
one should hear his departure (p. 453, and pl. XXXV c).

When far from city he stripped off his jewellery and fine garments,
and put on hermit’s robe, provided by an attendant demigod. With his
sword he cut off his flowing hair, and sent it back to his father with his
garments by hand of Channa. horse Kanthaka dropped dead from
grief, when he found that he was to be parted from his master, to be reborn
in one of heavens. Thus Siddhartha performed his “Great Going Forth”
( Mahābhiniṣ kramaṇ a), and became wandering ascetic, owning nothing
but robe he wore.

At first he begged his food as wanderer, but he soon gave up this life
for that of forest hermit. From sage named Ālāra Kālāma he learned the
technique of meditation, and lore of Brahman as taught in the
Upanisads; but he was not convinced that man could obtain liberation from
sorrow by self-discipline and knowledge, so he joined forces with five
ascetics who were practising most rigorous self-mortification in the
hope of wearing away their karma and obtaining final bliss.

His penances became so severe that five quickly recognized him as
their leader. For six years he tortured himself until he was nothing but a
walking skeleton. One day, worn out by penance and hunger, he fainted,
and his followers believed that he was dead. But after while he recovered
consciousness, and realized that his fasts and penances had been useless. He
again began to beg food, and his body regained its strength. five
disciples left him in disgust at his backsliding.

One day Siddhartha Gautama, now thirty-five years old, was seated
beneath large pīpal tree on outskirts of town of Gayā, in realm
of Bimbisara king of Magadha. Sujata, daughter of nearby farmer,
brought him large bowl of rice boiled in milk. After eating some of this he
bathed, and that evening, again sitting beneath pīpal tree, he made a
solemn vow that, though his bones wasted away and his blood dried up, he
would not leave his seat until riddle of suffering was solved.

So for forty-nine days he sat beneath tree. At first he was surrounded
by hosts of gods and spirits, awaiting great moment of enlightenment;
but they soon fled, for Mara, spirit of world and of sensual pleasure,
the Buddhist devil, approached. For days Gautama withstood [Page 259]
temptations of all kinds (pls. XXVIII, LXXV). Mara, disguised as a
messenger, brought news that wicked cousin Devadatta had revolted,
thrown Suddhodhana into prison, and seized Yasodhara, but Gautama was
not moved. Mara called his demon hosts, and attacked him with whirlwind,
tempest, flood and earthquake, but he sat firm, cross-legged beneath the
tree. Then tempter called on Gautama to produce evidence of his
goodness and benevolence; he touched ground with his hand, and the
Earth itself spoke with voice of thunder: “I am his witness”.

Mara then tried gentler means of shaking Gautama’s resolve. He called
his three beautiful daughters, Desire, Pleasure and Passion, who danced and
sang before him, and tried every means of seduction. Their wiles were quite
ineffectual. They offered him Universal Empire; but he was quite unmoved.

At last demon hosts gave up struggle and Gautama, left alone,
sank deeper and deeper into meditation. At dawning of fortyninth
day he knew truth. He had found secret of sorrow, and understood at
last why world is full of suffering and unhappiness of all kinds, and
what man must do to overcome them. He was fully enlightened—a Buddha.

For another seven weeks he remained under Tree of Wisdom ( bodhi),
meditating on great truths he had found.

For time he doubted whether he should proclaim his wisdom to the
world, as it was so recondite and difficult to express that few would
understand it; but god Brahma himself descended from heaven and
persuaded him to teach world. Leaving Tree of Wisdom, he
journeyed to Deer Park near Banāras (the modern Sārnāth), where his
five former disciples had settled to continue their penances.

To these five ascetics Buddha preached his first sermon, or, in
Buddhist phraseology, “set in motion Wheel of Law”. five were
so impressed with his new doctrine that they gave up their austerities and
once more became his disciples. few days later band of sixty young
ascetics became his followers, and he sent dm out in all directions to
preach Buddhist Dharma. Soon his name was well known throughout
the Ganges Plain, and greatest kings of time favoured him and his
followers. He gathered together disciplined body of monks (called
bhiksus, or in Pali bhikkhus, literally “beggars”), knit together by common
garb, yellow robes of order, and common discipline, acc to
tradition laid down in detail by Buddha himself. Many stories r told of
his long years of preaching. He returned to Kapilavastu, and converted his
father, wife and son, Rahula, as well as many other members of court,
including his cousin Devadatta, whose heart remained full of jealousy. At
the request of his foster-mother and aunt, Kṛṣā-Gautamī, he allowed with
much misgiving formation of community of nuns. Devadatta grew so
jealous of him that once he even tried to kill Buddha, by arranging for a
mad elephant to be let loose in his path; but beast, impressed by the
Buddha’s gentleness and fearlessness, calmly bowed at his feet (pl. XXXV
a). He averted war between Sakyas and neighbouring tribe of the
Koliyas, by walking between assembled armies and convincing dm of
[Page 260] uselessness and evil of bloodshed. He went alone to the
camp of notorious bandit, Aṅgulimāla, and converted him and his
followers from their evil ways.

Though acc to legend his life was attended by many wonders, the
earliest traditions record few miracles performed by Buddha himself.

Once, indeed, he is said to hv performed feats of levitation and other
miracles at Sravasti, as result of challenge from rival teachers, but he
sternly forbade monks to perform magical feats, and there is no record
of his healing sick by supernatural means. One touching story of the
Buddha is interesting in this connexion, since it contrasts strikingly with the
Gospel stories of miracles of Jesus. woman, stricken with grief at the
death of her only son, and hearing that Buddha was in vicinity,
brought child’s corpse to him in hope that he would restore it to life.

He asked her first to go to nearby town and bring handful of mustard
seed from family in which no one had died. She went from house to
house, but of course could find no such family, until at last she understood
the inevitability of death and sorrow, and became nun.

For eight months of year Buddha and his followers would travel
from place to place, preaching to all and sundry. For four months of the
rainy season, roughly corresponding to English summer, they would
stop in one of parks given to Buddhist order by wealthy lay
followers, living in huts of bamboo and reed-the first form of great
Buddhist monasteries of later times. For over forty years his reputation
grew and Saṅ gha (literally Society, Buddhist Order) increased in
numbers and influence. With exception of conspiracy of Devadatta
he suffered no persecution, though few of his followers were maltreated
by their religious opponents. His ministry was long, calm and peaceful
one, in this respect very different from that of Jesus.

The end came at age of eighty. He spent last rainy season of his
life near city of Vaiśālī, and after rains he and his followers
journeyed northwards to hill country which had been home of his
youth. On way he prepared his disciples for his death. He told dm that
his body was now like worn-out cart, creaking at every joint. He declared
that he had made no distinction between esoteric and exoteric teaching, but
had preached full doctrine to them.9 When he was gone they were to
look for no new leader-the Doctrine ( Dharma) which he had preached
would lead them. They must rely on themselves, be their own lamps, and
look for no refuge outside themselves.

At town of Pava he was entertained by lay disciple, Cunda the
smith, and ate meal of pork.10 Soon after this he was attacked by
dysentery, but he insisted on moving on to nearby town of Kusinagara
(Pali, Kusinara). Here, on outskirts of town, he lay down under sal


tree, [Page 261] and that night he died. His last words were: “All composite
things decay. Strive diligently!” This was his “Final Blowing-out”
( Parinirvāna). His sorrowing disciples cremated his body, and his ashes
were divided between representatives of various tribal peoples and King
Ajātaśatru of Magadha.

The Growth of Buddhism
According to tradition great gathering of monks met at Magadhan
capital of Rajagrha soon after Buddha’s death. At this council Upali,
one of chief disciples, recited Vinaya Piṭ aka, or rules of Order,
as he recalled having heard Buddha give them. Another disciple,
Ananda, who bears position in Buddhism similar to that of St. John in
Christianity, recited Sutta Piṭ aka, great collection of Buddha’s
sermons on matters of doctrine and ethics. Though there may hv been
some sort of council, story as it stands is certainly untrue, for it is
quite evident that scriptures of Buddhism grew by long process of
development and accretion, perhaps over several centuries.

A second general council is said to hv been held at Vaiśālī, one
hundred years after Buddha’s death. Here schism raised its head,
ostensibly over small points of monastic discipline, and Order broke
into two sections, that of orthodox Sthaviravādins (Pāli Theravādī) or
“Believers in Teaching of Elders”, and that of Mahāsaṅ ghikas or
“Members of Great Community”. tradition of second council is
as dubious as that of first, but it at least records that schism began very
early. minor points of discipline on which Order divided were soon
followed by doctrinal differences of much greater importance.

Numerous such differences appeared at third great council, held at
Pataliputra under patronage of Asoka, which resulted in expulsion of
many heretics and establishment of Sthaviravada school as
orthodox. At this council it is said that last section was added to Pali
scriptures, Kathāvatthu of Abhidhamma Piṭ aka, dealing with
psychology and metaphysics. In fact many of works of this part of the
canon r of later composition, and details of account of council
are suspect, but record shows that by this time widespread differences
had developed within Order.

Meanwhile great changes were taking place in constitution of
Buddhism. Some modern authorities believe that Buddha had no
intention of founding new religion, and never looked on his doctrine as
distinct from popular cults of time, but rather as transcending them
—a sort of super-doctrine, which would help his [Page 262] followers
further along road to salvation than brahmanism or Upanisadic gnosis.

This view is, in our opinion, very questionable. Though traditions of
Buddhism give little evidence of direct antagonism between Buddhists and
brāhmaṇs at this early period there was much antagonism between
Buddhists and other heterodox sects, such as Jainas and Ājīvikas. These
sects did not merely wrangle over doctrinal points, but carried on vigorous
propaganda among laymen for their support. We believe that even in the
days of Buddha himself Order consciously tried to build up a
following of layfolk, who would pay to Buddha their chief if not their
only homage. enormous gifts which so many wealthy people r said to
have made to Order r no doubt exaggerated, but tradition is more
probably partly true than wholly false, and at least some of wealthy
merchants who so liberally supported new teachings must hv looked
upon themselves as lay Buddhists. Whatever its position in Buddha’s
lifetime, 200 years later Buddhism was distinct religion. Aśoka classifies
all religions of his empire under five heads; (Buddhist) Saṅ gha, the
brāhmans, Ajivikas, Nirgranthas (or Jainas), and “other sects”. He
further declares that, while he gives his chief patronage to Buddhists, he
honours and respects dm all, and calls on his subjects to do likewise.36
By Aśoka’s time India was covered with vihāras, which were both
monasteries and temples. In becoming religion Buddhism borrowed and
adapted much from popular beliefs of time. Its simple ritual was in
no way based on sacrificial brahmanism, but on cult of caityas, or
sacred spots. These were often small groves of trees, or single sacred tree,
on outskirts of villages, and might also include tumuli, such as those in
which ashes of chiefs were buried. These caityas were abodes of
earth-spirits and genii who, to simpler folk, were more accessible and
less expensive to worship than great gods of Āryans. Jaina
scriptures show that unorthodox holy-men often made their homes in or
near caityas, no doubt in order to obtain alms from visitors; and the
Buddha is said to hv respected these local shrines, and to have
encouraged his lay followers to revere them.

Soon after Buddha’s death many communities of monks gave up the
practice of constant travel except in rainy season, and settled
permanently on outskirts of towns and villages, often near local
caityas. With time many of these little monasteries grew in size and
importance.

It was cult of caitya that Buddhism made its own. acc to
tradition stśpas or tumuli were built by recipients over [Page 263]
divided ashes of Buddha. Other stśpas, containing remains of locally
revered monks and ascetics of other denominations, rose up all over India in
succeeding centuries. Aśoka unearthed ashes of Buddha from their
original resting places and divided dm still further, rearing stśpas for them
all over India. sacred grove or tree of old popular cult became the
Bodhi Tree, pīpal, planted near stśpa to commemorate Buddha’s
enlightenment, and an object of great reverence. original Bodhi Tree of
Gayā, under which Buddha sat, became an object of pilgrimage, and
cuttings of it were carried as far as Ceylon. One feature of Buddhist Cult
which has now vanished is column, perhaps survival of phallic
emblem or megalith. Such columns existed in many ancient Buddhist
monasteries, but their place in cult is not clear. Temples proper, or
shrine-rooms, do not appear to hv been erected until beginning of the
Christian era, when Buddha began to be worshipped in form of an
image.

His simpler followers evidently raised Buddha almost to divinity
even in his lifetime, and after his death he was worshipped in his symbols—
the stśpa, recalling his Parinirvāna, and tree, recalling his
enlightenment. worship consisted of circumambulation in the
auspicious clockwise direction, and prostrations, with offerings of flowers.

Though more intelligent monks may hv recognized his true status, for
the ordinary believer he was greatest of gods. This is not surprising,
for to this day Indians feel and show utmost respect for those whom
they consider holy. It is rather matter of surprise that it was only 500 years
after Buddha’s death that theology developed which gave full
recognition to this state of affairs.

With support of Asoka Buddhism greatly expanded, spreading
throughout India and to Ceylon. There is some doubt as to how far the
doctrine had developed at this time, but at least rudimentary canon
existed, though perhaps not yet committed to writing. great Buddhist
holy places—the Lumbini Grove at Kapilavastu, where Buddha was
born, Tree of Wisdom at Gayā, where he gained enlightenment, the
Deer Park near Banaras, where he preached his first sermon, and grove
near Kusinagara, where he died-were visited by many pilgrims, including
Aśoka himself.

Though there is tradition of cruel persecution under Pusyamitra Śuṅga
the faith continued to grow. Of all religious remains of between 200 B.C.

and A.D. 200 so far discovered in India those of Buddhism far outnumber
those of brahmanism, Hinduism and Jainism, together. old stśpas were
enlarged and beautified with carved railings, terraces and gateways. All
classes of [Page 264] community, kings, princes, merchants and
craftsmen, made donations to Order, which r recorded in numerous
inscriptions. Though individual monk was bound by his vows to own no
property except bare necessities, and to touch no silver or gold, the
monasteries grew rich on alms of faithful. revenues of whole
villages were alienated to dm by pious kings, and even individual
monks began to take their vows of poverty lightly, for more than one
inscription records donations made to Order by ordained members of it.

Though there is little evidence of strong sectarian animus within Order,
sects already existed, and scriptures had been codified in more than one
recension. It is possible that much of Pali canon of Sthaviravadins,
in form in which we hv it, emanates from great monastery, the
remains of which, on hilltop near modern village of Sānchī, r among
the finest relics of early Buddhism.

Another very important sect, Sarvāstivādins, was strong in region
of Mathurā and in Kashmīr. It was in Kashmīr, acc to tradition,
preserved in China, that fourth great council was held, under the
patronage of Kaniṣka (1st-2nd century A.D., p. 60f), at which the
Sarvāstivādin doctrines were codified in summary, Mahāvibhāṣ ā. It
was chiefly among Sarvāstivādins, but also in old schism of the
Mahāsanghikas, that new ideas developed, which were to form basis of
the division of Buddhism into “Great” and “Lesser Vehicles”
( Mahāyāna and Hīnayāna). brāhmaṇs and their lay supporters had by
now largely turned from older gods, whom they worshipped with animal
sacrifices, towards others, who were worshipped with reverent devotion. In
N.-W. India rule of Greeks, Śakas and Kuṣāṇas in turn had thrown open
the gates to West, and ideas from Persia and beyond entered India in
greater strength than before. In these conditions teachers of early
Christian centuries gave to Buddhism wholly new outlook. They claimed
to hv found new and great vehicle which would carry many souls to
salvation, while Sthaviravadins and kindred sects had but small one.

The Great Vehicle became rapidly popular in many parts of India, for it
fitted mood of times and needs of many simple people better
than did Lesser Vehicle, which soon began to lose ground. In Ceylon,
however, Lesser Vehicle resisted all attacks of new sects and
thence it was taken to Burma, Siam and other parts of South-East Asia,
where it became national religion.

The Great Vehicle, on other hand, itself soon divided by various
schisms, was carried by succession of Indian monks to China and thence
to Japan. By time of Guptas it predominated, and [Page 265] Hsiian
Tsang, in 7th century, found Lesser Vehicle almost extinct in most of
India, and only flourishing in few parts of West; evidently it had
ceased to make strong emotional appeal in India of early Hinduism.

Buddhism as whole was already declining. In many places great
monasteries were in ruins, and places of pilgrimage almost deserted. But the
faith was still important, and had thousands of monks and many prosperous
monasteries. Chief of these was Nalanda (p. 164f), which, under the
patronage of kings of Pala line, remained centre of Buddhist piety and
learning until Muslim invasion. From Nalanda missionary monk
Padmasambhava went forth to convert Tibet to Buddhism in 8th
century, while pilgrims from as far afield as China and South-East Asia
visited it to learn pure doctrine.
