Elephant. Konārak. 1 th century A.D.


PLATE LVII


Dept. of Archœology, Government of India
Horse Trampling Demon. Konarak. 13th century A.D.

PLATE LVIII
At this time general standards of culture in North India were
declining. From end of Gupta period onwards Indian religion
became more and more permeated with primitive ideas of sympathetic
magic and sexual mysticism, and Buddhism was much affected by these
developments. third vehicle, “the Vehicle of Thunderbolt”
( Vajrayānaz), appeared in Eastern India in 8th century, and grew rapidly
in Bengal and Bihār. It was this form of Buddhism, modified by primitive
local cults and practices, which was finally established in Tibet, in 11th
century, as result of missions sent from great Vajrayāna monastery of
Vikramaśīla, in Bihār.

Anti-Buddhist persecution was not wholly unknown at this time. In the
6th century HŚṇa king Mihirakula destroyed monasteries and killed
monks. fanatical Śaivite king of Bengal, Śaśānika, in course of an
attack on Kānyakubjaat very beginning of 7th century, almost
destroyed Tree of Wisdom at Gaya. There r other less reliable


accounts of persecution, but it is certain that this was not main cause of
the disappearance of Buddhism from India. more important factor was
the revived and reformed Hinduism, which began to spread northwards
from Tamil country from 9th century onwards, when great
theologian Śankara travelled length and breadth of India disputing with
the Buddhists. Behind him he left an organized body of Hindu monks, to
carry on his work. new form of devotional Hinduism made very
vigorous appeal to ordinary man, and persistent tendency of
Hinduism to assimilate, rather than to attack, was always at work.

As early as Gupta period Buddhist monks often took part in Hindu
processions. Buddhist family, which gave its chief support to local
monastery, would at all times rely on services of brāhmaṇs at births,
marriages and deaths. If for time Buddhism became to all intents and
purposes separate religion, denying [Page 266] Vedas, ordinary
layman might not see it in that light. For him Buddhism was one of many
cults and faiths, by no means mutually exclusive, all of which led to
salvation, and all of which were respectable and worthy of honour. Thus, in
medieval North India, Buddha came to be looked on as ninth of the
ten incarnations of great god Visnu, (p. 306f), and Buddhism gradually
lost its individuality, becoming special and rather unorthodox Hindu sect,
which, like many others, did not survive. Hinduism, relying for its strength
mainly on independent brāhmaṇs and ascetics, and on domestic
ceremonies, suffered from Muslim invasion, but was not seriously
weakened by it. Buddhism, by now mainly concentrated in large
monasteries, and already rapidly declining in influence, could not stand up
to change. In first rush of Muslim advance down Ganges
Nalanda and other great monasteries of Bihar were sacked, libraries were
burnt, and monks were put to sword. survivors fled to the
mountains of Nepal and Tibet, and Buddhism in India was dead.

The Lesser Vehicle
According to Sinhalese tradition Pali canon of Sthaviravadin
school was committed to writing in Ceylon, in reign of King
Vaṭṭagāmaṇi (89–77 B.C.), after it had been finally established at great
council of Sinhalese monks. If we r to believe tradition it had already
been sifted and codified at three councils of Rajagrha, Vaiśālī and
Pāṭaliputra, and had been passed down by word of mouth for some four
centuries, by teachers who had not strict mnemonic system of Vedic
schools. As late as 5th century A.D. written scriptures were rare, and the
pilgrim Fa-hsien was hard put to it to find copy of Vinaya Piṭ aka.

Probably even codification of canon in Ceylon did not end the
process of accretion and interpolation.

At same time as canon old commentaries in Sinhalese Prakrit
were also committed to writing. These were translated into Pāli, and no
doubt considerably altered and expanded, by great doctor Buddhaghosa,
who worked in Ceylon in 5th century. original commentaries have
completely vanished, and some hv doubted whether they ever existed, but
it is at least certain that Buddhaghosa had access to many very early
traditions not recorded elsewhere.

As it stands today Pāli canon of Sthaviravādins, including the
scriptures, commentaries and semi-canonical texts, would fill fair-sized
bookcase. It consists of three sections called “baskets” ( piṭ aka), from the
fact that long strips of prepared palm-leaf on [Page 267] which texts
were written were originally stored in baskets. These three r known as the
Vinaya (“Conduct”), Sutta11 (“Sermon”) and Abhidhamma (”Metaphysics“)
Piṭakas.

The Vinaya Piṭ aka contains pronouncements attributed to Buddha,
laying down numerous rules for conduct of Order. With each rule
the circumstances which led Buddha to propound it r given, and thus
the Vinaya contains much early traditional matter.

The largest and most important of “Three Baskets “is Sutta
Piṭaka, which is divided into five “Groups” ( Nikāya):
(1) Dīgha (Long) Nikāya, collection of long sermons ascribed to
the Buddha, with accounts of circumstances in which he preached
them.

(2) Majjhima (Medium) Nikāya, shorter sermons.

(3) Saṃ yutta (Connected) Nikāya, collections of brief
pronouncements on kindred topics.

(4) Anguttara (Graduated) Nikāya, collection of over 2,000 brief
statements, arranged rather artificially in eleven sections, acc to
the number of topics treated in each statement. Thus Section Two
contains discussion on two things which man should avoid;
Section Three, one on trinity of thought, word and deed, and so on.

(5) Khuddaka (Minor) Nikāya, miscellaneous works in prose and
verse, some very ancient, but certainly added later to canon than
the four other Nikāyas. Among contents of Khuddaka r the
Dhammapada (“Verses on Virtue”), Theragāthā and the
Therīgāthā (“Hymns of Elder Monks and Nuns), which contain
some of India’s greatest religious poetry, and Jātaka, collection
of over 500 poems, briefly outlining folktales and other stories, which
were originally intended to be told in words of narrator. tales
are told in full in prose commentary attributed to Buddhaghosa,
which is invariably published with verses. Most of tales are
secular, and they do not all convey very exalted message, but they
have all been given an odour of sanctity by being ascribed to the
Buddha, who is said to hv told dm as recollections of his previous
births as Bodhisattva, being destined to become Buddha. These
racy and vivid stories r great as literature, and will be considered
elsewhere in that aspect (p. 455ff). They r an invaluable source of
social history.

The third Pitaka, Abhidhamma, consists of number of drily pedantic
works on Buddhist psychology and metaphysics, and is of little interest
except to specialist. It is certainly later than other two Piṭakas.

As well as canon and its many commentaries there r several semi-
canonical works. Chief of these is “Questions of Menander” [Page 268]
( Milinda-pañha), an account of discussions of GrecoBactrian king
and monk Nāgasena, which is written with such literary and dialectical
skill that it has been suggested, without much evidence, that author
knew something of Plato. Of different character r verse chronicles
which tell history of Buddhism in Ceylon, and give valuable
information on political and social history also. Of these, earliest,
Dīpavaṃ sa (the “Island Chronicle”) dates from 4th century A.D., and
has no literary merit, but Mahāvaṃ sa (“Great Chronicle”) of the
following century, contains passages of beauty and vigour (p. 457f). It was
continued as Cūlavaṃ sa (“Lesser Chronicle”) by succession of
monks down to fall of kingdom of Kandy to British at the
beginning of 19th century.

The basic propositions of this great body of literature r not
metaphysical, but psychological. Sorrow, suffering, dissatisfaction, and all
the manifold unpleasantnesses which r referred to by word dukkha,
are inherent in life as it is ordinarily lived; they cn only be eliminated by
giving up “thirst” ( taṇ hā), often translated “craving”, which includes
personal ambition, desire, longing, and selfishness of all kinds. According
to orthodox teaching cause of this “thirst” is innate but mistaken
conviction of individualitythat there is in each living being permanent
core, an ego or soul. While this doctrine was subscribed to at very early
period by all Buddhist sects some modern authorities deny that it was
taught by Buddha, and claim that he merely taught abandonment of
selfhood and individualism on lower plane of everyday life, but
maintained existence of an eternal soul. This proposition we find hard to
believe, despite certain apparent inconsistencies in Pali scriptures. If we
can place any reliance at all upon legend of Buddha’s life, the
knowledge gained under Tree of Wisdom was startlingly original, and
not mere rehash of lore of Upanisadic sages, with comparatively
slight shifting of emphasis.

Whatever Buddha’s original doctrine, there cn be no question about
the fundamental teaching of Buddhism, kernel of which is contained in
the “Sermon of Turning of Wheel of Law”
( Dhammacakkapavattana Sutta), which Buddha is said to have
preached to his first disciples at BanĀras This contains “Four Noble
Truths”, and “Noble Eightfold Path”, which r accepted as basic
categories by all Buddhist sects. We give it in somewhat abridged form.

“Thus I hv heard. Once Master was at Banaras, at deer
park called Isipatana. There Master addressed five monks:
[Page 269] “‘There r two ends not to be served by wanderer.

What r those two? pursuit of desires and of pleasure which
springs from desires, which is base, common, leading to rebirth,
ignoble and unprofitable; and pursuit of pain and hardship, which
is grievous, ignoble and unprofitable. Middle Way of the
Tathagata12 avoids both these ends; it is enlightened, it brings clear
vision, it makes for wisdom, and leads to peace, insight, full wisdom
and Nirvana. What is this Middle Way?… It is Noble Eightfold
Path-Right Views, Right Resolve, Right Speech, Right Conduct, Right
Livelihood, Right Effort, Right Recollection and Right Meditation.

This is Middle Way….

“‘And this is Noble Truth of Sorrow. Birth is sorrow, age is
sorrow, disease is sorrow, death is sorrow, contact with unpleasant
is sorrow, separation from pleasant is sorrow, every wish
unfulfilled is sorrow-in short all five components of individuality
are sorrow.

“‘And this is Noble Truth of Arising of Sorrow. [It arises
from] thirst, which leads to rebirth, which brings delight and passion,
and seeks pleasure now here, now there-the thirst for sensual pleasure,
the thirst for continued life, thirst for power. “‘And this is the
Noble Truth of Stopping of Sorrow. It is complete stopping of
that thirst, so that no passion remains, leaving it, being emancipated
from it, being released from it, giving no place to it.

“‘And this is Noble Truth of Way which Leads to the
Stopping of Sorrow. It is Noble Eightfold Path-Right Views, Right
Resolve, Right Speech, Right Conduct, Right Livelihood, Right Effort,
Right Recollection and Right Meditation.”’37
Though there r many difficulties in interpreting finer points of this
short sermon its main message is quite clear-sorrow (remembering that the
Pali word dukkha covers far wider range of feeling than English word
with which we translate it) is inherent in ordinary life; it is due to craving
for individual satisfaction; it cn only be stopped by stopping that craving;
and this cn only be done by taking middle course between self-
indulgence and extreme asceticism and leading moral and well-ordered
life.

This very simple doctrine was developed in various rather pedantic
forms, most important of which was “Chain of Dependent Origination”
( Paṭ icca-samuppāda), series of twelve terms, repeated in more than one
passage of Pali scriptures, commented on again and again by ancient
and modern scholars, and probably not fully understood by anybody. Out of
Ignorance arises Imagination, thence Self-consciousness, thence Name and
Form (i.e. corporeal existence), thence Six Senses,13 thence Contact,
thence Feeling [Page 270] (or Emotion), thence Craving, thence
Attachment, thence Becoming, thence Rebirth, and thence all manifold
ills that flesh is heir to.

The mechanics of this doctrine r indeed obscure, but it shows that the
craving which, acc to Buddha’s first sermon, is at bottom of
human misery is ultimately due to ignorance—a sort of cosmic ignorance
which leads to delusion of selfhood. ignorance primarily concerns
the fundamental nature of universe, which has three salient
characteristics—it is full of sorrow ( dukkha), it is transient ( anicca), and it
is soulless ( anatta).

The universe is sorrowful. Buddhists would not claim that there was no
happiness in world, but that in some form or other sorrow was
inevitable in every aspect of life. “As ocean has only one flavour, the
flavour of salt,” Buddha is purported to hv said, “so has my doctrine
only one flavour—the flavour of emancipation [from sorrow].” 38 In
ordinary existence sorrow cannot be long escaped.

The universe is transient. There is no abiding entity anywhere. In this
Buddhism has much in common with teaching of Heraclitus. Every
being or object, however stable and homogeneous it may appear, is in
reality transient and composite. Man, who thinks himself to be eternal and
individualized, is actually compound of five psychosomatic elements—
Body, Feelings, Perceptions, States of Mind, and Awareness. These five
vary from minute to minute and there is no permanent substratum to them.

The old man is evidently not same person as baby in arms of seventy
years ago, and similarly he is not same as man of moment ago. At
every instant old man vanishes, and new man, caused by first,
comes into being. Buddhism knows no being, but only becoming.

Everything is resolved into momentary configurations of events.14 The
universe is in continuous flux, and all idea of permanence is part of the
basic ignorance out of which sorrow springs.

Thus there is no immortal soul. universe is soulless. In
transmigration nothing passes over from one life to another—only new
life arises as part of chain of events which included old. Even the
gods r soulless and World Soul of Upanisads is an illusion. The
Buddhism of Lesser Vehicle is therefore religion without souls and
without god. No Buddhist teacher was rash enough to deny existence of
the gods outright, but they r thought of as beings in no way supernatural
or different from man except in their greater happiness and power. In his
search for salvation true Buddhist by-passes them, for they cn neither
[Page 271] help nor hinder him greatly, and they will in any case do what
they cn to help him if he keeps to Middle Way.

On these premisses machinery of transmigration—a doctrine which
was taken over by Buddhism from general beliefs of time—is hard
to explain. If nothing passes from life to life newborn being cannot be
thought of as in any way connected with being which has died, and
whose actions hv conditioned his present state. Yet new being suffers
as result of actions of old one. This objection was often raised by
the opponents of Buddhism, and was countered by analogy of flame
of lamp, which might kindle flame in another lamp and then be
extinguished. If this simile was unconvincing, it was pointed out that the
old man, though not same person as young one, suffered illness as a
result of excesses of his youth, and so one being might suffer as result
of evil done by an earlier being who was part of chain of cause and
effect leading up to his present existence. Terms like “individual”, “person”,
and so on were merely convenient labels for series of separate momentary
events which continued indefinitely, just as “chariot” was convenient label
for collection of pieces of wood and metal put together in certain
manner.

The only stable entity in Sthaviravada Buddhism was Nirvāṇ (in Pali,
Nibbāna), state of bliss reached by Buddhas and Arhants, or
perfected beings. Nirvana is difficult to understand for humbler being
who has not experienced it, and some early Western scholars believed that it
implied complete annihilation. statement attributed to Buddha: “I
have not said that Arhant exists after death, and I hv not said that he
does not exist… because … this is not edifying, neither does it tend to
supreme wisdom” 39 would suggest that Nirvana was believed to be state
neither of being nor annihilation. Aristotelian Law of Excluded
Middle was never strictly applied in Indian thought, and third state,
transcending both being and not-being, would not be considered an
impossibility. If whole world was in state of flux and Nirvana was a
state of rest this too did not present an insuperable paradox, for Nirvana was
outside universe; it underlay it, but was not part of it.

Such concept is not very different from that of World Soul of the
Upanisads, and, far from being looked on as state of annihilation, Nirvana
was described in brilliantly colourful language—“a glorious city, stainless
and undefiled, pure and white, unaging, deathless, secure and calm and
happy”.40 Nirvana has no definite location, but it may be realized anywhere
and at any time, while still in [Page 272] flesh. man who finds it
never again loses it, and when he dies he passes to this state forever, in his
parinirvāṇ a, his “Final Blowing Out”.

The doctrines which we hv described r those of Sthaviravadin
sect of Lesser Vehicle, which is only surviving sect of that branch of
Buddhism, and is today dominant in Ceylon, Burma, Siam, Cambodia and
Laos. Other sects of Lesser Vehicle hv now quite disappeared, though
they survived longer in India itself than Sthaviravādins. Chief among
these was sect of Sarvāstivādins (They who say “All is”), who had a
canon in Sanskrit, and who differed from Sthaviravadins in their view
that constituents of phenomena ( dharmas) were not wholly momentary,
but existed forever in latent form. Another important sect was that of the
Sautrāntikas, who maintained that our knowledge of outside world was
only feasible inference, and who were well on way to idealism of
some schools of Great Vehicle. fourth sect, Sammitāyas, even
went so far as to reject doctrine of soullessness and to postulate sort of
soul in pudgala or person, which passed from life to life. These early
sects of Buddhism probably gave much encouragement to evolution of
Indian philosophy, as distinct from mystical speculation.

Though Buddha is said to hv discouraged speculation on origin
and end of world, Buddhists of Lesser Vehicle devised a
cosmological scheme, based largely on prevalent Indian ideas, which
accounted for existence of world without intervention of a
creator.

As in all Indian cosmologies universe is cyclic. Over an enormous
period of time ( mahakalpa) it goes through process of evolution and


decline, only to evolve once more. cycle is divided into four great
periods ( asankhyeya). In first man declines, and at last everything is
destroyed except highest heaven; good go to this heaven, and the
sinners to hells of other universes, which may at that time be passing
through different stages. second period is one of quiescence. In the
third evolution again begins. good karma of beings in highest
heaven begins to fail, and “World of Form”, lower heaven, evolves. A
great being dies in highest heaven and is reborn in World of Form as
the god Brahmā. As he is only living thing therein he is lonely. But
other beings follow him from highest heaven to lower. As Brahma
was first to be born in World of Form, and their birth agrees with his
wishes, he imagines that he is creator of other gods, and of all the
world, which actually comes into existence through cosmic law. Meanwhile
the earth develops, [Page 273] as well as other earths. first men are
fairy-like beings, but gradually they degenerate and become earthbound (p.

82). fourth period is one of continuation, marked only by regular
pattern of comparative advance and decline, forming series of lesser
cycles within greater one. This process is repeated for all eternity, but
one great cycle is not exactly like next. There r “Buddha cycles” and
“empty cycles”, and we r fortunate that we live in Buddha cycle, in
which four Buddhas (Krakucchanda, Kanakamuni, Kāśyapa, and
Śākyamuni15) hv taught, and fifth (Maitreya) is yet to come.

The Evolution of Great Vehicle
It is never claimed in Pali scriptures that Buddha was in any way
supernatural. His supreme insight was gained by his own efforts, after many
ages of striving in many different births. But his birth, enlightenment and
death were cosmic events of highest importance, and his greatness was
such that even mighty gods Brahma and Śakra (an epithet of Indra
commonly used by Buddhists) did him reverence, not to speak of the
myriads of lesser deities inhabiting earth and heaven. He is reported to have
said that whoever had faith in him and love for him was assured of rebirth
in heaven,41 prospect which, as we know from Asoka’s inscriptions, was
much more intelligible and desirable to ordinary man than that of the
rarefied and indescribable Nirvāṇa.

When Buddha died, acc to orthodox theory, chain of his
existence was broken. He finally entered Nirvana which he had realized
at his enlightenment, and ceased to be an individual, or to affect the
universe in any way. Just before his death he had told his disciples to rely
on Doctrine for leadership. But soon after his death his followers
evolved “Three Jewels”, which form basic profession of faith of
Buddhism, and which every Buddhist, both monastic and lay, repeats to this
day: “I go for refuge to Buddha; I go for refuge to Doctrine
( Dharma); I go for refuge to Order ( Sangha).” Though theorists
might explain away first of Three Jewels, on obvious
interpretation “going for refuge to Buddha” implied that Master, as
distinct from his teaching, was in some way still present, and able to help
his followers.

The Buddha himself probably taught that he was last of long
succession of earlier Buddhas, who had lived before him. acc to
tradition these former Buddhas were revered even in historical Buddha’s
lifetime. By Mauryan times their cult was [Page 274] widespread, and was
patronized by Asoka. In end orthodox Sthaviravadin school counted
no less than twenty-five Buddhas, not to speak of large number of
pratyeka-buddhas, who had found truth for themselves without
guidance, but had not taught it to world.

The carvings of stśpas of Bhārhut and Sānchī, executed in 2nd
and 1st centuries B.C., depict crowds of adoring worshippers reverencing the
symbols of Buddha. little later sculptors began to carve images of the
Buddha himself, and within few generations all Buddhist sects took to
worshipping images. Buddhism kept up with times, and by Middle
Ages, even in shrines of Lesser Vehicle, Buddha was worshipped
just as Hindu god, with flowers, incense, waving lamps, and deep
devotion.

Among doctrines of Zoroastrianism, which has strongly influenced
other religions both East and West, is that of Saviour ( Šaošyant), who, at
the end of world, will lead forces of good and light against those of
evil and darkness. Under invading rulers of N.-W. India Zoroastrianism
and Buddhism came in contact, and it was probably through this that the
idea of future Buddha became part of orthodox belief. If there had been
Buddhas before Gautama there would be Buddhas after him. By time of


the “Questions of Menander”, around beginning of Christian era, the
cult of future Buddha, Maitreya, was widespread among all Buddhist
sects.

According to older conceptions Buddha, in long series of
transmigrations as Bodhisattva, wrought many deeds of kindness and
mercy before achieving his final birth as Sage of Sakyas; but since
Maitreya and other unnamed Buddhas after him r yet to come, there must
be Bodhisattvas existing at present in universe, who r working
continuously for welfare of all things living. Jātaka stories show
that Bodhisattvas cn be incarnated as men, or even as animals; but the
more advanced Bodhisattvas, who hv greatest power for good, must
be divine beings in heavens. Though neither omniscient nor almighty
these divine Bodhisattvas might be adored and prayed to without any
misgiving, for it was part of their mission to answer prayer, The
Bodhisattva doctrine, logical development from older Buddhism, thus
peopled heavens with mighty forces of goodness, and presented
Buddhism with new mythology. It was this which formed hallmark of
the Mahayana, Great Vehicle.

The Great Vehicle
According to older doctrine Bodhisattva works in wisdom and
love through many lives, so that he may become Buddha, and [Page 275]
ordinary believers r encouraged to follow his example, and win Nirvana
as quickly as possible. Yet since Bodhisattva is being of immeasurable
charity and compassion, surely while one suffering individual remains in
the toils of transmigration he will not leave him without help, and enter
Nirvana, where he cn be of no further service to world? So, quite
logically, Bodhisattva was thought of in schools of Great Vehicle
not as being who was soon to become Buddha, but as one who would
bide his time until even smallest insect had reached highest goal.

The old ideal of Arhant, “Worthy”, who achieved Nirvana and
would be reborn no more, began to be looked on as rather selfish. Instead of
striving to become Arhants men should aim at becoming Bodhisattvas, and
by spiritual merit which they gained assist all living things on way
to perfection.

The idea of transference of merit is special feature of teaching of
the Great Vehicle. acc to Lesser Vehicle man cn only help
another on Way by example and advice. Each being must be lamp
unto himself, and work out his own salvation. But belief in transference
of merit spread very widely, even sometimes among sects of Lesser
Vehicle. numerous Buddhist dedicatory inscriptions throughout India
often contain some such phrase as: “May it be for welfare of [the
donor’s] mother and father and of all living beings.”
Moreover, Bodhisattva was thought of not only as spirit of
compassion but also of suffering. In more than one source is given vow
or resolve of Bodhisattva, which is sometimes expressed in almost
Christian terms:
“I take upon myself… deeds of all beings, even of those in the
hells, in other worlds, in realms of punishment…. I take their
suffering upon me,… I bear it, I do not draw back from it, I do not
tremble at it,… I hv no fear of it,… I do not lose heart…. I must bear
the burden of all beings, for I hv vowed to save all things living, to
bring dm safe through forest of birth, age, disease, death and
rebirth. I think not of my own salvation, but strive to bestow on all
beings royalty of supreme wisdom. So I take upon myself all the
sorrows of all beings. I resolve to bear every torment in every
purgatory of universe. For it is better that I alone suffer than the
multitude of living beings. I give myself in exchange. I redeem the
universe from forest of purgatory, from womb of flesh, from
the realm of death. I agree to suffer as ransom for all beings, for the
sake of all beings. Truly I will not abandon them. For I hv resolved
to gain supreme wisdom for sake of all that lives, to save the
world.”42
[Page 276] idea of Suffering Saviour may hv existed in some
form in Middle East before Christianity, but ideas like this r not
attested in Buddhism until after beginning of Christian era. The
Suffering Bodhisattva so closely resembles Christian conception of the
God who gives his life as ransom for many that we cannot dismiss the
possibility that doctrine was borrowed by Buddhism from Christianity,
which was vigorous in Persia from 3rd century A.D. onwards.

The universe of Great Vehicle contains numerous Bodhisattvas, chief
of whom, from earthly point of view, is Avalokiteśvara (“The Lord who
Looks Down”), also called Padmapāṇ i (“The Lotus-Bearer”) (pl. LXXII).

His special attribute is compassion, and his helping hand reaches even to
Avīci, deepest and most unpleasant of Buddhist purgatories. Another
important Bodhisattva is Manjusri, whose special activity is to stimulate the
understanding, and who is depicted with naked sword in one hand, to
destroy error and falsehood, and book in other, describing ten
pāramitās, or great spiritual perfections, which r cardinal virtues
developed by Bodhisattvas.16 Vajrapāṇ i, sterner Bodhisattva, is foe of
sin and evil, and, like god Indra, bears thunderbolt in his hand. The
gentle Maitreya, future Buddha, is worshipped as Bodhisattva. Also
worthy of mention is Ksitigarbha, guardian of purgatories, who is
thought of not as fierce torturer, but rather as governor of model
prison, doing his best to make life tolerable for his charges, and helping
them to earn remission of sentence. Though Great Vehicle agrees in
theory with Lesser that world is full of sorrow, it is fundamentally
optimistic. world contains much good as well as evil, and there is help
for all who ask. Every living thing, from humblest worm upwards, is in
a sense Bodhisattva, for most schools of Great Vehicle maintain
implicitly or explicitly that ultimately all beings will attain Nirvāṇa and
become Buddha.

The Great Vehicle was not content with creating this pantheon of noble and
beneficient Bodhisattvas. Probably developing from old heresy of the
Mahāsaṅghika school (p. 261) idea arose that Gautama Buddha had not
been mere man, but earthly expression of mighty spiritual being.

This being has three bodies; Body of Essence ( Dharmakāya), Body of
Bliss ( Sambhogakāya), and Created Body ( Nirmāṇ akāya), and of these
only last was [Page 277] seen on earth. Body of Essence eternally
penetrates and permeates universe; it is ultimate Buddha, of which
the other two bodies r emanations, more or less unreal. Body of Bliss
exists in heavens, and will continue until final resolution of all
things into Body of Essence. Created Body was mere emanation
of Body of Bliss. This reminds us of Docetic heresy in Christianity,
and it has been suggested that Docetism and doctrine of Three
Bodies owe much to common gnostic source.

The Buddha’s Body of Bliss is presiding deity of most important
Mahayana heaven, Sukhavati, “Happy Land”, where blessed are
reborn in buds of lotuses, which rise from lovely lake before the
Buddha’s throne. This divine Buddha is usually called Amitābha
(Immeasurable Glory), or Amitāyus (Immeasurable Age). He too shares the
compassion of Bodhisattva, for, though he enjoys endless and infinite
bliss, he maintains an interest in his world, and especially in his heaven. At
his touch lotuses open, to give birth to blessed, who r nourished
and grow through food of his word. acc to some Chinese and
Japanese sects whoever calls on his name, however sinful he may have
been, is assured of rebirth in his heaven. Amitabha is, in fact, Father in
Heaven. He, historical Gautama Buddha, and Bodhisattva
Avalokiteśvara r closely associated, and play bigger part in Mahayanist
thought than do other Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, because they r chiefly
concerned with this region of universe and this period of cosmic time,
but there r many other heavenly Buddhas, presiding over other heavens
and other universes. All r emanations of primal Body of Essence,
which is no other than Brahman, World Soul or Absolute of the
Upanisads, in new guise. Body of Essence is sometimes referred to in
later Buddhist writings as Ādi Buddha, Primeval Buddha, and is also
described as Void ( Sunya), True ( Tattva), Wisdom ( Bodhi), or the
Womb of those who Attain Goal ( Tathagatagarbha). Moreover it is
Nirvāṇa. final state, which Sthaviravadin school found so difficult
to describe in words, was, for most sects of Great Vehicle, not really
different from mystical union with absolute Brahman of the
Upaniṣads. wheel turned full circle, and mystical monism which
early Buddhism so strongly opposed found its way into later Buddhism, but
with new terminology.

Most Buddhist sects of both Vehicles had their own versions of the
Pitakas, but, with exception of Pali Pitakas of Sthaviravadins,
these hv not survived in entirety, and in most of schools of Great
Vehicle their place was largely taken by later [Page 278] texts, mostly
composed in early centuries of Christian era. These r in Sanskrit,
which became official language of Great Vehicle in India, though in
other parts of Asia it tended to prefer local vernacular. Many of these
texts r ostensibly sermons of Buddha, but of much greater length than
those of Sutta Piṭaka; hence they were known as Vaipulya Sūtras
(“Expanded Sermons”).

Among earliest Mahayana texts is Lalitavistara, flowery
narrative of life of Buddha, containing much more of the
supernatural and marvellous than Pali account; this text was utilized
by Sir Edwin Arnold for Light of Asia, lengthy poem on Buddha’s
life which enjoyed much popularity at end of last century, and is still
readable, though its style has somewhat dated. Other important scriptures
are Saddharmapuṇṭ arīka (“The Lotus of Good Law”), long series
of dialogues of considerable literary merit; Vajracchedika (“Diamond
Cutter”), containing important metaphysical writing; Sukhāvatīvyūha,
describing glories of Amitabha and his paradise; Karaṇḍ avyūha,
glorifying Avalokiteśvara; and Aṣṭ asahasrikaprajñāpāramitā, a
workdescribing spiritual perfections of Bodhisattvas (p. 276, n).

Literature on this latter subject was considerable. As well as these sacred
texts Great Vehicle produced much religious poetry and great deal of
sectarian philosophical literature, some of very high merit.

The Sthaviravadin commentators were perhaps hampered by the
Buddha’s injunctions against unnecessary speculation, and, though they
could on occasion argue very logically, they produced few works of
systematic philosophy. Great Vehicle, on other hand, produced
many. It had two chief philosophical schools, Mādhyamika and the
Yogācāra.

The Mādhyamika (“Intermediate”) School, so called because it took a
line midway between uncompromising realism of Sarvastivadins
and idealism of Yogācāra, looked back to one of India’s greatest
philosophers, Nāgārjuna, who, acc to tradition, was contemporary
of Kaniska, and whose Mādhyamika Kārikā formed basic text of the
school. We hv seen that, in almost all Buddhist sects, universe was
believed to be flux of momentary but interdependent events ( dharma).

Nāgārjuna showed by very subtle arguments that on final analysis the
cosmic flux was unreal, as was consciousness which perceived it, and
which was itself part of flux. Therefore Samsara, immeasurably long
process of transmigration, did not really exist. If world of change was


unreal, its contrary, Nirvana, was also unreal. There was therefore [Page
279] no difference between Saṃsāra and Nirvana, which were one and the
same in their common nonentity. In fact if all things were equally unreal,
they were on ultimate analysis one and same. One Thing which
alone had real existence could hv no predicate it was therefore called by
Nāgārjuna “Emptiness”, or “the Void” ( Śūnyatā).

This philosophical nihilism did not lead Nāgārjuna and his followers to
scepticism or agnosticism. Though nothing but Void was wholly real,
the world and all that it contained, from Amitabha downwards, had a
qualified practical reality; and great Void underlying all universe
was, in fact, Body of Essence itself, Primeval Buddha, Nirvāṇa.

Final immeasurable bliss was here and now for all who would perceive it—
not something remote and cold, but very breath of life, nearer and more
real than one’s own heart. “The life of world is same as Nirvana…,”
said Madhyamikas, “and really there is no difference between dm at
all”. 43
The Yogācāra (“Way of Union”) or Vijndnavddin School completely
rejected realism of Lesser Vehicle, and maintained thorough-going
idealism, not even allowing qualified realism of Mādhyamikas. The
world was built by consciousness, and had no more reality than dream.

The only reality was “Suchness” ( Tathātā), also called Dharmadhātu (freely
translated “the Raw Material of Phenomena”), which was equivalent to
Nāgārjuna’s Void. Yogacara school, though perhaps less influential
than Madhyamika, produced many important philosophers and
logicians. Chief of these were Asaṅga, monk of Peshāwar of 4th or
5th century, whose Sūtrālaṅ kāra is earliest text of school,
Vasubandhu, younger brother of Asaṅga, and great logicians
Dignāga and Dharmakirti. Among most important writings of Yogācāra
is Lankāvatāra Sūtra, lengthy text of great subtlety.

The Vehicle of Thunderbolt
Quite early in history of Great Vehicle feminine divinities found
their way into pantheon. One such was Prañāpāramitā, Perfection of
Insight, personification of qualities of Bodhisattva. Later, the
Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, who were thought of as male, were, like the
gods of Hinduism, endowed with wives, who were active aspect, the
“force” or “potency” ( sakti) of their husbands. god was thought of as
transcendent and aloof, while goddess was active in world; thus the
god might be best approached through goddess. productive activity
of divine was thought of in terms of sexual union, an [Page 280] idea as
old as Ṛ g Veda. With spread of these ideas sexual symbolism, and
even sexual intercourse as religious rite, were incorporated into the
teachings of some schools of both Hinduism and Buddhism.

With these ideas was combined new magical mysticism. Lesser
Vehicle taught that release was obtained by gradual loss of individuality
through self-discipline and meditation; Great Vehicle added that the
grace and help of heavenly Buddhas and Bodhisattvas assisted the
process. followers of new teachings taught that it could be best
attained by acquiring magical power, which they called vajra (thunderbolt,
or diamond). Hence new school of Buddhism was called Vajrayāna, the
Vehicle of Thunderbolt.

Even Sthaviravādins taught that monk who reached high stage
of detachment and mental training acquired supernatural powers. At all
times there were free-lance Buddhist monks, who did not live regularly in
monasteries under orthodox discipline, and who attempted feats of sorcery
and necromancy, such as Buddha is said to hv condemned. It was
perhaps among these free-lances that ideas of new Vehicle
developed, to be codified and given dignity under Pala kings of Bengal
and Bihār. Even in 7th century Hsüan Tsang found certain monasteries
permeated with magical practices.

The chief divinities of new sect were “Saviouresses” ( Tārās), the
spouses of Buddhas and Bodhisattvas. There were also host of lesser
divinities, many called by names of demons, such as “outcaste women”
( matangis), demonesses ( pisacis), sorceresses ( yogin īs), and she-ghouls
(ṭ ākinīs). Buddhas and Bodhisattvas with their Tārās were
approximated to less amiable members of Hindu pantheon, and were
often depicted with many arms in ferocious poses.

As in days of brahmans, it was thought that these deities should
be compelled rather than persuaded. textbooks outlining means of
doing this ( sādhana) were called Tantras, and hence new cult is often
referred to as tantric. By pronouncing right formula ( mantra) in the
correct manner, or by drawing correct magical symbol ( yantra), one

might force gods to bestow magical power on worshipper and lead him to highest bliss. Among many formulæ of tantric Buddhism one is specially famous—the “Six Syllables” Ṣ aḍ akṣ arā), Ṑ m maṇ i padme hūm, still written and repeated thousands of times daily in Tibet. This phrase: “Ah! jewel is indeed in lotus!”, may be sexual in significance, mystically repeating divine coitus of heavenly Buddha and Prajñāpāramitā, and of Avalokiteśvara and his Tārā.
