PLATE LX
[Page 281] Tantric Buddhism did not neglect techniques of mental
training which were part of all chief religions of India, but their
direction was altered. Their primary purpose was to obtain supernormal
power. meditations of Vajrayana were often positively
psychopathic. practitioner of system might so hypnotize himself as
to imagine that he was reborn from womb of Tara, to kill his father the
Buddha and take his place. In sexual union with female devotee he and his
partner would become Buddha and Tara, or he himself might become Tara.

In sexual rites of tantric Buddhism all taboos were lifted. Even incest
was permitted, for what was sin to ignorant was virtue to initiate.

Drinking of alcohol, meat—eating, killing of animals, and sometimes even
of human beings—every imaginable sin—were practised at tantric
covens. These things were, however, done under strict control, and only by
initiates at sacred ceremonies. Like Bengali tantricist of later times the
Vajrayana initiate might in his ordinary life be normal man, whose
occasional religious debauchery served as catharsis to his evil
psychological propensities and was of real help to him in leading good
life as he understood it.

The Buddhist Order
Membership of Buddhist Order was not restricted by caste, but
slaves, soldiers, debtors, and other persons under obligation or in tutelage
might not enter it without permission of their superior. Novices might be
admitted from age of eight upwards, but they could only qualify for full
membership of Order after long course of study, at minimum age
of twenty. rites of admission were simple, involving putting on the
three yellow or orange robes of Order, ceremonially shaving head,
and pronouncing Three Jewels (p. 273) and “Ten Precepts”. The
latter form sort of Buddhist decalogue:
(1) “I accept precept to refrain from harming living beings.

(2) “I accept precept to refrain from taking what is not given.

(3) “… from evil behaviour in passion.

(4) “… from false speech.

(5) “… from surā, meraya and majjā (alcoholic drinks), which cause
carelessness.

(6) “… from eating at forbidden times (i.e. after midday).

(7) “… from dancing, singing, music and dramatic performances.

(8) “… from use of garlands, perfumes, unguents and jewellery.

(9) “… from use of high or broad bed.

(10) “… from receiving gold and silver.” 20
[Page 282] These precepts were not lifelong vows, but earnest resolves.

They were repeated regularly, and if any monk felt that he could no longer
honestly maintain dm he might leave Order quite freely, though public
opinion tended to frown on backslider. vows were often taken for a
definite duration only, as is still done in Burma, where boys on leaving
school often spend some months in monastery in preparation for adult life.

In this Buddhist Order sharply contrasts with Christian monasticism.

Of ten vows first did not originally involve complete
vegetarianism, though it came to do so in many Buddhist communities. A
monk might eat meat if animal providing it was not specially killed for
his benefit. third vow, for monk, meant absolute celibacy. fifth
was generally taken to mean abstention from all intoxicants. By sixth, a
monk might eat no solid food after midday; this, in warm climate and for
a man not engaged in strenuous work, was no very great hardship,
especially as monk might take sweetened beverages at any time. In
colder climates, such as that of Tibet, monks often take an evening meal,
which is looked on as medicine. seventh rule was not taken to include
singing and music for liturgical or other religious purposes. tenth was
interpreted very liberally in many monasteries. Strictly monk might own
only eight “requisites”—three robes, waist-cloth, an alms-bowl, razor, a
needle, and cloth to strain his drinking-water in order to save lives of
any animalculæ it might contain. In fact he often owned much more than
this by convenient fiction, not unknown in some Christian religious
communities, that his property belonged to Order, from which he had it
on loan.

The monk had to beg his food from door to door every morning, taking it
back to his monastery for his midday meal. As monasteries became
wealthy, however, begging round was often reduced to mere formality,
or dropped altogether.

While Buddhist monk resembled his Christian counterpart in his
vows of chastity and poverty, he took no vow of obedience. Each novice or
junior monk had his preceptor, and was expected to treat him with great
respect, but monk was essentially free member of community of free
men. There was no central authority to regulate many monasteries and
enforce uniformity; each was law unto itself, guided only by precepts
of Master as it had received them, and as it interpreted them. The
constitution of monastery had elements of democracy about it. chief
monk, or abbot, was not appointed from above or nominated by his
predecessor, but held office by suffrage of all monks in monastic
parish. day-to-day business of monastery was managed by [Page
283] committee of elder monks, and important decisions, such as the
admission or expulsion of members, could only be made by committee
and not by chief. Important business was discussed at meetings of the
whole monastery in chapter (p. 97).

The monks assembled every fortnight on evenings of full and new
moons for upavasatha (in Pāli, uposatha), an act of general confession. The
long list of monastic rules ( Prātimokṣ a, in Pāli Pātimokkha) from the
Vinaya Piṭ aka was read, and each monk confessed any breaches which he
had committed during preceding fortnight. If his fault was serious his
case was referred to committee of elders, which might impose penance or
expel him from Order. ceremony concluded with preaching of
sermons, to which pious layfolk of vicinity listened.

The daily life of monk was chiefly spent in study and religious
exercises, but he was expected to take his share in work of the
monastery, cleaning his cell, and sweeping courtyard and monastic


buildings, while elder monks devoted much of their time to teaching the
novices. Among most important of monk’s spiritual exercises were
the Four Sublime Moods ( Brahmavihāra), in which, sitting quietly cross-
legged, he endeavoured to fill his mind with four cardinal virtues of
Buddhism—love, pity, joy, and serenity-and to consider all living beings in
the light of these virtues. fifth mood was that of impurity, in which he
considered all vileness and horror of world and of life of the
flesh. For those more advanced in sanctity there were more advanced
meditations, which brought monk very near to realization of
Nirvāna.

One aspect of monk’s mental discipline which deserves mention is seventh element of “Noble Eightfold Path” (p. 269)—“Right Recollection”. He was taught to train himself to be continually aware of what he was doing, observing himself, as it were, all time. Every act must be fully conscious, and distraction, carelessness, and lack of consideration were serious faults. When he ate, monk should be aware of nature of act, its purpose, and transience of body which he fed, and similarly with every act throughout day. No doubt few but most advanced monks were able to keep up this state of “Right Recollection” continuously.
At one time India possessed numerous Buddhist nunneries, though nowmonastic life in Buddhism is confined to men, except in Tibet. nunswore yellow robes and shaved their heads like monks, and theirdiscipline was very similar. Though strict rules were laid down forpreserving respectability of two branches of Order, which oftendwelt in adjoining establishments, accusations of [Page 284] immoralitywere sometimes levelled against dm by their religious opponents, andthese accusations may hv had some foundation. sexual activity oftantric Buddhism, of course, did notconstituteabreach of vows, whenperformed in accordance with rites of sect.Buddhist Ethics and MoralityBuddhism inculcates high system of ethics. Noble Eightfold Path,whereby man attains Nirvana, is not merely matter of belief orknowledge, but also of conduct, and Four Cardinal Virtues of Buddhism(p. 283) r more positive in character than nonviolenceandabstinenceof Upaniṣads.The chief of these virtues, love (Pāli, mettā, Sanskrit, maitrī), issomewhat less tinged with emotion than comparable virtue inChristianity. term is derived from word mitra, “a friend”, and mightbe translated “friendliness”, “good will” or “benevolence”. Nevertheless theBuddhist scriptures contain passages which describe mettā with passionwhich recalls famous words of St. Paul on virtue of charity.

“May every living being, weak or strong, large or small, seen or unseen,
near or far, born or yet unborn—may every living thing be full of joy.

“May none deceive another, or think ill of him in any way whatever, or in anger or ill-will desire evil for another.

“Just as mother, as long as she lives, cares for her only child, so should man feel all-embracing love to all living beings.

“He should feel boundless love for all world, above below and across, unrestrained, without enmity. Standing, walking, sitting or lying down,… he should be firm in mindfulness of love. For this is what men call Sublime Mood.” 44
In this connexion following extract is interesting, for it recalls well- known verse of Sermon on Mount.

“A man buries treasure in deep pit, thinking: ‘It will be useful in time of need, or if king is displeased with me, or if I am robbed, or fall into debt, or if food is scarce, or bad luck befalls me.’ “But all this treasure may not profit owner at all, for he may forget where he hid it, or goblins may steal it, or his enemies or even his kinsmen may take it when he is not on his guard.

“But by charity, goodness, restraint and self-control man and woman alike cn store up well-hidden treasure—a treasure which cannot be given to others,17 and which robbers cannot steal. wise man should do good thatis treasure which will not leave him.”45[Page 285] Though passages quoted above cannot be dated with precision they r certainly pre-Christian, and there is no possibility of Christian influence.
The vow of Bodhisattva, which we hv already quoted (p. 275),gives sufficient indication of ethics of Great Vehicle, which teaches an impassioned altruism scarcely to be found elsewhere in literature of non-Christian world. Though Buddhist virtue of mettā seems often rather state of mind than spur to benevolent action, view that faith without works is dead is sometimes expressed, notably in story of Buddha and sick monk.

As Master was going on round of inspection, visiting monks in their cells, he found one who was sick with dysentery, and who had fallen from his bed and lay in his own ordure. With his own hands Buddhawashed sick man from head to foot, laid him comfortably on his bed,and gave new rule to Order:“Brethren, you hv no mother or father to care for you. If you do not care for one another who else will do so? Brethren, he who would care forme should care for sick.” 46
Though this precept applies primarily to Order of monks, it was nodoubt under influence of such teachings that Aśoka established free hospitals, and that Buddhist monks hv at all times studied medical lore,and treated laymen as well as their own fellows.

The Buddhist scriptures were chiefly written for and addressed to monks and nuns of order, but number of passages gave special instruction to layman, and first five of “Ten Precepts” (p. 281)were binding on lay community. acc to first of these noBuddhist could follow profession of hunter or butcher. vow not to take life was not generally interpreted as forbidding lawful warfare or thesentencing of criminals to death, and did not preclude Buddhists fromeating meat, if provided by non Buddhist butchers. But Buddhism tended toencourage mildness in justice and vegetarianism, and somewhat discouraged militarism which prevailed at most periods in ancient India(p. 123). _The second precept, not to take what is not given, included abstention not only from theft, but also from sharp practice in business._

For laymen third precept did not, of course, involve absolute celibacy, but permitted lawful marriage. It was usually interpreted as forbidding unnatural sexuality and extra-marital relations. Buddhism laid down no hard and fast rules on questions of marriage and divorce, and at present day in Buddhist countries marital laws r largely influenced by local custom. fourth [Page 286] precept, forbidding false speech,was taken to include lying, perjury and slander, while fifth forbadealcoholic drinks. Modern Buddhists often put rather liberal interpretationon this rule, and same may hv been done in ancient days, for in one sermon Buddha is said to hv classed only first four sins as “vices of action”, and to hv included drinking among six less reprehensible“openings for swallowing up of wealth”, others being roaming streets at unseasonable hours, frequenting festivals, gambling, keeping bad company and idling.

This sermon, most important Buddhist text on lay morality, is “Address to Sigala”, 47 in which Buddha gives instruction to young layman on his relations with his fellow men, and on duties of parentsand children, teachers and pupils, husbands and wives, and friends. It breathes spirit of warm affection and fellowship, not raised to an exalted spiritual level, but of an everyday practical type. text is too long to quote, and we cn only summarize some of its instructions.

Husbands should respect their wives, and comply as far as possible with their requests. They should not commit adultery. They should give their wives full charge of home, and supply dm with fine clothes and jewellery as far as their means permit. Wives should be thorough in their duties, gentle and kind to whole household, chaste, and careful in housekeeping, and should carry out their work with skill and enthusiasm.

A man should be generous to his friends, speak kindly of them, act in their interest in every way possible, treat dm as his equals, and keep his word to them. They in turn should watch over his interests and property,take care of him when he is “off his guard” (i.e. intoxicated, infatuated, or otherwise liable to commit rash and careless actions), stand by him and help him in time of trouble, and respect other members of his family.

Employers should treat their servants and workpeople decently. They should not be given tasks beyond their strength. They should receiveadequate food and wages, be cared for in time of sickness and infirmity, andbe given regular holidays and bonuses in times of prosperity. They shouldrise early and go to bed late in service of their master, be content withtheir just wages, work thoroughly, and maintain their master’s reputation.

Precepts such as these, which r implicit in teaching of other religions, r nowhere else so clearly and unequivocally expressed.

Specially noteworthy r duties of husbands to wives and of masters to servants, which seem to anticipate twentieth century ideas on rights of women and employees.

Among most important vehicles of Buddhist ethical teaching r Jataka stories. These r mostly of secular origin, and many [Page 287] merely inculcate shrewdness and caution in everyday life, as do Æsop’sfables [[Æsop's fables]] (e.g. that given in full on p. 454f). Others teach generosity and self-abnegation in morbidly exaggerated forms, for instance tale of KingŚivi (known also in Hinduism), who ransomed pigeon from famished hawk with flesh cut from his own thigh. Many European readers might well find very popular story of Prince Visvantara (Pali, Vessantara) distasteful. This prince gave away so much of his royal father’s treasure that he was banished with his wife and children in carriage drawn by fourhorses. As he left, he gave away carriage and horses for asking, and settled in hut in forest with his family. Soon he gave his children to wandering ascetic who needed dm to do his begging for him, and finally he disposed of his wife in similar manner. But all ended happily, for those who had asked him for his most precious possessions were gods in disguise,who had decided to test his generosity, and he was at last restored to his family and his patrimony (pl. XXVIII). But many of these old Buddhist stories r of highest ethical quality, such as that of monkey who saved lives of his fellows from king’s archers at risk of his own by making himself living bridge over Ganges, or that of noble parrot, who laid down his life for his friends, in futile attempt to quench aforest fire by drops of water scattered from his wings.


## (III) JAINISM AND OTHER UNORTHODOX SECTS
Jainism
Among many unorthodox teachers who were contemporary with theBuddha was Vardhamana, known to his followers as Mahāvīra (“the GreatHero”). Jainism, “Religion of Conquerors” ( jinas), which hefounded, had very different history from that of Buddhism. It succeeded inestablishing itself firmly, and in some places became very influential, but it never spread beyond India. Unlike Buddhism, there were no fundamental changes and developments in Jaina doctrine. But though history of Jainism is less interesting than that of Buddhism, and though it was neverso important, it survived in land of its birth, where it still has some twomillion adherents, mostly well-to-do merchants.

The legends of Vardhamāna Mahāvīra r less attractive than those of Buddha and r even more formalized and unreliable, but as he is referred to in Buddhist scriptures as one of Buddha’s chief opponents, hishistoricity is beyond doubt. He was born about 540 B.C. and was son ofSiddhārtha, chief of clan of Jñātrikas, [Page 288] associates of theLicchavis of Vaiśālī; his mother, Triśalā, was sister of Licchavi chief Cetaka, _and thus, like Buddha, he was wholly product of theoligarchic martial clans which were powerful political force at time._

Though he was educated as prince, and married and had daughter, his real interest lay in quest for salvation. At age of thirty, when hisparents were dead, he left his home for life of asceticism. At first he followed practices of an ascetic group called Nirgranthas (“Free from Bonds”), which had been founded some 200 years earlier by certain Pārśva. term Nirgrantha was later used for members of orderwhich Mahāvīra founded, and Pārśva was remembered as twentythird ofthe twenty-four great teachers or Tīrthaṅ karas (“Fordmakers”) of Jainafaith.

For over twelve years Vardhamana wandered from place to place, begging his bread, meditating, disputing, and subjecting his body to austerities of all kinds. At first he wore single garment, which he never changed, but after thirteen months he laid this encumbrance aside, and rest of his life was spent in complete nudity. For some six years his hardships were shared by another ascetic, Gosala Maskariputra, but ultimately two quarrelled, and Gosala left Vardhamana to found sect of Ajivikas.

In thirteenth year of his asceticism Vardhamana found full enlightenment and Nirvāṇa; he became “Worthy” ( Arhant), “Conqueror” ( Jina), “Ford-maker”’. He soon gained great reputation and large band of followers, and for thirty years he taught in Gangetic kingdoms, patronized by very kings who also patronized Buddha.

He survived death of his chief rival, Gosala, and probably also that of Buddha, and died of self-starvation at age of seventy-two, in little town of Pava, near Magadhan capital Rajagrha. There r conflicting traditions about date of his death, which was probably in 468 B.C.

For some two centuries Jainas remained small community of monks and lay followers, less important than rival sect of Ajivikas.

According to strongly held Jaina tradition Candragupta Maurya joined theorder as monk on his abdication, and it seems certain that there was anaccession of strength in Maurya times. serious famine at end ofCandragupta’s reign led to great exodus of Jaina monks from Gangesto Deccan, where they established important centres of their faith.

Out of this migration arose great schism of Jainism, on point of monastic discipline. Bhadrabahu, elder of community, who had led emigrants, had insisted on retention of rule of nudity, which Mahāvīra had established. Sthūlabhadra, leader of [Page 289] monks who had remained in North, allowed his followers to wear white garments, owing to hardships and confusions of famine. Hence arose two sects of Jainas, Digambaras (“Space-clad”, i.e. naked), and Śvetāmbaras (“White-clad”). schism did not become final until 1st century A.D., and there were never any fundamental doctrinal differences; later most monks of naked sect took to wearing robes in public, but division has persisted down to present day.

According to tradition an oral sacred literature had been passed down from days of Mahavlra, but Bhadrabahu was last person to know it perfectly. On his death Sthūlabhadra called great council at Pataliputra, and canon was reconstructed as best possible in twelve Aṅ gas, or sections, which replaced fourteen “former texts “( Pūrvas). This canonwas accepted only by Śvetāmbaras; Digambaras claimed that oldcanon was hopelessly lost, and proceeded to devise new scriptures forthemselves, many of which r still unpublished. texts of theSvetambara canon were finally settled and reduced to writing at council atValabhi in Kāthiāwār in 5th century A.D. By this time texts hadbecome very corrupt, and one of Aṅgas had been completely lost, whilenew material had been added to original canon in form of twelveUpāṅ gas, or minor sections, and various lesser works. In Middle Ages agreat body of commentarial literature was written both in Prakrit andSanskrit, and there were many able philosopher monks, who interpreted thescriptures of sect. Some monks turned their attention to secular literature and other branches of learning, apparently without losing theirpiety. One of last great poets in Sanskrit, Nayacandra, of 14thcentury (p. 431f), was Jaina monk, as was Mallinātha, author of standard commentary on poems of Kālidāsa. We owe much to Jainamonks’ love of literature. To copy manuscript, even secular one, was considered work of great religious merit, and thus old Jainamonasteries of Western India hv preserved many rare and otherwiseunknown texts, some of which hv still to be published, and many ofwhich r of non-Jaina origin.

In period between Mauryas and Guptas Jainism cn be traced from Orissā in East to Mathurā in West, but in later times it was chiefly concentrated in two regions—Kāthiāwār, Gujarat and parts ofRajasthan, where Svetambara sect prevailed, and central part of Peninsula, modern Mysore and South Hyderabad, where theDigambaras were dominant. Ganges Valley, original home ofJainism, was little affected by it. #quote prophet is never recognized in his time and land

The Svetambaras found much support among chiefs of Western [Page 290] India, and gained position of great prominence during reign of Caulukya king Kumārapāla, who ruled Gujarāt and Kāthiāwār in the12th century. Under guidance of great Jaina scholar, Hemacandra,Kumārapāla is said to hv instituted Jaina reformation; but on his deaththe sect lost much of its influence, and though it still flourished it neveragain became so important. Similarly in South Digambaras had great influence in early Middle Ages, thanks to patronage of manyimportant kings, but this influence gradually diminished as devotionalŚaivism and Vaisnavism grew. There r traditions, which some havedoubted, but which we believe to hv basis of fact, that Jainas weresometimes severely persecuted. But although Jainism declined it neverdisappeared.

Though Jaina scriptures r comparatively late in their final form, there is so little divergence in fundamentals between two great Jaina sects that it seems that basic teachings of both r very ancient indeed,and r essentially those of Mahavira himself. Jainism, like Buddhism, isfundamentally atheistic, in that, while not denying existence of gods,it refuses dm any important part in universal scheme. world, forthe Jaina, is not created, maintained or destroyed by personal deity, butfunctions only acc to universal law.

The universe is eternal. Its existence is divided into an infinite number ofcycles, each consisting of period of improvement ( utsarpiṇ ī), and one ofdecline (avasarpiṇī). Each period is to all intents and purposes like last,containing twenty-four Tirthankaras, twelve Universal Emperors( Cakravartins), altogether sixty-three Great Men( Śālāka-puruṣ as), who liveat regular intervals in cycle. At peak period men r of enormoussize and live to tremendous age. They hv no need of laws or property,for wishing-trees ( kalpa-vṛ kṣ a) give dm all they need for asking. Atpresent world is rapidly declining. last Tīrthaṅkara of this age haspassed to final Nirvāna, and gradually true religion will be lost—Mahāvīra,in his omniscience, even gave his followers name and address of lastJaina of this æon. process of decline will continue for 40,000 years,when men will be dwarfs in stature, with life of only twenty years, andwill dwell in caves, having forgotten all culture, even to use of fire.

Then tide will turn, and they will begin to improve again, only to decline once more, and so on for all eternity. Unlike cosmology of Buddhists and Hindus, that of Jainas involves no cataclysms of universal destruction.

The universe functions through interaction of living souls ( jivas, literally “lives”), and five categories of non-living entities ( ajiva): “ether” ( ākāśa), means or condition of movement [Page 291] ( dharma), means or condition of rest ( adharma), 18 time ( kāla), and matter ( pudgala).

Souls r not only property of animal and plant life, but also of entities such as stones, rocks, running water, and many other natural objects not looked on as living by other sects.

The soul is naturally bright, all-knowing and blissful. There r an infinite number of souls in universe, all fundamentally equal, but differing owing to adherence of matter in fine atomic form. This subtle matter, quite invisible to human eye, is karma, immaterial entity ofother systems interpreted materialistically. naturally bright soulbecomes dulled and clouded over by karmic matter and thus acquires first aspiritual and then material body. obfuscation of soul is comparedto gradual clouding of bright oily surface by motes of dust. Karma adheres to soul as result of activity. Any and every activity induceskarma of some kind, but deeds of cruel and selfish nature induce more andmore dangerous karma than others. karma already acquired leads to theacquisition of further karma, and thus cycle of transmigration continuesindefinitely.

On these premisses transmigration cn only be escaped by dispelling karma already adhering to soul and ensuring that no more is acquired.

This is slow and difficult process and it is believed that many souls willnever succeed in accomplishing it, but will continue to transmigrate for alleternity. annihilation ( nirjarā) of karma comes about through penance,and prevention ( saṃ vara) of influx ( āśrava) and fixation (bandha)19of karma in soul is ensured by carefully disciplined conduct, as resultof which it does not enter in dangerous quantities and is dispersedimmediately. When soul has finally set itself free it rises at once to thetop of universe, above highest heaven, where it remains in inactiveomniscient bliss through all eternity. This, for Jainas, is Nirvāṇa.

Though Jaina philosophers developed their doctrines, and evolved atheory of epistemology of great subtlety (p. 502f), these fundamentalteachings remained essentially unaltered. Mahavira and twenty-threeother Tīrthaṅkaras were adored in same way as Buddha and as theHindu gods, but Jainism never compromised in its atheism, and there wasno development in this sect comparable to Great Vehicle in Buddhism.

Jainism has survived for over 2,000 years on basis of these austere teachings alone.

[Page 292] Full salvation is not possible to layman. In this Jainism differs from Buddhism and Hinduism, which concede it in very exceptional cases. To attain Nirvana man must abandon all trammels, including his clothes. Only by long course of fasting, self-mortification, study andmeditation, cn he rid himself of karma, and only by most rigorousdiscipline cn he prevent fresh karma from entering his soul. Hence amonastic life is essential for salvation. Very early, however, many Jainamonks gave up rule of nudity, and today few if any monks, even of theDigambara sect, practise it regularly. Both sects of Jainas, however, wouldadmit that it is necessary to full salvation. universe is now rapidlydeclining, and no souls now reach Nirvana or hv any hope of reaching itin foreseeable future, so in these degenerate days clothes r worn as aconcession to human frailty.

The regimen of Jaina monk was, and still is, strict in extreme. At
his initiation his hair was not shaved, but pulled out by roots. He
subjected himself to many hardships, such as meditating in full sunlight
of Indian summer, or maintaining an uneasy posture for long periods on
end, though Jainism did not permit more spectacular penances of some
Hindu ascetics. monk’s frugal meals were interrupted by numerous
fasts, and many monks starved themselves to death, following example
of Mahavira himself.

The life of monk was governed by five vows, abjuring killing, stealing, lying, sexual activity and possession of property. These vows were interpreted quite strictly. Acts of violence and killing, whether intentional or not, were most potent cause of influx of karma, and were therefore particularly to be avoided. Meat-eating was quite forbidden to monk and layman alike. Even insect life was carefully protected. Like theBuddhist monks, Jainas strained their drinking-water to save lives ofanimalculæ. Jaina monks usually carried feather dusters, to brush ants andother insects from their path and save dm from being trampled underfoot,and they wore veils over their mouths, to prevent minute living things inthe air from being inhaled and killed. No lay Jaina could take up theprofession of agriculture, since this involved not only destruction ofplant life, but also of many living things in soil. Thus, in its insistenceon ahimsa, or non-violence, Jainism went much further than any otherIndian religion.

It has been suggested that Jainism survived in India, whereas Buddhismperished, because former sect took better care of its layfolk. Jainamonks perhaps paid greater attention to laymen than did Buddhists,and in Jainism layman was definite member of Order, encouragedto undertake periodical retreats, [Page 293] and to live as far as possible thelife of monk for specified periods. Like Buddhism, Jainism encouragedthe commercial virtues of honesty and frugality, and at very early periodthe Jaina lay community became predominantly mercantile. splendidJaina temples at such places as Mount Abu and Sravana Belgola aretestimonies of great wealth and piety of medieval Jaina laymen.

Jainism had no special social doctrines. domestic rites of layman,such as birth, marriage and death, were those of Hindus. At one timeJainism maintained cult of stśpas, in same way as Buddhism, but thishas not survived, and early in Christian era Tīrthaṅkaras wereadored in temples in form of icons. By Middle Ages this worshipapproximated to that of Hindus, with offerings of flowers, incense,lamps and so on. As with Buddhism, chief gods of Hindus foundtheir way into Jaina temples in subordinate positions, and though there wasno real compromise with theism sect easily fitted into Hindu order,its members forming distinct castes.

Jaina religious literature is generally dull, and often pedantic, and itsethics, though they inculcate such virtues as honesty and mercy, tend to benegative and fundamentally selfish. virtue of nonviolence in Jainismoften had little of love about it, but merely involved vegetarianism, andprecautions against accidental killing of small animals. There are,however, passages in Jaina scriptures which show warmth and humansympathy. Thus, discussing doctrine of non-violence, earlyĀcārāṅ ga Sūtra writes:
“A wise man should be neither glad nor angry, for he should know and consider happiness of all things…. Life is dear to many who ownfields and houses, who get dyed and coloured clothes and jewels andearrings, and grow attached to them…. Only those who r of controlledconduct do not desire these things; therefore, knowing birth and death, youshould firmly walk path.

“For nothing is inaccessible to death, and all beings r fond ofthemselves, they love pleasure and hate pain, they shun destruction andcling to life. They long to live. To all things life is dear.”48More typical of Jaina moral teachings r following verses, said tohave been spoken by Mahāvīra to Gautama, one of his disciples (not, ofcourse, to be confused with Gautama Buddha).

“As dead leaf when its time is up falls from tree to ground, so is life of man.

Gautama, always be watchful!

[Page 294] “As dewdrop that sways on blade of grass lasts but moment, so is life of man.

Gautama, always be watchful!

“For soul which suffers for its carelessness
is whirled about in universe,
through good and evil karma.

Gautama, always be watchful!

“When body grows old and hair turns white,
and all vital powers decrease…
despondency and disease befall, and flesh wastes and decays.

Gautama, always be watchful!

“So cast away all attachments,
and be pure as lotus, or as water in autumn.

Free from every attachment,
Gautama, always be watchful!” 49
As an example of Digambara teaching we give few verses, remarkable
for their conciseness, by 4th century monk Pūjyapāda.

“Body, house, wealth and wife,
sons and friends and enemies—
all r different from soul.

Only fool thinks dm his own.”

“From all directions come birds
and rest together in trees;
but in morning each goes his own way,
flying in all directions.”

“Death is not for me. Why then should I fear?

Disease is not for me. Why then should I despair?

I am not child, nor youth, nor an old man—
All these states r only of my body.”

“Time and again in my foolishness I hv enjoyed
all kinds of body and hv discarded them.

Now I am wise!

Why should I long for rubbish?”

“The soul is one thing, matter another—
that is quintessence of truth.

Whatever else may be said
is merely its elaboration.”50

### Ājivikas
A third unorthodox sect which emerged at same time as Buddhism and Jainism was that of Ājivikas, body of ascetics who [Page 295]were under rigorous discipline similar to that of Jainas, whichinvolved complete nudity. doctrines of founder of sect, GosalaMaskariputra, bear generic likeness to those of his contemporary andformer friend Mahavira. Like Mahavira, he looked back to earlier teachersand ascetic groups, whose doctrines he refurbished and developed.

According to both Buddhist and Jaina tradition he was of humble birth; hedied year or so before Buddha, about 484 B.C., after fierce altercationwith Mahavira in city of Śrśvastī. His followers seem to hv combined with those of other teachers, such as Pūraṇa Kāśyapa antinomian andPakudha Kātyāyana atomist, to form Ājivika sect. After period ofprosperity in Mauryan times, when Aśoka and his successor Daśaratha presented caves to Ājivikas, sect rapidly declined, and only retainedsome local importance in small region of Eastern Mysore and adjacentparts of Madras, where it survived until 14th century, after which wehear no more of it.

No scriptures of Ājivikas hv come down to us, and little weknow about dm has to be reconstructed from polemic literature ofBuddhism and Jainism. sect was certainly atheistic, and its main featurewas strict determinism. usual doctrine of karma taught that though aman’s present condition was determined by his past actions he couldinfluence his destiny, in this life and future, by choosing right courseof conduct. This Ajivikas denied. whole universe was conditionedand determined to smallest detail by an impersonal cosmic principle,Niyati, or destiny. It was impossible to influence course oftransmigration in any way.

“All that hv breath, all that r born, all that hv life, r without power, strength or virtue, but r developed by destiny, chance and nature,and experience joy and sorrow in six classes [of existence]. There are…8,400,000 great æons ( mahākappa), through which fool and wise alike musttake their course and make an end of sorrow. There is no [question of]bringing unripe karma to fruition, nor of exhausting karma already ripened,by virtuous conduct, by vows, by penance, or by chastity. That cannot bedone. Samsara is measured as with bushel, with its joy and sorrow and itsappointed end. It cn neither be lessened nor increased, nor is there anyexcess or deficiency of it. Just as ball of string will, when thrown, unwindto its full length, so fool and wise alike will take their course, and make anend of sorrow.”51
[[2021-12-03]]
Though nothing that man could do would in any way influence his future lot Ajivika monks practised severe asceticism, because force of destiny compelled dm to do so, although their religious opponents accused dm of licentiousness and immorality.

The Dravidian Ājivikas developed their doctrines in way [Page 296] resembling Buddhism of Great Vehicle. Gosala became an ineffable divinity, like Buddha in Mahayana system, while doctrine of destiny evolved into Parmenidean view that all change and movement were illusory, and that world was in reality eternally and immovably at rest. This view bears certain resemblance to Nāgārjuna’s doctrine of “the Void”.

### Scepticism and Materialism.

Buddha, Mahavira, Gosala, and many lesser teachers of their period ignored gods, but they were not thoroughgoing atheists and materialists.

All admitted existence of supernatural beings of strictly limited powers,and all accepted fundamental doctrine of transmigration, though they interpreted its mechanics individually. Some thinkers, however, rejected all immaterial categories completely, and their influence may hv been widerthan appears from religious texts of period. In fairly early KathaUpanisad interlocutor Naciketas (p. 157) questions Yama, god ofdeath, in these terms: “There is doubt about state of man who is dead -some say he is, others, he is not.” “On this point”, Yama replies, “even thegods formerly had their doubts. It is not easy to understand.” At this timeunbelief must hv been fairly widespread.

Ajita Kesakambalin (Ajita of Hair-blanket, no doubt so called from garb of his order), contemporary of Buddha, was earliest known teacher of complete materialism.

“Man,” he said, “is formed of four elements. When he dies earthreturns to aggregate of earth, water to water, fire to fire, and air toair, while his senses vanish into space. Four men with bier take upthe corpse; they gossip [about dead man] as far as burning-ground, where his bones turn colour of dove’s wing and hissacrifices end in ashes. They r fools who preach almsgiving, andthose who maintain existence [of immaterial categories] speak vain

and lying nonsense. When body dies both fool and wise alike r cut off and perish. They do not survive after death.” 52If we r to believe Buddhist scriptures, Ajita founded sect ofmonks. Buddha condemned dm as having no good motive for theirasceticism, degree of which is nowhere made clear. It is possible that,like Epicureans, they were not so much an ascetic order as fraternityof men with common aims, cultivating together simpler pleasures oflife. In any case, an undercurrent of materialism is traceable in Indianthought from this time onwards. Religious and philosophical literature,whether Hindu, Buddhist or Jaina, devotes much space to attacking eviltenets of Cārvākas [Page 297] or Lokāyatas, as materialist schoolswere called. Throughout period which we treat these unbelievers arereferred to with scorn and disapprobation, which sometimes seems tocontain an undertone of fear, as though pious authors thought it reallypossible that materialists might shake foundations of establishedorder. Materialist and irreligious undercurrents r traceable in some secularliterature, such as Arthaśāstra and Kāmasūtra.

The Rt. Rev. Bishop of Uganda
Christian Font. Kanduruthy, Travancore. Medieval.

The general attitude of materialist schools, acc to their adversaries, was that all religious observance and morality were futile. man should make most of life and get what happiness he could out of it.

The frugal virtues of Buddhism and Jainism were rejected.

“As long as he lives man should live happily and drink ghee, though he run into debt, for when body is turned to ashes how cn there be any return to life?”53 man must not turn back from pleasure for fear of concomitant sorrow. He must accept occasional sorrow gladly, for sake of joy which he finds in world, as he accepts bones with fish or husk with corn.

“Whoever turns in fear from joy that he sees before him is fool, no better than an animal.” 54 Their opponents ascribe only base ideals to materialists, and there is no definite evidence that they had any ethical doctrines, but one verse attributed to dm shows that they were not blind to warm ties of family and friendship.

“If man really left his body,and passed on to other world,would he not come back once more,drawn by his love for his kin?”55Besides numerous quotations attributed to materialists in religious andphilosophical works one materialist philosophical text has survived. This isthe Tattvopaplavasiṃ ha (freely “The Lion Destroying all Religious Truth”)written by certain Jayarasi in 8th century A.D. author was an out-and-out Pyrrhonist denying possibility of any certain knowledge at all,and he demolished with able dialectic, to his own satisfaction at any rate, allthe basic presuppositions of chief religious systems of his day.



## (IV) HINDUISM
Development and Literature
As well as aristocratic religion of brāhmaṇs, Buddhist and Jaina scriptures mention popular cults, connected with earth [Page 298] spirits ( yakṣ as), snake-spirits ( nāgas), and other minor deities, centred round sacred spots or caityas (p. 262). Very early god named Vasudeva was widely worshipped, especially in Western India. It was to this god thatthe Besnagar column, to which we hv more than once referred, waserected. inscription on column shows that by end of 2ndcentury B.C. cult of Vasudeva was receiving support of rulingclasses, and even of Western invaders. Soon after this Vasudeva wasidentified with Vedic god Viṣṇu, if indeed identification had notalready been made, and further syncretisms were taking place. Nārāyaṇa, agod of obscure origin mentioned in Brāhmaṇa literature, was alsoidentified with Viṣṇu, whose name was by now closely connected with thatof Krsna, one of heroes of martial traditions which were beingbrought together at this time to form great epic, Mahābhārata.

The character of Viṣṇu, and of gods associated with him, developedthrough centuries, as further popular divinities were in one way oranother identified with him. Among some of lower orders theriomorphiccults prevailed, especially in Eastern Mālwā, where divinity in form ofa boar was worshipped. By Gupta times cult of divine boar wasassimilated to that of Visnu. pastoral flute-playing deity, popular amongherdsmen and of uncertain origin, was identified with hero Krsna, bynow recognized as an incarnation of Viṣṇu. brahmanic heroParaśurāma was similarly accounted for, while in medieval times heroof second great Indian epic, Rama, was also brought into Vaisnavite pantheon.

Simultaneously fertility deity, whose cult may hv been kept alive innon-brahmanic circles from days of Harappā culture, rose inprominence. This was Siva, identified with Vedic Rudra and usuallyworshipped in form of phallic emblem ( linga). With Śiva were laterassociated certain other popular divinities, such as Skanda and elephant-headed Gaṇeśa. At end of Gupta period goddesses rose toprominence, together with magical cults, religious sexuality, and animalsacrifice in new form, which increased in importance throughout earlyMiddle Ages.

The final form of Hinduism was largely result of influence from Dravidian South. Here, on basis of indigenous cults fertilized by Āryaninfluences, theistic schools had arisen, characterized by intense ecstaticpiety. It was this devotional Hinduism, propagated by many wanderingpreachers and hymn-singers in medieval period, which had greatesteffect on Hinduism as it exists today.

During this period an enormous body of sacred literature was produced.

The Vedas, Brāhmaṇas and Upaniṣads, theoretically still [Page 299]most sacred of all India’s religious literature, were studied only by thosewho had undergone ceremony of initiation, and became more and morethe preserve of brāhmaṇs, who themselves often interpreted themfiguratively in light of new doctrines. real scriptures ofHinduism, as distinct from brahmanism, were available to all, even to menof low caste and to women. These were Epics, Purāṇ as, booksof Sacred Law, which we hv treated elsewhere (p. 112f), and numeroushymns and religious poems. For learned there was voluminousliterature of commentaries, and many treatises on various aspects oftheology and philosophy.

The two great Epics were originally secular, and in their literary aspect
will be treated later (p. 407f). Very early, probably before Christian era, Mahābhārata began to receive religious interpolations, and was soon looked on as sacred text. most sacred of these interpolations is thefamous Bhagavad Gītā, itself compilation of material from varioussources, to which we shall often refer in course of this chapter; butmuch literature on Sacred Law, as well as religious legends of manykinds, has found its way into Epic which, as it exists at present, formsan encyclopedia of early Hinduism. An important appendix to theMahābhārata is Harivaṃ sa, giving legend of god Krsna in adeveloped form. second epic, Rāmāyaṇ a, was also secular in itsearliest form, but at comparatively late period, probably after age ofthe Guptas, an introductory and final canto were added, together withother interpolations, which raised text to status of sacred scripture.

The Puranas (“Ancient Stories”) r compendia of legends and religious instructions. There r eighteen chief Puranas of which perhaps most important r Vāyu, Viṣṇ u, Agni, Bhaviṣ ya and Bhāgavata Purāṇ as. In their present form they r not very ancient, none going back earlier than Gupta period and all containing interpolations, but much of their legendary material is very old indeed.

Much later religious poetry is of small literary value, and has little more sanctity than hv “Hymns Ancient and Modern” in Church of England.

Certain poems, however, r looked on by modern sects as very sacred,especially Gītā Govinda, collection of interlinked religious songs bythe 12th-century Bengali poet Jayadeva (p. 428f). Some medieval stotras orhymns of praise, notably those attributed to theologian Śaṅkara, haveconsiderable literary merit, and r looked on with great respect. ThePeninsula produced much vernacular sacred poetry during our period, someof which is of great value, and is considered to be very holy. [Page 300] Abeautiful collection of moral aphorisms in Tamil verse, Tirukkural(“Sacred Couplets”), attributed to Tiruvalluvar, perhaps dates from 4thor 5th centuries A.D., though some authorities would put it much earlier.

Later, from 7th to 10th centuries, were composed eleven sacred books ( Tirumurai) of Tamil Saivites, anthologies of hymns by sixty- three Nāyanārs, or Teachers. Chief of these eleven works r Tevāram, containing songs by three poets Appar, Ñānasambandar, and Sundaramūrti, and Tiruvāśagam of Māṇikka Vāśagar. TamilVaiṣṇavites at about same period produced Ndldyiram (“FourThousand”), collection of stanzas attributed to twelve Alvars or saintsof sect. Similar collections of devotional poetry, still looked on locallyas very sacred, were composed at end of our period in Canarese andTelugu. At later time much devotional literature was written in Āryanvernaculars, but none survives from period before Musliminvasions, except perhaps works of some of Maratha Vaisnavitehymn singers, Jfinnesvar, Namdev and few others, who, acc totradition, lived at end of 13th century.

We cannot here catalogue great mass of religio-philosophical literature of Hinduism, some of which will be mentioned in followingpages.

Visnu
To Vaisnavite, or devotee of Visnu, this god is source of universe and of all things. acc to most famous cosmic myth of Hinduism he sleeps in primeval ocean, on thousand-headed snake Sesa. In his sleep lotus grows from his navel, and in lotus is born thedemiurge Brahma,20 who creates world. Once world is created Visnuawakes, to reign in highest heaven, Vaikuntha. He is usually depicted asa four-armed man of dark blue colour, crowned and seated on his throne,bearing in his hands his emblems, conch, discus, mace and lotus,wearing holy jewel called Kaustubha round his neck, and with tuft ofcurly hair ( Srivatsa) on his chest. He rides great eagle Garuda, generallyshown with half-human face, who is perhaps survival of an ancienttheriomorphic cult, and who was already associated with Vasudeva, one ofVisnu’s early forms, when Heliodorus erected his column at Besnagar.

Visnu’s spouse, Laksmi, is an important goddess in her own right.

Visnu’s status as Universal God, of whom all other gods r aspects or emanations, appears as early as Bhagavad Gītā.

[Page 301] “Now I will tell chief of my holy powers….

though there is no end to my fullness.

I am self in inmost heart of all that r born….

I am their beginning, their middle and their end….

I am beginning, middle, end, of all creation,
the science of soul among sciences,
of speakers I am speech,
of letters I am A. 21
“I am unending time,
I am ordainer who faces all ways,
I am destroying death,
I am source of all that is to be….

I am dice-play of gamester,
I am glory of glorious,
I am victory, I am courage,
I am goodness of virtuous….

I am force of those who govern,
I am statecraft of those who seek to conquer,
I am silence of what is secret,
I am knowledge of those who know,
and I am seed of all that is born….

“There is nothing that cn exist without me.

There is no end to my holy powers…
And whatever is mighty or fortunate or strong
springs from portion of my glory.”56
Though his counterpart Śiva has rather ferocious and dangerous side to
his character, Visnu is generally thought of as wholly benevolent. god
works continuously for welfare of world, and with this in view has
from time to time incarnated himself, wholly or partially. earliest
version of this doctrine is contained in Bhagavad Gītā, wherein Krsna
reveals himself as ever-active godhead incarnate.

“In essence I am never born, I never alter.

I am lord of all beings
and full master of my own nature,
yet of my own power I come to be.

“Whenever Sacred Law fails, and evil raises its head,
I take embodied birth.

To guard righteous and root out sinners,
and to establish Sacred Law,
I am born from age to age.” 57
[Page 302] Avataras (“descents”) or incarnations of Visnu are,
according to most popular classification, ten. divinities and heroes
composing list were adopted by Vaisnavism at different times, but all
were incorporated by 1 th century. It may be that Vaisnavite doctrine
of incarnation owes something to Buddhist and Jaina doctrines of
former Buddhas and Tirthaikaras, which r certainly attested earlier. An
incarnation might be total or partialfor “whatever is mighty or fortunate or
strong springs from portion of my glory.” In this sense every good or great
man was thought of as partial incarnation of Visnu. ten chief
incarnations, however, r of more special type, for in dm god is
believed to hv taken flesh to save world from imminent danger of
total destruction. They r as follows:
(1) Fish ( Matsya). When earth was overwhelmed by universal
flood Visnu took form of fish, who first warned Manu (the Hindu
Adam) of impending danger, and then carried him, his family, and the
seven great sages ( rsis) in ship, fastened to horn on his head. He also
saved Vedas from flood. fish legend first appears in the
brāhmanas, and Noah’s Ark theme suggests Semitic influence. Fish
incarnation was never widely worshipped.

(2) Tortoise ( Kurma). Many divine treasures were lost in flood,
including ambrosia ( amrta), 22 with which gods preserved their
youth. Visnu became great tortoise, and dived to bottom of cosmic
ocean. On his back gods placed Mount Mandara, and, twining divine
snake Vasuki around mountain, churned ocean in manner in
which an Indian dairyman churns butter, twirling mountain by pulling
the snake. From churned ocean emerged ambrosia, and various other
treasures, including goddess Laksmī. story is probably piece of
very early folklore, but identification of tortoise with Visnu is
comparatively late, and, though frequently mentioned in literature, this
incarnation had little real importance.

(3) Boar ( Varāha). demon, Hiraniyāksa, cast earth once more
into depths of cosmic ocean. Visnu took form of an enormous
boar, killed demon, and raised earth on his tusk (pl. XXXVII c). The
legend looks back to brāhmanas, but probably developed through a
primitive non-Āryan cult of sacred pig. cult of Boar incarnation
was important in some parts of India in Gupta times.

(4) Man-Lion ( Narasimha). Another demon, Hiranya [Page 303]
kasipu, had obtained boon from Brahma ensuring that he could not be
killed either by day or night by god, man or beast. Thus safeguarded he
persecuted both gods and men, including his pious son Prahlada. When
Prahlada called on Visnu for help god burst from pillar of demon’s
palace at sunset, when it was neither night nor day, in form half man and
half lion, and slew Hiranyakasipu. Narasimha was worshipped as their
special divinity ( istadevatā) by small sect, and was often depicted in
sculpture.

(5) Dwarf ( Vāmana). demon named Bali gained control of the
world, and commenced course of asceticism, by which his supernatural
power so increased that he menaced even gods. Visnu appeared before
him in form of dwarf, and asked as boon as much land as he could
cover in three strides. When boon was granted god became giant,
and in three strides covered earth, heaven and middle air, leaving only
the infernal regions to demon. three steps of Visnu r as old as the
Ṛ g Veda, but other popular elements were incorporated into story.

(6) Parasurāma (Rāma with Axe). Visnu took human form as son
of brahman Jamadagni. When his father was robbed by wicked King
Kartavirya, Paraśurāma killed latter. Jamadagni was in turn killed by the
sons of Kartavirya, after which enraged Paraśurāma destroyed all the
males of ksatriya class twenty-one times in succession. Though
Paraśurāma is frequently referred to in literature, he seems rarely to have
been specially worshipped.

(7) Rama, Prince of Ayodhya and hero of Rāmāyana. Visnu
incarnated himself in this form to save world from oppressions of
the demon Rāvana. To European his story is rather matter of literature
than of religion and will be told in later chapter (p. 412ff). Rāma may
have been chief who lived in 8th or 7th century B.C., and in earliest
form of story he has no divine attributes. Though he was believed to be
an earlier incarnation than Krsna, his cult developed later than Krsna’s, and
does not appear to hv been very important until end of our period.

Rāma is usually depicted as of dark hue, often bearing bow and arrow. He
is attended by his faithful wife Sita, personification of wifely devotion,
and often also by his three loyal brothers, Laksmana, Bharata and
Śatrughna, and by his friend and helper, monkey-god Hanumant. To his
devotees Rama combines ideals of gentle, faithful husband, the
leader brave in hardship, and just and benevolent king. It is perhaps
significant that his cult only became really popular after Muslim
invasion.

(8) Krsna was undoubtedly most important of incarnations of
Visnu. His legend in its final form is very long and cn only be outlined
briefly here.

[Page 304] Krsna was born at Mathurā, of tribe of Yadavas. His
father was Vasudeva, and his mother was Devaki, aunt of ruling
King Kamsa. It was prophesied that Kamsa would be killed by Devaki’s
eighth son, so he set out to destroy all her children. But Krsna and his elder
brother Balarāma were saved, and were brought up as children of thecowherd Nanda and his wife Yasoda. Kamsa, hearing that boys hadescaped his clutches, ordered slaughter of all male children in hiskingdom, but Nanda smuggled boys away, first to Vraja and then toVrndavana, districts not far from Mathurā which r still very sacred toKrsna.In his childhood incarnate god performed many miracles, killingdemons, and sheltering cowherds from storm by holding MountGovardhana over their heads with his finger; he also played numerouschildish pranks, such as stealing Yasoda’s butter. In his adolescence he hadmany amours with wives and daughters of cowherds ( gopis), andaccompanied their dances on his flute. His favourite was beautifulRadha.But his youthful days soon ended. Kamsa traced him and made furtherattempts on his life. Krsna then gave up his idyllic pastoral life, and turnedon his wicked cousin. He slew Kamsa, and seized kingdom of Mathurā,but, pressed between Kamsa’s father-in-law, Jarasandha king of Magadha,	and an unnamed Yavana king of North-West, he was forced to leave hiskingdom, and with his followers founded new capital at Dvaraka inKathiawar. Here he made Rukmini, daughter of king of Vidarbha(modern Berar), his chief queen, and amassed total of over 16,000 wivesand 180,000 sons. His adventures at this stage of his career include thedestruction of wicked kings and demons all over India. Throughout thestory of Mahdbhdrata he appears as constant friend and advisor ofthe five Pandavas, and he preached great sermon of Bhagavad Gitato Arjuna before battle which is centre of epic story.After seeing Pandavas safely installed in Kuru land, Krsnareturned to Dvaraka. Here ominous portents beset city, as Yadavachiefs quarrelled among themselves. Krsna banned strong drink, in hopeof staving off evil day, but, on occasion of festival, he relaxed theban. Yadava chiefs began to brawl, and whole city was soon inuproar. Krsna, for all his divinity, could do nothing to quell feud, whichinvolved whole people. His son Pradyumna was killed before his eyes,and his faithful brother BalaRāma wounded to death; nearly all chiefs ofthe Yadavas were slain. Krsna dejectedly wandered in forest near city;there, as he sat musing on loss of his friends and family, hunter spiedhim through undergrowth and mistook him for deer. An arrow piercedhis heel, which, like that of Achilles, was his one vulnerable spot, and hedied. city of Dvaraka was then swallowed by sea.Of many elements which hv gone to making of this story that ofKrsna as hero was earliest to hv been given place in orthodoxtradition. Krsna son of Devaki is mentioned as early as Upanisads58as studying new doctrines of soul, and it [Page 305] seems certainthat there is some historical basis for legend of hero-god; butevidently tales of many heroes from many ages and many parts of Indiahave been fused together in Krsna myth, including some which seemrather inconsistent with general character of conquering hero, suchas that of his somewhat ignominious retreat from Mathurā. Other elementsin story, such as destruction of Yadavas and death of god,are quite un-Indian in their tragic character. themes of drunkenbrawl leading to general slaughter, of hero slain by an arrow piercing hisone vulnerable spot, and of great city engulfed by sea, r wellknown in European epic literature, but do not occur elsewhere in that ofIndia, and r not hinted at in Vedas. concept of dying god, sowidespread in ancient Near East, is found nowhere else in Indianmythology. Kamsa, wicked cousin, seems to echo Herod, and perhapsalso Acrisius, cruel grandfather of Perseus. Some parts of story maybe derived from very ancient stories, handed down and developed by Āryanwarriors from days before they entered India; others r of indigenousorigin; and yet others r possibly inspired by garbled versions of tales fromthe West.Krsna in his pastoral and erotic aspect is evidently of different originfrom Krsna hero. name means “black”, and god is usuallydepicted as of that colour. Perhaps oldest clear reference to pastoralKrsna is in early Tamil anthologies, where “the Black One” ( Mayin)plays his flute and sports with milkmaids. He may hv been originally afertility god of Peninsula, whose cult was carried to North bynomadic tribes of herdsmen. tribe which appeared in Malwa and theWestern Deccan early in Christian era, Abhiras, is thought to haveplayed big part in propagation of worship of Krsna Govinda(“Lord of Herdsman”, 23 very common epithet of god in this aspect).The young Krsna’s erotic exploits hv been source of much romanticliterature which, superficially, contains but faint religious element.Invariably, however, love of god for cowherds’ wives isinterpreted as symbolic of love of God for human soul. notes ofKrsna’s flute, calling women to leave their husbands’ beds and dancewith him in moonlight, represent voice of God, calling man to leaveearthly things and turn to joys of divine love. So Jew and Christian alikehave interpreted Song of Songs, and so many mystical poets of allreligions hv depicted their spiritual experience. Despite its luxurianteroticism legend [Page 306] of Divine Cowherd has produced greatreligious poetry (p. 428f), and inspired many pious souls.The third element of Krsna legend is that of child god. This isdefinitely latest part to be assimilated, and its origin is quite unknown.Can it be partly inspired by tales brought by Christian merchants orNestorian missionaries to west coast of India in early Middle Ages?Most authorities would deny this, but we do not reject possibility out ofhand. In any case, story of child Krsna, often depicted in latersculpture as plump infant crawling on all fours, gave god rarecompleteness. As hero he met worshipper’s need of divine father andelder brother; as young cowherd, he was divine lover; and as infant, ason. cult of child Krsna made special appeal to warmmaternity of Indian womanhood; and even today simpler women ofIndia, while worshipping divine child, so delightfully naughty despitehis mighty power, refer to themselves as “the Mother of God”.Vasudeva, popular god of Western India in early centuries B.C.,was early identified with Krsna, and it may be that name, falselyinterpreted as patronymic, resulted in tradition that Krsn. a’s fatherwas called Vasudeva (with short in first syllable). Other deities,originally independent, were associated with Krsna in one way and another.Chief of these was his elder brother Balarama, also called Halayudha (”Armed with Plough”) and Sankarsana. Balarama, bearing woodenplough on his shoulder, was originally an agricultural deity. Traditionally hewas heavy drinker, and had some of characteristics of Silenus.Temples to him existed at one time, but his importance waned in MiddleAges, as that of Krsna increased. Less important were cults of Krsna’sson Pradyumna, of his grandson Aniruddha, and of his friend Arjuna, thePandava hero. chief feminine associate of Krsna was Rādhā, thefavourite mistress of his youth, who was often worshipped with him in thelate Middle Ages. Rukminī, his chief queen, also received some reverence.(9) Buddha, last historical incarnation of Visnu. acc to mosttheologians god became Buddha in order to delude wicked, leadthem to deny Vedas, and thus ensure their damnation. Jayadeva’s GītāGovinda, however, which contains one of earliest lists of incarnations,states that Visnu became Buddha out of compassion for animals, 59 in orderto put an end to bloody sacrifice. This probably gives clue to truebackground of Buddha avatāra. He was included in list, as otherdeities were included, in order to assimilate heterodox elements into theVaisnavite fold: Until quite recently temple of Buddha at Gayā wasin [Page 307] hands of Hindus, and teacher was there worshipped byHindus as Hindu god; but in general little attention was paid to theBuddha avatara.(10) Kalkin, incarnation yet to come. At end of this dark ageVisnu will appear in form of man mounted on white horse, with aflaming sword in his hand. He will judge wicked, reward good, andrestore age of gold. This is late addition to Vaisnavite myth, and doesnot play very important part in literature or iconography, though it is saidthat many simple Hindus hv taken Kalkin very seriously, and long forhis arrival just as oldfashioned Christians look forward to secondcoming of Christ. Christian parallels hv been found, especially with thehorseman of Book of Revelation, 60 but main inspiration of theKalkin may hv come from Buddhism, which taught coming ofMaitreya Buddha long before Vaisnavites devised Kalkin.Zoroastrian ideas may also hv helped in formation of myth.ŚivaAlmost as popular as numerous forms of Visnu was Śiva, whoevolved from fierce Vedic god Rudra (p. 238), with whom mergedelements of non-Āryan fertility deity. Though developed Śaivite sectsoften made of their chosen divinity wholly moral and paternal father inheaven, giva’s character, unlike that of Visnu, is ambivalent. He lurks inhorrible places, such as battlefields, burning-grounds and crossroads,which, in India as in Europe, were looked on as very inauspicious. Hewears garland of skulls and is surrounded by ghosts, evil spirits anddemons. He is death and time ( Mahakkla), which destroy all things.But he is also great ascetic, and patron deity of ascetics generally.On high slopes of Himalayan Mount Kailasa Śiva, great yogi,sits on tiger skin, deep in meditation, and through his meditation worldis maintained. He is depicted thus as wearing his long matted hair ( jata) in atopknot, in which crescent moon is fixed, and from which flows thesacred river Ganges. In middle of his forehead is third eye, emblem ofhis superior wisdom and insight. His neck is black, scarred by adeadlypoison which was last of objects churned from cosmicocean, and which he drank to save other gods from destruction. Snakes,of which he is lord, encircle his neck and arms. His body is coveredwith ashes, favourite ascetic practice. Beside him is his weapon, thetrident, while near him r his beautiful wife Pārvatī and his mount, bullNandi.Though in this aspect giva is continually wrapped in meditation, he [Page308] can, in his divine power, divide his personality. Not only is he godof mystical stillness, but also Lord of Dance ( Nataraja) (pl. LXVI).This aspect of giva is specially popular in Tamil country, wherereligious dancing was part of earliest known Tamil tradition. In hisheavenly palace on Mount Kailasa, or in his southern home, temple ofCidambaram or Tillai (near seacoast about fifty miles south ofPondicherry), mystically identified with Kailasa, Śiva dances. He hasinvented no less than 108 different dances, some calm and gentle, othersfierce, orgiastic and terrible. Of latter most famous is tandava, inwhich angry god, surrounded by his drunken attendants ( ganas), beatsout wild rhythm which destroys world at end of cosmic cycle.A further form in which god is worshipped is known as “South-facing” ( Daksinamurti) (pl. LXVIII); in this aspect he is universalteacher, depicted in an informal pose, with one foot on ground and theother on throne on which he sits, and with one hand raised in gestureof explanation. This form of Śiva perhaps owes something to Buddhistinspiration.But Śiva was and still is chiefly worshipped in form of liiga (pl.XXVIb), usually short cylindrical pillar with rounded top, which is thesurvival of cult older than Indian civilization itself. Phalli hv been foundin Harappā remains. Early Tamil literature refers to setting up ofritual posts, which seem to hv been phallic emblems. cult of thelifiga, at all times followed by some of non-Āryan peoples, wasincorporated into Hinduism around beginning of Christian era,though at first it was not very important. As early as Ṛ g Veda, Rudra,the mountain god, was connected with plants and animals. hornedithyphallic god of Mohenjo Daro, surrounded by animals, may well be theprototype of Siva, as patron of reproduction in men, animals and plants.In this form he is known as Paśupati (“Lord of Beasts”) and is oftenrepresented in South India as four armed man, with one hand in anattitude of blessing, second open, as though bestowing boon, an axe inthe third, and small deer springing from fingers of fourth (pl.LXVIIb).Some Saivite sects declare that Śiva has performed series of avataras,but these r pure imitations of those of Visnu and hv never played bigpart in Saivite thought. god has, however, manifested himself fromtime to time in theophanies, or taken temporary incarnation to destroydemons or test virtue of warriors or sages. Numerous legends r told ofhim, some of dm quite uncomplimentary. most famous of theselegends is that of his [Page 309] marriage to Pārvatī, daughter ofHimalaya, personified mountains.The gods were troubled by demon Taraka, and it was prophesied that hecould only be destroyed by child of Śiva and Daughter of theMountains. But Śiva was continually wrapped in meditation, and theprospect of his producing offspring seemed to other gods to be faintindeed. However Pārvatī, beautiful daughter of Himalaya, was sent attheir behest to wait upon Siva, but though she made many attempts to winthe god’s attention he took no notice of her, and in course of her effortsKama, lovegod, who had done his best to help her to win him, was burntto ashes by flames from Siva’s third eye. At last Plrvati decided tofollow god in his asceticism. Laying aside her ornaments she became ahermitess on nearby peak, and in this guise Śiva noticed her and fell inlove with her. They were married at great ceremony at which all godstook part, and soon Pārvatī gave birth to war-god Skanda, who, when hegrew to manhood, destroyed demon Taraka.In South India rather similar story is told of marriage of Siva andMinaksi, daughter of Pandyan king of Madurai, and event iscommemorated by one of most famous and splendid of South Indiantemples.The Relation of Visnu and SivaThe Relations of Visnu and Siva From beginning of Christian era,if not before, most educated Hindus hv been either Vaisnavites orSaivites-that is to say they hv looked on either Visnu or giva as highgod, or indeed as only God, others being merely secondaryexpressions of divine, holding rather same positions as saints andangels in mind of Roman Catholic. Thus Vaisnavite does notdeny existence of Siva, but believes that he is merely one god amongmany, creation or emanation of Visnu or of his demiurge Brahma. In thesame way Śaivite looks on Visnu as an emanation of Siva. Occasionallythis difference of viewpoint has led to friction and some degree ofpersecution, but generally two great divisions of Hinduism hv rubbedalong happily together, in conviction that, on ultimate analysis, both areequally right. Hinduism is essentially tolerant, and would rather assimilatethan rigidly exclude. So wiser Vaisnavites and Saivites recognized veryearly that gods whom they worshipped were different aspects of thesame divine being. Divine is diamond of innumerable facets; twovery large and bright facets r Visnu and Siva, while others representall gods that were ever worshipped. Some facets seem larger, brighter,and better polished than others, but in fact devotee, whatever his sect,worships whole diamond, which is in reality [Page 310] perfect. Themore devout Hindus, even when illiterate and ignorant, hv always beenfundamentally monotheist. Thus in Bhagavad Gita Krsna says:“If any worshipper do reverence with faithto any god whatever,I make his faith firm,and in that faith he reverences his god,and gains his desires,for it is I who bestow them.”61With this background of tolerance it is not surprising that attempts weremade to harmonize Vaisnavism and Śaivism. As early as Gupta times holytrinity of Hinduism, Trimūrti or triple form, was evolved, of Brahma thecreator, Visnu preserver, and Viva destroyer. doctrine of theTrimūrti was occasionally popular in some circles, and is proclaimed in thefine hymn of Kalidasa, which inspired once well-known poem ofEmerson:“Praise to you, O Trinity,one before creation,afterwards dividedin your three qualities!…“You, one causeof death and life and birth,in your three formsproclaim your own glory…“In cycle of your day and nightall things live and all things die.When you wake we live,when you sleep we perish….“Hard and soft, large and small,heavy and light, you r all things.You r both substance and form,ineffable in power….“You r knower and known,you r eater and food,you r priest and oblation,you r worshipper and prayer.” 62Early western students of Hinduism were impressed by parallelbetween Hindu trinity and that of Christianity. In fact parallel is notvery close, and Hindu trinity, unlike Holy Trinity of Christianity,never really “caught on”. All Hindu trinitarianism [Page 311] tended tofavour one god of three; thus, from context it is clear that Kālidāsa’shymn to Trimūrti is really addressed to Brahmi, here looked on as thehigh god. Trimūrti was in fact an artificial growth, and had little realinfluence.Another significant syncretism was god Harihara (Hari being title ofVisnu and Hara of Śiva), worshipped in form of an icon whichcombined characteristics of both gods. cult of Harihara developed inthe middle ages, and had some success in Deccan, where Hariharatemples were patronized by Vijayanagara kings, and where god is stillworshipped.The Mother GoddessThe Mother Goddess Mother Goddesses were worshipped at all times inIndia, but between days of Harappā Culture and Gupta periodthe cults of goddesses attracted little attention from learned andinfluential, and only emerged from obscurity to position of realimportance in Middle Ages, when feminine divinities, theoreticallyconnected with gods as their spouses, were once more worshipped bythe upper classes.The goddess was śakti, strength or potency of her malecounterpart. It was thought that god was inactive and transcendent,while his female element was active and immanent, and by Guptaperiod wives of gods, whose existence had always been recognized,but who had been shadowy figures in earlier theology, began to beworshipped in special temples. In early 5th century an inscription ofWestern India tells of certain Mayūrāksaka,“minister of king, who established, to gain merit,this most awful temple,a temple filled with demonesses,…sacred to Mothers, who shoutmost loudly in thick darkness,where lotuses r shakenby fierce windsaroused by magic spells.”63From this time onwards Mother Goddess increased in importance,until wave of devotional Vaisnavism swept Northern India early in theMuslim period, and stopped progress of her cult, which is still strong inBengal and Assam, and is known in other parts of India.The chief form of Mother Goddess was that of wife of Siva,called, in her benevolent aspect, Pārvatī (“Daughter of Mountain”),Mahidevi (“the Great Goddess”), Sati (“the Virtuous”), [Page 312] Gaurī (”the White One”), Annapūrnā (” Bestower of Much Food”), or simply “theMother” ( Mātā, Tamil Ammai). In her grim aspect she was known as Durg(” Inaccessible”), Kali (“the Black One”), and Candī (“the Fierce”). Theterrible Tamil war-goddess Korravai, who danced among slain on thebattlefield and ate their flesh, though independent in origin, was earlyidentified with her. In her fierce aspect she is often depicted as horriblehag (pl. LXX), frequently with many arms bearing different weapons, withfierce carnivorous tusks, red tongue lolling from her mouth, and garlandof skulls. Her mount is lion, and she is sometimes shown as sternlybeautiful woman, slaying buffalo-headed demon in manner of St.George and dragon (pl. XLIIb). more gentle aspect of goddessis that of beautiful young woman, often portrayed with her lord Siva. Aninteresting iconographical development is that of Ardhandrisvara, afigure half Śiva and half Pārvatī, representing union of god with hissakti. As Śiva is worshipped in linga or phallic emblem, so Durgā isworshipped in female emblem, or yoni. acc to legend Pārvatī, inthe incarnation before that in which she became bride of Siva, had beenborn as Sati, daughter of sage Daksa, and had then also become thewife of great god. When her father quarrelled with her divine lord sheflung herself into flames of his sacrificial fire, and ashes of her yonifell in various spots in India, which became pīthas, or sacred shrines ofher cult.Lesser GodsAs well as Visnu, Śiva and Durgā, many other gods were worshipped.Unlike gods of Veda, new gods of Hinduism were no longerclosely tied to natural phenomena, but were thought of moreanthropomorphically.Brahmā, Prajāpati of later Vedic times, had history of slow decline.In early Buddhist scriptures he and Indra were greatest of gods,and in Mahābhārata he was still very important; but though depicted inmedieval sculpture, sometimes with four faces, he was little worshippedafter Gupta times. single temple of Brahmā, by sacred lake Puskaranear modern Ajmer, is only one known.The numerous solar deities of Vedas were merged in Hinduism into asingle god, usually known as Sūrya (” Sun”) (pl. XXXVII a).
