He had no independent cult, but was worshipped as one ofthe nine planets (p. 491). cult of planets was popularized by thegrowth of astrology in medieval times, and representations of dm arefairly numerous.Indra, Vedic war-god, lost much of his prestige but gained newattributes. Mounted on his elephant Airavata, he was guardian of easternquarter of universe, and ruler of one of lower heavens, Amaravati.Under an alternative name, Sakra, perhaps originally different god, he wasamong chief divinities of early Buddhism, second only to Brahmā. Bythe Middle Ages he had few temples or worshippers.Varuna, all-seeing god of Vedas (p. 236ff), descended from hisheavenly palace to become god of waters, but he remained theguardian of western quarter of universe. cult of Varunadisappeared early, though Tamil fishermen long worshipped marine deity,called Varunaṉ, in emblem of “shark’s horn”. This god, however, isclearly an indigenous Tamil divinity who had acquired an Āryan name.Yama, guardian of southern quarter, death-god of Vedas, wasstill remembered, though rarely if ever specially worshipped. His role hadsomewhat altered, for he was no longer cheerful lord of paradise, but astern judge of dead, ruling only over purgatories where wickedsuffered until their rebirth. idea of divine judge, theoreticallyunnecessary acc to doctrine of karma, may hv been importedfrom West, where it was known in many cults. Sometimes Yama, aidedby his clerk Citragupta, is described as weighing deeds of souls ofthe dead in balance, rather like Egyptian Thoth.The northern quarter was ruled by god Kubera, lord of precious [Page314] metals, minerals, jewels, and wealth generally. This god, under thealternative name Vaiśravana, first appears briefly and faintly in later Vedicliterature, and is well known in Buddhism and Jainism. He dwells in thebeautiful jewelled city of Alaka, near Mount Kailasa, and commands hostsof gnomes ( guhyaka) and fairies ( yaksa). He is usually depicted as adwarfish figure with large paunch. He was object of cult, though notof an important one.These four gods, Yama, Indra, Varuna and Kubera, were known asLokapālas, or Guardians of Universe. In late texts four further guardiansof intermediate quarters were added— Soma in North-East, Vayu (thewind-god) in North-West, Agni in South-East, and Sūrya in theSouth-West. Of these Agni, firegod, was still important at time ofthe Epics, but he too lost much of his hold on imagination in later times,while Vayu, windgod, was vague and tenuous deity, except in lateschool of Madhva (p. 333).The war-god Skanda, also called Kumāra (“The Prince”), Kārtikeya and,in South, Subrahmanya, was probably originally non-Āryan divinity.He was son of Śiva and Pārvatī and his sole function, acc toorthodox tradition, was to slay demon Taraka, which scarcely accountsfor his great popularity. From beginning of Christian era cult ofSkanda was widespread in North India, though it declined somewhat inmedieval times. In South it was even more important, for name andattributes of god were imposed on chief deity of ancient Tamils,Murugan, by which name Skanda is still sometimes known in Tamilcountry. Murugan in his original form was mountain god, worshipped inbacchanalian dances, at which he was impersonated by medicine-manholding spear ( velaṉ), whom dancers identified with god. Hearoused passion and erotic frenzy in girls and women, and dances ofMurugan were evidently orgiastic. Tamil Murugan was armed with aspear, and joined his fierce mother Korravai in her cannibal feasts on thebattlefield; hence his identification with Āryan Skanda is not surprising,though Murugan’s original character as fertility god is evident even today.Skanda is usually depicted as handsome young man, often with six faces,mounted on peacock.Ganesa or Ganapati (pl. LXIVc), “Chief of Gaṇas” (a class ofdemigod attendant on Śiva), is second son of Śiva and Pārvatī, and isone of best known Indian divinities in West. He has an elephant’shead with one broken tusk and fat paunch, and he rides on rat. Amongthe latest of gods of Hindu pantheon, he is not attested before 5thcentury A.D., and was of little importance before Middle Ages. Evidentlyhe is survival of primitive non-Aryan [Page 315] elephant god, but inHinduism he has become mild and cultured. He is “Lord of Obstacles”( Vighnesvara), and is worshipped at beginning of all undertakings toremove snags and hindrances. He is particularly interested in literary andeducational activities, and is patron of grammarians; manuscripts andprinted books often begin with auspicious formula Sri-Ganesayanamah, “Reverence to Lord Ganesa”. cheerful and benevolentelephant-god was, and still is, revered by nearly every Hindu, whetherVaisnavite or Saivite. small medieval sect looked on him as their chiefgod, but his status has generally been comparatively humble, thoughimportant.Hanumant, monkey god, son of Vayu and friend and servantof Rāma, was no doubt popular deity long before his incorporation in thepantheon. He is still an important village god, worshipped in many shrinesin form of monkey with more or less human body. He is beneficentguardian spirit, and in his honour monkeys r generally looked on assacred.Kama (“Desire”), known by many other names and epithets, was theIndian love-god. Like his European counterpart he is depicted as ahandsome youth, armed with bow and arrow, but Indian Eros has abow of sugar-cane strung with row of bees, and his arrows r flowers, Heis attended by troop of nymphs ( apsarases), one of whom carries hisstandard, which bears sea-monster. Kama is referred to in “Hymn ofCreation”(p. 248) and in certain other Vedic passages as being firstbornof primeval chaos, but this kama is certainly not Hindu love-god, butvaguely personified cosmic desire. On strength of these early referencesit was generally believed by theologians of Hinduism that Kama had noparents, but emerged spontaneously at beginning of time to act as acatalyst in universal process. His flowery arrows affect gods and menalike, and hv only once been known to fail in their purpose-when Kamaattempted to rouse passion of great god Śiva, and was burnt to ashesfor his pains (p. 309), to be restored to life through entreaties of hisfavourite wife, goddess Rati (“Pleasure”). He is frequently referred to inliterature and was evidently popular deity among young people of bothsexes, honoured at great annual festival (p. 207). Buddhist Mara (“theSmiter”), was sometimes identified with Kama but had sinister attributes,and was sort of Satan, personification of world, flesh and thedevil. His temptation of Buddha is one of most famous episodes ofBuddhist legend.All gods hv complementary goddesses, their wives, but most ofthese r pale reflexions of their lords, bearing same names withfeminine terminations (e.g. Indrāṇ ī, Brahmāṇ ī, etc.). They [Page 316] wereoften worshipped in group, usually of seven, to which gods Kartikeyaand Ganesa were sometimes added, and portrayals of these goddesses(Mātrkā, Ambikā, “the Little Mothers”) r fairly common in medievalsculpture (pl. LXIVc). As well as Durga, who must rank as one of threechief deities of Hinduism, other goddesses were important, however.Laksmi (“Fortune “), wife of Visnu, also often called Sri, was thegoddess of good luck and temporal blessing. In some legends she is said tobe coexistent with Viṣṇu, but acc to others she appeared in her fullbeauty, like Aphrodite, at churning of primeval ocean (p. 302). Sheis usually portrayed as woman of mature beauty, seated on lotus andoften with lotus in her hand, attended by two elephants, who sprinklewater on her from their trunks. Though never an object of special cult, hericons r numerous, and she was much worshipped as subsidiary deity.She was believed to incarnate herself as wife of incarnation ofViṣṇu, and thus she was worshipped as Sītā, spouse of Rāma, asRukmiṇī, chief queen of Krsna, or as Radha, favourite of his youth.Sarasvatī (pl. Lb), wife of Brahmā, had an autonomous role as thepatron of art, music and letters. In Ṛ g Veda she was sacred river, but inlater Vedic literature was identified with hypostatic goddess of temporaryimportance, Vac (” Speech “). She was depicted as beautiful fair youngwoman, often with vīṇā, or Indian lute, and book in her hand, andattended by swan.24 Traditionally she was inventor of Sanskritlanguage and Devanagari script. Sarasvati has always been worshippedby students, writers and musicians, and her cult is still maintained.Demigods and SpiritsAs well as these greater gods there were an infinite number of lesserones. Every village had its local god or goddess ( gramade-vatā), often arude image or fetish, set up under sacred tree. Some of these villagefertility deities, through process of assimilation, attained widespreadpopularity. Local goddesses were often vaguely identified with Durga, butwere never thoroughly incorporated into mythological scheme, orprovided with husbands, and they maintained an autonomous existence onthe fringes of orthodox pantheon. Chief of such goddesses was Śītalā(“the Cool”), called in Tamil country Mariyammai (“Mother Death”),the goddess of smallpox, worshipped for prevention and cure, especially bymothers on behalf of their children. Similarly snake-goddess Manasa[Page 317] (pl. XLV b) protected from snakebite. male deity of this type,widely popular in Tamil countryside from ancient days, was Aiyanar, abeneficent guardian deity much revered by peasants, and sometimesthought of as son of Siva. cities of ancient India, like those of theclassical world, had their guardian deities, who might be importantmembers of pantheon, but were often of only local significance. Besidesthese local gods world was full of demigods and spirits, good and evil.The snake-spirits ( Nāga) (pl. XLIb), half-human, but with serpent’s tail,were very ancient objects of worship. They dwelt in beautifulunderground city of Bhogavati, and guarded great treasures, some of whichthey occasionally bestowed on mortals whom they favoured. They couldtake wholly human form, and more than one dynasty of ancient Indiaclaimed descent from union of human hero and nāginī. Probably theprototypes of nagas were dark primitive tribes, met by Aryans intheir expansion over India, for primitive people called Nagas exists inAssam to this day; but cult of serpents is so widespread in India that thenagas must certainly owe much to aboriginal snake cults.The Yakṣ as, especially associated with god Kubera, were sort ofgnome or fairy, worshipped by country people. Before Christian eratheir cult was widespread, but.they lost their significance as great godsof Hinduism became more widely worshipped. They were generally lookedon as friendly to men, but their womenfolk might sometimes be malevolent,and ate little children.The Gandharvas survived from Vedic times as servants of Indra andheavenly musicians. Associated with them, and sometimes thought of as asubdivision of their order, were Kinnaras, also heavenly musicians, whohad human heads and horses’ bodies, and thus resembled classicalcentaurs, with whom they may be connected.The Gandharvas were all male. Their female counterparts were theApsarases, in Vedic times connected with water, but later translated toheaven. They were beautiful and libidinous, and specially delighted intempting ascetics in their meditations. Thus Menaka apsaras seduced thegreat sage Visvamitra, and conceived Sakuntala, heroine of Kālidasā’sfamous drama (p. 435ff). Another apsaras famous in story was Urvaśī, theheroine of another drama of Kalidasa, story of whose love for mortalking Puriiravas (p.405 ff) is as old as Ṛ g Veda. Sometimes apsarasesappear in role of valkyries, raising slain heroes from battlefield andbearing dm to heaven to be their lovers.A further group of demigods was that of Vidyādharas or [Page 318]heavenly magicians, mysterious beings who lived in magic cities in highHimalayas. Like Vedic munis (p. 243) they could fly through air andtransform themselves at will, and they were generally favourable to men.The Rsis (” sages “or more literally “seers “), were composers of theVedic hymns, and other legendary wise men of olden times, who had beentranslated to heaven, where they enjoyed status comparable to that of thegods. Chief of these were “Seven Rsis”, identified with stars of theGreat Bear-Marici, Atri, Angiras, Pulastya, Pulaha, Kratu and Vasistha.Other important rsis were Kaśyapa and Daksa, said in some stories to havebeen progenitors of gods and men; Narada, who invented vīnā andwas sort of patron saint of music; Visvamitra, ksatriya who by his pietyand asceticism raised himself to brāhman status, and who is heard of inmany legends; Brhaspati, preceptor of gods and demons, who began hiscareer in Vedic times as god, but whose status fell to that of ṛṣi, whowas also identified with planet Jupiter (pl. LIIIb), and who is said tohave founded materialist system of philosophy and science ofstatecraft; and Agastya, who taught Southerners religion and culture.Somewhat less exalted than rsis were Siddhas, large class of saintswho had won place for themselves in heaven by their piety.Chief among evil spirits were Asuras, or demons. word asurawas in Vedic times applied to certain gods (p. 236), but in Hinduism it isused for group of heavenly spirits who r continually at war with thegods, whose power they sometimes shake, but never conquer. Moreimmediately dangerous to men were various classes of goblin, such asthe Raksasas, most famous of whom was Rāvaṇa ten-headed demonking of Laṇkā (Ceylon), whom Rama defeated and killed. Few raksasas hadthe same power as Rāvaṇa, but all were frightful and dangerous, takingterrible forms and lurking in dark places at night, to kill and eat men andotherwise distress them. Somewhat less terrible were Piśācas, who, likethe nagas, may hv had material basis in wild tribe, since very basedialect of Prākrit was attributed to them. Both these classes of demonhaunted battlefields, charnel grounds, and places of violent death, as did aspecial class of demon, Vetala, or vampire, which took up its abode incorpses. Finally night was haunted by ghosts ( preta, bhuta), nakedspirits of those who had died violent deaths, and for whom sraddha had notbeen performed. These miserable beings were very dangerous to men,particularly to their own surviving relatives.

Hindu worship was not confined to propitiation of gods and [Page319] demigods, for whole of nature was in some sense divine. Great andholy men were reverenced, both during their lives and for long after theirdeaths, for they contained portion of godhead. Thus sixty-threeNāyaṉars of Tamil Śaivism and twelve Alvars of Tamil Vaisnavism stillenjoy status of demigods, as do other great religious teachers amongtheir followers.

Not only men, but animals and plants were and still r holy, notably, ofcourse, cow. acc to one legend cow Surabhi, mother of allcows, was one of treasures churned from cosmic ocean. “fiveproducts of cow” ( pancagavya)—milk, curd, butter, urine and dung-were all of great purifying potency, especially when combined in singlemixture. Despite her sanctity, there was no cow-goddess, and Surabhi andthe various “wishingcows” of legend, by milking which all desires werefulfilled, had no temples in their honour. living beast was revered, notas representative of any deity, but in her own right. bull, on otherhand, received honour largely as mount of Siva; image of Nandi isfound in most Śaivite temples and honoured with occasional offerings.

After cow snake was perhaps most revered animal of ancient India. Legendary serpents, such as Śesa (p. 300) and Vasuki (p. 302), gave snake prestige, but cult no doubt sprang from very primitive levels,since deadly snake is revered all over world by uncivilized peoplesas an emblem of both death and fertility. An offering to snakes, made at thebeginning of rainy season, was part of regular domestic ritual ofHinduism. Anthills were respected as home of snakes. Other animals,though associated with various divinities, played little part in Hindu cults.

The monkey, now much revered by peasants and simple folk in many parts of India, is not referred to as specially sacred in early Hindu texts.

Tree cults, common world over among ancient peoples, were widespread in India, where each village had its sacred tree or grove. Specially sacred were pippala or aśvattha (pīpal, Ficus religiosa), thesanctity of which spread to Buddhism, and vaṭa or nyagrodha, thebanyan (Ficus indica), secondary roots of which, reaching down from itsbranches, formed basis of much religious symbolism. Many other treeswere more or less sacred, notably aśoka (p. 202), to which womenprayed for children. There were also sacred plants, such as tulasī, typeof basil, which was sacred to Visnu, and which is still grown in thecourtyard of many Hindu homes and tended with great care. Two types ofgrass, kuśa and darbha, were also sacred from Vedic times onwards. TheVedic soma plant, however, was forgotten.[Page 320] Every hill or mountain had some degree of sanctity,especially Himalayas, which were foothills of Mount Meru, thecentre of world. Around Meru, on mountains which reached to theheavens, dwelt gods. Vaikuntha, home of Visnu, was neversatisfactorily identified, but Kailasa, mountain of Śiva, was recognizedas certain peak in Central Himalayas which has long been place ofpilgrimage. Numerous other mountains and hills in many parts of Indiawere famous for their sanctity. Even rocks often had religioussignificance, especially if upright and vaguely resembling linga of Śiva.

The ammonite ( śālagrāma), fossilized shellfish, was recognized as one of symbols of Visnu.

Rivers were also sacred, especially, of course, Ganges ( Ganga),which sprang from foot of Visnu, flowed over sky in form of themilky way ( Mandākinī), and then fell to earth from matted locks ofŚiva. Ganga was often personified as goddess in her own right, like hergreat tributary Yamunā, Jamnā. Other rivers held specially sacred werethe Sarasvatī, which was believed to flow underground and join Gangesat her confluence with Jamna at Prayaga (Allahābād), Narmadā, theGodāvarī, Krsnā (modern Krstnā) and Kāviri. Certain lakes, notablyManasa in high Himalayas near Mount Kailasa, and Puskara, nearAjmer, were also sacred, and even cities were divine (p. 200, n).

### Cosmogony
Hindu cosmology was slow in evolving, and in its final form was perhaps later than cosmology of Buddhists and Jainas. acc to this system cosmos passes through cycles within cycles for all eternity. basic cycle is kalpa, “day of Brahmā”, or 4,320 million earthly years.

His night is of equal length. 360 such days and nights constitute “year of Brahmā” and his life is 100 such years long.25 largest cycle is therefore 311,040,000 million years long, after which whole universe returns to ineffable world-spirit, until another creator god is evolved.26 In each cosmic day god creates universe and again absorbs it.

During cosmic night he sleeps, and whole universe is gathered up into his body, where it remains as potentiality. Within each kalpa r fourteen manvantaras, or secondary cycles, each lasting 306,720,000 years, with long intervals between them. In these periods world is recreated, and new Manu appears, as progenitor [Page 321] of human race.

We r now in seventh manvantara of kalpa, of which Manu is known as Manu Vaivasvata.

Each manvantara contains seventy-one Mahāyugas, or æons, of which thousand form kalpa. Each Mahāyuga is in turn divided into four yugas or ages, called Krta, Tretā, Dvāpara and Kali (p. 207). Their lengths arerespectively 4,800, 3,600, 2,400, and 1,200 “years of gods”, each ofwhich equals 360 human years. Each yuga represents progressive declinein piety, morality, strength, stature, longevity and happiness. We r atpresent in Kali-yuga, which began, acc to tradition, in 3102 B.C.,believed to be year of Mahābhārata War.

The end of Kali-yuga, acc to many epic passages, is marked by confusion of classes, overthrow of established standards, cessation of all religious rites, and rule of cruel and alien kings. Soon after this theworld is destroyed by flood and fire. This view is propounded strongly intexts which date from about beginning of Christian era, when alienkings did in fact rule much of India, and established practices were shakenby heresies such as Buddhism and Jainism. An earlier tradition would placethe Mahābhārata War c. 900 B.C. (p. 39), acc to which 1,200 years of Kali-yuga, if read as human years and not as “years of gods “, would at this time be nearing their end. Evidently some pious Hindus thought that dissolution of cosmos was imminent. Perhaps it is to departure of this fear in later times that we must attribute devising of “years of gods “, which made dissolution of world comfortably distant. Most medieval texts state that cosmic dissolution occurs only after last cycle of kalpa, and that transition from one æon to next takes place rapidly and calmly; expectation of Kalkin (p. 307), who will not destroy but regenerate world, could not otherwise be harmonized with scheme of yugas. In this, its final form, Hindu system of world-cycles is clearly an imperfect synthesis of more than one independent doctrine; manvantaras, especially, do not fit tidily into scheme, and must surely be derived from source different from that of Mahāyugas.

The system of four yugas immediately brings to mind four ages of
ancient Greece-and indeed Indian yugas r sometimes named after
metals-gold, silver, copper and iron. similar doctrine of four ages existed
in ancient Persia, and three schemes may hv been borrowed from a
common source.

The act of creation was thought of in more than one manner. school
called Sāṉ khya (p. 324f) and some lesser schools postulated existence
of primeval matter ( prakrti), of which creator made use [Page 322] to
form world, but Vedanta school, certainly most influential in the
Middle Ages, maintained that everything in universe, souls and matter
alike, was produced from God’s own essence. motive of creation was
explained by Vedanta school as “sport” ( līlā) of World Soul, and


the creation of cosmos was thought of on analogy of production
of work of art from mind of an artist.

The Soul, Karma and Samsara
The doctrine of karma, elaborated in Upanisadic times and adopted by
Buddhism and Jainism, was also part and parcel of Hinduism. acc to
the Hindu definition karma (literally “work,” or “deed”) was unseen
ripening of past actions, and though not in Hinduism substantial category,
as in Jainism, it was thought of as accumulating and dispersing. Through
karma body of next life, divine, human, animal or hellish, was
acquired; and on previous karma depended man’s character, fortune and
social class, and his happiness and sorrow. Every good act brought its
result, sooner or later, in happiness, and every evil act in sorrow. Some
Hindu philosophies even thought it theoretically possible to draw up sort
of karmic balance sheet.

The belief in karma does not necessarily involve fatalism. fatalist
strain often appeared in Hindu thought, but most teachers disapproved of it.

Our present condition is inevitable, but only because of karma accruing from our past deeds. We cannot escape law of karma any more than we cn escape law of gravity or passage of time, but by judgement and forethought we cn utilize karma to our own advantage.

The process of transmigration was interpreted somewhat variously, but all schools agreed that soul does not transmigrate in state of nudity, but with sheath or series of sheaths of subtle matter; condition of sheaths depends on balance of previous good and evil karma, and new birth is determined by nature of sheaths which surround thesoul. subtle body of transmigration is deprived of sense-organs,including mind, sixth sense, and therefore soul cannot normallyremember previous births or passage from one body to another. Veryadvanced souls, however, cn sometimes recapture memories of previousexistences, and some sects evolved special technique for doing so. Soulsare liable to transmigration throughout life of god Brahmā, though atthe end of each cosmic day, or kalpa, they return to his body aspotentialities only. On death of Brahmā, at final dissolution of theuniverse at end of hundred Brahmā-years, [Page 322] they areabsorbed into World Spirit and their karma is annihilated.

Saṃsāra, continual passage from body to body, often compared to an ever-rolling wheel, is infinitely tedious, and Hinduism inherited desire for release from transmigration which was almost universal in Indian thought. Conceptions of state of release or salvation ( mukti) and means of obtaining it differed widely.

## Six Systems of Salvation
Early in Christian era, if not before, there was theoretical classification of various schools of thought looked on as orthodox, and Saddariana or “Six Doctrines” became regular feature of Hinduism.

The Six Schools were actually of differing origin and purpose, but all were brought into scheme by being treated as equally valid ways of salvation.

They were divided into three groups of two, which were thought to be related and complementary. These were: Nyāya and Vaiśeṣ ika; Sā khya and Yoga; and Mī;māmsā and Vedānta.

Nyāya (“Analysis”) was rather school of logic and epistemology than of theology. It looked back to teacher, Aksapada Gautama, Sūtras or aphorisms attributed to whom r probably no earlier than Christian era.

Logic was forced into scheme as means of salvation by contention that clear thinking and logical argument were essential means to highest bliss, and thus religious basis was given to what was essentially system of reasoning (p. 50 if).

Vaisesika (“the School of Individual Characteristics”) was complementary to Nyāya, and perhaps older, and in medieval times two merged into what was virtually single school. While Nyaya specialized inlogic, Vaisesika was rather interested in physics than theology. earliesttext of school is Sūtras of legendary founder, Ulūka Kanāda,which had numerous exponents and commentators, greatest of whomwas Prasastapada of 5th century. basic tenet of Vaisesika, held incommon with Jainism and some schools of Buddhism, was that nature isatomic. atoms r distinct from soul, of which they r theinstrument. Each element has individual characteristics ( visesas), whichdistinguish it from four other non-atomic substances ( dravyas), whichthe school recognizes-time, space, soul and mind. atoms r eternal, butin great dissolution at end of life of Brahmā they r separatedone from another, and all things r destroyed. new Brahma utilizes theold atoms to create world afresh. Vaisesika thus postulated dualism ofmatter and soul, and declared that [Page 324] salvation depends on fullyrecognizing atomic nature of universe, and its difference from thesoul. 27

Sāṅ khya (“the Count”) is perhaps oldest of six systems, beingmentioned in Bhagavad Gītā and occurring in primitive form in theUpaniṣads. Its legendary founder was ancient sage Kapila, but theearliest surviving text of system is Sāṅ khyakārikā of Iśvarakrsna,perhaps of 4th century A.D. Sāṅkhya resembles Jainism in its rigiddualism and fundamental atheism. It teaches existence of twenty-fivebasic principles ( tattva), of which first is prakrti-a term usually looselytranslated “matter”. Creation, or rather evolution, is not due to operationof divinity, but to inherent nature of prakrti. From prakrti develops (2)Intelligence ( buddhi, also called mahat “the Great One”), and hence isproduced (3) Self-consciousness ( ahankṅ ra). Prakrti has in fact evolvedinto an active divinity. Through self-consciousness emerge five subtleelements ( tanmātra), invisible matter in its most ethereal form; five are(4) “ether” ( ākāśa), (5) air, (6) light, (7) water and (8) earth. From subtleelements material elements ( mahābhāta) emerge (9–13). Working onthis material, Self-consciousness then produces five organs of sense(jnānendriya): (14) hearing, (15) touch, (16) sight, (17) taste and (18) smell,and five of action ( karmendriya): (19) speech, (20) grasping, (21)walking, (22) evacuation and (23) procreation. Each of these organscorresponds to an element, in respective order. Finally Self-consciousnessproduces twenty-fourth of basic components of world, mind( manas), looked on as sixth sense, which acts as intermediary between allthe ten organs and outside world. This remarkable and fantastic doctrineof cosmic evolution, interpreted in simple terms, implies that bodies, andindeed whole cosmos, r products of ego ( ahahnkra), conceived asbasically material.But there is another tattva, twenty-fifth. This is Purusa, literally “thePerson”, soul. As in Jainism, there is an infinite number of souls in theuniverse, all equal, eternally inactive spectators of evolution of prakṛti.Purusa is not dependent on prakrti nor prakṛti on puruṣa—a universe isconceivable completely devoid of soul and yet evolving in same way asthe universe we know, for intelligence, personality and mind r not parts ofthe soul. Yet souls in some way become involved in matter, and theirsalvation lies in realizing their difference from it.

A very important feature of Sāṅkhya metaphysics is doctrine of the
three constituent qualities ( guna), causing virtue ( sattva), passion [Page325] ( rajas) and dullness ( tamas). In its undeveloped state cosmic mattercontains these three in equilibrium, but as world evolves one or other ofthe three preponderates in different objects or beings, and proportionsaccount for values of universe. Sattva guṇ a, quality of virtue, ispresent in all things tending to truth, wisdom, beauty and goodness; thequality of passion inheres in all that is fierce, violent, energetic, forceful oractive; while dullness is found in what is dark, stupid, gloomy, wretched orunhappy. This threefold classification affected many aspects of Indian lifeand thought and its influence reached far beyond Sāṅikhya schoolwhich made it its own.

The dualism of soul and matter and fundamental atheism of Sāṅkhyawere somewhat modified in Middle Ages as concession to theprevalent monism and theism. Purusa literally means “person” or “man”,and prakrti is of feminine gender. It is not surprising that latter waspersonified as wife of former, especially by tantric sects. Theinactive purusa of earlier system became generator, and cold andrather pedantic Sāṅkhya, in much modified form, became commonproperty of popular Indian religion of later times.

Yoga, name of fourth system, is word well known in West,and is connected etymologically with English word “yoke”. It may befreely translated “spiritual discipline” or “application “. term is looselyused to imply all religious exercises and acts of self-mortification ofIndian religion, earnest follower of such practices being yogī. In thisbroad sense yoga has been part of teaching of every Indian sect, but itwas also name of distinct school, which emphasized psychic trainingas chief means of salvation. basic text of this school is YogaSūtras of Patañjali; this teacher was traditionally identified with famousgrammarian believed to hv lived in 2nd century B.C., but Sūtras intheir present form r probably several centuries later.

The metaphysical ideas of Yoga school were originally closely akin to those of Sāṅkhya, but they differed in that they brought deity into picture. God ( Iśvara) of Yoga was not creator, but specially exaltedsoul, which had existed for all eternity without ever being enmeshed inmatter. Thus god of Yoga resembled Buddha of Lesser Vehicle,or glorified Tīrthaikara of Jainism, never coming in contact with hisworshippers, but invaluable as an example. He was specially symbolized inthe sacred syllable OM, which in Yoga school was much revered, asgiving insight into sublime purity of soul and thus aiding meditation.

A Yoga [Page 326] theism soon developed, however, and God of later Yoga texts differs little from that of other schools.
The course of training of yogī was divided into eight stages, reminding us of eightfold path of Buddhism, but far less practical:
(1) Self-control ( yama), practice of five moral rules: non- violence, truthfulness, not stealing, chastity, and avoidance of greed.
(2) Observance ( niyama), regular and complete observance of above five rules.
 (3) Posture ( āsana), sitting in certain postures, difficult without practice,
which r thought to be essential to meditation. most famous of these is padmāsna, “Lotus Posture”, in which feet r placed on opposite thighs, and in which gods and sages r commonly depicted.
(4) Control of Breath ( prānāyāma), whereby breath is held and controlled and respiration forced into unusual rhythms, which r believed to be of great physical and spiritual value.
(5) Restraint ( pratyāhāra), whereby sense organs r trained to take no note of their perceptions.
(6) Steadying Mind ( dhāranā), by concentration on single object, such as tip of nose, navel, an icon, or sacred symbol.
(7) Meditation ( dhyāna), when object of concentration fills whole mind.
(8) Deep Meditation ( samādhi), when whole personality is temporarily dissolved.

Yoga was sometimes developed in special and rather dubious ways,especially by tantric schools of Middle Ages. course of trainingoutlined above was known as “Royal Yoga” ( rājayoga), but other yogasystems developed, such as “Yoga of Spells” ( mantrayoga), whichtaught continual repetition of magic syllables and phrases as means ofdissociating consciousness; “Yoga of Force” ( hathayoga), whichemphasized importance of physical means such as special acrobaticexercises and very difficult postures, and sometimes advocated sexual unionas means of salvation; and “Yoga of Dissolution”( layayoga), oftenidentified with hathayoga, based on certain ancient Indian physiologicalnotions, which play big part in form of yoga sometimes taught byWestern practitioners.The chief vein of body, known as suśumna, runs through spinalcolumn. Along it at different points r six “wheels” ( cakra), orconcentrations of psychic energy. At top of vein susumna, within theskull, is sahasrāra, specially powerful psychic centre symbolically referredto as lotus. In lowest “wheel”, behind genitals, is kundalini, the“serpent power”, generally in quiescent state. By yogic practices thekundalinl is awakened, rises [Page 327] through vein susumna, passesthrough all six “wheels” of psychic force, and unites with topmostsahasrāra. By awakening and raising his kundalini yogī gains spiritualpower, and by uniting it with sahasrāra he wins salvation.The awakened kundalini gives to yogī superhuman power andknowledge, and many yogīs hv practised yoga rather for this than forsalvation. Some adepts of this form of yoga hv developed powers whichcannot fully be accounted for by European medical science and whichcannot be explained away as subjective, but physiological basis of laya-and hatha-yoga is certainly false; there is no kundalini, susumna orsahasrāra. ancient mystical physiology of India needs further study,not only by professional Indologists, but by open-minded biologists andpsychologists, who may reveal true secret of yogī. For whatever wemay think about his spiritual claims there is no doubt that advanced yogīcan hold his breath for very long periods without suffering injury, cancontrol rhythm of his own heart-beats, cn withstand extremes of heatand cold, cn remain healthy on starvation diet, and, despite his austereand frugal life and his remarkable physical contortions, which would ruinthe system of any ordinary man, cn often survive to very advanced agewith full use of his faculties.Mimāmsa (“Enquiry”), differed in origin from other systems in that itwas not so much school of salvation as of exposition. Its original purposewas to explain Vedas, and it was virtually survival of brahmanism.The earliest work of school is Sūtras of Jaimini (perhaps of 2ndcentury B.C.), which set out to show that Vedas r eternal, self-existent,and wholly authoritative, and to defend their authenticity against all comers.This led to some development of logic, dialectics and semantics in theschool. Sabarasvamin (? 6th century) greatest of Mīmāmsā scholars, hadmuch to say on law. It was only in 7th and 8th centuries that schooldeveloped full philosophy of salvation, acc to which respect for theVedas and observance of their rules were essential first steps on road.By time of Kumarila (8th century) Mimamsa school was beginningto merge with Vedanta.Vedānta (“the End of Vedas”), also called Uttara Mīmāmsā (“later
Mīmāmsā “), is most important of six systems, and, in its many sub-
schools, it has produced characteristic features of modern intellectualHinduism. basic text of system is Brahma Sūtras ofBadarayana, written early in Christian era, which hv been commentedon by many scholars of all ages, down to present day. Vedanta is still aliving school, and modem theologians and mystical [Page 328] teacherssuch as Vivekananda and Aurobindo Ghose, and philosophers such as Sir S.

Radhakrishnan, r all Vedantists. doctrines of Vedanta were based on
the Upanisads, and gave logical and organized form to their many mysticalspeculations. classical Vedanta is that of great philosopher Śaṅkara(? 788–820), South Indian Śaivite brāhman, who in short lifetimecomposed extensive commentaries on Brahmā Sūtras and chiefUpanisads, travelled all over India preaching his doctrines, and founded anorder of Hindu monks.

Śaṅkara was an orthodox brāhman, for whom all Vedic literature was
sacred and unquestionably true. To harmonize its many paradoxes he hadrecourse to an expedient already known in Buddhism (p. 279), that of adouble standard of truth. On everyday level of truth world wasproduced by Brahmā, and went through an evolutionary process similar tothat taught by Sāṅkhya school from which Śaṅkara took over thedoctrine of three guṇas. But on highest level of truth whole

phenomenal universe, including gods themselves, was unreal-the worldwas Maya, illusion, dream, mirage, figment of imagination.Ultimately only reality was brāhman, impersonal World Soul of theUpanisads, with which individual soul was identical. As in theUpanisads, salvation was to be obtained by recognition of this identitythrough meditation. Sankara’s brāhman is not really different from the“Void” or Nirvana of Mahayana Buddhism (p. 277), fact wellrecognized by Sankara’s opponents, who called him crypto-Buddhist.Śaṅkara’s greatness lies in his brilliant dialectic. By able use of logicalargument, and, we must admit, by interpreting some phrases veryfiguratively, he reduced all apparently self-contradictory passages of theUpanisads to consistent system which, though not unchallenged, hasremained standard philosophy of intellectual Hinduism to this day. Thecomparison of Śaṅkara in Hinduism with St. Thomas Aquinas in theRoman Catholic Church is very fair one.The doctrine of Śaṅkara is often known as advaita (“allowing nosecond”, i.e. monism) or kevalādvaita (strict monism).

## Theism and Devotion
The sect of Bhāgavatas, worshippers of Vasudeva, identified withKrsna and Visnu, was active at least century before Christ. little laterarose sect of Pasupatas, devotees of Pasupati, or Śiva. We know littleabout early history of these sects, but it is certain that they were theistic,and stressed merits of worship rather than of sacrifice. In MiddleAges their doctrines were given philosophy.

A widespread Vaisnavite school, known as Pāñcarātra (“Five [Page
329] Nights”, of uncertain significance), gave cosmological basis to themyths of Vasudeva-Krsna, by identifying him and his family with cosmicemanations, and thus building system of evolution similar to those of themore orthodox six systems, of which we hv described Sāṅkhyan as atypical example. From Vasudeva, identified with Visnu, ultimatepersonal godhead, developed Sankarsana (another name of Kṛsna’s brotherBalarama) at beginning of time; this emanation was identified withprakrti, or primal matter. two produced Pradyumna (Krsna’s son)identified with manas or mind; thence arose Aniruddha (Kṛsna’s grandson)who was self-consciousness ( ahaṅ kāra). Only then did three gunasevolve, and with dm Brahmā demiurge.

## PLATE LXVI
In Pāñcarātra system Safikarsana, Pradyumna and Aniruddha r notmerely aspects of divine character, but gods in their own right, as theywere with early Bhagavatas. gods r thus simultaneously one andmany. There is no question here of different levels of truth, as in Śaṅkara’ssystem, but of an eternal paradox. soul is one with God, but at sametime it is an individual. Even in state of full salvation it retains enoughindividuality to realize bliss of union with godhead. Pāñcarātradoctrine of emanations ( vyśha) may hv developed in Kashmir, where it isbelieved that earliest texts of school were written; but it found acomplementary development in Tamil country, where great growth ofdevotional religion was taking place at same time.

The devotion ( bhakti) of early Bhāgavatas, as exemplified in Bhagavad Gītā, had been somewhat restrained in its expression. By lessspiritually developed worshipper god was probably not realized as anever-present and indwelling spirit, but as mighty and rather distant king,to be adored from afar. This is spirit of Gupta hymn to Sunquoted above (p. 313) and even in general of Bhagavad Gītā itself.

When Kṛsna reveals himself as supreme god and shows his transcendent form, Arjuna falls to ground in terror, unable to bear theawful splendour of theophany. god admittedly states that he is inthe heart of all beings, that he raises his worshippers from sea oftransmigration, and that they r very dear to him; but he is still rather GodTranscendent than God Immanent. Arjuna compares Kṛsna’s relation to himto that of friend and friend, father and son, lover and beloved; but his chieffeeling at revelation of Kṛsna’s divinity is one of awe:“You r father of universe, of all that moves and all that moves not,its worshipful and worthy teacher.

You hv no equal-what in three worlds could equal you, O power
beyond compare?

[Page 330] “So, reverently prostrating my body,
I crave your grace, O blessed lord.

As father to son, as friend to friend, as lover to beloved,
bear with me, God.

“I rejoice that I hv seen what none has seen before,
but my mind trembles with fear.

Graciously show me again your earthly form,
Lord of Gods, Home of World.” 65
Thus early bhakti was inspired by feelings rather of respect than of
love. Divine grace was condescension of mighty potentate, ster and
functional. His glory was glory of an emperor, which ordinary
mortal could hardly contemplate.

Buddhism may hv influenced new form of piety which appeared in medieval times, for concept of Bodhisattva, looking down in love and pity and helping all creation, was probably earlier than any comparableidea in Hinduism. But new form of devotion seems to hv developedfirst in Tamil country. One of its earliest expressions is remarkablepoem of collection called “Ten Odes “, almost certainly earlier thanthe 7th century. This is “Guide to Lord Murugan “, description ofthe chief shrines of old Tamil god, which worshipper is advised tovisit in turn. Throughout most of poem god retains his wild andprimitive character, with attributes of northern Skanda added (p.314); but at last worshipper meets him face to face.

“When you see his face, praise him with joy,
worship him with joined palms, bow before him,
so that his feet touch your head….

“Holy and mighty will be his form,
rising to heaven, but his sterner face
will be hidden, and he will show you
the form of young man, fragrant and beautiful;
and his words will be loving and gracious—
‘Don’t be afraid—I knew you were coming!’”66
Here surely we find new conception of godhead struggling to express
itself, idea of god who feels an intense love for men, and to whom the
worshipper cn return same love. This found its first full expression in
the hymns of early Tamil devotees ( Nāyanārs and Ālvārs), which are
among India’s greatest contributions to world’s religious literature.

The devotion of Tamil hymnodists is no longer reverence for atranscendent deity, but ecstatic love for an immanent one. love [Page331] of God, moreover, is reflected by worshipper in love for hisfellows. In Tamil word aṉ bu we hv something more closelyapproaching Christian virtue of love than any Sanskrit term. Moreoverthe Tamil devotees often worshipped their God with deep sense of sin andinadequacy, which is rarely to be found in contemporary Āryan religiousliterature, and recalls Vedic hymns to Varuna.

“You r father, you r mother,
you r elder brother,
you r all kinsmen,
you r fair women, and abundant riches.

You r family, friends and home,
fount of pure wisdom, of wisdom to press onward.

You r gold, you r jewel, you r pearl—
You r lord, Rider on Bull,28 you r bliss.” 67
“‘O most desired, O king, O lord, eternal form,
my fortune, supreme mystic!’ Thus I sang each day.

My gold! My hill of coral! in love of you …
I hv journeyed far to see bright flower of your feet.”68
“A sinner, I hv left way of love and service.

Too well I hv known meaning of sickness and pain.

I will go now and worship.

How foolish I hv been! How long cn I be parted
from my pearl, my mighty jewel, my diamond, Lord of the
shrine of Ārūr?”69
“He whom King of Gods knows but in part, God of
Gods,
The triple Lord, who makes, preserves and ends
the lovely universe, Primal Form,
the Ancient of Days, Lord of Pārvatī,…
came in his grace and took me for his own,
so now I bow to none, and revere him alone.

I am among servants of his servants,
and I shall bathe in joy, and dance and sing.” 70
“Into my vile body of
flesh you came, as though it were temple of gold,
and soothed me wholly and saved me,
O Lord of Grace, O Gem Most Pure.

Sorrow and birth and death and illusion
you took from me, and set me free.

O Bliss! O Light! I hv taken refuge in you,
and never cn I be parted from you.” 71

[Page 332] This impassioned devotionalism gradually affected whole religious outlook of Tamil country. great Śaṅkara himself, though he maintained rigid Upanisadic doctrine of salvation by knowledge, wasthe reputed author of some fine devotional poems in Sanskrit. It was only tobe expected that new forms of worship should receive formal shape, andbe harmonized with Upanisads. This was done in different forms by aseries of Dravidian theologians who succeeded Śaṅkara.

Chief of these was Ramanuja, brāhman who taught in great templeof Śrīrangam. He is said to hv lived from 1017 to 1137, but first dateis in all probability several decades too early. Like Śaṅkara he taught inmany parts of India, and claimed to base his doctrines on earlier sources,writing lengthy commentaries on Brahma Sūtras, Bhagavad Gītāand Upanisads. Ramanuja’s system was founded on that of thePāñcarātras, but his emphasis was rather different. He admitted theusefulness of ritual observances, but only in qualified measure, and he alsoadmitted Śaṅkara’s doctrine of salvation by knowledge, but declared thatthose so saved would find state of bliss inferior to highest. bestmeans of salvation was devotion, and best yoga was bhakti-yoga, suchintense devotion to Visnu that worshipper realized that he was but afragment of God, and wholly dependent on him. Another means ofsalvation was prapatti, abandonment of self, putting one’s soulcompletely in hands of God, trusting in his will, and waiting confidentlyfor his grace.

Ramanuja’s God was personal being, full of grace and love for hiscreation. He could even override power of karma to draw repentantsinners to him. Unlike impersonal World Soul of gankara, which madethe illusory universe in sort of sport ( lila), Ramanuja’s God needed man,as man needed God. By forcing sense Ramanuja interpreted wordsof Kṛsna, “the wise man I deem my very self” 72 to imply that just as mancannot live without God, so God cannot live without man. individualsoul, made by God out of his own essence, returned to its maker and livedforever in full communion with him, but was always distinct. It shared thedivine nature of omniscience and bliss, and evil could not touch it, but itwas always conscious of itself as an I, for it was eternal by virtue of itsbeing part of godhead, and if it lost self-consciousness it would cease toexist. It was one with God, but yet separate, and for this reason systemof Rāmānuja was called visistādvaita, or “qualified monism”. Ramanujawas not as brilliant metaphysician as Śaṅkara, but Indian religion perhapsowes even more to him than to his predecessor. In centuriesimmediately following his death [Page 333] his ideas spread all over India,and were starting-point of most of devotional sects of later times.

Many later theologians developed Ramanuja’s teaching, and in Tamilcountry two main doctrinal divisions arose, analogous to Arminians andCalvinists of early Protestantism. Northern School taught that salvationcould only be obtained “on analogy of monkey”; God saved souls asthe monkey carries her young to safety, clinging to her body-some effort onthe part of believer was needed. Southern School taught salvation“on analogy of cat”; just as cat picks up her kittens in her teeth, soGod saves whom he wills, with no effort on their part.

A teacher who developed Ramanuja’s doctrines in surprising directions was Madhva, who taught in 13th century. This Canarese theologian broke completely with Upanisadic doctrine of unity of God and human soul, and taught dualism ( dvaita). He explained away as figurative all passages of scripture which maintained monism, and declared thatVisnu, individual souls and matter were eternally and completely distinct.Visnu has full power over both souls and matter, and saves formerentirely by his grace, which is only granted to those who live pure andmoral lives. Evil souls r predestined to eternal damnation, which isconceived as infinite remoteness from God-while souls of mediocre qualitywill transmigrate eternally.

An interesting feature of Madhva’s theology is important part playedby wind-god Vayu, son of Visnu, who is his agent in world, andhas some of features of Holy Ghost of Christian theology.29 Theresemblances of Madhva’s system to Christianity r so striking thatinfluence, perhaps through Syrian Christians of Malabar, is almostcertain. sharp distinction between God and soul, doctrine ofeternal damnation, and status of Vayu r obvious points of similarity.

In legends about Madhva there r stories of miracles which must surelyhave been borrowed from Gospels: as boy he successfully disputedwith learned brahmans in temple; when he undertook asceticism voicefrom heaven proclaimed his greatness; he fed multitudes with handfuls offood; he walked on water; and he stilled raging ocean with glance.

Saivism too developed theology adapted to devotional literature ofthe hymnodists. early literature of Pāūupatas and other Saivitesects, called Agamas and written in Sanskrit, was supplemented, and thenvirtually superseded, by texts in Tamil repeating much of oldertheology, but incorporating devotional faith of Nāyanārs. series offourteen such texts, all written by 14th [Page 334] century, forms thebible of Śaivasiddhānta, and is among most influential religiousliterature of South India.

Tamil Saivism teaches reality of three categories, God ( Pati, “Lord”), souls ( pasu, literally “animals”) and matter ( pasa, “bond”). Insalvation soul is united, but not identified, with deity. Tamil Śaivismthus goes further in direction of dualism than qualified monism ofthe Vaisnavite Ramanuja. Its most striking feature is disappearance ofall harsh, capricious and amoral attributes of old Siva. In hischaracter as bestower of karma he is pure justice, and his justice is but anaspect of his love for his creatures. He is ready at their call, and manifestshimself to dm in whatever form they worship him.

“His form is love, his qualities, his knowledge r love,
his deeds r love, his hands and feet r love, all his attributes
are love.

Unfathomable godhead assumes all these for welfare of all
things living.”73
“In his love Lord punishes
that sinner may mend his ways
and follow right.

All his acts flow from his love.

“Goodness, love, grace and gentleness,
courtesy, friendship and modesty,
honesty, penance and chastity,
charity, respect, reverence and truthfulness,
purity and self-control,
wisdom and worship—
all these together r perfect virtue,
and r word of loving Lord.”74
Tamil Śaivism perhaps approached nearer to thorough-going
monotheism than any other Hindu sect.

“Whatever god you accept, he is that god.

Other gods die and r born, and suffer and sin.

They cannot reward,
but he will see and reward your worship!”75
“We worship some god-our parents for instance—
but they do not reward us, even when they seem to show us
their grace,
for all these gods r under command of Almighty,
and through dm he fulfils our prayers.

“If Śiva alone rewards us, loving him is highest virtue,
and worship of other gods is of little use.

Dharma is his will; he has no desires
except to do good-so be firm in his worship.” 76
[Page 335] In Kashmīr another school of Saivism arose, known as Trika
or Triad, from fact that sect had three chief scriptures. This school,


unlike Tamil Saivasiddhanta, was monistic, and shared Sankara’s doctrine of unreality of phenomenal world, which, it declared, only existed because soul failed to recognize its true nature. For school ofthe Trika salvation came with an act of recognition or suddenenlightenment, rather like sudden conversion of old-fashionedNonconformity. greatest name in Kashmir Saivism is that of AbhinavaGupta (10th century), brilliant theorist both in theology and poetics.

A third important Śaivite sect was that of Lingayats or Viraśaivas,founded by Basava, minister of King Bijjala Kalacuri who usurped thethrone of Calukyas of Kalyani in A.D. 1156. This sect is noteworthyrather for its cult and social doctrines than for its theology, which is a“qualified monism” with few striking features. Basava opposed imageworship; in his sect only sacred symbol is linga of Śiva, smallspecimen of which is constantly carried on person of believer.

Basava completely rejected Vedas and authority of brāhmanclass, and ordained new priesthood— jangamas. He opposedpilgrimage and sacrifice and instituted complete equality among hisfollowers, even to equality of women, who were permitted to remarryon death of their husbands. Among other Āryan practices which Basavacondemned was cremation, and his followers r still usually buried. It ispossible that he was influenced by what he had heard of Islam. TheLingāyats still retain their individuality, though they hv nowcompromised with orthodoxy in some respects, and r an important sect inparts of Hyderabad and Mysore. Their sacred literature is mainly inCanarese and Telugu.

## Hindu Rites and Ceremonies
Whereas basic rite of Vedic religion was sacrifice ( yajña), that ofHinduism is worship ( pūjā). In general god is worshipped in form ofan icon (arcā), which has been sanctified by special rites, after which it isbelieved that divinity has in some sense taken up his abode in it. Thoughdevotees often ask for boons at feet of idol, pūjā is not so much anact of prayer as of homage and entertainment. god is offered water forwashing feet, flowers and betel quids, like an honoured guest. In themorning he is ceremonially awakened with sound of music, ringingof bells, and blowing of conches. He is washed, dried and dressed. He ishonoured with flowers, garlands, incense and swinging lamps; he is fed,usually with rice and fruit, of which he eats subtle part, [Page 336]leaving gross material food for his worshippers, or to be given to thepoor. In many temples he is taken to his bedroom at night, where he joinshis wife or wives. In larger shrines he is fanned by attendants andentertained by dancing girls like any ancient Indian king. On festival dayshe tours city in splendid car, often pulled by his devotees, followed bylesser gods in their cars, musicians, bearers of yak’s-tail flywhisks ( cauri),parasols and fans, and dancers.

The temple originated as small wooden hut, enshrining rough icon orfetish, and by Gupta times India was probably as much land of temples asshe is at present. heart of temple was central shrine, home ofthe chief divinity. Usually “tank” or flight of steps leading down to ariver adjoined temple, for ritual ablution, important at all times, had bynow become an essential part of religious observance. temple mightalso contain meeting hall, where Epics, Puranas, and other non-Vedicsacred literature were recited for all who wished to listen, and rest-housefor pilgrims was also often provided, as well as many other offices andannexes, some of which served social needs of people.

Congregational worship of Christian or Islamic type was unknown inearly Hinduism, though it developed in few medieval sects. Theworshipper went to temple either alone or in family group, made hisofferings, and departed. In greater temples acts of worshipperformed by regular officiants might be watched by large number ofpeople, but they were rather an audience than congregation.

Though formal animal sacrifices of Vedic period graduallydisappeared, new type of bloody sacrifice, almost certainly adopted fromthe non-Āryan aboriginals, became popular in Middle Ages. Such ritesrarely if ever took place in Vaisnavite sects, but some Śaivites and manydevotees of Durga adopted new type of sacrifice. animals were nolonger killed with complicated ritual, but decapitated before sacred icon,in such way that some of blood fell on it. ritual slaughter ofanimals was justified by doctrine that soul of victim wentstraight to heaven, but it was not approved by best minds of times,and its survival in Bengal and elsewhere is matter of shame to mostmodern Hindus.

Favourite animals for sacrifice were buffaloes, goats, sheep and cockerels. Human sacrifice was also practised. Theoretically execution of every criminal was sort of sacrifice, and his soul was thought to be purged of guilt. victims of human sacrifice were thus often criminalsprovided by secular arm, but victims were also obtained by moredubious means. We read of girls being kidnapped to serve as humansacrifices in secret rites, and of temple of [Page 337] Durga at which adaily human sacrifice was offered. Voluntary human sacrifice, or religioussuicide’ in various forms, became quite common in Middle Ages,especially in Deccan, where numerous inscriptions commemorate themany pious souls who, in fulfilment of vows, or to ensure success oftheir king, leapt from pillars and broke their necks, cut their own throats, ordrowned themselves in sacred river. last rite of sati was, in oneaspect, human sacrifice.

Another form of religious ceremony was that practised by sects whichworshipped feminine divinities. These sects r generally known as tantric(from their scriptures, called tantras), saktic (from their worship of sakti,or personified energy of god), or “left-hand” (from fact that thegoddess sits on left of her lord). Their members believed that usualHindu rites and ceremonies, though not wholly ineffectual, were onlysuitable for ordinary worshippers of goddess; adepts, who hadundergone long rites of initiation, practised other ceremonies of muchgreater efficiency, similar to those of Buddhists of “Vehicle of theThunderbolt” (p. 280f). tantric rites involved breaking of all theusual taboos of Hinduism. Small groups of initiates met at night, often in atemple or private house, but also frequently in burning-ground, among thebones of dead. group formed circle, seated around thecircumference of large circular magical diagram (yantra, maṇḍdala)drawn on ground. Though members of circle might includebrāhmaṇs and outcastes, there was no class distinction at ceremony-allwere equal, and no ritual pollution occurred from their contact. Afterregular evening worship, propitiation of ghosts, and other rites, thegroup would indulge in five Ms ( panca-makara): madya (alcoholicdrink), māmsa (meat), matsya (fish), mudrā (symbolical hand gestures,known in other branches of Indian religion, and in dance and drama, p.

385), and maithuna (sexual intercourse). rites concluded with the


worship of five elements, to which five Ms mysteriouslycorresponded. Among some tantric groups last of five Ms involvedpromiscuous copulation, while members of others brought their wives tothe circle. With yet other groups those rites which were reprehensible toorthodoxy were performed only symbolically.The remarkable “black mass” of tantric sects, whether in Buddhismor Hinduism, became very popular in Eastern India in late medievalperiod. It is still sometimes practised, but quite without publicity, and it isprobable that with growth of puritanism and rationalism, number oftantric groups in India is now very small indeed.

[Page 338]
## Hindu Ethics
At bottom of most Hindu writing on ethics and morality lay concept of three ends of life (p. 170), and full recognition that individuals of different classes and ages had different duties and standardsof conduct. ascetic should set his whole mind on unworldly things, butthe layman was encouraged to blend claims of religion, profession andmaterial pleasure into harmonious whole. This aspect of Hindu moralitywe hv touched on already in other contexts and need not discuss further.

To uninitiated Westerner usual moral attitude of Hinduism,especially before great changes of modern times, must seem strangemixture of reason and taboo. following passage, taken from theMānasollāsa, text on duties and amusements of kings attributed to the12th-century Deccan king Somesvara III Calukya, illustrates perfectly thisaspect of Hindu morals.

“A king should avoid (1) untruth and (2) treachery, (3) illicit
inter
course with women, and (4) eating what is forbidden.

“He should shun (5) envy and (6) contact with outcastes, he
should (7)
revere all gods, and satisfy (8) cows and (9) brahmans,
“(10) reverence his ancestors, and (11) feed his guests, (12)
obey his
preceptors, (13) practise penance, and (14) bathe in sacred
waters.

“He should (15) nourish poor, and (16) orphan and
widow,
(17) afflicted, and (18) his kin, and (19) his servants,
“and (20) protect those who come to him for refuge.

These r twenty conditions of successful reign.” 77 This passage shows that great emphasis was placed on such virtues ashospitality, charity and honesty, but piety, in sense of performance ofsuch religious acts as worship, pilgrimage, and feeding of cows andbrahmans, was equally if not more important. maintenance of taboos oncontact with untouchables and eating forbidden food (not only meat, butfood handled by low-caste persons or left over from previous meal) wasnot clearly distinguished from honesty and self-control. At all times,however, more intelligent teachers realized that mere outwardobservance was not as meritorious as inner goodness. Thus in lawbookof Gautama, after catalogue of forty religious rites which Āryanshould practice, we read:
“There r eight virtues of soul-compassion for all beings, patience, contentedness, purity, earnest endeavour, good thoughts, freedom from greed, and freedom from envy. Whoever performs sacred rites without possessing these eight virtues does not come to Brahmā or to his heaven; but if man has performed only one rite and has all eight good qualities he comes to Brahmā.”78
[Page 339] Many other sources give lists of virtues like this, all tending to encourage an earnest kindliness and tolerance in human relations. doctrine of non-violence, qualified though it was, had real effect on Hindu life, going far beyond mere restrictions on killing of animals. All Hindutexts teach mercy, compassion and friendliness, but positive benevolence,except in form of almsgiving, is less prominent, though often amonglists of virtues we find “desire for welfare of all beings”. positiveethic of love and forgiveness is feature of much Tamil sacred literature.

We quote from maxims of early Tirukkural:
“Men without love think only of self,
but loving strip themselves to bone for others.”
“For kindness done without expecting reward
heaven and earth r hardly sufficient recompense.”
“The joy of avenger lasts but day.

The joy of peacemaker lasts forever.”
“They r great who fast and do penance,
but they who forgive wrongs r even greater.”
“This, they say, is highest wisdom—
to return no harm to dm that harm you.” 79
This exalted ethical tone is to be found in much Tamil literature,
notably in Nāladiyār, collection of moral verses of somewhat
later date than Tirukkural, and in devotional hymns which we
have quoted elsewhere. But it is not only in Tamil literature that we
find call to love and kindness.

“Visnu is most pleased with him who does good to others,
who never utters abuse, calumny or untruth,
who never covets another’s wife or wealth,
and who bears ill will to none,
who neither beats nor slays any living thing,
who is ever diligent in service of gods
and of brāhmans and his teachers,
who always desires welfare of all creatures,
as of his children and of his own soul.”80
If general ethical outlook of Hinduism favoured tolerance and kindliness, it was not equalitarian, and recognized needs of society divided into many sections and classes with varied functions. man’s relations with his social inferiors should naturally differ from his relations with his betters. His standards of conduct differed [Page 340] acc to his own social class. virtues of brāhman, such as recitation of Veda, were sin to śūdra, while śūdra might legitimately do things, such as drinking spirits, which were forbidden to brāhman.Similarly child, student, householder and ascetic, had theirown codes and standards. Certain broad principles applied to all sections ofthe community, but beyond these no detailed code of morality wasuniversally binding. Each group had its own rules of conduct, varyingwidely.

It is with this background in view that we must read most famous ethical text of ancient India, Bhagavad Gītā. Though this work containsmuch theology, its kernel is ethical, and its teaching is set in frameworkof an ethical problem. hero Arjuna awaits in his chariot beginningof battle. In ranks of enemy r his old friends, relatives andteachers, men whom he has known and loved all his life. Though convincedof justice of his cause his spirits begin to sink, and he feels that hecannot fight against those who r so dear to him. He turns to Kṛsna, who isacting as his charioteer, and asks his advice. Kṛsna first explains that thedeath of body does not involve death of soul and iscomparatively unimportant:
“He who thinks this [soul] is slayer
and he who thinks this is slain
do not understand.

It neither slays nor is it slain.

“It is never born and never dies,
nor, once it exists, does it cease to be.

Unborn, eternal, abiding and ancient,
it is not slain when body is slain…
“As man puts off his worn out clothes
and puts on other new ones,
so embodied puts off worn out bodies
and goes to others that r new.

“Weapons do not cleave it,
fire does not burn it,
waters do not wet it,
wind does not dry it.

“It cannot be cleft or burnt,
or wetted or dried.

It is everlasting, it dwells in all things,
firm, unmoving, eternal….

[Page 341] “To be born is certain death,
to dead, birth is certain.

It is not right that you should sorrow
for what cannot be avoided….

“If you do not fight this just battleyou will fail in your own lawand in your honour,and you will incur sin.” 81Then Kṛsna develops his teaching on topic of human activity. Theright course is not inactivity of meditating sage, for this attempt toput works on one side is impossible and futile. God him self is continuallyactive, and man also should act; but, as far as possible, he should actwithout attachment, without personal desires or ambition. He must fulfil hisfunction in society of which he is member, doing all things for theglory of God.

“There is nothing in three worlds which I need,
nothing I do not own,
nothing which I must get—
and yet I labour forever.

“If I did not always work unwearying …
men would follow my ways.

The worlds would perish if I did not work—
I should bring back chaos, and all beings would suffer.

“So, as unwise work with attachment,
the wise should work without attachment,
O son of Bharata,
and seek to establish order in world….

“Cast all your acts upon me,
with your mind on Highest Soul.

Have done with craving and selfhood.

Throw off your terror, and fight!…
“For there is more joy in doing one’s own duty badly
than in doing another man’s duty well.

It is joy to die in doing one’s duty,but doing another man’s duty brings dread.”82The teaching of Bhagavad Gītā is summed up on maxim “yourbusiness is with deed, and not with result”. In an organized societyeach individual has his special part to play, and in every circumstance thereare actions which r intrinsically right— from point of view of poetwho wrote Gītā they r those [Page 342] laid down by Sacred Lawof Aryans and traditions of class and clan. right course must bechosen acc to circumstances, without any considerations ofpersonal interest or sentiment. Thus man serves God, and in so far as helives up to this ideal he draws near to God.

The stern ethics of Gītā r clearly intended as defence of old established order against attacks of reformers and unbelievers. virtue of brāhman is wisdom, of warrior, valour, of vaiśya,industry, of śūdra, service; by fulfilling his class function to best ofhis ability, with devotion to God and without personal ambition, man willfind salvation, whatever his class. It may be that author of Gītāsought merely to convey this message, rather barren and uninspiring when thus condensed. But behind his teaching was fervour of great religiouspoet, which transcended narrow framework of contemporary social andreligious law. Hence inspiration of Bhagavad Gītā has been widelyfelt in India from time of Guptas to present day, and it has beencommended by Christians and Muslims, as well as by Hindus, whosemost influential scripture it is. No one has so ungrudgingly admitted hisdebt to its doctrine of tireless and unselfish service as Mahatma Gāndhī,who so strongly opposed two features of ancient Indian society whichthe Gītā itself was in part written to defend—militarism and classsystem.

## (v) NON-INDIAN RELIGIONS
If we r to believe very old tradition first Christian converts in India were made by Disciple Thomas himself, soon after Crucifixion. Indian king Gondophernes sent to Syria for skilful architect to build him new city, and envoy returned with St. Thomas, who told king of City not made with hands, and converted him and many members of his court. St. Thomas afterwards preached in other partsof India, and died martyr’s death at hands of king called in Christiantradition Misdeos, who cannot be identified. historicity ofGondophernes, however, is unquestioned (p. 60), and story in its mainoutline is not impossible, for at time contact between India and Westwas close, and an enterprising missionary could easily hv travelled fromPalestine to India. Roman Catholics believe that tomb of St. Thomas isto be found in cathedral at Mailapur, suburb of Madras, though theevidence for Saint’s martyrdom there is not sufficient to satisfy thehistorian.

Several rather unreliable references to other early missions [Page 343]exist in church tradition, but first certain evidence of Christian activityin India is found in “Christian Topography” of Cosmas Indicopleustes,an adventurous Alexandrian monk of 6th century, who left an account ofhis travels. He states that there were churches in Malabar and Ceylon, in thehands of Persian priests, and supervised by Persian bishop at Kalliana(perhaps modern Cochin). It is clear that Indian Christians hadembraced Nestorian heresy, which was then widespread in Persia. TheNestorians were active missionaries, and their intrepid monks even crossedthe wastes of Central Asia and founded successful churches in China.

Whatever truth there may be in legend of St. Thomas, it seems that these missionaries, no doubt following in wake of Persian merchants,were chiefly responsible for establishing Christian community in SouthIndia. When, at later date, Islam stamped out both Zoroastrianism andChristianity in Persia, Indian Christians turned for guidance to thepatriarch of Antioch, and has maintained contact with Syria to this day.

When European travellers again visited India they noticed Christianchurches of South. Marco Polo, at end of 13th century, saw thetomb of St. Thomas, and remarked on its popularity as place ofpilgrimage. But Syrian church was corrupt. There is no evidence thatIndian Christians ever accepted doctrine of transmigration, but manyHindu customs had been adopted, and Malabar Christians, like theBuddhists and Jainas before them, were in process of becoming ratherheterodox Hindu sect. Jesuit missionaries of 16th and 17th centuriessucceeded in preventing further decadence. One section of Syrianchurch in India accepted authority of Rome, while other, whichremained true to Antioch, reformed and purified itself.

It is in this connexion that we find first record of an Englishmanvisiting India. Anglo-Saxon Chronicle states that in A.D. 884 KingAlfred, to fulfil vow, sent an envoy to India with rich gifts for tomb ofSt. Thomas. Florence of Worcester, writing some 200 years later, adds thatthe name of envoy was Swithelm, and that he returned safely. Williamof Malmesbury, on other hand, gives his name as Bishop Sigelinus, and states that he brought back rich present of jewels and spices from localIndian king, who, if story is true, must hv been Cōla King Āditya Ior one of his chiefs. Anglo-Saxon Chronicle is generally reliable, and itis reasonable to believe that Alfred sent envoy, but “India” for 9thcentury Europe was very loose term, embracing many vaguely knownparts of Asia and Africa, and we cannot be sure that envoy actuallyvisited tomb of St. Thomas at Mailapur, or even that it [Page 344] wasin existence at time. discrepancy in names given to envoy bythe two later chroniclers shows that tradition was not vividlyremembered, and adds to our suspicion.

On other hand we know that Christian pilgrims undertook verydifficult journeys in order to visit holy places. At time Islam was notviolently anti-Christian, and pilgrim might hv found his way acrossEgypt without difficulty, and thence in an Arab merchant vessel to SouthIndia. It is pleasant to picture brave English cleric, whatever his name,telling Cōla king through Arab and Tamil interpreters of King Alfred’sbattles with Danes, and King Alfred, several years later, listening to theenvoy’s account of wonders of India and sampling rare spices of theTamil land. Whatever our doubts, we cannot but hope that story ofBishop Sigelinus is true one.

As well as Christians small communities of Jews settled in Malabar. Theearliest certain reference to this community is 10thcentury charter bywhich king of Ceras, Bhaskara Ravivarman, gave lands andprivileges to Jew named Joseph Rabbān; but tradition of Jews ofMalabar tells of large settlement at Cochin in 1st century A.D. In anycase small Jewish community has existed in India for well over amillennium. One branch has mixed closely with local Malayālīinhabitants and its members now hv typical Indian complexions andfeatures; other branch retains its racial purity, and is still evidentlySemitic.

Another non-Indian religious community was that of Zoroastrians,now generally known as Pārsīs. Under Achæmenid and Sasanian emperorsZoroastrianism was certainly practised in parts of N.-W. India, and hadsome influence on Hinduism and Buddhism, but no very clear traces of aZoroastrian community hv survived there. Though Zoroastrian merchantsfrom Persia may hv settled on west coast of India very early, we haveno record of dm until after Arab conquest of Persia, when Zoroastrianrefugees came to India in appreciable numbers. acc to Pārsīs’own traditions one band of refugees settled first at Diu in Kathiawar, andthen at Thana, near Bombay, in early 8th century.

Yet another community was that of Muslims. Arabs visited India longbefore days of Muhammad, and there is evidence of small Muslimcommunities in many of coastal towns of Peninsula from 8thcentury onwards. Mappila (Moplah) community of Malabar isundoubtedly descended from settlers and converts of long before daysof Muslim invasion of India. There is, however, no clear evidence of anyinfluence of Islam on Hinduism until after Muslim conquest.

## PILATE LXVIII
[Page 345] Thus India, though always loyal to her indigenous cults, gave welcome to those of West. If we except uncertain tradition of St.Thomas’ martyrdom there is no good evidence of persecution of any of these non-Indian sects. Their members quietly pursued their own cults,small but significant elements in religious life of coastal cities, whilethe great body of Hindus were scarcely aware of alien faiths, and in noway antagonistic to them. This capacity for toleration contributed to thecharacteristic resiliency of Hinduism, and helped to assure its survival.
