VIII
THE ARTS: ARCHITECTURE, SCULPTURE,
PAINTING, MUSIC AND DANCE


## SPIRIT OF INDIAN ART
[Page 346]
NEARLY all artistic remains of ancient India r of religious nature, or were at least made for religious purposes. Secular art certainly existed, for literature shows that kings dwelt in sumptuous palaces, decorated withlovely wall-paintings and sculpture, though all these hv vanished. Muchhas been said and written about Indian art since, some forty years ago,European taste began to doubt established canons of 19th centuryand looked to Asia and Africa for fresh æsthetic experience. Since thenmost authorities on subject, Indian and European alike, hv stressed thereligious and mystical aspect of Indian art. While admitting realism andearthiness of earliest sculpture, most critics hv read truths ofVedanta or Buddhism into artistic remains of our period, and haveinterpreted dm as expressions of deep religious experience, sermons instone on oneness of all things in Universal Spirit.1One student at least disagrees with this interpretation. There r indeed afew remains which seem imbued with an intensity of religious feeling rarein art of world, but it is full and active life of times which ischiefly reflected in art of ancient India, at first directly, as at Bhārhut,Sānchī and Amarāvatī, then with gentle idealism, as at Ajanta, and finallyin multitude of figures, divine and human, carved on many templesof Middle Ages. In all these phases there is horror vacui and anintense vitality which remind us rather of this world than next, andsuggest to us warm bustle of Indian city and turbulent pullulationof Indian forest.

Gothic architecture and sculpture r vertical. Spire and arch pointupward, and as style develops spire becomes taller and archmore pointed. Christs, saints and angels of Middle Ages in Europeare often disproportionately tall, and their tallness is accentuated by longgarments reaching to ankles. Their poses r generally restful, and theyrarely smile. Medieval European art was truly religious; its conventionsseem to hv been [Page 347] deliberately designed to lead theworshipper’s thoughts away from world of flesh to things of thespirit. Much of it was work of pious monks, or of men with deepreligious vocations.

The tendency of Indian art is diametrically opposite to that of medievalEurope. temple towers, though tall, r solidly based on earth. Theideal type is not abnormally tall, but rather short and stocky. Gods anddemigods alike r young and handsome; their bodies r rounded and well-nourished, often by European standards rather effeminate. Occasionallythey r depicted as grim or wrathful, but generally they smile, and sorrowis rarely portrayed. With exception of type of dancing Śiva thesacred icon is always firmly grounded, either seated or with both feet flat onthe ground. We need hardly mention that all Indian temple sculpture, Hindu,Buddhist and Jaina alike, made full use of female form as decorativemotif, always scantily dressed, and nearly always in accordance with Indianstandards of beauty.Asceticism and self-denial in various forms r praised in much Indianreligious literature, but ascetics who appear in sculpture r llusuay wellfed and cheerful. As an example we may cite colossal rock-cut medievalimage of Jaina saint Gommateśvara (pl. LIX) at Śravana Belgolā inMysore. He stands bolt upright in posture of meditation known askĀyotsarga, with feet firm on earth, and arms held downwards but nottouching body, and he smiles faintly. artist must hv tried toexpress soul almost set free from trammels of matter, and about toleave for its final resting place of everlasting bliss at top of universe.Whatever intentions of artist, however, Gommatesvara is still anordinary young man of his time, full of calm vitality. saint is said tohave stood for so long in meditation that creepers twined round hismotionless legs, and these r shown in sculpture; but, though intendedto portray his sanctity, they do but emphasize that he is creature of theearth whom earth pulls back.

Ancient India’s religious art differs strikingly from her religiousliterature. latter is work of men with vocations, brahmans, monksand ascetics. former came chiefly from hands of secular craftsmen,who, though they worked acc to priestly instructions and increasinglyrigid iconographical rules, loved world they knew with an intensitywhich is usually to be seen behind religious forms in which theyexpressed themselves. In our opinion usual inspiration of Indian art isnot so much ceaseless quest for Absolute as delight in world asthe artist found it, sensual vitality, and feeling of growth and movementas regular and organic as growth of living things upon earth.



## EARLIEST ARCHITECTURE
[Page 348] Of visual arts of ancient and medieval India much architecture and sculpture and little painting hv survived. As most of existing sculpture was intended to be ancillary to architecture we deal with latter first.k

The utilitarian brick buildings of Harappā Culture, strong and competent though they were, had apparently little æsthetic merit, and will not be mentioned here. With exception of walls of Rajagrha (p. 198),which also hv no artistic value, we hv no significant architecturalremains between Harappā period and that of Mauryas. This was dueto fact that few if any buildings were made of stone during this time.Megasthenes mentions that palace of Candragupta Maurya, thoughvery large and luxurious, was built of carved and gilded wood, and theearliest stone buildings to hv survived were evidently modelled onwooden originals. We must not assume, from complete lack of materialremains, that Indian building in Mauryan period, or even before, wasmean or primitive. Mauryan monolithic columns prove that thecraftsmen of those days had thorough mastery of working in stone, and ifthe great cities of Mauryan times were built of wood we must attribute thischiefly to comparative scarceness of stone in Gangetic Plain and theabundance of timber where it is now scarce. There is no evidence of acultural advance in Middle Ages, when building in stone becamecommon, but rather of decline. adoption of stone as buildingmedium was due partly to foreign contacts, but also to gradualdisappearance of timber forests from more populous and civilizedregions of India.

The wonderful Mauryan columns with their finely carved capitals fall rather under head of sculpture than of architecture, for most of thosewhich survive had no architectural purpose. Fragments of similar columns,found at Patna, supported roof of palace, which has been reasonablyidentified as that of Aśoka. remains of Patna pillared hall r sofragmentary that plan of building cannot be accuratelyreconstructed, but it was evidently large one. At this time, however, stonebuildings must still hv been very rare. All Mauryan pillars and otherproducts of Mauryan stonemasons come from same quarry, at Chunar,not far from Banāras, and all bear stamp of same school. They arethe work of craftsmen who had learnt much from Persia, and perhaps littlefrom Greece, but had given their output distinctive Indian characteristics.

Their workshops were probably maintained by Mauryan kings, and [Page 349] vanished with dynasty. Working in stone had then to make new beginning in India.

## STŪPA
The stupa began as an earthen burial mound, which was revered by local population, and we hv seen that cult of stūpas was taken up byBuddhism, and that Aśoka raised stūpas in Buddha’s honour all overIndia (p. 263). Only one stūpa, in Nepal, survives in form in which thegreat emperor left it, but excavations of existing stūpas hv shown thecharacter of earlier ones. They were large hemispherical domes,containing central chamber, in which relics of Buddha were placedin small casket, often beautifully carved in crystal. core of stūpawas of unburnt brick, and outer face of burnt brick, covered with thicklayer of plaster. stūpa was crowned by an umbrella of wood or stone,and was surrounded by wooden fence enclosing path for ceremonialclockwise circumambulation ( pradaksind), which was chief form ofreverence paid to relics within it. 1In period between Mauryas and Guptas much wealth andenergy were spent on Buddhist architecture, and older stilpas weregreatly enlarged and beautified. Of these three r specially noteworthy-those at Bhārhut in Madhya Bharat, Sānchī in old Bhopal state, andAmarāvatī in lower Kīstna Valley. Bhārhut stupa, perhaps in itspresent form dating from middle of 2nd century B.C., is importantchiefly for its sculpture, and stūpa itself has now vanished. That atSānchī, on other hand, is one of most striking architectural remainsof ancient India (pl. XIb).In 2nd century B.C. old Sānchī stūpa was enlarged to twice itsoriginal size, becoming hemisphere of about 120 feet in diameter. It wasthen faced with well-cut masonry laid in regular courses, and, besides thelower path on ground level, an upper terraced path some 16 feet from theground was added. old wooden railings were replaced by stone ones 9feet high, tenoned and mortised in imitation of carpentry. Finally, towardsthe end of 1st century B.C., four glorious gateways ( torana) were addedat four cardinal points. Lesser stūpas and monastic buildings surroundedthe great stūpa (fig. xviii).


The Sānchī gateways (pl. XXVII) r perhaps more noteworthy [Page 350] for their carved ornamentation than their architecture. Each consists of two square columns, above which r three curved architraves supported by animals or dwarfs, whole reaching some 34 feet above ground-level.

The construction of these gateways, from technical point of view, isprimitive, and it has been suggested that their design is based on log orbamboo portcullis of ancient Indian village.3 finish, on otherhand, is remarkably good, and carvings r among most fresh andvigorous products of Indian sculptor (pl. XXVIII).In respect of size few Indian stūpas greatly exceeded that of Sanchl, butin Ceylon stūpa reached tremendous proportions. AbhayagiriDagaba at Anuradhapura, capital of early kings of Ceylon, was 327feet in diameter, and larger than some of pyramids of Egypt. It reachedits present size, after succession of enlargements, in 2nd century A.D.Fig. xviii. stūpas and Monasteries at Sānchī. (Reproduced from Percy Brown’s “IndianArchitecture (Buddhist and Hindu)”, published by D. B. Taraporevala Sons & Co. Ltd., Bombay)In India stūpa architecture became more and more ornate. stūpa ofAmarāvatī (fig. xix), which in its final form was completed c. 200 A.D., waslarger than that of Sānchī, and its two promenades were adorned withcarved panels (some of which cn be seen in British Museum) tellingthe story of life of Buddha. Meanwhile in Northern India stūpasgrew taller in proportion to their bases. They were often set on square

platforms, which in Burma and Indonesia were developed into stepped pyramids, largest of which [Page 351] is enormous stūpa of Borobodūr, in Java, built in 8th century A.D. Pinnacles became higher, and developed towards spiring forms of present-day temples of Burma and Siam.  Of later Indian stūpas two most famous r those of Sarnath andNālandā. tall stūpa of Sarnath (pl. XIIa), near Banāras, scene of theBuddha’s first sermon, of which now little more than inner coreremains, was once most imposing structure of beautifully patternedbrickwork with high cylindrical upper dome rising from lowerhemispherical one, and large images of Buddha set in gable ends at thecardinal points. In its final form it dates from Gupta period. stūpa atNālandā (pl. XIIb), seven times successively enlarged, in its present ruinedstate gives impression of brick pyramid with steps leading up to itsterraces. It was originally tall stūpa raised on high base, with smallerstūpa at each corner, but monument underwent so many alterations inGupta and Pāla times that it is now difficult for untrained eye torecognize its original form at any one stage of its development.Fig. xix.-The Stiipa of Amaravatl. (Reproduced from Percy Brown’s “Indian Achitecture(Buddhist and Hindu)”, published by D. B. Taraporevala Sons & Co. Ltd., Bombay)Around great stūpas were lesser ones, often containing ashes ofmonks famous for their piety and learning, and whole complex ofbuildings-monasteries, shrine-rooms, preaching halls and resthouses forpilgrims (fig. xviii). At greater Buddhist sites such as Nālandā thegroups of monastic buildings were often [Page 352] surrounded by fortress-like walls. In their present partial dilapidation these heavy domessometimes seem little forbidding. Originally limewashed or plasteredstūpa shone brilliantly white in tropical sunlight, its pinnacle, nowgenerally broken, rising like golden spear from ceremonial stoneumbrella on top of dome. Then it must hv given differentimpression. great Ruvanvili Dāaiba at Anuradhapura in Ceylon, whichin recent years has been restored and is once more used in Buddhistworship, rising white in distance out of plain, shows stūpa at itsbest, as worthy emblem of great religion.

## CAVE TEMPLES
Of centuries before Gupta period chief architectural remains, other than stūpas and their surrounding gateways and railings, r artificialcaves, excavated for religious purposes. Early specimens show slavishimitation of carpentry which proves conclusively that art of building instone was still in its infancy. Thus two of caves of Barabar Hill, nearGayā, dedicated by Aśoka to Ājīvika monks, r in form of plainrectangular outer hall, at one end of which is an inner chamber with acurved wall and overhanging eaves. caves were evidently substitutedfor standardized religious meeting place consisting of round thatchedhut standing in courtyard, and their designer could not transcend thepattern to which he had been used. Similar dependence on wooden modelsis evident in many other features of design until Gupta period.

The caves of Barabar and Nāgārjunī Hills r quite unadorned, with exception of one at Nāgārjunī, near Barabar, which has comparatively simple carved entrance, added during or soon after Mauryan period. Theinner walls of all caves r finely polished, no doubt by workmen of theschool which was responsible for polish of Aśokan columns.Later cave temples and monasteries r to be found in many parts ofIndia, but it was in Western Deccan, under Satavahana Empire andits successors, that largest and most famous artificial caves wereexcavated. oldest Deccan cave, at Bhaja, near Poona, consists of deepapsidal hall, cut in solid rock, with row of plain octagonal pillars near thewalls, which support curved ribs carved to represent barrel vaulting of awooden building. At further end of hall is small stūpa, also cutfrom solid rock, and outside of cave has facade, carved like agable, with smaller ornamental gables on either side. Beside this cave,which was meeting hall for Buddhist monks and lay worshippers, is asecond cave [Page 353] consisting of broad cutting into rock, leadingto five cells, which were dwellings of monks.

From these beginnings cave temples developed in size and splendour.The finest single example is great caitya hall at Karli (pl. XIII),probably made about beginning of Christian era. This is cut 124 feetdeep into rock, and is of same general pattern as that at Bhājā andmany other caves of Western Deccan, but much developed in size andsplendour. columns r no longer plain and austere, but, by processwhich cn be traced through earlier stages, they hv become heavy andornate. Each is set on square stepped plinth, and rises from bulbousbase, which is carved to represent large pot with base and rim; this is
another survival of wooden construction, for octagonal wooden pillarsof earlier days were bedded in large earthenware pots [Page 354] to protectthem from ants and other insects. Each pillar carries complicated group ofhorses and elephants with riders to support roof, which is carved inimitation of timber rafters of barrel vaulting. caitya or shrine at theend of hall is much enlarged in comparison with those of other caves.


Fig. xx.-Early Capitals. (Reproduced from Percy Brown’s “Indian Architecture (Buddhist and Hindu)”, published by D. B. Taraporevala Sons & Co. Ltd., Bombay)

The simple facades of earlier caves were developed into elaborately carved verandas, usually with large window, full size of gable-end, which let light into hall (pl. XIVa). Karli cave has three fine entrances, and frieze of relief sculpture on lower levels, with small carved gable-ends above.

With caitya halls associated rock-cut monasteries or sanhārāmasalso developed in size and splendour. As cave monastery became toosmall for its inhabitants new cave was cut nearby and so complex ofcaves grew over centuries. most famous of these cave groups is thatof Ajanta, in north-west corner of Hyderābād. Here no less than twenty-seven caves, some going 100 feet deep into rock, were excavated in thehorseshoe curve of hillside, not far from great trade route leading fromthe North to Deccan (pl. XIV). earliest caves date from 2ndcentury B.C., while others r as late as 7th century A.D. splendidsculpture and lovely paintings with which they r adorned make dm oneof most glorious monuments of India’s past (p. 377f).

Perhaps even more impressive r later cave temples of Ellora, near Aurangabad, some thirty miles from Ajanta. Here r no less than thirty-four caves, constructed from 5th to 8th centuries A.D., most of themHindu but some Buddhist and Jaina. crowning achievement of Ellora isthe great Kailasanatha Temple, excavated on instructions of theRāstrakūta emperor Kīstna I (c. A.D. 756–773). With this concept of thecave temple was transcended, for king was not satisfied with merehollow in rock. entire rock face was cut away and splendid templecarved like statue from hillside, complete with shrineroom, hall,gateway, votive pillars, lesser shrines and cloisters, whole adorned withdivine figures and scenes large and small of grace and strength rarely seenagain in Indian art (pl. XV). ground plan of Kailasanatha is of about thesame size as Parthenon, and it is half as high again. labournecessary to construct it, however, was less than that which would berequired to build comparable temple of masonry, for transport created noproblem, and process of construction, beginning at top of cliffand working down to base, avoided need of scaffolding. But noconsiderations of this kind cn disparage glory of [Page 355]Kailasanatha, “the most stupendous single work of art executed in India “.4Kailasanatha is not earliest temple hewn from solid rock. Others areto be found at Mamallapuram, on sea-coast some thirty miles south ofMadras, where seventeen temples, none very large in size, were carvedfrom outcropping hillocks of granite under patronage of 7th centuryPallava kings. most famous of these, “Seven Pagodas”, still showthe influence of wood construction, and r of distinctive style, possiblylooking back to Dravidian prototypes.

The latest cave-temples of importance r those of Elephanta, beautiful
little island off Bombay. These, in same style as those of Ellora, arefamous for their sculpture, especially for great Trimūrti figure of Śiva(p. 372). After these no important caves were excavated. Indians had longknown art of building in stone. Kailasanatha Temple, carved inexact imitation of masonry, showed dissatisfaction with older caveform. great period of medieval temple building had begun.

## TEMPLES
The earliest free-standing religious building of which traces remain is small round hall, probably originally containing Buddhist stūpa, at Bairat near Jaipur; this dates from 3rd century B.C., and was made of brick and wood; little but foundations now exist, and form had no future.

The next landmark in temple architecture is temple generally known,
from modern name of site, as that of Jandiāl, excavated from one of
the mounds which covered city of Taksasila. This, one of importantbuildings of Greek city, contained square inner sanctuary, meetinghall and courtyard, and its outer and inner entrances were each flanked bytwo large pillars of orthodox Ionian pattern. Jandial temple wasprobably Zoroastrian, and had no direct successors, but influence ofWestern architecture is clearly to be seen in Kashmir, where columns ofHellenic type were used throughout medieval period, in conjunctionwith distinctive pyramidal roofs and arches surmounted by pointed gables,which give Kashmīr style an almost Gothic appearance. Most famous ofKashmīr’s early temples is Temple of Sun at Martand, dating fromthe 8th century. There r no remains of free-standing Hindu templeserected before Gupta period, though by this time they must long havebeen built in wood, clay and brick. From Gupta period, however, severalexamples survive, chiefly in Western [Page 356] India, all showing thesame general pattern. Pillars were usually ornate, with heavy bell-shapedcapitals surmounted by animal motifs, and entrances were often carvedwith mythological scenes and figures. All Gupta temples were small,and most had flat roofs. Their masonry was held together without mortar,and was far larger and thicker than was necessary for comparativelysmall buildings. Evidently their builders had not yet fully mastered theirtechnique, and were still thinking in terms of cave. finest Guptatemple, that of Deogarh near Jhānsī, probably of 6th century, marks agreat advance. Here iron dowels were used to hold masonry together,and small tower rose above sanctum. portal veranda wascontinued all round building, making covered walk.The standard type of Hindu temple, which has persisted from 6thcentury to present day, was not fundamentally different from that of theancient Greeks. heart of temple was small dark shrine-room( garbhagrha), containing chief icon. This opened on hall forworshippers ( mandapa), originally separate building, but usually joined tothe shrine-room by vestibule ( antarāla). hall was approached by aporch ( ardhamandapa). shrine-room was generally surmounted by atower, while lesser towers rose from other parts of building. wholewas set in rectangular courtyard, which might contain lesser shrines, andwas often placed on raised platform.

The medieval period in India was, like Middle Ages in Europe, an
age of faith. With better techniques of stone construction new temples
sprang up everywhere to replace earlier wooden buildings, and kings andchiefs vied with one another in their foundation. Strict canons of design inboth architecture and sculpture were laid down in textbooks ( silpasastra),some of which survive.5 technique of architecture was not faradvanced, despite great achievements of period. Though archesoccur in cave temples and in Kashmir, art of making true arch,dome or vault, seems to hv been ignored, although corbellingthe buildingup of an arch or dome by overlapping courses of brick or masonry-waswidely practised, and produced work of great beauty. Mortar was known,but rarely used, for style of archless and domeless architectureemployed made it virtually unnecessary.

The temple was ornately decorated, often even to dark shrineroomslighted only by flickering oil-lamps. Despite this ornateness theapprenticeship of his tradition in rock architecture gave architect astrong sense of mass. Heavy cornices, strong pillars, [Page 357] wide inproportion to their height, and broad base of śikhara, or tower, giveto Indian temple architecture feeling of strength and solidity, only in partcounteracted by delicately ornate friezes, and many figures in highor low relief which often fill whole surface of temple wall.Considering size of land, Indian temple architecture is remarkablyuniform, but authorities distinguish two chief styles and numerous schools.The Northern or Indo Āryan style prefers tower with rounded top andcurvilinear outline, while tower of Southern or Dravidian style isusually in shape of rectangular truncated pyramid. stages ofstylistic development r clearer in South than in North, where manyancient temples were destroyed by Muslim invaders. We thereforeconsider styles of Peninsula first.Temple building gained much from patronage of Pallava andCalukya kings in 6th-8th centuries. Important early temples of theformer dynasty r to be found at Mamallapuram, already referred to (p.355), and Kāñcī, while Calukyas left temple remains at their capitalBadami, and nearby site of Aihole, both in Hyderābād. Both styles showthe gradual emancipation of architect from techniques of carpentryand cave architecture. apogee of Pallava style was reached in theShore Temple at Mamallapuram (pl. XVIa) and Kailasanatha Temple ofKāñcī, built early in 8th century. latter has pyramidal towerformed of two courses of small barrel vaults, surmounted by solid cupolasuggesting Buddhist stūpa.

The style of Pallavas was developed further under C61a dynasty(10th-12th centuries), finest products of which r great temple ofŚiva at Tanjore, built by Rajaraja Great (985–1014), and temple builtby his successor, Rajendra I, at his new capital of Gangaikondacolapuram,near Kumbakonam. former was probably largest temple built inIndia up to that time; comparatively modest tower of Pallava stylewas replaced by great pyramid, rising from tall upright base andcrowned with domed finial, whole being nearly 200 feet high. This setthe style of Dravidian sikhara, which has continued with some variationdown to present day. Both these temples contain elaborate pillared hallsand beautiful decoration.

In next phase of Dravidian architecture emphasis shifted from the
tower above chief shrine to entrance gateway of surrounding
wall. Though there r few records of desecration of temples by
hostile sectarians or invaders, it is difficult to find practical reason for thegrowing custom of surrounding South Indian [Page 358] temples withstrong and high walls, unless this was done in imitation of palaces ofkings, with which temples had much in common. From 12th centuryonwards it became usual to fortify temple, often with three squareconcentric walls, with gates on four sides. gates were surmountedby watch-towers or gatehouses, and these developed into soaring towers( gopuram), generally much taller than modest sikhara over centralshrine. entrance tower was usually in form of an oblong pyramid,with its broadest side parallel to wall (pl. XIXa). new style is oftencalled Pāndyan, from name of dynasty which supplanted Cōlasin Tamil country, and kings of which were responsible for buildingwalls and gateway towers round many existing shrines. styleintroduced more elaborate ornamentation, and use of animal forms inpilasters and columns, including rampant horses and leogryphs whichgive distinctive character to late Dravidian architecture.

The culmination of Pandyan style lies in mighty temple
complexes of Madurai, Śrīranam, and elsewhere, which r strictly outside
our period, belonging in their present form to 17th century. greattemple of Madurai is most famous and beautiful of these (pl. XIXb), butthe largest is Vaisnavite temple of Srirangam (fig. xv, p. 201), which iscontained in an outer wall measuring 2,475 by 2,880 feet, and has six innerwalls, all with gopurams, surrounding shrine of comparatively modestproportions These later towers were covered with sculptured figures.

While these developments were taking place in Tamil country, other
styles developed in Deccan, under Calukyas, Rastrakutas and
Hoysalas. earliest Calukyan temples closely resemble Guptan instyle. By 8th century they had developed individual features, includingthe wide overhanging eaves which became characteristic of medievaltemples of Central Deccan. later Calukyas and Hoysalas (1 th-14thcenturies) developed more elaborate style. Their temples were no longerbuilt on rectangular plan, but were polygonal or stellate, raised on tallsolid platform of same shape as building. These temples give astrong feeling of flatness, for platforms and walls alike r covered withrather narrow carved friezes of elephants, horsemen, geese, monsters ( yāli),and scenes of mythology and legend (pl. XVII). grotesque mask( kīrtimukha) 2 became very common as decorative [Page 359] feature, andturned columns, often ornately carved, were widely used. largest andmost famous temples of this style, at Halebid (Dorasamudra, Hoysalacapital) and Bēlūr, hv no towers, and it is thought that they were notcompleted. Some smaller temples of same period hv towers, notablythe charming temple of Somnathpur (pl. XVIb), which has three low dome-like sikharas, their breadth emphasized by parallel mouldings. Its profusionof pillars, and its abhorrence not only of blank spaces but even of planesurfaces and straight lines, tend to give this style an impression ofweddingcake prettiness, despite solid proportions of its masonry and thebrilliance of its sculptured decoration.

The school which flourished under Vijayanagara empire, and reached
its apogee in 16th century, shows both Pandyan and Hoysala features.

The florid carving of Hoysalas was developed with even greaterexuberance, and new elements appeared in temple complex. As well asthe main shrine every important temple in South India was provided with ashrine for amman, god’s chief wife, which was often nearly as largeas main shrine itself, and marriage-hall ( kalyānamandapam), whereinthe icons of god and goddess were ceremonially united on festival days.

Another feature of Vijayanagara style is profusion of strong yet
delicate carving which adorns pillared halls, many columns of which
are so decorated that they become sculptures in their own right. Prancinghorses, vigorous and energetic, leap from stone (pl. XVIIIc), withleogryphs and other fantastic monsters. For brilliancy of decorativeimagination Vijayanagara style of architecture was never surpassed inHindu India. Its finest production is undoubtedly Vitthala Temple atHampi, old Vijayanagara.

In chief cities of Northern India almost all traces of architecture ofthe Hindu period hv vanished. Even in holy Banāras all great andfamous temples r comparatively recent. One important exception,however, is Buddhist temple at Gaya (pl. XXa) main tower of whichis probably as early as 6th century. This is large pyramid of brickwork,set on high plinth; it is adorned with parallel courses of “caitya window”pattern and is surmounted by lofty pinnacle which was originally smallstūpa. Similar towers existed in other Buddhist monastic establishments, buthave long since vanished. Gayā tower suggests rather Southern thanthe Northern style of śikhara, but other temples of period either hv notowers or hv small curvilinear ones which r evidently prototypes ofthe later Northern śikhara.

Medieval North Indian architecture is best illustrated by three [Page 360]
schools-those of Orissā, Bundelkhand, and Gujarat and South Rajasthan.


There were other local developments, as well as distinctive style of
Kashmīr which we hv already noted, but these three r certainly the
most important, and their products r best preserved.

The Orissan school flourished from 10th to 13th centuries, and its
chief monuments lie in and around towns of Bhubanesar and Purī. The
finest Orissān temple is Lingarūja at Bhubanesar (pl. XXb, fig. xxi),
which shows North Indian sikhara in its final form-a tower which
begins to curve inwards at about one third of its height, with rounded topcrowned by flat stone disc ( amalaka) and finial ( kalaśa). upwardmovement of this graceful curving tower is emphasized by deep verticalinlets, but its solidity and firm basis on earth r very evident. TheLingarāja, like most Orissan temples, is built as series of four halls-a hallof offerings, dancing hall, an assembly hall and sanctuary. 3 Thesanctuary is crowned by great tower, but other three elements of thetemple, leading one by one to shrine, r also roofed with characteristictowers of smaller size, carrying eye to main sikhara. wholetemple enclosure of Lihgaraja is filled with smaller shrines, built on thepattern of great one.

[Page 361] Orissan architects were lavish with their exteriordecoration, and their sculptors produced works of great merit, but theinteriors of their temples r unadorned. In larger temples corbelledroofs of halls rested on four large pilasters, but pillars were notgenerally used, and roofs were often partly supported by iron girders, astriking technical innovation.6Among most important Orissān temples r Temple of Visnu-Jagannatha at Purl, still one of most famous shrines of India, and the“Black Pagoda” of Konārak, built in 13th century. latter, templeof Sūrya, sun-god, was formerly one of largest and most splendidtemples of India, much larger than those of Bhubanesar (fig. xxii). Thetower, over 200 feet high, has long since fallen, but great assembly-hallremains. Unlike other temples of this region that of Konārak had thetwo smaller outer halls completely separate from main structure, andassembly-hall and tower were built on an imposing platform, round whichwere carved twelve decorated wheels, 10 feet in diameter (pl. XXIa). Theentrance is reached by broad flight of steps, flanked on either side byprancing horses, whole representing chariot in which sun-godrides across heavens. court of temple was decorated with largefree-standing sculptures of great strength and beauty (pls. LVII-III). Theexceptionally frank eroticism of many [Page 362] of Konārak sculptures has given “Black Pagoda” rather infamous reputation. Maithuna
figures, of couples closely embracing or actually in coitu, r commonenough as decorative features of many Indian temples, but those of Konārakare exceptionally vivid. Many suggestions hv been made as to truesignificance of these figures; it has been suggested that they merely servedthe mundane purpose of advertising charms of devadasis, or templeprostitutes, 7 or that they were intended to represent world of flesh, incontrast to bare and austere interior, which symbolized things of thespirit; probably they were connected, in minds of their designers, withthe sexual mysticism which played so great part in medieval Indianreligious thought. 8 No doubt temple of Konarak was centre of aflourishing tantric cult. 9


Fig. xxii.-Temple of Sun, Konārak, Orissā. (Reproduced from Percy Brown’s “Indian
Architecture (Buddhist and Hindu)”, published by D. B. Taraporevala Sons & Co. Ltd., Bombay)
Under Candella kings of Bundelkhand great school of architectureflourished in 10th and 11th centuries, chief work of which is abeautiful group of temples at Khajurāho, about 100 miles south-east ofJhānsī. These temples r built on rather different plan from those ofOrissā, and r not very large finest, ūaivite temple known asKandariya-Mahādeo, was built about A.D. 1000, and is not more than 100feet high. standard type of Khajurāho temple contains shrine-room orsanctuary, an assembly-hall, and an entrance portico. Whereas in theOrissān temple these elements were conceived rather as separate entitiesjoined together by vestibules, Khajurāho architects treated dm as awhole, and though each part has its own roof they r not structurallyseparate. Khaiuraho śikhara, like those of most Northern temples, iscurvilinear (pi. XXc), but differs fromthetype of Orissā. It is curved for itswhole length, and its upward thrust is accentuated by miniature sikharasemerging from central tower. crowning discsoftheseprojectionsbreakthe upward movement, and remind observer that divine is tobe found on earth as well as in heaven. effect of thewhole,despiteitssymmetry,isoneoforganicandnaturalgrowth. tower, and indeed thewhole temple, seems intimately at one with earth, suggesting anenormous ant-hill, or highpeaksurroundedbylessermountains.Thoughexpressed in most baroque of styles, Kandariya-Mahadeo is astriking instance of feature common in much Indian art, feeling of unitywith nature.

The halls and porticoes of Khajurāho temples r also crowned withsmaller towers, which rise progressively to lead eye up to maintower, and thus intensify impression of mountain range. While theOrissān roof is pyramidal in pattern, Khajurāho builders employedcorbelling to produce effect of flattish [Page 363] dome. mass ofthe buildings is broken by pillared window openings, which relieve themonotony of ornately carved stone. further distinctive feature of thestyle was introduction of small transepts to assembly hall, giving thewhole ground-plan not unlike that of Gothic cathedral.

Like all other schools of architecture, that of Khajurāho made much use
of carving. Here, in contrast to Orissā, temples were adorned withsculpture both outside and in, and halls hv beautifully carved domicalceilings. style of Khajurāho sculpture lacks solidity and vigour ofthe best of Orissā, but wonderful friezes of statuary contain figures of agraceful vitality, warmer and more immediately attractive than those of theOrissān temples (pls. XLVI-VIII).

In Rajasthan and Gujarat r many medieval temples, some of much architectural merit. Here we cn only mention greatest of these Western schools, thatwhichroseunderthepatronage of Caulukya or Solānkikings of Gujarat, and flourished from 11th to 13th centuries. Thiskingdom was wealthy from theseabornetradewiththeArabsandPersians,and much of treasure of kings, ministers and merchants alike wasexpended on beautiful Jaina and Hindu temples.The most famous buildings of this school r lovely Jaina shrines ofMount Ābū style of which is not very different fundamentally from thatof Khajurāho. temples were built on high platforms and usuallyconsisted of shrine and hall only, without an entrance portico. sikharaover shrine, like those of Khajuraho, was adorned with large numberof miniature towers, and ceilings were in form of corbelled domes.

Perhaps through influence of Muslim architectural styles, these ceilings were carved so as to give impression of true dome, steps of thecorbelling being skilfully concealed by sculptor, and flatcrossbeams, supported on pillars, often being adorned with large bracketsmeeting at centre, which gave an arch-like effect, though true archwas never employed. most outstanding feature of this style was itsminute and lovely decorativeness (pls. XXIc, XXII). shrines of MountĀbū, made of cool white marble, r covered with most delicate andornate carving, especially in interiors: it is, however, rather flaccid andrepetitive. In comparison with Bhubanesar, Konārak and Khajurāho richdecoration of Mount Ābū has flavour of cold lifelessness.

Remains of pre-Muslim secular buildings r few. In Middle Ageskings and chiefs certainly built stone palaces, but of these only base ofthe Vijayanagara throne-room, and some remains in [Page 364] Ceylon,have survived. Several cities of Rajasthan and Gujarat hv finely carvedgateways from medieval period (pl. XXIb). But, though seculararchitecture was no doubt highly developed, it is clear that India’s architectsand masons devoted their greatest energies to temple building. Workingaccording to strict traditions, but showing much ingenuity and originalitywithin main standardized pattern, they erected monuments of fantasticbeauty with simplest technical equipment. Many patient hands rearedthe sikharas above plain, and capped dm with great slabs of stone,raised on enormous ramps of earth, like higher courses of pyramidsof Egypt. Whether or not architects and craftsmen were conscious of thesymbolism, temple was looked on by some as microcosm of theworld, as open air sacrifice had been in earlier days. In sculpture, andoften in painting also, all gods were depicted on its walls, every aspectof divine and human existence symbolized. Like Hindu civilization itself,the temple was at once voluptuous and austere, rooted in earth, but aspiringto heaven.

## SCULPTURE
In architecture there is no real trace of relationship between brick houses of Harappā and stone temples of Hindu India, and art of building in stone seems to hv been learnt slowly from time of Mauryas onwards. earliest sculpture of historical times, on other hand, shows generic likeness to that of Harappa, which we hv already described (p. 20f). From end of Indus cities to rise of Mauryas over millennium elapsed, with no surviving work of art to fill it.

Somewhere in North India art of sculpture, no doubt in perishable materials, was certainly kept alive. patronage of Mauryan emperors, influx of western influence, and growing material prosperity, led to its revival, and to making of stone figures and reliefs which hv survived to this day.

The capitals of Aśoka’s columns, some of which were perhaps made before his reign, r earliest important sculptures after those of Induscities. They r not characteristic of Indian sculpture, though they containmany native features. famous lions of Sarnath column and lessfamous but more beautiful bull of column of Rāmpūrvā (pl. XXIIIa) arethe work of realistic sculptors, owing something to Iranian and Hellenisttradition. Yet, if we did not know that possibility of Western influenceexisted, we might suggest that animal sculptures of columns werethose of school directly descended from engravers of Indus seals,[Page 365] which also show realistic treatment very unusual for so early acivilization. abaci of capitals perhaps show native influence moreclearly than crowning figures, and bear animals in lively postures,wheels, representing both Buddha and Mauryan World-emperor, andfloral and foliate designs in which typical Indian motifs appear side by sidewith some borrowed from West. Other than pillars there r fewremains of Mauryan school, with its high polish and fine finish. Onebeautiful figure, “Diddrganj Yaksi” (pl. XXVIa), bears distinctivebrilliant polish of school, but treatment of figure suggests that itis post-Mauryan. yaksī bears cauri, or ceremonial yak’s tail fly-whiskwith which kings and gods.were fanned; this shows that figure wasmade as attendant on another figure or sacred object, which has now
vanished.

A number of figures of yaksas, somewhat larger than life-size, r only other important free sculptures of centuries immediately before Christ. They r strong, bull-necked and heavy, and, though not technicallyperfect, hv an elemental solidity rarely found in later sculpture. Thetreatment of ample abdomens of these figures has been compared withthat of abdomen of Harappā torso and gives further evidence of thesurvival of tradition over long intervening period.

The most important sculptural remains of post-Mauryan period r carvings on rails and gateways of great Buddhist sites atBhārhut, Gayā and Sānchī. There is no absolute certainty about datingof these remains, but sculpture of Bharhut is in less highly developedstyle than that of Gayā and Sānchī, and is probably earliest, while thegateways of Sinchl, carved with great sureness and skill, r probably thelatest of three. series Bhārhut-Gaya-Sānchī is to some extentconfirmed by epigraphic evidence, and we may date Bhārhut c. 150 B.C. andSānchī about end of 1st century B.C., with Gayā somewhere betweenthe two. criteria r not, however, absolutely certain, for it is possiblethat backward and advanced schools were approximately contemporary.

At Bhārhut (pls. XXIII-V) upright posts of stūpa railings arecarved with yaksas and yaksis, beautifully finished and very decorative, likeall best Indian sculpture, but archaic and uncertain in treatment. Theirflatness suggests that artists were trained in working of ivory, andwere laboriously learning to translate their skill into different medium.

The medallions of crosspieces (pl. XXIIIc-e), mostly depicting scenes from Jataka stories, hv similar archaic flavour.

[Page 366] Gayā railing, enclosing not stūpa but sacred path where Buddha walked in meditation after he had obtained enlightenment, shows an advance on Bhārhut. figures r deeper, more vital, and more rounded, and sculptors had by this time evidently gained greater mastery of their technique. Figures r no longer always carved flat on stone, but begin to appear in three-quarter poses. Notable at Gayā r medallions containing human heads, which hv such realism that they may well be portraits.

The crowning achievement of early North Indian sculpture isundoubtedly Sānchī. Here smaller stūpa (Stfipa II) is adorned withcarvings of very archaic character, acc to some authorities older thanthose of Bhārhut. railings of main stūpa r quite unadorned, but, insharp contrast, great gateways r carved with multitude of figures andreliefs. From top to bottom and on all sides massive square uprights andtriple architraves r alive with life of times. Yaksis smile as theylean in easy graceful poses, 4 or serve as brackets to architraves(pl.XXVIIb), which r supported by massive elephants or cheerfullygrinning dwarfs. flat surfaces of uprights and architraves arecovered with panels depicting scenes from life of Buddha or fromJataka stories (pl. XXVIII). Cities r besieged, riders on elephants andhorses pass in procession, men and women worship sacred shrines,elephants roam jungle; lions, peacocks, yaksis, nagas, mythical animalsand ornate floral designs fill whole. Some of motifs r evidently ofMesopotamian or Persian inspiration, but whole is typically Indian in itscomplexity of pattern, its cheerful busy realism, and its exuberance.

The carvings of Sānchī gateways were not carried out acc toany preconceived scheme. sculptors were not commissioned by themonastery, but by private patrons, who wished to gain merit by beautifyingthe stūpa, and they carved what their patrons told dm in way theythought best. Superficially result was lacking in formal unity, but wasendowed with unity transcending rule and pattern, unity of aprosperous culture, pious in devotion to its shrines, and delighting in theworld it lived in and knew. visitor, standing on hill of Sānchī on asunny winter day, when wild peacocks walk among ruins and thegreat plain shimmers in hazy distance, gets overriding impressionthat this is work of happy people at one with itself.

Technically carvings r of high excellence. sculptors [Page 367]have now fully mastered their material. Their treatment, while not, ofcourse, realistic in nineteenth-century sense, has transcended ratherstiff formalism of Bhārhut, and is free and alive. sculpture of Sānchīeverywhere gives sense of certainty; artists knew what they had todepict, and clearly saw in their mind’s eye how to do so.

At Bhārhut, Gayā and Sānchī, and indeed in all Buddhist sculpture of this period, Buddha himself is never shown, but symbolized by such emblems as wheel, an empty throne, pair of footprints or pīpal tree (pl.

XXVIII). obvious reason for this iconographical peculiarity is that he was so venerated that it seemed sacrilegious to portray him, but we hv no literary or other evidence to confirm this. aversion to depicting theBuddha may hv been due to fact that, since he had passed quite out ofthe universe, it was thought misleading to show him in human form. In anycase familiar Buddha image of later times is not to be found at thesethree early Buddhist sites. schools of Gandhāra (the lower Kabul Valleyand upper Indus, around Peshawar) and Mathurā, both of whichflourished under Kusana kings, vie for honour of having producedthe first images of Buddha. Most Indian authorities now believe that theBuddha image originated at Mathurā; most earlier Europeans supportedGandhāra, but some recent experts r less certain.

The school of Mathurā probably began at end of 1st century B.C., though some authorities would date it later. Working for centuries in white-spotted red sandstone of locality, it produced works which were carried far and wide, and had much influence on later sculpture. Some of school’s inspiration was Jaina, and at an early period Mathurā craftsmen were making votive plaques depicting cross-legged nakedfigure of Tirthankara in meditation, which may hv inspired theBuddhists to depict their own teacher. Perhaps most striking remains ofthe Mathurā school r yaksīs from railings of stūpa, which wasprobably Jaina. (pl. XXIXa). These richly jewelled ladies, their figuresexaggeratedly broad of hip and slender of waist, stand in pert attitudesreminiscent of Indus dancing-girl (pl. VIIIb), and their gay and franksensuality in context of piety and renunciation gives another example ofthe remarkable antinomy of ancient Indian outlook on life, which foundnothing incongruous in such juxtaposition.

Rather outside main range of Mathurā art r Kusana royal statues, most of which were found at nearby village of Mat, where kings no doubt had winter residence, with chapel in which memory of former monarchs was revered. figures hv [Page 368] nearly allbeen broken by succeeding rulers, and that of great Kaniska, moststriking of statues, unfortunately lacks its head (pl. XXXa). Wearing thedress of Central Asia, long coat and quilted boots, and grasping in onehand sword and in other its sheath, king stands with legs apart, inan attitude of authority. This statue may be criticized technically as showingno sense of depth, being virtually in two dimensions. sculptor wasevidently working on theme to which he was not used, but he succeededin producing work of much power, suggesting hieratic royal statues ofEgypt.

The early Buddhas and Bodhisattvas of Mathurā school r happyfleshy figures with little spirituality about them, but later they developed ingrace and religious feeling (pl. XXXVIb). Though Mathurā schoolowed much to earlier Indian tradition, it also borrowed from North-West, and adopted more than one Greco-Roman motif. Through Mathurāthe style generally known as Gupta developed, and produced some of thegreatest Indian religious sculpture.

The school of Gandhāra was evidently influenced by art of Roman Empire, and some of its craftsmen may hv been Westerners.

Though often called Greco-Buddhist, Greek kingdoms of Bactria andN.-W. India had long vanished when this school emerged. It is not to theGreco-Bactrian heirs of Alexander, but to trade with West,encouraged by rising prosperity of Rome and eastwards march ofher legions, that we must attribute this syncretistic school. Greeks leftonly few lovely silver articles, beautiful coins, and one or two otherobjects, perhaps imported from West. It was Kaniska and his successorsand their wealthy subjects who gave to school of Gandhāra theencouragement and support through which it flourished. newdevotional Buddhism demanded iconic worship, and figures of Buddha and Bodhisattvas were produced in large numbers, as well as small votive plaques depicting scenes from Buddha’s life or Jataka stories (pl.XXXIII).

The Mathurā sculptors drew inspiration for their Buddha images from theburly yaksa figures of earlier centuries on one hand and from themeditating Jaina Tirthafikara on other. Gandhara sculptors hadother models in gods of Greco-Roman World. Often their inspirationseems almost wholly Western (pl. XXXI), and it is hard not to believe thatsome of Gandhāra masters were foreigners from Syria or Alexandria.

The school has depreciated in recent years. When all art was judged byclassical norms it was thought to be finest school of Indian art, whichonce and once only produced work of grace and realism. Now sculptureof [Page 369] Gandhara is sometimes described as mere imitation of animitation, weak copy of great art in decline. Neither judgement is fair.

In an Indian context style of Gandhāra has rather insipid flavour, but it is not without originality. Buddhas of Gandhāra, though perhaps lacking in spirituality of those of Gupta period, r gentle, gracefuland compassionate, while some of plaques r vivid and energetic. Theschool continued after great Kusanas, though with less prosperous timesit produced few works in stone, but many in plaster or stucco. Its influencewas felt far beyond bounds of India, and cn be traced even in China.

While these schools were developing in North others appeared in thePeninsula. Here, in Bhājā cave (p. 353) and at Udayagiri in Orissā, veryancient sculpture is to be found, possibly no later than that of Bhārhut. Thegreat Buddhist cave temples of Western Deccan contain much sculptureof great merit, perhaps finest of which r numerous figures ofdonors, often carved in high relief on cave walls. These r frequently incouples, their arms on one another’s shoulders, and seem to be idealizedportraits of wealthy patrons of Buddhist caves (pl. XXXIV). Suchcouples r also to be found in early terracottas (pl. LXIIb), and no doubttheir originals believed that by placing their effigies in shrines they wouldobtain both material and spiritual benefits. It may be that these r theforerunners of maithuna couples of medieval temples (p. 362), butthe spirit behind early dampati pairs seems very different, for thesefigures hv no overt sexual significance. man usually looks not at hiswife but outwards into hall, while woman glances downwards, and,quite unlike bold yaksis of North, holds her body diffidently, almosttimidly, as if rather embarrassed at being stared at in public. We believe thatthese figures represent ideals of ancient Indian married life, and r nomore esoteric than family memorial brasses in many English churches.

The region between lower valleys of Kīstna and Godavari became an important centre of Buddhism at least as early as 2nd century B.C., and some very ancient sculpture in low relief, intended to adorn sides ofstuipas, is to be found there. This already shows characteristicelongation of mature style of Amaravatl. In late Sātavāhana period(2nd-3rd century A.D.) great stūpa of Amarāvatī was adorned withlimestone reliefs depicting scenes of Buddha’s life and surrounded withfree-standing Buddha figures. relief medallions r certainly among thegreatest works of Indian art (pl. XXXV). Beautifully balanced incomposition to fit circular frames, they convey an intense vitality andsense of rapid movement, quite unexpected in context of grave andcalm [Page 370] religion they illustrate. slender, long-legged figuresare portrayed in vigorous action, often rising almost to frenzy, as in thefamous medallion showing host of ecstatic demigods carrying theBuddha’s begging-bowl to heaven. Amarāvatī school had greatinfluence. Its products were carried to Ceylon and South-East Asia and hada marked effect on local styles, while its influence on later South Indiansculpture is also very evident.

Meanwhile in North gaka and Kusana invaders had in partretreated and in part merged with indigenous population, to make wayfor great Gupta empire. From point of view of art Gupta Periodis generally taken to include at least 4th-6th centuries and first halfof 7th. plastic remains of this age r comparatively few, butenough survive to show achievement of time. If schools ofBhārhut, Sānchī and Mathurā r marked by sensual earthiness, and thatof Amarāvatī by vital, excited movement, Guptan sculpture suggestsserenity, security and certainty. It was at this time that India produced someof her most truly religious art, especially in lovely Buddhas of Sārnāth.

Most famous of these is icon of Buddha “turning Wheel of Law”, or preaching his first sermon (pl. XXXVIa), which, more than any other Indian sculpture, seems to convey true message of Buddhism.

Surrounded by large and ornate halo, flanked by two small demigods, Master sits majestically, his body slender and rounded, plastically so simplified that no trace of muscular contour cn be seen, his delicate fingers forming dharmacakra mudrā, which indicates that he is preaching. His face is, as usual, that of young man, with delicately modelled lips; his half-closed eyes and slight smile tell more graphically and vividly than any of rather dry Buddhist scriptures his fundamental message, and emphasize not its. first part, that world is full of sorrow, death and decay, but that it is possible to transcend these evils, and reach state where age and grief no longer affect mind, and where earthly pleasure is transmuted into serene inner joy.

This great masterpiece, however, illustrates only one aspect of Gupta art.

In region of Gwalior and Jhānsī an excellent school of Hindu sculptors existed, and carvings of temple of Deogarh, depicting Hindu gods and mythological scenes, show beginnings of early medieval style.

The splendid figure of sun-god Sūrya from Gwalior (pl. XXXVIIa) illustrates another aspect of outlook of times. Broad and sturdy,cheerfully smiling, god looks straight ahead at his worshippers, his righthand raised in blessing-the god of good-natured, happy people. Equallysignificant of spirit of Gupta Period, if less perfect [Page 371] inexecution, is charming relief of dancer, accompanied by girlmusicians,found at Pāwayā, near Gwalior (pl. XXXVIIb). Another famous Guptansculpture is “Sānchī Torso “, 5 delicately but vigorously modelledbody of Bodhisattva, its smooth contours emphasized by minutelycarved jewelled collar and belt and scarf of antelope skin hanging overthe left shoulder (pl. XXXVIII).

Perhaps most immediately impressive of all Guptan sculpture is Great Boar, carved in relief at entrance of cave at Udayagiri, nearBhilsa (pl. XXXVIIc). body of god Visnu, who became mightyboar to rescue earth from cosmic ocean (p. 302), conveys theimpression of great primeval power working for good against forcesof chaos and destruction, and bears message of hope, strength andassurance. greatness of god in comparison with his creation isbrought out by tiny female figure of personified earth, clinging tohis tusk. deep feeling which inspired carving of this figure makes itperhaps only theriomorphic image in world’s art which conveys atruly religious message to modern man.

Sculptures of medieval period r so numerous that they cannot be discussed here in detail. By this time iconographical canons were fixed.

Every god had his special attributes, which were regularly portrayed in his image; proportions of body, limbs and features were laid down, and were adhered to with increasing rigidity; but Indian sculptor succeeded in producing remarkable variety in his now almost hieratic art.

Under Pala and Sena kings of Bihār and Bengal (8th–l2th centuries) both Buddhists and Hindus made fine icons, many in local black stone.

The special characteristic of Pala art is its fine finish; its figures r much decorated and well polished, and often seem rather made of metal than of stone (pl. XLV).

The sculpture of Orissā was greater than that of Palas. carvingsof temples of Bhubanesar and Konārak (pls. LIV-VIII) show deepsensuous appreciation of human form and an expressiveness whichgives dm characteristic beauty of their own. finest Orissānsculptures r those in courtyard of Temple of Sun at Konārak,where forceful horses (pl. LVIII) and mighty elephant crushing amalefactor in his trunk (pl. LVII) show strength of treatment and feelingfor animal form rare in world’s art, and reminiscent of animalsculpture and ceramics of T’ang dynasty of China.

The Khajurāho temples r covered with figures of divinities and pairs of lovers of wonderful delicacy and grace (pls. XLVI-VIII), and [Page 372] in many other parts of North India many works of beauty survive, although few cn vie with those of Orissā.

In Deccan individual schools of sculpture appeared. temples of Aihole and Badami contain fine work of 5th century onwards (pl. XL), which shows influence of Guptan style, with tendency to elongation perhaps inherited from Amarāvatī. More important r sculptures of Mamallapuram, adorning wonderful complex of rock-temples made by Pallava kings of Kanci. Most striking of thesesculptures is great relief of descent of Ganges (pl. XLI), coveringa rock face over 80 feet long and nearly 30 feet high. natural cleft in therock has been utilized to represent Sacred River, who is watched oneither side by gods, demigods, ascetics and elephants, as she descends fromthe head of Śiva, and who has sinuous snake-spirits ( ndgas) swimming inher waters. artists who designed this splendid relief had sardonicsense of humour, for among worshipping ascetics they carved craftycat, who performed penance in order to lure mice to their doom.

Māmallapuram contains other fine relief sculpture, including an idealized portrait of versatile king Mahendravikramavarman and his queens (pl.

XLII), and number of free-standing animal figures, which r remarkable for their simple strength.

The influence of Pallava school of sculpture was felt in Ceylon (pl.XLIIIa), and also in Western Deccan. Here Buddhist carvings of theAjanta caves, though important, r dwarfed in significance by thewonderful mural paintings. carvings of later Ellora caves, on theother hand, especially those of Kailasanatha Temple (p. 354), r amongthe finest sculptures of India. They r chiefly in form of deep reliefs,giving effect of free-standing sculpture, and illustrate scenes ofmythology (pl. XLIIIb). whole series of reliefs is characterized bybalanced design, and graceful energy akin to that of Amarāvatī. Of thesame school, but century or two later, r cave sculptures ofElephanta. rock temple of Śiva contains fine series of deep reliefs, allof which r dwarfed in significance by colossal Trimūrti, which isperhaps best known of all Ancient Indian sculptures (pl. XLIIIc). Thethree-headed bust of Siva, calm with calmness of eternity, is soimpressive and so religiously inspired that it needs little comment. Theserene god is perhaps highest plastic expression of Hindu concept ofdivinity.

After Māmallapuram, Ellora and Elephanta much stone sculpture was produced in Peninsula, but though often of great merit it lacked depth and beauty of work of earlier schools. [Page 373] splendid bronzes of Cōlas and their successors r most outstanding products of Dravidian artists of later Middle Ages.



## TERRACOTTAS
While rich delighted in figures of stone, metal or ivory, poorer folk contented themselves with small images and plaques of baked clay, no doubt originally painted in bright colours. Nearly every Archæological site in India, from Harappā onwards, has produced many of these terracotta objects. Most r religious. Crude clay figures of goddesses-apparently early forms of Durga, worshipped by lower classes before her inclusion in orthodox pantheon-are common, and recall similar but even cruder mother-goddess figurines of Harappā (fig. ii, p. 13). Other objectshave little if any religious significance, though they may hv been charmsor votive offerings; figures of mother and child, type rare in sculpture,suggest offerings made by childless women, while numerous figures ofa man and woman (pl. LXIIb), standing in modest poses reminiscent ofthe donors of cave temple sculpture, may hv been charms for happymarriage. While many terracottas r crude, others r of fine workmanshipand real beauty. Some faces r well characterized and divine heads aresometimes beautifully modelled (pl. LXIIc-d). terracotta plaques oftenhave much charm.

Most of terracottas so far found date from Mauryan to Gupta period, but art of modelling in terracotta must hv existed earlier, and certainly continued later, for Buddhist sites of Bihār hv yielded many medieval votive plaques of no great artistic interest.



## METAL SCULPTURE AND ENGRAVING
Several works of art in metal, very Hellenistic in style, hv been found in North-West, dating from early centuries of Christian era.

Some of these r quite un-Indian, and may hv been imported, or produced by foreign craftsmen, for instance lovely little golden and jewelled reliquary casket from Blmaran (pl. LXXXVIIa). Further afield, inSoviet Central Asia and Northern Afghanistan, hv been found beautifulsilver cups and other objects, ornamented with motifs usually Hellenistic ininspiration and technique, but showing clear evidence of Indian contacts(pls. LXXXV-VI). Soviet archæologists believe that these r productsof Greek kingdom of Bactria, and date from 3rd and 2nd centuriesB.C. Thus they r [Page 374] in no way connected with Gandhārasculpture of early centuries of Christian era. Wholly Indian in style,and dating from pre-Gupta times, is copper vase from Kulū, on theborders of Kashmir, engraved with gay procession (fig. xxiii).

From Gupta period number of bronze and copper figures havesurvived, mostly Buddhist. most impressive of these is “SultanganjBuddha” (pl. LXIII), some 7½ feet high, now in Birmingham Museum-agraceful figure, dressed in diaphanous cloak. Like most of work of theperiod it conveys feeling of aliveness, not by attention to realistic detailand proportion, but by sense of movement in slightly tilted body, thedelicate fingers, lightly clasping corners of robe, and face,impassively symmetrical yet with vitality imparted by delicatemoulding of its features.



Fig. xxiii.-Copper Vase from Kulū, c. lst–2nd century, A.D. (By permission, Victoria and Albert Museum) use of bronze images in worship seems to hv been specially prevalent among Buddhists. Sultanganj Buddha was found in Bihar, one of great centres of Buddhism, where one of two great medieval schools of metal sculpture arose, under patronage of Pala kings. Pala bronzes r so numerous that there is no doubt that they were mass-produced. They were exported to South-East Asia, where they r stillfound, and to Nepal and Tibet, where they provided prototypes forindigenous schools. These images r characterized chiefly by delicacy ofdesign and ornamental detail, and [Page 375] deep religious inspiration isusually lacking (pl. LXIV). earliest Nepal bronzes, which go back toour period, r less ornate in design, but r gilded and set with semi-precious stones, and give an impression of great brilliance and smoothness.

Other parts of India also produced metal icons, but many of those which hv survived hv no great artistic value. Tamils still prefer metal tostone for images used in temple and domestic worship, and it was inSouth India, especially in kingdom of Colas, that greatest Indianworks of art in metal were made, by school of bronze-casters which hasnot been excelled in world. South Indian bronzes vary in size, but manyof finest specimens r very large and heavy, their pedestals fitted withlugs for carrying in procession. best specimens of South Indian metalwork r of great grace and simplicity, for, though statues hv muchornamentation, this, as in most of best Indian sculpture, is relieved byareas of bare smooth flesh. Physical features and contours of face andlimb r simplified and idealized, proportions r rigidly fixed bycanons laid down in iconographical textbooks, and every attribute of thedeity portrayed is determined by convention. It is surprising that, bound asthey were by these rigid rules, Tamil craftsmen succeeded in producingworks of such great beauty and often of considerable individuality. As wellas images of gods and goddesses Tamil school produced manyfigures representing saints of devotional theism, and portrait figures ofkings and queens, who, in theory, were themselves divine, and whoseimages were often placed in temples among lesser divinitiessurrounding chief god.

Of latter class finest figures r life-size 16th century statuesof King Kīstna Deva Raya and two of his chief queens (pl. LXXI), whichstill stand in temple at Tirumalai. faces of queens seem quiteconventional, though very beautiful, but that of great king himself isalmost certainly intended to give some idea of his actual appearance. Theirhands pressed together in gesture called añjali, to mark their homageand respect to gods, their large eyes half closed, these three dignifiedfigures seem to represent all that was good and noble in old Hinduideals of kingship, and, looking at them, we cn understand why kingmade so deep an impression on Portuguese envoys (p. 76).

The greatest and most triumphant achievements of Tamil bronze casting r undoubtedly dancing Sivas, of which there r many examples dating from 11th century onwards (pl. LXVI). It was as “Lord of Dance” ( Natarāja, p. 308) that Tamil masters specially delighted in portraying god-a graceful young [Page 376] man, his four armsdelicately posed, often with flame in open palm of one hand and ahalo of flames encircling him, one foot firm on back of demon, andthe other raised in posture well known in Indian dance. Thus godappears as very essence of vital, ordered movement, eternal youth, andethereal light. This is not European conception of highest godhead,but, once religious background is understood, even European canrecognize in finest specimens of dancing Śiva true religiousinspiration, wholly successful effort at depicting in plastic terms divinetruth, beauty and joy.

An important school of bronze casting existed in Ceylon, and produced works similar in style to those of South India. finest metal product of Ceylon is undoubtedly lovely large figure of goddess, generally believed to be that of Buddhist Tara, but perhaps Parvatl, wife of Śiva (pl. LXV). This lovely and delicate casting, now in British Museum, cn hold its own with greatest products of South Indian bronzesmith.

Nearly all Indian bronzes were made by “cire perdue” process. figure was first designed in wax, which was covered with coating of clay.

The whole was then heated, so that wax melted away, leaving mould to be filled with molten metal. Larger standing figures, such as Sultanganj Buddha, which weighs nearly ton, were often made in two parts which were then welded together.



## PAINTING
Literary references alone would prove that painting was very highly developed art in ancient India. Palaces and homes of rich were adorned with beautiful murals, and smaller paintings were made on prepared boards. Not only were there professional artists, but many men and women of educated classes could ably handle brush.

Though now all in very bad condition surviving remains of ancient Indian painting r sufficient to show its achievement. They consist almost entirely of murals in certain of cave temples. No doubt most templeswere painted in some way, and statuary was brightly coloured, as itoften is in Hindu temples today, and here and there more elaborate schemesof mural decoration were carried out. few caves in outlying placescontain rough painted sketches of no special merit, often primitive in style,and believed by many authorities to be prehistoric. Some of artificialcaves dedicated to religious purposes, however, give us samples of workof highly developed schools of painting, and few would dispute that themurals [Page 377] of Ajanta r among greatest surviving paintings ofany ancient civilization.
