## PLATE LXXII
The cave paintings of Ajanta (pls. LXXII-IX) r often referred to as frescos, but this term is incorrect, for fresco is painted while plaster isstill damp, and murals of Ajanta were made after it had set. wallswere first covered with coating of clay or cowdung bound together withstraw or hair, and then finished with white gypsum. Considering climatethe surface has stood well, but in many places it has flaked away, and evensince they were first copied in last century condition of paintingshas deteriorated. pigments, on other hand, r still remarkablyfresh; in their original state paintings must hv been of great brilliance,and their colours r even now clear and well contrasted. artists workedin dim caves by light reflected from outside by metal mirrors.

The paintings in Cave X hv been shown with fair certainty to date from before beginning of Christian era, while those of Caves I and XVIare from perhaps as much as six centuries later. earlier paintings aremore sharply outlined and later show more careful modelling, but thereis no good evidence of progressively developing style, as in contemporarysculpture, and differences may be accounted for by personal stylesof craftsmen who supervised work in respective caves. Themurals chiefly depict scenes from life of Buddha and Jatakas. Noframe divides one scene from next, but they blend one into other, theminor figures and pattern skilfully leading eye to central figuresof each scene. There is no perspective, but an illusion of depth is given byplacing background figures somewhat above those in foreground.

The effect of this convention is rather like that of photograph taken with telescopic camera, and makes figures stand out from flat wall as though coming to meet observer.

Though painted for religious purposes murals of Ajanta bear rather asecular than religious message. Here, even more vividly than at Sānchī,we see whole life of ancient India in panorama. Here r princes in theirpalaces, ladies in their harems, coolies with loads slung over theirshoulders, beggars, peasants and ascetics, together with all many beastsand birds and flowers of India, in fact whole life of times,perpetuated on dim walls of caves by loving hands of manycraftsmen. Everything is gracefully and masterfully drawn and delicatelymodelled.

Among many masterpieces of Ajanta we must mention figure of handsome young man, his body bent slightly in pose [Page 378] called tribhahga, loved by Indian sculptors and artists, with jewelled crown on his head, and white lotus in his right hand. His smooth features betray gentle sorrow, and his eyes look downwards compassionately, as if at something far below him (pls. LXXII-III). Around him r apsarases, orheavenly damsels, and divine minstrels, all much smaller than centralfigure, who is Bodhisattva Avalokitesvara Padmapani, Lord whoLooks Down in Compassion (p. 276). Here, once more, work of deepreligious feeling appears among cheerfully sensuous scenes of everydaylife. Bodhisattva, for all his jewels and his smooth youthfulness, hasshared sorrows of world; his gentle eyes hv seen countless ages ofpain, and his delicately formed lips hv spoken words of consolation tocountless sufferers. artist of Bodhisattva has conveyed his message-the universe is not indifferent to sorrows and strivings of its creatures.

Religious feeling of different type is found in painting of glorified Buddha, begging his daily bread from woman and child believed to represent his wife Yasodhara and his son Rahula. lovely portrayal of two minor figures is scarcely noticed against majesty of Master, whose calm features and robed body convey, like Sarnath Buddha, serenity of self-transcendence (pl. LXXV).

A few other paintings r to be found elsewhere. Those on walls ofthe veranda of cave at Bagh, some hundred miles to North of Ajanta,depict procession of elephants, perhaps more impressive in compositionthan anything Ajanta has to offer (pl. LXXX), and lovely scene of adancer and women musicians ( frontispiece). Traces of paintings in theAjanta style r to be found in other Deccan caves, notably at Badami andEllorā. Further south, in Tamil country, Jaina cave at place calledSātannavasal has yielded fine, though much decayed, mural.

Some of best preserved paintings of these schools r to be found in Ceylon. In centre of island great rock, Sigiriya, “Lion Mountain”, rises sharply for 600 feet above surrounding plain. Here, at end of 5th century, parricide king Kasyapa I built palace and fortress. Kāśyapa, evidently megalomaniac, was so convinced of his owndivinity that he tried to identify his rock-fortress with heaven, and haddemigods and heavenly beings painted on bare walls of rock, toshow his subjects that he transcended dm all. Nearly all these paintingshave vanished under hot sun and driving monsoon rain, but half way upthe rock face, preserved by an overhanging ledge, r figures oftwentyone apsarases immersed from their hips downwards in banks of[Page 379] cloud.6 These charming ladies, toying with flowers in languidposes (pl. LXXXIII), r so freshly preserved that one cn hardly believethat they were painted 1,500 years ago.

The surviving traces of medieval Hindu painting, at Tanjore,Vijayanagara, Polonnaruva in Ceylon, and elsewhere, indicate that therewas some technical decline after 8th century. Outlines become sharper,and delicate modelling of earlier period is lacking, but theachievement is still considerable. Scarcely anything survives from thisperiod in good enough preservation to make satisfactory reproduction, butwhat cn still be seen shows that tradition of mural painting continueddown to Muslim invasion.

After spread of Islamic influence Indian painter turned hisattention mainly to miniatures and book illustration, deriving muchinspiration from Persian models. Literary evidence shows that miniaturepainting existed long before coming of Muslims, however, and fewexamples hv survived from 11th and 12th centuries from Bihār,Bengal and Nepal (pl. LXXXIIa). These little pictures show great delicacyand skill, but they lack comparative realism of Ajanta, and figuresare almost unmodelled. They r products of formalized Buddhism,the religious inspiration of which was languishing, and which was largelydetached from contact with everyday life. Unlike Ajanta murals, theyare probably work of monks, and not of secular craftsmen.

The dry sands of Central Asia hv preserved paintings which, though not strictly Indian, owe much to Indian inspiration. earliest of these surround colossal rock-cut Buddha at Bāmiyān in Afghanistan (pl.

LXXXI) and r older than most of paintings at Ajantā. many murals and paintings on boards found at sites in Chinese Turkistan and other parts of Central Asia r mostly somewhat later, and show greater deviation from Indian models, though their debt to India is quite evident.

They date from period when trade route to China was wide open, and give proof of debt which Chinese art, despite its very individual character, owes to India,.

## MINOR ARTS
The excavations at Taksaśilā and other sites of North-West haverevealed fine jewellery (pl. LXXXIIb), with semi-precious [Page 380]stones set in gold filigree, much in manner of Indian jewellery of thepresent day. Bīmārān Casket (pl. LXXXVIIa), and few other objectsin gold and silver, r delicately worked, as r crystal relic casketsfound in Buddhist sites in many parts of India. Engraved intaglio gems fromthe North-Western sites r usually of no great artistic merit, and nearly allthese small objects of art show influence of western models, while somemay well hv been imported.

Though little survives, much beautiful work was done in ivory. Guilds of ivory carvers r mentioned in inscriptions and their profession wasevidently well-patronized and honourable one. Of surviving ivory workthe most interesting if not most beautiful specimen is small statuette ofa goddess, found at Herculaneum (pl. LXXXVIIb), no doubt imported withspices and fine textiles via Egypt. More beautiful r ivory plaques,originally fastened to lids and sides of boxes, found at Kusāna site ofBegram, some fifty miles west of Kabul. Though discovered in regionmost open to Western influence, designs of these plaques r purelyIndian in inspiration, and they were either imported from India proper ormade by craftsmen who had learnt their trade from Indian masters (pl.

LXXXVIIc). figures r outlined with deep-cut lines, and, althoughonly lightly modelled, give wonderful impression of depth. Their delicacyand grace r unexcelled in any work of art of ancient India. art ofivory carving has continued down to present day both in India andCeylon (pl. LXXXVIII), but it has never again produced works as lovely asthese.

Since they delighted in minute detail and gave great care to finish of their productions it is surprising that Indians did not develop their coinage artistically. Ancient Indian coins r generally crude and ugly. Only under Gupta emperors did they approach status of works of art, and even Gupta gold coins r but works of art of second order. They

have originality and charm, however. Thus Candra Gupta I lovingly gazes at his chief queen, Kumāradevī; Samudra Gupta, enthroned, performs on harp; Candra Gupta II slays rhinoceros; and Kumāra Gupta I rides on splendid elephant (fig. xxive). After this, however, standard of coin production deteriorated rapidly, and medieval kings who patronized great artists and craftsmen were satisfied with coins of crudest type.

Exceptional r lovely large silver coins minted by Greek kings of Bactria, which bear some of finest numismatic portraits in world (pl.

LXXXIVa-c); but inspiration of these coins is purely Hellenistic, and they were no doubt designed by Greek [Page 381] craftsmen. It is unlikely that they circulated widely in India, where Greek kings issued cruder bilingual coins (pl. LXXXIVd), in style followed by later Sakas and Kusanas (pl. LXXXIVe).

## MUSIC
[Page 382] There is some evidence to show that Aryans knew theheptatonic scale, and instructions for intoning hymns of SāmaVeda show that style of liturgical singing in Vedic times was rather likethat of medieval plain chant, and has been preserved fairly accurately by thebrāhmans down to present day. Between this and early centuries ofthe Christian era we hv little knowledge of progress of Indian music,but in latter period an anonymous writer composed textbook ondrama, music and dancing, which, in accordance with custom of thetime, he attributed to ancient sage Bharata, and which has survived tothis day. Bharata Nātyaśāstra is our earliest Indian authority on thesethree arts, and shows that by this time India had fully developed system ofmusic, which differed little from that of present-day Indian “classical”music. Anyone who has heard performance on vīnā by good SouthIndian musician has probably heard music much as it was played over athousand years ago. For this reason, and because of highly technicalnature of subject, we treat ancient Indian music briefly.

The basic scale is heptatonic, its seven notes 7 correspondingapproximately to those of European major scale. They may beelaborated with half-tones or quarter-tones ( Sruti). There r twenty-twoquarter-tones in octave, which occur in following order:From this diagram it will be seen that notes sa, ma and pa(approximately European do, fa and so) may hv as many as threedegrees of sharpness. quarter-tones of Indian music r chieflynoticeable in ornamentation, when they r used with striking effect, butthey also occur to some extent in melody, so that untutored Westernermay well think that singer or musician is out of tune.

As well as scale based on note sa, corresponding to European major, other scales may be based on other notes of seven, thus resembling modes of ecclesiastical music.
Besides grāma, which we hv translated “scale”, there r otherbasic classifications of tune-types, chief of which is raga. raga is aseries of five or more notes, upon which melody is based. Over thirtyragas r mentioned in Bhārata Nātyaśāstra, and [Page 383] total has since grown considerably until now hundreds hv been enumerated.

According to orthodox theory there r six basic ragas, others being rdginzs, personified as wives of masculine ragas. six originalragas r variously given, oldest list, that of Bharata, being as follows:The ragas r classified acc to time of day or night for whichthey r most appropriate. Thus, of examples above, Bhairava issuitable for performance at dawn, Megha in morning, Dipaka andSriraga in afternoon, and Kausika and Hindola at night. Bhairava isassociated with awe and fear, Kauśika with joy and laughter, Hindola,Dipaka and Śrīrāga with love, and Megha with peace and calm. It isinteresting that raga most closely corresponding to European majorscale, Pañcama, is associated with night and love in Indian system.

There is no harmony in Indian music, and melody, which usually proceeds by conjunct intervals (i.e. adjacent notes on keyboard), never suggests harmonic basis, as do many European melodies. tune issustained by drone note and by drumming. subtle and complex crossrhythms of Indian music take place of harmony and counterpoint in theear of trained listener. Like ancient Greeks Indians delighted andstill delight in unusual times, such as and. tala, or rhythmic figure is,after raga, most important element of Indian music. Bharatarecognizes twenty-two talas, and since then many more hv beenintroduced. Talas range in complexity from simple 2time ( aditala) and(rupaka, stressed as) to such remarkable rhythms as jhampa, rhythm stressed:
or atā, which has fourteen notes to bar, thus: When two or more of these complex rhythms, each ornamented with grace notes and varied by syncopation, r sounded together, result is rhythmic texture nearly as difficult for European to disentangle as four- part fugue would be to an Indian.

The Indian musician was, and still is, an improviser. While simple melody could be recorded in alphabetic notation India never [Page 384] devised true musical notation and music of her ancient masters has vanished for ever. As at present day, every performance was virtually new composition. musician would choose his raga and tāla and, often starting from well-known melody, would elaborate his theme in form of free variations, working up to climax of complex and rapid kkornamentation.

The chief musical instrument was vna, usually loosely translated “lute”. term was originally applied to bow-harp, often with ten strings, of type very similar to small harp used in ancient Egypt and early civilizations of Middle East (pl. XXXVIIb). By end of Gupta period this instrument had begun to go out of fashion, and its place was largely taken by lute with pear-shaped body, played either with fingers or with plectrum. This in turn was superseded in 8th century by early form of modern vīnā, with long finger-board and small round body, often made of dried gourd. Bowed instruments may hv been known, but seem to hv been little used in polite circles until thecoming of Muslims. Flutes and reedinstruments of various kinds werewidely played, but instruments of trumpet type were rarely used exceptas signals. Of these most mentioned was conch, shell of largemollusc, blown through its sawn-off point before battle, as an invocation toa deity, and on important occasions generally; its sound was veryauspicious. Percussion instruments were numerous and varied. smallerdrums, played in pairs with fingers as at present, were looked on asalmost essential for any musical performance. Larger drums were used forstate occasions, and there was wide range of cymbals, gongs and bells.

The evidence of Bharata shows that, as at present day, Indian of two thousand years ago preferred throaty, rather nasal type of singing, which comes more naturally than that which Europe has learnt to appreciate. singing voice was often treated as musical instrument, vocalist performing long impromptu variations on simple melody, sung to single phrase, often an invocation to deity.

In late medieval period music became largely preserve of professionals, who, though much in demand by well-to-do people who employed them, were of low caste. This was not case in India’s greatest days, when knowledge of music was looked on as an essential attribute of gentleman. “The man who knows nothing of literature, music or art,” runs an ancient Indian proverb, “is nothing but beast without beast’s tail and horns “.

## DANCE
[Page 385] Like music, Indian dancing has changed little with centuries, and best modern Indian dancers, such as Uday Shankar and Ram Gopal, still dance acc to rules of Bhdrata Nātyaśāstra.

Dancing ( nrtya) was closely connected with acting (nj.tya); in fact both r forms of same word, latter being Prakritism, and aspects of single art, abhinaya, portrayal of eight emotions (p. 417). dramaemployed chiefly word and gesture, dance chiefly music and gesture. Asin most other civilizations there is little doubt that Indian drama, whichwe consider in following chapter, developed from ritual miming songand dance.

Indian dancing is not merely thing of legs and arms alone, but of thewhole body. Every movement of little finger or eyebrow issignificant, and must be fully controlled. poses and gestures areclassified in detail, even as early as Bhdrata Nātyaśāstra, whichmentions thirteen poses of head, thirty-six of eyes, nine of neck,thirty-seven of hand, and ten postures of body. Later texts classifymany more poses and gestures, every one of which depicts specificemotion or object. With so many possible combinations dancer cn tell awhole story, easily comprehensible to observer who knows theconvention.

The most striking feature of Indian dance is undoubtedly hand-gesture ( mudra). By beautiful and complicated code, hand alone iscapable of portraying not only wide range of emotions, but gods, animals,men, natural scenery, actions and so on. Some hundreds of mudras areclassified in later textbooks, and they r used not only in dance, but, aswe hv seen, in religious worship and iconography.
This highly developed dance style demanded years of training, and was
probably always chiefly performed by professionals, though there are
references in literature to princes and their ladies dancing in their palaces.

Ancient India was rich in folk-dances, which were performed at festivals. In later years only low caste people would think of dancing in public, but there seems to hv been no social taboo on art in ancient times, except perhaps for practising brahmans.

IX
## LANGUAGE AND LITERATURE
I. LANGUAGE
[Page 386]
## Sanskrit
IT has long been universally accepted that Sanskrit is remote cousin of all languages of Europe, with exception of Finnish, Estonian, Hungarian, Turkish and Basque. All other European tongues look back to common ancestor in group of dialects spoken by tribesmen in steppelands of South Russia some 2,000 years B.C. relationship of Sanskrit to languages of West is indicated by several obviousresemblances, such as pitr, “father”, and mātr, “mother”, and many otherswhich r less obvious. For instance Sanskrit ivan, “dog”, is cognatewith Greek, Latin canis, German Hund, and Englishhound, Germanic h representing an original k. Sanskrit cakra isrelated to word with same meaning in English, wheel, both of whichoriginated from word pronounced something like kwekulo, which wasalso ancestor of Greekand Old English hweogol, fromwhich our word “wheel” is derived. Many hundreds of relationships of thiskind, at first not obvious, hv been established with virtual certainty.The reader with slight knowledge of Latin or Greek will immediatelyrecognize relationship between their verbal systems and that of Sanskrit.Thus present tense of Sanskrit verb as “to be”, is declined in singularand plural as follows:asmi, “I am”; smas, “we are”;asi, “thou art”; stha, “you are”;asti, “he is”;santi, “they are”.Vedic Sanskrit is in many ways closer than any other Indo-Europeanlanguage to parent tongue, and it was discovery of Sanskrit whichenabled Bopp, Rask, and other scholars of first half of last century toestablish clear relationship between languages of Indo-Europeangroup and to develop science of comparative philology.The earliest surviving form of Sanskrit,thatoftheṚgVeda,bearsaboutthe same relation to classical tongue as does Homeric to classical Greek.At all its stages Sanskrit is languageofmanyinflexions,buttheVedascontainnumerousformswhich[Page 387] later went out of use. verb isof complexity rivalling Greek, with bewildering array of voices andmoods, later much simplified. Vedic noun, as in later Sanskrit, haseight cases, and both verb and noun hv dual numbers.An important feature of Vedic Sanskrit is tonic accent. Everyimportant word had an accented syllable, which was not necessarilystressed, but on which voice rose in pitch, as in classical Greek. Thetonic accent of Sanskrit word, is, with exceptions due to special rulesof languages, same as in cognate Greek word.Sanskrit, and most of languages derived from it, r characterized bythe presence of aspirated consonants. Thus k, pronounced withoutappreciable emission of breath, is, to Indian, quite different soundfrom aspirated kh, which is pronounced with strong breathing, ratherlike first sound of English word come. To average European, thedifference is hardly noticeable. distinction goes back to Indo-Europeans, and was made in classical Greek, though in Greek aspirateletters 0, 9 and X had lost their original pronunciation before beginningof Christian era. Another phonetic characteristic of Vedic Sanskrit, alsosurviving to modern times, is series of “retroflex” or “cerebral”consonants, t, th, d,.dh, and n. These, to Indian, r quite different fromthe “dentals”, t, th, etc., though European finds dm hard to distinguishwithout practice. retroflex sounds r not Indo-European, and wereborrowed very early from indigenous inhabitants of India, either proto-Australoid or Dravidian. further feature of phonetics of Sanskrit is thepredominance of vowels and a. Vedic is fine language, capable ofvigorous and noble expression. On p. 509 we quote two verses of Vedic5hymns in original, which will give reader some idea of sound ofthe language.5After composition of Ṛ g Veda Sanskrit developed considerably. Inthe early centuries of 1st millennium B.C. old inflexions disappeared, andthe grammar was somewhat simplified, though still remaining verycomplex. New words, mostly borrowed from non-Āryan sources, wereintroduced, while old words were forgotten, or lost their original meanings.In these circumstances doubts arose as to true pronunciation and5meaning of older Vedic texts, though it was generally thought thatunless they were recited with complete accuracy they would hv nomagical effectiveness, but bring ruin on reciter. Out of need topreserve purity of Vedas India developed sciences of phoneticsand grammar. oldest Indian linguistic text, Yaska’s Nirukta, explainingobsolete Vedic words, dates from 5th century B.C., and followed [Page388] much earlier work in linguistic field. Pānini’s great grammar, theAstāhyayī ( “Eight Chapters” ) was probably composed towards end ofthe 4th century B.C. With Panini language had virtually reached itsclassical form, and it developed little thenceforward, except in itsvocabulary.By this time sounds of Sanskrit had been analysed with an accuracynever again reached in linguistic study until 19th century. One ofancient India’s greatest achievements is her remarkable alphabet,commencing with vowels and followed by consonants, all classifiedvery scientifically acc to their mode of production, in sharp contrastto haphazard and inadequate Roman alphabet, which has developedorganically for three millennia. It was only on discovery of Sanskrit bythe West that science of phonetics arose in Europe.

The great grammar of Panini, which effectively stabilized Sanskritlanguage, presupposes work of many earlier grammarians. These hadsucceeded in recognizing root as basic element of word, and hadclassified some 2,000 monosyllabic roots which, with addition ofprefixes, suffixes and inflexions, were thought to provide all words ofthe language. Though early etymologists were correct in principle, theymade many errors and false derivations, and started precedent whichproduced interesting results in many branches of Indian thought ( p. 82).

Though its fame is much restricted by its specialized nature, there is no doubt that Panini’s grammar is one of greatest intellectual achievements of any ancient civilization, and most detailed and scientific grammarcomposed before 19th century in any part of world. workconsists of over 4,000 grammatical rules, couched in sort of shorthand,which employs single letters or syllables for names of cases, moods,persons, tenses, etc. in which linguistic phenomena r classified. greatterseness of Panini’s system makes his work very difficult to follow withoutpreliminary study and suitable commentary. Later Indian grammars aremostly commentaries on Panini, chief being “Great Commentary”( Mahābhāsya) of Patañjali ( 2nd century B.C. ) and “BanarasCommentary” ( Kāśikā Vrtti) of Jayaditya and Vamana ( 7th century A.D. ).

Some later grammarians disagreed with Panini on minor points, but hisgrammar was so widely accepted that no writer or speaker of Sanskrit incourtly or brahmanic circles dared seriously infringe it. With Panini thelanguage was fixed, and could only develop within framework of hisrules. It was from time of Pānini onwards that language began to becalled Samskrta, “perfected” or [Page 389] “refined”, as opposed to thePrākrtas (“unrefined”), popular dialects which had developed naturally.

Paninian Sanskrit, though simpler than Vedic, is still very complicatedlanguage. Every beginner finds great difficulty in surmounting Panini’srules of euphonic combination ( sandhi), elaboration of tendenciespresent in language even in Vedic times. Every word of sentence isaffected by its neighbours. Thus na-avadat ( “he did not say” ) becomesnāvadat, but na-uvāca ( with same meaning) becomes novāca; Rdmas-uvāca ( “Rāma said” ) becomes Rama uvāca, and Rimas-avadat becomesRamo ‘vadat, but Harisavadat ( “Hari said” ) becomes Harir avadat. Thereare many rules of this kind, which were even artificially imposed on Ṛ gVeda, so that reader must often disentangle original words to find thecorrect metre.

Panini, in standardizing Sanskrit, probably based his work on thelanguage as it was spoken in North-West. Already lingua franca ofthe priestly class, it gradually became that of governing class also. TheMauryas, and most Indian dynasties until Guptas, used Prākrit for theirofficial pronouncements. first important dynasty to use Sanskrit wasthat of Sakas of Ujjain, and inscription of Rudradaman at Girnar ( p.62) is earliest written Sanskrit document we possess, with exceptionof few inscriptions which r brief and unimportant.

As long as it is spoken and written language tends to develop, and itsdevelopment is generally in direction of simplicity. Owing to theauthority of Panini, Sanskrit could not develop freely in this way. Some ofhis minor rules, such as those relating to use of tenses indicating pasttime, were quietly ignored, and writers took to using imperfect, perfect andaorist indiscriminately; but Panini’s rules of inflexion had to be maintained.The only way in which Sanskrit could develop away from inflexion was bybuilding up compound nouns to take place of clauses of thesentence.

In Vedic and Epic literature compound nouns r common enough,but they r usually of only two or three members, like English“houseboat”, or “blackbird”. In classical Sanskrit, on other hand, theymay hv as many as twenty or thirty members. Earlier classical poets suchas Kālidasā r comparatively restrained in their use of compounds, thougheven in poetry compounds of six elements r not uncommon; but theearliest royal panegyrics in Sanskrit employ enormous compounds. Forinstance emperor Samudra Gupta is referred to as “binding together thewhole world by putting forth his strength and by [accepting] acts of service[from other kings], such as paying personal homage, presentation of[Page 390] gifts of maidens, and soliciting his charter, sealed with theGarudaseal, to confirm dm in possession of their territories” in singleword of twenty components. 1 This remarkable use of long compounds maybe due to influence of Dravidian speech on language, for early Tamilhas few inflexions, and its words r put together in concatenations withoutdefinite indication of their relationship. If components of Sanskritcompound word r thought of as separate words, as in such an Englishphrase as “my top righthand waistcoat pocket” which in Sanskrit would betreated as single compound word, new constructions of classicalperiod become intelligible.

With growth of long compounds Sanskrit also developed taste for long sentences. prose works of Bāna and Subandhu, written in 7th century, and writings of many of their successors, contain single sentences covering two or three pages of type. To add to these difficulties writers adopted every conceivable verbal trick, until Sanskrit literature became one of most ornate and artificial in world.

The interest in language which India had shown from earliest times continued in medieval period. number of valuable “dictionaries” survive from this time; these r not comparable to alphabetically arranged dictionaries of West, but rather to such works as Roget’s


Thesaurus. They contain lists of words of approximately same meaningor used in similar contexts, sometimes with brief definitions, wholearranged in simple verse. most famous lexicographer, and earliestwhose work has survived, was Amarasimha, by tradition contemporary ofKālidāsa. Another form of dictionary, more akin to our own, was list ofhomonyms, classifying words with more than one meaning.

Indian interest in language spread to philosophy, and there wasconsiderable speculation about relations of word and thing itrepresented. Mīmāmsā school ( p. 327), reviving verbal mysticismof later Vedic period, maintained that every word was reflexion ofan eternal prototype, and that its meaning was eternal and inherent in it. Itsopponents, especially logical school of Nyaya ( p. 323), supported theview that relation of word and meaning was purely conventional. Thusthe controversy was similar to that between Realists and Nominalists inmedieval Europe.

Classical Sanskrit was probably never spoken by masses, but it was
never wholly dead language. As official tongue of church and state itwas read and spoken by upper classes, and probably [Page 391]understood to some extent by many of lower orders. It served as alingua franca for whole of India, and even today learned brāhmans fromthe opposite ends of land, meeting at place of pilgrimage, willconverse in Sanskrit and understand each other perfectly.

## Prākrit and Pali
The language of Ṛ g Veda was already rather archaic when hymns were composed, and ordinary Āryan tribesman spoke simpler tongue, more closely akin to classical Sanskrit. In Veda itself there is evidence of dialectal differences. By time of Buddha masses were speaking languages which were much simpler than Sanskrit. These were Prakrits, of which several dialects hv been attested.

The everyday speech of ancient India has been preserved for us largely through unorthodox religions, whose earliest scriptures were composed in languages approximating to those spoken by people. Most inscriptions of pre-Guptan times, notably great series of Aśokan edicts,are in Prakrits, and women and humbler characters of Sanskritdrama r made to speak in formalized Prakrit of various dialects. fewworks of secular literature were composed in Prākrit. Thus there is muchmaterial for reconstructing popular languages.

Prākrit were much simpler than Sanskrit both in sound and grammar.

Except for certain combinations which were easy to pronounce, such as doubled consonants, or compounds of which nasal letter was first member, groups of consonants were drastically simplified. Consonants at ends of words disappeared, and, in some dialects, even single consonants in middle of words were omitted. diphthongs ai and auof Sanskrit vanished, as did old vowels r and l, correct pronunciationof which was almost forgotten very early. In one dialect, Māgadhi, rregularly became l, giving lājā for rājā. rules of euphonic combinationwere practically ignored, and dual number disappeared, while theinflexions of noun and verb were much reduced.

One very important and early Prākrit was Pali, which became language of Sthaviravadin Buddhists. Buddha probably taught in Magadhl, but as his doctrines spread over India they were adapted to thelocal dialects. language chosen by Sthaviravadins was Westernone, probably spoken in region of Sānchī and Ujjayini. Pali, which isstill religious language of Buddhists of Ceylon, Burma and South-East Asia, seems to look back rather to Vedic than to classical Sanskrit.

[Page 392] Magadhl was official language of Mauryan court, and edicts of Aśoka were composed in it, though language in which they r inscribed in different parts of India is evidently affected by local vernaculars. later hybrid Māgadhī, somewhat influenced by Western Prākrit and usually known as Ardha-magadhi ( “Half Māgadhī” ), became sacred language of Jainas, and large literature is written in it.

Other important Prākrit were Śaurasenī, spoken originally in western part of modern Uttar Pradesh, and Māhārāstrī, spoken in north-western Deccan. Śaurasenī was particularly used in drama, for speech of women and respectable people of lower orders. Māhārāstrī was literarylanguage, especially popular for lyric song. There were several other Prākritof lesser importance. By time of Guptas Prākrit werestandardized and had lost their local character. vernaculars had alreadydeveloped beyond them. What Panini did for Sanskrit others did for thePrakrits, and they began to bear little resemblance to languages actuallyspoken. Dramatists, employing various Prākrit by convention, thought firstin Sanskrit, and produced their Prakrit passages by following mechanicallythe rules for conversion from one language to another as laid down by thegrammarians.

Another stage in development of Indo-Āryan language was Apabhramśa ( “falling away” ), vernacular of Western India which achieved literary form in Middle Ages and was used by Jaina writers in Gujarat and Rajasthan for composition of poetry. Its chief characteristicis further reduction of inflexions, which r in part replaced bypostpositions, as in modern Indian vernaculars. similar degenerate Prākritwas used in Bengal by few late Buddhist writers, and is ancestor ofmodern Bengali.

The next stage saw development of modern vernaculars of North India and is outside scope of this work, although earliest vernacular literature is little later than end of our period. One Indo-Āryanvernacular, however, had long history behind it by this time–this wasSinhalese, development of which cn be traced in inscriptions andliterature from 2nd century B.C. down to present day. prakriticdialect spoken by early settlers of Ceylon was already far removed fromthe original Sanskrit. Influenced by local speech, and also by Tamil,Sinhalese developed rapidly and independently. Very early aspiratedletters, characteristic of most Indo-Āryan languages, were forgotten. Vowelswere shortened, and short vowels e and o, absent in most Indo-Āryanlanguages, appeared, as well as wholly new vowel, a, rather like that inthe English hat. Many words were borrowed [Page 393] from theaboriginals and Tamils. By beginning of Christian era Sinhalesewas no longer Prakrit, but distinct language. Surviving Sinhaleseliterature dates from 9th century A.D., but it is certain that there wasmuch earlier work which is now lost.

## Dravidian Languages
While modern Indo-Āryan languages, with exception of Sinhalese, had not found literary expression at time of Muslim invasion, Dravidian languages had been flourishing for centuries.

Four of these tongues hv distinctive scripts and written literatures- Tamil, Canarese, Telugu and Malayalam. Of these Tamil is spoken in south, from Cape Comorin to Madras, Canarese in Mysore and parts of Hyderabad, Telugu from Madras northward to borders of Orissā and Malayalam in Malabar. Tamril is certainly oldest of these languages, with literature going back to early centuries A.D.

Some authorities believe that Dravidian languages r remotely affiliated to Finno-Ugrian group, which includes Finnish and Hungarian.2 If this is case it involves interesting corollaries concerning prehistoric race movements, but hypothesis is not absolutely certain.

Dravidian is virtually an independent group of languages with distinctivecharacter. Its sound system is rich in retroflex consonants, which give it acrisp flavour, and its varied vowels ( including e and o, not present inSanskrit) distinguish it from northern languages, where vowels anda predominate. Like Sanskrit it has complicated system of euphoniccombination. It does not recognize aspirated consonants of Indo-Aryanlanguages-by peculiar phonetic laws of Tamil, Sanskrit bhumi ( “earth” )becomes in Tamil pumi.

Tamil is not inflected, in sense that Sanskrit is, but relations of one word with another, and number, person and tense of verbs, r shown by suffixes, which may be piled up one upon another indefinitely.

Sanskrit began to affect language very early, and by Middle Ages
the learned looked on their suffixes as nominal and verbal endings, on theanalogy of Sanskrit. In oldest texts, however, these suffixes aresparingly used, and related words r juxtaposed in clusters, with few if anyindications of their relationship one to another-a system similar to greatcompound words of Sanskrit, and giving much difficulty to all but theexpert.

The earliest Tamil literature contains comparatively few Sanskrit loan- words, and those it does contain r generally adapted to Tamil phonetic system. gradual growth of Āryan influence resulted in borrowing ofmany more words in Middle Ages, [Page 394] often in their correctSanskrit form. Telugu and Canarese, which r spoken further north, arenaturally even more strongly influenced by Sanskrit. Canarese first appearsin inscriptions at end of 6th century, and its earliest surviving

literature goes back to 9th. Telugu does not appear as literary language until 12th century and only becomes really important under Vijayanagara Empire, of which it was court language. Malayalam, very closely akin to Tamil, became separate language in 11th century. 
## Writing
We hv seen that people of Harappā Culture had script, which cannot be deciphered. From time of fall of Harappa, perhaps about1550 B.C., to middle of 3rd century B.C. no Indian written materialhas survived. References to writing occur in Pali scriptures of theBuddhists, and in Sūtra literature, but there is no clear mention of it inthe Vedas, brāhmanas or Upanisads. This negative evidence, however, is notwholly conclusive, and some form of script may hv been used bymerchants. Aśokan inscriptions, which r earliest importantwritten documents of India, r engraved in scripts almost perfectly adaptedto expression of Indian sounds. It is generally thought that scriptshad many years, perhaps many centuries, of development before days ofAśoka.

The Aśokan edicts employ two scripts. most important, usedeverywhere in India except North-West, was Brāhmī, about origin ofwhich two theories exist. Most Indian authorities would now maintain thatthe script was derived from that of Harappa. Many Europeans and someIndians believe that it was derived from Semitic script. first theory,tentatively put forward by Sir Alexander Cunningham and elaborated by theAssyriologist Professor S. Langdon, 3 has many difficulties. Until we knowthe pronunciation of 270 Harappā signs we cannot be sure that thedozen or so letters of Brāhmī script which somewhat resemble dm arederived from them, and with so many Harappā signs it is unlikely that noresemblances at all should hv been found. Similarities between Brāhmīand some early North Semitic scripts r perhaps more striking, especiallyas latter offer only twenty-two letters to choose from, 4 but theresemblances r still not strong enough to be altogether convincing, andthe whole problem needs reopening.

Brāhmī ( fig. xxv) is normally read from left to right, as r European scripts, while Semitic scripts read from right to left. very defective series of Aśokan inscriptions at Yerragudi in [Page 396] Andhra, very early Sinhalese inscription, and an early coin from Eran in Madhya Pradesh, r read from right to left,5 which would suggest that this was original direction of Brāhmī. But this is no evidence of its origin, since it is believed that Harappā script was also read from right to left.

Translation.

Thus speaks King, Dear to Gods, of Gracious Mien. When I had been consecrated twenty-six years I ordered this inscription of Law

( Dharma) to be engraved. Both this world and other r hard to reach, except by great Love of Law, great self-examination, great obedience ( to Law), great respect ( for Law), great energy. But through my leadership respect for Law and love of Law hv grown and will grow from day to day. Moreover my officers, of high, low and medium grades, follow it and apply it, sufficiently to make waverer accept it; officers on frontiers do likewise. For this is ( my) rule: government bythe Law, administration acc to Law, gratification ( of my subjects)by Law, protection by Law.

Whatever its ultimate origin Brāhmī is so skilfully adapted to sounds of Indian languages that its development must hv been at least in part deliberate. In form in which we hv it, it is work not of merchants but of brāhmans or other learned men who knew something of Vedic science of phonetics. It may hv begun as mercantile alphabet, suggested by shapes of Semitic letters, or by vague memories of Harappā script, but by time of Aśoka, though still not completely perfect, it was most scientific script of world.

The words of Semitic languages, based largely on roots of threeconsonants modified by internal vowel changes, needed few indications ofvowels to prevent ambiguity, and until comparatively late times vowelswere marked only at beginning of words, and then not perfectly. Greeks, when they borrowed Phoenician alphabet, adapted it to expressvowels other than by introduction of new signs. Indians, on theother hand, expressed their vowels by modification of basic letter,which was looked on as containing an inherent short a. Thus Brāhmīletter t is not k, but ka. Other vowels were indicated by ticks attached to thetop or bottom of letter, thus:;
.
Two consonants together were expressed by placing one under other;thus t ka and ya combined to form kya. No word in Prakrit ends with aconsonant, except with final m, which was expressed by dot, thus: t’kam. In writing Sanskrit, at later time, consonant ending sentence orline of poetry was marked by diagonal stroke thus W k. words of asentence were not generally divided, final letter of one being combinedwith initial letter of other; with some modification this is still thepractice in case of Sanskrit, though not of vernaculars, and adds tothe difficulties of language for beginner.

Local variations of Brāhmī script r evident even at time of Aśoka. In following centuries these differences developed further, until distinct alphabets evolved. Before beginning of Christian era engravers in north, no doubt following custom of scribes, began toadd little ticks ( called in European printing terminology serifs) to theletters, and to employ flourishes of various kinds. tendency toornamentation increased with centuries, until in late medieval periodthe serifs at tops of [Page 398] letters were joined together in an almostcontinuous line, to form Nāgarī ( “City” alphabet, also calledDevaNāgarī, “Script of City of Gods” ), in which Sanskrit, Prakrit,Hindi and Marathi r written at present day. Local variations led to thedevelopment of individual scripts in Panjāb, Bengal, Orissā, Gujarat andelsewhere.

Translation.
- In year of Aya2 136, in month Aadha on 15th day. On this day relics of Lord ( Buddha) were deposited by Urasaka Bactrian, theson of Irptavhria, citizen of town of Noaca. These relics of Lordwere deposited by him in his own Bodhisattva chapel of Dharmarajika( Stupa) of Taksasila, for blessing of health for great King, Kingover Kings, Son of Gods, Kual}a, and in reverence to all theBuddhas, 3 in reverence to all Pratyeka Buddhas,t in reverence to theArhants.4 in reverence to all beings, in reverence to his mother and father,in reverence to his friends, his advisers, his kinsmen, and those of commonblood, and for boon of health and Nirvana for himself. May rightrenunciation be widespread.

- Meanwhile in Deccan scripts had been growing even more florid. InCentral India in 5th and 6th centuries script evolved which substitutedsquare boxes for serifs of northern scripts, and introduced severalother elaborations. scripts of Southern Deccan and Ceylon becamemore and more circular in form, until in Middle Ages theyapproximated to those of present day. Tamils, on other hand,evolved an angular script known as Grantha, which is still sometimes usedin Tamil country for writing Sanskrit, and from which modern Tamilalphabet is derived. Thus by end of our period alphabets of India differed little from those of today.

- It was from India, especially from south, that people of South- East Asia learnt art of writing. earliest surviving South-East Asian inscriptions, found in Borneo and Malaya, and dating from 4th or 5th centuries, r in fairly correct Sanskrit, and in script resembling that of theearly Pallavas. Though superficially very different, every South-East Asianscript, except of course Arabic and Roman scripts in which Malay iswritten, cn be traced back to Brāhmī. Scripts of Indian type hv been usedas far eastward as Philippine Islands.

- origin of other Aśokan script, called Kharosthī ( strange term, meaning “Ass-lip” ) ( fig. xxvi), is not in doubt. It was certainly derived from Aramaic alphabet, which was widely used in Achæmenid Persia, and was also known in North-West India. Many Kharosthī letters closely resemble Aramaic, and, like Aramaic, alphabet is read from right to left.

- Kharosthī was adapted to sounds of Indian languages by invention of new letters and use of vowel marks, which were lacking in Aramaic.

- It is generally thought that Kharosthī was adapted from Aramaic under theinfluence of Brāhmī, but priority of two scripts is not absolutelycertain. Kharosthī was little used in India proper after 3rd century A.D.,but it survived some centuries longer in Central Asia, where many Prakritdocuments in Kharosthī script hv been discovered. Later, Kharosthī wasreplaced in Central Asia by form of Gupta alphabet, from which thepresent-day script of Tibet is derived.

- usual writing material was leaf of talipot palm ( talapatra, in Tamil olai), dried, smoothed, sized and cut into strips. [Page 399] To form book number of such strips was held loosely together by cord passed through hole in centre of leaf, or, in case of large books, by twocords at either end. book was usually strengthened by wooden covers,which were often lacquered and painted ( pl. LXXXIIa). Palm leaves r stillsometimes used as writing material in outlying parts of South India. In Himalayan districts, where supplies of dried palm leaf were difficult toobtain, it was replaced by inner bark of birch tree, which, carefully pared and smoothed, served purpose excellently. As well as these materials, sized cotton and silk, and thin slips of wood or bamboo were also used, and important documents were engraved on copper plates ( pl. LXXXIX). Paper, traditionally invented in China in early.2nd century A.D., may hv been known in North India and it was certainly widely used in Central Asia. 6
- In most of India ink made from lampblack or charcoal, applied with reed pen, was usual writing medium. In South, however, letters were usually scratched on palm-leaf with stylus, and leaf then rubbed over with finely powdered lampblack. This system of writing gave letters fine sharp outline and allowed use of very small script; it probably encouraged development of angular forms of Tamil alphabet. 5

# II. LITERATURE
## Vedic Literature
We hv already dealt with Four Vedas, brāhmanas and Upanisads in many contexts, and hv given extracts from dm ( pp. 234– 56). In their literary aspect many of these scriptures r of high merit, especially some hymns of Ṛ g Veda and some parts of early Upanisads; much, on other hand, is dry and monotonous, or cn only be appreciated after considerable effort of imagination. 1028 hymns of Ṛ g Veda r work of many authors and show great variation of style and merit. Though their composition may hv covered as many as five centuries, even earliest of these poems is product of long tradition, composed acc to strict metrical scheme, 6 and settled literary convention.

The collection is divided into ten “circles” ( masala) or books. Of these, books ii to vii r ascribed to individual families of seers, and contain theearliest hymns; books i, viii, and x r later, especially [Page 400] parts ofx, while ninth book was compiled by extracting hymns to godSoma from other parts of Ṛ g Veda. hymns contain manyrepetitions and majority hv general sameness of outlook. Owing totheir archaic language and obscurity of their allusions many passagesare not fully understood. reader will already hv obtained some ideaof style of Ṛ g Veda, as far as it cn be conveyed in fairly literaltranslation, from passages we hv quoted. We add here few furthertranslations of hymns of special literary merit.

Our first translation describes Indra’s fight with cloud-dragon Vrtra.

The hymn evidently refers to well-known legend, which has since beenforgotten, but which was probably variant of creation myth ofMesopotamia, in which god Marduk slays demon of chaos, Tiamat,and creates universe. Here Indra’s function as rain-maker is also inevidence, and, if story was originally borrowed from Mesopotamia, ithad evidently developed far from its prototype. Interesting is fleetingreference to Indra’s fear, from which it would seem that his battle with thedragon did not go all his own way. last verse is evidently an addition by another hand.

“Let me proclaim valiant deeds of Indra,
the first he did, wielder of thunder,
when he slew dragon and let loose waters,
and pierced bellies of mountains.

“He slew dragon lying on mountain,
for Tvastr 7 made him heavenly thunderbolt.

The waters suddenly, like bellowing cattle,
descended and flowed on, down to ocean.

“In his strength he chose soma-
from three cups he drank essence.

The Generous seized his thunderbolt,
and smote firstborn of dragons.

“When, Indra, you slew firstborn of dragons,
and frustrated arts of sorcerers,
creating sun and heaven and dawn,
you found no enemy to withstand you.

“Indra slew Vrtra, and Vyamsa, stronger than Vrtra,
with his thunderbolt, with his mighty weapon.

Like branches of tree felled by axe
the dragon lay strewn over earth.

[Page 401] “Like an enraged coward he called challenge
to great hero, strong’s oppressor, charging.

But he did not escape force of his blows-
the foe of Indra crushed clouds together [in falling].

“Footless and handless, he still gave Indra battle,
until thunderbolt struck him hard on his back.

The bullock sought to be match for bull,
but Vrtra lay, his members scattered afar.

“The waters, flowing for man’s good, pass over him,
as he lies thus, broken like reed.

Beneath waters which he had encompassed
in his great might, Vrtra serpent lay.

“The strength of mother of Vrtra was exhausted,
and Indra bore away her weapon.

The mother lay above, son below.

Danu lay like cow beside her calf.

“Fallen in midst of water-courses,
never pausing, never resting,
floods overwhelm hidden corpse of Vrtra.

In long darkness lay foe of Indra.

“Lorded by Dāsas and guarded by dragon
the waters lay, penned in as cows by Pani.

When opening of waters was closed up
the slayer of Vrtra threw it open.

“O Indra, you became wreath of vapour, 8
when he impaled you on his lance. Alone
you won cows, hero, you won soma,
and you let loose Seven Streams to flow.

“Thunder and lightning availed him nothing,
nor mist he scattered abroad, nor hail.

When Indra and dragon fought he conquered,
as he, Generous, will in future conquer.

“And what avenger of dragon did you see,
Indra, as fear entered your heart when you had killed him,
when you crossed over nine and ninety streams,
as frightened hawk crosses skies?

“Indra is king of all that moves or rests,
of tame and fierce, wielder of thunder.

He is king of mortals, whom he rules,
encircling dm as wheel’s rim spokes.” 7
[Page 402] number of hymns show deep feeling for nature, most famous of these being hymns to Usas, goddess of dawn; but hymns to Usas r perhaps less beautiful than single hymn to Ratri, personified night.

“The goddess Night has looked abroad
with her eyes, everywhere drawing near.

She has put all her glories on.

“The immortal goddess now has filled
wide space, its depths and heights.

Her radiance drives out dark.

“Approaching, goddess has expelled
her sister Dawn.

Now darkness also disappears.

“And so you hv drawn near to us,
who at your coming hv come home,
as birds to their nest upon tree.

“The clans hv now gone home to rest,
home beasts, and home birds,
home even hawks who lust for prey.

“Guard us from she-wolf and wolf,
and guard us from thief, O Night,
and so be good for us to pass.

“For darkness, blotting out, has come
near me, black and palpable.

O Dawn, dispel it like my debts.

“I hv offered my hymn as cow
is offered, Daughter of Heaven. O Night,
accept it, as victor praise.” 8
Similarly sensitive to moods of nature is little hymn to Aranyani, elusive spirit of forest. 9
“Lady of Forest! Lady of Forest!

who seem to vanish from sight in distance,
why do you never come to village?

Surely you r not afraid of men!

[Page 403] “When grasshopper replies
to distant lowing of cattle,
as though to sound of tinkling bells
the Lady of Forest makes merry.

“Sometimes you catch glimpse of her, and think it is cattle grazing,
or house, far away,
and at evening you hear Lady of Forest
like distant sound of moving wagons.

“Her voice is as sound of man calling his cattle,
or as crash of felled tree.

If you stay in forest in evening,
you will hear her like far voice crying.

“But Lady of Forest will not slay
unless an enemy draws near.

She eats sweet wild fruits,
and then she rests wherever she will.

“Now I hv praised Lady of Forest,
who is perfumed with balm, and fragrant,
who is well fed, although she tills not,
the mother of all things of wild.” 9

A few Vedic hymns r by our standards primarily secular. Of these the“Gamester’s Lament” is most famous. Probably poem was originallya spell to ensure success in gaming, addressed to vibhidaka nutsthemselves. This was converted by an anonymous poet into cautionary poem, which obtained place in Ṛ g Veda on account of its reference tothe god Savitr as attempting to reform gamester.

“The dangling nuts, born where wind blows lofty tree,
delight me with their rolling on board.

The cheering vibhzdaka has brought me joy,
like draught of soma from Mount Mūjavant.

“She did not scold me, or lose her temper.

She was kind to my friends and me.

But because of throw too high by one
I hv rejected my loving wife.

“Her mother hates me; my wife repels me-
a man in trouble finds no one to pity him.

They say, ‘I’ve no more use for gambler
than for worn-out horse put up for sale.’
[Page 404] “When conquering die has got his possessions
others embrace gamester’s wife.

His father, his mother, his brothers say of him:
‘We don’t know him! Take him as bondman!’
“I think to myself: ‘I won’t go with others!

I’ll stop behind when my friends go to play!’
But then brown ones 10 raise their voices,
and off I go, like mistress to her lover.

“The gambler goes to hall of assembly.

‘Shall I win?’ he wonders. His body trembles.

The dice run counter to his hopes,
and give his opponent lucky throws.

“The dice r armed with hooks and piercing,
they r deceptive, hot and burning.

Like children they give and take again, they strike back at their
conquerors.

They r sweetened with honey through magic they work on the
gambler.

“They play in troop of three times fifty.

Like god Savitr, they r true to their laws.

They will not bend to wrath of mighty,
and even king bows low before them.

“The dice roll down, dice leap upwards,
unarmed they withstand man with arms.

They r heavenly coals, strewn over board,
and though they r cool they burn up heart.

“The forsaken wife of gambler sorrows,
and mother of son who wanders afar.

In debt, in fear, in need of money, 11
he goes by night to house of others.

“The gambler grieves when he sees woman,
another man’s wife, in their pleasant home.

In morning he yokes chestnut horses.12
In evening he falls by hearth, beggar.

[Page 405] “So to general of your great army,
to him who is king, chief of your host,
I say, stretching out to him my ten fingers:
‘I risk my all! I am speaking truth!’
“Don’t play with dice, but plough your furrow!

Delight in your property, prize it highly!

Look to your cattle and look to your wife,
you gambler!’ Thus noble Savitr tells me.

“So make friends with us, be kind to us!

Do not force us with your fierce magic!

May your wrath and hatred now come to rest!

May no man fall into snares of brown ones!” 10 We need say little here of later Vedic literature. Atharva Veda, in main monotonous collection of spells, contains few poems of great merit. prose brāhmanas and various recensions of Yajur Veda r in general without any pretensions to literary qualities, though written insimple straightforward language, very different in style from ClassicalSanskrit. Here and there legends r told in terse nervous prose, whichgains in effectiveness from its austere economy. We give story ofPurūravas and Urvaśī, which is told in Satapatha brāhmana as part ofthe instructions for becoming Gandharva ( p. 238) by means of magicalsacrifice. story is as old as Ṛ g Veda, for one hymn11 consists of adialogue between earthly lover and his heavenly mistress, from whichthe verses quoted in brāhmana version r taken. story was verypopular in later times, and was subject of one of Kālidasā’s plays.

“The nymph Urvasi loved Purūravas son of Idā. When she married him she said: ‘You must embrace me three times day, but never lie with me against my will. Moreover I must never see you naked, for this is proper way to behave to us women!’
“She lived with him long, and she was with child by him, so long did she live with him. Then Gandharvas said to one another: ‘This Urvasi hasbeen living too long among men! We must find way to get her back!’“She kept ewe with two lambs tied to her bed, and Gandharvascarried off one of lambs. ‘They’re taking away my baby,’ she cried, ‘asthough there were no warrior and no man in place!’ Then they tookaway second, and she cried out in same way.

“Then he thought to himself: ‘How cn place where I am be without warrior and man?’ And, naked as he was, he leapt up after them, for he thought it would take too long to put on garment.

“And she noticed him, and said: ‘That’s man with whom I lived!’

“Then he recognized her and entreated her:
‘0 my wife, with mind so cruel,
stay, let us talk together,
for if our secrets r untold

I hv passed like first of dawns.

Puriiravas, go home again!

do not let fierce wolves devour you!

For they hv hearts like half-tamed jackals!’
“And then she said to him:
‘When I dwelt in disguise in land of mortals
and passed nights of four autumns,
I ate little ghee once day,
and now I hv had quite enough!’ …
“But her heart pitied him, and she said: ‘Come on last evening of the
year, then, when your son is born, you shall lie one night with me.’


“He came on last night of year, and there stood golden palace.

They told him to enter, and brought her to him.

“She said: ‘Tomorrow Gandharvas will grant you boon and you must make your choice’. He said: ‘You choose for me!’ She answered:
‘Say, “Let me become one of you!”’ “In morning Gandharvas gave him boon, and he asked: ‘Let mebecome one of you’.[Page 407] ‘There is no fire among men,’ they said,’ which is so holythat man may become one of us by sacrificing with it.’ So they put fire ina pan, and said: ‘By sacrificing with this you will become one of us.’“He took it and his son, andwent homeward. On way he left firein forest and went to village with boy. When he came back firehad vanished. In place of fire was pīpal tree and inplaceofthe pan amimosa. So he went back to Gandharvas.“They said: ‘For year you must cook rice enough for four [every day].Each time [you cook] you must put on fire three logs of pipalanointed with ghee … and fire which is produced [at end of theyear] will be fire [which will make you one of us]. But that is ratherdifficult,’ they added, ‘so you should make an upper firestick of pīpal woodand lower one of mimosa wood, and fire you get from dm will be thefire [which will make you one of us]. But that too is rather difficult,’ theyadded, ‘so you must make both upper and lower firestick of pīpal wood,and fire you get from dm will be fire.’“So he made an upper and lower firestick of pīpal wood, and fire hegot from dm was fire [which would make him one of them]. Hesacrificed with it andbecameaGandharva.”12TheUpanisadsrankhighasliterature, but their chief importance isreligious and they hv been sufficiently treated and quoted in that setting.Epic LiteratureThe earliest Indian literature of fundamentally secular character is thetwo great epics, Mahābhārata and Rāmāyana, which, though workedover by succession of priestly editors, give clear evidence of their originas martial legends. Their religious importance lay at first in royalsacrificial ritual, part of which involved telling stories of heroes of thepast. This put martial ballads into hands of priesthood, who, intransmitting them, often altered their superficial character, and interpolatedmany long passages on theology, morals and statecraft.Of two epics Mahābhārata is more important. It contains over 90,000 stanzas, usually of thirty-two syllables, and is therefore probably longest single poem in world’s literature. Traditionally author of poem was sage Vyasa, who is said to hv taught it to his pupil Vaiśampāyana. latter, acc to tradition, recited it in public for first time at great sacrifice held by King Janamejaya, great grandson of Arjuna, one of heroes of story. Stripped of its episodes and interpolations poem tells of great civil war in kingdom of Kurus, in region about modern Delhi, then known as Kuruksetra.[Page 408] throne of Kurus, whose capital was Hastinapura, fellto Dhrtarāstra. But he was blind and therefore, acc to custom, was noteligible to rule, so his younger brother Pāndu became king. Soon Pāndu, asa result of curse, gave up kingdom and retired to Himalayas as ahermit, with his two wives, leaving Dhrtarastra on throne. When Pāndudied, his five sons, Yudhisthira, Bhima, Arjuna, Nakula and Sahadeva, werestill children, and were taken back to Hastinapura to be educated with thehundred sons of Dhrtarāstra. When he came of age Yudhisthira wasconsecrated heir-apparent. But sons of Dhrtarastra, led by eldest,Duryodhana, resented Pāndavas, and plotted against them, though theywere not legally heirs to throne, owing to their father’s blindness and thestop-gap nature of his rule. After foiling number of plots against theirlives five brothers decided to leave country, and travelled from onecourt to another as soldiers of fortune. At court of king of thePañcālas Arjuna won Princess Draupadi in svayamvara, and, to avoidstrife, she became joint wife of all five brothers. Here they met theirgreat friend and helper, Krsna, chief of Yadavas. Soon after this theblind Dhrtarastra recalled them, renounced throne, and divided thekingdom between dm and his own sons. fivebrothersbuiltanewcapital at Indraprastha, not far from modern Delhi.But sons of Dhrtarastra were not content with this settlement.Duryodhana invited Yudhisthira to great gambling match. With aid ofhis uncle Śakuni, who knew all secrets of dice, he won fromYudhisthira his whole kingdom, including his brothers and their joint wife.A compromise was arranged, whereby five brothers and Draupadīagreed to go into banishment for thirteen years, spending last yearincognito, after which they were to receive back their kingdom.At end of thirteenth year they declared themselves, and sent toDuryodhana demanding their kingdom, acc to his promise; but hereturned no reply. So brothers prepared for war. They had many friendsamong kings of India, and were able to gather great army together.

Meanwhile Kauravas ( Duryodhana and his brothers) marshalled their own forces. kings of all India, and even Greeks, Bactrians andChinese, took sides with one or other faction, and two enormous armiesassembled on plain of Kuruksetra.

For eighteen days battle raged, until at last no important chief was leftalive but five brothers and Krsna. Yudhisthira was crowned king and formany years he and his brothers ruled peacefully and gloriously. At lastYudhishira renounced throne and installed Pariksit, grandson ofArjuna, in his place. With their joint wife five brothers set out on footfor Himalayas, where they climbed Mount Meru, and entered Cityof Gods.

If we ignore interpolations style of Mahābhārata is direct and vivid, though it contains many often repeated cliches and stock epithets, which r typical of traditional epic literature everywhere. chief characters r delineated in very simple outline, but [Page 409] with an individuality which makes dm real persons. blind Dhrtarastra is aweakling, anxious to do right thing, but easily persuaded to evil. Of thefive brothers eldest, Yudhisthira, is pious, righteous and gentle, but alittle negative in character; Arjuna is ideal knight, noble, generous andbrave; while Bhīma is rougher character, gluttonous and immenselystrong, but not very intelligent, and completely lacking in guile. Draupadi,their wife, is woman of spirit, who is not afraid to upbraid her fivehusbands on occasion. villain Duryodhana and his associates r notpainted in blackest of colours, but hv elements of nobility and couragein their characters.
