Gupta PeriodPLATE LXXVIISome of interpolated episodes r of much merit, while others r ofno literary value. longest is Śānti Parvan, dissertation on statecraftand ethics, recited by Bhīsma, elder statesman of Kurus, as he liesdying on pile of arrows after great battle ( p. 80). This has been treatedelsewhere and has little merit as literature. Bhagavad Gitā, sermonof Krsna to Arjuna before great battle, has already been quoted ( pp. 301,34of). There r many other theological and ethical passages, as well asmany narrative episodes. Some of latter tell legends of gods, butothers r more or less secular, including famous stories of Rama andSītā ( p. 412f), Sakuntala ( p. 435f), and Sāvitrī ( p. 181). longestnarrative episode is story of Nala and Damayanti, told to Yudhisthiraduring his exile to convince him of evils of gambling. It tells how KingNala won Princess Damayanti at svayamvara, at which she chose him inpreference to gods themselves, and then lost both his queen and hiskingdom at gambling tournament, to regain dm after many excitingadventures. This long story is probably as ancient as main part of theepic, and is told in very simple verse. As brief example of theMahabharata’s narrative style we give description of Damayanti’schoice. Among suitors at svayamvara r four great gods, who,knowing that she is determined to choose Nala, hv all taken hisappearance, in hope that she will choose one of dm by mistake.

“Then, when right time had come, at auspicious day and hour, King Bhima invited lords of earth to bride-choice.

“When they heard, lords of earth, all sick at heart with love, in haste assembled, desiring Damayanti.

[Page 410] “Like great lions kings entered hall, firmly founded, with its splendid porch and shining golden columns.

“There on their several thrones lords of earth sat down all decked in fragrant garlands, with bright gems in their ears.

“Their arms were thick as iron bars, shapely and smooth as five-headed snakes.

“With lovely shining locks, and well-formed noses, eyes and brows, faces of kings were bright as stars in heaven.

“Then fair-faced Damayanti
entered hall,
stealing with her splendour
the eyes and thoughts of kings.

“When glance of noble
spectators fell on her limbs
there it was fixed,
and never wavered.

“Then, while names of kings
were being proclaimed,
the daughter of Bhima saw
five men of same form.

“Whichever of dm she looked at
she recognized as Nala.

Wondering in her mind,
the fair one was filled with doubt.

‘Of all signs of godhead
that I learned from elders
I see not even one
in those who r standing here.’
“Thus thinking over and over,
and pondering again and again,
she resolved that time had come
to take refuge in gods.

[Page 411] ‘I heard from mouth of swans
that Nala had chosen me as his bride,
and so, if that be true,
may gods show him to me!

‘Never in word or deed
have I committed sin,
and so, if that be true,
may gods show him to me!

‘The gods hv ordained king of Nisadha to be my lord,and so, if that be true,may gods show him to me!’‘May great gods, world-protectorstake on their own true form,that I may recognizethe king of men, of good fame!’“When they heard Damayanti,mournful and piteousthey did as she had asked,and put on their true forms.

“She saw four gods
sweatless, not blinking their eyelids,
their garlands fresh and free from dust,
not touching ground with their feet.

“But king of Nisadha had shadow,his garlands were withered,his body bore dust and sweat,and he blinked his eyelids.

“The modest long-eyed girl
seized hem of his garment,
and on his shoulder she placed
the loveliest of garlands.

“She chose him for her lord,
she of fair complexion,
and suddenly all kings
together shouted and cheered.

“And all gods and sages
thereupon cried bravo,
and shouted at wonder,
praising Nala king.” 13

[Page 412] second epic, Rāmāyana, is rather different from Mahābhārata in style and content. It is little more than one quarter of size of other epic, and of its seven books first and last r certainly later additions. poem, like Mahabharata, contains manyinterpolations, but they r much briefer and r mostly didactic. mainbody of poem gives impression of being work of single hand,that of poet whose style was based on that of other epic, but showedsome kinship to that of classical Sanskrit poetry.

Though Rāmāyana does not contain so many archaic features as Mahabharata, and gives general impression of being later of two, Mahābhārata contains as an episode story of Rāma, in form which suggests that editor of final version of Mahdbharata knew Rāmāyana. Mahdbharata as it is at present is probably later than Ramayana, but its main narrative portions r appreciably earlier.

The traditional author of Rāmāyana was sage Valmiki, contemporary of its hero. In fact legend was perhaps committed to verse in form in which we hv it, but excluding first and last books, little before commencement of Christian era. central scene of poem is Ayodhya, capital of old kingdom of Kosala, and it evidently grew up in milieu to east of that of Mahābhārata.

Dasaratha king of Kosala had four sons by his three wives; sons’names were Rāma, Bharata, Laksmana and Satrughna. four attendedthe court of King Janaka of Videha, where Rāma won hand of Janaka’sdaughter, Sītā, at great archery contest. Rāma and Sītā were married and for time lived happily at court of Dasaratha. ( In this part of story,contained in first book of epic, Rāma is explicitly described as anincarnation of god Visnu, and original text has evidently been muchadded to and altered at late period. )When Dasaratha grew old he named Rāma as his heir; but his secondqueen, Kaikeyī, reminded her lord of boon which he had promised herlong since, and demanded its fulfilment in banishment of Rāma and theinstallation of her own son, Bharata, as heir apparent. Dasaratha andBharata both demurred, but Rāma insisted on his father fulfilling hispromise, and went into voluntary exile with Sītā and his brother Laksmana.

When Dasaratha died Bharata took over kingdom, but only as regent for
the exiled Rama.

Meanwhile Rāma, Sītā and Laksmana dwelt as hermits in forest of Dandaka, where Rāma destroyed many demons who were harassing ascetics and villagers. Rāvana, demon king of Lankā ( Ceylon), decided to avenge his fallen kinsmen, and, while Rāma and Laksmana were on ahunting expedition, came to their hermitage in guise of an ascetic,seized [Page 413] Sita, and carried her off to Lankā in his aerial car( vimāna). brothers sought far and wide for Sītā, and enlisted help ofSugriva, king of monkeys, and his general, brave and loyalHanumant. Hanumant went in search of Sītā, and, leaping over straits, atlast found her in Rāvana’s palace. With aid of great army of monkeysand bears Rama built causeway of stones across sea to Lankā. After afierce battle Rāma, Laksmana and their allies slew Rāvana and his hosts,and rescued Sītā.

Sita had been treated with respect by her captor, and had in no wayyielded to his blandishments. But she had dwelt under roof of anotherman, and Rāma, in accordance with Sacred Law, could do nothing butrepudiate her. She threw herself on funeral pyre, but fire-god Agnirefused to accept her. After this proof of her innocence she was reunitedwith Rāma, and two returned to Ayodhya, where Bharata renounced thethrone and Rāma was crowned, to rule long and righteously.

The last book, certainly an addition, gives an unnecessary sequel to story, which was probably added on account of growing prejudice, and misgivings about Sītā’s lawful status after her unwilling residence in her captor’s house. people murmured because their queen had been forced to break her marriage vows, and suspicions as to her purity were notallayed, even by her ordeal by fire. Though he was quite convinced of herinnocence Rama, whose first duty was to “please people”, wasregretfully forced to banish her, and she took refuge in Valmiki’s hermitage,where she gave birth to twins, Kusa and Lava. Years later Rāma found Sītāagain, and acknowledged her sons. As final proof of her innocence shecalled on her mother, Earth, 13 to swallow her up. earth opened, andshe disappeared. Soon after this Rāma returned to heaven, and resumed theform of god Visnu. 14The style of Rdmdyana is less rugged than that of Mahābhārata.

The latter contains occasional grammatical and prosodical errors, theformer few if any. It is work of greater art, but less vigour, though itcontains many dramatic passages, and beautiful descriptive writing, whichthe Mahābhārata lacks. We give much abridged translation of thedescription of death of Rāvana, which is typical of treatment ofbattle in both epics.

“Then Rāma, reminded
by words of Matali,
took his flaming arrow
like hissing snake….

[Page 414] “He spoke mantra upon it
as Vedas ordain.

The strong one placed in his bow
that great and mighty arrow. …
“Enraged he fiercely bent
his bow against Rāvana,
and, intent on his mark, he shot
the entrail-tearing arrow. …
“Bearing death of body
the arrow flew with great speed,
and tore through heart
of evil-working Rāvana.

“Then, red with his blood and rapid,
that arrow, destroyer of bodies,
robbing life-breath of Rāvana,
drove into face of earth …
“Swiftly struck from his hand,
his bow and his arrow
dropped, with his life-breath,
upon ground.

“Unbreathing, with awful speed,
the glorious lord of demons
fell from his chariot to earth,
like Vrtra struck by thunderbolt. 15
“When they saw him fallen to earth
the remaining demons of night
in terror, their lord destroyed,
fled in every direction. …
“Falling, struck down by monkeys,
they fled to Lankā in terror,
their faces swimming in tears,
piteous at loss of their refuge.

“And in joy monkeys
roared cheer of triumph
and proclaimed victory of Rama,
and his slaying of Rāvana.

[Page 415] “In sky there sounded
the lovely drums of gods,
and there blew pleasant wind
bearing heavenly fragrance.

“A rain of flowers fell
from heaven upon earth,
flowers rare and lovely

bestrewing Rama’s chariot.” 14 epic style and metre became usual for didactic literature of all kinds.

Much of this, Puranas, Dharma Sastras, and other texts, has been referred to elsewhere. They contain passages of literary merit, but we must pass dm over for great body of courtly literature.

## Classical Sanskrit Poetry
The earliest surviving Sanskrit poetry in classical style is that of theBuddhist poet Asvaghosa, who is believed to hv lived at end of 1stcentury A.D., and who composed metrical life of Buddha( Buddhacarita) in comparatively simple classical style. GirnarInscription of Rudradaman, dated A.D. 150, is earliest surviving exampleof courtly Sanskrit prose. Thus courtly style is comparatively latedevelopment in Indian literature, although it must hv had long period ofevolution before dates which we hv mentioned.

On whole classical Sanskrit literature has not been well received in West. Though works of Kālidasā delighted Goethe, literature taken as whole has been called artificial, over-ornate, lacking in truefeeling, or even an example of wasted and perverted ingenuity. Indiansthemselves r not always satisfied with it. Thus modern authority writes:“As result of particular demand in court atmosphere naturalspontaneity of poet was at discount. … Learning and adaptation tocircumstances were given more importance than pure flow of genius. …As result Sanskrit poetry not only became artificial but followed atraditional scheme of description. … magic of Sanskrit language …also led poets astray and led dm to find their amusement in verbalsonorousness.”15This judgement, which author later qualifies, is in part correct. It is,besides, an indication of how deeply modern India has been affected byEuropean æsthetic standards, judged by which much Indian classicalliterature is indeed artificial. It was written mainly for recitation orperformance at court, or for comparatively small circles [Page 416] oflitterati, all well versed in rigid canons of literary convention andhighly appreciative of verbal ingenuity. In such circumstances it would befutile to expect native wood-notes of Clare or natural mysticism ofa Wordsworth. poets lived in comparatively static society, and theirlives were controlled in detail by body of social custom which wasalready ancient and which had sanction of religion behind it. They werenever in revolt against social system, and Indian Shelleys andSwinburnes r lacking. Most of this literature was written by men wellintegrated in their society and with few of complex psychologicaldifficulties of modern literary man; hence spiritual anguish of aCowper, heart-searchings of Donne, and social pessimism of anearly T. S. Eliot, r almost entirely absent. Despite its reputation forpessimism in West, Hindu thought and literature is fundamentallyoptimistic, and tragic drama, or story with an unhappy ending, wasnot looked on with favour.

The chief raw materials of Indian poet were love, nature, panegyric,moralizing and story telling. Religious subjects, in sense of legends ofthe gods, r common enough, but deep religious feeling is comparativelyrare in courtly literature. few poets, such as Bhartrhari, wroteoccasionally on religious themes with intensity of deep faith, but for allits mythological trappings and polite invocations to deities classicalSanskrit poetry is predominantly secular. gods, when they appear, haveusually character of enlarged human beings.

Love was passionately physical, and we hv said something of theapproach of Indian poet to subject in another chapter ( p. 17 If). As inmost European literature of ancient and medieval times, nature was usuallytreated in its relation to man, and rarely described for its own sake. Thephenomena of seasons, day and night, birds and beasts and flowers, areemployed to frame human emotions, or r personified as counterparts ofthe human subjects of poet. But throughout literature deep love ofnature is implicit, especially in Kālidasā who, for this reason among others,has higher reputation in West than any other ancient Indian poet.

Panegyrics, in praise of king and his ancestors, r very numerous andform one of chief sources of our historical knowledge. element ofmoralizing is prominent in writing of most poets. Kālidasā wasparticularly fond of including generalizations of sententious or moralnature in his verses, and this practice was recognized as one of thelegitimate alamkiras ( “adornments” ) of Sanskrit poetry. Gnomic verses,often of dry worldly-wise humour, were very popular.

The technique of poetry was thoroughly studied and rules were [Page417] laid down in numerous textbooks. purpose of poetry is usuallydescribed as emotive; emotion aroused, however, is not pity andterror of Aristotle, but calmer experience, an æsthetic sensation based onfeeling lifted to such plane that grief is no longer felt as grief, and love nolonger as love-according to one definition “impersonalized and ineffableæsthetic enjoyment from which every trace of its component … material isobliterated.”16 basic rasas or “flavours” from which this æstheticexperience should arise r usually classified as eight-love, courage,loathing, anger, mirth, terror, pity and surprise. Theoretically every poemshould contain one or more of these flavours.

An important element in Sanskrit poetic theory was dhvani
( “reverberation” ), suggestion or incantation of words and phrases.

Words hv their denotations and their connotations, their primarymeanings and their undertones, and it is with these latter that poet has todo. By carefully choosing his words he cn make dm say far more thantheir bare meanings and induce whole series of emotions by single briefverse. Indian literary philosophers advanced far in this direction andproduced theories on psychology of poetic appreciation which, in broadoutline, would not be inacceptable to many modern poets of West. 16Perhaps most important tool of poet was alamkāra, orornamentation, which included simile and metaphor, generalization,punning, alliteration of various kinds, and so on. This branch of poetictechnique was also worked out in great detail by theorists, and freeuse of ornamentation resulted in poetry of great floridity. This wasencouraged by enormous number of synonyms and homonyms inSanskrit, and by very numerous and universally accepted stock epithets,such as “the mine of jewels” ( ratnakara) for “the sea”, “the unmoving”( acala) for “mountain”, “sky-goer” ( khaga) for “bird”, and “the frail”( abala) for “woman”. ancient Indian poet would hv been quite athome with Pope’s “denizens of air” and “finny tribes”.

The unit of poetry is stanza, usually grammatically complete in itself.

The mahākāvya, loosely translated “epic”, often degenerated into string of verses or groups of verses, linked only by very slender thread of narrative.

In more ornate courtly literature plot and construction r in generalweak, and there is little sense of balance. This is not case with purelynarrative poetry, as in such works as “Ocean of Story”, author ofwhich tells his tales [Page 418] with economy and restraint ( p. 429ff). Andoften, even in most ornate kāvya, poet will from time to time rise tothe occasion with vivid and dramatic description, though it must beadmitted that longer Sanskrit poem is usually prolix and shapeless.

On other hand individual verse is balanced and succinct. Single- verse poems, reminiscent of Persian rubā’ī or Japanese tanka, were very popular, either standing alone or included in dramas and prose works.

Many of these r very beautiful, and make an immediate appeal to Western reader, even in translation. They were collected in anthologies, of which number survive and hv preserved many lovely verses which would otherwise hv been lost.

Metrically Sanskrit poetry was quantitative, and rigidly regulated. Thenormal stanza was one of four quarters, each of length varying from eight totwenty-one syllables, generally equal and unrhymed. Epics usuallyemployed metre called śloka, of eight syllables to quarter, whichallowed some scope for variation; but classical poets preferred metres ofgreater complexity and rigidity, of which many r listed in textbooks onpoetics, though only dozen or so were popular. These metres allowed littleor no scope for variation and their syllables were arranged in complicatedpatterns, usually of great beauty. 17Owing to structure of Sanskrit, literal translation of classical Indianpoetry into English is quite impossible, and we cannot convey æstheticeffect of Sanskrit verse. brief extracts here translated in rhythmicprose give but faint impression of rich and closely knit texture of theoriginals or of wonderful sonority of language, which, when wellhandled, with all arts of prosody and ornamentation, surely has asplendour unsurpassed by any other language in world. Classical Indianpoetry, like Indian music and art, developed along lines of its own and itscanons r not those of West, but it has its own special merits andbeauties.

Indian and European judges alike agree that Kālidasā was greatest Sanskrit poet. He probably flourished in reigns of emperors Candra Gupta II and Kumāra Gupta I ( 375–455), and thus saw ancient Indian courtly culture at its zenith. Like murals of Ajanta, his work seems toreflect that culture completely and convincingly. Though deeply imbued intradition, he carried tradition lightly, and throughout his work hispersonality breaks through. few legends r told of him in late sources,but we hv no reliable information about his life and character. From hiswork he seems to hv been happy and gentle man, sympathetic tosorrow, deeply understanding moods of women and children, and lovingflowers [Page 419] and trees, beasts and birds, and pomp of courtceremonial. He was author of three dramas ( p. 435), two long poems,“The Birth of War-god” ( Kumarasambhava) and “Dynasty ofRaghu”( Raghuvamśa),andtwoshorter,the“Cloud-messenger”( Meghaduta) and “Garland of Seasons” ( Rtusamhāra),as well as of several other works which hv not survived.

The “Cloud Messenger” is work of little over 100 verses, which hasalways been one of most popular of Sanskrit poems. Its theme has beenimitated in one form or another by several later poets both in Sanskrit andthe vernaculars. More than most Indian poems this work has unity andbalance, and gives sense of wholeness rarely found elsewhere. In its smallcompass Kālidasā has crowded so many lovely images and word-picturesthat poem seems to contain quintessence of whole culture. Itdescribes yaksa who dwells in divine city of Alaka, in Himalayas.

He has offended his master Kubera ( p. 313 f), and has been banished for ayear to hill of Ramagiri, in modern Madhya Pradesh. worstaspect of his exile is his separation from his beautiful wife, whom he hasleft behind in mountain city. So, at beginning of rainy season, hesees large cloud passing northward to mountains, and pours out hisheart to it. After verse or two of introduction rest of poem consistsof yaksa’s address to cloud.

First he tells it route which it must take to reach mountains; hereKālidasā describes lands, rivers and cities over which it must pass invery beautiful verses. We quote two describing river Narmadā and theforests on its banks. Notable in first verse is bird’s-eye-view impliedin simile.

“Stay for while over thickets, haunted by girls of hill-folk,then press on with faster pace, having shed your load of water,and you’ll see Narmadā river, scattered in torrents, by ruggedrocks at foot of Vindhyas,looking like plastered pattern of stripes on flank of an elephant.

18
“Note by banks flowers of nīpa trees, greenish brown, with their stamens half developed, and plantains, displaying their new buds.

Smell most fragrant earth of burnt out woodlands, and as you release your raindrops deer will show you way.” 17 [Page 420] Then cloud is told to turn westward and visit splendid city of Ujjayaini. Kālidasā cannot long resist śrngāra rasa, eroticsentiment, and this is evoked by his description of city,“where wind from Sipra river prolongs shrill melodious cryof cranes,fragrant at early dawn from scent of opening lotus,and, like lover, with flattering requests,dispels morning languor of women, and refreshes their limbs.

“Your body will grow fat with smoke of incense from open windows where women dress their hair.

You will be greeted by palace peacocks, dancing to welcome you, their friend.

If your heart is weary from travel you may pass night above mansions fragrant with flowers, whose pavements r marked with red dye from feet of lovely women.”18 Then, as cloud nears Himalayas, it will see magic city “where yaksas dwell with lovely women in white mansions, whose crystal terraces reflect stars like flowers.

They drink wine of love distilled from magic trees, while drums beat softly, deeper than your thunder.” 19 Then yaksa describes his home, and his lovely wife, weak from sorrow and longing. He gives cloud message to her, that his love is still constant and that time of reunion is approaching.

“I see your body in sinuous creeper, your gaze in startled eyes of deer,your cheek in moon, your hair in plumage of peacocks,and in tiny ripples of river I see your sidelong glances,but alas, my dearest, nowhere do I find your whole likeness!” 20“The Birth of War-god” may be described as religious poem, butthough all its characters r supernatural, and include Śiva himself, theatmosphere of poem is essentially secular. It begins with finedescription of Himalayas, from which we quote few verses. Thedaring comparison of chain of mountains to surveyor’s measuring rodis worthy of John Donne, and gives another example of Kālidasā’s bird’s-eye-view approach.

“In northern quarter is divine Himalaya, lord of mountains, reaching from Eastern to Western Oceans, firm as rod to measure earth….[Page 421] “There demigods rest in shade of cloudswhich spread like girdle below peaks,but when rains disturb themthey fly to sunlit summits. …“The hollow canes r filled with windthat bursts from chasms,as though to provide an ostinatoto songs of heavenly minstrels …“All through night phosphorescent herbsshine in caverns with their glimmering radiance,and light lovesof hill-women and their paramours …“And wind forever shaking pinescarries spray from torrents of young Gangesand refreshes hunting hillman,blowing among his peacock plumes.”21The poem, which is long one, describes courtship and marriage ofŚiva and Pārvatī ( p. 309), and birth of their son, Kumāra or Skanda, thewar-god. As he grows to manhood Kumāra is appointed general of gods,and he leads dm forth to battle with terrible demon Taraka, who haslong been afflicting whole universe. Taraka hears of their approach,musters his forces, and goes out to meet them; but terrible omens greet thearmy of demons. Here Kālidasā embarks on remarkable description,which reminds us of more macabre work of Gustave Doré.

“A fearful flock of evil birds, ready for joy of eating army of demons, flew over host of gods, and clouded sun.

“A wind continually fluttered their umbrellas and banners, and troubled their eyes with clouds of whirling dust, so that trembling horses and elephants and great chariots could not be seen.

“Suddenly monstrous serpents, as black as powdered soot, scattering poison from their upraised heads, frightful in form, appeared in army’s path.

“The sun put on ghastly robe of great and terrible snakes, curling together, as if to mark his joy at death of enemy demon.

[Page 422] “And before very disc of sun jackals bayed harshly together, as though eager fiercely to lap blood of king of foes of gods, fallen in battle.

“Lighting heaven from end to end, with flames flashing all around, with an awful crash, rending heart with terror, thunderbolt fell from cloudless sky.

“The sky poured down torrents of red-hot ashes, with which were mixed blood and human bones, till flaming ends of heaven were filled with smoke and bore dull hue of neck of an ass.

“Like thundered threat of angry death-god great crash broke walls of ears, shattering sound, tearing tops of mountains, and wholly filling belly of heaven.

“The host of foe was jostled together.

The great elephants stumbled, horses fell, and all footmen clung together in fear, as earth trembled and ocean rose to shake mountains.

“And, before host of foes of gods, dogs lifted their muzzles to gaze on sun, then, howling together with cries that rent eardrums, they wretchedly slunk away.” 2219 poem ends with death of Taraka in single combat with Kumara.

We hv no space to discuss rest of Kālidasā’s poetry, all of which is  of fine quality. “The Dynasty of Raghu” especially contains many passages of great beauty, including concise version of [Page 423] story of Rāma, but work is apparently incomplete. “The Garland of Seasons” describes six seasons of Hindu year in relation to srngara, erotic sentiment, but though charming it is slighter and less impressive than rest of Kālidasā’s work.

Many other poets after Kālidasā, wrote mahakavyas, or long courtly “epics “, but none so ably as he. Kumaradasa’s “Rape of Sītā” ( Janaki- harana) continues his tradition, while Bharavi’s “Arjuna and Kirāta” ( Kiratarjuniya), describing an encounter of hero Arjuna and god Śiva, in guise of Kirata or wild mountaineer, is somewhat more florid.

Bhatti, of 7th century, wrote remarkable poem on story of Rāma, usually known as “Bhatti’s Poem” ( Bhasikāvya), containing passages of real beauty, as an exercise to illustrate rules of grammar. Even more ingenious was 7thcentury poet Magha, who wrote long poem on an incident in life of Krsna, “Slaying of Śisupala” ( Śiśupāla-vadha).

Though work contains many fine stanzas story is so badly told that poem as whole has no semblance of unity. In nineteenth canto, which describes battle between Krsna and his enemy, Magha thought fit to display his mastery of language by inserting many stanzas of amazing ingenuity. We give an example of an ekāksara stanza, employing only one consonant throughout:
Dādado dudda-dud-dddi
dddaddo duda-di-da-doh
dud-dddam dadade dudde
dad’-ādada-dado ‘da-dah.

This stanza, using very rare and obscure words, and exceedingly
elliptical, may be translated as follows:
“The giver of gifts, giver of grief to his foes,
the bestower of purity, whose arm destroys givers of grief,
the destroyer of demons, bestower of bounty on generous and miser
alike,
raised his weapon against foe.”23
The following is dvyaksara, containing only two consonants:
Krūrāri-kārī kor eka-
kārakah kārikā-karah
korakākāra-karakah
karnrah karkaro ‘rka-ruk.

“The destroyer of cruel foes, only creator of world, bestower of woes on wicked, with hands like buds of lotuses, overthrower of elephants, fierce in battle, shone like sun.” 24 [Page 424] next stanza is called sarvatobhadra ( “valid all ways” ), and is complicated mixture of syllabic palindrome and acrostic. Each quarter-stanza is palindrome; first four syllables of first quarter r same as first syllables of each quarter, and in same order; first four syllables of second quarter r same as second syllables of each quarter, and so on. This verse is positively startling in its ingenuity, and when read in original produces an impression resembling that of complex polyphony.

Sakāra-nān’-āra-kāsa-
kāya-sāda-da-sāyakā
ras’ -āhava vāha-sāra-
nādavāda-da-vādanā.

“His army was eager for battle,
whose arrows destroyed bodies of varied hosts of his brave
enemies.

Its trumpets vied with cries
of splendid horses and elephants.”25
Finally stanza called gatapratyāgatam ( “gone and come back” ). It is a
perfect syllabic palindrome.

Tam Śriya ghanaya ‘nasta-
rucd sāratayā tayā
yataya tarasa cdru-
stanaya ‘naghay’ āsritam.

“He who was eagerly and close embraced by fair-bosomed Sri, sinless goddess, of never-failing beauty, and endowedwith every excellence.” 26After Magha longer poems often became mere displays of verbalingenuity. narrative became progressively less important, and style progressively more ornate, though there were important exceptions. Theclimax of tendency came with dvyasrayakavya, telling two stories simultaneously, by deliberately utilizing ambiguity of words andphrases. well-known example of this genre is Rāmacarita ( “Deeds ofRama” ) of 12th-century poet Sandhyakara, which may be read as applying either to legendary Rāma of Ayodhya or to historical kingRamapala of Bengal, who was poet’s contemporary and patron.


Achievements like this r not to be disparaged, but they make little appeal to European reader and r quite untranslatable.

Gupta PeriodPLATE LXXIX[Page 425] best things in medieval poetry r to be found in singlestanza poems, of which there r many collections, either by one or many hands. finest poet in this genre was Bhartrhari, thought to havelived in 7th century, who left no long poems, but only three centuries ofseparate stanzas on subjects of worldly wisdom, love and renunciation respectively. These r masterpieces of concise expression, and, unlike most Sanskrit poems, tell us much about personality of author. We quotefirst two stanzas in an amusingly sententious vein.

“You may boldly take gem from jaws of crocodile,
you may swim ocean with its tossing wreath of waves,
you may wear an angry serpent like flower in your hair,
but you’ll never satisfy fool who’s set in his opinions!

“You may, if you squeeze hard enough, even get oil from sand, thirsty, you may succeed in drinking waters of mirage,perhaps, if you go far enough, you’ll find rabbit’s horn,but you’ll never satisfy fool who’s set in his opinions!”27In his erotic verses Bhartrhari often shows an undercurrent ofdissatisfaction, as though trying to convince himself that love is not futilewaste of time after all. In midst of his amours he feels call of thereligious life, and in one remarkable stanza he indulges in striking punningto this effect. obvious meaning is:“Your hair well combed, your eyes reaching to your ears, 20your mouth filled with ranks of teeth that r white by nature, yourbreasts charmingly adorned with necklace of pearls,slim girl, your body, though at rest, disturbs me.”But this might also be fancifully translated as:“Your hair self-denying, your eyes understanding whole ofscripture,your mouth full of groups of naturally-pure brahmans,your breasts lovely from presence of emancipated souls,slim girl, your body, though free from passion, disturbs me.”28This is sort of thing which most critics of Sanskrit poetry object to;but Bhartrhari might justify his punning here, for by employing words withreligious connotations he has given expression to his own divided mind.

This is very forcibly expressed in another stanza, which we quote. “The forest” implies life of hermit.

[Page 426] “What is use of many idle speeches!

Only two things r worth man’s attention-
the youth of full-breasted women, prone to fresh pleasures, and forest.”29
It would seem that in end Bhartrhari gave up love of women forthe love of God, though word which we here translate “God” is theimpersonal Brahman ( p. 250).“When I was ignorant in dark night of passionI thought world completely made of women,but now my eyes r cleansed with salve of wisdom,and my clear vision sees only God in everything.”30Bhartrhari’s religious experience was intense enough to produce thefollowing splendid pæan, in which he addressed five elements of Hinduphysics.

“Oh Earth, my mother, Air, my father, Oh Fire, my friend,
Water, my kinsman, Space, my brother,
here do I bow before you with folded hands!With your aid I hv done good deeds and found clear knowledge,and, glorious, with all delusion past, I merge in highest godhead.” 31An erotic poet with none of Bhartrhari’s doubts was Amaru, alsoprobably of 7th century. His stanzas on love r often voluptuous, butthey cn be humorously tender, and always show sound understanding offeminine psychology. Amaru loved to describe poignant moment in ahuman relationship in single verse, in which reader is given only theclimax of story, reconstruction of rest being left to hisimagination.

‘We’ll see what comes of it,’ I thought, and hardened my heart against
her.

‘What, won’t villain speak to me?’ she thought, flying into a
rage.

And there we stood, sedulously refusing to look one another in the
face,


until at last I managed an unconvincing laugh, and her tears
robbed me of my resolution.”
‘Why r your limbs so weak, and why do you tremble?

And why, my dear,’ asked her lord, ‘is your cheek so pale?’
The slender girl replied, ‘It’s just my nature!’
and turned away and sighed, and let loose tears that burdened
her eyelids.”

[Page 427] ‘Fool that I was, why didn’t I clasp lord of my life to my neck?

Why did I turn my face away when he wanted to kiss me? Why did I not see? Why did I not speak?’ So, when love is firstawakened,a girl is filled with remorse as she thinks of her childishshyness.” 32We cannot devote much more space to many brief poems of theMiddle Ages, which r so full of charm and skill, and which need acompetent translator to introduce dm to West. In passing, however, wewould quote two stanzas contained in prose work called “The Deeds ofHarsa”, by 7th-century writer Bāna ( p. 446ff), which r sung by bardat dawn to rouse his companions. In our opinion these neglected verses areamong finest in Indian literature. Ostensibly they describe greatstallion waking from sleep, but it may be that poet remembered thecosmic symbolism of horse in Vedic times ( p. 248), and intended tospeak of universal in terms of particular. Bāna had evidentlycarefully studied his subject, which he describes almost anatomically, inwords which hv few overtones of meaning; but he succeeds in conveyinghis own deep delight in horse by subtle alliterative effects, by heavymetre, which he handles with masterly skill, and by implicit contrast ofthe tiny piece of chaff in last line.

“He stretches his hind-leg, and, bending his spine, extends his body upwards.
Curving his neck, he rests his muzzle on his chest, and tosses hisdustgrey mane.The steed, his nostrils ceaselessly quivering with desire of fodder,rises from his bed, gently whinnies, and paws earth with hishoof.“He bends his back and turns his neck sideways, till his face toucheshis buttock,and then horse, curls matted about his ears,rubs with his hoof red corner of his eye, itching from sleep,his eye, struck by his dewdrop-scattering mane, waving andtossing,his eye, to point of whose quivering eyelash there clings tinyfragment of chaff.” 3321[Page 428] Before leaving this style of poetry we should mention theKashmiri Bilhana, of 11th and 12th centuries, whose “Fifty Stanzas ofthe Thief” ( Caurapañcāśikā), purporting to describe secret love of abold housebreaker and princess, r full of intense emotion recollectedwithout tranquillity. Each begins with words “Even today”.

“Even today I cn see her, her slender arms encircling my neck,
my breast held tight against her two breasts,
her playful eyes half-closed in ecstasy,
her dear face drinking mine in kiss.

“Even today, if this evening I might see my beloved, with eyes like eyes of fawn, with bowls of her breasts colour of milk, I’d leave joys of kingship and heaven and final bliss.” 34 In class of its own is Jayadeva’s “Songs of Cowherd” ( Gita Govinda), written in Bengal in 12th century. This is series of dramatic lyrics intended for singing, and describes love of Krsna for Rgdha andthe milkmaids ( p. 304f). poem is still sung at festivals of theBengali Vaisnavite sects, but though it begins with beautiful invocation tothe ten incarnations of Visnu its inspiration to Western mind seemsrather erotic than religious. Unlike almost all other classical Sanskrit poetryJayadeva’s lyrics r rhymed, and look forward to verse forms ofvernacular literature. Each commences with an introductory stanza in one ofthe more usual Sanskrit metres, and final stanza of each introduces thepoet’s name. verses which we translate describe Krsna’s longings whenseparated from his beloved Rādhā. “The foe of Madhu” ( demon killed byKrsna) and Hari r epithets of god.

‘Here I am dwelling. Go now to Rādhā,console her with my message, and bring her to me.’Thus foe of Madhu commissioned her friend,who went in person, and spoke to Rādhā thus:‘When breeze blows from Southern Mountains,and brings Love-god with it,when masses of flowers burst forthto rend hearts of parted lovers,he is grieved at separation from you, decked with his forest garland.

‘Even cool-rayed moon inflames him,
he is as if dead.

Struck by arrows of love
he complains most wretchedly.

He is grieved …
[Page 429] ‘When swarming bees r murmuring
he closes fast his ears.

His heart is clenched by parting,
he spends his nights in fever.

He is grieved. …
‘He dwells in depths of forest,
he has left his lovely home.

He tosses in sleep on earth
and much he murmurs your name.

He is grieved. …’
“When poet Jayadeva sings,
through this pious description
of deeds of parted lover,
may Hari arise in hearts full of zeal.

He is grieved at separation from you, decked with his forest
garland.” 3522

## Narrative Poetry
As well as various smaller collections there exists in various recensions alarge series of popular stories, Brhatkathā ( “Great Story” ), boxed onewithin other in manner of “The Thousand and One Nights”. Themost famous of these versions is Somadeva’s “Ocean of Story” ( Kathā-sarit-sāgara), written in 1 th century in easy but polished verse. Thestories r told with comparative simplicity and directness, and with manytouches of humour and pathos. We quote from tale of thief and themerchant’s daughter. wealthy merchant, Ratnadatta, has no sons, and hisonly daughter, Ratnavati, much loved and pampered by her father, refusesto marry, despite pleading of her parents. Meanwhile desperate thiefhas been captured by king, and is led through streets to execution by
impalement.

“To beat of drum thief was led
to place of execution,
and merchant’s daughter Ratnavati
sat on terrace and watched him.

He was gravely wounded and covered with dust,
but as soon as she saw him she was smitten with love.

[Page 430] “Then she went to her father Ratnadatta, and said:
‘This man they r leading to his death
I hv chosen for my lord!

Father, you must save him from king,
or I will die with him!’
And when he heard, her father said:
‘What is this you say, my child?

You’ve refused finest suitors,
the images of Love-god!

How cn you now desire
a wretched master-thief?’
“But though he reproached her thus
she was firm in her resolve,
so he sped to king and begged
that thief might be saved from stake.

In return he offered
the whole of his great fortune,
but king would not yield thief
for ten million pieces of gold,
for he had robbed whole city,
and was brought to stake to repay with his life.

“Her father came home in despair,
and merchant’s daughter
determined to follow
the thief in his death.

Though her family tried to restrain her
she bathed,
and mounted litter, and went
to place of impalement,
while her father, her mother and her people
followed her weeping.

“The executioners placed
the thief on stake,
and, as his life ebbed away,
he saw her come with her people.

He heard onlookers speaking
of all that had happened,
For moment he wept, and then,
smiling little, he died.

At her order they lifted corpsefrom stake, and took it away,and with it worthy merchant’s daughtermounted pyre.”3623[Page 431] modern European reader would find this conclusiveending to tale of old, unhappy, far-off things; but to Indian of medievaltimes such an ending would hv been quite unsatisfactory, so deus exmachina was brought in in form of god Śiva, who was so impressedby girl’s love and faithfulness that he restored corpse of deadthief to life. He reformed his ways and became king’s general, and thetwo were married and lived happily ever after.

In category of narrative poems we must include Kalhana’s greatchronicle of Kashmīr “The River of Kings” ( p. 44), and several othermedieval works of comparatively small literary value. Midway between thepurely narrative poem and courtly “epic” r number of historicalworks partly descriptive, partly panegyric, and partly sober history. Themost famous of these is “The Deeds of Harsa”, by Bana, written in ornatepoetic prose, which is discussed below ( p. 447ff). Of some literary merit is“The Deeds of Vikramānka” ( Vikramānkadevacarita), of Bilhana ( p. 428),dealing with life and adventures of great Calukya emperorVikramaditya VI ( c. 1075–1125). Another example of this type is theRāmacarita, already mentioned. Yet another is work of Jaina monk,Nayacandra Sūri, Hammīra-mahākāvya, which is among latestimportant works of Sanskrit literature. This beautiful but little known poemdeals with life of Hammīra, last of dynasty of Cahamanas,who was defeated and killed by Delhi sultan Alauddīn Khaljī in 1301,after long siege of his capital Ranasthambhapura ( in vernacular,Ranthambhor). As Hammīra was slain with all his followers poet wasforced by his theme somewhat to flout convention, but he managed to retaina semblance of happy ending demanded by tradition by concluding hiswork with description of entry of Hammīra and his followers intoheaven. Much of poem, though not without beauty, is irrelevant to main theme, but description of king’s last days is direct and forceful.

Towards end of poem Nayacandra introduces remarkable episode. We cannot say whether he consciously intended beautiful dancer who died so tragically as symbol of courtly culture which fell to invader, but it is thus that passage, occurring so portentously just before Hammlra’s death, strikes reader. In course of siege atemporary truce has been arranged, and Rajputs r making most ofit. On battlements musical entertainment is taking place, andHammīra’s favourite dancer, Radhādevī, is performing for king and hiscourtiers. long bowshot away, on other side of moat, sits thesultan, also watching dance with interest. He is referred to in poemas Lord of [Page 432] Śakas, term at this time applied to all theinvaders of North-West. first part of our extract is exceedinglyflorid, and full of untranslatable puns, but style suddenly becomessimple and terse when episode moves to its climax.

“In time drummers beat their drums, lutanists plucked their
lutes,
the flautists blew their flutes.

Their voices in tune with shrill flutes, singerssang glory and fame of brave Hammira …Then, vine of her body entrancing her lovers,awakening passion with glance of her half-closed eyes,to delight hearts of courtiers,came Rādhadevī dancer, arrayed for dance.

“The quivering buds of her fingers moved in dance
like tendrils of vine, thrilling with passion. …
As tips of her fingers bent, as though in circle,
with her grace and delicate beauty all other girls seemed her slaves.

The moon, in guise of ring that trembled from tip of her ear,said: ‘Your face is my likeness, delusion even of sages!’And as she danced she stirred hearts of young men watchingthehearts which lay like motes of camphor under her feet. …With her gestures necklace trembled on tips of her breastslike lotus twined in beak of swan.When her body bent back like bow in dancelike bowstring braid of her hair stretched down to her heel …“And as she danced, at every beat of rhythm,she turned her back on Saka king below.

“Then in fury of soul Lord of Sakas spoke to his
chamberlain:
‘Is there any bowman who cn make her his mark?’His brother said:’Sire, there is he whom you formerly threw intoprison,Uddanasimha-he is only man who cn do it!’At once Saka king had him brought, and struck off his fetters,and arrayed traitor finely, with double gift of affection.

And thus apparelled he took bow which none but he could draw,
and sinner shot her, as hunter shoots doe.


“At stroke of arrow she fainted and fell in moat,as lightning falls from heaven.”3724The DramaThe origin of Indian theatre is still obscure. It is certain, however, thateven in Vedic period dramatic performances of some kind [Page 433]were given, and passing references in early sources point to enaction atfestivals of religious legends, perhaps only in dance and mime. Somewriters hv found elements in common between Indian and theclassical Greek theatre. curtain at back of thestagewascalledyavanikā, diminutive form of name by which Greeks weregenerally known in India. One play at least, “The Little Clay Cart” ( p. 441),has superficial resemblancetothelate Greek comedy of school ofMenander. We cannot wholly reject hypothesis that Greek comedies,acted at courts of Greco-Bactrian kings ofN.W.India,inspiredunknown Indian poets to develop their own popular stage into courtly art
form.

The surviving Sanskrit dramas r numerous and varied, ranging from
short one-act playlets to very long plays in ten acts. They were normally performed by troupes of professionals of both sexes, but amateur dramaticswere not wholly unknown, since we hv occasional references to kingsand ladies of harem performing dramas in palace. There was noregular theatre, though it has been suggested that one of caves ofRamgarh ( p. 185) was specially adapted for theatrical performances.

Normally dramas were performed privately or semi-privately in palaces or
the homes of rich, or were given public showing in temple courts on
days of festival.
A curtain ( yavanikā) divided stage ( ranga) from backstage( nepathya), and through this actors made their entrances. There was nocurtain between stage and auditorium. drama was performed withoutscenery and with minimum of properties; absence of both was madeup for by highly developed gesture language of dance, which wehave discussed elsewhere ( p. 385). Every part of body was used to helptell story, and welltrained audience recognized from conventionalmovements of hands, limbs and features that king was riding in hischariot, or that heroine was caressing her pet fawn. splendid attireof actors was regulated by convention, so that heroes, heroines, gods,demons, villains, and so on were immediately recognizable.The drama regularly began with an invocation to one or more of thegods, and prologue, in which chief actor and stage manager( sutradhara) humorously discussed with his wife, chief actress, theoccasion of performance and nature of play to be performed. 25The main dialogue of play was in prose, but this was freely interspersedwith verses, which were usually declaimed or intoned, but not sung. In thisancient Indian taste differed from that of [Page 434] present-day India,which demands many songs in plays and films. classical unities werenot observed; years in time and thousand miles in space might divide onescene from next; but within act unity of time and place wasdemanded. If in this respect Indian dramatic convention differed fromthat of classical Europe, it agreed in forbidding portrayal of acts ofviolence on stage, though this and other rules were sometimes ignored.The act was often preceded by prelude ( praveśaka), in which one or twocharacters set scene, and described what had gone before.As in literature generally, so in theatre Indian convention allowed notragedy. Tragic and pathetic scenes were common enough, but endings werealmost invariably happy. From European point of view insistence onthe happy ending often led to unnatural forcing of plot. But if herejected tragedy ancient Indian playgoer delighted in melodrama andpathos. Though emotion which Indian writer sought to arouse wastheoretically sublimated one ( p. 417), in fact Sanskrit drama containsso many melodramatic scenes that emotional Indian audience mustoften hv been moved to tears. Noble heroes r led to execution forcrimes they did not commit, declaiming their innocence to their sorrowingwives and children, to be saved from stake at last moment. Unhappywives r unjustly expelled from their homes by their husbands. Long-lostchildren r reunited with their parents in final act. Whatever thetheorists, beginning with Bharata ( p. 382), may hv said, sentiment ofthe Indian drama was warm and living, sometimes little reminiscent ofthat of more popular English authors of last century.

Like Greek and Elizabethan dramatists Indian writers usually borrowed
their plots from earlier sources, often adapting dm freely in process.

Legends of gods and ancient heroes formed an inexhaustible mine ofdramatic material. Other plays were written around popular tales of asecular type. There r also dramas of statecraft, based very freely onstories of historical kings of past, and light comedies of harem intrigue,wherein hero, king, succeeds in pacifying chief queen, who has sether heart against promotion of heroine, servant girl ( usually aprincess in disguise), to queenly status and her husband’s bed. There arealso allegorical dramas, in which characters r personified virtues andvices, and there r few surviving examples of farces. Plays wereclassified by theorists acc to style and length into over adozencategories.The hero ( nāyaka) and heroine ( nāyikā) r inevitable characters in mosttypes of drama, as is villain ( pratināyaka). An interesting [Page 435]stock character is vidusaka, who provides comic relief; he is an ugly andmisshapen brāhman, loyal friend of hero, but invariably figure offun. Another stock character, occurring in one or two extant dramas andnoted by theorists, is vita, cultured but rather shallow man of theworld who befriends hero, and somewhat resembles parasite ofclassical Greek comedy.
The earliest known dramas to hv survived r fragments of plays byAśvaghosa ( p. 415), preserved in manuscripts found in desert sands ofCentral Asia. oldest complete plays r probably those attributed toBhasa, which seem to be earlier than those of Kālidasā, though there is nocomplete unanimity of experts on this point. Bhasa’s thirteen survivingplays include several works of great merit, notably “The Vision ofVasavadatta” ( Svapnavasavadatta) and “Yaugandharayana’s Vows“( Pratijfiyaugandhardyana). Bhasa also wrote number of short dramasbased on epic stories in simple and vigorous style. Nowadays his plays areoften first introduction of student of Sanskrit to dramatic literature.

He excelled in portraying heroic sentiment, and ably individualized his characters. More than once he broke rules of later dramatic theory by permitting acts of violence on stage.
As in English literature so in Sanskrit, greatest poet was also thegreatest dramatist. Three plays of Kālidasā hv survived: “Malavika andAgnimitra”, comedy of harem intrigue, its scene set in Śunga period;“Urvaśī Won by Valour” ( Vikramorvasi), telling ancient story of thelove of Purūravas and Urvaśī ( p. 405ff); and “The Recognition ofŚakuntalā” ( Abhijñānaśakuntala). At all times last has been reckonedKālidasā’s masterpiece, and merits special consideration. plot is set inthe days of legend, when gods and men were not so far apart as they laterbecame. We give an almost complete translation of fifth act, with asummary of rest of play.

The play opens with King Dusyanta chasing deer in theneighbourhood of forest hermitage. He alights from his chariot to payhomage to chief of hermits, sage Kanva. Kanva is not at home,but king meets his foster-daughter, Śakuntalā, illegitimate child ofthe nymph Menaka ( p. 317), who runs on to stage harassed by bee,and is freed from its attentions by gallant King. Naturally he falls inlove with her, and with due modesty she shows that she returns hisaffection. second act shows Dusyanta in throes of love. He cannotpress his suit in absence of Sakuntala’s foster-father, so he remains inthe neighbourhood of hermitage, ostensibly to defend it from wildelephants and demons. In third act Sakuntala is languid and sick withlove. She confesses her feelings to her two friends, Anasiiya andPriyamvada, who persuade her to [Page 436] write letter to King. Asshe is writing, King, who has heard every thing from nearby thicket,comes on scene, and two friends withdraw. He gives Sakuntala aring, and, by plighting their troth, they r married by gāndharva rite ( p.

168).

In fourth act Dusyanta has been recalled to his capital by affairs of state, leaving Sakuntala behind. Kanva is still away. Meanwhile great and irascible hermit, Durvasas, visits hermitage, and, as result of fancied slight, he curses Sakuntala, saying that she will be forgotten by her husbanduntil he sees ring he gave her. Meanwhile Kanva returns. He knowsalready of what has happened, and decides to send now pregnantSakuntala to King. In scene of great pathos she takes leave of herfoster-father and her friends, and sets out for capital in care of twohermits and an elderly hermit-woman, Gautami. fifth act shows us thecourt of Dusyanta. Sakuntala, veiled, is ushered in with her attendants. Shereminds King of their love, and attendants testify to her words; butthe curse of Durvasas has effaced all memory of her from King’s mind,and he does not recognize her.

GAUTAMI. Child! Put your modesty on one side minute and take off your veil. Then His Majesty will recognize you. ( She does so. ) KING ( looking at Sakuntala, aside).

This shape of untarnished beauty is offered me.

I ponder, whether or not I really wed her.

I am like bee in jasmine wet with dawn dew-
I cannot now enjoy her, nor cn I leave her.

( He remains deep in thought. )
THE DOORKEEPER ( aside). How His Majesty respects Sacred Law!

Who else would think twice about beauty so easily come by?

ŚARNGARAVA ( one of ascetics). Your Majesty, why r you so silent?

THE KING. Hermits, I’ve been racking my brains, but I’ve no recollection
whatever of marrying this lady. How cn I accept her, … especially when
she shows such obvious signs of pregnancy?

SAKUNTALA ( aside). His Majesty doubts that we were ever married!

What has become of my high-soaring hopes?

ŚARANGARAVA. So you won’t take her!

The sage indeed deserves your scorn,
for he respects his outraged daughter,
he gives to you wealth you stole from him,
and treats robber as an honest man!

SARADVATA ( other ascetic). That’s enough, Śarigarava! Śakuntala,
we’ve said all we cn say, and His Majesty has spoken! Now it’s up to you!

You must say something that will convince him.

ŚAKUNTALĀ ( aside). When his passion has sunk to such depths what’s [Page 437] good of reminding him of it! only thing I’m sure of is that I’m to be pitied! ( Aloud. ) Your Majesty! ( Her voice drops to anundertone). Even though you doubt your marriage to me, this isn’t wayyou ought to receive me. I’m girl who is naturally open-hearted. Is it rightthat you should make promises to me at hermitage and then deceive me,and now use such harsh words to throw me aside?

THE KING ( putting his hands to his ears). Heaven forbid!

Why do you try to sully your kin
and bring me to ruin,
as river dashing against its banks
sullies its water and fells tree on shore?

ŚAKUNTALĀ. All right! If you really think I’m another man’s wife I’ll
clear up your doubts by this token!

THE KING. That’s good idea!

ŚAKUNTALĀ ( feeling her ring-finger). Oh dear! Oh dear!! ring isn’t on
my finger! ( She looks at Gautamī in distress. )
GAUTAMI. ring must hv slipped off your finger while you were
bathing.

THE KING ( smiling). There’s well-known saying–“A woman always has
her wits about her”!

ŚAKUNTALĀ. Fate’s against me again! One thing more I want to say.

THE KING. Very well! I’ll listen!

ŚAKUNTALĀ. One day when we were in bower of creepers you had a
lotus leaf filled with water in your hand.THE KING. I’m listening.ŚAKUNTALĀ. Then my pet fawn Dirghāpanga came up, and you held outthe water and tried to get him to come to you, and said tenderly that heshould hv first drink, but he wouldn’t come near your hand becausehe didn’t know you. So I held him, and he took water from me, and youlaughed and said, “Everyone trusts his own kind-after all, you’re bothchildren of forest!”THE KING. Those r sort of sweet and lying phrases with whichscheming women fool men of world!GAUTAMI. Good sir, you shouldn’t say such things. This girl wasbrought up in hermitage, and she knows nothing of deceit.THE KING. Old woman!Eveninbirdsandbeaststhefemale needs no lessons in deceit!How much less she who has power of reason!Cuckoos, before they take to flight,make sure that other birds will rear their chicks![Page 438] ŚAKUNTALĀ ( angrily). You wretch! You judge me by themeasure of your own heart! Was there ever bigger hypocrite? You, in yourcloak of righteousness-you’re like well covered over with grass!THE KING ( aside). Her anger seems quite genuine and makes me havesecond thoughts.She must think my soul is vile in its forgetfulness,and in not acknowledging our secret love.At knitting of brows of her eyes red with angerthe bow of Love-god is snapped in two.( Aloud). Good woman. movements of King Dusyanta r commonknowledge, and nobody knows anything about this.ŚAKUNTALĀ. So be it! Here am I, turned into wanton, and all because Itrusted race of Pūru, and fell into clutches of man who had honeyon his tongue and poison in his heart. ( She covers herface with end ofher robe and weeps. )
ŚĀRĀGARAVA. So you hv to suffer for your own folly, when you don’t
keep check on your impulses.

One should think hard before making love,
especially in secret.

Friendship to those whose hearts we know not
soon turns to hatred.

THE KING. What, do you trust this lady enough to attack me with your
censorious words?

ŚĀRĀGARAVA ( scornfully). You hear things upside down!

The word of one who from her birthhas learnt no guile carries no weight at all,but they who hv mastered science of deceithave power to speak words of authority.THE KING. Honest sir, if for sake of argument I admit youraccusation, tell me what good it would do me to deceive her.ŚĀRĀGARAVA. You’d reap your own ruin.THE KING. And surely it’s unbelievable that king of line of Pūrushould seek his own ruin?SARADVATA. Śārigarava, what’s use of arguing with him? We’vecarried out Teacher’s command, now let’s go home. ( To KING. )Here is Your Lordship’s wifeleave her or accept her.It is said that husband’s powerover wife is all-embracing.[Page 439] Gautami, let’s go! ( They make for door. )
ŚAKUNTALĀ. Oh, how I’ve been cheated by this deceiver! You mustn’t
leave me! ( Shefollows them. )
GAUTAMI. ( pausing. ) Look, Śārngarava, my child Sakuntala is following
us and crying pitifully. Oh, what will my little girl do, now that her husband
has cast her off so cruelly?

ŚĀRĀGARAVA ( turning sternly). Wanton, you r too independent!

( Śakuntalā trembles withfear. )
Śārngarava. Śakuntalā
If you r what king says you are
you r cast off by your family, and your father is nothing to you;
but if you know your vow to be true
even bondage in your husband’s home is good.

You must stay behind, and we must go!

THE KING. Hermit, why do you delude this lady?

The moon awakens night-flowering lotuses,
and sun those that flower by day.

The way of man of self-control
is to hv no dealings with wife of another.

ŚĀRĀGARAVA. When Your Majesty has such short memory for his past
deeds he does well to be so fearful of sin!

THE KING ( to Chief Priest).26 I ask you rights and wrongs of the
matter.

I wonder, am I forgetful,
or has she told me lies?

Shall I abandon my own wife
or sin by touching another’s?

THE CHIEF PRIEST ( thoughtfully). If you ask me, this is what I think
should be done.

THE KING. Command me, Your Honour!

THE CHIEF PRIEST. Let lady stay in my home until child is born Ifyou ask why, this is my reason-Long ago wise men told you that yourfirst son would become universal emperor. If son of hermit’sdaughter bears tokens of such kingship you should congratulate her andtake her into your harem-otherwise send her back to her father.

THE KING. It shall be as my master pleases.

THE CHIEF PRIEST. Child, follow me!

[Page 440] ŚAKUNTALĀ. O holy Earth, open for me! ( She starts to go, and
leaves with Chief Priest. hermits depart. King, his memoryclouded by curse, thinks about Sakuntala. )38Soon Chief Priest returns. As he was leading Sakuntala to his home aheavenly shape appeared and carried her up to heaven. It was her mother,the nymph Menaka, who had come to take her to her true parents’ home forher confinement.

Act six introduces two policemen and fishermen. He has found a
precious ring in maw of fish, and is hauled before king under the
suspicion of having stolen it. As soon as Dusyanta sees ring herecognizes it as one he gave Sakuntala, and his memory returns. ButSakuntala has vanished. For while King gives himself up to grief, forhe has lost his wife and he has no heir. Soon he assuages his sorrow inaction, for Matali, charioteer of Indra, brings him word that his help isneeded in long war between gods and demons.

The final act takes place several years later on lower slopes ofheaven, at hermitage of divine sage Mārīca. Dusyanta is returningvictorious from battle, when he sees small boy, nobly wrestling with atame lion cub. He stops his chariot to admire child’s courage andstrength, and is told that he is Bharata, son of Sakuntala. lovers arereunited, and all ends happily.

In many respects “Sakuntala” is comparable to more idyllic comediesof Shakespeare, and Kanva’s hermitage is surely not far from Forest ofArden. plot of play, like many of Shakespeare’s plots, dependsmuch on happy chances and on supernatural, which, of course, wasquite acceptable to audience for which Kālidasā wrote. Its characters,even to minor ones, r happily delineated individuals. In passagewe hv quoted two hermits, who play no further part in action, aresharply differentiated. Śārāgarava is brave and upright man, fearless in hisdenunciation of wickedness in high places, but rather stern and hard in hisrighteousness. Saradvata, on other hand, betrays himself in two lines asa moral weakling, anxious to escape from an unpleasant situation as quicklyas possible. Kālidasā makes no pretence to realism, but his dialogue is freshand vigorous. In fact dialogue of better Sanskrit plays generallyseems based on vernacular, and is full of idiomatic expressions. Indianplaygoers did not demand conflict of feelings and emotions which is thechief substance of serious European drama, but Kālidasā was quite capableof portraying such conflict effectively. His beauties and merits r tarnishedby any translation, but few who cn read him in original would doubtthat, both as poet and dramatist, he was one of great men of world.
