PLATE LXXXII
[Page 441] There were many other dramatists, of whom we cn only mention few. Śūdraka, probably Kālidasā’s approximate contemporary, has left only one play “The Little Clay Cart” ( Mrcchakatika). This is most realistic of Indian dramas, unravelling complicated story, rich inhumour and pathos and crowded with action, of love of poor brāhman,Carudatta, for virtuous courtezan Vasantasena; this story is interwovenwith one of political intrigue, leading up to overthrow of wickedking Palaka, and play contains vivid trial scene, after which hero issaved from execution at last moment. It is notable for its realisticdepiction of city life, and for its host of minor characters, all of whom aredrawn with skill and individuality. It has more than once been performed intranslation on European stage, and, to Western audience, is certainlythe most easily appreciated of Indian plays.

Visakhadatta ( 16th century) was dramatist of politics. His onlycomplete surviving play, “The Minister’s Signet Ring “( Mudrdrāksasa),deals with schemes of wily Canakya ( p. 50) to foil plots ofRaksasa, minister of last of Nandas, and to place CandraguptaMaurya firmly on throne. plot is exceedingly complicated, but isworked out with great skill, and play is beautifully constructed to leadup, like “The Little Clay Cart”, to pathetic scene where one of chiefcharacters is saved from death by impalement at last moment. Anotherplay by Visakhadatta, “The Queen and Candra Gupta” ( Devicandragupta),purporting to tell story of rise to power of Candra Gupta II ( p. 65),exists only in fragments.

Three plays r ascribed to great king Harsa ( p. 68f), though they maybe work of “ghost writer”. They r “Ratnavali”, “Priyadarāikī”, and“The Joy of Serpents “( Nāgānanda). first two, named after theirheroines, r charming harem comedies, while last is play of religiouspurport, telling of prince Jīmūitavahāna, who gives his own body to put astop to sacrifice of serpents to divine Garuda ( p. 300).

With Harsa we may link his royal contemporary, Pallava king Mahendravikramavarman, who has left one-act play “The Sport of Drunkards “( Mattavilasa). It treats of drunken Saivite ascetic, who loses skull which he uses as begging bowl, and accuses Buddhist monk ofstealing it. After much satirical dialogue, in which other dissolute asceticsof various persuasions and both sexes r involved, it is found that skullhas been stolen by dog. This little farce, though slight, throws flood oflight on life of times and is full of Rabelaisian humour.

Second only to Kālidasā in esteem of critics was Bhavabhāti, [Page 442] who lived at Kānyakubjain early 8th century. Three of his plays survive-“Mālatī and Mādhava”, “The Deeds of Great Hero” ( Mahdviracarita), and “The Later Deeds of Rama” ( UttaraRāmacarita).

The first is love story with pseudo-realistic background, full of incident of an exciting or horrific type, in which heroine is more than once rescued from death, while two latter plays tell story of Rāma. ByWestern standards as dramatist Bhavabhūti falls short of those we havementioned earlier. His plots r weakly constructed and his characters lackindividuality. His greatness rests on his deep understanding of sorrow; inhis treatment of pathetic and terrible he perhaps excels Kālidasā.

After Bhavabhūti quality of Sanskrit drama declined. Playwrights ofsome merit, such as Bhatta Nārāyana ( ? 8th century), Murāri ( early 9thcentury), Rājaśekhara ( 9th-loth centuries), and Krsnamiśra ( 11th century),continued to write dramas, but their work grew more and more literary, andwas evidently often rather intended for reading than for performance. Wehave records of occasional production of Sanskrit plays until theMuslim invasion, after which Sanskrit theatrical tradition, though notforgotten, became thing of past.

## Sanskrit Prose Literature
The earliest surviving prose stories r few narrative episodes in brāhmanas ( p. 405f), followed by Pali Jatakas ( p. 454f). In Gupta period, however, there developed style of ornate prose narrative, which was very different from simple Pali stories, and was classed as kavya.

The chief writers in this genre were Dandin, Subandhu and Bana, all of whom lived in late 6th and early 7th centuries.

Dandin’s “Tales of Ten Princes” ( DaśaKumāracarita) is collectionof exciting and ingenious stories, held together by framing narrative andall interwoven with great skill. prose is comparatively simple. Longcompounds r numerous, but inordinately lengthy sentences of Bānaare not to be found. stories r secular, often humorous, and sometimesamoral, while characters r well delineated. Some of interest of the“Ten Princes “lies in its comparative realism, for in their adventures tenheroes come in contact with merchants and thieves, princesses andprostitutes, peasants and wild hillmen. Few works of Indian literature tell usso much about low life.

As examples of Dandin’s style we give two little stories which arecontained within larger tales, and r intended to show contrastingaspects of character of fair sex. styles r sharply [Page 443]differentiated to fit themes; grisly story of Dhūminī is told in crispshort sentences with great economy of detail, while in domestic idyll ofGomini Dandin lingers lovingly on his words, and describes charmingscene in leisurely periods.

“There is country called Trigarta, where there lived three householders, who had accumulated great fortune. They were brothers, called Dhanaka, Dhanyaka and Dhanyaka. In those days Indra gave no rain for twelve years.

The corn withered, plants were barren, trees bore no fruit, and cloudswere impotent; water courses dried up, ponds became mere mudholes, andthe springs ceased to flow. Bulbs, roots and fruit became scarce, folk-taleswere forgotten, and all festive merrymaking ceased. Robber bandsmultiplied, and people ate one another’s flesh. Human skulls, white ascranes,rolled on ground. Flocks of thirsty crows flew hither and thither.Villages, cities, whole districts, were deserted.“The three householders first ate their store of grain and then one by onetheir goats, their sheep, their buffaloes, their cows, their maidservants, theirmenservants, their children, and wives of eldest and middlebrother. Finally they decided that next day they would eat Dhūminī, thewife of youngest; but youngest brother, Dhanyaka, could not bringhimself to eat his darling, so that night he stole away withher.“When she grew weary he carried her, until they came to forest … andthey walked on through it until at last they came upon man who waswrithing on ground, with his hands, feet, ears and nose cut off. Hecompassionately supported this man too on his shoulder, and for long timethe three dwelt in hut which he painstakingly built of leaves in corner ofthe forest which abounded in edible bulbs, roots and game. He healed theman’s wounds with almond and sesamum oil, and fed him with full shareof his own meat and vegetables.

“One day when man had quite recovered and was restored to health,
when Dhanyaka had gone hunting, Dhūminī approached man withdesire for pleasure, and though he upbraided her she compelled him tosatisfy her. When her husband came back and asked for water she said,‘Draw it from well yourself, I’ve got splitting headache’, and tossedhim bucket and rope. As he was drawing water from well she creptup suddenly behind him and pushed him in.

“Supporting cripple on her shoulder she wandered from land to land,
and gained reputation of devoted wife, and was much honoured.

Finally she settled in Avanti, and lived in great affluence, thanks to thegenerosity of king. One day she heard that her husband had beenrescued from well by band of thirsty merchants, and was now roamingabout land of Avanti, begging his food. So Dhūminī declared to theunwitting king that he was villain who had crippled her husband, and hecondemned good man to death by torture.“As Dhanyaka was being led to execution, knowing that his appointedtime had not yet come, he boldly said to officer in charge, ‘If beggar[Page 444] I’m supposed to hv crippled is ready to condemn me I deservemy punishment!’ officer thought that no harm could come of testing[his words, so he sent for cripple]. As soon as cripple was broughtand saw Dhanyaka his eyes filled with tears. He fell at good man’s feet,and, being man of noble mind, he told of Dhanyaka’s kindness and thefalse Dhūmini’s wickedness. enraged king had wicked woman’sface disfigured, and made her serve as cook in his kennels, while hebestowed great favour on Dhanyaka. And that is why I say that women arehardhearted.”“In land of Dravidians is city called Kāñcī. Therein dwelt thevery wealthy son of merchant, by name ŚaktiKumāra. When he wasnearly eighteen he thought: ‘There’s no pleasure in living without wife orwith one of bad character. Now how cn I find really good one?’ So,dubious of his chance of finding wedded bliss with woman taken at theword of others, he became fortune-teller, and roamed land with ameasure of unhusked rice tied in skirts of his robe; and parents, takinghim for an interpreter of birthmarks, showed their daughters to him.

Whenever he saw girl of his own class, whatever her birthmarks, he
would say to her: ‘My dear girl, cn you cook me good meal from this
measure of rice?’ And so, ridiculed and rejected, he wandered from house
to house.

“One day in land of Śibis, in city on banks of Kāverī, he examined girl who was shown to him by her nurse. She wore little jewellery, for her parents had spent their fortune, and had nothing left buttheir dilapidated mansion. As soon as he set eyes on her he thought: ‘Thisgirl is shapely and smooth in all her members. Not one limb is too fat or toothin, too short or too long. Her fingers r pink; her hands r marked withauspicious lines-the barleycorn, fish, lotus and vase; her anklesare shapely; her feet r plump and veins r not prominent; her thighscurve smoothly; her knees cn barely be seen, for they merge into herrounded thighs; her buttocks r dimpled and round as chariot wheels; hernavel is small, flat and deep; her stomach is adorned with three lines; thenipples stand out from her large breasts, which cover her whole chest; herpalms r marked with signs which promise corn, wealth and sons; her nailsare smooth and polished like jewels; her fingers r straight and taperingand pink; her arms curve sweetly from shoulder, and r smoothlyjointed; her slender neck is curved like conch-shell; her lips r roundedand of even red; her pretty chin does not recede; her cheeks r round, fulland firm; her eyebrows do not join above her nose, and r curved, dark andeven; her nose is like half-blown sesamum flower; her wide eyes r largeand gentle and flash with three colours, black, white and brown; her brow isfair as new moon; her curls r lovely as mine of sapphires; her longears r adorned doubly, with earrings and charming lotuses, hanginglimply; her abundant hair is not brown, even at tips, 27 but long, smooth,glossy and fragrant. character of such girl cannot but correspond to[Page 445] her appearance, and my heart is fixed upon her, so I’ll test herand marry her. For one regret after another is sure to fall on heads ofpeople who don’t take precautions!’ So, looking at her affectionately, hesaid, ‘Dear girl, cn you cook good meal for me with this measure ofrice?’“Then girl glanced at her old servant, who took measure of ricefrom his hand and seated him on veranda, which had been wellsprinkled and swept, giving him water to cool his feet. Meanwhile girlbruised fragrant rice, dried it little at time in sun, turned itrepeatedly, and beat it with hollow cane on firm flat spot, very gently, soas to separate grain without crushing husk. Then she said to thenurse, ‘Mother, goldsmiths cn make good use of these husks for polishingjewellery. Take them, and, with coppers you get for them, buy somefirewood, not too green and not too dry, small cooking pot, and twoearthen dishes. ‘28“When this was done she put grains of rice in shallowwidemouthed, round-bellied mortar, and took long and heavy pestle ofacaciawood, its head shod with plate of iron. … With skill and grace sheexerted her arms, as grains jumped up and down in mortar.

Repeatedly she stirred dm and pressed dm down with her fingers; then
she shook grains in winnowing basket to remove beard, rinsed
them several times, worshipped hearth, and placed dm in water which had been five times brought to boil. When rice softened, bubbledand swelled, she drew embers of fire together, put lid on thecooking pot, and strained off gruel. Then she patted rice with ladleand scooped it out little at time; and when she found that it wasthoroughly cooked she put cooking pot on one side, mouth downward.
Next she damped down those sticks which were not burnt through, andwhen fire was quite out she sent dm to dealers to be sold ascharcoal, saying, ‘With coppersthatyouget for them, buy as much asyou cn of green vegetables, ghee, curds, sesamum oil, myrobalans andtamarind.’“When this was done she offered him few savouries. Next she put therice-gruel in new dish immersed in damp sand, and cooled it with softbreeze of palm-leaf fan. She added little salt, and flavoured it with thescent of embers; she ground myrobalans to smooth powder, untilthey smelt like lotus; and then, by lips of nurse, she invited him totake bath. This he did, and when she too had bathed she gave him oil andmyrobalans [as an unguent].

“After he had bathed he sat on bench in paved courtyard, which had
been thoroughly sprinkled and swept. She stirred gruel in two
dishes, which she set before him on piece of pale green plantain leaf, cutfrom tree in courtyard. He drank it and felt rested and happy, relaxedin every limb. Next she gave him two ladlefuls of boiled rice, servedwith little ghee and condiments. She served rest of rice [Page 446]with curds, three spices [mace, cardamom and cinnamon], and fragrant andrefreshing buttermilk and gruel. He enjoyed meal to last mouthful.

“When he asked for drink she poured him water in steady streamfrom spout of new pitcher-it was fragrant with incense, and smelt offresh trumpet-flowers and perfume of full-blown lotuses. He put thebowl to his lips, and his eyelashes sparkled with rosy drops as cool as snow;his ears delighted in sound of trickling water; his rough cheeksthrilled and tingled at its pleasant contact; his nostrils opened wide at itssweet fragrance; and his tongue delighted in its lovely flavour, as he drankthe pure water in great gulps. Then, at his nod, girl gave him amouthwash in another bowl. old woman took away remains of hismeal, and he slept awhile in his ragged cloak, on pavement plasteredwith fresh cowdung.

“Wholly pleased with girl, he married her with due rites, and took her
home. Later he neglected her awhile and took mistress, but wife
treated her as dear friend. She served her husband indefatigably, as shewould god, and never neglected her household duties; and she won theloyalty of her servants by her great kindness. In end her husband was soenslaved by her goodness that he put whole household in her charge,made her sole mistress of his life and person, and enjoyed three aims oflife-virtue, wealth and love. So I maintain that virtuous wives make theirlords happy and virtuous.”39Subandhu, next of three great prose writers, is known only fromone work, called after its heroine Vdsavadattd, which tells of thevicissitudes of her love for prince Kandarpaketu. Unlike Dandin,Subandhu was quite unable to tell story, and had no sense of character.

His merits lie in his ornate descriptions and his mastery of language, and his
work consists of series of descriptive tableaux, linked by thin thread ofnarrative, each long description told in single sentence which covers twoor more pages of type. work abounds in flowers of speech of all kinds-puns, doubles entendres, alliterations and assonances, and is typicalexample of Gauda ( Bengali) style of literary composition, asdistinguished from simpler Vaidarbha ( Berar) style, with shorter, lessinvolved sentences, employed by Kālidasā and Dandin. It cannot beenjoyed in translation and its merits r only apparent in framework ofits own standards. Of European literature perhaps Lily’s Euphues andsimilar late Renaissance prose works most closely approach it in style andspirit.
Bana’s style is similar to that of Subandhu, but his work is much morevital and congenial to Western taste. Not only do his elaborate descriptionsshow accurate and close observation, but throughout his two works, the“Deeds of Harsa” ( Harsacarita) and Kddambarn, personality of theauthor breaks through. In former [Page 447] work, moreover, he givesus fragment of autobiography unparalleled in Sanskrit literature. Bāna wasborn of well-to-do brahman family, and his mother died in his earlychildhood. At age of fourteen he lost his father also, and, after periodof mourning, he began to sow his wild oats. He names with evidentaffection bosom friends of his dissolute youth, which was spent in
wandering from city to city among intellectual bohemians of time.

His circle was remarkably wide, including ascetics of various sects, bothorthodox and otherwise, literary men, actors, musicians, entertainers,doctors, and even humble people of low caste. list of Bana’s friends,mentioned in no special order, is in itself sufficient to show how lightly therules of caste weighed on educated man. author gives us no detailsof his adventures, but it would seem that in course of dm he wasreceived at court of Harsa, whom he offended in some way. Later hereturned for while to his home, and resumed peaceful life of countrybrahman; but soon message came from Harsa, demanding his attendanceat court. He was at first received coldly, but afterwards was restored tofavour.

Though religiously minded, Bāna seems throughout his life to have
transcended bounds of orthodoxy and to hv retained some of theunconventionality of his wild youth. He was not afraid to put forwardopinions which might hv made him unpopular with his royal patron —forinstance he condemned doctrine of royal divinity as gross sycophancy,and attacked Macchiavellian system of statecraft associated with thename of Kautilya as immoral and inhuman. Here and there in his workoccur passages which show implicit sympathy with poor and humble-asentiment rarely found in ancient Indian literature-and he is master ofexact observation. For all floweriness of his style Bāna’s outlook hasmore in common with that of 20th century than that of any other earlyIndian writer.
Of his two works “Deeds of Harsa” tells of events leading up toHarsa’s rise to power with general authenticity, but with some evidentexaggeration, and with lack of circumstantial detail which historianfinds irritating. work was apparently unfinished, since when itconcludes hero’s destiny is still somewhat in doubt. Kādambarī isperhaps conscious and successful attempt to improve on Subandhu’sVāsavadattā. story is romance, told in series of narrated episodeswhich link together to build upacomplicatedplot.This work also wasunfinished, and was completed by author’s son, whose prentice hand isquite evident.As an example of Bāna’sstylewegiveasomewhatabridged and adaptedversion of his description of Harsa’s army striking camp to march againsthis enemies. In original whole consists of [Page 448] singlesentence, basisof which is phrase “the royal court was filled withchieftains” near end of passage. separate sentences or clauses ofour translation r single compound words in original.‘“Then it was time to go. drums rattled, kettledrums beatjoyfully, trumpets blared, horns blew, conches sounded. Bydegrees hubbub of camp grew louder. Officers busily roused theKing’s courtiers. sky shook with din of fast-hammering mallets anddrumsticks. generals assembled ranks of subordinate officers.The darkness of night was broken by glare of thousand torcheswhich people lighted. Lovers were aroused by tramping feet of thewomen who kept watch. harsh shouts of elephant-marshalsdispelled slumber of their drowsy riders as awakened elephants left theirstables.

“Squadrons of horses woke from sleep and shook their manes. camp resounded loudly as spades dug up tent-pegs, and tethering chains of elephants clinked as their stakes were pulled up. … As foragers released elephants all space was filled with clanking of their fetters. Leather bags full to bursting were placed on their dusty backs, which had been rubbed down with tufts of hay. Servants rolled up canvasses andawnings of tents and pavilions, and bundles of tent-pegs were storedaway in bulging leather sacks. Store-keepers assembled their stores, andmany elephant-drivers loaded them. dwellings of vassals werecluttered with cups and cooking utensils, which were lifted on to backsof elephants, steadied by their riders. soldiers laughed as fatstrumpets were dragged away by force, resisting vigorously with feet andhands. many mighty and savage elephants trumpeted, as girthbandsof their bright harness were tightened, and restricted freedom of theirlimbs. …. Camels neighed in annoyance as sacks were loaded on their
backs.

“The wives of highborn gentlemen were visited in their carriages by gobetweens sent by princes. Elephant-captains, who had forgotten that itwas time to go, looked for their servants. splendid horses of King’sfavourites were led by footmen wealthy with their masters’ gifts. Troops ofhandsome warriors adorned their bodies with circles of unguent, scentedwith camphor. harness of marshals’ horses was hung with bags ofsalted peas, little bells, and whistles. 29 Monkeys sat among troops ofhorses, as grooms straightened their tangled reins. Stablemen draggedsacks of musty fodder for horses’ morning meal. calls of thegrasscutters grew louder and louder. There was uproar in stables asyounghorses strained and reared and swerved at confusion of starting.Girls hurried at call of riders of harnessed horses with unguentsfor their faces. As elephants and horses set out poor folk of the[Page 449] neighbourhood ran up to loot remains of heaped grain.
Donkeys plodded on together, loaded with piles of clothing. trampledroads were filled with carts with creaking wheels. Oxen were loaded withequipment which would suddenly fall off. strong oxen, first to bedriven away, lagged behind, drawn by grass which grew by theroadside.

“In front went field-kitchens of chief vassals. Standard bearers led ranks. As troops left their small huts hundreds of their friends came out to meet them. feet of elephants trampled hovels by roadside, and people came out and threw clods at their keepers, who called on bystanders to witness their assaults. Poor families ran fromtheir wrecked and ruined huts. Oxen, bearing wealth of unfortunatemerchants, fled from hubbub. Clearing path through crowd withthe glare of their torches, runners led way for elephants bearing thewomen of harem. Horsemen shouted to dogs running behind them.

The veterans praised tall Tangana horses, which trotted so smoothly and quickly that they made travelling pleasure. Unhappy Southerners upbraided their fallen mules. whole world was swallowed in dust.

“The royal court was filled with chieftains who had come from everyquarter, riding on cow-elephants, whose drivers bore bows adorned withstripes of gold-leaf. Seated within [the howdahs] their batmen carried theirswords. Their betel-bearers fanned dm with flywhisks. soldiers seatedin rear bore bundles of javelins in cases. trappings [of theelephants] bristled with curved sabres and gilded arrows. … thighs [ofthe chieftains] were clothed in fine-patterned silk, but their legs werecovered with mud-stained trousers. … Their tunics were decked with darkjewels, which glistened against their bodies. They wore Chinese cuirasses,doublets adorned with bright clusters of pearls. … and scarves as bright as aparrot’s wing. All ends of earth were filled with knights andwarriors, who hurried on with tossing shields and plumes. ends ofheaven were loud with jingling golden ornaments on harness of theprancing Kamboja steeds in their hundreds. ear was deafened by theharsh booming of hundreds of large kettledrums, mercilessly beaten. Theroll was called. With upturned faces footmen awaited order tomarch.” 40After Bāna similar prose romances were often written, as well as storiesin mixed prose and verse ( campū), but none is of much literary importance,and most r derivative, pedantic and dull.

Another branch of prose narrative literature was fable, which we meetfirst in Pāli Jātakas. These cheerful little stories, whose characters areoften talking animals, hv much in common with fables popular inancient Greece, and there has been some discussion on question ofinfluence. Direct borrowing is unlikely, though it may be that some of thetales were derived from common source in ancient Middle East.

Whatever origin of these stories Indian folklore did influence theliterature of West, for one of most [Page 450] famous Indiancollections of fables, Paicatantra, was translated into Pahlavl, or MiddlePersian, in 6th century. Thence it was translated into Syriac, and thenceagain, in 8th century, into Arabic. In various versions it appeared in Hebrew, Greek and Latin, and found its way all over Europe. earliestEnglish version is that of Sir Thomas North, called “The MorallPhilosophie of Doni” after name of translator of Italian version,which North used. This appeared in 1570, and was earliest work ofIndian literature ( much garbled by successive translations) to be publishedin English. fables of La Fontaine r admittedly based on “Pilpay”, theform in which Vidyapati, title of Indian sage who is said to havenarrated stories, reached Europe. As well as fables of La Fontainethe stories of Reynard Fox, popular in folk literature of many partsof Europe and given finished form by Goethe, owe much to this source.

Other Indian tales, including several from Brhatkatha ( p. 429), found their way westwards, and “Arabian Nights” owes several of its stories and themes to India, including some of marvels met by Sindbad Sailor.

The Pañcatantra ( “Five Treatises” ) is in theory book of instruction inniti, or conduct of one’s affairs, especially intended for kings andstatesmen. little stories r contained in framing narrative which tellshow king was distressed at evil and stupidity of his sons, and entrustedthem to sage who reformed dm in six months by telling dm series offables. book exists in several versions of varying length and merit, mostly in prose, but with many verses of gnomic type. most famousof these versions is Narayana’s Hitopadeśa ( ” Salutary Instruction” ),composed in Bengal in 12th century. work was intended as a“reader” for students of Sanskrit, and serves that purpose well down to thepresent day. Never was school textbook better written. author wascompelled by his purpose to avoid euphuisms and pedantries whichaffected most of literature of his time, and he wrote lucidly and wittily,liberally including memorably terse gnomic stanzas. Ethically many of thestories r dubious, for they encourage caution and self-interest rather thanaltruism. two stories we quote r boxed within others.

‘It is said:
He who takes well-spoken knave
to be man of his own stamp
is fooled by rogues, like brahman
who was robbed of his goat.’
‘How did that happen?’ asked King.

[Page 451] ‘In forest of Gautama,’ said Meghavarna, ‘there lived brahman famous for his sacrifices. Once he went to village and bought goat for sacrifice, and as he was carrying it home on his shoulder he wasseen by three rogues. “If we could find way to get that goat,” they said tothemselves, “it would be fine trick!” So they stationed themselves eachunder tree about krośa apart. As brāhman passed by, first roguesaid, “Why, brāhman, that’s dog you’re carrying on your back!” “It’s not adog,” replied brahman,” it’s goat for sacrifice!”‘Then next rogue addressed him with same words. This time thebrāhman put goat on ground and looked at it hard, and again slung itover his shoulder and went on, his mind wavering like swing; forThe words of rogues make even mind of good man waver.

If he trusts dm he dies like Pretty-ears.’
‘How did that happen?’ asked King.

‘In forest land,’ he said,’ there lived lion named Madotkata, who had three servants, crow, tiger and jackal. Once as three were out walking they met camel, and they asked him whence he came, and whether he had fallen out of caravan. He told dm his story, and they took him back and handed him over to lion, who gave him his freedom and security; and he took name of Pretty-ears.

‘Later lion was taken ill, and there was heavy rain and they were very distressed for want of food. So they agreed so to arrange matters that their lord should kill Pretty-ears. “Of what other use,” they said to themselves, “is that eater of thorns to us?” “But how cn we manage it,”said tiger, “when our master has given him pledge of security and hashim in his favour?” “At time like this,” said crow, “when master isreduced to skin and bone, he won’t scruple at sin; forA woman torn by hunger will abandon her child.

A snake torn by hunger will eat its own eggs.

What evil will hungry man not do?

Lean men r always pitiless!

And, what is more,
A drunkard, an imbecile, lunatic,
a man tired out, an angry man, hungry man,
a greedy man, frightened man, hasty man,
or man in love never do right thing.”
‘After thus deliberating they all went to lion. “Have you found
anything to eat?” lion asked. “We’ve done our best,” they replied, “but
we haven’t found thing!” “Well,” said lion, “how r we to keep alive
now?” “Sire,” said crow, “if we don’t get our natural food we’ll all
surely die.” “And what,” asked lion, “is our natural food?” “Pretty-
ears!” whispered crow in lion’s ear.

[Page 452] ‘The lion touched earth and covered his ears in horror.

“We’ve given him pledge of security,” he said, “and we must stand by it.

How cn we eat him? For
Not gifts of land nor gifts of gold,
nor gifts of cattle nor gifts of food
are said to be greatest gift.

Of all gifts greatest is gift of safety.

Moreover
The merit of horse-sacrifice,
the fulfilment of all desires,
comes to man who protects
those who take refuge with him.”
‘“True!” said crow. “Our lord must not kill him. But there’s no
reason why we shouldn’t so arrange things that he offers his body
voluntarily.” At this lion kept silence. So when suitable occasion
offered crow found pretext to bring dm all into lion’s presence.

“Sire,” he said, “however hard we try we cn find no food. Your Majesty is
weak from days of fasting. So now make meal of my flesh, for
All subjects r dependent on their lord.

Only well-rooted trees bear fruit,
and only when king is strong
do men’s works prosper.”
“‘“I’d rather die myself than do such thing!” said lion.

“‘Then jackal made same offer. “Never!” lion replied.

‘The tiger next spoke up. “Let my lord live on my own body!” he said.

“Such thing cn never be right!” lion replied.

‘Finally Pretty-ears, full of confidence, offered himself in same way.

And, in accordance with his offer, lion ripped his belly open and they all
ate him up.

‘And that is why I say:
The words of rogues make even mind of good man waver. If he trusts
them he dies like Pretty-ears.

‘Meanwhile brāhman met third rogue, who spoke to him in the
same way. This time he decided that his senses were defective. So he

abandoned goat, took ritual ablution, and went home, while roguestook goat away and ate it. And so I say:He who takes well-spoken knaveto be man of his own stampis fooled by rogues like brahman who was robbed of his goat.’” 41[Page 453] Pali LiteratureThe Pali language was closer to speech of ordinary man than wasSanskrit, and its style was in general simpler; but though they contain manyfine passages Pali scriptures r largely prosaic and repetitive. samestock phrases and descriptions, often quite lengthy, occur again and againwith dull monotony which cn only be circumvented by drasticabridgement. Yet narrative portions of Pali canon r frequently ofmuch merit. Here for instance, somewhat abridged, is an account of theBuddha’s “Great Going Forth”, passage of intense dramatic force.

“Then lovely women, decked like damsels of gods with every kind of ornament and well trained in dance and song, began to perform. Butthe Bodhisattva had no taste for dancing, and for while sleep overcamehim. women thought: ‘He for whose sake we danced and sang hasfallen asleep-why should we trouble ourselves further?’ And they put uptheir instruments and lay down. lamps of scented oil burned on.

“The Bodhisattva awoke and sat cross-legged on his couch. He saw women with their instruments laid aside, fast asleep. Saliva trickled from mouths of some; some were covered in sweat; some ground their teethin sleep; some snored; garments of some were in disarray, so that theyrepulsively showed their private parts. When he saw dm thus in theirdishevelment he was more than ever disgusted with life of passion. Thegreat hall, decked like heavenly palace of Indra, seemed to him like charnel ground full of scattered corpses. Life seemed as fleeting as houseon fire. ‘How wretched it all is! How afflicted it all is!!’ he cried, and hismind was set even more strongly on asceticism. ‘Today I must leave on theGreat Going Forth,’ he thought, and he rose from his bed and went to thedoor.

“There lay Channa, his head on threshold. ‘Today I must go forth on Great Going Forth,’ he said, ‘get ready my horse’. … When he had thus sent Channa he thought ‘I will see my son’, and he went to apartments of Mother of Rahula, and opened bedroom door. little lamp ofscented oil burned in inner room. Mother of Rahula was sleepingon bed thickly strewn with flowers, with her son’s head on her arm. TheBodhisattva set one foot on threshold and stood gazing at them. ‘If Imove her hand and take up my son I shall waken queen,’ he thought,‘and then I shall not be able to go. When I am Buddha I will come backand see my son.’ And he left palace.”42As further example of Pali prose we give Jataka tale. This story,inculcating fickleness of women, has of course no religious value, andits origin is certainly secular, but we give its framework, in order that thereader may see how most unpromising material has been pressed intoservice for religious purposes. This story is typical of terse dry style ofthe collection, and of tales of [Page 454] marvels which were verypopular in India then as now. reader will recall that verses r theoriginal, round which story itself is built as sort of commentary.

“The Master, who was living at Jeta’s Grove at time, told this story in connexion with backsliding brother. Master asked him if he wanted toreturn to world and regretted taking orders. ‘It’s all because of wilesof women.’ monk answered. ‘Brother,’ said Master, ‘it’s impossibleto keep on your guard against women! Wise men of old couldn’t guardagainst them, even when they dwelt in realms of suparnas.’ 30 Andwhen brother pressed him Master told an old story. ‘In former timesKing Tamba ruled kingdom of BanĀras He had chief queen namedSussondi, woman of utmost beauty. Bodhisattva was born then asa suparna. At that time there was an island of serpents called Island ofSeruma. In that island Bodhisattva dwelt in palace of suparnas.

‘One day he went to Banāras in human guise, and gambled with KingTamba. attendants saw how fair he was, and told Sussondi that ahandsome man was gambling with King. She wanted to see him, so oneday she put on all her ornaments and came to gambling-hall, where,standing among her maids, she watched him. And then he saw Queen.

The two fell in love with one another. King of Suparnas stirred up magic wind in city, and everyone rushed from royal palace, fearing that it might fall. With his magic power he created darkness, seized Queen, and flew to his palace in Isle of Serpents.

‘Nobody knew where Sussondi had gone, but Suparna took hispleasure of her and went back to play with King. Now King had aminstrel named Sagga. Not knowing what had happened to Queen hesaid to minstrel, “Go and seek over land and sea, and find out where theQueen has gone.” So he took money for his journey and, starting in thesuburbs, he sought everywhere until he came to Bhrgukaccha. Just thensome merchants of Bhrgukaccha were setting out by ship for Land ofGold ( ? Burma). He went up to dm and said, “I’m minstrel. If you’llremit my fare and take me with you I’ll make music for you.” They agreed,took him aboard, and set sail.

‘When ship was well under way they called him to make music forthem. “I’d willingly make music for you,” he said, “but if I did fishwould leap out of water and smash your ship”. “When mere manmakes music fish don’t get excited,” they said, “so tune up!” “Thendon’t blame me for anything that may happen,” he said, and he tuned hislute and made music, with strings and voice in perfect unison. fishheard sound, and leapt with excitement. Then sea-monster ( makara)leapt from sea, fell on ship, and smashed it to pieces. Sagga lay on aplank and drifted with wind to Isle of Serpents, and landed by abanyan tree near palace of King of Suparnas.

‘Now King of Suparnas had gone away to play dice, and so [Page455] Queen Sussondi had come down from palace and was walking onthe shore; and she saw and recognized Sagga minstrel, and asked himhow he came. He told her all his story. She told him not to be afraid, andcomforted him, and clasped him in her arms, and had him taken to thepalace, where she laid him on couch. When he was revived she gave himfine food, bathed him in sweetly scented water, dressed him in fine clothes,adorned him with beautiful fragrant flowers, and again made him rest on thefine couch. So she cared for him, and whenever King of Suparnasreturned she hid him; then, as soon as he went again, she took passionatepleasure with him.

‘When month and half month had passed, merchants from Banāras
landed on that island at foot of banyan tree in search of fuel and
water. He boarded their ship, went back to Banāras, and saw King while
he was gambling. Then he took his lute, and, making music, sang first
stanza:
“There blows scent of timira trees
with sounding of evil sea,
but Sussondi is far away.

Tamba, desires torment me!”
‘When he heard this, Suparna sang second stanza:
“How did you cross ocean?

How came you to see Seruma?

How was it, Sagga,
that she and you did meet?”
‘Then Sagga sang three stanzas:
“From Bhrgukaccha there sailed
traders in search of wealth.

A monster broke their ship.

I floated on plank.

“In her soft and tender lap
ever fragrant with sandal
the gentle lady pillowed me,
as mother her own son.

“This you should know, King Tamba,
the fair-eyed lady gave me
food with her own hands,
and drink, and raiment, and bed.”
‘Even as minstrel sang Suparna was filled with regret. “Though I
dwelt in Palace of Suparnas,” he thought, “I could not keep her!

What is wanton to me?” So he brought her back, gave her to King,
and went away. And he never came again.’
“When story was over Master declared Four Noble Truths ( p.

269), and identified births. … ‘Ananda ( p. 261) was King o,
Banaras, and I was King of Suparnas.’” 43
[Page 455] As examples of Pali poetry we give few verses from the
“Songs of Elder Monks and Nuns” ( Theragāthā and Therāgāthā), a
collection of poems ascribed, falsely no doubt, to great disciples of the
Buddha in early days of Order. style of these poems is simpler
than that of courtly Sanskrit literature, and suggests influence of popular
song. first is attributed to Ambapālī, beautiful courtezan of Vaisali
who became Buddhist nun.

“Black and glossy as bee and curled was my hair;
now in old age it is just like hemp or bark-cloth.

Not otherwise is word of truthful. …
“My hair clustered with flowers was like box of sweet perfume;
now in old age it stinks like rabbit’s pelt.

Not otherwise is word of truthful …
“Once my eyebrows were lovely, as though drawn by an artist;
now in old age they r overhung with wrinkles.

Not otherwise is word of truthful. …
“Dark and long-lidded, my eyes were bright and flashing as jewels;
now in old age they r dulled and dim.

Not otherwise is word of truthful. …
“My voice was as sweet as cuckoo’s, who flies in woodland
thickets;
now in old age it is broken and stammering.

Not otherwise is word of truthful. …
“Once my hands were smooth and soft, and bright with jewels and
gold;
now in old age they twist like roots.

Not otherwise is word of truthful. …
“Once my body was lovely as polished gold;
now in old age it is covered all over with tiny wrinkles.


Not otherwise is word of truthful. …
“Once my two feet were soft, as though filled with down;
now in old age they r cracked and wizened.

Not otherwise is word of truthful. …
“Such was my body once. Now it is weary and tottering,
the home of many ills, an old house with flaking plaster.

Not otherwise is word of truthful.”44
Few ancient Indian poems show such deep love of nature as some of
these verses, ascribed to pious monks of 5th century B.C.

[Page 457] “When drum of clouds thunders in heaven,
and all ways of birds r thick with rain,
the monk sits in hills in ecstasy
and finds no joy greater than this.

“When by rivers covered with flowers,
and gaily adorned with reeds of varied hue,
the goodly monk sits on bank in ecstasy
he finds no joy greater than this.

“When rain pours down at night,
and elephants trumpet in distant thickets,
the monk sits in hills in ecstasy,
and finds no joy greater than this.” 45
“When crane with clear pale wing
flies in fear from black cloud,
seeking shelter and finding none,
The river Ajakaranī gives me joy.

“Who would not love
the rose-apple trees
fair on either bank
beside great cavern?

“Freed from fear of flocks of cranes
the frogs croak softly now.

This is no time to leave hills and streams!

Safe, good and pleasant is Ajakaranā.” 46 As an example of Pali descriptive poetry we give stirring passage from Ceylon Chronicle, Mahāvamsa, describing capture of Vijitanagara, capital of Tamil invader Elara, by Sinhalese national hero, King Dutthagamani ( 161–137 B.C. ), with aid of his favourite elephant, Kandula.

“The city had three moats,
and was guarded by high wall.

Its gate was covered with iron
hard for foes to shatter.

“The elephant knelt on his knees
and, battering with his tusks
stone and mortar and brick,
he attacked iron gate.

[Page 458] “The Tamils from watch-tower
threw missiles of every kind,
balls of red-hot iron
and [vessels of] molten pitch.

“Down fell smoking pitch
upon Kandula’s back.

In anguish of pain he fled
and plunged in pool of water.

‘This is no drinking bout!’
cried Gothaïmbara.

‘Go, batter iron gate!

Batter down gate!!’
“In his pride best of tuskers
took heart and trumpeted loud.

He reared up out of water
and stood on bank defiant.

“The elephant-doctor washed away
the pitch, and put on balm.

The King mounted elephant
and rubbed his brow with his hand.

‘Dear Kandula, I’ll make you
the lord of all Ceylon!’
he said, and beast was cheered,
and was fed with best of fodder.

“He was covered with cloth,
and he was armoured well
with armour for his back
of seven-fold buffalo hide.

“On armour was placed
a skin soaked in oil.

Then, trumpeting like thunder,
he came on, fearless of danger.

“He pierced door with his tusks.

With his feet he trampled threshold.

And gate and lintel
crashed loudly to earth.” 47

## Prākrit Literature
Space will not permit more than brief reference to Prakrit scripturesof Jainas, examples of which we hv already quoted ( p. 293f). Ingeneral they hv little literary value. Like Jainism itself they tend to bearid, and, like Pali scriptures but in even greater measure, they repeatlengthy stock phrases and descriptions, which may hv had somemnemonic value, but which to modern reader r very irritating.Lengthy descriptions of Tirthaskaras, of pious monks, mighty kings,wealthy merchants, prosperous cities etc. occur over and over again, inexactly same words throughout canon, and give it flavour ofuninspired dryness. style is somewhat more ornate than that of Paliscriptures, and closer to courtly Sanskrit.The poetry of Jainas is better than their prose. In this connexion wecannot refrain from quoting remarkable poem, which is one of mosthumorous things in ancient Indian literature, and which, by some luckychance, has found its way into Jaina canon, among austere pages ofthe Sutrakrtānga. It is intended as warning of grim fate in store for thebacksliding monk, and throws most unexpected light on one aspect ofIndian marriage. Our translation is rather free, but we hv tried to keepsome of lively vernacular style of original.

“A celibate monk shouldn’t fall in love,
and though he hankers after pleasure he should hold himself in
check,
for these r pleasures
which some monks enjoy.

“If monk breaks his vows,
and falls for woman,
she upbraids him and raises her foot to him,
and kicks him on head.

‘Monk, if you won’t live with me
as husband and wife,
I’ll pull out my hair and become nun,
for you shall not live without me!’
“But when she has him in her clutches
it’s all housework and errands!

‘Fetch knife to cut this gourd!’
‘Get me some fresh fruit!’
“‘We want wood to boil greens,
and for fire in evening!’
‘Now paint my feet!’
‘Come and massage my back!’…
[Page 460] “‘Get me my lip-salve!’
‘Find my sunshade and slippers!’
‘I want knife to cut this string!’
‘Take my robe and hv it dyed blue!’…
‘Fetch me my tweezers and my comb!’
‘Get me ribbon to tie my hair!’
‘Now pass me my looking-glass!’
Put my toothbrush down beside me!’…
‘Fetch pot and drum and rag-ball,
for our little boy to play with!’
‘Monk, rains r on way,
patch roof of house and look to stores!’
‘Bring me chair with twine seat,
and my wooden-soled slippers to go out walking!’
So pregnant women boss their husbands,
just as though they were household slaves.

“When child is born, reward of their labours,
she makes father hold baby.

And sometimes fathers of sons
stagger under their burdens like camels.

“They get up at night, as though they were nurses,
to lull howling child to sleep,
and, though they r shamefaced about it,
scrub dirty garments, just like washermen. …
“So, monks, resist wiles of women,
avoid their friendship and company.

The little pleasure you get from them
will only lead you into trouble!” 48
A number of medieval works of secular nature were written in Prakrit,
chief of which r poems “The Building of Causeway”
( Setubandha), describing Rama’s invasion of Ceylon and falsely ascribed to
Kālidasā; “The Slaying of King of Bengal” ( Gausavadha), long
panegyric by 8th-century poet Vakpati, describing exploits of
Yasovarman, king of Kānyakubja ( p. 70); and drama named after its
heroine, Karpūiramañjarī, by 10th-century dramatist Rājaśekhara. These
works, though not without merit, r indistinguishable in style and content
from comparable Sanskrit productions, and need not detain us.

[Page 461] most important literary work in Prākrit is “SevenHundred” ( Saptasataka) of Hala. This is large collection of selfcontainedstanzas of great charm and beauty, in Āryā metre ( p. 51 If). Theirtraditional author was shadowy Sātavāhana king Hala, who ruled in theDeccan in 1st century A.D., but in fact many of these verses seemconsiderably later, and they must be looked on as anonymous. They arenotable for their conciseness; like Amaru, their authors were able to suggesta whole story in four short lines. This great economy of words and masterlyuse of suggestion would indicate that verses were written for highlyeducated literary audience; but they contain simple and natural descriptionsand references to lives of peasants and lower classes, which point topopular influence. treatment of love affairs of country folk remindsus of early Tamil poetry, and suggests that “Hāla” may hv tapped awidely diffused source in South Indian folksong.

“Last night with scorn lady gave wanderer
straw for his bed.

This morning she gathers it together,


weeping.”
‘This morning, my friend, I heard man singing,
and his song reminded me of my lover,
and opened all wounds
that shafts of Love-god had made in my heart.’”
“‘Waiting for you, first half of night
passed like moment.

The rest was like year,
for I was sunk in grief.’”
“When season of rains, with its high clouds, 31
has passed like youth,
the earliest single kāsa flower
comes, like grey hair on earth.”
‘Ungrateful lover, still I see mud
in village street,
which, on rainy night,
I trod for your sake, shameless one!’”49
Tamil Literature
The oldest Tamil literature goes back to early centuries of the
Christian era. Its dating is still matter of some dispute but it [Page 462]
seems almost certain that earliest stratum was composed before the
great Pallava dynasty of Kāncī became dominant in Tamil Land in the
6th century, and it is probably some centuries older than this.

Tamil tradition tells of three literary academies ( śangam) which met at Madurai. earliest of these was attended by gods and legendary sages, and all its works hv perished. Of second, there survives only early Tamil grammar, Tolkāppiyam. poets of Third Śangam, on other hand, wrote “Eight Anthologies” ( Ettutogai), which r greatest monument of ancient Tamil literature, as well as number of later works.

Some authorities hv doubted tradition of Śangams, and it is almost
certain that grammar Tolkāppiyam, attributed to Second Śangam, is
later than many of poems of Third. But tradition of an —gams, which is strongly held one, has no parallel in Northern legend, andwe may believe that bards of Tamil Land, who wandered over thecountry enjoying patronage of chieftains and villagers alike, would meetfrom time to time in city of Madurai for great festivals of poetry andmusic, and that many of verses of Anthologies were recited there.

The poetry of “Eight Anthologies” is little known outside land of
its origin, and its language is so archaic that modern educated Tamil cannot read it without special study. relation of language of theŚangam literature to Tamil as it is now written is perhaps similar to that ofPiers Plowman to modern English. tradition of Tamil poetry at timeof composition of these works must already hv been long one, forthe poetic conventions finally fixed in Tolkāppiyam had almost reached their finished form even in earliest poems of Anthologies. But theirstyle is much nearer that of folk literature than is style of courtlySanskrit. life of peasant and scenes of countryside, thebustle of towns and ruthlessness of war, r here depicted as thoughfrom direct experience, and with no formal unrealistic idealization.

Together “Eight Anthologies “32 make up very large body of poeticliterature, and contain well over 2,000 poems, ascribed to more than 200authors. To dm must be added “The Ten Songs” ( Pattuppāttu), containingten longer poems of similar style but somewhat later date. Until end of last century this great collection was [Page 463] almost forgotten, evenby Tamils themselves; only within last fifty years hv raremanuscripts containing it been edited and given to world. Much is stilluntranslated, and full and thorough study of Śangam literature fromthe critical and historical point of view has yet to be made.

Very early Tamils developed passion for classification which is noticeable in many aspects of ancient Indian learning. Poetry was divided into two main groups: “internal” ( agam), dealing with love, and “external” ( puram), dealing with praise of kings. further division was made acc to region of Tamil Land to which poem referred orwas most appropriate. Conventionally there were five regions ( tinai): thehills ( kurinji), dry lands ( pālai), jungle and woodland ( mullai), thecultivated plains ( marudam), and coast ( neydal). Each was connectedwith some special aspect of love or war; thus hills were scene ofpoems on pre-nuptial love and cattle-raiding; dry lands, of longseparation of lovers, and of laying waste of countryside; jungle,of brief parting of lovers, and of raiding expeditions; valleys, ofpost-nuptial love or wiles of courtezans, and of siege; and seacoast,of parting of fishermen’s wives from their lords, and of pitched battle.

To each region were attributed its own appropriate flowers, animals and people. Every poem of “Eight Anthologies” was classified in one of five sections, but much of poetry was written with little regard for this formal classification.

A unique feature of Tamil poetry is initial rhyme or assonance. This
does not appear in earliest Tamil literature, but by end of the
Śangam period it was quite regular. first syllable, or syllables, of each
couplet must rhyme. Thus:
ISAITAD’ eninum iyarrior drrdl
AIrADu nirpadm dnmai; isaiyungal
KANDARirai alaikkuh kdnal an tan serppa
PENDIRum valaro marru.”
“Though you fail, to work and struggle,
unwaveringly steadfast-this is manliness.

Lord of cool and lovely shore, where waves shake thorny
groves!

Will not even women flourish in prosperity?’” 50 This initial assonance, in some poems continued through four or more lines, is never to be found in poetry of Sanskritic languages, or as far as we know, in that of any other language. Its effect, little strange at first, rapidly becomes pleasant to reader, and to Tamil is as enjoyable as end rhyme of European poetry.

[Page 464] We give brief anthology of short poems and extracts from
this wonderful literature. 33
Here mother tells of her son, who has gone to war.

“If you lean against pillar of my little home
and ask whereabouts of my son,
I reply, ‘I cannot tell you’.

Behold, like tiger’s cavern of rock,
the womb that bore him!

You will find him on field of war.”52
The three following poems r attributed to poetess Avvaiyar.

“It charms not like harp,
it accords not with time-beat,
it conveys no meaning,
but prattling of son
brings bliss to his father.

So, O King Nedumai Anji,
through grace of your favour

“To allow little children of village

Here Avvaiyar compares wealth of luxurious king of Tondai

“Bedecked with peacock-feathers, garlanded with flowers,

[Page 465] “O bee, fair of wing, ever in search of flower-garlands,

Here girl speaks to her playmate:
“What bright bracelets you have! Do listen!

As I was playing in road

Here newly married girl makes her first attempts at cooking:
“Her fingers, slender as kandal blossom, had been squeezing new

Her clothes had not been washed since she wiped her fingers on them.

The appetizing steam had got into her lily-like eyes.

He of bright brow was most pleased with what he was eating.”61
Striking touches of natural description often illumine rather

“Though milk turn sour, though day turn to night,
though path of Vedas lead men astray,
may you stand unshaken, long famed, with loyal

of hermits who perform hard penances.”62

O king, like death, for whom there is no cure,

In an uninhabited land, land of bitter hardship,

Here girl consoles her lovelorn friend:
“‘The toiling fishermen catch shoals
in their close-meshed nets, and soft-headed prawn,

A young man praises his sweetheart’s cookery:
‘At every post before house
is tied gentle calf of crooked-horned buffalo.

There dwells my sweetheart, curving and lovely,

“‘She has cut leaves of garden plantain

A village festival:
“The farmers who harvest rice in hot sun
now leap into waves of clear sea.

The sailors, captains of stout craft,

women, bright-bangled and garlanded, drink
the juice of palm and pale sugar-cane,
and juice of coconut which grows in sand,
then running they plunge into sea.” 66
A poignant description of famine:
“The hearth has forgotten cooking:
It is overgrown with moss and mould.

The woman, thin with hunger,
has breasts like wrinkled bladders.

Their nipples r quite dry,
but child chews them, weeping.

She looks down at his face
and tears hang on her lashes.”67
[Page 468] Our final quotation from “Eight Anthologies” is plaint
of neglected wife:
“My garment smells of ghee and frying curry,
and is stained with dirt and lampblack.

“My shoulders stink with sweat of child


whom I carry upon dm and feed at my breast.

“I cannot face my lord, who, in gay attire,
rides in his car to street of harlots.” 68
The next stratum of Tamil literature shows much greater Aryan influence.

Āryan religious ideas and practices, not unknown even in Eight Anthologies, had by now been thoroughly grafted on to original Tamil heritage, and Jaina influence is prominent. “The Eighteen Minor Works”( Padinenkilkanakku) r largely gnomic and moralizing in character, thetwo most famous being Tirukkural, and Nāladiyār. former,sometimes called “Bible of Tamil Land” is series of brief metricalproverbs on many aspects of life and religion, and we hv already quoted some of its aphorisms ( p. 339). We add few others of more secular type.

“Vain is kingdom where r all good things
but no love between ruler and ruled.”

“Even hermit ceases his penance
if husbandman folds his arms.”

“Earth laughs in scorn
at those who plead poverty.”

“No food is sweeter than rice-gruel,
when you hv worked for it.”

“Wide as sea is joy of love,
but wider still sorrow of parting.”

“Love is stronger than wine,
for very thought of it intoxicates.”


“Sweethearts delight in lover’s quarrel
for greater delight of making it up.” 69
Ndla.diyar is more formal and literary in style, and contains verses of
much merit and high ethical content.

[Page 469] “Better hatred than friendship of fools.

Better death than chronic illness.

Better to be killed than soul-destroying contempt.

Better abuse than praise undeserved.”
“True housekeeping is to eat meal
sharing, as far as may be, with friend and foe alike.

The useless men who eat their food alone
will never pass gate of heaven.”
“Though you feed him with care from golden dish
a dog will always prefer carrion.

Though you deal with base as you would with good
their deeds will always show dm up.”
“Hillmen remember their lovely hills.

Farmers remember their fertile fields.

The good remember another’s kindness.

The base recall only fancied slights.”
“As scroll read by one who well understands it,
as wealth to man of generous spirit,
as sharp sword in warrior’s hand,
is beauty of faithful wife.”
“To those who once embraced their lovers
whose broad chests were hung with garlands,
when their loved ones r away
the thunder sounds like funeral drum.”70

By 6th century Āryan influence had penetrated whole of Tamil land, and her kings and chiefs worshipped and supported gods ofHinduism, Jainism and Buddhism. indigenous style of poetry wasrapidly altering under influence of Sanskrit, and Tamil poets took towriting long poems which they called by Sanskrit name kivya. Theearliest and greatest of these is “The Jewelled Anklet” ( Śilappadigāram),which is still very different from Sanskrit poetry. Though written for aneducated audience and in faultless literary style it is near to life of thepeople; it is by comparison realistic, dealing with lives of two ordinaryfolk enmeshed in unhappy circumstance, and, unlike Sanskrit courtly“epic”, it sounds note of true tragedy.

The traditional author of poem was Ilangovadigal, grandson of great Cola king Karikalan, who lived in 1st or 2nd century A.D. tradition is certainly false, and poem is several [Page 470] centurieslater. Its author, whoever he was, though great poet, was not greatstoryteller. His tale was well known to his hearers, and he could afford to be irritatingly allusive and terse in important narrative passages, and lingerlovingly over interesting description. He successfully drew together all thethemes of earlier Tamil poets and welded dm into whole, in theframework of story of luckless Kovalan and Kannagi. Rightly thispoem and Kamban’s Rdmdyanam r looked on as national Epics of theTamil people. We give an outline of story, with translation,considerably abridged, of its climax, which has grimly baroque force andsplendour, unparalleled elsewhere in Indian literature. It is imbued withboth ferocity of early Tamils and their stern respect for justice, and,incidentally, throws much light on character of early Tamil kingship.

Kovalan, son of wealthy merchant of city of Pugar or Kavirippattinam, married Kannagi, lovely daughter of another merchant. For some time they lived together happily, until, at festival at royal court, Kovalan, met dancer Madavi, and fell in love with her.

He bought her favours and in his infatuation forgot Kannagi and his home.

Gradually he spent all his wealth on dancer, even to Kannagi’s jewels.

At last he was penniless, and returned repentantly to his uncomplaining  wife. Their only fortune was precious pair of anklets, which she gave to him willingly. With these as their capital they decided to go to great city of Madurai, where Kovalan hoped to recoup his fortunes by trade.

On their arrival at Madurai they found shelter in cottage, and Kovalanwent to market, to sell one of Kannagi’s anklets. But queen ofNedunjeliyan, king of Pandyas, had just been robbed of similar ankletby wicked court jeweller. jeweller happened to see Kovalan withKannagi’s anklet, and immediately seized it and informed King. Guardswere sent to apprehend Kovalan, who was cut down immediately, withouttrial. When news was brought to Kannagi she fainted away; but shequickly recovered and, with her eyes ablaze with anger, she went out intothe town, carrying remaining anklet in her hand as proof of herhusband’s innocence.

‘Chaste women of Madurai, listen to me!

Today my sorrows cannot be matched.

Things which should never hv happened hv befallen me.

How cn I bear this injustice?’…
“All folk of rich city of Madurai
saw her, and were moved by her grief and affliction.

In wonder and sorrow they cried:
‘Wrong that cannot be undone has been done to this lady!

[Page 471] ‘Our King’s straight sceptre is bent!

What cn this mean?

Lost is glory of King Over Kings,
the Lord of Umbrella and Spear! …
‘A new and mighty goddess
has come before us,
in her hand golden anklet!

What cn this mean?

‘This woman afflicted and weeping
from her lovely dark-stained eyes
is as though filled with godhead!

What cn this mean?’
“Thus, raising loud accusing voices,
the people of Madurai befriended and comforted her,
and among tumultuous throng
some showed her her husband’s body.

“She, golden vine, beheld him,
but her he could not see. …
“Then red-rayed sun folded his fiery arms
and hid behind great mountain,
and wide world
was veiled in darkness.

“In brief twilight
Kanagi cried aloud
and whole city
echoed her wailing.

“In morning she had taken wreath from his neck
and decked her hair with its flowers;
in evening she saw him lying
in pool of his own blood.

“But he saw not agony of her grief
as she mourned in sorrow and wrath. …
[Page 472] ‘Are there women here? r there women
who could bear such wrong
done to their wedded lords?

Are there women here? r there such women?

‘Are there good men here? r there good men
who cherish their children
and guard dm with care?

Are there men here? r there such men?

‘Is there god here? Is there god
in this city of Madurai, where sword of king
has slain an innocent man?

Is there god here? Is there god?’
“Lamenting thus she clasped her husband’s breast,
and it seemed that he rose to his feet and said,
‘The full-moon of your face has faded,’
and he stroked her face with his hands.

“She fell to ground, sobbing and crying,
and clasped her lord’s feet with her bangled hands;
and he left behind his human form
and went, surrounded by gods.

“And, as he went, he said,
‘My darling, you must stay!’
‘Surely this
was vision,’ she cried.

‘I will not join my lord
till my great wrath is appeased!

I will see cruel King,
and ask for his explanation!’
“And she stood on her feet,
her large eyes full of tears,
and, wiping her eyes,
she went to gate of palace.

“I saw, alas, I saw in dream
the sceptre fall and royal umbrella.

The bell at palace gate rang of itself,
while whole heaven shook in confusion!

‘A darkness swallowed sun,
a rainbow glowed in night,
and burning meteor
crashed to earth by day.’


“Thus spoke Queen,
and took her maids and her bodyguard,
and went to King on lion-throne,
and told him her evil dream.

[Page 473] “Then came cry from gate:

Kannagi was then admitted to King’s presence.

‘Cruel King, this I must say. …

to Madurai to earn wealth,
and today you hv slain him

‘Lady,’ said King,
‘it is kingly justice
to put to death
an arrant thief.’”
Then Kannagi showed her anklet to King. On comparing it very
carefully with remaining anklet of pair belonging to Queen, he
realized that Kovalan had been innocent.

“When he saw it parasol fell from his head
and sceptre trembled in his hand.

‘I am no king,’ he said,
‘who hv heeded words of goldsmith.

‘I am thief. For first time
I hv failed to protect my people.

Now may I die!’
[And he fell to ground, dead. 3
[Page 474] Then Kannagi said to Queen:
‘If I hv always been true to my husband
I will not suffer this city to flourish,
but I will destroy it as King is destroyed!

Soon you will see that my words r true!’
“And with these words she left palace,
and cried out through city, ‘Men and women
of great Madurai of four temples,
listen! Listen you gods in heaven!

‘Listen to me, you holy sages!

I curse capital of King
who so cruelly wronged
my beloved lord!’
“With her own hand she tore left breast from her body.

Thrice she surveyed city of Madurai,
calling her curse in bitter agony.

Then she flung her fair breast on scented street. …
“And burning mouth of Fire-god opened
as gods who guarded city closed their doors. …
“The high priest, astrologer and judges,
the treasurer and learned councillors,
the palace servants and maids,
stood silent and still as painted pictures.

“The elephant-riders and horsemen,
the charioteers and foot-soldiers
with their terrible swords, all fled from fire
which raged at gate of royal palace. …
“And street of sellers of grain,
the street of chariots, with its bright-coloured garlands,
and four quarters of four classes
were filled with confusion and flamed like forest on fire. …
“In street of singing girls
where so often tabor had sounded
with sweet gentle flute and tremulous harp …
the dancers, whose halls were destroyed, cried out:
‘Whence comes this woman? Whose daughter is she?

A single woman, who has lost her husband,has conquered evil King with her anklet,and has destroyed our city with fire’”71[Page 475] At last patron goddess of city interceded withKannagi, and she agreed to withdraw her curse, and fire abated. Weakwith loss of blood from her self-amputated breast, Kannagi struggled to ahill outside city, where, after few days, she died, and was reunitedwith Kovalan in heaven. Meanwhile news of her death spreadthroughout Tamil Land. She was deified, and temples raised andfestivals held in her honour, and she became patron goddess of wifelyloyalty and chastity.

A little later than “The Jewelled Anklet” was composed its sequelManimigalai, attributed to poet Sattan of Madurai. Though by traditionit is earlier of two all other evidence suggests opposite, for itassumes reader’s knowledge of “The Jewelled Anklet”, to which it is asort of Buddhistic supplement. “The Jewelled Anklet”, though containingmany religious and moral lessons, was primarily written to tell story,while in Manimegalai story is mere framework for philosophicalpolemic, and atmosphere of narrative passages has some of theotherworldly formality of courtly Sanskrit kavya. heroine,Manimegalai, is daughter of Kovalan, hero of “The JewelledAnklet”, by dancer Madavi, who became Buddhist nun on hearing ofher former lover’s death. story tells of love of PrinceUdayakumaran -for Manimegalai, and miraculous preservation of herchastity. In end she becomes Buddhist nun like her mother, and mostof poem is taken up with her discussions with members of various sects,both Hindu and heterodox, and her triumphant refutation of their doctrines.A third Tamil “epic”, Sivaga-Sindimani, describes exploits of thehero Sivaga or Jivaka, superman who excels in every art from archery tothe curing of snake-bite, and who wins new bride for his harem with everyfeat, only to become Jaina monk after his many triumphs. author wasa Jaina, Tiruttakkadevar. His work is fantastic and lacking in any contactwith real life; its style is elegant and ornate, and much influenced by courtlySanskrit. It is definitely later than other two “epics”.By now Tamil poets were not satisfied with their own traditions, andtranslations and adaptations of many Northern works were made, mostnotable of which is Kamban’s Rāmāyanam, composed in 9th century.

This great poem is still known and loved in Tamil Land, and is by nomeans mere translation of original, for Kamban adapts themes as hethinks fit, and here and there adds episodes of his own. It is noteworthy thatin Kamban’s hands demon Ravan frequently takes on proportionsof heroic figure, and contrasts favourably with rather weak andunimpressive Rāma. Like Milton, Kamban was of devil’s party withoutknowing [Page 476] it. real glory of medieval Tamil literature,however, is undoubtedly hymns of Śaivite and Vaisnavite devotionalteachers, which r among great religious literature of world, andwhich we hv discussed and quoted in another connexion ( p. 330ff). Otherthan these, later Tamil literature produced little of first order.

The canon of Tamil saivites contains work of merit ( p. 334), but theadaptations of Puranas and lengthy commentaries on earlierliterature, though not unimportant, need not be discussed here. 34The early literatures of Canarese, Telugu and Malayalam, which hadbegun to be written before end of our period, r less important than thatof Tamil, and need not detain us. They originated at time when Āryaninfluence was already thoroughly entrenched, and, though containing manybeauties, lack originality of early Tamil poetry. Thus they cannot aspireto importance of Tamil, which cn claim one of longest unbrokenliterary traditions of any of world’s living languages.

## Folk Poetry
35
The literatures which we hv been discussing were all work of literary schools with formal conventions and long traditions. Some poetry,obviously, is less formalized than that of classical Sanskrit, and here andthere, notably in verses of Tamil anthologies and PrākritSaptaiataka, we seem to catch echoes of folk-song and popular oralliterature. No Indian writer, however, as far as we know, thought fit torecord folk-song of ancient India, which, if we r to judge by modemanalogy, must hv been plentiful and of high quality. But few verses havebeen preserved in Chinese translation, which may well be words ofgenuine folk-songs of pre-Gupta times.

That part of Buddhist canon called Samyutta NikSya ( p. 267) was first translated into Chinese about A.D. 440, from manuscript acquired in Ceylon by Fa-hsien in 411. At end of book occurs section which isnot to be found in Pali version as it exists at [Page 477] present, butwhich must hv been included in Fa-hsien’s manuscript. Probably theverses here quoted were sung in India between time of codificationof Pali canon in 1st century B.C. ( p. 266) and beginning of 5thcentury A.D.The passage in question describes monk, who hears singing ofvarious secular songs, and converts dm to Buddhist purposes bycomparatively slight alterations. Thus first verse quoted is capped by themonk with pious wish that he may gently flow to Nirvana, and so on.

The song of lady who got on badly with her “in-laws”:
“O river Ganges, all I now wantis to go with your waters that flow gently to sea;that never again by my father- and mother-in-lawI may at every turn be scolded and abused.”The song of melon-thief:“Bright moon, I beg you not to come out.

Wait where you r till I hv cut these melons.

But when I hv got my melons safely away,
then come out or not, just as you please.”
The song of poor man:
“So long as I own just one pig,
and single jar full of good wine,
one cup to pour wine into,
and someone to fill my cup again and again-
so long as I own just as much as that,
there is nothing else that bothers me at all.”
The song of girl who, going to tryst with her lover on rainy night,
slips and falls in mud:,
“The hair of my head is all loose and astray;
my lovely necklace has fallen in deep mud.

My rings and bracelets r all broken and spoiled;
when I come to my lover, what shall I give him to wear?”
The song of lover, picnicking with his mistress:
“With thoughts of love, all for our ease and pleasure,
we loiter under shade of green trees.

The running stream flows swift and clear,
the sound of my zither is very tuneful and sweet.

The spring weather is just right for our jaunt;
what happiness could there be greater than ours?”
[Page 478] Advice to dove:
“Dove, my bird, you must lay up your stores-
sesamum-seed, rice, millet and rest-
and take dm to tree on very top of hill,
and make yourself nest-cavern high and bright.

Then when Heaven sends rainy season
you will be sure of lodging, food and drink.”
