X
EPILOGUE: HERITAGE OF INDIA


## IMPACT OF WEST
[Page 479]
INDIA’S ancient culture did not perish before onslaughts of Muslims, as did that of Persia. Under rule of some of Delhi sultans of Middle Ages there was persecution, and we read of temples being razed to ground and brāhmans put to death for practising their devotions in public; but in general Muslims were reasonably tolerant, and at alltimes Hindu chiefs continued to rule in outlying parts of India, payingtribute to their Muslim overlords. Conversions to Islam were numerous,though only in few regions were majority of Indians persuaded toembrace new faith. Hindu and Muslim lived side by side and, after afew centuries, Hindus in those parts of India dominated by Muslimsoften accepted situation as normal. In such conditions mutual influencewas inevitable. Hindus began to learn Persian, official language of theirMuslim rulers, and Persian words found their way into vernaculars.

Well-to-do Hindu families often adopted system of “strict parda” from Muslims, and made their womenfolk veil their faces in public. surviving Hindu kings borrowed new military techniques from theMuslims, learnt to employ cavalry with greater effect, and to use heavierarmour and new types of weapon. One great religious teacher of medievalIndia, Kabīr (1440–1518), poor weaver of Banāras, taught thebrotherhood of Hindu and Muslim alike in fatherhood of God, andopposed idolatry and caste practices, declaring that God was equally to befound in temple and mosque. Later, Nanāk (1469–1533), teacher of thePanjāb, taught same doctrine with even greater force, and founded anew faith, that of Sikhs, designed to incorporate all that was best of bothHinduism and Islām.

Nevertheless Muslim invasions, and enforced contact with, newideas, did not hv fertilizing effect upon Hindu culture which mighthave been expected. Hinduism was already very conservative when thelieutenants of Muhammad of Ghor conquered Ganges Valley. In theMiddle Ages, for every tolerant and progressive teacher there must havebeen hundreds of orthodox brahmans, who looked upon themselves as thepreservers of immemorial Āryan Dharma against barbarians whooverran holy [Page 480] land of Bhāratavarsa. Under their influence thecomplex rules of Hindu way of life became if anything stricter and morerigidly applied.

In 16th and 17th centuries Mughal emperors unified practicallythe whole of North India and much of Deccan, and built up an empiresuch as had not been seen since days of Guptas. Mughal periodwas one of great splendour, which has left its mark on India in form ofmany lovely buildings, wherein Islamic and Hindu motifs often blended ina perfect unity. Taj Mahal at Agra, Mughal capital, is of course themost famous memorial of times. Akbar ( 1555–1606), contemporaryof Queen Elizabeth I and first of four great Mughal emperors, fullyrealized that Empire could only stand on basis of complete toleration.

All religious tests and disabilities were abolished, including hated poll-tax on unbelievers. Rajput princes and other Hindus were given high officesof state, without conversion to Islam, and inter-communal marriages wereencouraged by example of Emperor himself. If policy of thegreatest of India’s Muslim rulers had been continued by his successors, herhistory might hv been very different.

The great-grandson of Akbar, Aurangzeb (1659–1707), reversed policy of toleration. Restrictions were placed on free practice of Hindu rites and preferment at court was confined to orthodox Muslims; later thetax on non-Muslims was reimposed. After nearly century of equality thiswas bitterly resented by many Hindus, especially by chiefs, many ofwhom had loyally served earlier Mughals. main resistance camefrom Western Deccan where, around Poona, Maratha chief Śivājī(1627–1680) laid foundations of new Hindu empire. At about thesame time Sikhs of Panjāb, incensed at new policy and thepersecution of their leaders, reformed their faith, and were welded into acloselyknit martial brotherhood. When aged Aurangzeb died theMughal empire was virtually at an end.

Politically 18th century was one of Hindu revival. Though Maratha successors of Śivājī could not build up large, closely-knit empire their horsemen ranged far and wide over India, levying tribute from local chiefs, Hindu and Muslim alike. In Panjāb towards end of century Sikhs built an important kingdom, and almost everywhere Islamwas on defensive. But there was still no real cultural revival inHinduism. Śivājī, brilliant leader, just ruler, and statesman ofconsummate craft, was conservative in his outlook, and appeared to hiscontemporaries rather as restorer of old than as builder of new.

Unlike Akbar, he had no fresh vision of state transcending religious differences, though he learnt [Page 481] much from Mughals in statecraft and military science and respected faith of his adversaries.

The Marathas did not encourage reforms in Hindu society, and India of 18th century was if anything more conservative than it had been in days of first Muslim invasions. It was through influence of Europe that revival came. Early in the16th century Portuguese founded first European trading stations andsettlements. They were followed by Dutch, British, Danes and French, andthroughout 17th century number of European “factories “increased.In 18th century, with breakup of Mughal empire, Europeansbegan to take greater interest in local politics, and by early 19th centurythe British East India Company had virtually pushed out its rivals anddominated most of sub-continent. comparative ease with which theBritish established their supremacy is measure of political decadenceof India at time. By middle of 19th century whole of Indiawas either directly ruled by Britain, or governed indirectly through pettyprinces with local autonomy. new conqueror had come, conqueror farmore alien to Hindu than Muslims had been, with an aggressiveculture and immense technical superiority.

Hindu society reacted at first to British rulers as it had done to Muslims, tending to withdraw itself even more into closed circle of its ancient traditions, and there was no realization of fundamental break with past. From orthodox point of view British rulers of Indiaconstituted caste, low in social scale, which had succeeded in gainingpolitical power. This caste had its own rules and customs which were notthose of Āryan, and should therefore not be imitated. British readilyaccepted this position, and, after 18th century, made few attempts atsocial contact. Any real friendship between Englishman and Indian becamemore and more difficult as century progressed-in fact Englishman inIndia unconsciously tended to adopt ideas of social stratification of theIndians whom he ruled, and to look upon his own people as members of aclass so exalted above Indians that any close association with dm wastaboo. This attitude was strengthened by Mutiny of 1857.

Nevertheless presence of Europeans could not but hv its effect. Except in certain parts of South India missionary activity in 18thcentury was insignificant; but early in 19th century Britishevangelical conscience awakened to India, and missions and missionschools sprang up in all larger towns. Meanwhile Company felt agrowing need for subordinate officers and clerks trained in English. Just as,in Muslim times, Hindu desirous of [Page 482] governmentemployment was compelled to learn Persian, so now he had to learnEnglish. Middle class Hindu fathers began to send their sons to Europeanschools, despite dangers of ritual impurity, and Western ideas began toaffect well-to-do educated Indian.

The Portuguese had succeeded in “westernizing” many of their Indian and Sinhalese subjects, and to this day Indian blood flows in veins of some old Portuguese families; few Indians in service of France cameto understand and admire culture of their conquerors; but perhaps thefirst Indian to learn enough from West to be able to hold his own withthe best minds of Europe, and yet still to love and respect his own culture,was Bengali Ram Mohan Roy, friend of Jeremy Bentham. RamMohan Roy, who was born in 1772 and died in England in 18S5, advocatedthe frank acceptance of all that Europe had to teach, and sect whichlooked to him for inspiration, Brahma Samaj, was in many ways closerto Christianity than to Hinduism. Never large in numbers, its influence waswidespread.

From days of Ram Mohan Roy young Indians, at first very few, but soon in greater numbers, began to come to England for education. littleband of Hindus educated on western lines, first in Bengal and then in otherparts of India, tended to go further in rejection of their own culture thantheir descendants; they were fully conscious of degeneracy which besettheir land, and many seem to hv been rather ashamed of their Hindubackground. Mutiny, which was fundamentally reactionary, found nosupport among tiny westernized intelligentsia. Universities ofCalcutta, Bombay and Madras, founded in 1857, year of Mutiny, atfirst paid scant attention to ancient culture of India, but taught apredominantly Western curriculum through Western staff.

By end of 19th century, however, situation had changed. Anew generation began to realize that Hindu culture had much of permanentvalue, and that slavish imitation of West could not solve India’sproblems. New organizations gave expression to this outlook. AryaSamaj claimed to reform Hinduism by purging it of all later degeneratefeatures and by return to Vedas, very liberally interpreted, and hadconsiderable success. Indian National Congress, founded in 1885,became mouthpiece of Indian public opinion. Newspapers in Englishand vernaculars multiplied.

Not only was Hindu culture largely rehabilitated in eyes of intelligent Hindus, but it even began to make counter-propaganda. few learned Europeans and Americans had long recognized nobility of much ancient Indian religious thought. Now, through [Page 483] TheosophicalSociety (which, despite its claim to represent quintessence of allreligions, propagates modernized Hinduism) and RamakrishnaMission, voice of Hinduism was heard in West. Swāmī Vivekānanda(1862–1902), splendid speaker of great spiritual power and personalmagnetism, preached Hinduism to large audiences in Europe and Americaand found willing hearers. Here and there Indians abjured West root andbranch, and fanatically defended even those aspects of Hinduism which hadcompletely outlived their usefulness; but, despite these reactionaries, thenew Hinduism was very different from old.

Rām Mohan Roy had sounded theme with his passionate advocacy ofsocial reform; Vivekananda repeated it with more nationalist timbre, whenhe declared that highest form of service of Great Mother was socialservice. Other great Indians, chief of whom was Mahatma Gandhi,developed theme of social service as religious duty, and thedevelopment continues under Gandhi’s successors.

Mahātmā Gāndhī was looked on by many, both Indian and European, as epitome of Hindu tradition, but this is false judgement for he was much influenced by Western ideas. Gandhi believed in fundamentals of his ancient culture, but his passionate love of underdog and hisantipathy to caste, though not unprecedented in ancient India, wereunorthodox in extreme, and owed more to European 19th-centuryliberalism than to anything Indian. His faith in non-violence was, as wehave seen, by no means typical of Hinduism-his predecessor in revolt, theable Maratha brāhman B. G. Tilak, and Gāndhī’s impatient lieutenantSubhas Chandra Bose, were far more orthodox in this respect. For Gandhi’spacifism we must look to Sermon on Mount and to Tolstoy. Hischampioning of women’s rights is also result of Western influence. Inhis social context he was always rather an innovator than conservative.

Though some of his colleagues thought his programme of limited social reform too slow, he succeeded in shifting whole emphasis of Hindu thought towards popular and equalitarian social order, in place of thehierarchy of class and caste. Following up work of many less well-known 19th-century reformers Gandhi and his followers of IndianNational Congress hv given new orientation and new life to Hinduculture, after centuries of stagnation.

Today there r few Indians, whatever their creed, who do not look back with pride on their ancient culture, and there r few intelligent Indians whoare not willing to sacrifice some of its effete elements that India maydevelop and progress. Politically and [Page 484] economically India facesmany problems of great difficulty, and no one cn forecast her future withany certainty. But it is safe to predict that, whatever that future may be, Indians of coming generations will not be unconvincing and self-consciouscopies of Europeans, but will be men rooted in their own traditions, andaware of continuity of their culture. Already, after only seven years ofindependence, extremes of national self-denigration and fanaticalcultural chauvinism r disappearing. We believe that Hindu civilization isin act of performing its most spectacular feat of synthesis. In past ithas received, adapted and digested elements of many different cultures-Indo-European, Mesopotamian, Iranian, Greek, Roman, Scythian, Turkish,Persian and Arab. With each new influence it has somewhat changed. Nowit is well on way to assimilating culture of West.

Hindu civilization will, we believe, retain its continuity. Bhagavad Gītā will not cease to inspire men of action, and Upanisads men ofthought. charm and graciousness of Indian way of life willcontinue, however much affected it may be by laboursaving devices ofthe West. People will still love tales of heroes of Mahābhārataand Rāmāyana, and of loves of Dusyanta and Sakuntala and


Purūravas and Urvaśī. quiet and gentle happiness which has at all times pervaded Indian life where oppression, disease and poverty hv not overclouded it will surely not vanish before more hectic ways of West.

Much that was useless in ancient Indian culture has already perished. extravagant and barbarous hecatombs of Vedic age hv long since been forgotten, though animal sacrifice continues in some sects. Widows havelong ceased to be burnt on their husbands’ pyres. Girls may not by law bemarried in childhood. In buses and trains all over India brāhmans rubshoulders with lower castes without consciousness of grave pollution,and temples r open to all by law. Caste is vanishing; process beganlong ago, but its pace is now so rapid that more objectionable features ofcaste may hv disappeared within generation or so. old familysystem is adapting itself to present-day conditions. In fact whole face ofIndia is altering, but cultural tradition continues, and it will never belost.

## WORLD’S DEBT TO INDIA

We hv said much about India’s debt to other cultures, but we must make it clear that she has given as much as or more than she has taken. Let us summarize world’s debt to India.

[Page 485] whole of South-East Asia received most of its culture from India. Early in 5th century B.c. colonists from Western India settled in Ceylon, which was finally converted to Buddhism in reign ofAśoka. By this time few Indian merchants had probably found their wayto Malaya, Sumatra, and other parts of South-East Asia. Gradually theyestablished permanent settlements, often, no doubt, marrying nativewomen. They were followed by brāhmans and Buddhist monks, and Indianinfluence gradually leavened indigenous culture, until, by 4thcentury A.D., Sanskrit was official language of region, and therearose great civilizations, capable of organizing large maritime empires, andof building such wonderful memorials to their greatness as Buddhiststūpa of Borobodūr in Java, or Saivite temples of Angkor in Cambodia.

Other cultural influences, from China and Islamic world, were felt in South-East Asia, but primary impetus to civilization came from India.
Indian historians, proud of their country’s past, often refer to this regionas “Greater India”, and speak of Indian “colonies”. In its usual modernsense term “colony” is hardly accurate, however.Vijaya, legendaryĀryan conqueror of Ceylon, is said to hv gained island by sword,but beyond this we hv no real evidence of any permanent Indian conquestoutside bounds of India. Indian “colonies” were peaceful ones, andthe Indianized kings of region were indigenous chieftains who hadlearnt what India had to teach them.

Northwards Indian cultural influence spread through Central Asia to China. Faint and weak contact between China and India was probably made in Mauryan times, if not before, but only when, some 2,000 years ago, Han Empire began to drive its frontiers towards Caspian did India andChina really meet. Unlike South-East Asia, China did not assimilate Indianideas in every aspect of her culture, but whole of Far East is inIndia’s debt for Buddhism, which helped to mould distinctivecivilizations of China, Korea, Japan and Tibet.

As well as her special gifts to Asia, India has conferred many practical blessings on world at large; notably rice, cotton, sugar cane, manyspices, domestic fowl, game of chess (p. 208), and, most importantof all, decimal system of numeral notation, invention of an unknownIndian mathematician early in Christian era (p. 495f). extent of thespiritual influence of India on ancient West is much disputed. Theheterodox Jewish sect of Essenes, which probably influenced earlyChristianity, followed monastic practices in some respects similar to thoseof Buddhism. Parallels may be traced between passages in NewTestament [Page 486] and Pali scriptures. 1 Similarities between theteachings of western philosophers and mystics from Pythagoras to Plotinusand those of Upanisads hv frequently been noticed. None of thesesimilarities, however, is close enough to give certainty, especially as wehave no evidence that any classical writer had deep knowledge of Indianreligion. We cn only say that there was always some contact between theHellenic world and India, mediated first by Achaemenid Empire, thenby that of Seleucids, and finally, under Romans, by traders of theIndian ocean. Christianity began to spread at time when this contact wasclosest. We know that Indian ascetics occasionally visited West, and thatthere was colony of Indian merchants at Alexandria. possibility ofIndian influence on Neo-platonism and early Christianity cannot be ruledout.

Many authorities may doubt that Indian thought had any effect on that of ancient West, but there cn be no doubt of its direct and indirect influence on thought of Europe and America in last century and half, though this has not received adequate recognition. This influence hasnot come by way of organized neo-Hindu missions. last eighty yearshave seen foundation of Theosophical Society, of various Buddhistsocieties, and of societies in Europe and America looking for inspiration tothe saintly 19th-century Bengālī mystic, Paramahamsa Ramakrishna, andhis equally saintly disciple, Swāmī Vivekānanda. Lesser organizations andgroups hv been founded in West by other Indian mystics and theirdisciples, some of dm noble, earnest and spiritual, others of more dubiouscharacter. Here and there Westerners themselves, sometimes armed with aworking knowledge of Sanskrit and first-hand Indian experience, hv triedto convert West to streamlined Yoga or Vedanta. We would in no waydisparage these teachers or their followers, many of whom r of greatintellectual and spiritual calibre; but whatever we may think of Westernpropagators of Indian mysticism, we cannot claim that they hv had anygreat effect on our civilization. More subtle, but more powerful, has beenthe influence of Mahatma Gandhi, through many friends of India in theWest who were impressed by his burning sincerity and energy, and by theultimate success of his policy of non-violence in achieving India’sindependence. Greater than any of these influences, however, has been theinfluence of ancient Indian religious literature through philosophy.

The pioneers of Asiatic Society of Bengal quickly gained small butenthusiastic following in Europe, and Goethe and many other writers of theearly 19th century read all they could of ancient Indian literature intranslation. We know that Goethe borrowed device [Page 487] of Indiandramaturgy for prologue to “Faust” (p. 433n), and who cn say that thetriumphant final chorus of second part of that work was not in partinspired by monism of Indian thought as he understood it? From Goetheonwards most of great German philosophers knew something of Indianphilosophy. Schopenhauer, whose influence on literature and psychologyhas been so considerable, indeed openly admitted his debt, and his outlookwas virtually that of Buddhism. monisms of Fichte and Hegel mightnever hv taken forms they did if it had not been for Anquetil-Duperron’s translation of Upanisads and work of other pioneerIndologists. In English-speaking world strongest Indian influencewas felt in America, where Emerson, Thoreau and other New Englandwriters avidly studied much Indian religious literature in translation, andexerted immense influence on their contemporaries and successors, notablyWalt Whitman. Through Carlyle and others German philosophers intheir turn made their mark on England, as did Americans through manylate 19th-century writers such as Richard Jeffries and Edward Carpenter.

Though in contemporary philosophical schools of Europe and America monistic and idealist philosophies of last century carry little weight, their influence has been considerable, and all of dm owe something at least to ancient India. sages who meditated in jungles of Ganges Valley six hundred years or more before Christ r still forces in world.

It is today something of an anachronism to speak of European civilization or Indian civilization. Until very recently cultures were sharply divided, butnow, when India is but thirty hours’ journey from London, culturaldivisions r beginning to disappear. If modus vivendi is reached betweenliberal democracy and communism, and civilization survives, world ofthe future will hv single culture with, it is to be hoped, many local differences and variations. India’s contribution to world’s cultural stockhas already been very large, and it will continue and grow as, in her newfreedom, her prestige and influence increases. For this reason if for no otherwe must take account of her ancient heritage in its successes and itsfailures, for it is no longer heritage of India alone, but of all mankind.



# APPENDIX I
COSMOLOGY AND GEOGRAPHY
[Page 488]
THE universe of Vedas was simple affair-a flat circular earth below, a
heaven above, through which sun, moon and stars moved, and between
them middle air (antarzksa), abode of birds, clouds and demigods.

This picture of world was much complicated by later religious thought.

Indian ideas on origin and evolution of universe r rather a
matter of religion than of science and r considered elsewhere (p. 320ff).

All Indian religions, however, show certain concepts of cosmology incommon, which were fundamental presuppositions of Indian thought, andwere strikingly at variance with Semitic ideas which long influenced thethinking of West-the universe is very old; its evolution and decline arecyclic, repeated ad infinitum; it is immensely large; and there r otheruniverses beyond our own.

The Hindus believed that universe was shaped like an egg-theBrahmānda, or Egg of Brahma-divided into twenty-one zones or regions, ofwhich earth was seventh from top. Above earth were six heavens(not, as with Greeks, associated with planets), of increasingbeatitude. Below earth were seven stages of Pātāla, nether world,which were abode of nagas and other mythical beings and were notthought of as in any way unpleasant. Below Patala lay Naraka, or purgatory,also divided into seven zones, which were of increasing misery, andinhabited by souls in torment. universe hung in empty space, and wasvirtually isolated from other universes.The cosmic schemes of Buddhists and Jainas differed from this inmany details, but in fundamentals were same. All originally postulated aflat earth, but this was recognized by Indian astronomers to be incorrectearly in Christian era, and, though idea of flat earth remained forreligious purposes, learned realized, perhaps through influence ofGreek astronomy, that it was in fact spherical. Various estimates of its sizewere made, most popular being that of Brahmagupta (7th century A.D.),who gave its circumference as 5,000 yojanas. Assuming Brahmagupta’syojana to be short league of about 4½ miles, this figure is not far out,and is as accurate as any given by ancient astronomers.

The modest spherical earth of astronomers did not satisfy the
theologians, however, and even later religious literature described earthas flat disc of enormous size. In its centre was Mount Meru, round whichsun, moon and stars revolved. Around Meru were four continents (dvlpa),separated from central peak by oceans, and named acc to thegreat trees which stood on their shores opposite Meru. southerncontinent, on which human beings dwell, had ajambu (rose-apple) as itsdistinctive tree, and it was therefore called Jambudvīpa. southern zoneof this continent, [Page 489] separated from rest by Himalayas, was“the Land of Sons of Bharata” (Bhratavarsa), or India. Bharatavarsaalone was 9,000 yojanas across, and whole of Jambudvipa 33,000, or,according to some sources, 100,000 yojanas.

This fantastic geographical scheme was not only one. In Puranas
Jambudvipa is described as ring around Meru, separated from nextcontinent, Plaksadvīpa, by an ocean of salt. Plaksadvīpa in turn forms aconcentric circle round Jambudvīpa, and so on to make total of sevencontinents, each circular and divided from its neighbour by an ocean ofdifferent composition-starting with Jambudvipa’s salt ocean and movingoutwards, of treacle, wine, ghee, milk, curds and fresh water respectively.
This brilliantly imaginative picture of world, which aroused scorn ofLord Macaulay, seems to hv been implicitly believed in by later Hindutheologians, and even astronomers could not emancipate themselvesfrom it, but adapted it to their spherical earth by making Meru earth’saxis, and continents zones on earth’s surface.

The oceans of butter and seas of treacle formed an effective barrier to growth of true science of geography. seven continents cannot in any way hv been related to actual portions of earth’s surface, though some modem students hv tried to identify dm with parts of Asia, and, as far asis known, no attempt was made to collate experience of travellers aspractical geography. astronomers gave fairly accurate longitudes ofimportant places in India. In early centuries of Christian eraAlexandria was known, and there r vague references to city of theRomakas in astronomical works; but geographical knowledge of thelearned was of vaguest description. Even within India distances anddirections, as given in texts, r usually very inaccurate and vague. Theconquerors who led armies thousands of miles on their campaigns, themerchants who carried their wares from one end of India to other, andthe pilgrims who visited sacred places from Himalayas to CapeComorin must hv had sound practical knowledge of Indian geography,while that of seamen who sailed ocean from Socotra to Canton musthave been even wider; but there r few echoes of this knowledge in theliterature of time.



# APPENDIX II
## ASTRONOMY
One of subsidiary studies (vedānga) of Vedic lore was jyotisa, aprimitive astronomy designed mainly for purpose of settling datesand times at which periodical sacrifices were to be performed. existingliterature on this topic is comparatively late, and gives no true indication ofIndia’s astronomical knowledge in Vedic period, though it is quite clear[Page 490] from passages in Vedic texts themselves that it was adequatefor practical purposes of time. It is probable that even at this earlyperiod there was some Mesopotamian influence on Indian astronomicalideas, but this cannot be established with certainty. Virtually certain,however, is influence of classical European astronomy, whichwasfeltin early centuries of Christian era, if not before.Several Greek words hv become common in Sanskrit and in laterIndian vernaculars through astronomy (p. 230), and other technical terms,not so widely known, r indisputably of Greek origin. Of fiveastronomical systems (siddhanta) known to 6th-century astronomerVarahamihira one is called Romaka Siddhdnta and another PaulidaSiddhanta, title which cn only be reasonably explained as recollectionof name of classical astronomer Paul of Alexandria.
The new astronomy was adopted chiefly for purposes of prognostication;for establishment of dates old luni-solar calendar, based on simplerobservations, was quite adequate. In earlier times Indians, though no lessinterested than other ancient peoples in foretelling future, preferred todo so by interpretation of dreams and omens (utpāta), and byphysiognomy, birthmarks, shape and size of features, and other signswhich were believed to give tokens of an individual’s fate. oldersystems of prognostication were not forgotten, but from Gupta timesonwards they gave pride of place to astrology, which from that day to thishas been implicitly believed in by nearly all Indians.Until this great development of astronomical knowledge heavens hadbeen charted by means of lunar mansions or naksatras, which wereapparently known even in time of Rg Veda. moon’s relation tothe fixed stars changes through cycle of approximately 27 solar days and71 hours, and thus heavens were divided into 27 portions, namedaccording to group of stars on ecliptic (the apparent orbit of sun)near which moon passes on each day of its cycle. As sidereal monthis in fact nearly eight hours more than 27 days twenty-eighth intercalarynaksatra was added by later astronomers to correct error. 1Western astronomy brought to India signs of zodiac, sevendayweek, hour, and several other ideas. Thanks to their achievements [Page491] in mathematics Indian astronomers made some advances on theknowledge of Greeks, and passed their lore, with that of mathematics,back to Europe by way of Arabs. As early as 7th century Syrianastronomer Severus Sebokht knew of greatness of Indian astronomy andmathematics (p. vi), and caliphs of Baghdad employed Indianastronomers. One word of terminology of medieval Europeanastronomy, aux, highest point of planet’s orbit, is certainly borrowedfrom Sanskrit ucca through Arabic.

Like all ancient astronomy, that of India was restricted owing toignorance of telescope; but methods of observation were perfectedwhich allowed very accurate measurement, and calculations were aided bythe decimal system of numerals. We know of no remains of observatories ofthe Hindu period, but those of 17th and 18th centuries, at Jaipur, Delhiand elsewhere, with their wonderfully accurate instruments, constructed onan enormous scale to minimize error, may well hv had their ancientcounterparts.

With naked eye as their sole means of observation Indians knew
only seven planets (graha) of ancients-Sun (SiSrya, Ravi), Moon(Candra, Soma), Mercury (Budha), Venus (Sukra), Mars (Mangala), Jupiter(Brhaspati) and Saturn (Śani);2 to these grahas two more were added, Rdhuand Ketu, ascending and descending nodes of moon. 3 At thebeginning of each æon all planets were believed to commence theirrevolutions in line, and to return to same position at end of it. Theapparently irregular course of planets was explained on hypothesisof epicycles, as in classical and medieval astronomy. Unlike Greeks, theIndians believed that planets had equal real motion, and that theirapparently different angular motion was due to their different distancesfrom earth.
For purposes of calculation planetary system was taken as geocentric,though Aryabhata in 5th century suggested that earth revolved roundthe sun and rotated on its axis; this theory was also known to laterastronomers, but it never affected astronomical practice. precession ofthe equinoxes was known, and calculated with some accuracy by medievalastronomers, as were lengths of year, lunar month, and otherastronomical constants. These calculations were reliable for most practicalpurposes, and in many cases more accurate than those of Greco-Romanworld. Eclipses were forecast with accuracy and their true causeunderstood.



# APPENDIX III
## CALENDAR
[Page 492] In recording dates basic unit was not solar day, but the
tithi, or lunar day, approximately thirty of which formed lunar month (i.e.

the four phases of moon) of about 291 solar days. month was
divided into two halves ( paksa) of fifteen tithis each, beginning with full
( pirnimdvdsyd) and new (amāvāsyā or bahuliāvsyā) moons respectively.

The fortnight beginning with new moon was called bright half(iuklapaksa) and other dark half (krsnapaksa). acc to thesystem followed in Northern India and much of Deccan monthbegan and ended with full moon, while in Tamil country monthgenerally began with new moon. Hindu calendar is still in usethroughout India for religious purposes.
The tithi might begin at any time of solar day. For practicalpurpose of recording dates that tithi current at sunrise was supposed toprevail for whole day and gave that day its number in paksa. If atithi began just after sunrise and ended before sunrise of next day, itwas expunged, and there was break in numerical sequence of days.

The year normally contained twelve lunar months: Caitra (March-April),Vaiśkha (April-May), Jyaistha (May-June),. Āsādha (June-July), Śrva (July-August), Bhādrapada or Prausthapada (August-September), Āsvina orĀsvayuja (September-October), Kārttika (October-November), Mārgasā orĀgrahāyana (November-December), Pausa or Taisa (December-January),Māgha (January-February) and Phālguna (February-March).4 acc tothe usual systems of reckoning year began with Caitra, but it wassometimes taken as beginning with Karttika or another month.

A group of two months formed season (rtu). six seasons of the
Indian year were: Vasanta (Spring, March-May), Grīsma (Summer, May–
July),
Varsā
(The
Rains,
July-September),
Sarad
(Autumn,
SeptemberNovember), Hemanta (Winter, November-January) and Sisira
(the Cool Season, January-March).

Twelve lunar months make only about 354 days, and problem of discrepancy between lunar and solar years was solved very early; sixty- two lunar months r approximately equal to sixty solar months, and so every thirty months an extra month was added to year, as in Babylonia.

This leap-month was generally inserted after Āsādha or Śrāvana and called second (dvitiya) Āsādha or Śravana. Thus every second or third year contains thirteen months, and is some twenty-nine days longer than others.

[Page 493] Hindu calendar, though quite efficient, is thus rather cumbrous, and is so different from solar calendar that it is impossible to reduce dates from one to other without very complicated calculations or lengthy tables. It is even impossible to establish at glance month in which given Hindu date falls with any certainty.

Indian dates r usually given in order-month, paksa, tithi, abbreviations sudi and badi being used for bright and dark halves of month; e.g. Caitra sudi 7 means seventh day from new moon of month Caitra.

The solar calendar, imported with Western astronomy, was also known from Gupta times onwards though it did not oust old luni-solar calendar until recent years. Where solar dates r given in early records they r usually mentioned for extra accuracy, with prevailing naksatra of day in question, after regular luni-solar date. In solar calendar themonths r named after signs of zodiac, which r literal or nearlyexact translations of their Greek originals: Mesa (Aries), Vrsabha (Taurus),Mithuna (Gemini), Karkata (Cancer), Sizmha (Leo), Kanyd (Virgo), Tula(Libra), Vrścika (Scorpio), Dhanus (Sagittarius), Makara (Capricornus),Kumbha (Aquarius) and Mzna (Pisces). With solar calendar seven-day week was also introduced, days being named after their presidingplanets as in Greco-Roman system: Ravivara (Sunday), Somavāra(Monday), Mangalavāra (Tuesday), Budhavāra (Wednesday), Brhaspativāra(Thursday), ukravāra (Friday) and Śanivāra (Saturday).

## ERAS
Until 1st century B.C. there is no good evidence that India had anyregular system of recording year of an event by dating in definite eralike A.U.C. of Rome or Christian era of medieval and modernEurope. Early inscriptions r dated if at all in regnal year of rulingking. idea of dating over long period of time from fixed year wasalmost certainly introduced into India by invaders of North-West,who hv left earliest inscriptions thus dated in India. Unfortunately theIndians did not adopt uniform era, and number of systems of datingwere in use from that time onwards, chief of which, in order ofimportance, r as follows:

The Vikrama Era (58 B.C.), traditionally founded by king calledVikramaditya, who drove Sakas out of Ujjayini and founded era tocelebrate his victory. only king who both took title Vikramadityaand drove Sakas from Ujjayini was Candra Gupta II, who lived over400 years later than beginning of Vikrama era, and so legend iscertainly false. In earliest inscriptions using this era, all from WesternIndia, it is called simply Krta (” established”), or “handed down by theMalava tribe “. Some authorities believe that many inscriptions of Sakas[Page 494] and Pahlavas of North-West India r to be read in this era, andthat it was founded by Azes, one of their early kings; but this is by nomeans certain. This era was most popular in North India. Its year beganoriginally with month KIrttika, but by medieval times Vikrama yearsbegan in bright half of Caitra in North, and in dark half of thesame month in Peninsula.

The Saka Era (A.D. 78) was, acc to tradition, founded by Saka king who occupied Ujjayini 137 years after Vikramaditya. This era may in fact hv been founded by Kaniska, and was certainly used early in 2nd century A.D. by “Western Satraps”, who ruled Malwa, Kathiawar and Gujarat. Thence use of era spread through Deccan and was exported to South-East Asia.

The Gupta Era (A.D. 320) was probably founded by Candra Gupta I, and its use was continued by Maitraka dynasty of Gujarat for some centuries after Gupta empire fell.

TheHarsa Era (A.D. 606), founded by Harsavardhana of Kanyakubja, was popular in Northern India for century or two after his death.

The Kalacuri Era (A.D. 248), perhaps founded by small dynasty called
the Traikutaka, was current in Central India down to Muslim invasion.
Other eras of local or temporary importance were Laksmana Era ofBengal (A.D. 1119), wrongly said to hv been founded by King LaksmanaSena; Saptarsi or Laukika Era, current in Kashmār in Middle Ages,and recorded in cycles of one hundred years, each cycle commencingseventysix years after each Christian century; Licchavi and Nevar Erasof Nepal (A.D. 110 and 878); Kollam Era of Malabar (A.D. 825); and theEra of Vikramaditya VI Cdlukya (A.D. 1075). Era of Kaliyuga (3102B.C., v. p. 39 above) was often used for religious dates and rarely forpolitical. In Ceylon Buddha Era from 544 B.C. was in use from anuncertain date, when it probably replaced an earlier reckoning from 483 B.C.

The Jainas used an Era of Mahdvmra, reckoned from 628 B.C. two latter eras, together with Vikrama and Saka Eras, r still in use for religious purposes, but others r extinct.

In reducing dates in Indian eras to Christian era it must beremembered that year, acc to most reckonings, begins with themonth of Caitra, which usually commences in middle of March. Thusthe months Magha and Phalguna, and generally second half of Pausa,occur in Christian year after that in which Hindu year began. Dateswere usually given in expired years; this was sometimes explicitly stated(e.g. “when 493 years had passed from establishment of tribe of theMalavas”), but more often taken for granted. In medieval dates it is best toassume an expired year, even when this is not specified, unless there isspecial reason to believe otherwise.

# APPENDIX IV
## MATHEMATICS
Through necessity of accurately laying out open-air site of a
sacrifice Indians very early evolved simple system of geometry, but in the
sphere of practical knowledge world owes most to India in realm ofmathematics, which were developed in Gupta times to stage moreadvanced than that reached by any other nation of antiquity. success ofIndian mathematics was mainly due to fact that Indians had clearconception of abstract number, as distinct from numerical quantity ofobjects or spatial extension. While Greek mathematical science was largelybased on mensuration and geometry, India transcended these conceptionsquite early, and, with aid of simple numeral notation, devised arudimentary algebra which allowed more complicated calculations thanwere possible to Greeks, and led to study of number for its ownsake.

In earlier inscriptions of India dates and other numerals r written in notation not unlike that of Romans, Greeks and Hebrews, with separate symbols for tens and hundreds. earliest inscription recording date by system of nine digits and zero, with place notation for tens and hundreds, comes from Gujarat, and is dated A.D. 595.5 Soonafter this however, new system had been heard of in Syria (p. vi), 6 andwas being used as far afield as Indo-China. Evidently system was in useamong mathematicians some centuries before it was employed ininscriptions, scribes of which tended to be conservative in their systemof [Page 496] recording dates; in modem Europe cumbrous Romansystem is still sometimes used for same purpose. name of themathematician who devised simplified system of writing numerals isunknown, but earliest surviving mathematical texts-the anonymous“Bakshali Manuscript”, which is copy of text of 4th century A.D., andthe terse Jryabhatzya of Aryabhata, written in A.D. 499-presuppose it.

For long it was thought that decimal system of numerals was inventedby Arabs, but this is certainly not case. Arabs themselves calledmathematics “the Indian (art)” (hindisat), and there is now no doubt that thedecimal notation, with other mathematical lore, was learnt by Muslimworld either through merchants trading with west coast of India, orthrough Arabs who conquered Sind in A.D. 712.

The debt of Western world to India in this respect cannot beoverestimated. Most of great discoveries and inventions of whichEurope is so proud would hv been impossible without developed systemof mathematics, and this in turn would hv been impossible if Europe hadbeen shackled by unwieldy system of Roman numerals. unknownman who devised new system was from world’s point of view, afterthe Buddha, most important son of India. His achievement, thougheasily taken for granted, was work of an analytical mind of firstorder, and he deserves much more honour than he has so far received.

Medieval Indian mathematicians, such as Brahmagupta (7th century), Mahavira (9th century) and Bhaskara (l2th century), made several discoveries which in Europe were not known until Renaissance or later.

They understood import of positive and negative quantities, evolvedsound systems of extracting square and cube roots, and could solvequadratic and certain types of indeterminate equations. For iT Aryabhatagave usual modern approximate value of 3 1416, expressed in formof fractionThis value of rr, much more accurate than that of theGreeks, was improved to nine places of decimals by later Indianmathematicians. Some steps were made in trigonometry, spherical geometryand calculus, chiefly in connexion with astronomy. mathematicalimplications of zero (sUnya) and infinity, never more than vaguely realizedby classical authorities, were fully understood in medieval India. Earliermathematicians had taught that, but Bhaskara proved that it wasinfinity. He also established mathematically what had been recognized inIndian theology at least millenium earlier, that infinity, however divided,remains infinite, represented by equation


# APPENDIX V
## PHYSICS AND CHEMISTRY
Ancient Indian ideas of physics were closely linked with religion and theology, and differed somewhat from sect to sect. As early as time of Buddha, if not before, universe was classified by elements, of which[Page 497] all schools admitted at least four-earth, air, fire and water. Tothese orthodox Hindu schools and Jainism added fifth, dkda, which isgenerally translated “ether”. It was recognized that air was not of infiniteextension, and Indian mind, with its abhorrence of vacuum, found ithard to conceive of empty space. five elements were thought of as themediums of sense impressions-earth of smell, air of feeling, fire of vision,water of taste, and ether of sound. Buddhists and Ajivikas rejected ether, butthe latter added life, joy and sorrow, which were thought of as in some waymaterial, making total of seven elements.

Most schools believed that elements other than ether were atomic.

Indian atomism was certainly independent of Greek influence, for an atomictheory was taught by Pakudha Katyayana, an older contemporary of theBuddha, and was therefore earlier than that of Democritus. Jainasbelieved that all atoms (anu) were identical, and that differences of thecharacter of elements were due to manner in which atoms werecombined. Most schools, however, maintained that there were as manytypes of atom as there were elements.

The atom was generally thought to be eternal, but some Buddhists conceived of it not only as minutest object capable of occupying space, but also as occupying minutest possible duration of time, coming into being and vanishing almost in an instant, only to be succeeded by anotheratom, caused by first. Thus atom of Buddhism in some measureresembles quantum of Planck. atom was quite invisible to thehuman eye; orthodox Vaisesika school believed single atom to be amere point in space, completely without magnitude.

A single atom had no qualities, but only potentialities, which came into play when atom combined with others. Vaisesika school, which specially elaborated atomic doctrines, and was school of atomism par excellence, maintained that, before combining to form material objects, atoms made primary combinations of diads and triads. This doctrine of molecules was developed differently by Buddhists and Ajivikas, who taughtthat in normal conditions no atoms existed in pure state, but onlycombined in different proportions in molecule (samgh.dta, kalapa). Everymolecule contained at least one atom of all four types, and obtained itscharacter from predominance of given element. This hypothesisaccounted for fact that matter might show characteristics of more thanone element: thus wax might melt and also burn, because its moleculescontained proportions of water and fire. acc to Buddhists themolecules cohered by virtue of atoms of water in each, which acted asadhesive.

Indian atomic theories were not based so much on experiment, as on intuition and logic. They were not universally held. great theologian Safikara (p. 328) did not believe in atoms and argued strongly against their existence. But atomic theories of ancient India r brilliant imaginative explanations of physical structure of world; though it is probably mere coincidence that they agree in part with theories of modem physics, they r nevertheless much to credit of intellect and imagination of early Indian thinkers.

[Page 498] Beyond this ancient Indian physics developed little. Without knowledge of an all-embracing law of gravity it remained in rudimentary state, like all physical systems of ancient world. It was generally believed that elements of earth and water tended to fall, and fire to rise, and it was recognized that solids and fluids alike generally expanded onheating, but no serious effort was made to study such phenomenaexperimentally. In science of acoustics, however, India made realdiscoveries based on experiment, and ear, highly trained by phoneticstudy necessary for correct recitation of Vedas, learned todistinguish musical tones far closer than those of other early musicalsystems. Before Christian era octave was divided into twenty-twosrutis, or quarter-tones (p. 382), and their proportions were measured withgreat accuracy. It was recognized that differences of timbre were caused byovertones (anuranana), which varied with different instruments.

We know from evidence of Iron Pillar of Delhi (p. 219 f) and other sources that Indian metallurgists Śained great proficiency in extraction of metal from ore and in metal-casting, and their products were known and valued in Roman Empire and Middle East; but their knowledge appears to hv been largely pragmatic, and had no counterpartin highly developed science of metallurgy. Chemistry in ancient India wasthe handmaid, not of technology, but of medicine; her chemists did notshare interest of medieval Europe in transmuting base metal into gold,but apparently devoted most of their attention to making medicines, drugsto promote longevity, aphrodisiacs, poisons, and their antidotes. Thesemedical chemists did succeed in producing many important alkalis, acidsand metallic salts by simple processes of calcination and distillation, and ithas even been suggested, without good basis, that they discovered form ofgunpowder.

In Middle Ages Indian chemists, like their counterparts in China, Muslim World and Europe, became engrossed in study of mercury, perhaps through contact with Arabs. school of alchemists arose, who experimented with wonderful fluid metal, and decided that it was thespecific for all diseases, source of perpetual youth, and even surestmeans to salvation. In this infatuation with mercury Indian chemistryfoundered, but not before it had passed many ideas on to Arabs, whogave dm to medieval Europe.


# APPENDIX VI
## PHYSIOLOGY AND MEDICINE
The Vedas show very primitive stage of medical and physiological lore,but basic textbooks of Indian medicine-the compendia of Caraka (lst-2nd centuries A.D.) and Sufruta (c. 4th century A.D.)-are products [Page499] of fully evolved system which resembles those of Hippocrates andGalen in some respects, and in others has developed beyond them. We haveno medical texts of intervening period, but there is little doubt that twofactors encouraged medical knowledge-the growth of interest in physiologythrough phenomena of yoga and mystical experience, and Buddhism.

Like Christian missionary of later times Buddhist monk often served as doctor among layfolk from whom he begged his food; moreover he was encouraged to care for his own health and that of his fellow-monks,and his creed tended towards rationalism and distrust of medicalmagic of earlier times. development of medicine was also probablystimulated by contact with Hellenic physicians, and resemblancesbetween Indian and classical medicine suggest borrowing on both sides.

After Susruta Indian medicine developed little, except in growing use of mercurial drugs, and of others such as opium and sarsaparilla, which were introduced by Arabs. In its essentials system practised by ayurvedic physician of present day India remains same.

The basic conception of Indian medicine, like that of ancient and medieval Europe, was humours (dosa). Most authorities taught that health was maintained through even balance of three vital fluids of body-wind, gall and mucus, to which some added blood as fourth humour. three primary humours were connected with scheme of three gunas, or universal qualities (p. 324 f), and associated with virtue, passion and dullness respectively.

The bodily functions were maintained by five “winds” (vdyu): udana, emanating from throat, and causing speech; prana, in heart, and responsible for breathing and swallowing of food; samana, fanning fire in stomach which “cooked” or digested food, and dividing it into its digestible and indigestible parts; apana in abdomen, andresponsible for excretion and procreation; and vyana, generally diffusedwind, causing motion of blood and of body generally. fooddigested by samana became chyle, which proceeded to heart, andthence to liver, where its essence was converted into blood. blood inturn was in part converted into flesh and process was continued throughthe series fat, bone, marrow and semen; latter, when not expelled,produced energy (ojas), which returned to heart and was thence diffusedover body. This process of metabolism was believed to take place inthirty days.

Ancient Indian doctors had no clear knowledge of function of brain, and believed with most ancient peoples that heart was seat of intelligence. They realized, however, importance of spinal cord (p.

326 f), and knew of existence of nervous system, though it was not properly understood. progress of physiology and biology was impeded by taboo on contact with dead bodies, which much discouraged dissection and study of anatomy, although such practices were not completely unknown.

Despite their inaccurate knowledge of physiology, which was by no means inferior to that of most ancient peoples, India evolved developed empirical surgery. caesarian section was known, bone-setting reached high [Page 500] degree of skill, and plastic surgery was developed far beyond anything known elsewhere at time. Ancient Indian surgeonswere expert at repair of noses, ears and lips, lost or injured in battle orby judicial mutilation. In this respect Indian surgery remained ahead ofEuropean until 18th century, when surgeons of East IndianCompany were not ashamed to learn art of rhinoplasty from Indians.

Though Indians very early conceived of existence of microscopic
forms of life, it was never realized that these might cause diseases; but if
Indian surgeons had no true idea of antisepsis or asepsis they encouraged
scrupulous cleanliness as they understood it, and recognized therapeutic value of fresh air and light. pharmacopoeia of ancient India was verylarge, and comprised animal, vegetable and mineral products. Many Asiaticdrugs were known and used long before their introduction into Europe,notably oil of chaulmugra tree, traditionally prescribed as specificfor leprosy, and still basis of modern treatment of disease.

The physician was highly respected member of society, and vaidyas
rank high in caste hierarchy to this day. rules of professionalbehaviour laid down in medical texts remind us of those of Hippocrates andare not unworthy of conscientious doctor of any place or time. We quotepart of sermon which Caraka instructs physician to preach to hispupils at solemn religious ceremony to be performed on completion oftheir apprenticeship.

“If you want success in your practice, wealth and fame, and heaven after
your death, you must pray every day on rising and going to bed for thewelfare of all beings, especially of cows and brahmans, and you must strivewith all your soul for health of sick. You must not betray yourpatients, even at cost of your own life. …. You must not get drunk, orcommit evil, or hv evil companions. … You must be pleasant of speech… and thoughtful, always striving to improve your knowledge.

“When you go to home of patient you should direct your words,
mind, intellect and senses nowhere but to your patient and his treatment. ….

Nothing that happens in house of sick man must be told outside, nor
must patient’s condition be told to anyone who might do harm by that
knowledge to patient or to another.” 7
Under patronage of more benevolent kings and religious foundationsfree medical aid was given to poor. AMoka took pride in fact that hehad provided medicines for man and beast, and traveller Fa-hsien, in theearly 5th century A.D., made special note of free hospitals maintained bythe donations of pious citizens. Unfortunately we hv no detaileddescriptions of such establishments.

Veterinary medicine was also practised. doctrine of non-violenceencouraged endowment of animal refuges and homes for sick and agedanimals, and such charities r still maintained in many cities of India. Thehorse and elephant doctors were members of skilled and respectedprofessions, much in demand at court, and texts on veterinary sciencesurvive from Middle Ages.


# APPENDIX VII
## LOGIC AND EPISTEMOLOGY
[Page 501] With such an intense interest in metaphysical problems and atradition of lively debate and discussion it is not surprising that Indiadeveloped her own distinctive system of logic. basic logical text is theNyaya Sātras of Gautama, perhaps composed in early centuries of theChristian era, series of brief aphorisms much commented on by laterwriters, and foundation-text of Nyaya, one of six schools oforthodox philosophy (p. 323). Logic was not, however, confined to this oneschool, but was utilized and adapted by Hindu, Buddhist and Jaina alike.

One of most important topics of Indian thought in this field was the
question of pramdna, which may be translated “means of reliable knowledge’8. acc to later Nyaya schools there were four pramanas, perception (pratyaksa), inference (anumdna), inference byanalogy or comparison (upamdna), and “word” (6abda), pronouncementof reliable authority, such as Vedas. Vedanta school addedintuition or presumption (arthdpatti) and non-perception (anupalabdhi), thelatter an unnecessary scholastic refinement. six categories overlappedsomewhat, and Buddhists generally included all forms of knowledgeunder first two categories, while Jainas usually allowed only three,perception, inference and revelation. materialists allowed onlyperception, and their opponents made short work of their efforts at provingby inference that inference could not give reliable knowledge.

It was probably in study of process of inference that schools oftrue logic arose. From necessities of metaphysical discussion falsearguments were analysed and classified; of these logicians recognized thechief fallacies of classical logic, such as reductio ad absurdum(arthaprasanga), circular argument (cakra), infinite regression (anavasthd),dilemma (anyonyairaya), and ignoratio elenchi (atmdsraya).

A correct inference was established by syllogism, of which Indianform (paicdvayava) was somewhat more cumbrous than Aristotelian. Itsfive members were known as proposition (pratijia), reason (hetu), example(uddharana), application (upanaya) and conclusion (nigamana). Theclassical Indian example may be paraphrased as follows:
(1) There is fire on mountain,
(2) because there is smoke above it,
(3) and where there is smoke there is fire, as, for instance, in kitchen;
(4) such is case with mountain,
(5) and therefore there is fire on it.

The third term of Indian syllogism corresponds to major premiss
of that of Aristotle, second to Aristotle’s minor premiss, and first to his conclusion. Thus Indian syllogism reversed order of that ofclassical logic, argument being stated in first and second [Page 502]clauses, established by general rule and example in third, and finallyclinched by virtual repetition of first two clauses. “example” (inthe above syllogism kitchen) was generally looked on as an essentialpart of argument, and helped to strengthen its rhetorical force. Evidentlythis elaborate system of syllogism is outcome of much practicalexperience in discussion. Three-membered syllogisms were admitted by theBuddhists, who rightly rejected fourth and fifth members of theorthodox syllogism as tautological.
The basis of generalization (for example “where there is smoke thereis fire”) on which every inference rests was believed to be the’quality ofuniversal concomitance (vydpti). nature and origin of this quality wasmuch discussed, and its consideration led to theories of universals andparticulars, which r too recondite for consideration in this book.

No treatment of Indian thought is complete without brief reference to
the remarkable epistemological relativity of Jainism. Jaina thinkers, andsome other heterodox teachers also, explicitly rejected what in classicallogic is called law of excluded middle. For Jaina there were notmerely two possiblities of existence and non-existence, but seven. Thuswe may affirm (1) that an object, say knife, exists as knife. We mayfurther say (2) that it is not something else, say fork. But it exists as aknife and does not exist as fork, and so we may declare of it (s) that in oneaspect it is and in another it is not. From another point of view (4) it isindescribable; its ultimate essence is unknown to us and we cannot positanything final about it-it is inexpressible. By combining this fourthpossiblitywith three former ones we obtain three further possibilities ofpredication-(5) it is, but its nature is otherwise indescribable, (6) it is not,but its nature isindescribable,and(7)itbothisand is not, but its nature isindescribable. This system of seven aspects of predication is known assyadvada (“the doctrine of ‘maybe’”), or saptabhangi (“the sevenfolddivision”). 9As well as syadvada Jainas had another sevenfold system ofpredication known as nayavdda, theory of standpoints, or ways ofapproaching an object of observation or study. first three of these areconnected with object itself (dravydrthika), and latter four with itsmodifications and words used to describe it (parydydrthika). (1) Amango tree may be considered simultaneously as an individual having adefinite size and shape and as member of species “mango tree”; (2) itmay be treated merely as representative of “universal” mango tree,and as corresponding to general concept of mango tree, without takingits individual qualities into account; or (s) it may be considered merely asan individual, without taking note of its specific qualities. Further it may bethought of (4) as it is at present moment, for instance as bearing ripefruit, without any regard to its past as sapling or its future as firewood. (5)We may think of it from point of view of its name “mango”, consideringall [Page 503] synonyms of that name, and their implications. Thesesynonyms may be subtly differentiated, and (6) we may consider theirnuances and connotations. Finally (7) we may consider an object in itsrelation to given epithet; thus by referring to hero as “lion” wementally abstract all his unlionlike qualities, and think of him only as abeing of strength and courage.10 Some Jaina schools rejected last threestandpoints, which r hardly consistent with first four, being rathersemantic in character than epistemological.

Modern logicians might make short work of these rather pedanticsystems of ontological and epistemological relativity, but they hv afundamental quality of breadth and realism, implying full realization thatthe world is more complex and subtle than we think it, and that what is trueof thing in one of its aspects may at same time be false in another.

# APPENDIX VIII
## WEIGHTS AND MEASURES

MEASURES OF WEIGHT
The basic weight of ancient India was raktikd, bright red seed of gunja (abrus precatorius), which was conventionally reckoned at about 1.83 grains (.118 grams). Many sources give series of weights rising from this, which r not wholly consistent, and show that standards varied very widely with time and place.

The goldsmith’s scale given by Manu, which was probably most widely followed, was:
5 raktikds = 1 mdsa,
16 mdsas = 1 karsa, tolaka, or suvarna,
4 karsas = 1 pala,
10 palas = 1 dharana.

The weight of pala was thus approximately 1j oz., or 37–76 gms. Of heavier weights chief were prastha, usually given as of 16 palas, and drona of 16 prasthas. prastha was thus approximately 21 oz., and drona 21¼ lb.

MEASURES OF LENGTH
The commonest table, omitting microscopic measurements, was:
8 yava (barleycorns) = 1 angula (finger’s breadth, I in.)

12 ahgulas =
1 vztasti (span, 9 ins.)

2 vitastis =
1 hasta or aratni (cubit, 18 ins.)

4 hastas =
1 daynda (rod) or dhanus (bow, 6 ft.)

2,000 dhanus =
1 krosa (cry) or goruta (cow-call, 2j miles)
4 kroias =
1 yojana (stage, 9 miles approx.).

[Page 504] Though most sources give krosa (in modern Indian languages kos) as of 2,000 dandas Arthas’stra gives it as of only 1,000, yojana, which was commonest measure of long distances in ancient India, being thus of only 41 miles. It is therefore clear that there were at least two yojanas, and distances as given in texts r thus very unreliable. It would seem that for practical purposes shorter yojana was more often used than longer, especially in earlier times.



MEASURES OF TIME
Ancient Indian learned men devised detailed terminology for minute intervals of time, which had little relation to everyday life and must be looked on as flight of fancy. longer measurements in most general use were:
18 nimesas (winks) = 1 kdsthd ( secs.),
30 kdsthas =
1 kala ( mins.)

15 kalds =
1 nd.dikd or ndlikd (24 mins.)

30 kales or 2 nddikds = 1 muhirta or ksaza (48 mins.)

30 muhurtas =
1 aho-rdtra (day and night, 24 hours).

A measurement frequently used, but not consistent with this system, was ydma or watch, one-eighth of day and night, or three hours. In some sources, however, ydma is given as three muhurtas, or one-tenth of day and night. hour (hord) was introduced from West in Gupta period and was used in astronomy, but was not widely employed in everyday life.

For longer measures of time see p. 492 ff.

# APPENDIX IX
## COINAGE11

EARLY PUNCH MARKED COINS
Uninscribed punchmarked coins were minted from 6th century B.C.

onwards, and were in circulation for many centuries. Among earliest silver specimens r those in shape of small bent bar, largest of which, satamdna, weighed 180 grains. Half, quarter and half-quarter satamdnas r attested.

The basic silver punchmarked coin of usual type was kdr.sdpana or pana, of 6578 grains. mdsa or mdsika weighed one-sixteenth of this, or 3.6 grains. Various intermediate weights r attested, as well as large silver coins of so and 20 mdsas and small half-mdsa pieces.

Punchmarked copper coins were generally based on different standard —a māsa of 9 grains and kdrsdpana of 144. Quarter-mdsas in copper, or [Page 505] kdkinis (2.25 grains) r attested, as well as large coins of 20, so and 45 copper masas.

Only one gold punchmarked coin is known, and it must be assumed that gold was very rarely minted before beginning of Christian era.

## INDO-GREEK COINS
The earlier Greek kings minted coins acc to Attic standard, based on drachm of 67.2 grains and obol (6 drachm) of 11 2 grains.

Silver coinage of this type ranges from hemiobols to very large double decadrachms, struck by king Amyntas, which hv recently been found in Afghanistan. After their southward expansion Greeks adopted reduced weight, with silver coins of 152 and 38 grains.

The Greek kings issued numerous copper coins, but their metrology is not clear. Gold coins must hv been very rare. There exist very large 20 stater piece of Bactrian usurper Eucratides and rare staters of few other kings.  Śaka and Pahlava coins in silver and copper follow reduced IndoGreek standard.

## KUSANA COINS
These were minted in gold and copper. gold dinras or suvarnas were based on Roman denarius and were of 124 grains. Double and quarter dinras were also issued. copper coins were large, of from 26 to 28 mdsas, or 240 to 260 grains.

## PRE-GUPTAN AND GUPTAN COINS
A large range of coins in silver and copper, of very varied weight andcharacter, was issued by indigenous kings, tribes and cities of NorthernIndia in centuries immediately preceding and following beginning ofthe Christian era. Satavahanas of Deccan also issued coins of leadand potin (base silver), while Sakas of Gujarat, Malwa and WesternDeccan issued distinctive series of coins in silver.

The gold coins of Guptas (dfndra) originally approximated to theKusana standard, but in middle of 5th century rose in weight to 144grains, thus returning to Indian standard of copper kr.sapana. Guptasilver coins (ripaka), based on those of Sakas of Ujjayini, weighed 32–36 grains. metrology of Gupta copper coinage is obscure, and weightsof from 33s to 101 grains r attested.

## MEDIEVAL COINS
Gold coins (suvarna, tanka) were minted by only few dynasties in 11th century. These approximated to Greek drachm standard of 67 grains. Silver coins (dramma, tanka) also conformed to this standard, andcoins of i, i and i dramma r attested. Numerous types of copper coin wereissued, of diverse metrology. coinage of medieval dynasties of thePeninsula was very varied and full study of its metrology is yet to bemade.

II. CONSONANTS

[Page 507] To these letters Dravidian languages and Sinhalese add
the short vowels e (between I and e) and 6 (between e and o). Sinhalese has
also additional vowels and d (between and i). Tamil adds the
consonants 1, I (not same as vocalic I of Sanskrit), r, and n at end
of alphabet; these letters cannot stand at beginning of word. The
Tamil alphabet omits aspirate letters and several others, and the
unvoiced letters serve to express sound of voiced. system of
transliteration used for Tamil words and quotations in this book does not
show this peculiarity.

It will be seen that this alphabet is methodical and scientific, its elements
classified first into vowels and consonants, and then, within each section,
according to manner in which sound is formed. gutturals are
formed by constriction of throat at back of tongue, the
palatals by pressing tongue flat against palate, retroflex by
turning up tip of tongue to touch hard palate, dentals by
touching upper teeth with tongue, and labials by pursing lips.

The vowels a, i,,, i,, e, ai, o, and au r pronounced approximately as in
German or Italian, e and o being “close” sounds, as in German beten and
boten, but short has dull sound of English shut. In very early times
r and vocalic / were pronounced approximately as r second
syllables of words water and bottle by Americans, but before the
Christian era they were sounded as ri and Iri. Sinhalese d and are
pronounced approximately as vowels in English hat and hair
respectively. acc to traditional phonetics e and o r classed as
diphthongs and in Sanskrit r invariably long.

Of two first consonants h, occurring only at end of words or
syllables, is rough breathing, replacing an original s or r. It is distinct
emission of breath, often followed by faint continuation of preceding
vowel. Anusvara, or m, written in Indian scripts as dot, is in part mere
abbreviation, representing nasal sound before stopped consonant. Thus
samdhi is pronounced as sandhi, and atmga as aniga. Before semi-vowels,
sibilants or h it had effect of nasalizing precedingvowel, as in
Frenchor Portuguese; thus amSu was pronounced very approximately as the
French un chou. By many moder speakers m in this position is pronounced
as English ng in sang.

The distinction between aspirate and unaspirate consonants is not
immediately recognized by European, but it is clear to Indian. K, for
instance, is pronounced without any noticeable emission of breath, and kh
(written as one letter in Indian scripts) with strong emission, as in the
usual pronunciation of English c in come. Thus reader should avoid
the temptation to pronounce th and ph as initial sounds of English
thing and phial; they approximate to sounds in pothook and shepherd. C
is pronounced approximately as second consonantal sound in the
English church, and ch as first sound in same word, i.e., with a
stronger emission of breath. J is pronounced as in English, and not as in
German or French. clear distinction is made between retroflex or
cerebral [Page 508] consonants and dental, though it is not very evident
to untrained English ear. English t and d r nearer to Indian
retroflex t and d than to Indian dentals t and d, which approximate to the
corresponding sounds in Italian.

Modern Indians do not generally differentiate in speaking between f and
s, and inscriptions show that two sounds began to be confused at an
early date. Both resemble sh in English shut. Originally s was
pronounced, like other retroflex consonants, with tip of tongue
touching top of hard palate.

Of special Tamil letters I has sound of an I with tongue turned
as far back as possible. Many modem Tamil speakers pronounce this letter
rather like s in English measure or Frenchj, but more harshly.

The consonantal I (which also occurs in Vedic and some Prakrits) is
pronounced by placing tongue on top of hard palate and flapping
it forward; r at end of syllable is often pronounced as t; between two
vowels it is approximately dr, and when doubled tr, while nr is usually
pronounced as ndr; though distinction formerly existed Tamil n is in
modern speech indistinguishable from n.

We hv seen that Vedic Sanskrit, like Greek, had tonic accent, but this,
again as in Greek, disappeared very early from ordinary speech, its place
being taken by stress accent, as in most European languages. stress is
placed on last prosodically long syllable of word (i.e. syllable
containing either long vowel or short vowel followed by two
consonants) other than final syllable, which never has accent. In a
word with no long syllables accent is on first syllable. E.g. sābhā,
Himalaya, Śakuntalā, ávayava. stress is not as marked as in English.



APPENDIX XI
PROSODY
Like those of classical Europe metres of Indian poetry are
quantitative, based on order of long and short syllables, and not, as in
English, on stress. As in classical European languages syllable was
counted as long if it contained long vowel (ā, ī, ū, r, e, o, ai or au), or a
short vowel followed by two consonants. favourite stanza form at all
times was of four lines or “quarters” (pāda), usually equal, and varying in
length from eight to over twenty syllables each, with full caesura between
the second and third quarters. Most of metres of classical poetry
were set in rigid patterns and not divided into feet, but broken only by one
or two caesure in each quarter. metres of Veda, however, and the
epic sloka metre, allowed considerable variation.

Though most of Vedic hymns r in stanzas of four quarters there are
some with three or five divisions. Of former, one, called Gdyatr, is
common, and is that of famous Gayatri verse quoted on p. 162. It [Page
509] consists of three sections of eight syllables each, first four of which
are free, while last four hv cadence
.

The commonest Vedic stanza is Tristubh, consisting of four quarters of
eleven syllables each. quarter normally has caesura after fourth or
fifth syllable, and is prevailingly iambic. last four syllables of each
quarter hv cadence. For example:
índrasya nu vtridni pra vocam
yini cakira prathamani vajrt.

Ahann Ahim, anu apds tatarda,
pra vaksdnd abhinat parvatdnmn. 12

twelvesyllabled Jagatā, with cadence


In later hymns of Rg Veda stanza of four eight-syllable quarters,
called Anustubh, became popular. This was much same as Gayatry, with
a fourth line added, but there was considerable variation in final
cadence. For example:
Sahdsra-sirsd Purusah,
sahasrdksdh, sahdsrapdt.

Sd bhimim visvdto vrtva
dty atisthad dasāngulām.13

metre of later times. This consisted of four quarters of eight syllables each,
the first and third normally ending with cadence

kind, many with fanciful names, but only some twenty or thirty were
popular. Of these we mention few of most common.

The metres employed by Jayadeva in his Gītā Govinda r exceptional,
although imitated by later poets. They r no doubt borrowed from popular
song. stanzas of lyric quoted on p. 429, excluding refrain,
consist of four quarters of nine, eight, nine and ten syllables respectively, all
of which r short except last rhyming syllable in first and third
quarters and penultimate in second and fourth.

The prosody of Tamil poetry differs considerably from that of Sanskrit.

In Tamil basic unit is “metrical syllable” (aśai), which may be a
single syllable or long syllable preceded by short one. Two, three or four
of these form foot, of which line of poetry may contain from two to six
or occasionally more. Complicated rules, which cannot be discussed here,
much restrict order of syllables and feet in line.



APPENDIX XII
THE GYPSIES
Among India’s many gifts to world we must include Gypsies,
who, with their music and dancing, hv formed romantic and colourful
element in European life for over five centuries.

The European Gypsies hv no recollection of their Indian origin, but
have generally claimed to be Egyptians. Russian Gypsies, it is said,
even declare that their ancestors were single soldier of army of
Pharaoh and young girl, who escaped drowning when Moses led the
Israelites over Red Sea. This tradition of Gypsies’ Egyptian origin
was for long taken at its face value, until, in 1763, Hungarian protestant
theological student, Stefan Valyi, published brief paper pointing to the
close similarity between language of Gypsies of his native plains
and that of three Indian theological students whom he had met at the
University of Leyden. It was long before true significance of this fact
was recognized, but it is now universally agreed that Gypsy language,
or Romani, is an Indo-āryan one, and that fact cn only be accounted for
by postulating that Gypsies came from India.

The relationship of Romani to languages of Northern India is very
obvious, even to those with no linguistic training, for many of the
commonest words of Romani r little different from those of India. Thus:
