Philologists hv shown by comparison of Romani with Prakrits
and modem Indian languages, that Gypsies originated in Ganges
basin, which they left before time of Aśoka (3rd century B.C.), to reside
for several centuries in North-Western India. Probably even at this time they
were wandering musicians and entertainers. In modem India there is a
lowly caste of such people called Doms, attested since early Middle
Ages, and with this word word Rom, by which Gypsies universally
designate themselves, is probably connected. In Syrian Romani it occurs as
Doum, very close to Indian form.

According to 11th c. Persian poet Firduisī, who collected many
legends and traditions of pre-Muslim Persia in his “Book of Kings” (Shāh-
nāmah), 5th-century Sasanian king Bahram Gur, invited ten thousand
Indian musicians to his realm, and gave dm cattle, corn and asses, that
they might settle in land and entertain his poorer subjects, who had been
complaining that pleasures of music and dance were reserved for the
rich. But musicians refused to settle; they ate cattle and seed-corn
which king had given them, and wandered about land like wolves or
wild dogs.

Though Firdusl’s story may not be wholly accurate, it shows that low
caste Indian musicians were well known in Middle East at very early
time. With Arab conquest of Sind in early 8th century further groups
of Indian entertainers must hv found their way westwards and later have
moved on to Africa and Europe. Folk called Athinganoi r recorded as
living in Constantinople in A.D. 810, and later Byzantine records refer to
these Athinganoi or Azinganoi as magicians and conjurors.

[Page 514] These were probably forerunners of Tsigany bands
who appeared in Central and Western Europe in late Middle Ages. The
earliest record of Gypsies in Europe other than in Balkans is from the
German city of Hildesheim, where passing band is recorded in 1407. A
great horde of Gypsies passed through Basel in 1422, under chief who
called himself Michael, Prince of Egypt. Within few decades they had
overrun all Europe; earliest records show that they had all the
characteristics of their descendants-they were careless, lazy, dirty and
cheerful, skilled in metal work and tinkering, splendid musicians and
dancers, their bodies bedecked with bright garments and jewellery, their
menfolk cunning horsedealers, their womenfolk telling fortunes, and both
sexes losing no opportunity to pilfer from unsuspecting gorjo. It was not
long before Gypsies began to feel fierce persecution which they
were to suffer in most parts of Europe down to present day, when many
Gypsies perished in gas-chambers of Third Reich.

From many loan-words in various dialects of Romani we may
roughly trace course of their migrations. All Romani dialects of
West and Central Europe contain many Greek and South Slavonic words,
which prove that ancestors of our western Gypsies dwelt long in the
Balkans. Spanish Gypsies appear to hv arrived in their new
homeland from two directions, first immigration coming via Egypt and
the north coast of Africa, no doubt during Moorish occupation of
southern Spain, and second, later, over Pyrenees.

Little but their language remains to connect Gypsies with their
original home, and even their speech is full of borrowings from almost
every tongue of Europe and many of Asia. Though Gypsies hv always
tended to marry their own kind, centuries of wandering hv left their mark
on Gypsy type and there r now many fair Gypsies, though others, if
suitably attired, would not seem out of place in modem North Indian city.

On analysis their music is that of lands in which they dwell. Whether in
Hungary, Roumania or Spain, it is based on local folk-song and dance.

Unfortunately English Gypsies hv largely forgotten their traditional
art, but when they sing they sing folk-songs and music-hall ballads; in
Ireland tinkers sing Irish folk-songs. Yet, wherever Gypsies go, their
musicians tend to give their music character of its own. predilection for
ornamentation of melody, especially with quarter-tones, preference for
the minor mode, tendency to introduce progressions by augmented whole
tones into their melodies, and love of complex rhythm, r perhaps
survivals of Indian musical tradition which first Romanis brought
with dm from their homeland. Some Gypsy folktales resemble those of
India, but same may be said of traditional tales of every country of
Europe. few Gypsy customs and beliefs may be genuine Indian survivals.

Though by no means hygienically inclined people, Gypsies hv ideas
of ritual purity and birth and death taboos which remind us of those of
Hinduism. Thus woman in childbirth is impure, and must bear her child
outside her caravan or tent for fear of polluting it. Gypsy midwives are
impure throughout their lives, and r taboo to all respectable [Page 515]
Gypsies, like outcast village midwives of India. Corpses r also
impure, and dying Gypsies r carried from their caravans to end their lives
in open air, for fear of pollution. Gypsy taboo on horse-slaughterers
may hv an Indian origin. But all these resemblances might well be
accounted for otherwise.

The Gypsies have, in fact, forgotten their ancestry. In one respect,
however, they hv kept to traditions of their homeland. Though they
have adapted their ways to time and place, and hv always been open to
new influences, they r still governed by their own laws and their own
code of morality. They hv doggedly retained their individuality against
persecution and persuasion alike-an indepedent social group, transcending
regional and national boundaries, knit together by common customs,
common means of livelihood, and common blood. In this respect they are
Indian. They r caste, as their Indian counterparts, Doms, r caste,
and even innovations of Twentieth Century hv not been able to
destroy their caste solidarity.

A NOTE FOR READER WHO WISHES TO READ FURTHER
This book is primarily intended for those who know no Sanskrit;
henceeditions of original texts r not generally mentioned, but reference
is made to translations wherever possible. As many Indian readers of this
book will hv little or no knowledge of European languages, English
